title: AvantGarde Unites Over Burroughs
description: New York's avantgardists love to band together for celebrations. Whether it's a benefit to restore St. Mark's Church intheBowery or a New Year's Day festivity or a Tibetan Buddhist benefit, each season's calendar includes more than one occasion in which artists and intellectuals in several different arts join together for potpourri performances.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 30 (AP) A Federal judge today prohibited the Big Eight Conference from considering information about Jim Stanley, the former Oklahoma State football coach, and an alleged slush fund unless it comes from witnesses who may be crossexamined by Stanley.

title: Modern Jewelry With Ancient Roots
description: After running what was, in effect, an underground operation, Helen Woodhull has surfaced on Madison Avenue at a chic boutique devoted to the classic jewelry that she designs. It was a move guaranteed to simplify life for her admirers, who have been having difficulty adding to their collections.

title: Dimitrijevic Is Put On Waivers by Cosmos
description: Vito Dimitrijevic, who at times gave the impression he did not want to play for the Cosmos, was put on waivers yesterday by the North American Soccer League champions.

title: Cus D'Amato Is Back and Still Talking
description: In a dark corner of Mike Manuche's restaurant on West 52d Street, Cus D'Amato came out of the shadows yesterday.

title: U.S. Will Move Against Age Bias In Programs Getting Federal Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30The Federal Government proposed a broad set of rules today to, root out discrimination based on age in programs that receive Federal funds.

title: A Gathering to Celebrate Music of the Balkans
description: This Sunday people from all over will gather to delight in the sounds of faraway places  places that are for some a memory and for others a dream.

title: Broadway
description: THERE have been Bob and Ray, Flanders and Swann, Peter Cook and Dudley Moore, but not since Nichols and May have there been a man and woman. (Comden and Green do not count; they sang.) Now there will be Monteith and Rand  John Monteith and Suzanne Rand  a comedy team that will open at the Booth Theater on Jan. 2. They do scenes and improvisations, and when they played the Theater East last fall they sold out. Alone, they say, they are hopeless, but together they are grand.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAHAMSRebeCCa G. on Hoverher 27. Beloved wife of the late Samuel K., devoted mother of Richard K. and Norbert S. Dear sister of Sade Hauseman. Anne Hirsch, Frank Greenberg and the late Herman Greenberg and Fan Greenberg. Service and interment private.

title: Standards Board's Proposals Broaden Data on Accounting
description: Financial accounting is changing its emphasis and will look more toward the future as a result of fundamental changes proposed by the Financial Accounting Standards Board.

title: Farm Prices Drop 1.5% As Cattle, Hog Costs Fall
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP)Prices that farmers get for raw products dropped 1.5 percent in the month ended Nov. 15, the first decline since last summer, the Agriculture Department reported today.

title: The Pop Life
description: THE totality of music invariably resists any neat categorization. But for a while, at least. the category of disco as applied to presentday popular music really did mean something. Of course, songs varied  lyrics (however vestigial) did change (they weren't all just boogie down); the music had its individual accents, too.

title: Insurance Is Schoolboy Issue
description: A football player like me, you don't worry about getting hurt, you want to play and have fun, was the way 19yearold Jeff Boynton remembered the charity allstar game in Pittsburgh on July 21. I never expected to get hurt seriously.

title: CARTER IS TROUBLED BY MIDEAST DELAYS; SADAT AIDE ARRIVES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  President Carter said today that he was dissatisfied and disappointed over delays in concluding a peace treaty between Egypt and Israel. But he pledged that the United States was certainly not going to give up on the effort. [Question 10, page A22.]

title: Manufacturer Says Parents Fail To Heed a Recall of Riviton Toys
description: BEVERLY, Mass., Nov. 30 (AP) Patter Brothers, a toy manufacturer, says parents have not heeded a recall of its Riviton construction sets after two children choked to death en pieces from the sets.

title: Topics
description: After an explosion of horror like the mass suicide in Guyana, the mind clings gratefully to evidence that not everything has been upended, that some things remain just as they were.

title: Corporate Earnings Reported
description: FIX periods as Shown (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Recital Violin Master
description: THE Carnegie Hall Corporation inaugurated a Masters of the Violin series last night, and the appropriate first master was Isaac Stern, who has been so long and loyally associated with the hall (he's currently president of the corporation).

title: I.C.C. Votes To Relax Truck Rule
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  The Interstate Commerce Commission gave preliminary approval today to a proposal that it lower its historic barriers to new entry into the trucking business and instead promote wider access.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Jersey Psychiatrist, Studying the Guyana Survivors, Fears Implications for U.S. Society From Other Cults
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Nov. 30  A psychiatrist working with survivors of the People's Temple tragedy said today that there was little likelihood that any of the other 1,500 cults estimated to be currently active in the United States could be capable of similar acts of selfdestruction.

title: Books of The Times
description: ONE of the reasons that Edward W. Said; Parr Professor of English and Comparative Literature at Columbia University, has writtenthis book is that he himself was an Oriental child wbo grew up in the British colonies of Palestine and Egypt. His life is on the spindle.

title: Blazers Top Cays, 9897, On Foul Shots. by Lucas
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, Nov. 30 (AP) Maurice Lucas tossed in a pair of free throws with nine seconds left to insure the Portland Trail Blazers a 9897 National Basketball Association victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers tonight.

title: Britain's Rhodesia Aide, Lord Carver, Quits Post
description: LONDON, Nov. 30  Britain's designee as resident commissioner for Rhodesia in the final transition to black rule resigned today.

title: Tax Shift to Aid Schools Sought For Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 30  Hoping to satisfy a court mandate for devising new method of school financing in Connecticut, a blueribbon commission tonight recommended an innovative program for shifting the bulk of educational costs onto a statewide tax system.

title: 2 Horses Die in Race In Unrelated Accidents
description: Two horses died as a result of unrelated mishaps during the running of the third race yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: Bluegrass Goes to Jersey For the Weekend
description: The sound of bluegrass music will fin The Englishtown (N.J.) Music Hall 24 Water Street, this weekedd.

title: Chamber Music Finds Home All Over Town
description: CHAMBER MUSIC is just what it says it is  music for an intimate space. It is so for the simple reason that it is music written for one instrumental player to each part (as distinct from orchestral music, where there are several players to a part). It is why it finds a home in all sorts of places  museum rooms, university halls, the drawing rooms of old mansions, churches, conventional auditoriums. (In the country, it can be found in barns and oneroom schoolhouses, too.) Chamber music particularly thrives in the Big Apple, partly because there is a growing audience for it, but perhaps even more because the city is so full of young and gifted musicians, who want to play together, sometimes at financial sacrifice to themselves.

title: Coast Woman Is Guilty In Giant Welfare Fraud
description: COMPTON, Calif., Nov. 30 (UPI) Barbara Williams, accused of collecting $240,000 for six dozen fictitious children, was convicted today of 23 counts of welfare fraud and perjury.

title: PrizeWrnning Cellist Tests a New Hall
description: There's a new concert hall in town, not far from Lincoln Center, and Nathaniel Rosen  the cellist who won a gold medal in Moscow's Tchaikovsky competition last summer  will inaugurate it tomorrow night at 8 with a benefit performance for the Hebrew Arts School.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAIDLING TODAY

title: South Africans Halt Demolition Of Black Camp
description: PRETORIA. South Africa, Nov. 30 South Africa's new minister for black affairs, Pieter G. Koornhof, said today that plans to demolish the homes of 20,000 blacks at the Crossroads squatter camp near Cape Town had been set aside indefinitely.

title: Advertising
description: ABOUT a year and a half ago, when Richard Donner, the film director, began work on the Warner Brothers movie Superman, Steven O. Frankfurt, president of Frankfurt Communications, began working on the advertising and marketing plans for the film. Now both are ready to show off their creations.

title: Met Unwraps Egyptian Riches In New Setting
description: THAT most quotable of men, Dr. Samuel Johnson, once said: Greek, sir, is like lace. Every man gets as much it as he can. As far as Greek is concerned, times have changed. But it is certainly true of ancient Egypt that every man gets as much of it as he can.

title: Finds a Tremendous Increase In Its Youngsters Abuse of Drugs
description: Long Island narcotics officials say there has been a significant increase in drug use on Long Island recently, an increase that some attribute to boredom, others to the affluence of many in the area and others, conversely, to a high unemployment rate among the young.

title: Kentucky Salutes Seattle Slew
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 30  The big yellow buttons with the black lettering told the story: Seattle Slew Day.

title: Study Says Soviet Has Gained Nuclear Superiority
description: Two former Defense Department officials have warned that the nuclear balance of terror is no longer in balance but seriously lopsided. so much so that in a confrontation with the Soviet Union the United states would seek an escape hatch, as the Russians did in the Cuban missile crisis of 1962.

title: Ousted DrugUnit Workers Sue
description: Program workers at the drugdetoxification unit at Lincoln Hospital, which was closed Wednesday following accusations that it was badly mismanaged, filed suit yesterday in Federal District Court against Mayor Koch and the Health and Hospitals Corporation, contending that their constitutional rights were violated when the unit was evicted from the hospital.

title: GRAND JURY ENTERS RYAN DEATH INQUIRY
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30  A Federal grand jury here today began questioning members of the People's Temple sect about the possibility that some members of the tult had planned in advance the murder of Representative Leo J. Ryan, the California Representative who was killed 12 days ago at the Temple's settlement in Jonestown, Guyana.

title: Arsonist Set Fire That Killed 10, Investigator Says
description: ROCHESTER, Nov. 30  Sunday's fire at the Holiday Inn in suburban Greece, in which 10 persons were killed, was deliberately set, Police Chief Gerald D. Phelan said today.

title: Bridge:
description: In rubber bridge, a player has to be sure of his ground to double a partscore that will give the enemy a game if it succeeds. The usual rule is to have a margin of safety and double only if a twotrick defeat seems assured.

title: 2 Admit Guilt in G.S.A. Kickbacks
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI)  In one of the biggest payoff scandals yet uncovered in a broad investigation of the General Services Administration, two private contractors pleaded guilty today to charges of conspiring with Federal employees to cheat taxpayers out of $1.9 million.

title: Gulf Finds Gas Off New Jersey
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation announced yesterday that it had found natural gas below 17,640 feet in its well in the Baltimore Canyon off New Jersey but that the amount was insufficient to be considered a commercial discovery.

title: Business and the Law
description: CRIMINAL lawyers often slip into the jargon spoken by rogues. Negligence lawyers sometimes sound like physicians talking. And patent lawyers occasionally lapse into scientists' lingo. Lawyers who specialize in corporate takeovers are no different. They have a language of their own, and it is the language of attack  of Saturday night specials and white knights, of bear hugs and safe harbors.

title: 10 Held in Marijuana Smuggling
description: PORT ARTHUR, Tex., Nov. 30 (UPI)  Customs Service agents broke up the unloading last night of 25 to 30 tons of marijuana from a shrimp boat to two trailer trucks and arrested 12 suspects at a downtown dock. A Customs spokesman said the suspects, 10 men and two women were unloading the marijuana, whose street value was estimated at $12 million. from the Agnes Pauline when the agents moved in about 9:45 P.M.

title: PRESIDENT CONCEDES GROWTH RATE IN '79 MAY NOT REACH 3%
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  President Carter said today that he did not expect either a recession or depression next year, but he conceded that the nation's economic growth rate might fall below the 3 percent that the Administration's economists had been predicting. The growth rate so far this year has been 3.75 percent.

title: The Chinese Rock
description: Thirty years ago, on the docks of Shanghai, my parents said goodbye to their families. They had married a few days before, and were sailing for America, where my father was to study engineering. No one spoke of adventure or opportunity that day. Instead, most of the relatives wept over the separation, and begged them to return in one year rather than two. But just before departure, my grandfather took my father aside and told him that turmoil was coming to China, that he might have to remain in America indefinitely, and that they probably would never see each other again.

title: Shell Start Rationing Its Gasoline; Dealers to Get 75% of Usual Total
description: The Shell Oil Company will begin nationwide rationing of all its gasoline today, limiting dealers to 75 percent of previous monthly volumes, the company announced last night.

title: Around the Nation
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 30 (AP)  Steelladen trucks, escorted by the state police, moved along the Pennsylvania Turnpike in protective convoys after 10 more incidents of violence were reported today.

title: Le Cid Tests Mettle Of Cocteau Players
description: The Jean Cocteau Repertory Theater is building a strong reputation for finding and staging some infrequently performed classics of the theater: it was this group that last year brought to the Bouwerie Lane Theater the first major New York production of Percy Bysshe Shelley's verse drama The Cenci Tonight the Jean Cocteau breaks new ground again with the opening of what the company believes is the first New York performance in English of Corneille's Le Cid.

title: Opposition Leaders Skeptical
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 30  Nicaraguan opposition leadders tonight described President Somoza`s conditional acceptance of a plebiscite on his future as an effective rejection of the proposals of the mediation team.

title: Rose Rejects Mets and Phillies
description: Pete Rose took his traveling auction to Philadelphia yesterday but unexpectedly rejected a $1.8 million offer from the Phillies a few hours after he had turned down $2 million from the New York Mets.

title: Books: Columnist's Start
description: WHEN Sheilah Graham was a little girl, she looked like a little boy. She grew up in an orphanage where the children's heads Were routinely shaved, and in those days just before World War I it was unimaginable that she might ever enter the enchanted world of the rich, as she now describes it. But she managed, after a sad and harrowing childhood, to work her way up: There was a housemaid's job, then a stint selling toothbrushes in a department store and an early marriage to a very helpful older man. By the end of The Late Lily Shiel, her account of these early years, she had studied singing, dancing and acting, adopted the stage name of Sheilah Graham and won a leading role in the London production of Nol Coward's revue This Year of Grace,

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The nation's money supply declined fairly sharply in the week ended Nov. 22, encouraging moneymarket economists to conclude that the Federal Reserve may keep shortterm interest rates stable for a while.

title: Police Accuse 3 Of Poor Actions In Fatal Assault
description: Two police officers and a civilian 911 operator were suspended yesterday by Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire on charges of having failed to take proper action with connection to last Friday's slaying of Bonnie Anne Bush, a Mount Sinai Hospital nurse supervisor.

title: One Defendant Settles in Sun Suit
description: A securities case against the Sun Company, Salomon Brothers and others  widely expected to create new case law  took a new turn yesterday with an outofcourt settlement by one of the defendants.

title: Rescuing Bankruptcy From Bankruptcy
description: The need for a new Federal bankruptcy law has become steadily more evident. The number of personal and business bankruptcies has been soaring  filings have increased 20fold in 30 years. The whole creaking bankruptcy system is on the verge of collapse.

title: 3,000 March in Midtown to Attack J. P. Stevens' AntiUnion Policies
description: More than 3,000 demonstrators, protesting J. P. Stevens & Company's antiunion policies, marched in front of the textile manufacturer's midtown headquarters yesterday as part of a nationwide day of boycotting that was endorsed by Governor Carey and the City Council.

title: Washington Star Is Still Troubled With Critical Economic Problems
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  The critical economic problems that are afflicting some daily newspapers in competitive markets have again overtaken The Washington Star, which was widely believed to have been rescued when it was purchased by Time Inc. early this year.

title: The Right Place for Firefighters
description: Increasingly, the nation's fire problem is an arson problem  and an urban one. What more appropriate place, then, for a National Academy of Fire Prevention and Control than New York City?

title: Art: Viewing With Nave Eyes
description: ASYNONYM for naive painting is chutzpah. Conceived by men and women who have usually taken up art late in life, it reckons neither with time nor place. Some primitives are quainter and more ingenious than others, but they tend to be more alike than dissimilar. Despite (or because of) its roots in a defiance of the world, this bestseller genre cuts across all preferences in the audience, attracting connoisseurs as well as novices alike.

title: Transcript of President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: Following is a transcript of President Carter's news conference yesterday in Washington,as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:

title: Five Are Killed as Blaze Sweeps A Department Store Near Manila
description: MANILA, Nov. 30 (UPI)  Fire apparently caused by faulty electrical wiring swept a twostory suburban department store, killing five people and injuring six others, fire officials reported today.

title: Count of Guyana Dead Is Now Lowered to 911
description: DOVER AIR FORCE BASE, Del., Nov. 30 (UPI)  A total of 911 bodies. not 912 as previously estimated, were recovered from the scene of the killings and suicides of members of the People's Temple in Guyana, an Air Force spokesman said today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Express Company, providing travelrelated and insurance services, has elected Morris Tanenbaum a director of both the American Express Company and its internationalbanking subsidiary, the American Express International Banking Corporation. Mr. Tanenbaum is president of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company.

title: Music: Tashi's Messiaen
description: OLIVIER MESSIAEN will he 70 years old this month and he is accepting congratulations from many parts of the world in this musical season. At the Beacon Theater on Wednesday night, it was the turn of Peter Serkin and the chamber group known as Tashi to pay their respects, with an entire concert of the French composer's works.

title: Sadat's Premier and ForeignPolicy Engineer
description: CAIRO, Nov. 30  When President Anwar elSadat journeyed to Jerusalem to address the Israeli Parliament a year ago, he generated little enthusiasm among his colleagues. A notable exception was Mustafa Khalil, then secretary general of the Arab Socialist Union, who volunteered for the trip.

title: Pupils on L. I. Seen Preferring Softer Drugs
description: NORTHPORT, L.I., Nov 30  Students, teachers and counselors at the high school here said today they did not need the state's statistics to tell them that an increasing number of Long Island teenagers were using drugs

title: Mexico Plans Record Budget
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 30 (UPI)  The Mexican Government will announce tomorrow a 1979 budget expected to break the trillionpeso mark for the first time, at a sum equivalent to about $48.4 billion.

title: Television
description: 6:00(4) What in the World Is . . . (5)New Zoo Revue (13)Captioned ABC News

title: Economic Scene
description: NEWS that the United States ran a trade deficit of $2.1 billion in October  a marked worsening of the September result  was a blow to Administration officials frequent contention that the tide has begun to turn and that the trade balance will be a lot better next year.

title: Otto Kaffir, Discoverer of Grandma Moses, Dies
description: Otto Kallir, the art dealer who launched the latelife career of Grandma Moses and introduced the work of the Austrian Expressionist painters Egon Schiele and Gustav Klimt in New York, died yesterday morning at his home, 15 West 72d Street. He was 84 years old.

title: Deaths
description: BROWNCharles. To our most esteemed employer and valued friend, Mr. Charles Brown, we mourn a great loss. Adolph & Kay Rosenberg, employees of Brown's Hotel

title: West Europeans FarReaching Money Bloc
description: PARIS, Nov. 30  West European nations, pursuing their quest for unity and greater independence from the United States, plan to put the finishing touches next week on a new monetary system that observers believe may be one of the most significant initiatives the countries have attempted in decades.

title: Dominica Asks U.N. Admittance
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 30 (Reuters)  The Caribbean island of Dominica, which became independent on Nov. 3, has,applied to become the 151st member of the United Nations.

title: Carter's Door Is Open, He Tells Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  Thirty Democrats, newly elected to the House of Representatives, were promised by President Carter today that we have an open door at the White House.

title: UTC Bid for Carrier Is Upheld by Court
description: SYRACUSE, Nov. 30 (UPI)  A Federal judge today rejected petitions by the Justice Department and the Carrier Corporation and refused to block a takeover of Carrier by United Technologies of Hartford. In his ruling, District Judge Howard Munson denied the petition in all respects.

title: Ethiopia's Eritrea Gains Attributed to soviet Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  The State Department today attributed Ethiopia's recent victories over secessionist forces in Eritrea to overwhelming arms superiority provided by the Soviet Union and to the role played by both Soviet and Cuban military advisers.

title: WNET Plans Series on Jews
description: An ambitious Jewish history series, with Abba Eban, former Israeli Am. bassador to the United Nations, possi. bly playing a central role as narrator and writer, is in the early stages of re. search by WNETTV.

title: Radio
description: 67:30 A.M., WNYCFM. Ballet Music from ldomeneo. Mozart; Piano Concerto No. 5, Beethoven; Symphony No. 41, Haydn.

title: 3dWorld Fund: New Failure
description: GENEVA, Nov. 30  Developing and industrialized countries ended today their third unsuccessful attempt to establish an international fund to bolster the earnings of the third world from its raw materials.

title: Opera: World Premiere in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 30  Krzysztof Penderecki's Paradise Lost had its world premiere last night under the auspices of the Lyric Opera of Chicago. It is hard to believe, but it has been pointed out that not since 1921 has a major opera by a major European composer been given a world premiere by a major American opera house.

title: At the Movies
description: I'LL tell you the kind of movie Justine was, Cliff Gorman said at Sardi's the other day. George Cukor, the director, told Irene Sharaft, the costume designer: Cliff has got to be elegant, elegant, elegant. I want him to have a gold cigarette case. Send out to Cartier's  there's a Cartier's in Beverly Hills, isn't there?  and buy a gold cigarette case for Cliff. I don't care how much costs. Somebody said that no one would be able to tell what kind of cigarette case I was carrying. Cukor said that that didn't matter. The important thing was for me to know I was carrying one.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: The White House, after a search for a labormanagement troubleshooter to work with Alfred E. Kahn. its antiinflation chief, has settled on John N. Gentry. according to Government and labor sources.

title: The Chief Justice as Lobbyist
description: Much less meritorious than the new bankruptcy bill was the lobbying of Chief Justice Warren Burger against it.

title: Deaths
description: Abrahams. R.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Thursday, November 30, 1978.

title: Pop Music: Dalida Sings
description: FOR 20 years, a singer known as Dalida, born in Cairo of Italian parents, has been a leading posinging star in Europe. Despite an international following that has applauded her performances in Japan, South America and Canada, as well as Europe and the Middle East, her appearance in Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening was her American debut.

title: Housing Bonds Yield Up to 7%
description: The New York State Housing Finance Agency yesterday sold $106 million of bonds that winning underwriters priced to yield as much as 7 percent  exempt from Federal, state and city income taxes. Investors bought them up rapidly.

title: Music: Ursula Oppens Plays Carter Concerto
description: ELLIOTT CARTER is about to be 70 years old, and in line with timehonored musical tradition he has been enjoying a spate of honors and tributes this season. The New York Philharmonic brought out his Piano Concerto last night, with Ursula Owens as the soloist and Zubin Mehta conducting. The twomovement piece, composed in 1964 and 1965, had been performed in New York twice previously, neither time finding much success with audiences. Perhaps the third time would be the charm?

title: Bella Abzug: Picking Up the Pieces
description: Everything is very quiet. The office is quiet and empty; just the lawyer and a lone secretary. The telephone rings occasionally, but otherwise the cartons of old files and the photographs of famous faces lining the walls are the only reminders of the way things used to be.

title: Art: Roszak Evokes Spirit of Bauhaus
description: ART history  even the art history of the present century abounds in unexpected shifts and convergences. Impulses once believed to be at odds with each other are now, in a changed perspective, seen to be very much united in common enterprise.

title: Russian Couple With Ailing Infant Land in Boston
description: BOSTON, Nov. 30  A Russian couple who had sought for a year to bring their infant daughter to the United States for medical treatment arrived here today, the latest in a steady stream of Jews being allowed to leave the Soviet Union.

title: Where Writers and Muses Commune in Peace
description: It's not a house. But it is a home. Right in midtown Manhattan, away from yowling babies, ringing telephones, the plumber's knock, the laundry chores and other sources of psychological angst, there is a quiet little room created for a special kind of assignation.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO, AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500: SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: Dance: Ailey Gala With a Difference
description: ALVIN AILEY celebrated his dance company's 20th anniversary Wednesday night at the City Center, and the best part of this gala occasion was that was not a gala in the usual sense.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Bids U.N. Support Camp David Agreement
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 39 The United States appealed to General Assembly members today to put aside sloganeering and to support the EgyptianIsraeli accords reached at Camp David as the most promising effort ever made to resolve the Palestine problem. the speech by Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut, a member of the delegation to the Assembly, was described by Americans as an effort to break the conspiracy of silence by Arab strategists hostile to the peace effort.

title: The Region
description: WEST ORANGE. N.J. (UPI) Several reporters and other staff members of the New Jersey edition of The Daily News of New York were notified they would be laid off on Jan. 12. Jonathan Thompson, a spokesman for The News, said that about 13 persons on the 25member staff would lose their jobs.

title: About Real Estate
description: Ask Edward J. Logue about priorities is the South Bronx and he says at once that the first priority should be the rehabilitation of the Grand Concourse.

title: Sadat Will Not Attend Nobel Prize Ceremony
description: CAIRO, Nov. 30 (AP)  President Anwar elSadat will not go to Oslo to accept the Nobel Peace Prize he is sharing with Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel, the official Middle East News Agency said today.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: ART (GR 37014)

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: A few years ago, a talent scout for the North Shore Community Arts Center in Great Neck, L.I., heard a young performer in the Berkshires and decided to book her for a concert. This was one of the first local appearances by Elizabeth Swados, before she went on to acclaim for her work with Andrei Serban and awards for her own hit show, Runaways. Miss Swados hasn't forgotten her friends in Great Neck, though, and she will perform again tonight and tomorrow at 9 P.M. At the Arts Center, 236 Middleneck Road. Her show includes a preview of. her new musical, Alice in Wonderland. Tickets are $7.50. Reservations: (516) 4663636. From New York City, take the Long Island Expressway to Exit 33 and go north about four miles.

title: Deaths
description: SKOMOROWSKYBella. The Board of Trustees of the Educational Alliance extends its condolences to our esteemed Treasurer, Peter Skomorowsky and his family on the loss of his mother.

title: Oklahoma Shows That It's Always Been Serious About Its Civil Defense
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 30  Five feet below the state capital complex, in a 50yard tunnel separated by two steel doors, a handwritten sign hangs loosely in the Office of Civil Defense. The sign reads: 197879year of change.

title: Kenya Opening 2 Embassies
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 30 (Reuters) Kenya announced today that it would reopen an embassy in China and would establish a high commission, or Commonwealth equivalent of an embassy, in Canada for the first time.

title: Deaths
description: SCANLONMarguerite M. Belove sister of Thomas & Fr.Vincent, funeral Saturday 9:30AM from John J. Fox & Sons, Inc 201 St & Grand Concourse. Mass of the Resurrection, St. Philip Neri Church 10AM

title: Dutch Treat in Yonkers: Carols at the Manor
description: St. Nicholas Eve, in early December. was among the first holidays celebrated in this country, and its Dutch origins will be recalled in unusual musical fashion over the next three weekends by the Nieuw Nederlande Consort.

title: Joe Paterno Says No Thanks
description: Joe Paterno made it to the first landing of the stairs the Roosevelt Hotel ballroom yesterday before the question was asked: Have you had any communication with Them?

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: DEMOCRATS MAY LAG ON HEALTH POLICIES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  Democratic Party officials sought today to shelve calls for action next year on national health insurance and for more Federal aid for cities as they worked to thin a stack of 170 resolutions proposed for the party's forthcoming conference in Memphis.

title: Cheaper Solar Energy Proclaimed by Inventor
description: A controversial scientistinventor, who leaped from obscurity to prominence 10 years ago when he introduced a new class of lowcost electronic materials, said yesterday that he could now use one of those materials to convert sunlight into electricity cheap enough for the average house.

title: Dartmouth Upset Victor Over Holy Cross, 76 to 71
description: HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 30 (UPI) Mark Gautier scored off a rebound with 33 seconds remaining to help send Dartmouth to a 7671 upset victory over Holy Cross tonight.

title: TV Fare: Five Contenders and the Giants
description: There are a halfdozen games in the National Football League this Sunday matching teams in contention for the 10 playoff positions. Two will be televised in the New York City area  New England at Dallas. Channel 4, at 4 P.M. and Denver at Oakland, Channel 7, 9 P.M. The Giants' home game against the Rams can be seen on Channel 2 starting at 1 P.M., initiating the television tripleheader. Other contests crucial to the playoffs are Pittsburgh at Houston, Cleveland at Seattle, Philadelphia at Minnesota and Miami at Washington. Previews of all games follow, with wonlosttied records in parentheses.

title: Hackensack Meadowlands Still Paradise for Trappers
description: CARLSTADT, N.J., Nov. 29  In his worn plaid jacket and hip boots, with a musk at tucked under his arm and his face covered by grayish stubble, Willie Royka seemed to be stepping out of another era as he emerged from a thicket of 12foot marsh feeds into a crowd of secretaries returning to their jobs in two new office buildings in the Hackensack Meadowlands.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The RCA Corporation said yesterday that it planned to sell for $200 million Alaska Communications, a subsidiary, to the Pacific Power and Light Compa ny.

title: LEVICH QUITS SOVIET AFTER 6YEAR WAIT
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 30  Veniamin G. Levich, the most prominent Jewish scientist to receive permission to emigrate, left today with his wife, Tanya, six years after they first atoned for exit visas.

title: Carter Presses West's Proposal for Namibian SelfRule
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  President Carter assumed a personal role today in the efforts of the United States and four other Western governments to persuade South Africa to cooperate in a United Nations plan for bringing independence to SnuthWest Africa.

title: S.E.C. Chief Sees Danger In New Brokers' Services
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Nov. 30  Harold M. Williams, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, warned the securities industry today about problems that could arise from the increasing number of additional services, such as insurance and tax planning, offered or planned by brokerage and investment banking concerns.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 1, 1978

title: Investigation Chief Disputes Shea on Smith Interview
description: New York City's Investigation Commissioner yesterday rebutted William A. Shea's account of the background interview last January concerning Peter P. Smith 3d, who resigned in August as Commissioner of General Services. Mr. Smith, pleaded guilty on Wednesday to charges that he had diverted $70,000 from the politically powerful law firm of Shea, Gould, Climenko & Casey.

title: Postal Service Called Delinquent on Taxes
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP)  The Postal Service, which is having trouble avoiding budget deficits and delivering the mail an time, hat tax problems as well, a published report said today.

title: Chain Store Sales Gain; Sears Off
description: Most of the nation's leading retail chains yesterday reported doubledigit percentage sales increases for this month above the level a year ago, gains that they said augured a strong Christmas season.

title: Cartmen Strike After Rejecting Offer on Pact
description: More than 2,000 private sanitationmen, who pick up the trash and garbage from New York City's hotels, restaurants, private hospitals and commercial establishments, went out on strike last night after voting to reject a contract offer from the carting companies.

title: For Children
description: ANNUAL HOLIDAY BAZAAR, on Saturday from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., at the Riverside Church Weekday School, Riverside Drive end 122d Street. The fair, sponsored by the children of the school, will include movies, a magician. handcrafts, face painting homebaked foods, plants and books. The proceeds will aid the school's Scholarship program. Information: 7497000.

title: STATE DEPT. CALLED LAX ON MASS DEATHS
description: SAN FRANCISCO. Nov. 30  The State Department received explicit warnings for more than a year that the lives of American citizens were in jeopardy at the People's Temple commune in Guyana and that the Guyanese Government had been corrupted by the Rev. Jim Jones, according to two lawyers.

title: Regulations Sought for Pesticides
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  The American Chemical Society today urged the Federal Government to require manufacturers of pesticides to develop safe means to dispose of them before they can be marketed.

title: Eritrean Defeat Portends Revival of Guerrilla War
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 30  Ethiopia, repeating claims of recent days, said yesterday that its forces had crushed the Eritrean secessionist movements that have been fighting for the independence of the largely Moslem northern province for 17 years.

title: U.S. Moves to Avert Any Violence Stemming From Deaths in Guyana
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  The Justice Department disclosed today that both the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Secret Service had been enlisted to prevent violence in this country in the aftermath of the mass deaths in Guyana. Meanwhile, President Carter warned against an overreaction to the Jonestown tragedy.

title: U.S. Studying Report of 30 People Seen Fleeing Guyana After Deaths
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  The United States Government is investigating an unconfirmed report that a group of 30 to 40 people were sighted moving toward the GuyanaVenezuela border shortly after the killings at Jonestown and may have entered Venezuela, authoritative Government sources said today.

title: The City
description: A fourjustice Appellate Division decision yesterday unanimously upheld the right of a socialservice agency and its workers to maintain privileged confidential relationship with a client. The case had set a precedent when Justice Arnold L. Fein of State Supreme Court in August 1977 fat quashed a subpoena by the state's Welfare Inspector General, who had sought information furnished to the Community Service Society by Gladys Baez, a 1979 welfare client.

title: Brazil Trade Deficit
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Nov. 30 (UPI)  Brazil's commercial trade deficit reached $748 million in October, and a Treasury official predicted today it might reach $800 million by the end of the year.

title: A Witness Says No Fingerprints Link Texan to Payment for Killer
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 30 (AP)  A witness for the state testified today that fingerprint experts from the Federal Bureau of Investigation had found nothing to link T. Cullen Davis, the industrialist, to $25,000 allegedly earmarked for a hired killer:

title: Holiday Tradition and Then Some
description: The New York City Ballet's The Nutcracker has been a New York tradition for 25 years now. The holiday season just isn't complete without its battalions of fat mice. gliding snowflakes and the giant tree that grows 28 feet onstage; somehow the spell is never broken. But for the 82 children picked from the City Balletaffiliated School of American Ballet to perform in it, the holiday classic is a tradition of another kind, the first step toward a career and that first magic experience of the stage. On Wednesday night and yesterday afternoon, the children gathered for final rehearsals before opening night tonight. This year's party guests and toy. soldiers (below) may one day become grownup Snowflakes (left) or perhaps even Sugar Plum Fairies or Cavaliers. The world of The Nutcracker is, after all, a world where toys come alive, holidays last forever and all dreams have happy endings.

title: WELCOME FOR NIXON AT OXFORD IS WARM
description: OXFORD, England, Nov. 30  The Oxford Union, a student debating society at the university here, gave Richard M. Nixon a warm, at times almost rapturous reception today, and he declared that he would continue to speak on world affairs so long as I have a breath in my body.

title: Deaths
description: KAUFMANIrene. on November 28th, 78, beloved slater of Louis & Jerome Oppenheimer.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: PUBLIC Television is demanding the lion's share of attention this weekend as, beginning tomorrow, the system begins weeklong effort to heighten viewer awareness of and participation in local public broadcasting stations. In translation, that means frequent pitches for money. Actually. Channel 13 got started early with a special fund raising. film following Wednesday night's showing of Choreography by Balanchine, Part 3. For those sub Ject to irritation by this kind of thing. the word is beware.

title: Seoul's Exports Celebrated
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 30  Government and business leaders here marked an economic milestone today by celebrating South Korea's more than $11 billion in exports in the last 11 months.

title: $2 Million Bail Is Set In the Case of Suspect Termed a Con Man
description: Bail of $2 million was set yesterday for an unemployed 56yearold man described by a Federal prosecutor as a sophisticated con man who was charged with stealing more than $2 million from shirt company and an elderly widow in Manhattan.

title: Notes on People
description: Pamela Price was a Yale University junior when, she says, she was offered an A in a course if she yielded to the professor's sexual demands. But because she refused, she got only a C. That contentionformed the basis of formal charges brought by the 22yearold woman, and now Judge Ellen Burns of Federal District Court in New Haven has said that Miss Price has a right to sue Yale University for not taking steps to prevent alleged sexual harassment of female students.

title: Union Protests Inflation Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP)  About 100 leader's and members of the International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers demonstrated outside the White House today to protest limits on wages and benefits in President Carter's antiinflation guidelines.

title: A Little Bit of Soul From the Staples Family
description: Roebuck Staples? asked the puzzled Detroit hotel operator. Is he one of the Staple Singers? Oh, you must mean Pop Staples. That's how we have him registered. In another minute, the patriarch of the singing Staples family was on the line. You going to be at Carnegie Hall? Mr. Staples asked the writer. Whoowee!

title: Publishing: $2.25 Million For Love Signs Rights
description: WHAT is believed to be the highest price paid for the paperback rights to a non fiction book was reached Wednesday, when Fawcett Books paid Harper & Row $2.25 million for the rights to Linda Goodman's Love Signs, a book of popular astrology. Harper & Row is the hardcover publisher.

title: Services for Barbara R. Michel
description: Funeral services will be held tomorrow for Barbara Richards Michel, a member of the president's council at Columbia University and a board member of the Episcopal Mission Society. Mrs. Michel died Wednesday at her home in New York City at the age of 61. The services are scheduled for 10 A.M. at St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue, at 71st Street.

title: Dow Rebounds, Climbing 8.92 on FarmPrice Drop
description: Stocks bounced back yesterday from Wednesday's sharp drop, thanks mainly to the report of a decline in November farm prices and strength in the American dollar in foreignexchange dealings. Glamour issues led the rally.

title: Dance: From Japan
description: SUZUSHI HANAYAGI's concert of solo dances at Japan House on Wednesday challenged many familiar Western notions of what dancing ought to be like.

title: Islanders Shake Off Slow Start, Gain 55 Tie and a Share of First
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Nov. 30  Bill Torrey leaned against the wall in the corridor outside the Islanders dressing room last night at the Forum. The grin on his face reflected the thoughts that were streaming through his mind like so many days of California sunshine. He knew that the Islanders had just stolen a point by gaining a 55 tie with the Los Angeles Kings.

title: Art People
description: ONE of the more demanding things to be in the world of art at this moment is a Russian artist in exile. Your roots are gone. your constiutuency is gone, your sense of the continuity of art is gone, and after the first excitement of your arrival people are likely to get on with their own business and forget all about you.

title: BUSINESS
description: The nation's growth rate may fall below the 3 percent predicted earlier by Administration officials, President Cartersaid. But noted that he did not expect either a recession or depression next year. The President's remarks were taken as his first acknowledgment that recent forecasts by private economists might be closer to the mark than those of his top advisers. [Page A1.]

title: Doctor in Laboratory Conception Says First 100 Attempts Failed
description: The birth of Louise Brown in Britair last July as a result of implantation in her mother's womb of a laboratoryfertilized embryo came after roughly 100 unsuccessful efforts, according to one of the two doctors who developed the procedure.

title: 5Year Term in July 4 Shooting
description: A gasstation attendant who shot and killed an 11yearold boy while using his 38caliber revolver as a noisemaker during Fourth of July festivities last summer was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn to a fiveyear term. Judge Hyman Barshay pronounced the sentence on Recep Ahmedoff, a 23yearold Bulgarian immigrant and resident of Brooklyn. The victim was Mario Arroyo of 6309 20th Avenue. Mr. Ahmedoff acknowledged at his trial that he had drunk several beers and that he fired several shots into the air. One bullet subsequently hit the boy.

title: Stage: Expressionism Today
description: WITH more than 70 plays to his credit, Georg Kaiser was not only one of Germany's most productive playwrights, he was alsoas a leading Expressionist  a pivotal figure in 20thcentury theater. However, in contrast to Ins countryman Bertolt Brecht, he has been largely neglected in the United States. The Direct Theater has somewhat rectified that oversight with Approaching Zero, Thom Thomas's adaptation of Kaiser's massive Gas trilogy, which opened Wednesday as a guest attraction at La Mama.

title: Events and Openings
description: THE VOYAGE, directed by Vittorio de Sica; starring Richard Burton and Sophia Loren; at the Thalia Theater

title: Suspect in the Murder Of Nurse Is Captured After Street Shootout
description: Nathan Giles, who had been hunted for six days by the police for the murder of nurse, was wounded and captured early yesterday after a highspeed automobile chase through lower Manhattan that began with a minor traffic violation and ended in a wild gun battle.

title: City Studies Leasing of Cabs to Drivers
description: Taxi owners in New York City may soon be permitted to lease their cabs, changing the face of an industry that some people some say is badly in need of a facelift.

title: Taiwan Hints at Olympic Entry
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Nov. 30  In a surprising turnabout, Taiwan's sports officials hinted today that the nation would participate in the 1980 Olympic Games in Moscow.

title: InjuryPlagued Knicks Lose To Hawks in Overtime, 102  96
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 30  The New York Knicks, playing without Spencer Haywood and Bob McAdoo, got solid fillin performances from John Rudd and Glen Gondrezick tonight, but still lost their third straight game, this time by 10296 in overtime to the Atlanta Hawks.

title: Explosion in Jerusalem Kills Arab; Police Believe He Carried a Bomb
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 30  A powerful bomb went off on a road on the Mount of Olives today, killing one man.

title: President Calls for Steps to Improve U.S. Intelligence on Foreign Crises
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  President Carter ezpressed concern today over the quality of American intelligence reporting on foreign political crises and said that he had asked top aides to take steps to improve methods for collecting and analyzinginformation on sensitive developments abroad.

title: Restaurants
description: HISAE VILCA, the Japanese genius of the kitchen, who has created a completely new style of fish and vegetable cookery based on Oriental, Italian and vegetarian precepts, can be considered a culinary Pied Piper. Just as soon as she opens another new outpost, loyal fans follow in droves. The telephone line becomes busy immediately and incessantly, and reservations are generally needed days in advance for the busiest lunch and dinner hours.

title: Blumenthal Going to Bonn
description: BONN, Nov. 30 (AP)  Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal is expected in Bonn next week for talks with Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany and other officials on monetary matters. West German sources said today that Mr. Blumenthal would arrive here Dec. 8 from Moscow, where he is to attend a meeting of the SovietAmerican economic commission.

title: Rate of Lost Workdays Falls
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP)  Working days lost because of strikes during October fell to the lowest level for the month in six years, the Labor Department reported today. Its Bureau of Labor Statistics said that work stoppages cost the economy 2.3 million workerdays during October for a rate of 1.2 idle days per thousand.

title: Mandel Venture To Review Media
description: Charles Mandel has, he says, parlayed his turnaround of Madison Avenue magazine and success as ad director of Penthouse's new Omni magazine into a successful magazineconsulting venture and plans for still another magazine. This time, a review of communications (including advertising) and journalism. Sort of a popular More, he hopes.

title: Flyers Set Back Blues, 30
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 (AP) Blake Dunlop and Bobby Clarke had a goal and an assist apiece tonight as the Philadelphia Flyers defeated the St. Louis Blues, 30, in a National Hockey League game.

title: MIRIAM P. W. de CASTRO
description: Miriam Perkins Walker de Castro, a teracher in elementary schools for 40 years, died of cancer yesterday at her home on Central Park West. She was 78 years old.

title: A Success Story At Farrar, Straus
description: In an ordinary office building bordering Union Square, somewhere above Wright Way Tours and below the Dance Notation Bureau, there is a complex of offices where the furniture is some years from being new and the waiting room offers nothing to read. This is Farrar, Straus & Giroux, and these are some of its monuments: The Assistant,', To the Finland Station, The Dead Father, Coming into the Country, Day by Day, A Crown of Feathers,','August 1914, The Professor of Desire, Love in the Ruins.

title: Hostage Calls Abductor Crazy
description: Mr. Smith, the son of a Baptist minister, is a quiet young man. His 126pound frame scarcely fills a blue peacoat that is wrapped tightly around him..

title: Hostility of Icelanders to American Base Melts a Bit
description: KEFLAVIK, Iceland  An afternoon newspaper published a photo of a display of cockroaches recently and accompanied it with the explanation that they seem to thrive in the presence of the American military man.

title: Koch Appeals To State to Pay Costs of City U.
description: Mayor Koch yesterday called on New York State to assume the costs of running the City University of New York's eight fouryear colleges and graduate school, but he said he would oppose very aggressively any attempt to merge the State University of New York with the City University.

title: Somoza Agrees to Allow Plebiscite To Decide His Future in Nicaragua
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Nov. 30 (Reuters)  President Anastasio Somoza Debayle agreed tonight to a plebiscite on his future, as proposed by an international mediation team.

title: Gilbert, Miss Miller Lead by Shot on 65
description: LARGO, Fla., Nov. 30  Ostensibly what is going on this weekend at the Bardmoor Country Club is the third annual mixed team championship, but basically it amounts to a test of cornpatibility. Two strange personalities a man from the PGA Tour and a woman from the tour of the Ladies Professional Golf Association  are brought together and either they adapt to each other or they don't score many birdies.

title: World News Briefs
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 30 (AP)  The exiled Moslem leader who heads efforts to topple the Shah of Iran has called on his supporters to begin an indefinite general strike Saturday, sources among Iranian dissidents reported today.

title: U.S. Warning Aircraft Grounded
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP)  The Air Force announced today that it had grounded its entire 14plane fleet of advanced airborne warning aircraft because of fuel pump defects.

title: Young Will Succeed Biemiller  In A.F.LC.I.O. Legislative Post
description: WASHING ON, Nov. 30 The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations announced today the appointment of Kenneth Young as director of its department of legislation, succeeding Andrew J. Biemiller, who is retiring at the end of the year.

title: Donald Joseph Hurley, 71, Dies; Boston Lawyer and Civic Leader
description: Donald Joseph Hurley, president of the Permanent Charity Fund, Boston's largest foundation, and retired senior partner of the law firm of Goodwin, Proctor & Hoar, died Wednesday of cancer at his home in Weston, Mass. He was 71 years old.

title: Times of London Halts Publication Amid Bitter Disputes With Unions
description: LONDON, Nov. 30  The Times of London, a British and international institution, suspended publication tonight in a bitter dispute with its unions.

title: Film: A Late de Sica:From Pirandello Novel
description: IN common with many other great men, Vittorio de Sica, the Italian film maker who died four years ago. had a chronic weakness that was as disorienting to him as a whiff of booze can be to the alcoholic. Mr. De Sica, the social critic ("The Bicycle Thief") with an immense talent for comedy as both an actor ("It Started in Naples") and as a director ("Marriage Italian-Style"), was from time to time subject to fits of teary sentimentality that upset his balance and completely dissolved his judgment.As a sentimentalist Mr. De Sica never went on a bender by himself. He surrounded himself with friends, as if the making of these ponderously romantic movies were really occasions of great conviviality. Perhaps they were, though it never shows in the completed pictures.Think of the laughably long-faced "A Place for Lovers," in which the magnificently structured Faye Dunaway succumbed to Marcello Mastroianni and death (in that order) in some of the most beautiful scenery in the world, from a disease never identified except for the lack of horrid symptoms.In "Sunflower" he persuaded Mr. Mastroianni and the exuberant Sophia Loren to play out a woeful tale about a plucky little peasant woman who hitchhikes her way to the Soviet Union after World War II to search for her reportedly lost-in-action soldier-husband. Does she find him? Does Naples have a bay?That "The Voyage," which Mr. De Sica made the year before he died, is only now reaching us is not difficult to understand. The film, which opens today at the Thalia Theater, has the manner of something out of sync with itself and the world around it.I'm not referring to the sound of the English-dubbed dialogue, which isn't great (though the film's three stars, Miss Loren, Richard Burton and Ian Bannen, are speaking their own lines), but to other aspects of the film that are even more important."The Voyage," based on a Luigi Pirandello novel I do not know, is set in Sicily in the years just before World War I and is another unnamed-fatal-disease picture.It's the unusually unconvincing story of Cesare Braggi (Mr. Burton), the scion of rich landed gentry, his younger brother Antonio (Mr. Bannen), and the beautiful young seamstress Adriana (Miss Loren) whom Cesare loves but whose hand he presents to Antonio in accordance with the wishes expressed in their father's will.Nothing in the movie fits. The casting of two extremely English actors as Sicilian aristocrats need not have been ludicrous  one of the best performances Burt Lancaster ever gave was in Luchino Visconti's "The Leopard."But even if Mr. Burton and Mr. Bannen had been Italian they would have been wrong for the movie. They are too old and their temperaments do not suit the cinematic landscape. Miss Loren's age is not right but, worse, she has no role.The movie, now at least four years old, may have been edited somewhere along the line  I do not know  but the evidence on view at the Thalia suggests there never was a role for this most intelligent, inventive, seductive, profoundly surprising of actresses."The Voyage" consists of a lot of pretty sets and costumes, much period detail (an early automobile with unreliable brakes is a key plot device), some comically irrelevant references to world events (like that nasty shooting in Sarajevo), while the two lovers refuse to acknowledge their passion until a major obstacle to that passion falls off the side of a mountain.Movies like "The Voyage" couldn't be made without falls off mountains, nor without the sort of heart trouble Adriana suffers without too much inconvenience until it's time for the film to end. Then it's gulp, over and out.The English-language screenplay, which, I assume, is faithful to the Italian one written by Diego Fabbri, Massimo Franciosa and Luisa Montagnana, is chock full of the kind of lines you haven'y heard since Andrew and Virgina Stone penned their screen version of "Song of Norway."Some are funny ("Who was that, dear?" "That was the maestro Puccini") but most are simply out of touch with the feelings and emotions the movie should be dealing in.

title: Most Companies Drop Insurance Of Properties of People's Temple
description: Nearly all the insurance companies that had been insuring the United States properties of the People's Temple have canceled their policies in the aftermath of the mass deaths at the Temple's jungle commune in Guyana.

title: U.S. Urged To Extend Steel Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  Specialty steel companies and the United Steelworkers of America petitioned today for an extension of import restraints initiated in 1976, but a high Common Market official warned that an extension could further impede already retarded negotiations to liberalize world trade.

title: Extradition of Suspect in Racial Bombing Is Denied
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 39  A Georgia judge ruled yesterday that J. B. Stoner, a selfstyled white racist, could not be extradited to Alabama for trial on a charge that he dynamited the church of a black civil rights leader in Birmingham more than 20 years ago.

title: Plankton Found; Scientist Sought
description: A visiting West German scientist's 80 vials of plankton, a form of minute marine plant and animal life, were stolen Wednesday night when his rented car was broken into near Union Square.

title: EARNINGS
description: Profits of the British Petroleum Company Ltd. rose by 42.8 percent in the third quarter compared with the same period a year ago. The sales gain was 19.3 percent. However, the giant international oil company's net for the first nine months declined by 7.2 percent on an 18.2 percent sales increase, according to yesterday's report.

title: TV Exports Off in Japan
description: TOKYO, Nov. 30 (AP)  Japan's color television exports in October totaled 285,015 units, down 7.9 percent from the year before, and down 38 percent from the previous month, the Electronic Industries Association said today.

title: U.S. Judge Denies Plea to Dismiss Charges Against 3 F.B.I. Officials
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 30  A Federal judge today denied a motion to dismiss charges that L. Patrick Gray 3d, the former Acting Director of the Federa Bureau of Investigation, and two other former bureau officials conspired to violate the rights of Americans in connection with the F.B.I.'s hunt for radical fugitives.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  The news out of China these days seems almost as vague as the flickering shadows on the wall of Plato's cave. Nobody here knows what it means, but everybody senses that something of historic importance may be happening.

title: Execution Stay Vacated for Pair
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 30 (AP) Minutes after a Utah Supreme Court justice stayed the execution of two convicted killers, the entire fiveman court today vacated the stay.

title: Mugger Is Given Four to 12 Years In Assault Case
description: Davereaux Wiggins, who was accused of hurling a 28yearold airline stewardess.in front of an onrushing subway train last July after putting a knife to her throatand grabbing her, handbag, was sentenced to four to 12 years in prison yesterday after pleading guilty to a robbery charge. A charge of attempted murder was dropped, and the sentence was half the maximum that could have been imposed.

title: Peking Reportedly Orders a Halt To Rallies and AntiHua Posters
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 30  Chinese authorities have reportedly ordered people in Peking to stop putting up wall posters critical of Hua Kuofeng, the Communist Party Chairman, and have told them not to join in inflamatory demonstrations calling for democracy.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Third international Invitational of Photography, which opened Wednesday at the French Embassy, 975 Fifth Avenue, at 79th Street, will be open to the public from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Monday to Friday through next Thursday. The exhibition will not be open weekends, as was incorrectly stated on Wednesday in the Going Out Guide. Admission to the auction of photographs Thursday evening will be free, but tickets to a gala reception start at $25 and are taxdeductible.

title: Market Place
description: IT'S a staggering idea, but this year 29 percent of all United States households are expected to buy new cameras.

title: IN THE NATION
description: SWAKOPMUND, Namibia  Just south of here along the road to Walvis Bay, the Atlantic Ocean sweeps in grandly from the west. Beyond the beach, high. and shifting sand dunes roll away into the African interior.

title: Thousands Attend Funeral Mass For Slain San Francisco Mayor
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30As a thick fog hung over this city for the third straight day, thousands attended a funeral Mass this morning at St. Mary's Cathedral for Mayor George R. Moscone, who was slain Monday morning in his City Hall office.

title: Taiwan Seeks Chrysler Plant
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Nov. 30  Taiwan has invited the Chrysler Corporation to enter a $70 million joint venture for the production of heavyduty trucks in Taiwan, the Ministry of Economics announced today.

title: U.S. Aides Tour Third Water Tunnel
description: High Federal officials descended 400 feet into a shaft and rode for a mile on a damp, bumpy work train in a New York City water tunnel yesterday to demonstrate their concern for urban water problems.

title: Auctions
description: THE toylands children rarely see are those assembled by the auction galleries each December. But adults with a passion for vintage windup toys, chinahead dolls, electric trains and lead soldiers are usually very much in evidence bidding briskly for additions to their colletions. Next week there will be at least two opportunities for toy collectors to excercise their handwaving and winking skills at auction. The first gaveling sessions are at PB EightyFour, 171 East 84th Street, the uptown annex of Sotheby Parke Bernet, on Wednesday at 10 A.M. and 2 P.M.. At this auction of 625 lots, there are more than 2,000 lead soldiers and a wagonload of castiron banks, Lionel trains, doll houses and their furnishings, Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck watercolors, and 19thcentury and 20thcentury dolls. The choicest selections are a 1930 Lionel sixcar set that is estimated to sell for $9,000 to $11,000, 40 groups of model soldiers that are expected to range from $300 to $800, a late 19thcentury Screaming Jumeau doll ($4,000 to $5,000) and a Kestner Googleyeyed doll that may bring $3,500 at the outside.

title: Youthful Dancers From Yugoslavia Soar at Carnegie Hall
description: The stage will be overtaken by a kind of terpsichorean children's crusade tonight when Abrasevic, the Yugoslav dance company, makes its New York debut at Carnegie Hall. They are young people, Dragoslav Dzadzevic, artistic director and choreographer of Abrasevic, said of the 60 company members, who range in age from 9 to 20. But they are not young dancers. Some have been dancing for 10 years.

title: Russian Child, Called Gravely Ill, Has Apparently Long Been Well
description: Jessica Kats, the infant daughter of Russian couple whose effort to emigrate to the United States was aided by widely circulated reports that the child was gravely ill, has apparently been in good health ever since the campaign on the family's behalf began last spring, the leaders of the principal organization supporting the family said yesterday.

title: Union Sues U.S. In Move to Void PayPrice Curbs
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 1  President Carter's antiinflation program was challenged as unconstitutional today in a Federal court suit brought by a striking West Coast union. The action is believed to be the first test of the program's legality.

title: Democratic Party to Collect Fee For Promoting Visa Credit Cards
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1  The Democrats are joining the Republicans in promoting credit cards, and plan to take a commission on the charges a cardcarrving Democrat runs up.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: COLOGNE, West Germany, Dec. 1 (AP)  The West German airline Lufthansa said today it had ordered 32 Boeing 737 twinjets valued at $400 million.

title: Amoco 2d To Allocate Gasoline
description: The Amoco Oil Company yesterday became the second company to start allocating gasoline supplies.

title: Emergency Phone Set For Garbage Removal
description: City officials have set up a special telephone number so that instances where garbage has piled up and created health or safety hazards can be reported.

title: Suspended 911 Operator on Job Past Retirement Age
description: The Police Department's civilian operator of the 911 emergency phone who was suspended on charges of mishandling a call involving the murder of Bonnie Anne Bush, the Mount Sinai Hospital nurse supervisor, was allowed to remain on the job last September past the mandatory retirement age of 65 so she could qualify for a city pension, police officials acknowledged yesterday.

title: Lawyer for 2 in Killings Asserts Guyana Survivors Are Held Illegally
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 1  A Guyanese lawyer for two members of the People's Temple who are charged with murder says that more than half of the surviving members of the cult, who number more than 70, are being detained here unlawfully.

title: For Army, Navy, It's the Only Game
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1  There was a small gathering on The Plain at West Point, N.Y., that fall day in 1890 when an established Navy football team rode up the Hudson River by boat, picked up a stray goat along the way and then whipped the new Army team in the Cadets first football game. Just a. few officers and their families stood there watching.

title: Michele L. McEvoy Bride of Equestrian
description: Michele Lee McEvoy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Raphael McEvoy of WinstonSalem, N.C., formerly of Summit, N.J., was married yesterday in London to Timothy Richard John Grubb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard John Grubb of MeltonMowbray. Leicestershire. Eneland.

title: Deaths
description: Bancroft. Janet

title: Radio
description: Music

title: EARNINGS
description: The City Stores Company, which operates Franklin Simon, W. & J. Sloane and Hearn's in its retail chain, reported yesterday a net income of $25,000 for its third fiscal quarter ended Oct. 29, compared with $64,000, or 2 cents a share, earned in the corresponding three months last year. Sales for the quarter increased 5.7 percent to $78.1 million from $73.8 million a year ago.

title: Hometown of the Leader of People's Temple Is Troubled
description: RICHMOND, Ind., Nov. 29  It took Sparky Anderson's dismissal by the Cincinnati Reds to knock the Rev. Jim Jones and his cult in Guyana off the front page of The Richmond PalladiumItem. Even those who thought the manager had got a raw deal agreed it was about time this city had something else to think about.

title: U.S. Accuses 6 Serbians Of Plotting to Slay Tito
description: CHICAGO, Dec 1 (Reuters)  The United States authorities announced today that six Serbians had been indicted on charges of plotting to assassinate President Tito of Yugoslavia on a visit to Washington last March.

title: TaxFree Capital Gains Proposed
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Dec. 1 Representative William A. Steiger, whose amendment proposing a substantially lower capital gains tax rate became a cause clbre for the securities industry this year, said today that he would introduce a bill in the next session of Congress to establish special capital gains investment accounts on which no taxes would be paid.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers to quiz are on page 28.

title: Customs Patrol: Seagoing Ferrets
description: They don't write novels about the nosiest seafarers in New York, the United States Customs Patrol officers, but they have their moments as they board ships and prowl through piers looking for things that should not be found in the company of lawabiding sailors.

title: Letter: On M.T.A. Investments
description: To the Editor:

title: Koch Is Said to Have Picked Kelly, An Urban Expert, to Run Hospitals
description: Mayor Koch has chosen Eamon M. Kelly. a Ford Foundation executive, to be the next president of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation, according to highly placed city officials.

title: Your Money
description: WITH housing prices rising almost geometrically, the outofpocket expense of buying a home has torn through the roof, too. According to the Department of Housing and Urban Developulent, closing costs  including brokerage fees range from 7 to 12 percent of purchase price.

title: CEAUSESCU APPEALS FOR SOCIALIST UNITY
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, Dec. 1 President Nicolae Ceausescu, in what appeared to be a conciliatory gesture toward the Soviet Union, appealed today for socialist unity as he restated Rumania's apposition to Soviet demands for increased military spending and for closer integration of Warsaw Pact commands.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON AN additive for lubricating oils was patented this week and is reported to increase car mileage by 10 to 15 percent and sometimes much more. Trademarked Tufoil, the additive is in use by more than two dozen municipal police department fleets in New Jersey and by several industrial fleets.

title: Rockwell Sells Admiral
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said that it had sold its Swissbased subsidiary, Admiral S.A., which owns the Admiral television manufacturing plant in Taiwan, to a group of Asian businessmen. Terms of the sale were not disclosed. Rockwell said the purchasers were a group of Far Eastern businessmen who have interests in Hong Kong, the Philippines and other Asian countries.

title: Connecticut School Funds
description: The proposed new method of financing public schools in Connecticut represents a concerted effort both to avoid the mistakes of other states and to respect the political realities in a state that clings tenaciously to the tradition of local control of schools.

title: Money
description: FRIDAY., DEC. 1, 1978

title: Soviet Doctor's Comments
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 1  A. Soviet doctor who treated Jessica Kats here said last May that her illness was grave and subject to complications but added that Soviet medicine was giving her the best possible care.

title: ExSheriff Is Sentenced to 2 Years
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 1 James G. Clark, the former sheriff who became a symbol of resistance to black voting rights during the civil rights demonstrations in Selma in the mid1960's, was sentenced today to two years in Federal orison for smuggling marijuana.

title: Eamon M. Kelly's Rise From Fordham to Ford
description: Eamon M. Kelly, who was born in the Bronx, attended Fordham University on a football scholarship. His playing weight as a guard was 210 pounds, and he reluctantly concedes that his 5foot 9inch frame has filled out since those days despite thriceweekly bouts on the squash court to keep in shape.

title: Free Parking in Brooklyn
description: Motorists will be allowed to park free in a parking field in the heart of downtown Brooklyn during December, the Department of Transportation announced yesterday. Commissioner Anthony R. Ameruso said the Albee Square Municipal Parkins Field. scheduled to be closed permanently on Jan. 1, would provide free parking for shoppers as a holiday bonus. The 241space parking field, on Flatbush Avenue between Fleet and Willoughby Streets, will be closed for construction of the Fulton Street pedestrian mall.

title: Mary Townsend Moore, at 60, Wife of Former Canada Dry Head
description: Mary Townsend Moore, the wife of Roy W. Moore Jr., former thief executive of the Canada Dry Corporation and a trustee of the Roosevelt Hospital, died at her home yesterday after a long illness. She was 60 years old and lived at 1481 Hillside Road, Fairfield, Conn.

title: Kennecott, Fighting Off Curtiss, Picks New Chief
description: Directors of the Kennecott Copper Corporation, preparing for a second election battle against the CurtissWright Corporation, yesterday elected Thomas Davies Barrow, a leading geologist, as its chairman and chief executive.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Free Taped Radio Spots Will Be Provided By the White Howse to 600 U.S. Stations
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 This is Rich Nelson at the White House...

title: Long Urges A Radical Tax Shift
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1  Senator Russell B. Long has recommended a radical change in the Federal tax system  a repeal of the Social Security payroll tax and the imposition of, in his words, a hidden sales tax that could raise enough revenue to permit a deep cut in personal incometax rates.

title: Torsney Release Sought in Court By Psychiatrist
description: A courtappointed psychiatrist yesterday seconded the recommendation of state mental health officials that Robert H. Torsney, a former New York City police officer involved in the killing of a 15yearold black youth, be released from custody  although with some conditions, such as reporting regularly for some kind of outpatient medical care.

title: Corporate Earnings Reported
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Amin, Reappearing After 2 Days, Said to Be Leading Border Force
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 1  President Idi Amin of Uganda, whose whereabouts has been uncertain for the last two days, was reported in a Ugandan broadcast today to be conducting a successful military operation in the south to drive the Tanzanians out of Uganda.

title: 20YearOld Is Given A 4to12Year Term In Central Park Rape
description: A 20yearold sandwichshop employee who raped one woman jogger in Central Park 10 minutes after he attempted to rape another woman was sentenced yesterday to four to 12 years in jail.

title: McHargue Surpasses $6 Million, But Postpones Pursuit of Record
description: Darrel McHargue became yesterday only the second jockey in thoroughbredracing history to earn more than $6 million with his mounts in one season. But the odds are long that he will set a oneyear earnings record bebause I'm tired and plan to start a threeweek vacation Monday.

title: TENG AND HUA JOIN IN PEKING RECEPTION
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 1  In what seemed to be an attempt to demonstrate unity in China, the Communist Party Chairman, Hua Kuofeng, appeared with Teng Hsiaoping and other senior leaders today. There were increasing indications that a decision had been made to clamp down on the public political debate in Peking.

title: Plan to Lease Taxis Is Debated
description: Hundreds of cab drivers went before the Taxi and Limousine Commission yesterday and did what some say they do more often than anyone: They offered opinions.

title: World Gold
description: FRIDAY, DEC. 1, 1978

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions on page 21

title: Manville Registration
description: The JohnsManville Corporation announced yesterday that the registration statement for shareholder approval of its acquisition of Olinkraft Inc. had been declared effective by the Securities and Exchange Commission and that mailing to shareholders would start shortly.

title: Abduction Leads to Placing of Ad
description: Philips, the Dutchbased electrical equipment company, has placed a twopage Spanishlanguage advertisement in The New York Times today in response to demands from a group in El Salvador that said it had abducted a Philips executive, Frits Schuitema, last Friday.

title: Agencies Held Powerless
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1  Faced with one of the most shocking and extensive losses of American lives outside wartime, top Federal officials consider themselves almost powerless to cope with the after math of the Guyanese tragedy, in terms of criminal responsibility for the past or domestic security for the future.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: A West Coast union filed suit against the guideline program of the Carter Administration in the first court test of the program's legality.
