The 22,000member Association of Western Pulp and Paper Workers charged in Federal court in Portland, Ore., that the Administration's voluntary wage and price standards are unconstitutional because they are actually mandatory controls that the President has no Congressional authority to impose. [Page 1.]

title: 1980 Primary Off to Early Start For G.O.P. in New Hampshire
description: CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 1  The 1980 Presidential primary campaign got off to an early start here tonight as some of the nation's leading Republicans gathered to court the favor of Gordon Humphrey, the virtually unknown conservative airline pilot who unexpectedly unseated Senator Thomas J. McIntyre last month.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday, Dec.1,1978

title: Spending Up For Building
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UPI)  Construction spending rose 0.1 percent in October to an annual rate of $208 billion, the Commerce Department said today.

title: McEnroe Takes Second Place
description: MILAN, Italy, Dec. 1 (AP)  John McEnroe defeated Adrian Panatta of Italy, 6.3, 76, tonight and won the $30,000 second prize in a fourman roundrobin indoor tournament. The match lasted only 1 hour 9 minutes.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: TOKYO, Dec. 1  The United States dollar rose sharply In heavy foreignexchange trading here today, surpassing the 200yen level for the first time in almost four months.

title: Steel Lockout In Germany
description: ESSEN, West Germany, Dec. 1 (AP)  Iron and steel managers locked out 29,000 workers from eight plants in northwestern Germany today, aggravating the first steel strike in the region in 50 years.

title: Chicago Hospitals Are Using New Kit to Help Rape Victims Collect Evidence
description: CHICAGO  Innocuouslooking brown cardboard boxes, newly stacked alongside medicines and bandages on the shelves of emergency rooms of Chicago and suburban hospitals, could be a powerful new weapon in the conviction of rapists in Illinois.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Coffee futures tended to drop yesterday the 4centapound daily limit on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, continuing Thursday's sharp decline. The March coffee contract closed at $1.2998. off 4 cents.

title: Judge Raises Jury Award to Burned Youth
description: MINEOLA, L.I. Dec. 1  A jury's award of $50,000 to a severely burned youth was criticized by a State Supreme Court justice today as so grossly indequate as to shock the conscience of the court.

title: Panel Backs Opening of a Fertility Clinic in Norfolk
description: The committee on human experimentation of East Virginia Medical School in Norfolk has approved the opening of a clinic to conduct laboratory fertilization and implantation of embryos as a means of overcoming sterility in some women.

title: Officials Uneasy Over the Effects Of Trash Pileup
description: Garbage started to pile up in front of hotels, restaurants and other commercial establishments in New York City yesterday, prompting city officials to express concern over possible health and safety hazards as 2,000 private sanitation workers struck the carting companies in a dispute over a new contract.

title: Herbert Gellendr 77, A Director, Producer And Teacher Is Dead
description: Herbert V. Gellendr, an actor, drama teacher, director and producer, died Thursday in Roosevelt Hospital after long illness. He was 77 years old and lived at 426 East 58th Street in Manhattan.

title: Carter Uncommitted on Money For Plan to Bolster Civil Defense
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 White House officials said today that, while President Carter had approved a new program for expanding the nation's civil defenses against nuclear attack, he had not yet committed himself to a level of financing for the plan.

title: Refugee Vessel Sinks; 43 Vietnamese Drown
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Saturday, Dec. 2 (AP)  A boat packed with refugees from Vietnam capsized in rough seas today after Malaysian police barred it from docking, leaving 43 drowned and 99 others missing, the police said.

title: Fire Destroys Fraternity House
description: OXFORD, Ohio, Dec. 1 (UPI)  A fire destroyed the Sigma Nu fraternity house at Miami University here today. The authorities said that the 68 residents of the house escaped unhurt.

title: Deaths
description: RESNICKLaura. beloved sister of Edith Zunder, loving aunt of Naomi Brander and Anne Cohen. Services Sunday, 11:30 AM, Parkside Chapels. Queens Blvd. e 66 Ave., Forest Hills.

title: Bridge:
description: Almost half a century ago, Ely Culbertson's books on bidding decreed that a suit was worth rebidding if it contained five cards with fair honor strength in the suit. But opinions in this area have hardened, and nowadays experts very rarely rebid a suit unless it contains six cards or more. Inexperienced players would be welladvised never to do so.

title: Antiboycott Law Held Success
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1  A year and a half after enactment, the hotly disputed legislation designed to combat the Arab embargo of Israel and of comparries involved with Israel is by general agreement having a positive effect.

title: Watts in a Chamber Group
description: Andr Watts, who is in the middle of an eightconcert celebration of Schubert, has appeared so far as a piano soloist, as a partner for a lieder singer and as a member of a chamber ensemble. It was in the last guise that he turned up in Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night. In this concert. he was joined by Charles Treger, violinist, and Laurence Lesser, cellist  constant colleagues in the series  plus Scott Nickrenz, violist, and James VanDemark, double bassist.

title: A Fivefold Rise in Errant Doctors
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP)  The number of physicians disciplined by state medical boards has increased fivefold in the last six years, according to the American Medical Association.

title: U.S. Women Advance At Federation Cup Net
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 1 (AP)  The United States, again paced by Tracy Austin and Chris Evert, defeated France in the first two matches today and advanced to the semifinals of the $130,000 Federation Cup tennis tournament. The two Americans had helped the United States gain the quarterfinals yesterday with victories over two New Zealand players.

title: Pushover Sentence for a Mugger
description: An airline stewardess waiting for a subway train on a deserted station at 96th Street and Central Park West was accosted by a man early one morning last July. He put a knife to her throat and grabbed her handbag. Then he pushed her off the platform. When she attempted to climb up, he kicked her in the face and she fell sprawling back onto the tracks.

title: Carter Will Not Seek to Deport Former Vietnam General, Aide Says
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1  The Carter Administration has no intention of deporting a former South Vietnamese general whose summary execution of a Vietcong prisoner in 1968 was shown on American television, a Justice Department official said today.

title: Turkish Bar in Berlin Attacked
description: WEST BERLIN, Dec. 1 (Reuters) Five knifewielding youths smashed up Turkish bar in an immigrant area of West Berlin last night and stuck Nazi swastikas and antiJewish slogans on the furniture, the police said today. The youths beat up a German customer and injured Turk.

title: Guyana
description: Nine hundred children of blessed memorynine hundred bodies rotting there in the jungle: her most sincere children renounce life, their cruel mother.

title: Skronski Faces A Crucial Call
description: RECRUITERS from such football powers as Penn State and Michigan State have been wending their way to Staten Island this fall to see John Skronski, a 17yearold senior at Monsignor Farrell High School, in action.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY TransAtlantic

title: A Brezhnev Loyalist Moving Up
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 1  There were two men at the gathering Wednesday of the Soviet Union's high and mighty who behaved as if they were supremely, serenely, in command.

title: Market Pushes Higher On Expanded Volume
description: A rejuvenated stock market pushed broadly higher on expanded volume yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average gained more than a dozen points.

title: Embassy Also Defended
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1The State Department, stung by persistent charges that it had ignored advance warnings of a plan for mass deaths at the People's Temple commune in Guyana, issued today a strongly worded defense of its actions and those of the United States Embassy in Georetown.

title: 2 Railroads Unable to Agree On How to Run an Escalator
description: A sign at the middle of the train platform reads Escalator  a promise of a welcome lift at the end of a long rail trip into Manhattan. But for the hundreds of travelers who regularly pour off trains at Tracks 15 and 16 at Pennsylvania Station, there is no ride and has not been one for more than four years while two railroads fought over who would pay the freight.

title: 10,000 Who Received Welfare Fraudulently Repay by Installments
description: More than 10,000 New York City welfare recipients who collected payments fraudulently in the past are repaying the money on the installment plan, interest free, sometimes over decades.

title: Amin's Loyal Aide, a Briton, Is Court Jester and Survivor
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 1  The second most hated man in Uganda, refugees from that country agree, is not a Ugandan at all. He is a middleaged Britishborn major with a saltandpepper mustache, a cockney accent and a shadowy past.

title: Deaths
description: BANCROFT Janet (Nee Goldsmith) of Ridgefield. New Jersey on November 30,1978 Age 45 years. Beloved wife of The Reverend Francis S. Bancroft III and the late William A. Currey Jr. Devoted mother of Wayne A. and the late Bruce William Currey. Dear daughter of Mabel (nee Carlson) end the late Harry A. Goldsmith. Dear sister of Robert A. Goldsmith. Visiting hours at Blade ley Funeral Home,Ccrner Broad & Elm Ave., Ridgefield. N.J. Saturday 24 and 79PM. Friends and relatives are invited to attend the Episcopal B urial Office at Saint Matthew's R.C. Church, Ridgefield, N.J. Sunday December 3, at 2 PM. Interment in Wellfieet, Cape Cod. Mass. at the convenience of the family. Those who so desire may send flowers or make gifts to Saint James Episcopal kid. N.J.

title: New NBCTV Program Tactics
description: There is something of a grand design to NBC's extensive midseason overhaul of its programming.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: A Drama Of Family Tragedy
description: Our lives go on. That's all I know, says Nikos, the protagonist  in suffering and finally in a kind of belligerent acceptance  of The Ballroom in St. Patrick's Cathedral.and often wise. What is wrong with this play by Louis Phillips, amid all that is right with it, is simply pace. The scenes are drugged by their own abundance and the effect on us is that of being held too long in the same place, of moving in amber from action to action.

title: Hinkle Pair Leads By 4 Shots
description: LARGO, Fla., Dec. 1  The rules of golf may be fair, but seldom are they kind.

title: Duke Downs N.C. State On a LastSecond Shot
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., Dec. 1 (AP) Gene Banks scored a basket with six seconds left tonight to give topranked Duke a 6563 victory over North Carolina State in the opening round of the Big Four basketball tournament.

title: About New York
description: Not only the eagles, but the jackals; too, would have it no other way. Once upon a time in this city, when Robert Moses was a soaring eagle, Joseph Kahn was a confessed jackal, a newspaper reporter good at unthreading secrets and scandals, but terrible, he admits, on feature stories because he always went around with an attitude that things were not being done right in the city.

title: CORRECTION
description: The time of tomorrow's concert by the Union Musical Band of Liria, Spain, at Columbia University's International House, 500 Riverside Drive, was given incorrectly in Weekend yesterday. The concert will be at noon, not 3 P.M.

title: DR. JOHN P. WEST
description: Dr. John P. West, a surgeon on the attending staff of St. Luke's Hospital, died there yesterday. He was 73 years old and lived at 200 East 66th Street.

title: Music by Five Young Composers
description: Youth was the keyword at the League of ComposersInternational Society for Contemporary Music concert Thursday night in Carnegie Recital Hall. The program featured recent works by five young composers, most of them in their 20's. Because the word mostly has become the fashion for so many concerts nowadays, this one was called Mostly Clarinet. Although that instrument was present in all but one composition, it hardly seemed prominent enough to justify the title.

title: EGYPT AND ISRAELIS WILL RESUME TALKS, U.S. AIDES DISCLOSE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 American of ficials said today that the stalemated EgyptianIsraeli negotiations would be resuming at an unspecified date. Earlier, President Carter had received Egypt's latest porposals for concluding a peace treaty with Israel.

title: In the City of Light, There Are Shades of Bright and Dark
description: PARIS  JeanPhilippe Lecat, the Minister of Culture, was suavely ambivalent at the ceremony dedicating the monumental sculpture by Joan Miro in the vast plaza of La Dfense, the complex of office skyscrapers at the western end of Paris on the line of sight that leads through the Arc de Triomphe, the Place de la Concorde and the gardens of the Louvre. It is a brutal confrontation of two universes, Mr. Lecat said, for there are no two universes more different than that of Joan Midi and the glass towers of La Dfense.

title: Around the Nation
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 1 (AP) Senator Edward W. Brooke, Republican of Massachusetts, under threat of having a court take over his assets, has come up with $55,000 and and a contract to turn over his Caribbean home to his former wife.

title: OBSERVER
description: With gourmet cooking becoming America's biggest indoor sport, the mail is filled with requests for advice about the best way to pamper the innards. A New Jersey woman, for example, writes to ask, When is it appropriate to serve cauliflower?

title: Giants' Newest Rumor: Bill Walsh of Stanford
description: The same National Football League team executive who correctly predicted in 1974 that Bill Arnsparger would take over as coach of the Giants, is now saying that Bill Walsh, the coach of Stanford University, will be the Giants' head coach in 1979.

title: TV: Duke Street Duchess
description: It may not measure up to his Upstairs, Downstairs, a tough act to follow in any case, but John Hawkesworth's The Duchess of Duke Street, which is being shown on Channel 13 from 9 to 10 P.M. on Sundays, has very substantial merits of its own.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, DEC. 1, 1978

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, Smetana's The Bartered Bride. 2: Verdi's Alda,

title: Division II Soccer Final A Rematch of Last Year
description: MIAMI, Dec. 1 (AP)  Seattle Pacific scored a suddendeath, tripleovertime victory by 10 over Southern Connecticut State College and Alabama A. & M. shut out Eastern Illinois University, 50, today to set up a rematch of last year's National Collegiate Athletic Association Division II soccer final.

title: Earl C. Sifers Jr. Marries Elizabeth T. Merriam
description: Elizabeth Thayer Merriam and Earl Churchill Sifers Jr. were married yesterday in the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien, Conn., by the Rev. Edward R. Danks.

title: The City
description: The New York State Board of Regents announced it had revoked the licenses of two Manhattan physicians on charges of incompetence, fraudulent practice and unprofessional conduct.

title: Chief Botha Sigcau, 66, First Transkei President
description: EAST LONDON, South Africa, Dec. 1 (Reuters)  The first President of the Transkei African homeland, Chief Botha Sigcau, died today. The 66yearold chief was rushed to a hospital yesterday after a heart attack.

title: A T.&T. and G.M. Support Wage Plan
description: The top officers of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the General Motors Corporation, two of the country's biggest companies, pledged yesterday to comply with the guidelines of the Carter Administration's voluntary wageprice stabilization campaign.

title: Japan Price Index Up
description: TOKYO, Dec. 1 (AP)  The consumer price index for Japan rose 0.2 percent in November over October, leaving it 3.3 percent above the November 1977 level, the Government reported today.

title: Begin Said to Consult Top Aides On Reopening Talks With Egypt
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 1 Prime Minister Menachem Begin was reported today to be consulting with senior aides as to whether Israel should reopen the stalled negotiations for a peace treaty with Egypt.

title: Protesters in Teheran Clash With the Army Over Holiday Curfew
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 1  Several violent clashes took place tonight between the Iranian Army and demonstrators who were violating the allnight curfew here on the eve of the holy month of Moharram.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 2, 1978

title: Dances by Faison, Lamb and Butler at the Ailey
description: On the whole, it was the dancers rather than the dance that shone Thursday at the City Center55th Street Theater, when the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater presented an evening of works by George Faison, Rael Lamb and John Butler.

title: The Changing Room
description: The whole matter of whether female sports reporters can be shut out of male locker rooms has gone from the silly to the exasperating. It all started last year when a woman baseball reporter for Sports Illustrated, Melissa Ludtke, sued Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn and cohorts, charging that her sex was being used to deprive her of the opportunity for postgame interviews routinely available at Yankee Stadium and elsewhere to her male competitors.

title: Fire Captain Is Partly Paralyzed After Wall Falls During S.I. Blaze
description: A 41yearold fireman was reported yesterday to have been partly paralyzed by injuries incurred when a brick wall at a vacant Staten Island dairy building tell on him and a partner.

title: Rose to Visit Again With Pirate Owners
description: Pete Rose, the object of a fourteam bidding war, will meet with the owners of the Pittsburgh Pirates for the second time today as he nears a decision on his baseball future.

title: Japanese To Be Freer In China
description: TOKYO, Dec. 1  China has proposed that Japanese trading companies open offices in Peking and receive longterm visas for their representatives a plan greeted with enthusiasm by Japanese businessmen here.

title: Chrysler Asks Loan Guarantees
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1  The ailing Chrysler Corporation, the nation's No. 3 auto manufacturer, is seeking $250 million in loan guarantees from the Farmers Home Administration, an Agriculture Department agency that supports economic development in rural areas.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: THEY'RE THE TOP Starting tomorrow afternoon, three of New York's bestknown club pianists can be heard free on successive Sundays on the third floor of Blomingdale's, Third Avenue and 59th Street, in a piano lounge of the new Christmas shop called Putting on the Ritz.

title: Books of The Times
description: Before Upstairs, Downstairs appeared on television, very few Americans seemed to be interested in a novel about a group of English servants looking after a wealthy English woman and her daughterinlaw in an Irish castle during World War II. Yet, Loving by the late Henry Green is one of the best novels I have ever read. Here are a few scenes from it.

title: Holiday Shopping Special
description: The ninth annual Fifth Avenue Holiday Festival will be held on consecutive Sundays, Dec. 10 and Dec. 17, during which Fifth Avenue will be closed to traffic from 39th to 57th Street from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M. The stretch will become a pedestrian mall for shoppers and sightseers.

title: Council on Sports Proposed for State
description: ALBANY, Dec. 1  Legislation to create a Council on Sports and Physical Fitness for New York State will be introduced to expand the commitment to amateur sports throughout the state.

title: Nets Conquer Warriors, 120110, On Comeback in Fourth Quarter
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 1 (AP)  Ed Jordan scored a seasonhigh 26 points and George Johnson added a careerhigh 25 tonight as the New Jersey Nets heat the Golden State Warriors 120110.

title: Conrail Postpones Plan To Abandon Some Lines
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1  The Consolidated Rail Corporation will put off for one year its plan to.abandon hundreds of miles of unprofitable lines in hopes that possible regulatory changes will permit a more creative approach to restructuring, the company said today.

title: Football's Hall of Persistence
description: In the years when Vin Draddy was hustling donations for a College Football Hall of Fame, he hosted a luncheon in Palm Beach, Fla., for several captains of industry. One of them, an oilman from Texas named Joe O'Neill, had promised to put up $100,000, and that day he rode over to the luncheon with a tire tycoon named Tom O'Neill, no relation. Tom O'Neill had another date. but Joe O'Neill suggested. Stop in for a drink. Tom O'Neill agreed and, after he was introduced around. Draddy asked him how much he planned to give to the Hall of Fame fund. Tom O'Neill shrugged, so Vin Draddy suggested, Why don't you pledge the same amount that Joe has? Tom O'Neill agreed, then casually inquired how much Joe O'Neill had pledged. Informed that the amount was $100,000, he blinked and then Draddy laughed. In the renegotiations, Tom O'Neill pledged $25,000 and departed in a daze.

title: The Nutcracker Season Opens at the State Theater
description: Not all ballets concentrate on dancing. In the past the performance of the giant Christmas tree and other spectacular stage effects in George Balanchine's version of The Nutcracker has seemed just as important as the various little cameo appearances by the dancers

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PRINCEVILLE, Hawaii, Dec. 1 (AP)  Dave Barr shot a solid 69 despite strong winds and teamed with Dan Halldorson to pace Canada to a surprising sevenstroke lead today after two rounds of the 26th World Cup golf tournament.

title: An Aide Denies Sadat Boycotts Nobel Award As Protest Over Talks
description: CAIRO, Dec. 1  The aide President Anwar elSadat has chosen to pick up his Nobel Peace Prize in Oslo Dec. 10 denied today that Mr. Sadat was boycotting the ceremony in protest against the stalemate in Egypt's peace talks with Israel.

title: New Fingerprints From Guyana Called Boon in Identifying Bodiet
description: DOVER AIR FORCE BASE, Del., Dec. 1  Federal officials expressed hope today that fingerprints taken in Guyana when members of the People's Temple entered the country would permit identification of virtually all adults who died in the mass deaths.

title: 2 Britons Reported Kidnapped
description: SAN SALVADOR, Dec. 1 (AP)  Two British bankers have been reported kidnapped in El Salvador following the abduction of a Dutch executive by leftist guerrillas. The bankers, Ian Massie and Michael Chatterton, were kidnapped early today near the Bank of London and Montreal, which they run, a bank employee said.

title: CARTER DESIGNATES U.S. LAND IN ALASKA FOR NATIONAL PARKS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1  President Carter placed more than 56 million acres of Alaska's Federal lands in the National Park system today, locking them away from mineral or oil development unless Congress acts to open some of them.

title: Tokyo Getting the Disney Style
description: TOKYO, Dec. 1  The tentative agreement announced this week to build a Disneyland in Japan, Walt Disney Productions' first international venture, was four years in the making. Discussions on a business tieup with the Oriental Land Company, a Tokyobased land developer, started in 1974 when Disney officials first visited Japah. The project has been delayed by rising local costs for construction and labor and protracted negotiations with Disney over royalty payments.

title: Kahn Says Carter Will Ask Governors' Price Aid
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 1  Alfred E. Kahn, the director of President Carter's antiinflation program, said today that the President would ask the nation's governors to use the purchasing power of state governments to encourage businesses to follow the Administration's price guidelines.

title: Oklahoma. Osage. Oil Camps. Frankie. Cecilia. Mike.
description: FAIRFAX, Okla. By 1958, when I graduated from high school here, my father had a secure job with an oil company that leased drilling rights from the Osage Indian nation.

title: Both Arts and Patrons Benefit, at Two Lively Parties
description: Isolated in lonely cabins in the snows of New Hampshire, at this very moment a small but determined band of artists and writers labors over selfimposed creative tasks. Doubtless they are clad predominantly in blue jeans and boots, as befits the locale; and in the cold quiet woods, not a telephone call nor a sitcorn can disturb them.

title: Early Polaris Missile Had Defects
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1  The Department of Energy said tonight that approximately threequarters of the A1 model Polaris nuclear warheads deployed on submarines in the mid1960's were probably duds because of mechanical defects.

title: Hollander Alters Concert Program
description: Between a neighbor's complaints about the noise and his own inability to find a place outside his Manhattan apartment to practice, Lorin Hollander, the pianist, has been forced to reshuffle the program for a concert appearance in Portland, Me., next Tuesday night.

title: N.Y.R.A. Cites Gain, Rebuts OTB Charge
description: The New York Racing Association has disputed charges made last Tuesday by Bernard Rome, president of New York's City Offtrack Betting Corporation that the state's three major race tracks were being mismanaged by the N.Y. R.A. and that as a result the N.Y.R.A. should be abolished.

title: Iranian Denies Charges
description: Former Prime Minister Jamshid Amouzegar of Iran said yesterday that charges by the opposition that he was among 183 Iranians who allegedly transferred $2 billion out of the country were totally false. He said: I did no such thine. This fact has been confirmed at my request this week by the Central Bank of Iran. His name was among those on a list distributed to several journalists in Teheran by striking employees of the Central Bank. The list was described by the Government as a total fabrication.

title: F.A.A. Will Revise Air Procedure At Issue in San Diego Jet Collision
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 1  An airtraffic procedure whose significance in the midair collision here on Sept. 25 has been a focus of dispute will be revamped by next week, a Federal aviation official testified today.

title: U.S. Concedes a Conflict On VisaGranting Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP)  The Carter Administration is struggling to develop a policy for dealing with cases like that of two Soviet diplomats who have so far been denied visas to come to Washington for a conference, a State Department spokesman said today.

title: World News Briefs
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua. Dec. 1 (AP) President Anastasio Somoza Debayle said today that opposition leaders can go to hell if they did not like his plans for a plebiscite to determine whether he wouldstay in office.

title: FOSTER S. CUNNINGHAM SR.
description: Foster S. Cunningham Sr., president of the Fishkill (N.Y.) National Bank, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Highland Hospital in Beacon. He was 45 years old and lived on Philipse Brook Road.

title: A Mortgage Bill Raising Interest Gains in Albany
description: The New York State Senate's Republican leadership announced yesterday that it would accept limited restrictions against redlining as part of a bill to increase the ceiling on interest rates for mortgages, and called on Governor Carey to get the Assembly to move to an agreement.

title: WhiteCollarCrime Deterrents Urged
description: NEWARK, Dec. 1  The top law enforcement officials of New York and New Jersey told a Congressional committee today that whitecollar crime was so pervasive it was destroying the moral fabric of American society.

title: British Sports Disrupted
description: LONDON, Dec 1, (Reuters)  Frost and ice today forced the postponement and cancellation of many British sports events and caused a major disruption of tomorrow's English and Scottish football leagues' games.

title: Bonanza for the Blockbusters
description: While New York breathes, New York builds. After a long period of overbuilding, and then of no building, more than 30 major commercial and residential projects are under way in the city, while the conversion of smaller, older buildings has reached epidemic proportions. Largescale construction includes three corporate world headquarters, for A.T.&T., I.B.M. and Philip Morris, and a number of new hotels and office buildings. The American Stock Exchange, after flirting with other locations, plans a new home downtown. The Manhattan skyline is changing again.

title: The Region
description: WHITE PLAINS  Consolidated Edison has asked the Public Service Commission for permission to build a $66 million overhead transmission line between its Buchanan substation and Mount Pleasant to prevent blackouts. The request was filed last week, and public hearings have been scheduled for next week.

title: Police Seek to Tie More 9mm. Killings to Giles Gun
description: Nathan Giles, who was shot in a gun battle with the police and arrested as a suspect in the murders of three women in Manhattan, may be connected with several more P38 pistol murders, top official in the Detective Bureau said yesterday.

title: U.S. Will Help Israelis With Loan And Grant Totaling $785 Million
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. I (Reuters) The United States and Israel signed an agreement today under which Israel will receive $785 million during fiscal 1979 to help finance commodity imports, rebuild foreign exchange reserves and reduce shortterm indebtedness.

title: Court in Jersey Voids Bond Plan Passed by Voters
description: TRENTON, Dec. 1  A $100 million bond issue for prison construction was invalidated today by a threejudge state appeals court, which called it an unconstitutional form of legislative logrolling. The bond issue had been approved by voters on Nov. 7 by 918,000 to 642,000.

title: ISAAC BASHEVIS SINGER'S UNIVERSE;
description: Next Sunday, in Stockholm, Isaac Bashevis Singer will receive the 1978 Nobel Prize in Literature. Seldom before has he spoken publicly with such candor and intimacy as he does in these sometimes droll, often exalted, conversations with Richard Burgin, a writer. This week, in matchless Singer fashion, the Nobel laureate explores many of his favorite subjects: love and betrayal, Spinoza and Schopenhauer, his experiments in free will and his natural laziness, his admiration for Tolstoy and his private quarrel with the Almighty with hints, as Mr. Singer says, grinning puckishly, that if the Messiah won't come by Himself, we will have to force Him to come by picketing the gates of Heaven1

title: Proposition 13: Better Late Than Never
description: BECAUSE we have not retrieved enough from that rising, enforced remuneration that we are required to provide, even before we have the money in our own hands, before we have seen it smell it or ledgerize it as our own possession  maybe even save some of it for educating our children or ensuring our own independent comfort when the term fixed income becomes a reality  the selfcombustion of tax revolt has been smoldering for a long time.

title: American History on the Record
description: Avoice can cut through the hazy fog of time and bring yesterday's Images sharply into focus. With those recorded words in 1948. Edward R. Murrow not only introduced his brilliant I Can Hear It Now series, but also created a new medium for hearing history as it happened  the documentary record.

title: THE RISE AND FALL OF JEREMY THORPE
description: He was the brightest promise of the Liberal Party. There was a chance he would become Prime Minister of Britain. But today his career is in ruins, and the Rt. Hon. Jeremy Thorpe is facing the charge that he conspired to murder a former male model.

title: ANTIQUES
description: NEWARK LIKE icing on an already glorious cake, Christmas decorations are up in Ballantine House, an adjunct of the Newark Museum. They will remain on view through Jan. 8.

title: Carrying Title IX Too Far
description: The Federal Government's everexpanding role in the affairs of American higher education has struck home. And I am not happy about it.

title: A Victorian Don Pasquale
description: Gaetano Donizetti's comic opera Don Pasquale is, as Kurt Vonnegut might say, unstuck in time. When it had its premiere, in 1843, and for some years thereafter, the opera was given in contemporary dress. Soon after the composer's death, in 1848, fashion dictated that the staging of an opera in everyday clothes was senseless, and so Don Pasquale was moved back a century to the 1700's. In our century, the prevailing custom has been to reinstate the work to its original time frame, and that is how the Metropolitan Opera has presented it in the three productions and 61 performances it has mounted since 1900.

title: For the Neediest
description: This is the season of lists  of presents wanted and of gifts for family and friends. There are letters Santa, expectations for Hanukkah, and hints everywhere. The time for giving and receiving is only a few weeks away.

title: Engagements
description: KofflerKlein

title: Selling Classical Records by the Box
description: The customary seasonal flood of new classical records is upon us, new releases from virtually every major musician one would care to name. This year, however, we seem to be witnessing the full flowering of a trend that has been building for some time  boxed sets or collections of single disks covering various areas in a composer's oeuvre. Take Haydn, for example: At present there are, or will be in the near future, boxes devoted to the complete symphonies, string quartets, operas, oratorios, piano sonatas, piano trios and concertos, often in competing versions from different companies. Telefunken even has a grandiose scheme to record every last note of Haydn's vast output, a project that could well run to over 1,000 disks.

title: Philadelphia Plans Birth Control Course
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2 (UPI) The Philadelphia School District has proposed that junior and senior high school students be offered a course in birth control. If approved by the school board, students would study 11 types of birth control, seven for men and four for women.

title: PARLEY TO EXAMINE STATUS OF FREEDOM
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UPI)  In the name of William 0. Douglas, the status of individual freedom will be assessed next week by a number of officials, including Adm. Stansfield Turner, Director of Central Intelligence: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, Robert H. Bork, former Solicitor General, and Representative Barbara Jordan, Democrat of Texas.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: BECAUSE those who own snowthrowers never know just when the machine will be needed  snowstorms often arrive with little or no advance warning  the average homeowner never even thinks of doing anything with his snowthrower until the first snow actually falls. Unfortunately, this all too often leads to frustration and aggravation some dark night or early morning when the machine fails to start the way it should, or stubbornly acts up in some other manner.

title: The Only Thing We Have to Fear Is...
description: PERHAPS it comes from living in a place that is affectionately known as Cancer Alley. But whatever the reason, New Jersey will go down in history as the birthplace of Creative Paranoia.

title: THE CASE AGAINST THE WILMINGTON TEN
description: Six years ago, nine black men and one white woman were convicted of arson and conspiracy. Are they criminals or, as their supporters claim, political prisoners?

title: Forecasters Expect East To Have a Mild Winter
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UPI)  The Eastern Seaboard from Massachusetts to Florida, which has had two consecutive frigid winters, will bask in abnormally warm temperatures this year if the national longrange forecast holds true.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: Jones's Papers Show Influence Attempt in Guyana
description: JONESTOWN, Guyana, Dec. 2 (AP) Senior aides to the Rev. Jim Jones sought to force Guyana's Police Commissioner to stop an impending investigation of the People's Temple settlement here earlier this year, according to material contained in 120 pages of Mr. Jones's personal papers acquired by The Associated Press.

title: Places
description: The city's retail areas have shifted with changing residential areas, but department stores have not moved as fast.

title: Other Proiects Get $5 Billion in Interstate Road Trades
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2  By trading in 110 unbuilt miles of their interstate highway allotments, a dozen urban areas have earned allocations of $5 billion in Federal funds for other transportation projects, primarily mass transit.

title: Even the Camp David Accords Have Not Won Total Approval
description: CAIRO  Egyptian President Anwar elSadat disclosed last week that instead of going to Oslo himself to pick up the Nobel Peace Prize he is sharing with Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel, he will send a representative. Despite official disclaimers, observers saw this as an expression of Mr. Sadat's unhappiness with the current stalemate in peace negotiations. and with Mr. Begin, who will be in Oslo.

title: Euroloan Markets Feel Profit Squeeze
description: Ferocious competition and an abundance of liquidity have produced a dramatic upsurge in lending in the syndicated Eurocurrency market, both to industrialized and developing countries. But as the volume of loans in this borrower's market has escalated, the terms and standards of loanS have been declining, triggering a squeeze on the profitability of one of the major sources of earnings of multinational banks. The erosion of profit margins has gotten so bad, in fact, that American bankers say they are opting to stay out of more and more major credit arrangements.

title: Legislature Is Urged to Approve Job Development Agency for L.I.
description: Legislative proposals have lives of their own. Some seem to have the capacity to stay around for decades. Others disappear almost as soon as they are put forth.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: Today  Thomas School, Round Swamp Road, Melville, L.I. special working hunters, special jumpers, horsemanship. 8:30 A.M.

title: SPORTS
description: FROM the moment it was conceived, the'Four Seasons Tennis Club suffered from visions of grandeur. The largest such facility in New England 11 HarTru clay courts indoors, 14 HarTru clay courts outdoors  it has also tried to be the most luxurious, the most innovative, the most pampering, the most deluxe, the most avant garde club available anywhere.

title: St. John's Defeats Princeton
description: St. John's had the consistent shooting, and Princeton did not. That was the difference in their basketball game last night in Alumni Hall, where the Redmen trounced the Tigers, 7151, before 3.500 fans.

title: Bucks 106, Cavaliers 100
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, Dec. 2 (AP) Marques Johnson scored 15 of his gamehigh 34 points in the fourth quarter to rally the Milwaukee Bucks to a 106100 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers tonight. It was the Bucks' third straight triumph.

title: Knicks Rout Trail Blazers by 11177
description: The Knicks, who have struggled through close games, win or lose, much of the season, found a patsy last night.

title: CALENDAR
description: Today. Christmas Antiques Bazaar. Civic Center, 18 Harding Road, Old Greenwich. Take Exit 5 from Connecticut Turnpike. Noon to 6 P.M. Benefit Historical Society.

title: NEW BREED TAKING PACIFIC ISLES' REINS
description: COLONIA, Yap  Like all natives of Yap, a small Western Pacific island group best known for its stone money, John Mangefel grew up in simple village surroundings. Now he represents a new breed of island politician whose credentials for leadership include an American university diploma.

title: Police in California City Accused of Harassment
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2 (UPI)  The American Civil Liberties Union has filed a suit charging that MexicanAmericans in Anaheim live in fear because of harassment by the police and other officials there.

title: Mummy Is a Dummy At Tut Minimuseum
description: ROSLYN HEIGHTS LIKE thousands of others in the metropolitan area, the 132 sixthgrade students at the willets Road School here were unable to get tickets for the Tutankhamun exhibition that opens Dec. 20 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. But they have had their share of Tutanmania: a King Tut show all their own. get tickets for the Tutankhamun exhibition that opens Dec. 20 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. But they have had their share of Tutanmania: a King Tut show all their own.

title: Does America Have A Major Poet?
description: IN 1944 T.S. Eliot set himself the question What is minor poetry? and went some distance toward answering it by saying that minor poets are those whom we only read in anthologies. He then qualified that account by saying that every reader of poetry ought to have some minor poets whom, for one reason or another, he would want to read entireot's implication was that a major poet, though he will appear in anthologies, is miserably represented there and must be read entire or not at all. The distinction seems to me not only neat but valid. Sometimes the minor poet declares himself as such by writing little or by confining himself to one kind of poem or a restricted range or experience. A major poet is likely to be abundant; not necessarily in the sense that his published work is massive Eliot's own poetry'is not  but in the sense of being commensurate with the scale and latitude of his ambition.

title: Edwin W. Dickinson Dies at 87; Noted Representational Artist
description: Edwin W. Dickinson, an important representational American artist highly regarded by painters and critics as a master of painting in the Romantic tradition but one whose work stirred an equally deep interest among those drawn to the Abstract and Modernist schools, died yesterday at the Orleans Convalescent and Retirement Center in Cape Cod, Mass. He was 87 years old.

title: Cleveland, Facing Crisis on Loans, Held Likely to Default on Millions
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 1  Barring an 11th hour turn of events, this troubled industrial city appears headed for fiscal default, possibly this month.

title: Dryer, the ExGiant, Reflects, Laughing
description: It doesn't take much to make Fred Dryer laugh. He laughed all the way to Los Angeles when the Giants traded him seven years ago, and he's laughing as he returns today with the Rams.

title: Simple Ways to Balk Theft of Travel Funds
description: Leonard B. Mountford keeps his travelers checks aid other valuables in an inside pocket of his suit jacket. It does not show, but the pocket is fastened with an oversize safety pin.

title: Margo Sappington Medusa Given Premiere at the Ailey
description: Medusa, a new work by Margo Sappington, had its world premiere with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater Friday night at the City Center. It was full of sound and fury and signified nothing.

title: Switzerland Is Voting On Proposal to Create National Police Force
description: GENEVA, Dec. 2  Always suspicious of possible encroachment by Switzerland's federal administration on the rights of the 25 semiautonomous cantons, the Swiss are taking a hard look at a plan to provide the policeless central Government with a specially trained security force.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 2 (AP)  Dan Driessen, the Cincinnati first baseman, has agreed to a sixyear contract longest in the Reds' historythe Reds' president, Dick Wagner, announced today.

title: What's in a Name? A Sense of History
description: FASCINATION began for Richard M. Lederer Jr. when he became curious about the origin of the name of his White Plains street, Heathbloom Road. It was named after a racehorse, he found out. Later he moved to Horseguard Lane in Scarsdale and traced that street name, too. It emerged from a Revolutionary War term for the Westchester Guides, an auxiliary force of military scouts.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The Chief Justices of the United States have had short shrift thus far from the medalmakers of the Mintonly John Jay and Warren Burger have been honored up until now  so the threeinch bronze medals recently announced for Earl Warren and John Rutledge are overdue.

title: U.S. SENDING MISSION ON TRADE TO SOVIET
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2  President Carter, signaling an interest in pursuing the recent improvement in relations with the Soviet Union, sent a highlevel trade delegation to Moscow today with the word that he would relax export curbs imposed last summer, but not abandon them.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: The world of the future, or at least the housing of the future, has been taking shape in London since 1968, and is nearing completion now on Alexandra Road in South Hampstead. Although the 520unit project for approximately 1,660 people is still not finished, families have been moving in since spring. But the most frequent visitors are probably architects, who can be seen singly and in clusters, leaning over the balconies and crawling around the structure, curious to find out what the London Borough of Camden has wrought.

title: CHINA OFFERS IDEAS ON TAIWAN REUNION
description: PEKING, Dec. 2  Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping says that, in seeking the return of Taiwan to the Chinese motherland, China wants to retain the higher Taiwanese standard of living and to arrange a settlement that takes into account the island's different political system.

title: PEOPLE
description: Goldman Sac's last week added 11 new partners to its fold, bringing the number to 61. Among the new men on the roster:

title: Founder of Synanon Held in Snake Attack On California Lawyer
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2 (UPI) Charles Dederich, founder of Synanon; the drug rehabilitation colony, was arrested in Arizona today on a California warrant charging suspicion of conspiracy and solicitation to commit murder in the rattlesnake attack on a Los Angeles lawyer.

title: A Surprised Borough Park Taking Stock
description: It was 11:20 in the morning, and in the basement of the 66th Precinct statoon house was Brooklyn Sgt. Leonard Pittinsky was about to dig into what he knew would be a delicious chocolate cake, for it was homemade. Suddenly, the ceiling shook, and there was a great roar upstairs.

title: ARCHITECTURE
description: THESE are the days in which Architectural Digest's pages of pictures of lavishly decorated houses sell out each month at the newsstand, when realestate agents cannot find enough highpriced houses to meet the demand, when this newspaper fills a section each week with design tips for the house. We have been seeing this fascination with our own places of residence reflected In the publishing of howto decorating and design books for some time. This year, however, publishers seem to have expanded the turf to take in not just how to decorate our own houses, but also the fantasies and dreams we have about other houses. Books about great houses are nothing new, but this season they seem to dominate the Christmas selection. What publishers have decreed for the coffee table of the architecturally minded is a book about someone else's coffee table, most likely a very old and very expensive one.

title: BIG VERMONT STORES IN BLUELAW BATTLE
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Dec. 2  A county prosecutor has charged two feuding grocery stores with violations of the state's Sunday blue laws, which have already been ruled unconstitutional in District Court.

title: Listen to Me, Kid, All the Trainers Are Saying
description: FARMINGDALE. IT'S a case of bad casting. The onestory brick building centered in the open space of Ellsworth Allen Park in Farmingdale just doesn't look the Dart of a boxer's hangout.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: AFTER more than 50 years in hardcover, one of the great works of historical fiction published in this century has gone into paperback. The first of the three volumes that make up Sigrid Undset's Kristin Lavransdatter has just been issued by Bantam, exactly a halfcentury after the author was awarded the Nobel Prize for literature. The two concluding volumes are due from Bantam early next year.

title: Among the Spirits of the GodKings
description: In the quest for hard currency and goodwill, Cairo has eased travel restrictions and taken some of the irritation and unneeded adventure out of touring the monuments of Pharaonic Egypt, the civilization that rose from the muddy Nile more than 5,000 years ago.

title: Cmecticut/ThisWeek
description: FAIRFIELD  Annual exhibit; Young Artists Association of Fairfield, Friday through Dec. 30, Library, 1080 Old Post Road. Informadon 2598303.

title: INTERVIEW
description: BACK in 1970, Richard F. Schneller sold his business and retired at age 98. I have less vacation time, less personal time now than I did then, he said last week.

title: Arkansas 49, Texas Tech 7
description: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Dec. 2 (AP) Ben Cowins, a running back for the University of Arkansas, scored two touchdowns and topped 1,000 yards rushing for the third straight year today as the Razorbacks defeated Texas Tech, 497, in a Southwest Conterence game.

title: ANTIQUES
description: American silver, long overshadowed by British and continental designs, is gaining in popularity among collectorsat least some relatively late designs are. Several recent developments  a museum show, numerous auctions and the publication of a book have focused attention on the late 19th century when such stateside silver producers as Tiffany & Co. became known not only coast to coast but around the world too.

title: GIVING
description: For many people, Christmas shopping is not a chore; it is the enjoyable art of finding the right gift for the right person, of sharing the delight in discovered treasures, and a chance to share. Starting here, and continuing through the next twenty five pages, is a special collection of gift ideas that range from the practical to the luxurious, from knit hats and chocolate bars to precious objects in crystal and gold. They are Christmas pleasures of unique quality, design and craftsmanship that celebrate the art of giving.

title: Al Laney's Prose
description: Twentyfive years late but still not too late, the Metropolitan Golf Association has chosen Al Laney to receive the organization's Distinguished Service Award. The choice speaks well for the literary taste and for the memory of the selection cornmittee, for more than a decade has classed since Al's sensitive reporting and beautifully crafted prose last appeared in the daily press. He covered sports in America and abroad for The New York Herald Tribune, retiring in 1966 when the paper died. Now 82, he lives quietly in Spring Valley, N.Y. When Al was a schoolboy in Pensacola, Fla., the Cleveland baseball team, called the Naps after their manager, Napoleon Lajoie, pitched its spring training camp there. It was a thrilling enough experience, Al has written, to speak with Joe Jackson and Napoleon Lajoie, but of course they were not the Giants. In those days Christy Mathewson was a shining knight, and if the Giants won, then were the gods just and life a lyric.

title: Support for Rhodesia's Guerrillas Gets Costlier
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  In another apparent sleight of the white supremacist hand, Rhodesia announced last week a new framework for multiracial government that seems designed to maintain minority control behind a facade of black majority rule. The announcement, which dimmed the prospects for peace in Rhodesia, reverberated across its borders in the five socalled frontline states that have provided sanctuary and succor to Rhodesian black guerrillas at a cost of casualties, economic hardships and political instablity as severe or worse as any besetting the Salisbury regime.

title: Hot Dogs No Substitute For Turkey Luncheon
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Dec. 2 (AP) Thanksgiving will arrive in December this year at the Lincoln Elementary School, where students were forced to eat hot dogs on Thanksgiving because of forgetful administrators.

title: Venezuelans Are Voting for New President Today
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 2  After an expensive, long and noisy election campaign, dominated by heavy use of advertising rather than debate of the issues, Venezuelans vote tomorrow to choose a successor to President Carlos Andrs Perez.

title: Teacher Evaluation: Should It Be Based On Pupil Progress?
description: DISCLOSURE by the state's Board of Education that pupil progress will be used as one aspect of the evaluation of teachers has brought forth articles, editorials, letters to editors and, finally, a court sut assailing such a procedure.

title: Susan L. van Diepen Plans Spring Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Townsend van Diepen of Ormond Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Louise van Diepen, to Bruce Winthrop McShane, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon McShane of New Vernon, N.J., and Delray Beach. Fla. A spring wedding is planned.

title: What's Doing in PITTSBURGH
description: STEEL TOWN  Pittsburgh, with a metropolitan area population of approximately 2.5 million and a city population of about 500,000, is the largest city in western Pennsylvania. It is widely known as a city of steel mills, but its downtown sector is a handsome, bustling core brimming with gleaming modern structures like the 62story United States Steel Building (the tallest in town) and the I.B.M. Building, interspersed with nostalgic older buildings like the late Victorianstyle Jenkins Arcade (entrances on Liberty and Penn Avenues and Stanwix Street) and the Beaux Artsstyle Bank Center at Wood, Forbes and Fourth Streets. The downtown is crowned by Point State Park at the tip of the Golden Triangle where the Allegheny and Monongahela Rivers form the Ohio. Besides its buildings Pittsburgh offers a number of other attractions, such as the Duquesne and Monongahela funicular lines, boat cruises, a zoo and aviary, the Stephen Foster Memorial, the Cathedral of Learning at the University of Pittsand cultural and sporting events.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: Informed that 35 to 95 percent of the more than 10,000 tenants of municipally owned properties were not paying their rent, Mayor Koch was wroth last May. What an outrage, he said during A meeting with officials of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development. He said his administration would evict the deadbeats  including welfare tenants.

title: Deaths
description: LEVINEHoward Norman on Dec 1st. beloved and cherished husband of Jill. loving and adored father of Kelly and Gwen. devoted son of Evelyn and Morris Levine and dear son gy law of Douglas and Muriel Nystrom. Loving and dear brother of Richard and Faith, and Arlene and Mark Goldsmith. Adored uncle. Taken from us in Ms prime, our loss and sorrow is inconsolable. Services at BoulevardPark West 1450 Broadway. Hewlett. L. I., Sunday 12 won.

title: Georgia 29, Georgia Tech 28
description: ATHENS, Ga., Dec. 2 (AP)  Anthony Arnold caught a 42yard touchdown pass and then ran for a 2point conversion with only 2 minutes 24 seconds remaining, as Georgia edged Georgia Tech today, 2928.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: PreCoumbian Gold Items In Largest London Display
description: LONDONThe largest exhibition of gold objects ever seen outside Latin America, a glittering testament to the skills of preColumbian craftsmen, has opened at the Royal Academy.

title: Births
description: BRESS

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: The election of Bill Bradley is a sad commentary on the political sophistication of the people of New Jersey, and quite possibly on the nation as a whole.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: If music hath charms to soothe the savage breast, Long Islanders should be well soothed this week  beginning today, when James Conlon, a native Long Islander who has. made his mark as a leading conductor at the age of 28, returns to the Orchestra Da Camera to lead it in the first of, three allMozart afternoons. With David Golub as piano soloist, the concert gets under way at 3 P.M. at Half Hollow Hills High School West, Wolf Hill Road, Dix Hills. Tickets are $9; for students and the elderly, $5. 6944195.

title: Deborah R. Jones And David Boillot Are Wed in Jersey
description: Deborah Rachel Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Henry Jones of Norwood, N.J., and St. Barthelemy, was married in Norwood yesterday to David A. Boillot, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse B. Boillot of St. Louis. The Rev. Richard Cromwell performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of the Holy Communion.

title: Hawks 128, Jazz 94
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 2 (UPI)  Armond Hill and Tom McMillen scored 19 points apiece tonight to lead the Atlanta Hawks to a 12894 rout of the New Orleans Jazz.

title: City Council Warned Against Eliminating Corps of 83 Marshals
description: Eliminating the muchcriticized patronage corps of city marshals and turning their work over to the sheriff's office may be impractical and costly, City Council members have been told by their budget advisers.

title: A.T. Mason, Miss von Stade Plan to Marry
description: Mary Dudley von Stade, an account executive with Dancer Fitzgerald Sample Inc., and Alexander Taylor Mason, a lending officer with the Bankers Trust Company, plan to be married in New York on Jan. 13.

title: TV VIEW
description: The general condition of public television these days is not good. That is the key fact to be grasped as the system gets ready to receive the comprehensive report card of the second Carnegie Commission. Conclusions of a yearlong study are scheduled to be released early in 1979. Meanwhile, it is instructive to return to the 1967 report of the first Carnegie Commission, a report that played a formative role in establishing the present system. Here is one representative paragraph:

title: Late TV Listings
description: 11:30 A.M. (Channel 2) Face the Nation: Yasir Arafat, leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: BALDWIN PLACE  Fantasticks, Thursday to Saturday at 8 P.M., next Sunday 2 P.M. (through December). $5.50 to $7, discount available for students, the elderly and groups. Reservations. Mahopac Farm Playhouse, Routes 6 and 118. 6281169.

title: Music in Review
description: Raquel Bolderini, whose New York debut took place Thursday night at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A., is a Uruguayanborn pianist who has won a number of awards in international competitions. She impressed as a gracious artist with sound musical instincts and a fluent command of the instrument.

title: THE BLACK MIDDLE CLASS: MAKING IT
description: While the schism between white and black America is still painfully present, the existence of a thriving black middle class is also a reality  and it's carving a strong identity for itself.

title: Realty News
description: Aer Lingus Irish Airlines has sold two midtown office buildings to the Bank Leumi Trust Company and has leased space at 122 East 42d Street.

title: JeanneMarie Darr, the Pianist, Gives Recital at the Met Museum
description: It has been five years since JeanneMarie Dam last played in New York, so the extra measure of warm enthusiasm she received from the audience before beginning her recital at the Metropolitan Museum of Art Friday night was hardly surprising. Miss Darr has been something of a favorite among piano connoisseurs ever since her first records appeared in the 1930's and even more so after her longdelayed debut here in 1962.

title: A Correction
description: Due to an editing error last week, the result of an American Federation of State County and Municipal Employees election was incorrectly stated. The sentence should have stated that at last count, the federation had secured the right to a runoff election, if not an outright victory, in that bargaining unit.

title: CAMERA
description: There's a large cult of photo enthusiasts who feel that filters create magic  and they are at least partly right. You can do tricks by placing a filter in front of a camera lens, such as turning a sky black, multiplying a friend into a repetitive group, or creating such dramatic oddities as making an older person look absolutely free of lines and wrinkles. Thus, there are grounds for a filterandspecialeffects cult, provided the offbeat effects In themselves are not mistaken for worthwhile photography.

title: Talks Halt in Pressmen's Strike That Has Shut St. Louis Papers
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 1 (UPI)  Talks btween striking pressmen and The St. Louis PostDispatch have been recessed until next week, ending speculation about a quick end to the walkout that has shut down the city's two newspapers.

title: POLITICS
description: PETER A. PEYSER is confident that none of the Republicans he knew during his three terms in the House of Representatives as a member of their party will cross the street to avoid talking to him when he returns in January as a Democrat. And Ogden R. Reid, agrees.

title: IN BRIEF
description: The Shell Oil Company, the nation's largest marketer of gasoline, began a nationwide program of gasoline ration. ing last week in an attempt to conserve its dwindling stocks. The company said dealers would receive 75 percent of the previous month's shipment. Shell cited, unusually high demand caused by higherthannormal amounts of driVing this fall as well as what it termed unrealis tically low federally regulated prices. The company will have to cut its wholesale gas price by onehalf cent a gallon because it has exceeded those Federal price limits.

title: In Corona, They Look for a Lift From Tennis
description: On 46th Avenue and 111th Street in Corona, Queens, J.P.'s Live Poultry Market has live chickens, turkeys, ducks and rabbits for sale, catering to the neighborhood's Hispanic and Dominican residents who have not yet become used to the American way of buying food in packages and supermarkets.

title: After 200 Years, The Trenton Prison Is Being Replaced
description: TRENTON NEW JERSEY'S 18thcentury maximumsecurity prison here is coming tumbling down, to be replaced in time at a cost of $42.5 million.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: EGYPTIAN PAINTING, by Arpag Mekhitarian. (Rizzoli/Skira, $14.95.) Life as it was lived on the farms and in the palaces along the Nile during the time of the Pharaohs is vividly revealed in 94 faithfully reproduced color photographs of paintings found in tombs at Thebes and elsewhere. That high time of Egyptian art, the 15th and 14th centuries B.C., is given its special due. The accompanying text by a Belgian authority is lucid and most informative.

title: City Council Measures Call for Improvements At All S.R.O. Hotels
description: Legislation requiring better maintenance standards and full disclosure of ownership at singleroomoccupancy hotels was introduced last week in the City Council.

title: A Cure for Winter: Chartering a Yacht
description: Despite the first snowfall, all is not lost for the fairweather skipper. Growing legions of sailors are setting a course for the warm breezes of winter in the Caribbean.tent, she said. A good broker will advertise in leading yachting magazines and will give references.

title: Assassinations Committee Last Week Ended Its Investigative Phase
description: WASHINGTON  IN 1792, the first investigative committee of the House of Representatives sat across a table from Maj. Gen. Arthur St. Clair and inquired why troops under his command had been handed one of the worst defeats inflicted on white men by Indians.

title: Number of Doctors Disciplined Reported Up 6 Times in 6 Years
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 2 (AP)  The number of physicians disciplined by state medical boards has increased by almost six times over the last six years, according to the American Medical Association.

title: Doctor Ads Approved
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Trade Commission is all over the privatesector map these days, wielding its mandate to stop antitrust violations and consumer abuses and telling industries as varied as the medical profession, the auto manufacturers, funeral parlors and children's advertisers what they can and cannot do in pursuit of the dollar.

title: Letters
description: The first few Sundays of the newspaper strike were spent wandering aimlessly around the house, sorting and mounting years of accumulated snapshots, updating my penny collection, ironing old Christmas ribbons, tidying drawers, replacing buttons, patching old sheets and, all in all, driving my poor husband crazy. I even had an insane urge to watch football on television with him. That, in itself, would have threatened our normally happy marriage. My addiction to the Sunday crossword puzzle was out of control. I desperately needed a fix. Thank you for settling the

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: WHAT you can't see is 20th century, said Was B. Langhaas. By exclusion, then, what one can see at the newly renovated Arsenal in Huntington is mainly 18th century, which is a period fondly regarded by many in the area, especially Mr. Langhans, the town historian.

title: THE LIVELY ARTS Theater Right in Their Laps
description: AT first, the reactions were tentative, even slightly bored. The juniors gathered in the auditorium at Copiague High School to watch the Arena Classical Theater perform excerpts from Macbeth seemed more interested in combing their hair than in learning about Elizabethan audiences. But then Susan Freeman, the actress leading the commedia dell'arte introduction to the program, managed to strike a responsive chord. She jumped on a young man's lap and kissed him, just to illustrate the bawdy; fun nature of the original Shakespearean experience.

title: CONNECTICUT MOVES ON POLLUTED WELLS
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 1  Connecticut officials are sympathetic to the plight of Auto World Inc.  they're really getting the raw end of the deal, one said  but they say the cmpany is going to have to lay for the cleanup of chemically poluted drinking wells in Canton, Conn., even though the state believes someone else caused the pollution.

title: DETROIT TV STATION REFUSES AD ON PLAY
description: DETROIT, Dec. 2  Television station WXYZ, an ABC affiliate, has refused to broadcast commercials for Estelle Parsons's onewoman show, Miss Margarita's Way, calling the commercials lewd and sexually suggestive.

title: Supreme Soviet Elections Set
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 2, (Reuters)  The Soviet Union has announced it will hold elections in March for the Supreme Soviet, the nation's parliament. The present one was elected in June 1979, but a new electoral law extends the mandate of the body to five years. The ballot contains a single list of candidates selected by Communist Party officials. Voters drop their ballots into a box to signifiy approval.

title: North Bergen Wins; Seton Hall Is Victor
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. Dec.  Rick Capozzi scored twice in the closing minutes to help North Bergen score a 2614 victory over Passaic Valley and its second straight North Jersey, Section 1 Group 4 championship before 14,000 fans tonight at Giants Stadium.

title: Garret Mt. Reservation to Get a New Look
description: PATERSON THE vast Garret Mountain Reservation will undergo a major expansion and facelift at a cost of nearly $1 million in Federal, state and local funds.

title: FOOD Trenton Market Fights to Survive
description: TRENTON ACONGLOMERATION of lowroofed open sheds, pickup trucks and parked cars near the corner of Spruce Street and Princeton Avenue is all that denotes what is believed to be the oldest produce market in the state and one of the oldest truckfarm markets in the East.

title: Medical School Enrollment Up, but Black Total Drops
description: The number of blacks in the nation's medical schools declined this year despite an increase in overall medical school enrollment, and the proportion of blacks in the firstyear medical class is now the lowest it has been since 1970.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Writeityourself. In the Chicago offices of The Critic, a magazine published by the notforprofit Thomas More Association, the staff recently stole time from its appointed duties  assessing books religious and social significance  to create a kit that would help Its readers win fame and fortune by writing a bestselling romantic novel. The kit consists of the following choicest words':

title: Project Joey: New Chance for Youths on Probation
description: Fourteenyearold Cameron's reality was rife with jagged edges  poverty, a broken home and streetcorner loitering punctuated by infrequent school attendance.

title: The Fascination Of Staghorn Ferns
description: Fems have been on the earth longer perhaps than man. They are the first vascular plants, the first to live on land and attain any height.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  President Carter might have concluded that economic policy is too important to leave to the economists. Though the President has no fewer than five Cabinet officers with Ph.D.'s in economics, none of them has yet been tapped as the leader in shaping the Administration's economic policy.

title: SurvivalA Daily Struggle
description: The blunt reality of the shrinking dollar, though known to all of us, hits home most to those on fixed incomes, pensions and other limited resources. Often persons with low income have to scrimp on food just to be adequately dressed and have a roof over their heads. As inflation continues to erode the purchasing power of their meager income, they find it more and more difficult to afford life's bare necessities. They are waging a daily struggle for survival.

title: Boston Changes Time and Place Of Fireworks on New Year's Eve
description: BOSTON, Dec. 2 (AP)  Boston's New Year's Eve fireworks display will be held at 11 P.M. this year instead of midnight, and at City Hall Plaza instead of on Boston Common.

title: Trade Equals Growth
description: WASHINGTONIn Bonn last summer, the chiefs of state of the world's seven leading industrialized nations reached a consensus on political commitments that can shape and significantly improve world commercial relations for the next decade. President Carter was the leading and decisive voice in those discussions.

title: Death
description: Bancroft, Janet

title: A SELECTION OF THE BEST BOOKS OF 1978
description: The following list has been selected from titles reviewed since the Christmas Issue of December 1977. Such a list can only suggest the high points in the main fields of reader interest. Books are arranged alphabetically under subject headings. Quoted comments are from the Book Review.

title: Navy to Hold 2Week Maneuvers
description: WASHINGTON, Dec 2 (Reuters) The Navy announced yesterday that it would conduct major maneuvers off the coast of southern California for two weeks starting Monday. The exercise, called Varsity Lance, wilt involve 38 ships, 250 aircraft and nearly 20,000 sailors and marines, the Navy said.

title: Eleanor P. Friend Plans to Wed
description: The engagement of Eleanor Provost Friend to Sanford Drake Hickok has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Walter William Friend Jr. of South Norwalk, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Sanford Hickok of Morristown. N.J.. and Brewster, Mass.

title: ANTIQUES
description: Norwalk EVEN the setting for the show at the LockwoodMathews Mansion next weekend will be antique. The show will be set up in the 1868 mansion itself, a oneofakind example of high Victorian grandeur built of European marble. stone, fine metals and rare woods by skilled French and Italian craftsmen who were brought here on the same ship that carried the building materials.

title: ART VIEW
description: The practice of combining collage with the art storytelling, or with sundry other forms of literary expression, has an older history than is commonly supposed. In a huge study of the collage medium written some years ago, and mainly focused. of course, on the accomplishments of collage since Cubism  the late Herta Wescher gave us an interesting glimpse of some of these premodernist uses of collage. She cited examples from 12thcentury Japan, 13thcentury Persia and 17thcentury Europe, and recalled that in the 19th century literary eminences on the order of Victor Hugo, Hans Christian Andersen and Christian Morganstern turned to collage for artistic purposes.

title: Council Rebuffs Ravo Tax Plan
description: THE GOOD news in Yonkers last week was the disbanding of the city's Emergency Financial Control Board, the state

title: Israeli Theater Is Now Developing Its Own Character
description: JERUSALEM The play is called Endgame. But it is a peculiar Israeli .Endgame. It's about a sophisticated American director who cames to an isolated town on the fringes of the Negev desert and tries to put on Beckett's play there. The attempt collapses. And it is through this that the play reveals the special desolation of life in the remote, barren parts of Israel. For Israelis, the play speaks of a uniquely Israeli experience.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week

title: BUFFALO POLICE NET 164 IN STING DRIVE
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 2  In a combined drive that has led to 164 arrests and the recovery of nearly $2 million in stolen property, undercover police officers posing as thieves have been working in tandem here in recent months with former criminals serving as police informers.

title: Paterno Pleased Alabama Is Foe
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Dec. 2 Penn State's football coach, Joe Paterno, was not surprised by Alabama's 3446 victory over Auburn, giving.the Crimson Tide the home position for the Sugar Bowl game in New Orleans Jan. I.

title: CULT GUN SHIPMENTS HAD BEEN REPORTED
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2  Treasury Department agents here were being told 18 months before the murder of Representative Leo J. Ryan that members of the People's Temple sect were illegally shipping large quantities of guns and cash from this country to their settlement in Jonestown, Guyana, according to some of those knowledgeable about the shipments.

title: Ambitious Plan Seeks to Rescue Agricultural Land in Seattle Area
description: KENT, Wash., Dec. 2 (UPI)  Cipriano Primero has a weatherbeaten roadside vegetable stand, an occasional stall in Seattle's Pike Place Farmers Market and a sixacre truck farm that he is willing to sell to developers.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: One of the more demanding of human activities to look long and concentratedly at a major painting by Henri Matisse. Not only is the painting itself likely to be dense and complex beyond all elucidation, but Matisse was also the personification of French thrift. Over a period of more than 50 years, during which he worked virtually all day and every day, he never wasted anything, never lost anything and never forgot anything. And it all fits together: What may look at first sight like disconnectedness results from a lifelong sense of what should be undertaken at what time and in what way.

title: Holiday Craft Shows Offer Unusual Gifts
description: CONNECTICUT has a unique diversity of craft centers and craftsmen throughout the state, said Beth Parrott, director of Guilford Handcrafts. There's a selection of wellmade craft gifts that I'm not aware of in any other state, and the Christmas shows are the perfect time to take advantage of this crafts activity.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING
description: NORWALK ON Devil's Garden Road here, Dave and Teal Lindsay, who were married in August, are completely remodeling a ramshackle 1931 Colonial house they bought in June. Meanwhile they are living in the extra twobedroom guest cottage on their halfacre wooded lot.

title: Tutankhamun in Roslyn Heights Thanks to Certain SixthGraders
description: ROSLYN HEIGHTS, L.I.  Like thousands of others in the metropolitan area, the 132 sixthgrade students at the Willets Road School here were unable to get tickets for the Tutankhamun exhibition that opens Dec. 20 at the Metropolitan Mueum of Art in New York. But they have had their share of Tutankhmania: a King Tut show all their own.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: I'm enclosing your birdfeeder diagram (Westchester Opinion, Nov. 19), revised both in title and technique. A spongerubber ball, such as children play with, is the key to the solution.

title: Rohatyn Says Problems of U.S. Threaten Its Future as a Nation
description: Felix G. Rohatyn, the retiring chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, says that the economic, social and political problems facing the United States threaten the very structure of its democratic system and its future as a nation.

title: Fanning the Fire at Giants Stadium
description: Where there's smoke, there's fire. And there is supposed to be smoke outside Giants Stadium today. The fire will be in the eyes of the fuming and frustrated fans whose tickets to the Giants game with the Los Angeles Rams will be burned in protesting Wellington Mara's mismanagement of the franchise. It's about time. Nothing embarrasses a sports franchise more than to have its fans go public with their complaints. Criticism by the press can scar a franchise's image. But only the fans can humiliate it. The noshow total at today's game might be significant. Notithat the Giants' front office appears concerned with the proposed bonfire. Almost smugly, one Giant official wondered if those fuming fans would really be burning tickets.

title: Philosopher Takes Over as Rutgers Dean
description: NEW BRUNSWICK APHILOSOPHER who was educated at universities in Cincinnati, Berkeley (Calif.) and Oxford, and who most recently served as an administrator and teacher at 18yearold York University in Toronto, has joined 212yearold Rutgers College as its dean.

title: Barbara Suffness Fiance Of Ira Kornblatt, Surgeon
description: Barbara Stamler Suffness and Dr. Ira Bennett Kornblatt plan to be married Jan. 21. Dr. and Mrs. Gustave Suffness of Elizabeth, N.J., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Robert Kornblatt of Wilmette, Ill.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: When Adelhaeid Wette decided to stage a little Christmas play for the family and persuaded her brother to compose the music for it, he became so fascinated by her version of one of Grimm's fairy tales that he extended it into a fulllength opera  and that's how Engelbert Humperdinck came to write Hansel and Gretel. Now a new production has been devised by the fairy godmother of Opera New England, Sarah Caldwell.
