In the homey spirit of the original, the audience will be encouraged to sing along with the cast at certain times, and children will be given cookies to eat from the gingerbread house on the stage. Only one public performance is scheduled in Connecticut  today at 2:30 P.M., in Mertens Theater, University of Bridgeport. Tickets are $7, children and the elderly $5. Phone 2592750 or 7628107

title: Acute Pictorialitis
description: IHAD seen them depart on their great mission, those valiant knights of Daguerre, AmfortasSteiglitz, suffering from acute pictorialitis; GurnemanzKeiley . . . TiturelSteichen . . . and young ParsifalCoburn ... The witness and companionin

title: Biologists Defend Eastern Coyote
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Dec. 2 (AP)  Deer hunters in northern New England were convinced that the packs of Eastern coyotes they heard howling at the moon stole their prey before the hunting season started this fall.

title: Michael Rowland to Marry Judith Kahan
description: Rabbi and Mrs. Norman Kahan of East Williston, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter. Judith Kahan, to Michael Rowland, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Rowland of London.

title: Hospital's Need for Growing Room Worries Its Neighbors in L.I. Town
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I.  It is not as if the hospital suddenly appeared there, shattering the tranquillity of the comfortable clapboard houses and treelined streets. Huntington Hospital has been an integral part of its community for more than half a century.

title: Chinese Restaurants:
description: FOR most of us in the metropolitan area, the search for fine Chinese cuisine usually ends in that labyrinthine 15squareblock neighborhood of downtown Manhattan called Chinatown.

title: Deborah A. Gorst Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard Gorst of Manhattan have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah A. Gorst, to Roy S. Goldfinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Goldfinger of Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Blenheim Hotel: Politics on the Boardwalk?
description: ATLANTIC CITY PRESERVATIONISTS contend that Donald T. Graham, director of the Division of Marine Services of the state's Department of Environmental Protection, is being influenced by political pressure to permit the demolition of historic hotels here to make way for casinos.

title: A Marriage of Convenience
description: HARTFORD UNTIL recently, United Technologies Corporation, the giant manufacturing and aerospace company headquartered here, had no program of support for the arts. This year the company's direct grants to arts groups and institutions in the state reached half a million dollars and company officials hope to increase that sum next year.

title: Inflation Affects Congress, Too
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP)  With more than twice the work force and seven times the money, Congress produces about the same volume of leeislation it did 20 years ago.

title: Miami 22, Florida 21
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Dec. 2 (AP) Ottis Anderson scored two secondhalf touchdowns and rushed for more than 100 yards for the eighth time this season to lead the University of Miami to a 2221 comeback victory today. It was Doug Dickey's final game as Florida coach.

title: In Toyland, Armies of Supermarts
description: A funny thing happened to Interstate Stores on the way out of bankruptcy. In a kind of tailwaggingdog scenario, the company  once a formidable discount and department store giant  emerged from Chapter X last spring bearing the name of a onetime subsidiary, Toys R Us. And in the months since, the organization has consolidated its leading position in the $500 million toy supermarket business.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY
description: THIS Christmas season the reader interested in photographic books has a rich choice: the masterful Polaroid color photographs by Marie Cosindas, the powerful documentary views of America and Americans by Walker Evans and Robert Frank, the mystical, evanescent images by Minor White, the elegance of Richard Avedon's fashion people, the purity of Edward Weston's still fifes and the grandeur of Leni Riefenstahl's jewellike underwater life.

title: The Lyrical Trumpet Of Lester Bowie
description: The trumpeter sports a goatee, a broad tie and a surgeon's long white jacket. He sits in a chair staring at the instrument in his hands while the other musicians begin to olay. After some apparent deliberation, he puts the horn to his lips and blows a testy smear, a snort, wisp of a phrase, a raspberry. Gradually it becomes apparent that he is constructing a solo from these apparent fragments. He begins to weave and bob back and forth, spewing out cackles, grunts, and vituperation, and then, without warning, he segues into a ballad melody, affecting a sound so reedy and vulnerable that he seems to be sighing.

title: For a Widow, Old Age Provides No Peace
description: When a woman passes her eightieth birthday having gracefully sustained early widowhood, near poverty, eye and heart problems and a collection of haunting memories dating back to her father's murder by antiSemites in Hungary, it would seem only just that fate provide her a moment's respite.

title: PUERTO RICO PARTY TAKES UNITY STEPS
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 2 (UPI)  After two years of fighting over leadership and ideology, the political party that wants to keep Puerto Rico a selfruing commonwealth of the United States seems to have patched up its differences, but just barely.

title: SPORTS
description: EAST RUTHERFORD IT IS called an attitude. A winning attitude. A sense of coming together. For the last six years, the Giants have been searching for just such a reunion of body and soul.

title: Michaels Is Cautious as Jets Oppose Colts
description: The New York Jets are celebrating the 10th anniversary of their victory in Super Bowl III at halftime of today's game with the Baltimore Colts at Shea Stadium. Coach Walt Michaels of the Jets does not want to be the one to reiterate Joe Namath's guarantee of that victory over the Colts.

title: Best Sellers
description: FICTION

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: FROM the air, much of the Island looks like a toy railroad setup, with tract houses broken only by the parallel lines of the train tracks.

title: U.S.India Relations: The Rub
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn.When the Congress begins work, it should take another look at the Nuclear NonProliferation Act, passed last March.

title: Inmate Suit to Close Upstate Prison Denied
description: SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 2  A lawsuit brought by two inmates to close the Jamesville Correction Facility on the ground of cruel and unusual punishment was denied in Federal District Court here today by a judge who said conditions at the prison were gloomy and unpleasant, but tolerable.

title: Liberty Ship Memorial Due
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2 (AP) About 200 men who built or sailed the 2.742 Liberty Ships in World War II are working on a memorial to the ships, termed ugly duckings by President Franklin D. Roosevelt.

title: El Salvador Prohibits Guerrillas' Manifesto
description: SAN SALVADOR, Dec. 2 (UPI) The government forbade today the publication of a communiqu by a leftist guerrilla orgnization, one of the conditions for the release of the kidnapped local manager of a Dutch company.

title: Now It's Time For Post Mortems
description: If the capitalists came over the hill I just drink the potion as fast as I can do it. I wouldn't let.the capitalists get me but if they did I would not say a word.

title: Andrea Denise Dill Wed To Michael E. Harbison
description: Andrea Denise Dili, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert D. Dill of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday in the St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church to Michael Ellis Harbison. The Rev. Robert Daly performed the ceremony. He was assisted by Msgr. John J. Feeley, Msgr. Harrold Murray and the Rev. Mark Jorjorian.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: The Times of London is not like other papers. Rarely thicker than 34 pages, its circulation is only 300,000 about the same as The Houston Chronicle or The Los Angeles Herald Examiner But that circulation consists mostly of Britain's political, professional and business elite, who read The Times to find out what is happening in the far corners of the world, or use its famous letters column to argue learnedly with each other and to report rare birds in Britain's own green and pleasant shires. But Friday morning there was no Times.

title: Maxine Goldenson Wed to Peter Meyerson
description: Maxine Goldenson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard H. Goldenson of New York and Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married in Los Angeles yesterday to Peter A. Meyerson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Meyerson of Hallandale, Fla. Rabbi Lawrence Goldmark performed the ceremony at Temple Wilshire.

title: POLITICS
description: IT SEEMED during Connecticut's recent campaign for Governor that the state's tradition of selecting statewide candidates by political convention was headed towards extinction, like the 20cent Hershey bar and the free call to information to get a telephone number.

title: Don't Complain About the Snow Till You See Red Mountain Pass
description: OURAY Colo., Dec. 2 (AP)  Don't look for Lloyd Berry next winter on Red Mountain Pass.

title: Sludge Healing Land Scarred by Strip Mine
description: HARRISBURG, Ill., Dec. 2 (UPI)  A 192acre no man's land in the Shawnee National Forest is getting a facelift with liberal applications of Chicago sludge.

title: Beach Erosion Battle Cannot Be Won, Expert Says
description: SOUTH KINGSTOWN, R.I., Dec. 2 (AP)  The ocean is eating away an average of eight inches a year from Rhode Island bftches, a geologist has found. He also reported that sand was not being deposited in equal amounts on the shore elsewhere, as scientists once believed.

title: All Over Europe, the Atoms Are Restless
description: PARIS  Fifteen years ago, the nations of Western Europe believed they could beat the swords of nuclear warfare into plowshares for peaceful development. Today, efforts to promote nuclear energy are frustrated by public anxiety over safety, the environmental impact. and nuclear waste disposal.

title: Study of Boston City Employees Indicates Abuse of Sick Leaves
description: BOSTON, Dec 2 (UPI) Boston's municipal employees are costing city taxpayers close to $15.2 million a year in sick leave pay, according to figures compiled by the Municipal Research Bureau, a nonprofit organization.

title: Editors' Choice
description: AMERICAN CAESAR: DOUGLAS MACARTHUR 18801964, by William Manchester. (Little, Brown & Co., $15.) Voluminous research; narrative sweep; judicious ambivalence.

title: Yugoslav Folk Dance Ensemble in Local Premiere
description: New Yorkers have had a rather skimpy diet of imported Yugoslavian folk dance over the past few decades. On Friday, Abrasevic, a folk ensemble culled from an arts conservatory just outside Belgrade, made its New York debut at Carnegie Hall. The fresh charm of the young performers  said to be between 8 and 20 years of ageand their colorful costumes were irresistible.

title: CASINOS IN NEVADA SHOW A PROFIT RISE
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Dec. 2 (AP) Nevada's big hotelcasinos grossed $2.6 billion last year and managed to net a pretax profit of about $364 million after deductions for various expenses, according to a Nevada Gaming Commission report.

title: POLITICS
description: SUFFOLK County Legislator Anthony Noto, a relative unknown outside his own Babylon district, has emerged as the leading contender for the second most important governmental post in Suffolk County, that of Presiding Officer of the 18member County Legislature.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: In a dance era that has concentrated on movement and puredance works rather than storytelling, it is amazing to see how attentive choreographers can be to dramatic detail. The key word here is detail. This season, we have seen revivals and premieres that convey drama but are not dramatic ballets in the way Antony Tudor's works were in the 1930's and 40's. These were the model dancedramas. Like the modern dancers of the same period, characters in Tudor ballets expressed their emotions and psychological concerns through gesture incorporated into movement. The drama was inherent in the choreography.

title: Miss Runstedler Planning Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Diamond of Old Brookville, L.I., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Diamond's daughter, Elizabeth Ann Runstedler, to Michael Belfield du Pont, son of Mr. and Mrs. Reynolds du Pont of Wilmington, Del., and Fishers Island, N.Y.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: BECAUSE those who own snowthrowers never know just when the machine will be needed  snowstorms often arrive with little or no advance warning  the average homeowner never even thinks of doing anything with his snowthrower until the first snow actually falls. Unfortunately, this all too often leads to frustration and aggravation some dark night or early morning when the machine fails to start the way it should, or stubbornly acts up in some other manner.

title: Justice Dept. Is Considering Plea For a Pardon for Patricia Hearst
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (Reuters) The Justice Department has assured members of Congress that a petition for pardon for Patricia Hearst is under active consideration.

title: Bergen Forum Discusses Rising Housing Costs in County
description: PARAMUS, N.J., Dec. 2  When the time came for Carla McDermott to hunt for a new apartment, she found almost nothing in Bergen County that she could afford.

title: ART
description: OLD WESTBURY LEON POLK SMITH is a prominent American abstractionist who is known for his extraordinary color. Thus when we see no color in a selection of his work at the College of Old Westbury Art Gallery, we are surprised and perhaps shocked.

title: Teheran Is Decked With Symbols of Death
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 2  Black flags hung from trees along Shah Avenue and from balconies and buildings in various neighborhoods of Teheran today.

title: 2 Former High Chinese Officials, Purged in '66, Are Rehabilitated
description: TOKYO, Dec. 2 (UPI)  Two major Chinese political figures who were purged during the Cultural Revolution of the 1960's have been rehabilitated and allowed to return to public life, according to a radio broadcast from Peking monitored here today.

title: The Region
description: Lincoln Hospital in the South Bronx is only two years old, but it is probably a terminal case. Moreover, its major life support system, the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, is itself in trauma, awaiting Eamon M. Kelly, who is expected to be named the next president of the corporation.

title: Drive to Ban Textbooks Succeeds
description: CHARLESTON, W Va., Dec. 2 (AP)Four years after a bitter dispute erupted over the selection of school textbooks in Kanawha County, it appears that victory has gone to those who had sought to ban books that they regarded as godless and unAmerican.

title: Inventor Claims Another Coup
description: A grayhaired Michigan inventor stepped up before a news conference here last week to announce that he knew how to make cheap power from the sun. No, he said, he hadn't built any prototypes, and yes, he did need at least $10 million to finish the development work.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: MASS MARKET

title: La Belle Dame Sans Merci
description: NANCY CARDOZO takes the title of her scrupulous and admiring account of Maud Gonne from a poem by W.B. Yeats in which the heroine is presented as greatbodied and greatlimbed,/ Fashioned to be the mother of strong children; also as possessing a wisdom that made her beautiful and fierce/ Sudden and laughing. Quoted as epigraph to her biography, the lines reaffirm a major way in which its subject is known to us: as a beautiful woman, greatlimbed (she was nearly six feet tall), too fierce and sudden ever to accept in marriage the man for whose poems, early and late, she provided the major motive power. Any student of those poems remembers at some point being told that, when in such a one as No Second Troy Yeats begins with a passionate, selfjustifying rhetorical question  Why should I blame her that she filled my days/ With misery ... ?  we are at least to think of Maud Gonne before reminding ourselves that the poem can't be understood merely by invoking her name.

title: Some Novembers Are Longer
description: AUBURN, N.Y.. Dec. 1 (AP) November had 31 days, according to the desk calendars used used by Cayuga County. A spokesman for the manufacturer, Keith Clark Inc. Of Sidney. N.Y., said he did not know how many calendars got out with today listed as Nov. 31. He said the mistake was discoverd early in the press run and corrected. The company distributes as many as 300.000 calendars nationally every year.

title: Koch's Former Health Chief Reportedly Being Investigated for Improprieties in Office
description: H. Axel Schupf, who resigned two months ago as the Koch adminstration's top health official, is reportedly being investigated for alleged improprieties during his tenure, it was learned Friday.

title: Lifeline Revisions Are Urged
description: NEWARK MAJOR changes in the lifeline utilities law have been proposed by the state's Board of Public Utilities.

title: 181 Shot Scores at Aqueduct
description: Darby Dan's Robin's Song. who has spent most of the season racing on grass. was the surprise winner of the $54,250 Buckpasser Handicap on Aqueduct's main dirt track yesterday.

title: Hurricane Season Over, Warning on '79 Is Made
description: MIAMI, Dec. 2 (AP)  The 1978 Atlantic hurricane season has ended, but forecasters will be working through the winter to end the complacency of millions of coastal residents who have never experienced a major storm.

title: Panel Urges President To Establish Agency Dealing With Oceans
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 2 (UPI)  A Federal advisory committee wants President Carter to consolidate a myriad of agencies, departments and fiefdoms dealing with ocean and atmospheric programs into a new Federal department.

title: A British Casino Company Plans Gaming Facility in Atlantic City
description: The Coral Leisure Group, Europe's biggest casino operator, is planning a casinohotel in Atlantic City that would be radically different from the small, elegant English clubs it operates because it would cater to the masses rather than people who gamble for very high stakes.

title: Miss Lord, D.G. Gillespie Are Married
description: MaryLouise Lord, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Couper Lord of Buffalo and Southampton, L.I., was married in the Chantry Chapel of St. Thomas Episcopal Church yesterday to David Gillespie, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenrick Samson Gillespie of New York and Southampton. The Rev. John Andrew, rector of the church, performed the ceremony.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: BLOOMFIELD (Bloomfield College, Franklin and Fremont Streets) A View From the Bridge, in an Actor'sCafe Theater production. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through Dec. 16). $3.50$5.50; students and the elderly, $2.50$4.50. (201) 4297662.

title: Visions of Order and Domestic Disarray
description: THIS uncommonly large and handsome book has a jacket that approaches the color of a pomegranate, the magical fruit that comes to us each Christmas carrying with it pagan myths of death and rebirth, love and agriculture, winter and spring: of Pluto, the god of the underworld, who gave a pomegranate to his captive bride Persephone, the daughter of Demeter, and thus could keep her with him half the year. Like a pomegranate, these sixtyone stories are a gift at or.e sweet and sad, nourishing, voluptuous and nostalgic. They are most often about love and loss, rebirth and decline. They are filled with nostalgia  which my dictionary abruptly and unsentimentally calls homesickness as a disease. In John Cheever's case, the disease has brought forth works of art.

title: Article 9 -- No Title
description: Detail from Faerles

title: Ross Wilson Duncan Will Marry Kathryn S. Eichenwald
description: Kathryn Suzanne Eichenwald, a field consultant with the American Red Cross in Los Angeles, and Ross Wilson Duncan, a territory manager for the Burroughs Corporation in Los Angeles, plan to be married March 31.

title: Dentists Discrimination Lawsuit Remains a Threat to Hawaii Governor's Effort to Limit Island Growth
description: HONOLULU, Dec. 2  George Ariyoshi will be sworn in Monday for his second fouryear term as Governor of Hawaii, but the program to which he has given top priority  controlled population growth  is still being threatened by a Federal lawsuit brought by two dentists.

title: Deaths
description: SANCROFT Janet (Nee Goldsmith) of Ridgefield, New Jersey on November 30,1978 Age 45 years. Beloved wife of The Reverend Francis S. Bancroft III and the late William A. Currey Jr. Devoted mother of Wayne A. and the late Bruce William Currey. Dear daughter of Mabel (nee Coulson) and the late Harry A. Goldsmith. Dear sister of Robert A. Goldsmith. Visiting hours at Blackley Funeral Home,Corner Broad & Elm Ave., Ridgefield, N.J. Saturday 24 and 79PM. Friends and relatives are invited to attend the Episcopal Burial Office at Saint Matthew's R.C. Church, Ridgefield. N.J. Sunday December 3. at 2 PM. Interment In Wellfieet, Cape Cod, Mass, at the convenience of the family. Those who so desire may send flowers or make gifts to Saint James Episcopal Church, Ridgefield, N.J.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: The very Pukka Sahib novel by M. M. Kaye, The Far Pavilions, is nearly a thousand pages long and its many readers in the United States puzzle and please the author.

title: DINING OUT
description: LE BISTRO, in the Delaware River community of Stockton, opened to high acclaim two years ago because the young owner, Donald Mascia, was serious about making food the center of his enterprise. Physically, the kitchen is the center of his dining space and the center of attention for diners, who can watch a trio of young men working their heads off.

title: 5 Killed in Los Angeles Fire
description: LOS ANGELES. Dec. 2 (UPI)  A fire in a downtown apartment building early today killed five persons and injured another 13. An estimated 100 persons were left homeless. The police said none of the victims were immediately identified. All were MexicanAmericans and few of the survivors spoke English.

title: B.Young 28, Las Vegas 24
description: YOKOHAMA, Japan, Dec. 2 (UPI)Marc Wilson threw three touchdown passes and Casey Wingard ran 7 yards for the winning touchdown today to lead Brigham Young to a 2824 victory over the University of NevadaLas Vegas at Yokohama Stadium. Wilson threw 8yard touchdown passes in the second and third quarters and a 2yard touchdown pass in the final quarter.

title: PARENTS GIVEN AID IN MOONSECT FIGHT
description: GUILFORD, Conn. Nov. 29  Carolyn and Elton Helander have spent more than $60,000 in a fouryear physical and legal battle with the Unification Church over control of their 21yearold daughter, and their friends and neighbors are stepping in to help them.

title: New Freedoms And Their Limits Unveiled in China
description: You have been weighed in the balance and found wanting. That was the message of the handwriting on the wall for Nebuchadnezzar. In Peking last week, wall posters delivered the same message to many of China's recent leaders, living and dead.

title: NEW ORLEANS FACES A CRISIS OVER TAXES
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 2  There is new element of sobriety in New Orleans this fall, even as the city touts its traditional image as a freewheeling river town of pleasure seekers preoccupied mainly with jazz, restaurants and carnivals.

title: Koch Goes to Station To Talk to the Crowd
description: Mayor Koch went to Brooklyn yesterday for what he thought was going to be a routine public appearance as the host of one of his neighborhood constituent hours.

title: THE TRAGEDY AT TOWER NO.2
description: The terrifying collapse of a scaffolding at a construction site in West Virginia last April left 51 dead and gouged a deep wound in the fabric of a small community. Portfolio of photos by Mary Ellen Mark.

title: Aging's Joys and Pangs Reprised In My Old Friends at La Marna
description: There's a prevailing sentiment, it sometimes seems, that old age is some sort of an unmentionable disease whose sufferers must be called senior citizens, when they are actually graduate students of life, and are going through their golden age, a period that often is the most bitter and lonely of a lifetime.

title: Blast by Bretons in Paris Kills Employee in Store
description: PARIS, Dec. 2 (Reuters)  A bomb exploded in a Paris department store today, killing a woman employee. Breton separatists claimed responsibility for the attack.

title: Shows and Events
description: Today  Annual show and sale, V.F.W. Hall, 600 Washington Avenue, Manville. 40 dealers. Benefit for the Somerset County unit of the New Jersey Association for Retarded Citizens, Inc. Hours: 11 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title: ...But Private Pilots Are Soaring
description: ON a Sunday afternoon 14 years ago, Israel Golden sat in a fivehour traffic jam on Route 17. The next morning he was at the Westchester County Airport, signing up for flying lessons.

title: Dalmatian Selected As Best at Camden
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 2  It's the greatest thrill I've had since I've been showing dogs, said Mrs. Alan Robson of Glenmoore, Pa., after William Kendrick chose het Dalmatian, Ch. Green Starr's Colonel Joe, best in a field of 2,738 at the 46th annual Camden County Kennel Club show in Convention Hall tonight.

title: GARDENING
description: LAST winter, during one of the bad weather delays on the New Haven commuter line, the train halted for a time at a place where the tracks bordered some suburban backyards just south of New Rochelle. I had finished my crossword puzzle and my thoughts wandered as I gazed out the window.

title: Jaycee Deadline on Ousting Women Members Passes Without Reprisals
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 2  Joan Petranovich was scornful.

title: Some Bad Blips In the Economy
description: President Carter and his economic advisers needed their stiff upper lips last week. The latest economic statistics left room for optimism, but the news that made headlines was another high in consumer prices, up .08 percent for October, and a bulge in the United States trade deficit, to $2.13 billion from $1.69 billion in September.

title: Many in Soviet Call Stalin a Hero Despite His Decades in Disfavor
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 2  An old veteran moved furtively along the swaying corridors of an overnight train bound for Moscow. At each compartment he stopped, holding out a cupped hand, clandestinely offering something for sale. The price: a ruble. The illicit merchandise: small homemade 1979 calendars, each page bearing a heroic photograph of Stalin.

title: ChildCare Is a Release for Women in Prison
description: LAURA BARBERIO says she likes to spend time with children because they are free human beings. For Cynthia Freeman, being with children is a release. I only wish we could do it seven days a week, she says.

title: The Nation
description: For Mayor Tim Moody of Columbus, Ohio, President Carter's warning, to 4000 mayors meeting in St. Louis that the cities will have to bear their fair share of budget restraint, was like his mother's potato soup, There's nothing new in it, he said, but whenever I get sick I have to have it.

title: Carter Says He Knew of Inquiry When He Offered Hatcher a Job
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP)  President Carter has acknowledged that he offered a White House job to Mayor Richard G. Hatcher of Gary, Ind., earlier this year and was aware at the time that Mr. Hatcher was under investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and Internal Revenue Service.

title: After the Game ...
description: WHAT do athletes think about when a game is over? It varies. Sometimes it is mundane but appropriate.

title: TASK FORCE STUDIES PINE BARRENS ON L.I.
description: A New York State task force is studying ways to protect the Long Island Pine Barrens and their underground reservoirs of pure water, including a possible bid for Federal protection such as New Jersey recently won.

title: Anne Lan Fiance Of Donald F. Luke; June Wedding Set
description: Dr. and Mrs. Caspar A. Lian of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Manchester, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Elizabeth Lian, to Donald Frank Luke, son of Robert A. Luke of Chevy Chase, Md., and Sally Luke of Silver Spring, Md. A wedding is planned for June.

title: Found: Connoisseur w/Admin. Exp. for the Neuberger
description: PURCHASE SUZANNE DELEHANTY, the recently named director of the State University of New York's Neuberger Museum, is the kind of woman who meets the requirements of a museum director of our age, especially the special requirements of a museum like the Neuberger. More than a connoisseur, she has a multifaceted professional background as an administrator and curator, and she is thoroughly schooled in many fields of art.

title: Entertainment Events
description: NONGOGO, aplay by Athol Fugard Directed by Oz Scott. Presented by the Manhattan Theater Club. 321 East 73d Street. at 8.

title: U.S. Reaches Final Of Federation Cup
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. (AP)  The United States gained the Federation Cup women's tennis final for the 10th time by defeating Britain today. 30.

title: Partners for Progress
description: a new state was born in the Arabian Gulf The United Arab Emirates. Composed of the separate Sheikhdoms that had previously, under British control, been known as the Trucial States or the Trucial Coast, the U.A.E. was a Federal Union of six EmiratesAbu Dhabi, Dubai, Sharjah, Ajman, Ymm Al Quaiwain and Fujairah. A seventh, Ras Al Khaimah, joined the U.A.E. a couple of months later.

title: Chilean Press Asserts Traitors Are Behind Planned Exports Curli
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 2  The threat by American unions to institute a shipping boycott against Chile's military regime is being used here to stir nationalist feelings against foreign aggressors and opponents of the Govertfment's labor policies.

title: Article 13 -- No Title
description: Children adjust pretty easily to a new situation, especially if it consists of magically maldng the landscape whiz by the kitchen window at 55 miles an hour. It may take the adults in the family a bit longer to adjust, but it was not long into our month on the road in a new motor home that we, too, learned to thrive in this atmospherethe outside always changing, from farmland to mountain to ocean, while inside the bus it remained the same.

title: P.L.O.'s Move in U.N. For Aid Stirs Concern, Of Donors Pulling Out
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.. Dec. 2The Palestine Liberation Organization, seeking to enhance its international standing, is asking to be regarded as a fullfledged recipient of United Nations development aid.

title: Events Today
description: Nyack Craft Invitational: Glass, leather, batik, ceramics, weaving and holiday cratts; 1 to 4 P.M.; Rockland Center for the Arts, Greenbush Road, West Nyack.

title: WESTCHESTER HOUSING
description: ROOM FOR RENT: Quiet professional man preferred. This is a typical advertisement run by families with a spare bedroom and a need for extra cash  but they usually advertise only once, because they get so many calls.

title: Movies Are Revised for TV Showings
description: LOS ANGELES  Two Minute Warning, a 1976 Universal Movie about a psychotic sniper who kills dozens of spectators at a Los Angeles RamsBaltimOre Colts football game, will have a change of plot before it appears on television early next year.

title: Chaminade Defeats South Shore, 6 to 2
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 2  Chaminade's unbeaten Catholic Schools champions encountered unexpected difficulty in winning the first Metro Bowl, 62, from the New York public school champion, South Shore, today before a crowd of 3,000 at Hofstra University. In the opener of the schoolboy doubleheader, the Catholic City Division allstars defeated their Island Division counterparts, 60, in the league's third Senior Bowl.

title: Bringing Opera to Inmates, Patients and Children
description: WASHINGTON  Donnie Ray Albert, the bassbaritone whose performance as Porgy in the Houston Grand Opera's production of Porgy and Bess in New York City and Washington won critical acclaim, is appearing before different kinds of audiences these days. And they do not qualify as opera lovers.

title: Letters: Who Really Cares About That Trip You Took?
description: To the Editor:

title: PLANS ARE TERMED READY FOR WINTER
description: Most municipalities in the New York metropolitan area, and the utilities and rail lines that serve them, say they have learned from the calamitous snow and ice storms of last January and February and have made extensive plans to meet emergencies this winter.

title: Notes: The Time for Messiah Is Here Again
description: This is the time of year when performances of Handel's Messiah turn up all over the map. One of the most appreciated, at least by those taking part, is the annual Messiah SingIn sponsored by the National Choral Council. This kind of communal event brings together everyone who would like to read through the famous oratorio with some 20 conductors from the metropolitan area each leading a different choral section of the work. Soloists take part, giving the choristers a chance to rest. For New York City it will be the 11th year that it has taken place, and it will be held at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday, Dec. 22.

title: On a Visit to Raleigh, Don't Eat the Flowers
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 2 (UPI)  The sign on the grounds of the North Carolina capitol says, Please Don't Eat the Flowers.

title: Tennessee 41, Vanderbilt 15
description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 2 (AP)  Jimmy Streater, the quarterback, ran for two touchdowns and his teammate, Alan Duncan, kicked two field goals today as Tennessee defeated Vanderbilt. 4115.

title: Parking Lots Attracting Thieves
description: BOSTON, Dec. 2 (AP)  At the major malls in Massachusetts, a different breed of shoppers have been staying in the parking lots and not paying for the merchandise they have taken away.

title: Louisville Teachers End Dispute
description: LOUISVILLE. Ky Dec. 2 (AP) Teachers in this city's countywide school system yesterday voted by a 3to1 margin to end a tourmonth pay dispute with the Board of Education and approve a compromise wagebenefit package. The count was 3.139 to 931. to ratify a oneyear contract that provides for a 9.5 percent salary increase, a life insurance policy with coverage equal to the teacher's yearly salary, and a $30 per teacher annual payment for instructional supplies and field trips.

title: Sunday Observer
description: The man and woman behind us at the theater were talking about a friend who was reluctant to have her face lifted. She'd made all the arrangements and then canceled at the last minute, said the woman.

title: Ingmar Bergman: Still Asking The GodQuestion
description: Ingmar Bergman, filmmaker, is hooked on God. Though the Lutheran pastor's son can protest and deny it in interview after interview, his films provide incontrovertible evidence to the contrary: The Swedish director's genius is wedded to a world in which the Godquestion is as real and present as the physical presence of Liv Ullmann. When we are in Mr. Bergman's world, the presence of God  or the presence of God's absence  is overpowering.

title: The Man Inside the Kid
description: SKIPPY was a popular comic strip about a puckish and philosophical little boy who wore a floppy polkadot bow tie, crumpled plaid hat and droopy socks. Born in the 1920's, he lasted until 1945; his creator, Percy Crosby, unfortunately lived on for 19 more years, most of them spent as a de facto prisoner in the psychiatric wards of a veterans hospital.

title: The Region
description: NEW HAVEN (AP)  Stung by the recent theft of five valuable maps by a visiting professor, officials at Yale University's Sterling Memorial Library said they were reassessing their security measures to make it more difficult for thieves to steal documents.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2  Whenever something goes violently wrong in this country, there is a natural desire to find some general explanation, some failure in the nation or its institutions, or at least some villain or conspiracy of scoundrels.

title: Fire Damages Embassy in India
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 2 (AP)  Fire damaged three rooms of the United States Embassy last night, a Marine guard reported. The guard, Sgt. Olin Brown, estimated damage in the 90minute blaze at $250,000. He said that papers, books, carpets and airconditioning ducts burned, but no diplomatic files were damaged. There were no casualties in the fire, which he said was caused by an electric hot plate.

title: Democrats Kept Happy
description: GOVERNOR BYRNE is about to complete a longrange deal that he made with Mayor Thomas F.X. Smith of Jersey City, a deal that required some complicated shuffling of public officials and wound up costing a respected Republican his job.

title: SHOP TALK
description: THERE'S no energy crisis in two Connecticut families who have made it their business for generations to bring light to their customers' homes and stores. The families run three companies with stores around the state that sell thousands of lighting fixtures of almost every size and description.

title: Pre1974 Gift Tax Ruled Illegal, But It's Too Late to Get Refund
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP)  The United States Tax Court says political contributions should not have been taxed as gifts even before the 1979 law that exempted them from gift tax.

title: Interest Rates Soar: The Impact, the Prospects
description: As interest rates soar into the wild blue yonder, many businessmen, investors and economists are starting to suffer from an acute attack of acrophobia  an abnormally intense. fear of heights. As it happens, the fear may indeed be excessive, or at least premature, given the economy's current forward momentum and the high degree of liquidity.

title: Vietnamese Said to Shatter a Big Cambodian Force
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2  A fullscale dry season offensive by Vietnamese troops has shattered a Cambodian Army division in the worst setback the Phnom Penh Government has suffered in the 18monthold conflict, Administration sources said today.

title: Officials Revive Greenwich Bus Plans
description: GREENWICH IDEAS for some kind of bus system to replace the proposal that suffered a crushing defeat in the Greenwich Representative Town Meeting last June are beginning to emerge from official and unofficial quarters, indicating that the bitter controversy culminating in the rejection vote was not the last word on the possibility of some form of mass transit within the town.

title: Other Ideas & Trends
description: Viking artifacts found in North America have often proved to be fakes. The latest one may be real; a coin in the Maine State Museum at Augusta, dug up in 1961 and previously classified as English, has been identified as probably an 11thcentury Norse silver penny. Museum officials think the coin was brought to Maine from further north by an Indian.

title: L.I. Radio Stations Are Booming As Residents Seek Local Identity
description: Radio stations on Long Island are sending up new towers, and increasing their wattage in a battle for local listeners who seem to be increasingly less interested in the big New York City stations.

title: Water in Sections of Manhattan May Show a Slight Discoloration
description: The New York City Environmental Protection Department yesterday informed residents of Manhattan from Houston Street to 35th Street and from the East River to Third Avenue that there might be a slight discoloration in their water.

title: Some Sounds of the Season
description: LOVERS of choral music, take heart. Christmas is coming, and with it the perennial outpourings of Messiahs and other seasonal favorites in songs. Today, for instance, in Shrub Oak you can near Handel's great oratorio, or sing it yourself in Chappaqua; you can give Bach equal yuletide time in White Plains, or celebrate St. Nicholas Day in Philipse Manor. Later in the week, you can spend a Victorian evening at Lyndhurst, while carols from Cuba, Colombia, Italy and Spain, plus another Messiah, are in the cards for next Sunday.

title: She Treats Songs Like Jewels
description: SMALL bars equipped with pinball machines and videogames are not especially conducive to subtle, nuanceladen music. Their clientele tends to regard music as important but secondary, a mere aural backdrop to other activities.

title: Retrial in Kent State Shootings To Begin Tomorrow in Cleveland
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 2 (AP)  Eight years after the killing of four students and wounding of 13 others by Ohio National Guardsmen at Kent State University, a Federal court here is to again consider the case against 28 defendants.

title: Bonaire: Exploring in Depth
description: A fly lands on the menu, right where it says the Zeezicht has a graduated Chinese cook in charge. Across from the little portside cafe, two rowboats rock gently in the turquoise Caribbean beneath an idly circling seagull. In the back, our waiter takes a nap. Between 12 and 2, nothing, except the scorching equatorial sun, moves in Bonaire  it's siesta time on this sparsely populated little island.

title: Obituary 7 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 354-3900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 3-3900 WESTCHESTER CO. AND NONTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300, NASSAU CO. (515) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800 CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767

title: Joanmarie Tully Is Bride of Editor
description: Joanmarie Tully, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Tully of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Thomas Quinn O'Connor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. O'Connor of Yarmouth Port, Mass., were married yesterday.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest AfricaAndreas Shipanga is back in Namibia after two years in Zambian and Tanzanian prisons. Now his SWAPO Democrats  known locally as SWAPOD further confuse the tangled politics of this last surviving fragment of colonialism.

title: Columbia Triumphs In Garden
description: College basketball was the only attraction on display yesterday at Madison Square Garden from 11 A.M. to a few minutes past 5 P.M. But it was not a very big one. A crowd estimated at 2,205 was the best the Garden could lure with a tripleheader featuring metropolitan area colleges.

title: Picture Credits
description: 1CONTACT/GIANFRANCO GORGONI

title: Jones Cultists Shared Backgrounds and Aims With Their Hosts
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana  When the Rev. Jim Jones transported his People's Church adherents and their mystic ideology, combining Christianity and Communism, to the jungles of Guyana, his choice og destination was not without basis. For Guyana itself is ruled by a Government that avows Marxist goals and finds its political strength in a segment of the population that is similar in color (black), religion (lowchurch Protestant) and economic status (poor) to most of the Jones flock.

title: NEW GROUP TO BACK NONPROFIT SECTOR
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP)  John W. Gardner, a former Cabinet officer and founder of Common Cause, is organizing a new group to insure the survival of the nonprofit sector, which he says is threatened by government encroachment and tax policies.

title: NEW JERSEY HOUSING
description: FOR Jack and Phyllis Greenman and a few other pioneers, the glory days of having a large and luxurious condominium development, together with all its attendant services, just for themselves are over.

title: P.J. Vecchio Fianc Of Lois M. Jadwin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Jadwin of Madison, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lois Margaret Jadwin, to Paul John Vecchio, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph A. Vecchio of Dover. N.J.

title: Daughter Held in Savings Theft
description: BOULDER, Colo., Dec. 2 (UPI) After buying a new Thunderbird, a Jaguar and a $25,000 Lincoln Continental to make herself popular and change her humdrum life, a high school student has been charged with seconddegree forgery in the theft of about $32,000 from her parents' savings accounts.

title: China's Press Agency Plans Own Roman Spelling
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 2  In a move that may make Chinese names and places hard to recognize abroad, the goverment press agency, Hsinhua. announced today that, starting Jan. 1, its international wire service will use the phonetic Roman alphabet that has been officially adopted in China as an aid in rendering Chinese characters.

title: OFFICIALS OPTIMISTIC ON GARBAGE STRIKE
description: Garbage continued to pile up yesterday in front of hotels, restaurants and other commercial establishments as 2,000 private sanitation workers stayed awayfrom their jobs in a contract dispute with carting companies. But city officials privately expressed optimism that the strike might be settled soon, possibly in negotiations scheduled to resume today.

title: Abate Takes The Speaker's Gavel
description: STAMFORD I THOUGHT it would be awfully presumptuous to run, said Ernest N. Abate, who is completing his second term as a,State Representative from Stamford. But people around me kept saying, Run, do it.  So Mr: Abate rani, and campaigned hard, and last week he was elected Speaker of the House of Representatives, possibly the first time so junior a member has attained that rank.

title: A Good Detective Leaves No Trail
description: ROGER STARETT lives on the Island not too far from Exit 69 of the Expressway. But he doesn't like it much. Roger Starett lives there mainly for the sake of his family. He'd really rather be in New York City, where his work is. Roger Starett is a detective for the New York City Police Department. Like a lot of cops, Roger Starett moonlights but as a hit man for the Mafia.

title: Truce Is Called in Landfill Battle For Salute to Martin Van Buren
description: KINDERHOOK, N.Y. Dec. 1  Columbia County will celebrate on Tuesday the 196th birthday of its most illustrious son, Martin Van Buren, the eighth President of the United States, with a truce in a continuing battle about a proposed sanitary landfill in the area of his home, now a national historic site.

title: Amity Stops Ansonia Streak
description: Ansonia High School's 36game winning streak  a New Endland schoolboy record came to an end yesterday as Rich Lena of Amity ran for four touchdowns to lead his team to a 3520 victory in the Connecticut Class championship game that was played before a crowd of 10,000 at Bowen Field in New Haven.

title: A Place Indoors for Hydroponics
description: Does hydroponics have a place in indoor gardening? It may well have, according to Dr. P. A. Schippers of the Cornell University Long Island Horticultural Laboratory in Riverhead. At a recent meeting of the MidIsland Hobby Greenhouse Association, he displayed several houseplants grown hydroponically in his home and office, and discussed the hydroponics research program he heads at the laboratory.

title: Pendleton Rides Out The Woolens Storm
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  How to succeed in the woolen business: Doggedly produce 100 percent virgin wool clothes while everyone else is turning to polyester. Charge a good piece of money for them. Keep the same designs year after year.

title: Simulated Liquefied Gas Disaster Will Help Train Student Firemen
description: BOSTON, Dec. 2 (AP)  Students at the Massachusetts Firefighting Academy will soon be able to prepare for explosions of liquefied gas by practicing on the world's first operational model of a burning liquefied gas tank.

title: STAMPS
description: The big omnibus issue of this year was the celebration of the 25th anniversary of the Coronation of Queen Elizabeth II of Britain by countries still in allegiance to the British Crown  former colonies with stillstrong loyalties, nations in the Commonwealth of Nations spearheaded by Great Britain, and many other nations around the world that joined in paying tribute to the monarch and the unique institution she represents.

title: Lawyers' Work Has Had National Implications
description: THE Westcheter Legal Services program nandles 3,000 cases a year through its five district offices. The majority of them involve housing disputes, publicassistance claims and Federal administrative irregularities.

title: Official Seeking to Aid Family of Slain Mayor
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2 (UPI) Acting Mayor Dianne Feinstein has said that she will introduce legislation Monday to help the family of slain Mayor George Moscone meet its financial needs.

title: Finding a Place for Jazz on Broadway
description: Jazz has never had more than a peripheral place in the Broadway musical theater. And most of that periphery was concentrated in the 20's and 30's  usually in black musicals such as Shuffle Along and Hot Chocolates, although Duke Ellington's orchestra appeared in Florenz Ziegfeld's otherwise white production of Show Girl in 1929 and, a decade later, a mixed cast that included Louis Armstrong, Maxine. Sullivan, Lionel Hampton, Benny Goodman and Bud Freeman's Summa Cum . Laude Orchestra appeared in Swingin the Dream, an adaptation of A Midsummer Night's Dream.

title: Althea J. Bradbury Becomes the Bride Of Peter C. Bullard
description: Althea Johnson Bradbury, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Bradbury 3d of Philadelphia, was married at noon yesterday to Peter Crapo Bullard, son of Dr. and Mrs. John C. Bullard of South Darmouth, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Edward G. Gammons in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Yardley, Pa.

title: Illinois Legislators Override Veto. Become Highest Paid in Nation
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Dec. 2 (UPI)Illinois legislators will soon be able to boast that they are the highest paid in the nation, but the taxpayers will have to put up $8.4 million a year for the honor.

title: Cashing In On Coop Fever: It Calls for Nerve And Timing
description: If you acquired a cooperative apartment in a luxury building here in recent years, the chances are you have begun to feel a certain pressure.

title: BROOKLYN COLLEGE ASSESSED BY KNELLER
description: Dr. John W. Kneller, who resigned last week as the president of Brooklyn College, acknowledges shortcomings in his administration, but lays many of its problems to vindictive faculty members who were unable to obtain special favors.

title: DINING OUT
description: SALISBURY IT could be one of life's ironies that one Cronnecticurs better Chinese restaurants is hiding its talents behind the white clapboard facade of an oldfashioned country inn. But that is exactly the case at aie White Hart Inn.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: THEY say  and don't ask me who they are  that you really don't know people until you have them as guests in your home. I've found this to be all too true.

title: The NewOld Art Of Liturgical Dance
description: Next Saturday and Sunday, the Omega Liturgical Dance Company will perform in its new studio in the crypt of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street. The studio is as extraordinary a space as that occupied by any company in the city  a soaring, brickfaced, converted burial chapel, whose previous occupants included a bishop (deceased).

title: Asian Athletes Face Olympic Sanctions
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 2  A heavy political shadow lies over the Asian Games, which open here Dec. 9, and seems to have taken enthusiasm out of organizers and participants of the Olympicstyle sports festival.

title: New Music From N.Y.U.
description: The New York University Contemporary Players offered a concert Friday night at Carnegie Recital Hall that consisted of contemporary music composed, conducted and performed by N.Y.U. faculty or students. The small hall was packed with a generally enthusiastic audience, although the family nature of the affair made it hard to determine how much of the enthusiasm was for the actual music.

title: Expert Says U.S. Population Will Hit Peak by 2015
description: The population of the United States is growing much more slowly than was forecast only a few years ago, and a leading demographer has calculated that the number of Americans is likely to peak at 253 million in the year 2015.

title: Police Killing Reflects the Racial Tensions of a Washington Suburb
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2  The slaying of two young white policemen by a 15yearold black youth, using the revolver of one of the victims, has focused this city's attention on the mood of its least affluent and often troubled suburb, Prince Georges County, Md., where flat miles of apartment clusters are interspersed with shopping centers, automobile dealerships, enclaves of singlefamily suburban comfort and old crossroads towns overrun by urban sprawl.

title: Sampling of New Nonfiction Shows That Many Lives Are an Open Book
description: Besides being women, Lauren Bacall, Margaret Trudeau, Patty Hearst, Marilyn Monroe, Greta Garbo, Cissy Patterson, Lillian Hellman, Aline Bernstein, Henrietta Szold, George Sand, Jane Austen and Sophia Loren have another thing in common: all have books by or about them on the 1979 publishing lists.

title: Law Firms Keep Up With Jones Jones & Joneses
description: Once at Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, a threeman committee was set up to buy art work for the firm's new Park Avenue offices. Art arrived and art departed in quick succession. This is one of the firms that bluechip corporations turn to to settle crucial disputes, but when it came to art work the lawyers could not agree. Then a oneman committee was appointed, and  presto! Andy Warhol, Robert Rauschenberg and many others began to take their place along the firm's corridors.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: To Claudette Colbert, Broadway Is Home
description: BOSTON At 73, Claudette Colbert looks good enough to make you want to check the date on your calendar not the day, but the decade. Was it really 44 years ago that she and Clark Gable sat on a fence rail, glumly munching carrots, in the classic Frank Capra film comedy, It Happened One Night? The familiar features are unchanged  those high cheekbones framing that generous smile, the auburn hair cut low in feathery bangs, the figure trim and petite.

title: Another Leap?
description: HONG KONG  For a few weeks in the late spring 1957, wall posters calling for freedom of speech and an end political persecution suddenly festooned Peking University. Enthusiastic students staged impromptu rallies and harangued crowds, while intellectuals elsewhere in China criticized the Communist Party for becoming a privileged new class. In the excitement of the moment, some professors even offered classes on Keynesian economics and the philosophy of Bertrand Russell.

title: Huntington Hospital Fights to Expand
description: HUNTINGTON IT is not as if the hospital suddenly appeared there, shattering the tranquillity of the comfortable clapboard homes and treelined streets. Huntington Hospital has been an integral part of its community for more than half a century.

title: CUTBACKS PROPOSED FOR U.S. HEALTH AID
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2  President Carter's Office of Management and Budget is seeking to make drastic cuts in Federal health programs in the next budget, including the elimination of some major programs altogether.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The New York Knicks have games in Madison Square Garden at 7:30 P.M. Tuesday against the Kansas City Kings and 8 P.M. Saturday against the Chicago Bulls. The San Diego Clippers pay an 8 o'clock visit Saturday night to the New Jersey Nets in Rutgers gymnasium in Piscataway, N.J.

title: INVESTING
description: Back in January, three market analysts were asked by The New York Times to prepare investment portfolios for the recipient of a sudden $20,000 windfall. The analysts addressed themselves to three broad groups with differing investment objectives: a single person in the 20to30yearold age bracket, a middleaged head of household and a widow over 65.

title: Medical Examiners Find Failings By Government on Cultist Bodies
description: DOVER AIR FORCE BASE, Del., Dec. 2  The Government's actions concerning the bodies of 911 People's Temple members who died in Guyana two weeks ago were illogical and based on dubious legal principles, according to several medical examiners not connected with the investigation of the deaths.

title: 1,096 Works
description: BETWEEN a catalogue raisonn of an artist's total artistic production and the more familiar largeformat coffeetable monograph on the life and work, there are certain superficial resemblances. They both tend to be big, expensive, unwieldy and more fun to look at than to read. Both have the effect of aggrandizing the subject's reputation, and thus

title: Patient Holmes Waits for Ride
description: These are troubled times in some areas of motor sports. A powerful group of racecar owners, calling themselves Championship Auto Racing Teams (CART), says it has broken away from the United States Auto Club and will stage races for Indytype cars next season. In Formula One, the top international governing body and the car owners' association appear to be on a collision course over control of that series in 1979.

title: Michigan BottleDeposit Law Takes Effect Today
description: DETROIT, Dec. 2  Tomorrow Michigan becomes the first large industrialized state with a mandatory deposit law for bottles and cans. Environmental and industry experts will be watching the developments carefully for clues to possible application to other populous, urbanized states.

title: Patricia G. Bloom Bride of W.S. Sheppard
description: In St. Timothy's Episcopal Church in Greenfield Hill, Fairfield, Conn., yesterday afternoon, Patricia Gillis Bloom of Rowayton, Conn., daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Gillis of Vista and Palm Spring, Calif., became the bride of W. Stevens Sheppard, a widower of Southport. Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert Bast.

title: Julie Kurnitz Offers Satire
description: Julie Kurnitz, who has proved an able and versatile interpreter of Al Carmines's songs as a regular member of Mr. Carmines's little performing company in recent years, is out on her own this week at the Ballroom, where she is appearing through this evening, giving heartening evidence that the art of supperclub satire has not com pletely disappeared with the late lamented Julius Monk revues.

title: GARDENING
description: HOLLY trees catch one's eye more than ever at this time of year, for it is now that their berries are at their peak of brilliance. Actually, it is hard to beat a holly tree for attractiveness at any season.

title: Job Agency for Island Pressed in Albany
description: LEGISLATIVE proposals have lives of their own. Some seem to have the capacity to stay around for decades. Others disappear almost as soon as they are put forth.

title: Town's Police Officers To Get Driving Lessons
description: LONGMEADOW, Mass., Dec. 2 (UPI)  Police officers in this small western Massachusetts town are going to get some lessons in defensive driving.

title: A Town Prints Comics About Garbage Habits
description: WILTON, N.H., Dec. 2 (UPI)  Wilton has borrowed a page from the cartoon characters that campaigned for United States Savings Bonds in World War II. The southern New Hampshire town of 2,700 is printing comic books to promote Rood garbage habits.

title: GARDENING
description: LAST winter, during one of the bad weather delays on the New Haven commuter line, the train halted for a time at a place where the tracks bordered some suburban backyards just south of New Rochelle. I had finished my crossword puzzle and my thoughts wandered as gazed out the window.

title: Notes: Mrs. Carter's Friendship Force Makes a Fresh Start
description: A revitalized Friendship Force, the peopletopeople exchange organization whose honorary chairwoman is Rosalynn Carter, is back on the track after a slump caused by lack of funds.

title: Hunters Help Efforts to Save Mountain Lion
description: RENO, Dec. 2 (UPI)  The battered jeep jerks to a halt. A tawny form moves swiftly across the wintry meadow. The hounds, several hundred yards behind but closing in, fill the eastern Nevada mountains with their baying.

title: Reports on Privacy Safeguards Prepared for Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2  The Carter Administration is nearing the end of a yearlong study of how to protect computerized personal records against misuse by Government agencies and private companies.

title: The Sponz Is State's Teacher of the Year
description: GLEN ROCK TELEVISION may have its Fonz, but education in New Jersey has its Sponz  Alan N. Sponzilli of Glen Rock High School, the state's Teacher of the Year.

title: Last Swing at Success for a Boxer
description: Though the paydays are not bad for a winner in professional boxing, they do not come often enough, says John Capobianco of Huntington, a secondgeneration boxer who sounds as if he's almost ready to throw in the towel.

title: COMING OF AGE WITH
description: To the dismay of their parents, millions of preteenagers are devouring this author's explicit books for children.

title: Steinbeck's Days in Sag Harbor
description: IT seems appropriate that Southampton College is honoring John Steinbeck's memory by providing in his name a place for writers to write in.

title: SHOP TALK
description: RIVERHEAD is a bustling small town, where residents of the scattered villages that dot the North and South Forks converge to do their serious shopping, particularly when the trendy, seasonally run boutiques of the Hamptons are closed and the Christmas holidays approach. Many of the Riverhead stores are open long hours to accommodate their customers, some of whom make a 100mile roundtrip drive from Montauk to shop in what is locally considered the capital city of the East End.

title: Other National Events
description: It's back to the drawing board with the E3A, one of the United States Air Force's more expensive projects. Twelve of the 14 planes that make up the Airborne Warning and Control System  at $122.2 million each  are on the ground in Oklahoma, temporarily restricted to missionessential operations (the other two are off standby and on the runway in Iceland). The reason: a potential fuel booster pump failure problem. The modified, elaborately equipped Boeing 707's are designed to direct F15 fighters to attack. enemy planes slipping below groufidbased radar.

title: Through a Lens, Diversely
description: CROTONONHUDSON THE VARIETY of art captured in the photographer's lens is the focus an exhibition opening today at Temple Israel of Northern Westchester on Glengary Road. The show features the work of 10 photographers reptesenting a cross section of styles and specialties from fashion photojournalism  many of them from Westchester and nearby Connecticut.

title: Power Lies With Eight Soldiers Who Fought Along With Houari Boumediene
description: ALGIERS  Algeria's bloody struggle for independence from France, which triumphed in 1962, is one of the great, almost mythic, chapters in the 20th century's history emancipation from colonial rule. Its lingering legacy is a key element in the question of who will succeed President Houari Boumediene, now gravely ill, who has ruled Algeria for 13 of its 16 years of independence.

title: The Historic Charm Of Rockingham
description: ROCKYHILL

title: Taking Aim at Inflation Target  Q & A, but Still Mostly Q
description: WASHINGTON  These are confused times for economywatchers, and for just plain people. Everyone seems agree on the problem. It's inflation. But there's far less unanimity on the correct solution, and understanding the disagreement is a challenge for the nonspecialist. What follows is an attempt to unravel the complexities.

title: Bringing Order To the Shoreline
description: THE need for coastalzone management is well recognized by those who have watched the helterskelter laissezfaire development of Connecticut's shoreline, and the resultant limitation of access for our burgeoning population. I am frustrated with delays, costly overlapping, interminable studies, stalling tactics and the absence of forthright leadership that have resulted in no action.

title: Penguins 5, Black Hawks 2
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 2 (AP)  Rod Schutt and Dale Talon scored a goal and an assist each to pace the Pittsburgh Penguins to a 52 triumph over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight.

title: Gunfire Hits Russian Freighter
description: BALTIMORE. Dec. 2 (UPI)  A Russian freighter bound for Baltimore earlier this week was struck by gunfire as the ship entered the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal from the Delaware River, the Federal Bureau of Investi ation said today. The Delaware state police said that two shots had been fired from a passing car on the Reedy Point Bridge in Delaware and had pierced the steel wall of the radio room of the Andrian Goncharov.

title: FOOD
description: ANYONE for Santa Claus? A chocolate Santa Claus? With the Christmas season upon us, shopping lists are bound to include gifts of sweets. Several places on the Island specialize in excellent chocolates for giftgiving, from Santas to holidaywrapped assortments.

title: Super Bowl Jets Return for Shea Tribute
description: They are frozen forever, like some prehistoric creature fossilized in rock, and for many of them there is no identity other than this: I played for the Super Bowl Jets.

title: Who Helped Win Battle of Britain
description: SUMMIT WILLIAM J. SWEENEY and Charles E. Starr never saw combat duty with any of the armed forces. Neither did Alexander R. Ogston or P.H. Holt.

title: Rockefeller Center Remodeling Concourse of Shops
description: A $2 million plan for remodeling the underground shopping concourse at Rockefeller Center, featuring new open promenades at three locations, has been announced by Alton G. Marshall. the president of Rockefeller Center.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE name of the new French restaurant in Huntington, Pch Mignon, is a colloquialism meaning a weak spot, like an innocent bad habit. It would indeed be hard not to develop a weakness for the irresistible temptations in the dessert department here. At the same time, gluttony would never be a problem: The portions are too small.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: WE HAD been to the old place  the one shaped like a truncated railroad car, the way diners are supposed to be shaped  and had forgiven it for not serving its homemade pies while reconstruction was going on. Wait, just wait, we were told.

title: Amish Battling County To Retain Outhouse
description: CENTRAL LAKE, Mich., Dec. 2 (UPI)  An AmishMennonite family has accused village officials here of religious persecution for trying to force them to tear down their backyard outhouse.

title: Libby Nye Troupe Juxtaposes Dance and Sculpture
description: The Libby Nye Dance Company was certainly not afraid to ally its Thursday night concert at the Entermedia Theater with great music and sculpture.

title: Conductors of the Past Revisited
description: Ever since the introduction of the electrical recording process in 1925, we've amassed what amounts to an aural documentation of the modem symphony orchestra and its conductors. And many of the older recordings can still provide a good deal of musical pleasure for the averaee person as well.

title: Report Cards For Teachers
description: RESENTING what they feel is a blot on their good name, teachers around Connecticut are. reacting with dismay to the increased public debate over their competency.

title: THEATER
description: WHILE one hears a great deal of theater talk about the revue as a dead form and the growing stagnation of the American musical comedy, no one seems to talk much about farce as an endangered species of theater fare. Farce is the blacksheep relative of comedy. While comedy has good manners and intelligence, farce only makes the briefest of bows to logie and sense before taking a wild; insane lean into the air where, if its parents  the playwrights  have done their work well, it will stay, alive and kicking until the final curtain.

title: EqualEmployment Unit To Stress Bias Patterns
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UPI)  The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission will shift its emphasis next year from individual complaints to broad patterns of discrimination in the workplace, the agency's administrator has told Congress.

title: CHESS
description: The FrenchPolish grandmaster Savielly Tartakover once quipped, Sacrifices only prove that someone has blundered, meaning that either the sacrifice is unsoundly offered or the opponent's error made it possible. Often, however, sacrifices prove that the defender has put up so much resistance that a routine prosecution of the attack would fail.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE LIGHTHOUSE is one of the very few restaurants in Westchester situated right on the Hudson shore. For that alone we think it's worth twisting your way through the factory district of Yonkers to get to it. The view of the Palisades Across the river down to the George Washington Bridge, the movement of river traffic, and the sunsets will amply reward the effort.

title: Stalin's Compatriots Regard Him As Georgian Who Ruled Russia
description: LORI, U.S.S.R.  In this Georgian town, where Stalin was born on Dec. 21, 1879, a defiant statue of the dictator still stands in front of city hall. A museum enshrines the house where he came into the world as losif Vissarionovich Dzhugashvili. Nowhere is there a sign of the official disgrace into which he fell everywhere else in the Soviet Union soon after he died in 1953.

title: Other World Events
description: The biannual meetings of the Supreme Soviet, the Soviet Union's nominal parliament, are often as notable for the seating arrangement on the rostrum as for the economic plans they rubber stamp. The new face in the front row last week belonged to Konstantin U. Chernenko, a protg of Leonid I. Brezhnev, who was elevated to full membership on the ruling Politburo. Absent from the rostrum was Kirill T. Mazurov, who resigned for reasons of health and his request.

title: Search for 2 on Tug Ended
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 2 (AP) The Coast Guard has abandoned the search for two New Bedford, Mass., men aboard the tugboat Hall Brothers and will concentrate on investigating the cause of the sinking, a spokesman says. The search for the men was broken off Friday night, several hours after Navy divers found the steelhulled craft under 74 feet of water off Sakonnet Point.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE State Department's first passport office between New York City and Boston has opened in Stamford and officials expect that it will issue 250,000 passports in its first year of operation.

title: Auto Workers to Get Increases
description: DETROIT, Dec. 2 (UPI)  About 820,000 hourly employees of the General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation will receive a costofliving pay increase of 19 cents an hour as of Dec. 4, the United Automobile Workers has announced. Thirteen cents of the increase was based on a rise in the Consumer Price Index and six cents stemmed from the restoration of costofliving allowance funds that had been diverted to U.A.W. retirees since 1977, the union said.

title: Ambitious Young Boxers Have Training Ground In the Old Mold at Basement Gym in Farmingdale
description: FARMINGDALE, L.I.  It's a case of bad casting. The onestory brick building centered in the open space of Ellsworth Allen Park in Farmingdale just doesn't look like a hangout for boxers.

title: Atlantic City Homeowners Under Pressure to Sell
description: Slum tenants and apartment residents are not the only ones in Atlantic City who are feeling the pressure to give up their homes for casino development. Homeowners in a neatly kept beach block near Convention Hall are urging fellow homeowners who do not want to move to give in and sell their homes for $100,000 each so their neighbors can do the same.

title: Losing The Revenue Game
description: WHEN in, 1976 the national commiss on to study, gambling conchided in its final report to Congress, that the states, and not the Federal Government, should have primary control over legalized gambling, it assumed that the problems inherent to illegal gambling would not transfer themselves to stateregulated gaming. This was an erroneous conclusion. Organizedcrime figures and hidden ownership (through multistate and multinational operations) are just as potentially rampant in legal gambling as ever they were in the local or syndicated bookie shops.

title: News Summary
description: Riots broke out in Iran at the start of Moharram, the most emotionally charged month of the Iranian religious year. Three times during a 24hour period thousands of antiGovernment demonstrators spilled into the streets of Teheran, defying the curfew and a ban on marches, and three times soldiers with fixed bayonets, backed by tanks and helicopters, dispersed them. The Government said seven persons were killed and 37 injured in the first burst of violence last night, but the total may be many times larger. An opposition group said 67 victims were buried during the day. [Page 1, Col. 6.]

title: Reform Leader Urges A Program to Convert Seekers to Judaism
description: Rabbi Alexander Schindler, president of the congregational arm of Reform Judaism, has called on Reform Jews to reverse the practice of centuries and begin a drive to convert the unchurched to Judaism.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Golf for Fun, Profit
description: LARGO, Fla., Dec. 2  November and December are the doldrum months in professional golf, so the third annual mixedteam championship, touching the last week of November and the first week of December. fills a void. For anyone who still feels like playing and who wants to round out the season by winning a few more dollars, the tournament comes at a felicitous time, though Florida weather at this time of year is unpredictable.

title: Hill Pair Posts 63; Gains 2d
description: LARGO, Fla., Dec. 2  Under ideal playing conditions  rainsoftened greens and no wind  21 of 35 teams shot 70 or better today in the third round of the third annual Mixed Team Championship, but one foursome provided the big fireworks.

title: Atlantic City Is Not Fulfilling All Its Promises
description: ATLANTIC CITY  Although legalized gambling is not turning out to be a cureall for this resort town's many longstanding problems, giving people a place to take their chances with slot machines and playing cards has produced jobs for many Atlantic City residents.

title: Deaths
description: DAVIDOWITZLawrence B. on December 1. 1978, beloved husband of Edna, devoted father of Suzanne, Diane and Jane. Adored son of Helen, dear brother of Jean Kann and Edward Davidowitz. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave at 81 St, Saturday. 79 pm. Service Sunday, 10 am.

title: Former Cult Aides Contend Jones Secretly Banked Over $10 Million
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2  The Rev. Jim Jones, who died with more than 900 followers in Guyana on Nov. 18, left a network of secret bank accounts around the world totaling more than $10 million, according to former aides. With his death, a mysterious international battle has begun for the fortune amassed by the People's Temple.

title: Ert Gets Around
description: It's hard to believe that the legendary Ert  whose fashion sketches and costume designs so typified the Paris of the 1920's is still going strong. But he is. Right now his works are on exhibition all over town  and out of town. The Rizzoli Gallery has a show of lithographs and original sketches that will run through December. Sketches for fashions he designed for Henri Bendel in 1915, 16 and 17 are in one of the store's windows. A new portfolio of lithographs is on display at the Circle Gallery in SoHo. The Boston Center for the Arts is having a Latin Quarter show of many of his original costumes and drawings. And the Smithsonian Institution is putting together a show of his works that will travel around the country for two years.

title: More Thoughts About China
description: America's triangular relationship with a feuding Russia and China poses no harder question than whether the West should sell arms to one of them. Peking wants weapons and advanced technology heretofore denied to both Communist powers. Moscow rages against the idea; a warning of serious consequences London sells military jets to China was only the latest of many dmarches. Still, the Carter Administration is reluctant to turn the Chinese away emptyhanded. It hopes to encourage the pragmatic politics of a postMao Government that seems eager to open its doors to the world to promote its economic development.

title: Head of Catholic Order Supports Wearing of Special Garb by Nuns
description: ALTON, Ill., Dec. 2 (AP)  Nuns who abandon habits in favor of secular dress are out of step with what society expects. according to the head of the American branch of an international order of nuns.

title: Have Pinter and Stoppard Turned to Naturalism?
description: LONDON No British playwright presently stands higher than either Harold Pinter or Tom Stoppard in the stockmarket of taste; and so it is natural that the coincidental opening of a play by each man within a week should have provoked avid comparisons among the cultural brokers. Both plays, it is said, represent a new departure for their respective authors. Both are more truetolife, more naturalistic than the work that preceded them had led us to expect. And both present a somewhat conservative view of their subjects; in the case of Mr. Stoppard's Night and Day (at the Phoenix), trade unionism; in that of Mr. Pinter's Betrayal (at the National), marriage and adultery.

title: Emergency Phone Set For Garbage Removal
description: City officials have set up a special telephone .number so that instances where garbage has piled up and created health or safety hazards can be reported.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: UNDER THE SHADOW OF THE KREMLIN
description: To the small nations that must cope with it as an uncomfortable neighbor, the Russian giant often looks significantly different from the image it projects across the Atlantic.

title: 3 Journalists Arrested In Scuffles in Teheran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 2  Three journalists were arrested tonight after scuffles with soldiers and policemen outside the InterContinental Hotel where foreign reporters are staying.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Competitions are very much a way of life for many young musicians these days, and there even are such things as competition bums. Like tennis bums, they shuttle from event to event, hoping to pick up some prize money, the sponsors in the meanwhile picking up the tabs. Before World War II there were perhaps only a halfdozen really prestigious musical competitions in the whole world. Now there are dozens of major ones plus  literally  hundreds upbn hundreds more of lesser importance.
