Somewhere along the line any young musician with any kind of talent is going to garner a muddle of medals, jiggling them in his pocket like a bunch of subway tokens.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Today  Boardwalk Kennel Club allbreed and obedience, Convention Hall, Mississippi Avenue and Boardwalk, Atlantic City; 3,127 dogs; 9A.M.

title: Tremors of Grief In San Francisco
description: Perhaps there is another fault in California, as deep and awful as the one in the earth's crust, where the jagged edges of the American dream collide with reality. Or perhaps to think so is just another way of trying to make sense of the senseless.

title: National Trust Establishes Fund To Preserve Historic Buildings
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP)  In a symbolic setting, a drive was announced yesterday to protect some of the nation's endangered historic buildings.

title: Outside Criticism
description: While the Peking wall poster campaign was calling for Western freedoms, Amnesty International last week published a report on political imprisonment in China, calling for similar reforms. The Londonbased rights organization said Chinese law including the new Constitution adopted last March  still allows arrest and imprisonment on loosely defined political grounds. The report listed specifics, including unlimited pretrial detentions, mass arrests when the political climate suddenly changes, obligatory confessions and administrative penalties without trial. The report was submitted to China in June. There has been no reply.

title: New Pastor Is Named For Park Ave. Church
description: The Rev. John Wade Payne has been selected as senior minister of the Park Avenue Christian Church, near 84th Streetm the oldest continuing congregation of the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ). The congregation was established in 1810.

title: Deaths
description: TRICARICOJohn J.,beloved husband of Josephine. father of Vito and Metltuew, 2 daughters. Mn. Ralph Nardi of Bayside. NY, Ws. Donald Rizzuto. 13 grandchildren. Prominent inert Brooklyn architect, former President of Brooklyn Society of Ar. detects. former President Italian American Professional and Businessmen's Associetion.Member Emeritus. Knights of Columbus Member, Mayor's Panel of Architects and the Brooklyn Diocese Committee of Architects. Reposing Pitta Funeral Home. 300 McDonald Avenue, Brooklyn. N.Y..25.7.10 PM Sunday. Funeral Mass Monday, 9:30 AM, Church of Sts. Simon and Jude. Ave T and VanSidoen St. Brooklyn. In lieu of flowery family requests donations be sent to the National A.L.S. Foundation. 105 Madison Ave.NY, NY 10016

title: THE MARKETS
description: There were days last week when the stock market, with prices apparently taking their cue from rapidlyunfolding news developments, seemed quite undecided about its future course. In fact, if an investor took his eyes off the market for as much as a single day, all the signals seemed to be scrambled.

title: ART
description: HUNTINGTON THE Heckscher Museum has decked its halls with its sixth annual Holiday Exhibition and Sale, featuring the work of some 50 Long Island artists and designed to solve giftgiving problems while raising funds for one of the Island's most venerable cultural institutions.

title: COOKBOOKS
description: WHATEVER else 1978 may become known for, it certainly has been a vintage year for cookbooks, with excellent new works by such old reliables as Elizabeth David (bread), Marcella Hazan (Italian), Diana Kennedy (Mexican) and Julia Child (this time, international). In addition, there are several equally interesting and trustworthy offerings by some lesser known cooks and food writers who will not be lesser known for long. Inevitably, of course, there are the elaborate holiday gift books that do not deliver what their glossy color prints and lofty price tags promise, and a few others that are collections of recipes from women's magazines calling for canned, frozen and otherwise processed ingredients. Nevertheless, the good outweighs that bad this year, which is, after all, about as much as one can ask.

title: Comatose Algerian Chief's Condition Called Stable
description: ALGIERS; Dec. 2  An inteinational medical effort to save the life of Algeria's comatose President, Houari Botunediene, appears to have temporarily stabilized his condition.

title: The World
description: Iran's military regime had all its fingers in the dike last week but the tides of protest burst through. Crying Allah Alchbar,*God is Great, thousands of demonstrators surged through the streets of Teheran and other large cities in defiance of a Government ban. Troops armed with machine guns were admonished to wound, not kill, but many were reported to have died nonetheless.

title: Article 8 -- No Title
description: CONTENTS: PAGE 4

title: Holy Cross 30, Boston Coll. 29
description: NEWTON, Mass., Dec 1 (AP) Glenn Verrette, a safety, batted down a pass on Boston College's try for a 2point conversion with 64 seconds remaining, and Holy Cross hung on for a 3029 victory today as the Eagles lost their 10th game without a victory. It was the 74th meeting of the teams. Boston College has one remaining game, against Temple in Japan.

title: Priceless Documents Are Found in a Vault
description: CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 2 (UPI) Priceless parchment copies of the Bill of Rights and the 11th Amendment and a valuable copy of the Declaration of Independence have been found in excellent condition in a dusty vault at the New Hampshire statehouse.

title: ONTARIO WELCOMING CONCERNS FROM U.S.
description: TORONTO, Dec. 2  New York, New England and the Midwestern states can expect greatly increased competition from Ontario as the struggle for regional economic development stiffens in the coming months and years, according to Ontario's Premier, William G. Davis.

title: Headliners
description: Basically, he doesn't seem to be a man with a lot of friends. Nevertheless, Nathan Giles, charged with the murder of 25yearold Bonnie Ann Bush, seems to have had a good deal of help. Paroled early last year from a murder sentence, Mr. Giles was later charged with rape, sodomy and armed robbery, but was allowed to plead guilty to a misdemeanor and released. On Friday morning, Nov. 24, Miss Bush was assaulted on the street, dragged into a building on West 102d Street, stripped, shot to death and set on fire. Witnesses identified Mr. Giles as the assailant and he was arrested six days later after a running gunfight. The same day, Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire suspended two police officers and a 911 telephone operator. The officers allegedly failed to follow up on the statements of a witness who might have guided them to the the attack. The operator, according to police transcripts, kept a witness who had called 911 on the phone for several minutes going over details, in the end getting the location wrong. After Mr. Giles's arrest, police announced his gun had been linked to two other murders. The emergency number has been beset with management and morale troubles, and Mr. McGuire said he had told officials to shape it up.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: THE Tax Commission is dead, long live the Tax Commission. in Westchester, as in royalty, the name lives on but the identity changes  and for the better, we are encouraged to believe.

title: BRIDGE
description: The Italian Blue Team that dominated world championship play for two decades was created and inspired by two men, both of whom died recently.

title: Stratford to Stage Bond's The Woman
description: Edward Bond's The Woman, whose recent inaugural production by Britain's National Theater generated critical enthusiasm, will have its North American premiere next summer at the 27th.Stratford Festival in Ontario, Robin Phillips, Stratford's artistic director, has announced.

title: A.C.L.U. Sues a School System To End Its Religious Assemblies
description: SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Dec. 2 (UPI) The American Civil Liberties Union has filed suit in Federal District Court challenging religious and Christmas assemblies held in the city school system here.

title: GARDENING To Grow Some Plants, Who Needs Soil?
description: DOES hydroponics have place in indoor gardening? It may well have, according to Dr. P.A. Schippers of the Cornell University Long Island Horticultural Laboratory in Riverhead. At a recent meeting of the MidIsland Hobby Greenhouse Association, he displayed several houseplants grown hydroponically in his home and office, and discussed the hydroponics research program he heads at the laboratory.

title: Putting the Atlantic Into the Laboratory
description: PRINCETON MARINE scientists and students from 22 colleges and universities in New Jersey and from Lehigh University in Bethlehem, Pa., will soon celebrate the 10th anniversary of a working agreement designed to force the ocean environment to give up some of its secrets.

title: INDIANS TO GET HELP MONITORING FISHING
description: CHARLEVOIX, Mich., Dec. 2 Michigan Indians and state officials, locked for 10 years in a heated dispute over treaty fishing rights, have taken steps to cooperate in policing the fishing in Lake Michigan.

title: Rare Gull Excites Chicago Bird Watchers
description: CHICAGO, Dec 2  The 70 bird watchers ers met at dawn today on the Lake Michigan beach, determined to keep their vigil despite eight inches of snow and 29degree weather.

title: Why Johnny Can't Write: The Student View
description: EVERYONE has an opinion about why Johnny can't write. But has anyone asked Johnny? As a topic for their first essay in collegefreshman English composition (a kind of academic blood sample that I used to diagnose the usual plethora of writing problems) I asked my 60 students to analyze those elements of their high school English experience that most affected their abilities, or disabilities, in writing.

title: Observing Cranes in Their Fight for Survival
description: It is a sight to behold. The tall young man  bearded, bespectacled  hops and shuffles backward along the dusty road like someone in a happy seizure. He is followed closely by a longnecked, longbilled bird, white except for a red skullcap and black markings on head and wings. The bird stands nearly five feet tall and matches the man's every move. The man flaps his arms; the bird flaps her wings. He jumps upward; she jumps higher. He bows his head; she bends her sinuous neck. He calls to her and she gives a piercing cry.

title: Army Tightens ChildCare Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP)  The United States Army has given its commanders the authority to get rid of men and women soldiers, whether married or unmarried, if the responsibilities of caring for their children interferes with their military duties.

title: Deaths
description: GUIDASanto. Dr. Samuel and Frances Blumgarten regret sorrowfully the passing of Santo Guida,father of our dear friend, Dr. Peter Guide and extend our sincere condolences to his family.

title: Bergen Is Divided Over Arts Center
description: HACKENSACK THE, director of the Bergen County Board of Chosen Freeholders has taken a harsh view of a recommendation to forgo a major centralized arts center for the county in favor of cultural outlets in two cities.

title: Strange Hauntings
description: This is not a book of faerie tales for children. Two artists, Brian Froud and Alan Lee, both of whom live in Devon, England, have created from old sources and their own vivid imaginations the history of Faeriea wondrous, terrible, magical world of water and tree faeries, elves, pixies, sprites, spirits, leprechauns, Brownies, as well has a horrendous variety of banshees, bogies and goblins. The abundance of faerie lore is meant not only to entertain, to enlighten, but to fill one with strange hauntings and ap prehension.

title: Letters
description: I read with dismay your article Growth Pains at Candlewood Lake. Nov. 19. Years ago I spent many a relaxing weekend there. Friends had a cottage at New Milford, which they have since sold, finding that weekends and vacations at Candlewood Lake were no more restful than if spent in Central Park.

title: Jane Malcolm Betrothed To Kyle Bern Van Saun
description: Mr. and Mrs. W. Fraser Malcolm of Summit, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Elder Malcolm of New York, to Kyle Bern Van Saun, a partner in Bromley's Sport and Ski in Goshen, N.Y. He is the son of Lieut. Col. Richard F. Van Saun, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Van Saun of Goshen.

title: 17 Men Ordered to Write Essays After Charges on Prostitution
description: LANSING, Mich., Dec. 2 (UPI) Seventeen men arrested by policewomen posing as prostitutes have been fined total of $3,500 and ordered to write essays on the problems they have faced in their lives.

title: Begin Will Go to Oslo to Get Prize
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 2  Prime Minister Menachem Begin intends to go to Norway to receive the Nobel Peace Prize on Dec. 10 despite the announced decision by President Anwar elSadat of Egypt that he will not be present, a Government spokesman said today.

title: ART
description: AKI books were never cheap, and to form a comprehensive private art library today would not leave much change out of $10,000. What historians call the literature proliferates; and as for catalogues of major exhibitions, you could easily spend $1,000 a year on them alone.

title: To One Musician, Brevity Is the Soul of Rock
description: Arock song should be short and get to the point right away, according to Johnny Castro's formula. Say what you have to say and then get out, said Mr. Castro, 26, who leads a quartet known as Johnny Castro and the Convertibles, which has developed a substantial local following.

title: Job Outlook for College Graduates Said to Be Good
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Dec. 2 (UPI)  Despite pessimism about the economy, the job outlook for 197879 college graduates is good, according to one of the nation's largest job placement centers.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: A New Season

title: Picking a Charter
description: If chartering a yacht is your goal, first decide on the type.

title: INTERVIEW
description: SENIOR power is a reality, said Manny Steen, director of Senior Citizens of River Edge (SCORE), Bergen County's largest and most active organization devoted to the elderly.

title: World News Briefs
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Africa, Dec. 2 (AP)  Two bombs exploded and wounded 14 shoppers today in the SouthWest African capital, long a relatively safe haven in the smallscale guerrilla war here. The police warned that more violence could occur in advance of this week's disputed elections.

title: Footnote to a Major Judicial Reform
description: ALL across the state, dozens of prominent jurists will be going to bed Wednesday night as County Court judges  and waking up Thursday morning as judges of the Superior Court. This nocturnal novelty will represent the legal demise of New Jersey's 30yearold County Court system and the automatic elevation of its 116 judges to the Superior Court.

title: Tight Little Island
description: Once more to Guyana. Not to the 900 who drank their death there, but the 900 million of us who consumed the ineffable event as entertainment. Pictures in living color. Jungle prose in lush profusion. Philosophy poured out like KoolAid.

title: Immunization Notice Sent to Schools
description: AFTER a measles outbreak in Westchester last year, the County Health Department set up clinics and vaccinated more than 5,000 students who were considered susceptible to the disease. Last month, the department sent notices to all schools reminding them of the need to immunize students. Despite a state law that makes it mandatory for children entering school to be immunized, the number of children attending who have not been vaccinated against measles ranges from 12 percent in the nursery schools to 5 percent in the public schools.

title: Trends In Audio, Or, Adding Luxury to Pleasure
description: Atechnology as lively as audio just can't stand still. Almost by definition, the whole hifi movement is the pursuit of something better. And since perfection obstinately stays out of reach, there's always one more notch to go.

title: U.S. TESTING POLICY ON SOUTH AFRICANS
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Dec. 2 President Carter's meeting with Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha of South Africa this week provided a first crucial test of the Administration's sevenweekold effort to win the Pretoria Government's cooperation on the racial issues of the region by reducing official attacks on apartheid.

title: Government in Taipei Reaffirms Opposition to Talks With Peking
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 2 (UPI) President Chiang Chingkuo has said that his Government will never negotiate peace with Peking or allow Taiwan to become an independent country.

title: LETTER TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: Recently I stood on Fifth Avenue in the archways of St. Patrick's and. watched the passing parade. My eye was caught by 40 raccoons, clinging closely to one faceless mannequin, who performed a dance macabre along the pavement, closely followed by many other symbols of death, depredation and despise of nature. In about 10 minutes I counted 580 raccoons, 16 lynx, eight seals, 20 beaver, 12 coyotes, oppossums and muskrats too numerous to tally, minks galore, and thousands of other animals I couldn't identify positively.

title: Robbie Jane Horwitz Engaged
description: Robbie Jane Horwitz, an account executive with Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith in New York, and John Edward Longhi, an account executive with Paine Webber in White Plains, plan to be married in January. Their engagement has been announced by Mrs. Jack David Horwitz of Livingston, N.J., mother of the bridetobe, who is the daughter also of the late Mr. Horwitz. Mr. and Mrs. Edward John Longhi of Purchase, N.Y., are the parents of the fianc.

title: They're Taking the $ Out of Christmas
description: For those who don't believe in Santa Claus, there is now a national Alternative Santa Claus Movement. Its symbol: a skinny figure in a white beard, red cap and ratty overalls. Its slogan: Kick the Commercial Christmas Habit. Its members: mostly church people, students and activists like 22yearold Earl Pike, Coordinator of Elves in last season's Twin Cities Alternative Christmas Campaign.

title: Lawyer Weds Miss Fiedler
description: Deborah Fiedler, an associate withthe New York law firm of Debevoise, Plimpton, Lyons & Gates, was married in Christ and St. Stephen's Episcopal Church yesterday to Ned B. Stiles, a partner in Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton, New York lawyers.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE powers of the Governor's office, said be among the most farreaching in the country, are coming under a new attack. Much of the power that a New Jersey Governor has stems from the State Constitution. He appoints judges and prosecutors, and can interfere in the management of cities and counties.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: BECAUSE those who own snow throwers never know just when the machine will be needed snowstorms often arrive with little or no advance warning  the average homeowner never even thinks of doing anything with his snowthrower until the first snow actually falls. Unfortunately this all too often leads to frustration and aggravation some dark night or early morning when the machine fails to start the way it should, or stubbornly acts up in some other manner.

title: Turning O'Neill's Electra Into A TV MiniSeries
description: I am neither spiritual nor superstitious, but I've never before worked with material where I felt something like the shades o?? Eugene O'Neill lurking. I never knew whether he was laughing at or sort of enjoying our struggle.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: If I were an actor hoping to dominate the stage, I'd ask be cast as the play's utterly helpless victim, preferably strapped, chained or otherwise confined to a pillar, a rock or a chair at the center of the action, possibly with Zeus hurling thunderbolts in my direction or with a total stranger leveling a pistol at my head. It's the ideal spot from which to rule the roost.

title: Delaware Eleven Advances
description: Newark. Del., Dec. 2 (AP)  Jeff Komlo passed to Mike Mill for two touchdowns and scored once today as Delaware routed WinstonSalem. 410. in a National Collegiate Division H semifinal game. The Blue Hens face Eastern Illinois next Saturday in the final at Longview. Tex.

title: OUTBREAKS IN IRAN GROWING AS RIOTERS DEFY CURFEW ORDER
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 2  Thousant of shouting antiGovernment demonstrators spilled into the streets of Teheran three times in the last 29 hours, defying a curfew and a ban on marches. Soldier with fixed bayonets, backed by tanks anti helicopters, succeeded in dispersing the crowds. Many protesters,. some of them wrapped in white robes, were cut down by rifle and machinegun fire.

title: 143 Feared Lost as Refugee Boat Sinks off Malaysia
description: KUALA LUMPUR. Malaysia. Dec. 2 (AP)  A boat packed with refugees from Vietnam sank in rough seas today after having been denied permission to land in Malaysia, and as many as 143 were drowned, the police said. The disaster increased the number of such refugee deaths in recent weeks to more than 330.

title: Bridal Jan. 6 For Lese Orr
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth C. Lutz of New York have announced the engagement of Mrs. Lutz's daughter, Laura Elizabeth Orr, to Richard Patrick Mcllwee, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis McIlwee of Northwood, England, a London suburb.

title: Choices Opens Women's Program
description: Choices, the first studio production to be developed under the Women's Project of the American Place Theater, will run through Dec. 17, Thursdays through Sundays.

title: U.S AND EGYPT EASE OBSTACLES TO PEACE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Prime Minister Mustafa Khalil of Egypt held what were described as useful and constructive talks today, as the tempo of efforts to conclude the EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty seemed to accelerate.

title: Poll of G.O.P. Puts Ford in Lead
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford holds an edge over Ronald Reagan among Republicans as their choice for a 1980 Presidential candidate, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Will Albany Run the City University System?
description: New York is the only city in the United States that still boasts its own municipal university. Whether will still hold this distinction when classes open next fall is an open question. Last week, the Higher Education Committee of the New York State Assembly began hearings on the future of the City University. The immediate issue was what to do about the Board of Higher Education, which is scheduled selfdestruct on June 30 when its legislative mandate runs out. The real agenda, though, is who will run the third largest university system in the country.

title: Heidemarie Dittmer Is Married
description: The marriage of Heidemarie Ann Dittmer, daughter of Mrs. Anna Dittmer of West Caldwell. N.J., and Friedrich Dittmer of Brooklyn, to James Anthony Preiss, took place yesterday in the First Lutheran Church in Clifton, N.J. The Rev. Earl R. Modean performed the ceremony. The bridegroom, whose previous marriage ended in divorce, is a son of Col. Hollis James Preiss, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Preiss of Colonial Heights, Va. The bridegroom is president and chief executive officer of Preiss & Preiss Inc., an industrial realestate concern in Fairfield, NJ.

title: Cleary Smith, R.G. Thomas Plan Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip C. Smith of Rye, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Cleary Joan Smith, to Robert Glegge Thomas, son of Mrs. Robert H. Thomas of St. Petersburg, Fla., and the late Lieut. Col. Thomas, U.S.M.C. Plans have been made for a wedding next April.

title: Oil Ooze in Brooklyn Has Officials Puzzled
description: A Coast Guard helicopter on a routine patrol last Sept. 2 spotted the telltale iridescence of a large oil spill oozing into Newtown Creek, which runs between Brooklyn and Queens.

title: Cutbacks in Legal Help for County's Needy
description: WESTCHESTER Legal Services has been forced to cut back its aid to the needy because of a Federal agency's decision to remove volunteer Vista lawyers from such local programs.

title: Health
description: The world seemed to be rushing past her. She couldn't concentrate and was failing miserably at the simplest task. What happened to the time when things moved at her pace? Her body ached. Why were her hands moving so slowly? Why did her mind creak so? Frustrated by her mistakes, angry that she couldn't remember details, she finally gave up, grumbling.

title: The Battle of the L.I. Airwaves
description: RADIO stations on the Island are aiming their antenas higher and higher in a hardfought battle for local listeners. The stations are reaching out with a growing intensity to an audience they view as largely welltodo. And, as reflected in a recent survey of the suburbs conducted by The New York Times, it is an audience less dependent on New York City than ever before and more involved in its local community.

title: 34% Increase in Suburban Blacks Tied to Incomes and New Laws
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP)  The number of blacks living in the nation's suburbs increased by 34 percent from 1970 to 1977 as they took advantage of fair housing laws and rising incomes, the Census Bureau has reported.

title: The City
description: Two men armed with a rifle and a pistol burst into the lobby of the 200room Beverly Hotel early yesterday morning and shot the night manager in the head after he was apparently unable to open the hotel safe, the police said.

title: S.B. Ross to Wed Carol Fein Jan. 20
description: Carol Ann Fein and Sander B. Ross plan to be married on Jan. 20 at the Warwick Hotel. Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin H. Fein of East Meadow, L.I., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon R. Ross of Brockton, Mass.

title: ART
description: PRINCETON UNIVERSITY museums have become increasingly important in the art world in the last decade, and those at Princeton and Rutgers, among other schools in New Jersey. are no exception.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Today  MG Car Club Long Island Center 150mile T.S.D. rally; start at Howard Johnson's, Route 112 off Exit 64 of Long Island Expressway. Medford, L.I. Registration: A.M.; first car off 9:01.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: BROOKVILLE  Fine Arts Exhibition, commemorating Oyster Bay's 325th anniversery; noon to 5 P.M. weekdays; 3 to 5 P.M. Saturdays; through Dec. 15; Schwartz Memerial Library, C.W. Post Center.

title: Turbulence Over Airport...
description: THE County Board of Legislators, in voting last week to place a limit on the number of landings and takeoffs at Westcheater County Airport, appeared to have strained its relationship with its resident voice in policymaking for the countyowned facility. One member of the Airport Advisory Board asserted that the legislators had made a mockery of the very board they have created, while the sponsor of the measure attacked the advisory panel as stacked in favor of airport expansion. The developments, meanwhile,. introduced a new element of confusion into efforts to develop a new airport master plan.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: Apparently, HastingsonHudson is a community that takes art to heart. And its artists seem to return the favor. There'll be considerable excitement in the village of 10,000 this afternOon when a new, large outdoor sculpture, David, by Paul Chandler, is dedicated at 3:30 P.M. on the front lawn of Grace Episcopal Church, at the Five Conners in the heart of town.

title: Radio
description: 7:308 A.M., WABC: Message of Israel. The Problem of Loneliness.

title: Canada Waterfowl Raids Costly
description: Most American waterfowl hunters are probably aware that four of five ducks shot in this nation were born in Canada's prairie provinces, but few know that these birds are often fattened for their southward fall migration at the expense of Canadian barley and wheat farmers.

title: Medicine's Loss Is Broadway's Gain
description: A FUNNY thing happened to Paul Giovanni on his way to becoming a doctor from Atlantic City. Instead of performing surgery, he wound up performing one of the rarer feats in show business: double duty as writerdirector of one of this season's authentic Broadway successes, The Crucifer of Blood.

title: An Ordeal on Skis In Canada's Wilds
description: It began with an innocuous call from an old friend, a physics professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, asking if I would care to join him and his colleagues on a skiing expedition to the Canadian Rockies. For someone who tried his first skis in Washington Square Park, then graduated to the slopes of Central Park, became a downhill skier in the Catskills and eventually did postgraduate skiing in Vermont, an opportunity to ski deep powder high in the mountains of British Columbia was not to be missed. If we don't do it this time we never will, my friend, Francis Low, urged. With the galloping approach of senility, I had to agree. It was now or never.

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: Today's dollar buys only half what it could buy in 1967. Thus the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index last week confirmed in numbers what every Christmas shopper already knows: Inflation perseveres. And the figures for October clinched the point.

title: A Christmas Appeal: Give to The Neediest Cases Fund
description: The first hint of the T. family's problems came when Robert, a handsome 22yearold, walked into a social worker's office at the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services and, in a quiet voice, said that life at home was uncomfortable.

title: Bill Mauldin's Father Dies
description: LAS CRUCES, N.M., Dec. 2 (AP)Sidney A. Mauldin, the father of Bill Mauldin, the cartoonist, died yesterday at a nursing home in Las Cruces. He was 87 years old. Mr. Mauldin was a disabled veteran of World War I. In addition to the cartoonist, who won prominence for his work in World War II in the military newspaper, Stars and Stripes, he leaves his wife, Emily, and another son, Sidney A. Mauldin Jr.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The 10 largest banks in the United States, comprising 0.07 percent of the industry, control 29 percent of all banking assets. At the other extreme, 14,600 banks, comprising 97 percent of the industry, manage only 38 percent of the assets. The obvious conclusion drawn by many: The giant institutions exert monopoly control.

title: Dr. Charles Gordon to Wed Susan Feldman
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Susan Marian Feldman, a thirdyear student at the Cardozo School of Law at Yeshiva University, and pr. Charles Richard Gordon. a resident in pediatrics at Duke University Medical Center. The wedding is planned for Jan. 14

title: Stage Set for 3 Major League Divisions; Carew, Lee Trades Expected at Meeting
description: After a record summer on the field, professional baseball will turn indoors tomorrow for its winter business meetings. And, before the week ends, the Boston Red Sox are expected to trade Bill Lee, the Minnesota Twins may trade Rod Carew, and a formal plan will be offered to restructure the major leagues into three divisions apiece.

title: Angels Are Integrated In Christmas Display
description: YAKIMA, Wash., Dec. 2 (AP) Yakima's affirmative action program protects Christmas angels of all colors.

title: Guyana Leader Terms Cultists American Problem
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 2Prime Minister Forbes Burnham said today that Guyana would like to close the chapter of the People's Temple sect as soon as possible and that he wanted surviving members of the group who are not needed as witnesses in criminal cases to go back where they are a United States problem.

title: MUSIC
description: LOVERS of choral music, take heart. Christmas brings with it the annual outpouring of music from massed voices. There will be more details next Sunday, but meanwhilewe can already start this afterneon with the holiday conceits of the Greenwich Choral Society.

title: 70 Are Hurt, Including 62 Officers, As Hasidim Storm a Police Station
description: Hundreds of angry Hasidic Jews, outraged over the fatal stabbing of an elderly Jewish man in a predawn street robbery and demanding greater police protection, besieged and briefly took over a police station house in Brooklyn yesterday. They were ejected in a bloody, 30minute melee of screams, punches, swinging clubs and hurtling rocks.

title: 6 GUYANA SURVIVORS ARRIVE AT KENNEDY
description: Six members of the People's Temple arrived at Kennedy Airport last night in the second group of survivors returning to the United States after the cult deaths in Guyana.

title: FILM VIEW
description: The films haven't been great this season but there have been a number of performances that have . made them seem worthwhile in this something less than best of all possible worlds. I'm thinking of what is virtually a brandnew Ingrid Bergman in Ingmar Bergman's handsome though patchy exercise in familial selfanalysis, Autumn Sonata; Laurence Olivier as the Nazihunter in Franklin J. Schaffner's The Boys from Brazil; Bette Davis, Peter Ustinov and their travelling companions in Death on the Nile; Richard Farnsworth's small but very affecting performance in Comes A Horseman, which is billed as a Western but looks like a documentary on the weather; George C. Scott, Trish Van Devere and a group of newtomovies actors in Stanley Donen's Movie Movie, and Isabelle Huppert as the beautiful, mysterious teenager with armored emotions in Claude Chabrol's Violette.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Around the Nation
description: About 400 demonstrators gathered yesterday at the Civic Plaza in Albuquerque, N.M., for a rally against nuclear wastes.

title: Engagements
description: PECKMAURO

title: POLITICKING BEGINS FOR SAN FRANCISCO
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2  The murder of Mayor George R. Moscone, who had forged a coalition of minorities and activists to win office and then solidified his position with appointments and programs that won the admiration of his critics, has dramatically altered local politics.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Little Leagues Help Children to Function
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Rangers Bow by 52; Islanders 52 Victors
description: TORONTO, Dec. 2  The Rangers hoped to break a club record tonight against the Toronto Maple Leafs, but all they ended up breaking were a few sticks in a frustrating 52 loss, the first in their last eight road games.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: BECAUSE those who own snowthrowers never know just when the machine will be needed  snowstorms often arrive with little or no advance warning  the average homeowner never even thinks of doing anything with his snowthrower until the first snow actually falls. Unfortunately, this all too often leads to frustration and aggravation some dark night or early morning when the machine fails to start the way it should, or stubbornly acts up in some other manner.

title: PLACES
description: Nobody knows the Greek islands like Lawrence Durrell. He fled from them in 1940 when the Nazis came. He wrote memorably about them in. Bitter Lemons(1943) and in Prospero's Cell(1945). Even more than the Alexandria that made him famous when he used it as the setting for his famous trilogy of of novels, the whitewashed, beetling Greek islands can inspire Mr. Durrell to feats of metaphor and loquacity. Patmos, he writes in this personal but thoroughly researched tour of all the major islands (except politically embroiled Cyprus) lies like a tortoise in a spatter of atolls. Mykonos, overrun by tourists since Durrell first strolled there, is a flaring nightmare of whiteness, and still worth visiting. Its colonnades and curling streets, with their. kennellike houses, sprouting extravagant balconies of tottering painted wood, lead on and on, turning slowly inward upon themselves to form labyrinths, hazingin all sense direction until one surrenders to the knowledge that one is irremediably lost in a village hardly bigger than Hampstead.

title: Fishing
description: FISHING along the New Jersey coast is in a state of flux, for this is the time of year when summer fish are heading for warmer waters and winter fish move in toward shore.

title: Transportation Unit Studies Rule On RadioactiveShipment Routes
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP)  The Transportation Department has said that it will decide early next year whether to issue more stringent rules for the routing of truck shipments of radioactive materials.

title: $3.6 Million Subway Loss Alleged
description: Past failure to open subwayconcession contracts to competitive bidding has cost the New York City Transit Authority $3.6 million a year. an audit by Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin declared yesterday..

title: Deaths
description: CANTWELLHelen V., of Tuckahoe, N.Y., on December 3, 1978. Dear sister of Mildred J. Cantwell, Gertrude Collins. Muriel Larkin and Edward Cantwell. The family will be present at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, N.Y., between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM Monday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Tuesday, December 5 at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Heart Fund.

title: Syracuse Five in High Gear
description: The Syracuse players thought and talked about basketball since the overtime loss to Western Kentucky last March in the opening round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. Now the concentration is apparently paying off. The Orangemen won their Carrier Tournament Saturday night by defeating highlyregarded Iona, 8976, and are undefeated in four games.

title: Bronx Facing Political Battle
description: The struggle for the Bronx borough presidency, with its racial and ethnic overtones, is a complex and potentially bitter one. And politicians on both sides agree that the struggle, is providing a classic example of what happens when black and Hispanic people, who now constitute a majority of the population in the Bronx, do not constitute a voting majority. Even if a black or Hispanic candidate were elected next month for an interim term by the Bronx delegation on the City Council because of the prodding of Mayor Koch and minority leaders, there is no guarantee that the minority politician could win nomination for a twoyear term in next year's Democratic primary. For in that primary, white voters will almost certainly outnumber black and Hispanic ones.

title: Jets Win, 2416; Two for Walker
description: While celebrating the 10th anniversary of their Super Bowl III victory over Baltimore at Shea Stadium yesterday, the New York Jets celebrated their eighth victory of this season with a 2416 decision over the Colts before a crowd of 50.248 at Shea Stadium.

title: Deaths
description: Anderson, Anna

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: China has decided to permit its companies to open offices Japan, as well as to allow Japanese companies to open in Peking and to engage in joint ventures with the Chinese. It is also studying whether to accept economic aid in the form of lowcost loans. [Page A1.]

title: State and City Bond Push
description: With taxexempt yields near the peaks they reached last summer, a hefty volume of more than $1 billion of new state and city bond issues is scheduled for sale this week. The corporate boiid market faces a light $225 million of new fixedincome financing.

title: Spain Set for Constitution Vote
description: MADRID, Dec. 3 (Reuters)  Specially mobilized troops guarded communication centers and other strategic installations today to prevent possible sabotage as Spain prepared for Wednesday's referendum on a new constitution. The constitution would guarantee basic human rights, define Spain as a parliamentary monarchy and allow considerable selfrule for the country's regions.

title: Sports Today
description: FOOTBALL

title: LRC Unit Buys H.C. Cook
description: LRC North America Inc. announced that it had acquired the B.C. Cook Company, the Lighter Corporation of America and Lighter's affiliated companies. The purchase price was not disclosed.

title: Sheila Ginsberg Married To Daniel Riesel, Lawyer
description: Sheila M. Ginsberg, daughter of Jacob Ginsberg of Goshen, N.Y., and the late Augusta Ginsberg, was married yesterday morning to Daniel Riesel. son of Marie V. Riesel of Croton, N.Y., and the late Nathan Riesel. Rabbi Mark Angel performed the ceremony at the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue in Manhattan.

title: Bronx Boy Found Shot in Throat
description: An 11yearold Bronx boy was found shot in the throat last night, according to the police, who could give no immediate explanation for the shooting. They said the boy, whose name and address were withheld, was found shortly after 7 P.M. in the hallway of 3604 Bronx Boulevard in the Williamsbridge section. He was taken to Misericordia Hospital, where he was reported in serious condition.

title: EXAIDE MAY KNOW OF TEMPLE MILLIONS
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 1 The key to the People's Temple's hoard of millions of dollars in foreign bank accounts  and to a reputed contingency plan with the potential for more murders and suicides by cult members  may be held by a former mistress of the Rev. Jim Jones who left Guyana shortly before the mass deaths Isst month.

title: Whippet Is Best
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 3  A seek, elegant whippet, Ch. Sporting Fields Clansman, owned by Mr. and Mrs. James Butt and their 17yearold daughter. Dionne, tonight led a field of 3,127 dogs in Convention Hall at the Boardwalk Kennel Club's 12th annual extravaganza.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: FUKUOKA, Japan, Dec. 3 (AP) Toshihiko Seko, a littleknown Japanese collegian, captured the Fukuoka international marathon today, thus thwarting Bill Rodgers's bid to become the first triplecrown winner in marathon history.

title: Potato Harvest for Russians Is Time of Toil and Trouble
description: MOSCOW. Dec. 3  Where potatoes are concerned. Soviet farmers may sow but they do not reap.

title: A File Check Led to Slaying Suspects
description: Routine police work by a task force of 35 detectivesmany working around the clock  led the police to the capture of a 20yearold man and three youths in connection with the murder of Irving Sussmah as he made his way home from a synagogue in Brooklyn's Borough Park section Friday evening. A fifth youth is being sought.

title: Around the Nation
description: ANCHORAGE, Dec 3 (Reuter)  When President Carter turned almost onesixth of Alaska into national parks and wildlife reserves last week, the reaction on the other side of the continent was immediate, varied and, above all, intense.

title: Convict Seeking a New Trial In 1970 Killing of Policeman
description: On a mild. May evening in 1970, a 23yearold offduty rookie policeman, Miguel Sirvent, stopped at a Brooklyn drivein restaurant for hamburgers. Moments later, with his wife looking on from a distance, he was shot in the heart when he tried to stop a holdup inside the restaurant.

title: Rockland County Board of Health Facing Opposition on Fluoridation
description: NEW CITY, N.Y., Dec. 2  Fluoridation of the local water supply to reduce tooth decay in children a measure that has stirred turmoil in many communities  has suddenly erupted into a major public issue in Rockland County.

title: The City
description: An increased undercover police force that has started patrolling the Port Authority Bus Terminal in midtown made six arrests early yesterday, including one for attempted armed robbery in a men's room, according an authority spokesman.

title: Kissinger, During Trip To West Berlin, Tells OF Fears Over Dtente
description: WEST BERLIN, Dec. 3 In a series of public appearances in this outpost city during the weekend, Henry A. Kissinger voiced concern about the future of detente unless the West strengthened its position and checked Soviet military intervention in the world.

title: A Giants Fan Is Burned Up
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 3  While thousands of fans showed their tickets and got in to see the Giants lose to the Los Angeles Rams today, Ron Freiman of Livingston, N.J., stood outside Giants Stadium and put a match to about 100 tickets in a demonstration of his dissatisfaction with the way the team is managed.

title: Slaying Victim Sought More Police for Section
description: Almost exactly a year before he was slain on a Brooklyn street early Saturday morning, Irving Sussman wrote a letter to a neighborhood synagogue urging that the congregation pressure then Mayorelect Koch for more police protection for what he called the deteriorating, Borough Park neighborhood.

title: Music: Ray Charles's American Program
description: NOW we're going to play what we call some true American music, Ray Charles declared during his concert Saturday night at Carnegie Hall. The announcement was hardly necessary. More than any other performer since World War II, Mr. Charles incarnates American popular music.

title: Legislators Under Pay Pressure
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  The Carter Administration, opening a new front in its wage and price stabilization campaign, said today that it would rely on statesmanship and informed public opinion to reduce hefty pay increases that some state and local governments have voted for themselves.

title: Memo Links 3 Senators to Plan to Acquire DairyIndustry Donations
description: The Washington Star

title: De Gustibus
description: When a reader wrote to inquire about vanilla sugar and where it might be purchased, I noted that the vanilla sugar used in my kitchen was homemade. It was stated that,vanilla beans were considered by kitchen purists to be superior by far to vanilla extract when making vanilla custards, eggs  la neige and so on. It was added that once a vanilla bean is used, it can be rinsed off, patted dry and then packed in a jar surrounded by granulated sugar. The result is vanilla sugar.

title: Music: Debut Of Waverly Waits Group
description: THE Waverly Consort has been probably our most prominently active earlymusic ensemble in recent years, and Saturday night the group introduced an extension of itself called the Waverly Waits, in its debut performance at Alice Tully Hall.

title: CAREY IS REPORTED IN MOVE TO UNSEAT CITY U. CHANCELLOR
description: Governor Carey has told Albany legislators that Dr. Robert J. Kibbee should be replaced as chancellor of the City University of New York because it is time for a change at the top of the 18unit university system.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: One day last June my eye was caught by a headline on Page 1 of The Times of London. Vasectomies for Coypu Suggested, it said.

title: Christian Party's Candidate Takes Lead in Venezuela
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 3  A large turnout was reported here today as one of Latin America's few democracies voted to elect a new President from a crowded field of candidates ranging from a former guerrilla to a supporter of an ousted rightwing dictator.

title: The Engineering of Deceit
description: If the Army Corps of Engineers tries to sell you a new Brooklyn Bridge, better swim. F.D.R.'s former Secretary of the Interior, Harold Ickes, used to rage against the trickery by which the Corps justified its projects. No more lawless or irresponsible Federal group, he fumed, has ever attempted to operate in the United States, either outside of or within the law. We raise that unpleasant memory because the Corps again stands accused of deception, this time in the promotion of the most extensive project it has ever devised  the TennesseeTombigbee Waterway through Alabama and Mississippi.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HIGH AND BRIGHT It's that time again  treelighting time beside the Rockefeller Center skating rink, in the lower plaza off Fifth Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets.

title: TV: Joey and Redhawk, a Miniseries for Young People on CBS
description: CBS is not quite sure how to compose its publicity fanfare for Joey and Redhawk. which begins a run of five consecutive days this afternoon at 4.

title: Deaths
description: GOLDENBERGAnn. Beloved wife of irving. Loving mother of Stephen and Marjorie Mayer. Cherished grandmother of Lisa, Russell, Jon. Tracey, Benjamin and Miriam. Dear sister of Doris Hochman, Gertrude Levy. Sylvia Lerner, Sam and Harry Bresiauer. Services today 11:30 at I.J. Morris. Inc. 1895 Flatbush Avenue (1 block north of Kings Hwy), Bklyn NY.

title: Women, Pornography, Free Speech: A Fierce Debate at N.Y.U.
description: Feminists and civil Iibertarians and some people who said they were both  gathered at the New York University School of Law Saturday to tackle an issue that has been simmering in the women's movement for the last few years: Obscenity Degradation of Women Versus Right of Free speech.

title: Hanoi Reports Creation of Front Seeking to Oust Cambodia Regime
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 3  The Hanoi radio announced this evening the formation of a Kampuchean United Front for National Salvation in what it termed the liberated zone of Cambodia and reported that the front had Called on the entire people of Cambodia to rise up for the struggle to overthrow the Pol Pot and Ieng Sary clique.

title: South Africa Promises a Decision This Month on U.N. Plan for Namibia
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 3 South Africa, under pressure to accept the United Nations independence plan for SouthWest Africa, has replied equivocally, saying that it will make a final decision by the end of this month. It has also pledged it will not use the internal elections beginning tomorrow to install a government in the mineralrich territory.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The credit markets brightened last Friday. causing bond prices to rise and interest rates to decline sharply for the first time since the day before Thanksgiving, but many money market analysts were skeptical about whether the trend would last long.

title: Somoza Crisis: Shock Waves
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Nov. 27  The shock waves from Nicaragua's deepening political crisis are buffeting all of Central America, encouraging guerrilla and popular movements to step up their own campaighs for change and provoking clampdowns by neighboring military regimes that fear unrest may spread.

title: Segal to Head New Committee To Resurrect Arts Celebration
description: A NEW start for a postponed International Celebration of the Arts, to be held in New York, was announced yesterday with the appointment by Mayor Koch of a 12member planning committee, headed by Martin E. Segal, to bring the project to reality.

title: Hinkle, Miss Bradley Triumph in Playoff
description: LARGO, Fla., Dec. 3  It was a strenuous struggle most of the way, but Lon Hinkle and Pat Bradley stood off rousing threestraightbirdies finish today by Mike Hill and Vivian Brownlee and then beat them on the first hole of a playoff to win the. third annual Mixed Team Championship.

title: Notes on People
description: For a while over the weekend, the top two members of the Nixon Administration were again under one roof, albeit a roof that rented by the night. Former President Richard M. Nixon and former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew were both staying in New York City at the WaldorfAstoria, but unexpected proximity did not alter the personal distance they have maintained since their hasty departures from government. Mr. Agnew, in town on unspecified business, said he had no intention of seeing his former boss.

title: Meadowlands Aide Takes Helm and Peers Ahead
description: SECAUCUS, N.J Dec. 1 A bright bouquet of the daisies and yellow moms and a lush green plant graced the dent of Patricia Sheehan today as she arrived for her first day as executive direce tor of the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission.

title: Dividends
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: MahaffeyNorth Take Cup Golf
description: PRINCEVILLE, Hawaii, Dec. 3 (AP)  John Mahaffey won the individual title today and led his partner, Andy North, to the team championship in the final round of the 26th World Cup golf tournament.

title: 382 Million Trips Taken in 1977
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP)  Americans took 382.6 million trips to destinations in the United States in 1977, half of which involved interstate travel, the Census Bureau has found. The bureau said that its national traffic survey showed the most common destination of travelers was California, although only about 20 percent of trips to destinations in California originated in other states.

title: Rangers Checked By Bruins
description: The flashier, faster, slicker and more exciting Rangers played the stoddy, plodding, heavyhanded Boston Bruins last night at Madison Square Garden. The flashier team lost, 32.

title: World News Briefs
description: PEKING, Dec. 3 (Reuters) A poster calling for a public trial of China's disgraced radicals drew large crowds here today.

title: Music: RosenSanders Recital Is First in New Concert Hall
description: NEW YORK has long needed a truly intimate concert hall one that seats between 950 and 500 people  for solo recitals and chamber music. Carnegie Recital Hall has long served that purpose for debuts and musical events on a small scale. For all its popularity, however, that auditorium is an acoustical horror, especially for the inexperienced young performers who use it most and who often find it difficult to adjust to its harsh, clangorous resonance.

title: G. & W. Bid For Simmons
description: Gulf and Western Industries said that its offer to purchase, at $19 cash a share, any and all common shares of the Simmons Company would be extended to Dec. 15. The offer to buy Simmons common stock started on Oct. 24 and was scheduled to expire last Friday. Simmons makes bedding equipment and furniture.

title: Bombed Village In Egypt Views Peace Uneasily
description: BAHR ELBAKR, Egypt  A lilting chorus of children's voices recited over and over the morning's lesson written in Arabic on the blackboard: The bell rang. Dingaling. The pupils ran to the classroom. Ahmed looked and said, This is a Den.

title: Guards Continue  Job Action
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3 (UPI)  Security guards at 43 city public housing projects continued their job action today, forcing the city police to supplement patrols around the projects. Robert Alotta, a spokesman for the Philadelphia Housing Authority, said that 25 of 26 guards scheduled to work had called in sick. No serious incidents were reported.

title: Israeli Bus War Jams Road Traffic in 2 Cities
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 3  A bus war between rival, cooperatives tied up the twin cities of Holon and Bat Yam south of here today in a traffic jam that left tens of thousands of passengers and motorists stranded in heavy rain for hours.

title: Carter May Seek Again to Curb Jobs Preference Given Veterans
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  The Carter Administration is considering renewing its uphill fight for legislation curtailing the preference given military veterans in Civil Service hiring and job security.

title: Weapon That Fights Missiles Could Alter World Defense Focus
description: Missiledestroying ray weapons, the development of which could upset the world balance of power and revolutionize the art of war, have become the subject of an intense debate that is rapidly gaining momentum among key American Government officials and scientists.

title: Nets Defeat Lakers On 101 Final Surge
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3 (AP) George Johnson's slam dunk at the buzzer tonight gave the New Jersey Nets a 107105 National Basketball Association victory over the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: Jazz: Surprises From Burrell And Jackson
description: ONE of the important fuctions the New Jazz at the Public Theater concert series can serve, or so it seems to this observer, is the presentation of accomplished musicians in unexpected contexts. One learns to expect certain things from certain musicians, especially when these musicians are working as side artists. On their own, they can be surprising, and surprise is something a series of new jazz concerts should concern itself with.

title: Bolger Warns Postal Employees Of Threats to Future of Service
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP)  Postmaster General William F. Bolger says the future of the Postal Service is being challenged and postal workers must draw together to provide good service to the public.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249, or to any of the following organizations:

title: For JapaneseAmericans, Erosion
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md.Within one short generation, JapaneseAmericans have moved from secondclass citizenship to enviable socioeconomic success.

title: Opera: 3 OneActers at Hunter
description: THE American Opera Gala presented by the National Federation of Music Clubs at Hunter College Saturday afternoon consisted of New York premieres of oneact operas by Joyce Barthelson. Margaret Garwood and Julia Smith. The performances, if hardly lavish, were lively enough, and the music, if sometimes quaint, was rarely less than entertaining.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Two apparently unassailable records are Joe DiMaggio's 56game hitting streak in 1941 and Bob Beamon's incredible long jump of 8.90 meters (29 feet 2 inches) in the 1968 Olympics in Mexico City. Do you think those records will ever be broken?

title: Oil Imports Climb Again, Adding to Trade Deficit
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  Imports of oil into the United States have begun to creep up over the last several months after a steady slide that lasted for more than a year, according to the latest Government reports.

title: Spacecraft Is Set to Survey Venus
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Dec. 3 Pioneer Venus I neared the end of its 300millionmile journey from earth tonight and was set to swing into orbit of the mysterious cloudcovered Venus tomorrow.

title: Tarkenton Keeps Vikings in Tie
description: One of the few National Football League passing records that had eluded Fran Tarkenton fell to the Minnesota's ace quarterback yesterday as he tossed four touchdown passes, the last with 1 minute 49 seconds to play, as he guided the Vikings over the Philadelphia Eagles, 2827, at Bloomington, Minn.

title: Trustees of Reform Jewish Group Vote to Seek Religious Converts
description: The trustees of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, the congregational arm of reform Judaism, unanimously approved a program yesterday to encourage nonJewish spouses in a mixed marriage and other unchurched Americans to convert to Judaism.

title: Dance and Music Series Set for Flushing Meadow
description: Performances by the Joffrey II Ballet and the Tokyo String Quartet will on a new, limited subscription series at the Queens Theater in the Park in Flushing MeadowCorona Park early next month.

title: Indoor Tennis Suffers a Decline After Big Boom
description: THE indoor boom that made tennis a yearround sport and attracted millions of new players has subsided after a 10year run. A general reduction of play has occurred in the metropolitan area, where the largest number of clubs in the country is centered. Once, it was almost impossible to rent a court in prime time evening hours. Now there are many such openings.

title: Alexandra Klebnikov, Descendant Of an Admiral in Imperial Russia
description: Alexandra Klebnikov, granddaughter of Arkady Nebolsine, an admiral of the Imperial Russian Navy, died Saturday at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital after a long illness. She was 49 years old and lived at 12 East 97th Street.

title: A Convert to Teachings of the Quakers
description: Lisa Layton, partly under the influence of her mother, also became a Quaker and plunged even more deeply into the faith than her husband. Relatives suggest two reasons for her zeal: a contempt for warfare and violence rooted in the trauma of her brush with Nazism, and a contempt for affluence rooted in the lesson of her childhood that wealth did not assure happiness.

title: The Sky's The Limit
description: NOW that Sparky Lyle is gone the Yankees are left without a spare premiere relief pitcher, but as best I can figure it, counting standbys, they still have two managers, two fleet center fielders, two famous young second basemen, at least two stars who want be the straw that stirs the drink, two hot young Italian former Texas Ranger pitching prospects (Dave Righetti and Paul Mirabella) and almost a full battalion of aging famous pitchers with interesting arm histories.

title: Nongogo, a Drama
description: ATHOL FUGARD's plays about the knifeedge life of blacks and coloreds in South Africa furnish some of the strongest and most moving stage literature being written in the English language.

title: Deaths
description: FORSTERGreta (nee Voelcker), of Beyville, LI on Dec 2. 1978, wife of The late Herbert W., dear mother of Virginia Joyce and Claire Latham and grandmother of Barbara, also survived by two sisters Elsa Voelcker and Hildegarde Hardy and one brother Emil Vcelcker. Religious services Wed. 11AM at Raynor and D'Andrea Funeral Home, West Sayville, LI. Visiting Tuesday, 2 to 4 and 7 to 9PM. Interment private.

title: Japanese Are Buying Art Worth $4 Million
description: TOKYO (Reuters)  The Japanese Government has announced that it is buy ing works of art worth 59 million, including paintings by Henri Rousseau, Pabl?? Picasso and Henri Matisse.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Chess:
description: The Soviet team had an easy time winning the women's division of the World Chess Olympiad in Buenos Aires.

title: City College Wins
description: City College overcame a strong secCedhalf surge by Lehman College yesterday to defeat the Lancers, 7258, at the victors' gym.

title: Events
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, Verdi's Luise Miller, 8.

title: Dollar's Gains Stir Joy, But Risks Lie in Future
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  American officials are cockahoop over the first month's experience in the campaign to prop up the dollar. But their ebullience is tinged with concern about some future risks, including oil pricing, accelerating American inflation and moves to integrate European currencies.

title: Fiedler Released From Hospital
description: BOSTON, Dec. 3 (AP)  Arthur Fiedler, the conductor of the Boston Pops orchestra, was discharged today from TuftsNew England Medical Center, where he had been hospitalized several days for treatment of exhaustion. Hospital officials would not disclose details of the 83yearold conductor's condition.

title: 18 CULT SURVIVORS BARRED BY AIRLINE
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 3  In what was explained as a safety precaution, 18 men from the People's Temple, including four members of the Rev. Jim Jones's security force, were barred from boarding a Pan American World Airways flight to New York today because the group was not escorted by armed American officials, as the airline said it had been promised.

title: Family Not Notified of Mother's Death
description: Last week, almost seven months after her escape, Deborah still seemed slightly amazed that her mother had agreed not to report this infraction. She said that Mr. Jones usually got family members to spy on one another. and that when she offered her mother the wine, she said she would not hold it against her mother if she turned her in for violating the rules.

title: Sports World Specials
description: When a 220yard indoor track at Harvard University was being planned in 1976, Bill McCurdy, the coach, sought out the assistance of Thomas A. McMahan and Peter Greene in its design. McMahon is Gordon McKay Professor of Applied Mechanics at Harvard, and Greene is a postdoctoral fellow working with McMahon on biomechanical problems.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American, Home Products Corporation has elected to its board of directors Edwin A. Gee, president of the International Paper Company.

title: CORRECTION
description: A column in SportsMonday on Nov. 13 said that The Boston Globe, in reporting Carl Yastrzemski's support for Edward J. King in the Massachusetts gubernatorial election, had not mentioned that Mr. King had previously given Mr. Yastrzemski's father a job with the Massachusetts Port Authority. Actually the Globe article did contain this information.

title: Miss Bellamy and Council Engage in War of Words
description: Open warfare is on the verge of breaking out between the members of the City Council and the Council President, Carol Bellamy. She has angered the legislators by, among other things, gaveling meetings to order on time and calling the roll. The Council members complain that she treats them like schoolchildren.

title: 1980 Budget Faces Tight Restrictions
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  In shaping President Carter's 1980 budget, to be submitted to Congress in just seven weeks, Administration planners and economists are being forced to walk a tightrope.

title: Peking to Let Chinese Businesses Open Offices in Japan Next Year
description: TOKYO, Dec. 3  In a decision described as having great significance for China's economic relations with Japan in particular and with the West in general, Peking has widened its ties to the outside world with a move to allow Chinese companies to open offices In Tokyo, high Japanese officials said over the weekend.

title: Redlining Foe Opposes Albany Plan
description: The director of the New York Public Interest Research Group warned yesterday that acceptance of a State Senate version of a proposal to raise the limit on ho emortgage interest rates would represent a total cavein by Democrats trying to halt the practice of redlining by banks in New York State.

title: Top Ohio Legislators Defend Big Pay Raises After Sharp Criticism
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 3  The large pay increases enacted for most statewide office holders in Ohio were defended by legislative leaders here this weekend amid sharp criticism and an announcement yesterday by President Carter's chief inflation fighter, Alfred E. Kahn, that the increases would be investigated.

title: Investors List Brokerage Woes
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  Gentlemen: I want to express my utmost indignation at the practices of one of the large, reputable brokerage houses, one handwritten letter began.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: The word is that you are in line for the S.E.C, Dallas's Brian Smith was asked. Are you interested?

title: ExParr Village Seeking a New Image
description: YAPHANK. L.I., Dec. 2  The complei of attractive, twostory condominiums just west of the William Floyd Parkway here used to be called Parr Village, a name that indicated its shared identity with the quarterhorse race track nearby and with its ambitious builder, Ronald J. Parr, who expected to construct a new planned community complete with shopping center and hospital.

title: Sterling W. Fisher at 79; Reader's Digest Official
description: Sterling Wesley Fisher, a journalist whose career encompassed newspapers. broadcasting and magazine work, died Friday at his home in Santa Monica, Calif., from complications following a stroke. Mr. Fisher, who was mayor of Tarrytown, N.Y., from 1947 to 1949, was 79 years old.

title: U.S. Wins Federation Cup
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 3 (AP)  he United States became the first nation to win the Federation Cup in three successive years when it rallied to beat the host nation, Australia, by, 21 behind the doubles victory of Chris Evert and Billie Jean King in the decisive match today.

title: Rains Flood Much of Singapore
description: SINGAPORE, Dec. 3 (Reuters)  Hundreds of people were evacuated from their homes today as Singapore suffered one of its worst monsoon floods for many years. Several parts of the island state were under water that in some places rose as high as 4 feet.

title: U.S. Ability to Mobilize By a Draft Is Questioned
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP)  The Selective Service System is incapable of mobilizing enough recruits to meet Pentagon needs in time of a crisis, according to a Congressional report.

title: Susan J. Holleb Is Wed
description: Susan J. Bolleb, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur I. Holleb of Larchmont. N.Y., was married yesterday to Rand Warren Stoll, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Stoll of New York and Amagansett, L.I. Rabbi Martin J. Zion performed the ceremony at the Explorers Club in New York.

title: Executive of U.S. Church Council Calls Trip to Guyana Foolhardy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UPI)  An executive of the National Council of Churches said that Representative Leo J. Ryan's trip to Jonestown, Guyana, was foolhardy just very dangerous.

title: Ryan Aide Cites Lack of Warning on Guyana Danger
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 3  Representative Leo J. Ryan's legislative counsel. who was critically wounded in the Guyana shooting that cost the Congressman his life, said today that the State Department had never warned the Ryan party of any danger of violence in its missign to Guyana.

title: Poor People Migrating to South In Reversal of a Historic Pattern
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  For the first time since the exodus of the poor from the rural South began more than half a century ago, more poor people have been entering than leaving in the last couple of years, according to a new analysis of migration patterns by the Census Bureau.

title: Frederic Gorog, 88, Led Hungarian Jews' Group
description: Frederic Gorog, a lawyer associated with the securitiesbrokerage firm of Loeb Rhoades, Hornblower & Company and the founder of the World Federation of Jews of Hungarian Descent, died Saturday at his home at 160 East 84th Street. He was 88 years old.

title: Schultze Would Prefer Strikes to Steep Wages
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UPI)  President Carter's chief economic adviser said today that, in general, he would rather see businesses accept strikes than grant inflationary pay increases to labor unions.

title: Susan R. Denburg, Lawyer. Married to Paul Brian Yellin
description: Susan Roberta Denburg and Paul Brian Yellin, both of New York. were married at noon yesterday at the Old Westbury (L.I.) Hebrew Congregation by Rabbi Albert Thaler.

title: Theater: Winning, a Comedy
description: SEEING Winning Isn't Everything. which opened last night at the Hudson Guild, one can readily understand why this Off Off Broadway company wanted George Abbott to direct the play. This is the sort of breakneck comedy that Mr. Abbott has been closely associated with throughout his 65year career  as director, playwright and play doctor.

title: Washington Watch
description: IMPORTANT Internal Revenue Service public hearings are scheduled this week on the agency's efforts to lift the tax exemption from private schools that pursue discriminatory admission policies. The I.R.S. already has some rules on its books denying a tax exemption to such schools, a move that was aimed principally at segregationist academies in the South.

title: Market Place
description: BY now holders of Carrier Corporation shares will have decided a difficult question: whether or not to tender their shares to United Technologies under an offer expiring at 10 o'clock this morning.

title: Guerrillas Set Fire to a Computer In Rome Transport Center Attack
description: ROME. Dec. 3 (Reuters)  Urban guerrillas set fire to the main computer in a Ministry of Transport registration center in Rome today causing damage estimated at millions of dollars. the police said.

title: 10Kilometer Race Won by Rodriguez
description: Only my hands got cold, said Victor Rodriguez, a slender Westinghouse Vocational High School senior, after he had won the open division 10kilometer crosscountry race over Van Cortlandt Park's frozen turf yesterday.

title: McEnroe Enlivens Davis Cup Interest
description: There will be national television, a major sponsor and even a touch of history. John McEnroe will make his singles debut for the United States, and John Lloyd will play for Britain while his close friend Chris Evert ponders love of country or man.

title: Rossman's Aim: Bigger Paydays
description: MIKE ROSSMAN, half the lightheavyweight boxing champions of the world, will earn $100,000 tomorrow night for fighting Aldo Traversaro, the European champion, who has a sign on his bedroom wall in Italy reading, Quiet, sleeping!

title: NEEDIEST CASES GAIN FUNDS FROM ESTATES
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund started its 67th annual appeal yesterday with $473,727.40 already donated by estates, trust funds and individual contributors.

title: Israeli Cabinet Postpones Decision On Resuming Its Talks With Egypt
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 3  The Israeli Government discussed at length today the impasse with Egypt over peace efforts, but made no decision on whether the stalled treaty negotiations should be resumed.

title: Bridge:
description: Bridge is a game of disappointments. You are let down in turn by the cards, your partner, your opponents and even yourself.

title: Federated Dividend Raised
description: The indicated annual dividend rate for Federated Department Stores Inc. was increased Friday from $1.60 a share to $1.70 when directors of the chain increased the quarterly dividend to 42 cents a share from 40 cents. The dividend is payable Jan. 26 to shareholders of record Jan. 10.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: SOUTH AFRICA TRIES 11 IN SOWETO RIOTS
description: JOHANNESBURG. Dec. 3  For the last two months, a small suburban courtroom more accustomed to trafficviolation hearings has been the scene of one of the most important political trials in recent South African history: the case of the state versus the Soweto 11.

title: Still Praising Sect, 10 Reach U.S.
description: Ten more survivors of the People's Temple deaths in Guyana, including seven women released yesterday from the cult's Lamaha Gardens headquarters in Georgetown, the Guyanese capital, arrived at Kennedy International Airport last night.

title: New York Weekend: Cocoon Shed, Fancy Flies
description: If you can put down your Saturday morning newspaper and your fourth cup of coffee and listen, you can hear New York take on a new cadence on weekends. It is still as fastmoving, the dress is nearly as formal, the weather is as cold or as hot, but something has changed.

title: Yanks, Phils to Talk
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 3 The Philadelphia Phillies, who apparently have lost Pete Rose, their most wanted man, could wind up doing business with one or both New York teams at the baseball winter meetings, which get under way tomorrow.

title: Veterans of Radio Create New Series
description: The men of the future, the near and alreadycontracted future, in radio are such as Henry Morgan, Fletcher Markle, Norman Corwin and Arch Oboler, all of them talents out of the past and returning to write scripts for a new daily feature, Sears Radio Theater.

title: AMF Faces the Guidelines
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 3  The morning after President Carter outlined his program of wage and price guidelines. W. Thomas York, the chairman of AMF Inc., sent a telegram to the managers of each of AMF's 25 domestic divisions and subsidiaries saying, I expect each of you to plan now to help the corporation and the nation achieve the antiinflation goals established by the President.

title: 3Day Nova Convention Ends at the Entermedia
description: THE Nova Convention, three days and nights of readings, panel discussions, film showings and various sorts of performances that sought to grapple with some of the implications of the writing of William S. Burroughs, concluded Saturday night with a program at the Entermedia Theater. Actually, the convention was not entirely over; there was a midnight concert featuring Robert Fripp, Biondie, and other rock performers. But it was over for Mr. Burroughs and his inner circle, who all went immediately to a private party.

title: TEHERAN IS CALMER BUT SOLDIERS SHOOT INTO CROWDS AGAIN
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 3  Heavily armed troops fired on antiGovernment protesters in at least a halfdozen incidents this morning and afternoon, but it was the calmest period in this capital since violence broke out on Friday night with the beginning of Moharram. the Shiite Moslem month of mourning.

title: Authorities Investigate People's Temple Amid Former Members' Fear of Hit Squads
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3  Investigation of the People's Temple are being carried out in a haze of veranda fed by allegations of hit squaft organized by the Rev. Jim Jones to deal with his enemies after his death.

title: A Threat to the St. Lawrence
description: ALEXANDRIA BAY, N.Y.Americans and Canadians are in danger of losing one of their most beautiful tourist attractions  the scenic St. Lawrence River, which flows 1,200 miles from the Great Lakes to the Atlantic and contains the famous Thousands Islands, a region matched in beauty only by the Norwegian fjrds.

title: Hard Passage in Southern Africa
description: Charts of the shores of SouthWest Africa are studded with such ominous warnings as Foul bottom; discolored waters. So numerous are the shipwrecks in that forbidding region that it is called the Skeleton Coast. As South Africa prepares to withdraw from its 63year stewardship of the muchdisputed territory, it may be steering straight and recklessly into political waters just as dangerous.

title: Rate Rise Concerns Brokers
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Dec. 3  Formal speeches abounded at the annual convention of the Securities Industry Association last week, but the topic dominating the conversation in the corridors, lounges and hospitality suites was the impact of the sharp rise of the prime rate on the stock market.

title: Synanon Chief Arraigned In an Alleged Murder Plot
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3  The founder of Synanon, Charles Dederich, is expected to be returned to Los Angeles tomorrow to face charges that he conspired to murder a Los Angeles lawyer by having two of the group's security guards place a four and a half foot rattlesnake in the lawyer's mailbox.

title: Outdoors: Selecting the Right Shotgun
description: WITH so many different shotguns on the market, choosing the proper one poses a problem to the hunter who has not had a long acquaintance with fowling pieces.

title: Drawn to Rebellion and Drug Culture
description: The two oldest Layton children were graduated from college and began their careers; they would not be drawn into the People's Temple. But Larry and Deborah Layton, who would be caught up in the cult, became involved in Berkeley's student rebellion of the 1960's and the drug culture that permeated the area at that time.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Wilbur Mills Offers Sober Testimony to an Alcoholic Past
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 3  Wilbur Daniel Mills has always had the look of a favorite, vaguely reprobate uncle, the smile of Lyndon Johnson, the nose of W.C. Fields, and a fine, gravelly whisky voice compounded of mahogany, two quarts of good bourbon a day and long dark times unsalvaged by the slightest memory.

title: Dr. Harry Sherman, 72, Practiced As Ophthalmologist for Children
