description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  Two widely celebrated mountain men from the farthest hills of Appalachia were among seven persons honored at a dinner here tonight with gifts of $10,000 from the Rockefeller Public Service Awards.

title: A Player Who Does It All, and With Flair
description: If a club owner could walk Into a factory that manufactured baseball players and say, Build me the perfect athlete, a virtual basebal machine, regardless of cost, the final product Would come out looking very much like Peter Edward Rose.

title: Notes on People
description: As a giant to the held of photojournalism, and one of its founding fathers, Alfred Eisenstaedt has photographed scores of the world's greats, from Churchill and Eisenhower to Marilyn Monroe. Al Capp, Gloria Vanderbilt, Queen Elizabeth II and Jonas Salk have been subjects of the pioneer's use of the 35millimeter camera as an original member of the staff of Life magazine. Mr. Eisenstaedt, who was born in Germany, turns 80 today, and tonight the new monthly Life, to which he is a contributor, is throwing a birthday party for him at New York, New York, and has enticed him to come into Manhattan for it from his home in Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: Met: Carreras Sings Verdi
description: JOSE CARRERAS was originally scheduled for the role of Rodolfo in the Metropolitan Opera's revival this fall of Verdi's Luisa Miller, but the Spanish tenor defected from the first few performances for reasons of health. He has now assumed his place in the production, and he is indeed one of its most valuable ornaments.

title: President's Economic Bind
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 5  President Carter has put himself in something of a policy bind with his penchant for publicly committing himself to specific target figures before reviewing the entire budget for next year.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: LONDONIn the Horn of Africa, now largely unreported in the news media, the killing continues on a terrible scale, while the Russians and Cubans adventurously stand by their commitment to help consolidate the MarxistLeninist revolution proclaimed by Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam's military regime. Because the weapons being used in Ethiopia come not from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization powers but exclusively from the Warsaw Pact members, while the troops come from Cuba, the campuses in the West are silent. So, too, is the rest of Western opinion.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: DURING my many years as chef at the late Pavillon Restaurant New York, I was as fascinated by the food preferences of.le patron, Henri Soul, as were any of the clientele. Cost in that kitchen meant very little in those bygone years; there was always count or a duke with an appetite to be appeased by grouse or breast of guinea hen or fresh foie gras or turbot freshly flown in from France.

title: Personal Health
description: NO one ever suspected that Richard might have something wrong with his eyes. He learned to read before the age of 4 and raced through book after book. He had no trouble in school. But he never could learn how to catch a ball, or how to hit one, for that matter.

title: Two Bombs Explode in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 5 (Reuters) Two powerful bombs hidden in vehicles exploded in Belfast today, causing traffic chaos. Hundreds of families were evacuated from their homes while experts checked other suspected trucks and cars. No one was injured in the attacks, which appear to be part of a new wave of bombings launched in recent weeks by Irish Republican guerrillas who have threatened a winter offensive.

title: Entertainment Events
description: THE KINGFISHER, a comedy by William Douglas Home, starring Rex Harrison and Claudette Colbert, Biltmore Theater, West 47th Street, 7.

title: Schaefer Wins a Round
description: The F. & M. Schaefer Corporation of New York, vigorously opposing a hostile takeover bid by C. Schmidt & Sons of Philadelphia, won a preliminary injunction in New York yesterday to prevent Schmidt from going ahead with takeover plans.

title: Cooking Schools In Manhattan
description: SPIRALING food costs allow one few options for economizing, especially for those whose tastes Tun to exptic and unusual foods. The best answer. we can think of is to learn to cook. Given the number, range and variety of cooking schools now operating in the city, there is little excuse not to. A world of cuisines, antique, classic and modern, are represented, as are courses that stress convenience while others are allout classics. Beginners who are shy and not sure they are interested at all would do well to take one of the less expensive, less thorough courses first. Then, when they have gained confidence, they can make a larger investment in both time and money.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 6, 1978

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: A heavy volume of new taxexempt state and city bond issues was marketed yesterday as this week's $1.1 billion schedule of financing hit full stride. Yields were generally slightly lower than expected early this week, and yet the slight decrease did not deter investors from buying most of the bonds.

title: World Gold
description: TUESDAY, DEC. 5, 1978

title: Of Horses, Halberds, Railbirds
description: OSSINING, N.Y.  Bernard Rome, president of the New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation, has proposed that the State Legislature abolish the New York Racing Association and entrust Belmont Park, Saratoga and Aqueduct to a public authority. He has attacked one of the last bastions of feudal privilege  and none too soon.

title: Israel Will Ask Dutch To Surrender Suspect
description: THE HAGUE, Dec. 5 (AP)  The Israeli Embassy said today that its Government would seek , extradition of Pieter Menten, the Dutch millionaire whose conviction on war crimes charges was reversed by a Dutch court yesterday.

title: From Tut's Tomb, a Lively Fad
description: The old dead king really put a lot of life into our distillery.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 5  Sometimes anniversaries have their uses. They make us think about where we've been and where we're going. And on this 37th anniversary of Pearl Harbor and the entrance of the United States into World War II, current headlines may remind us of the transformation and progress of the modern world.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW. Dec. 7

title: St. Louis Press Strike Still On
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 5 (AP)  The press. men's strike against The St. Louis PostDispatch and The GlobeDemocrat entered its third week today with nc progress reported in the dispute that has shut down the papers. The pressmen struck Nov. 20 in a dispute over the number of journeymen pressmen to be employed by the newspaper.

title: Robert C. Turner, 70; Advised 3 Presidents On Economic Affairs
description: BOSTON, Dec. 5 (AP)  Robert C. Turner, an economic adviser to three Democratic Presidents and a former vice chancellor of Indiana University, died today at a local hospital. He was 70 years old.

title: The City
description: The owner and an employee of a grocery store in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn were shot to death last night and a suspect was wounded in a robbery attempt. the police reported.

title: Economic Scene
description: REACTION to President Carter's antiinflation program varies greatly among different interest groups. Labor unions, with few exceptions, are opposed to the voluntary program. Labor, leaders contend that wage guidelines, with management to enforce them, will cut workers real incomes but that prices will rise without effective restraint from the Government. A small papermakers union has gone so far as to bring suit to have the President's guidelines declared unconstitutional.

title: CORRECTION
description: In a Reporter's Notebook article about Guyana in The Times yesterday, Geoff Boycott, a cricket star in Britain, was erroneously identified as a West Indian black. Mr. Boycott is a white Yorkshireman.

title: SCANDAL CONFIRMED BY SOUTH AFRICANS
description: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 5  A judicial report today confirmed a political and financial scandal in South Africa's Information Ministry but absolved the coun. try's two top officials, President John Vorster and Prime Minister P.W. Botha, of blame in the affair.

title: Bache Authorizes Issuance of Stock
description: The Bache Group Inc., parent company of Bache Halsey Stuart Shields, has authorized the issuance of an additional 700,000 shares of its common stock for use in purchasing insurance brokerage firms. Harry A. Jacobs Jr., chairman, said that product line diversification will be a key element in the growth of Bache.

title: For Scallops, A Very Fine Year
description: THERE is a good deal of poetry in the names the French have chosen for their foods  Du Barry, Richelieu, ravigote, Rachel. One of the most interesting names, coquilles St. Jacques, is applied both to a food  scallops  and to a dish made up of that food. Many people, even among the French, don't know that the name in its beginnings had religious connotations. The word coquille, of course, means shell in French. Starting in the Middle Ages, it was commonly believed that St. James (in French, St. Jacques) was buried in the province of Galicia in northwest Spain. The place of his burial is said to be in Compostela. now indicated on maps as Santiago (St. James) de Compostela.

title: More Policemen In Borough Park  Temporarily
description: Brooklyn's Borough Park area was saturated with police officers on foot patrol yesterday, a temporary assignment that pleasantly surprised the area's residents but was unrelated to last Saturday's murder of a 65yearold Jewish Sabbath observer that led to fights with police in demands for more protection.

title: Issue and Debate Civil Defense Drive: A Turnabout in U.S Strategic Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  Earlier this month Carter Administration aides disclosed that the United States was about to embark on a new drive to save as many as 140 million American lives in the event of a major nuclear war. The disclosure stirred considerable skepticism, even disbelief, in many circles. Observers asked why, after civil defense was essentially abandoned 15 years ago, President Carter had decided to revive it.

title: Deaths
description: DICKSONWilliam, A. Jr., President Manhattan Savings Bank on October 9, 1978 at Yonkers, NY. Beloved husband of Isabelle Cornell Dickson, lather of Paul, Peter Dickson & Andrea Wells.A lifelong banker and Yonkers civic leader, Mr. Dickson served on many local, state and national bank committees, was former President of Yonkers Savings Bank. served as VP of Yonkers Board of Education, Planning Board & Industrial Council, President of YMCA Board, Exec VP of Yonkers Council of Churches, Treasurer of Yonkers General Hospital, NYC Board of Salvation Army. Economics Club of NY & St. Andrew's Golf Club. Funeral was held on October 13 at St. Paul's Episcopal Church. Yonkers. interment Oakland Cemetery.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Nippon Steel agreed to build a $2.03 billion steel mill for China in the largest SinoJapanese trade agreement on record. The project will include a blast furnace, a basic oxygen furnace, a coke plant and other facilities on a site near Shanghai. China will pay for the project in cash, either Japanese yen or United States dollars. [Page A1.]

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: LAST Friday evening, writes Debora Wiesenthal, we took some outoftown guests to 45th Street to see a play. During the intermission, we stepped out into the street in front of the theater, where a crowd had already formed.

title: Deaths
description: Biller, Anne

title: Technology
description: THE longpredicted convergence of such consumer electronic products as television sets, videotape recorders, video games, stereo sound systems and the coming videodisk machines into a computerbased home informationentertainment center is getting closer.

title: WEBSTER TO DISMISS TWO F.B.I. OFFICIALS FOR BREAKIN ROLES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  William H. Webster, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that he intended to discharge two supervisors who were involved in a series of allegedly illegal breakins, wiretaps and mail openings in the early 1970's but would not discipline 59 other bureau employees, most of them street agents, who were also involved.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HIS COUNTRY Most of the 40 paintings by Cemil Eren that go on exhibition today depict views of Turkey, the artist's homeland. This is the latest display in one of the most attractive art showcases along First Avenue, the spicandspan gallery at the entrance to the Turkish Center, at 47th Street. Upstairs the building houses the permanent mission of that country to the United Nations. It's always a pleasure to step inside this intimate gallery, a quiet and restful contrast to the bustle outside on United Nations Plaza.

title: No Rise Expected In Bank Deposits
description: Savings banks will tail to cha?? up a net gain in savings and time deposits next year, according to a projection by the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks.

title: ABCTV Still Leads In Ratings
description: Despite a rash of seasonal television specials, the Nielsen popularity ratings this season have been dominated by regular weekly series and, as usual this season, most of them were on ABCTV. Laverne and Shirley, Happy Days and Three's Company were the top shows, as they have been almost every week since the season opened in September.

title: Combe Retains McCannErickson
description: In Belgium. Denmark. Japan and Spain, advertising for the products of Combe Inc. has been done by local offices of McCannErickson. a worldwide unit in the Interpublic Group of Companies. Now the agency's New York office has picked up the big enchilada the United States assignment.

title: Cartmen Talks Go On Uncertainly As Trash Piles Continue to Mount
description: Garbage continued to pile up yesterday at the rate of 5,000 tons a day at New York City's restaurants, hotels, hospitals and department stores as a strike by private sanitation workers went into its fifth day.

title: Jersey Hunters Thin Deer Herd in Refuge
description: HARDING TOWNSHIP, N.J., Dec. 5  By late morning, the luckiest deer hunters had emerged from the wet woodlands of the Great swamp National Wildlife Refuge and were converging on the weighing station outside the small olivedrab barn. Dead bucks and does were stretched across the tallgates of station wagons, tied to rooftop ski racks, and squeezed behind thee spare tires on the backs of jeeps.

title: Books of The Times
description: ONE difference between Hollywood children and the rest of us is that they go ahead and write the exposs of their parents that we only dream of doing in fits of adolescent transport. But who is to say: Perhaps Christina Crawford is justified in committing Mommie Dearest against her late adoptive mother, the movie queen Joan Crawford.

title: A Correction
description: In an article in The Living Section last Wednesday on food gifts for Christmas, the name of the store selling the Bourdier d'Auvergiie oils, vinegars, pickles and mustards was inadvertently omitted. They are all available at Maison Glass, 52 West 58th Street (7553316).

title: New York Is in the Running for G.O.P. Convention
description: New York City was assured last night by the Republican Party's national chairman, Bill Brock, that the city had caught up with six other cities under consideration as the site of the party's 1980 convention and was now competing on an equal basis.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Justice Thurgood Marshall of the United States Supreme Court yesterday denied a request by the Kennecott Copper Corporation for a stay of a lower court order that the company rerun the April election of directors at which Kennecott and the CurtissWright Corporation fought for control of the Kennecott board. Kennecott was the victor in that election.

title: President Flies In to Assist Beame At a $2,500aCouple Gala at Met
description: Looking to the past and the future, President Carter helped former Mayor Abraham D. Beame last night by sharing dinner and the opera with more than 200 of New York's politically influential men and women.

title: Tesoro Petroleum Discloses Payments
description: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation has disclosed questionable payments of more than $1 million domestically and abroad. It said also that the Internal Revenue Service had proposed to bill the company $129,554 for taxes on some of these transactions conducted in 1974 and 1975, and that the company planned to make up an additional $31,498 plus interest to cover 1973.

title: U.S. Warns Vietnam Growing Soviet Links Imperil American Tie
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  The Carter Administration said today that it was seriously concerned about the growing conflict between Vietnam and Cambodia and warned Hanoi that the possibility of normal relations with the United States could be set back by Vietnam's growing ties with the Soviet Union.

title: Wine Talk
description: AS more and more people get into wine, the demand for the most famous names goes up and up  and so do the prices. The wine ads and the catalogues are beginning to adopt the hysterical tone they affected six or seven years ago when prices were making a similar reach for the heavens.

title: Chilean General's Home Bombed
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 5 (UPI)  A powerful bomb damaged the home of Gen. Alberto Spoerer, a former Health Minister under President Augusto Pinochet, early today. No injuries were reported.

title: Close Encounters to Get Even Closer
description: HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 6  When Close Encounters of the Third Kind is relesyed next year. It will include 13 or 20 minutes, of film that was not in the original movie.

title: Bankruptcy Trustee's Fee Denied
description: A Federal judge yesterday denie?? fees for a Federal trustee and two law firms and ordered them to return al lowances received in connection with the bankruptcy of Arlan's Department Stores, a New England discount chair liquidated in 1975.

title: Wang Labs: Healthy Survivor
description: By all accounts, the next threshold for the automated office of the future is the intelligent printer: a reasonably priced, highspeed office copier that can be linked electronically to small computers, wordprocessing, textediting typewriters and other automated equipment.

title: Careers
description: NEVER brighter. That is the pithy description James H. MacNeill gives for the opportunities existing for prospective accountants and auditors..

title: Jessica Kats Riding Hood
description: Who was it that kept crying Wolf? or, to be precise, Kats? The Kats baby is dying of a disease, went the cry, that only America's glorious medicine can cure, but those awful Russians won't let Jessica and her parents Boris and Natalva Kats. emigrate. Progressively exaggerated in parental pleas, protest meetings, newspaper commentary and the petitions of Congressmen, Jessica's condition became an international cause even as the child improved. She arrived in the United States last week, with her parents and newborn sister, looking healthy and, it seems, feeling fit.

title: Adams Scores Lack Of Auto Innovation
description: DETROIT, Dec. 5  Transportation Secretary Brock Adams assailed the American automobile industry today as having failed to make any major technological breakthroughs in the last 60 years and as having set low goals in planning for the future.

title: Rules Changes in House Pass Democratic Caucus
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  The House Democratic Caucus, organizing for the 96th Congress, today approved a series of rules changes designed to answer complaints heard in the last Congress about burdensome committee assignments, dilatory floor tactics and overly hasty consideration of certain bills.

title: Supreme Court Upholds California Franchise Law
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  The Supreme Court upheld today a California franchise law that allows the state to delay the opening of a new automobile dealership while deciding whether nearby dealerships will be unduly injured by the added competition.

title: Blazers to Test McMillian
description: PORTLAND. Ore., Dec. 5 (AP) The Portland Trail Blazers have offered a twoday tryout to Jim McMillian, who played out his option with the New York Knicks last season and has been a free agent.

title: TV: Jacques Cousteau's Easter Island
description: WHEN it comes to a subject like Easter Island, as it does tonight from 8 to 9 on WNET/13, Jacques Cousteau is like a fish out of water. On dry land, the man who virtually invented aqualung exploration is pretty much just another tourist, asking questions of the experts instead of being one himself.

title: Advertising
description: AN advertising exposition that the promoters call the first of its kind began a threeday stay at the New York Coliseum yesterday. There was a long list of speakers, which proves it was an advertising gathering.

title: O! This Too Too Solid Flesh
description: Roberto Duran of Panama, who conducts his business wearing 8ounce gloves because meataxes are against the rules, arrived in New York ,the other day looking like a man who would not enjoy sweating down to 135 pounds. He won't have to on this visit, even though it is a professional call. The one and only lightweight champion of the world is here to fight Monroe Brooks. a junior welterweight from Los Angeles, in the overtheweight feature of a card offering four 10round bouts in Madison Square Garden Friday. For this caper, Duran is entitled to weigh 147 pounds if he chooses and his title will not be at stake.

title: Kings Early Surge Halts Knicks, 10592
description: The Knicks, with only eight men in uniform, gave their poorest performance of the season for almost 33 minutes last night. They fell behind by 32 points to the Kansas City Kings.

title: Rossman Scores by Knockout
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5  The secret of Aldo Traversaro was unlocked quickly and efficiently, if a bit bloodily, by Mike Rossman tonight.

title: Samuel Goudsmit, Codiscoverer Of Electron's Spin, Is Dead at 76
description: Samuel A. Goudsmit codiscoverer of the electron's spin and long a leading figure in American physics, died in Reno, Nev., Monday at the age of 76.

title: The A.M.A.'s Bad Case
description: We feel the very nature of professionalism... in this country, perhaps the world, is at issue, said Dr. Robert Hunter, the chairman of the American Medical Association's board of trustees. What roused him to such hyperbole was the ruling by a judge of the Federal Trade Commission that parts of the A.M.A.'s code of ethics violate the antitrust laws. Restrictions on advertising, on the solicitation of business and on contractual arrangements with health care organizations, he decided, are really intended to protect doctors' incomes. The judge makes a good case.

title: U.S.Japan Accord
description: TOKYO, Dec. 5  After more than 12 months of tough bargaining aimed at increasing Japanese imports of American citrus fruit and beef products, the United States and Japan reached final agreement today liberalizing ground rules governing their $4 billion annual bilateral farm trade.

title: VIKTOR D. LEBEDEV
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 5 (Reuters  Viktor D. Lebedev, a leading Soviet planning official, has died at the age of 62, the Communist daily Pravda reported today. Mr. Lebedev was a First Deputy Chairman of the State Planning Committee, where he had worked since 1957. He was responsible for the planning of machine manufacturing.

title: Prime Minister Links Iranian Strife To Saboteurs, Not True Moslems
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 5  Gen. Gholam Riza Azhari, the Iranian Prime Minister, charged today that atheists and saboteurs, not true Moslems, were responsible for the continuing strife that has imperiled the reign of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlavi.

title: 20Year Treaty Moves Afghans Closer to Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 5  Afghanistan and the Soviet Union signed a 20year treaty of friendship and cooperation today, binding the countries to close economic and military ties.

title: Back Page History: A Collector's Choice
description: Anwar elSadat and Menachem Begin struggled toward a peace agreement this year. Jimmy Carter grappled with inflation. John Paul I arrived and gave way to John Paul II. Prince Charles turned 30.

title: The Gin Game to Close After 517 Performances
description: After 517 performances, The Gin Game, starring Maureen Stapleton and E. G. Marshall, will end its Broadway run on Dec. 31. The twocharacter play, which won a Pulitzer Prize for its author, D. L. Coburn, opened Oct. 6, 1977, with Jessica Tandy and Hume Cronyn under the direction of Mike Nichols.

title: U.S.Made Auto Sales Climb 4%
description: DETROIT, Dec. 5  The sale of new Americanmade cars in the final 10 days of November rose 4 percent above the level of the corresponding period year ago, the nation's four major automobile manufacturers reported today. However, as was the case in the previous sales period, the benefits of the gain were felt only by the General Motors Corporation.

title: TV: Mourning Becomes Electra Begins on WNET
description: MOURNING Becomes Electra is not likely to be found on the average theatergoer's list of plays most wanted for revival. The 1931 Eugene O'Neill trilogy runs to about six hours in performance. It is dated, sometimes turgid, often obvious and always relentless. The classical Greek concept of fate is fortified constantly with massive doses of Irish Catholic guilt. The result is an uncompromising O'Neill at his most impossibly demanding.

title: 5 Angolans Face Firing Squad
description: LONDON, Dec. 5 (Reuters)  The Luanda radio said today that five members of a proWestern rebel movement in Angola had been sentenced to death by firing squad for sabotage. The radio, monitored in London, said they belonged to the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola and were sentenced at a mass rally yesterday at the Benguela sports ground, south of Luanda, the capital.

title: Companies Report Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange,(A) the American Stbck Exchange and (O) overtheCounter.

title: State Dept. Had Called Suicide Threat a Ploy
description: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Dec. 6 (AP)  A United States official discounted as a psychological ploy a threat last summer by members of the People's Temple that they would commit mass suicide if their leader, the Rev. Jim Jones, should lose a child custody suit, Federal officials said last night.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: An OrderOut Yule Tree

title: Jones's Son Says He Opposed Revolutionary Suicide
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 5 Stephan Jones, the 19yearold son of the Rev. Jim Jones, said today that he argued against revolutionary suicide at a Jonestown public meeting eight months ago, saying that those who died would be seen as fanatics rather than martyrs to socialism as his father had preached. But he said he was shouted down.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: More Help For Myasthenics
description: In an article in The Living Sec. Lion last week, the Muscular Dystrophy Association was given as a source of information on myasthenia gravis, a neuromuscular disease. An additional source is the Myasthenia Gravis Foundation, begun in 1952 (it now has 53 chapters in 46 statese) The foundation provides patient services to myasthenics through clinics. literature, selfhelp groups, patient counseling, and it provides prescription medicine at reduced cost.

title: New Children's Space Shows to Come From Space
description: Youngsters, who seem to be charmed by television shows about space, will now be able to get television shows designed specifically for them from out in space under a new satellite network to be started by next February by the Warner Cable Comoration.

title: The Cruller Master: Baking with a Heart
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I. SOME men search a lifetime for worldly success and that elusive inner sense of selffulfillment. Not Fenton E. Crutchley. He has long since found all he wants of both in the somewhat unlikely guise of the doughnut. These fried cakes, often called crullers, have for many years been pronounced masterpieces of the baker's art. And Mr. Crutchley is widely esteemed by connoisseurs as the Picasso of the doughnut.

title: Debate Over Domestic Budget Cuts Heats as Democratic Parley Nears
description: DETROIT, Dec. 5  Douglas A. Fraser, head of the nation's second largest union, and Mayor Coleman Young, one of President Carter's firmest allies among blacks, warned today that a Federal budget that curbed or cut domestic programs while raising Pentagon spending would damage the country and the Democratic Party.

title: High Court Curbs Challenge to Police Search of Car
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 The Suprenie Court ruled today by a narrow majority that an automobile passenger does not have the legal right to challenge the constitutionality of a police search of the car in which he is riding, even if the search turns up evidence later used to convict him of a crime.

title: State Aides Set on Mortgages Bill
description: ALBANY, Dec. 5  Staff negotiators for Governor Carey and the legislative leaders reached agreement tonight on a bill to increase interest rates on home mortfages and attempt to halt redlining, discrimination by banks against particular areas.

title: Police Arrest 2 TeenAlters in the Slaying of Designer
description: The police last night arrested two teenagers who they said had stabbed and killed a Scottish fashion designer Sunday night in lower Manhattan.

title: William Shea Law Firm Makes Business of Power
description: Late in the afternoon of October 18. a dozen of New York City's business and political leaders met in a 15thfloor conference room at the law offices of Shea Gould Climenko & Casey. They were there to decide who should be invited to last night's $2,500acouple fundraising event at the Metropolitan Opera House for former Mayor Abraham D. Beame.

title: Book Jackets Were Not Made for Stripping
description: I AM SHOCKED. I am not easily shocked, and I find I can't even utter the words without feeling like Claude Rains in Casablanea expressing horror at the discovery that there is gambling going on at Rick's place. Inasmuch as Mr. Rains is pocketing his personal winnings as he speaks, his high moral indignation is shall we say  something less than sincere. I too feel a bit insincere whenever I pretend to astonishment at the wieked ways of this world, though. of course. I can't be insincere with quite the same charm I did spend some time, when I younger, trying to emulate the lotted single eyebrow and the quizzically catlike smile of that master of elan. Mr. Rains, but some how I wasn't the type. Or so my friends kept saying.

title: European Monetary Setback
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 5  Western Europe's ambitious plans for inaugurating a new currency bloc at the start of next year plans that could eventually reduce the dollar's international prestige  appear to have suffered a setback.

title: Private Lives
description: THE situation is this: We are in the living room, my son and I. He is on the floor, reading Gravity's Rainbow for a book report. He is laughing; Thomas Pynchon cracks him up. I am on the couch, reading my son's first novel, which is science fiction. I am not laughing. both because his science fiction is serious and because at his age I, too, wrote science fiction and among the many things I wish for my son, one is another life, with more sinew and less semiotics.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Stage: Siblings, Love
description: NEW HAVEN A KIND of patness, an emotional tidiness that swells into selfcongratulation, mars the humors and sentiments of Bernice Rubens's I Sent a Letter to My Love at the Long Wharf Theater.

title: Topics
description: The English language service of China's news agency, Hsinhua, will. begin on Jan. 1 to use a different system of transliterating Chinese names into the R....an alphabet. (The agency itself will thus become Xinhua.) This is a small external manifestation of an attempt at internal reform that may lead to the phoneticization and standardization of the Chinese language.

title: Cooking Schools: Other Boroughs . .
description: FLEDGLING cooks as well as those looking for a group to share their love of the culinary life shouldn't limit their search to Manhattan. There's some fine cooking going on in the brownstone schools of Cobble Hill and Brooklyn Heights and in the kitchen workshops of Forest Hills and Staten Island.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: EAST RUTHERFORD. N.J. Dec. 5 (AP)  Joe Pisarcik, the New York Giant quarterback does not need surgery on his in??ured left knee, the National Football League team an nounced today. His availability for the last two games of the season was uncertain, however.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: John H. Dietze has been been named president of the new household products division of the American Cyanamid Company.

title: Chess:
description: Grandmaster Raymond Keene has been campaigning with patriotic fervor in the last several years to obtain recognition for the contribution to chess theory by the classical English masters, and the results of his researches have been surprisingly fertile.

title: WESTWAY PROJECT SEEMS STALEMATED
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 Eight months after he had persuaded Mayor Koch to accept the Westway, Governor Carey remains unable to win the necessary approval for the $1.16 billion highway project from Federal and state environmental officials.

title: Advice of Dallas to New Yorkers: Don't Cry About Loss of Airline
description: DALLAS, Dec. 1  Good morning. This is your captain aboard American Airlines' flight No. 1 from Dallas to New York City. We expect good weather all the way. However, we do suggest that you keep your seat belt fastened as we near New York City, as we are expecting some turbulence from antiaircraft fire.

title: Failure to File Death Certificates May Hinder the Burial of Cultists
description: DOVER AIR FORCE BASE, Del., Dec. 5  Delaware officials today cleared a major legal obstacle to the shipment of bodies of members of the People's Temple from here to other communities in the country. Despite this, however, it is unclear whether any of the bodies can be buried or cremated in any state because there are no death certificates for the more than 900 cultists who died in Guyana almost three weeks ago.

title: Some Big Hits and Near Misses Mark Post Office Auction
description: A clock fancier from Long Island's South Shore sort of dozed off for a bit, he confessed later, during the General Post Office's fourhour auction yesterday of merchandise from mailed packages that had proved undeliverable or unreturnable. Intending to bid on two cuckoo clocks lot 323, in the parlance of the auctioneers  the collector roused himself prematurely when lot 303 was announced, winning it with a noncancelable bid of $32.

title: Bomb Goes Off at an Oil Depot as Namibians Vote
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Africa, Dec. 5 (Reuters)  A bomb exploded at a gasoline storage depot here today as voting continued in a controversial election called by South Africa as a step toward deciding the future of SouthWest Africa, or Namibia.

title: Japanese to Build Giant Steel Mill For Chinese in $2.03 Billion Deal
description: TOKYO, Dec. 5  The Nippon Steel Corporation has reached an agreement with China to provide about $2.03 billion in equipment to build a giant steel mill at Paoshan, on the estuary of the Yangtze River near Shanghai, the company said today.

title: 5 New Shows Will Join CBS Roster Next Month
description: In a far more modest midseason shakeup of its primetime schedule than NBCTV produced last week, CBSTV yesterday announced a new lineup for next month that includes five new programs and timeperiodchanges for seven existing shows.

title: Fire starts Chemical Unit Blasts
description: DECATUR Ala., Dec. 5 (AP)  A fire in a chemical transfer pump ignited a series of explosions at the Monsanto Chemical plant yesterday, forcing the evacuation of 1.000 employees. No injuries were reported. A Monsanto spokesman said that firemen allowed the chemical in the pump to burn itself out while spraying water onto nearby storage tanks. A plant worker said the chemical that exploded was acrylonitrile, a colorIess liquid used to make acrylic fibers.

title: Fed Chief Sees Long Cost Fight
description: G. William Miller, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said yesterday that it would take from five to eight years to bring inflation down from its current neardoubledigit levels to an acceptable rate.

title: Bridge:
description: For good players who hope to bridge the gap that separates them from the experts, the most useful book to appear for a long time is Expert Bridge, published in California and available at $6.95 from Barclay Bridge Supplies, Bush Avenue, Port Chester, N.Y. 10573.

title: Lebanese Rebuild Amid Ruins but Think of Leaving
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 1 Rebuilding has resumed in the predominantly Christian section of eastern Beirut after devastating round of fighting between militiamen and Syrian peacekeeping troops.

title: All That Glitters at a Tiffany Party
description: MONDAY afternoon was a dead loss except to the hairdressers. Who could think of Christmas shopping when Harry Platt was having his biennial party?.Certainly not the gorgeous glitterers who ice the layer cake known as the international set.

title: Letters
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Textron Halts Iran Copters
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 5 (UPI)  Textron, Inc. announced today that its Bell helicopter division had halted work on its large coproduction program with Iran because the Shah's Government had not met the advance financing requirements of the contract.

title: U.S. DEFENDS CONSUL ASSIGNED TO GUYANA
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  The State Department strongly defended Richard A. McCoy, the United States consular officer in Guyana who dealt with the People's Temple settlement, saying today that he had had regular contact with the Guyanese police for a year and had reported to them his suspicions about the group.

title: Court Hears Arguments in Job Discrimination Case
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  The Supreme Court heard arguments today on a major employment discrimination case that had been expected to settle the power of the Federal courts to order quotas for the hiring of members of minority groups.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Tuesday. Dec: 5, 1978

title: Venezuela's PresidentElect
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 5  Luis Herrera Campins was never the dominant figure in the Social Christian Party, nor did he stir great excitement during his campaign for Sunday's presidential election here. Yet his twinkling eves and warm smile seemed toconvey the kind of honesty and decency that many Venezuelans were looking for in their next leader.

title: U.S. Detail Financing In Germany
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  The Treasury, announcing certain details of its first public offering in a foreign credit market in history, said today that on Dec. 12 it would begin selling to German residents threeyear and fouryear notes denominated in marks worth the equivalent of $1.5 billion.

title: Mexico's Price Index Up
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 5 (AP)  Mexico's national consumer price index rose 1 percent in November because of rising food prices and rents in Mexico City, the Bank of Mexico said today. The index has risen 15.2 percent this year, an average of 1.3 percent a month. Mexico City's wholesale price index rose 1.3 percent in November, the bank said.

title: Baltic Builduh Alarms Danes
description: Denmark is the latest member of the Atlantic alliance to register alarm over the boldness of the steadily expanding Warsaw Pact forces in its area. The prime cause of concern is Soviet air and naval activity in the Baltic Sea and the waters that lead past Denmark to the North Sea.

title: The President and Beanie Outshine Aida at the Opera
description: Backs were turned to the gold curtain at the Met last night. Opera glasses pointed up to the parterre boxes. A clutch of television crews backed up against the stage in the right aisle, the snouts of their cameras pointed up.

title: The Region
description: NORWALK, Conn. (AP)  Health officials said they had found Legionnairedisease organisms in the airconditioning cooling tower of Norwalk Hospital. The tower, which has not been used since last month, is being disinfected.

title: Decision Made After a Hectic Tour of Clubs
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 5  La Thursday Pete Rose ate Welsh rarebit for lunch at the Ruly Carpenter estate in Montchanin, Del. It was the most delicious Welsh rarebit I've ever had. Reuven Katz, Rose's lawyer, said today, and no one enjoyed it.

title: Other U. S. and Foreign Stock Exchanges
description: TUESDAY, DEC. 5, 1978

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Advanced Technologies, a subsidiary of Thomas Tilling Ltd., a diversified international company based in London, has appointed Hugh K. Stevenson president and chief operating officer. He was president of Clarkson Industries, which was acquired by Thomas Tilling in March.

title: Expert Advises School Officials To Seal Off Asbestos Fiber Areas
description: An expert on chemicals has told New York City Board of Education officials that they should simply seal off school areas where cancercausing asbestos fibers have leaked into classrooms and hallways from insulation sections.

title: Finances Still a Problem at Coop City
description: The financial problems of the huge Coop City housing project inthe Northeast Bronx have again become acute. The project has failed to make its full mortgage payments to New York State for three months in a row, and the deficit now totals $1.5 million and is expected to grow.

title: Ambassador Young Sees Pope
description: VATICAN CITY, Dec.5 (Reuters) Pope John Paul II received Andrew Young, the chief American delegate to the United Nations, in a private audience today, Vatican officials said. No details were disclosed.

title: Market Place
description: FOR more than a year, Puerto Rico was absent from the bind market, suffering in part from the problems of the Northeast and particularly those of New York City. New York's financial travail effectively closed the market to the island.

title: Mets Get Falcone In Cardinal Trade
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 5  The New York Mets entered the trading market at baseball's winter convention today when they sent Torn Grieve and Kim Seaman to the St. Louis Cardinals for Pete Falcone, a 25yearold southpaw from Brooklyn.

title: Holders Vote LTV Merger
description: DALLAS. Dec. 5  Stockholders of the LTV Corporation and the Lykes Corporation, meeting simultaneously here and in New Orleans, today approved a merger that will create the nation's thirdlargest steel company.

title: Columbia Five Tops Manhattan, 8476
description: Manhattan wasted a 36point performance by Jojo Walters and dropped a 8476 basketball decision to a determined Columbia team last night.

title: Humphrey Scholarship Initiated
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  A new scholarship that will allow hundreds of young people from developing nations to study in the United States was initiated today as a memorial to the late Senator Hubert H. Humphrey.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249, or to any of the following organizations:

title: Gen. George Brown, Retired Chairman of Joint Chiefs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  Gen. George S. Brown, a fourstar Air Force general who retired last June as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, died at a hospital here today of cancer of the prostate. He was 60 years old.

title: Levitt to Change Accounting Plan Of State Budget
description: ALBANY, Dec. 5  The retiring New York State Comptroller, Arthur Levitt, announced today that his office would begin using a new accounting method intended to make it far more difficult for a governor to disguise the fiscal manipulations that have become a standard part of state budgeting.

title: Singer: Jerry Jeff Walker
description: THE term cult artist has insidious connotations for recordcompany executives who want megamillion hits, and even for cult artists themselves who covet the wealth and praise of their more famous peers. But cult status can have its charms, too, so long as one remains content with one's lot.

title: Study of U.S. Options For Persian Gulf Area To Be Headed by Ball
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  George W. Ball, who was an Under Secretary of State in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, has been asked by President Carter to lead an interagency study on American policy options in the Persian Gulf. White House officials said today.

title: Stocks Up As Glamour Rules Day
description: Boeing, International Business Machines and other glamour issues led the stock market sharply higher yesterday on increased trading volume. The Dow Jones industrial average advanced more than 13 points.

title: Real Estate
description: WITH an executive order dated Sept. 7, Mayor Koch has set in motion a longterm evaluation of real property in New York City aimed at satisfying the legal requirement that all property be assessed at 100 percent of full value.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Islanders, Penguins In 33 Tie
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Dec. 5  The Islanders set a oneperiod club record of 28 shots on goal tonight during the middle session, but a penalty shot that was missed by Pittsburgh in the final period was the key in a 33 tie with the Penguins.

title: Rate Peak Seen By Rockefeller
description: LONDON, Dec. 5 (AP)  David Rockefeller, the chairman of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, said today that fears of a credit squeeze in the United States were misguided and that shortterm United States interest rates might be near their peak for the present cycle.

title: Tenant Fight Cuts EgyptianBulgarian Ties
description: CAIRO, Dec. 5  Egypt broke diplomatic relations with Bulgaria today after a strange episode that began as a feud between a landlord and a tenant and culminated in occupation of the Bulgarian Embassy here by Egyptian policemen.

title: Guyana Denies Cult Link
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 5  The Guyanese Government sought tonight to refute charges that it had given special treatment to the Rev. Jim Jones and his followers in the People's Temple.

title: Witnesses Contrast U.S. and Canadian Health Cost
description: DENVER  Almost all the American witnesses selected by Senator Edward M. Kennedy to testify at recent hearings here and in Chicago on his plan for national health insurance told harrowing stories of personal medical trouble followed by financial ruin.

title: Millionaire in Old Brookville Slain; Clues Sought at 30Acre L.I. Estate
description: OLD BROOKVILLE, L.I., Dec. 5  A wealthy realestate developer was slain last night, and the Nassau County police searched his 30acre estate today for clues.

title: Deaths
description: BILLERAnne. Beloved wife of Morris (Moe) Biller passed away suddenly on Tuesday, December 5th. Funeral services will take place on Wednesday, December 6th at 1PM at the Gramercy Park Chapel, 152 Second Avenue (Between 9th and 10th Streets) N.Y.C. She is survived by her husband, sons Michael and Steven, daughterinlaw Carolyn and grandclauohfer Debra Rachel. The period of mourning will be observed at the home of Steven Biller.

title: Egypt Assails Israeli Demolitions
description: CAIRO. Dec. 5  The Foreign Ministry issued a statement tonight condemning Israel for demolishing Arab houses on the West Bank of the Jordan. It said such actions were terrorist measures that undermined Middle East peace efforts.

title: New York Fed Reports Active Dollar Support
description: Officials at the New York Federal Reserve Bank, commenting for the first time on its activities since the Administration's Nov. 1 announcement of a dollarsupport package, said yesterday that the bank had actively intervened in foreign currency markets during the period.

title: World News Briefs
description: UNITED NATIONS,N.Y., Dec. 5 Three watchdog groups on human rights jointly appealed to President Carter today to press for Senate ratification of longpending United Nations treaties on the subject.

title: The Troubled Presidency: I
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.  Presi dential government is now almost half a century old, and it is in trouble.

title: EARNINGS
description: Sharply higher foreignexchange losses were primarily responsible for a 3 percent dip in earnings for the fourth fiscal quarter at Deere & Company, the world's largest manufacturer of farm equipment and construction machinery said.

title: Californians Clash at Hearing on Big Atomic Plant
description: AVILA BEACH, Calif., Dec. 5 legal battle as complex as a chess game took shape behind the scenes today as a procession of citizens expressed contradictory views on whether one of the nation's biggest atomic power plants should be allowed to start operation.

title: Around the Nation
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 5 (AP)  Policemen and firemen reacted angrily today to the city's proposal to lay off 400 safety employees in an effort to keep Cleveland from becoming the first major American city to default since the Depression.

title: ExAgent Alleges Fraud in F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  A retired agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday that he had provided Federal investigators with evidence of 25 separate instances of fraud and corruption within the bureau.

title: Music: Wyner Premiere
description: WHEN the history of 20thcentury, music is finally written, one phenomenon may jut out over all others. To an extraordinary, extent, composers have spent their energies in struggling to make their works sound like no music that was ever composed before. The need to be original above all else began to obsess composers  and artists in most other fields as well  about 50 years ago, and serious music began to go into a serious decline about the same time.

title: Phone Number to Call For Garbage Removal
description: City officials have set up a special telephone number so that instances where garbage has piled up and created health or safety hazards can be reported.

title: Nicaraguans, Seeing Strife as Inevitable, Get Ready
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua  As national guard jeeps, often accompanied by informers, patrol the streets of the capital's slums, groups of young rebels crouch in shacks cleaning pistols and making bombs for the next offensive against the Government of President Anastasio Somoza Debayle.

title: William Still, 83, Black Composer
description: William Grant Still, dean of black classical composers, died Sunday in a nursing home in Los Angeles. He was 83 years old.

title: 3 Policemen Slain in Basque Area
description: MADRID, Dec. 5  On the eve of a historic referendum on Spain's new democratic constitution, three young gunmen burst into a crowded bar in the Basque city of San Sebastin this afternoon and assassinated three policemen.

title: Jersey Hearing Set Jan. 8 In Resorts' License Case
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 5  An attorney for Resorts International told the Casino Control Commission today that the state's charges of criminal associations and mismanagement were so damaging that the company wanted the speediest hearing.

title: P??cer Venus 1 Is Seeking Source of Gamma Rays
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Dec. 5On its ?? millionmile voyage before it sw?? into an orbit of Venus yesterday, Pi?? Venus I made observations that sh?? enable scientists to solve one of mo?? astronomy's major mysteries the ?? of enormous bursts of gamma rays it ??ep space.

title: A Part of Via Dolorosa Is Closed in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 5 (AP)  A 30foot section of the Via Dolorosa has been closed for fear that a 100yearold Franciscan church would collapse, and the route may not be reopened in time for Christmas pilgrimages.

title: Alan E. Murray, at 84; Invented Space Shoes
description: Alan E. Murray, inventor of the Murray Space Shoes, which are handmade and molded to the wearer's foot, died Oct. 24 in ParSons Hospital in Flushing, Queens, it was disclosed last week. Mr. Murray, who lived in Long Island City, was 84 years old.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: U.S. Urging Compromise
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 5  The United States is reported seeking to break the deadlock in IsraeliEgyptian negotiations by suggesting that Israel and Egypt each drop key demands in return for progress toward a peace treaty.

title: Rose Signed by Phils To $3.2 Million Pact
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 5  The wildest auction in baseball history ended today when Pete Rose signed a fouryear contract with the Philadelphia Phillies for $800,000 a year and became the highestpaid player in the game.

title: VANCE TO MAKE TRIP TO EGYPT AND ISRAEL ON PEACE DEADLOCK
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  President Carter is sending Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance to Egypt and Israel early next week in a new effort to overcome oa stacles holding up an EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty, the State Department announced today.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Soybean prices, which had declined on Monday, reversed course yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade and closed higher for some sound reasons.

title: Deaths
description: FOSTER  Ruth B. On December 4th. Beloved wife of Jacob F. Foster. Devoted mother of Marguerite Gartick & Walter J. Foster. Funeral private.

title: Cairo Newspaper Reports Saudis. Agree to Buy 50 F5E's for Egypt
description: CAIRO, Dec. 5 (Reuters)  Saudi Arabia has agreed to finance Egypt's purchase of 50 Northrop F5E military jets at an estimated cost of $590 million, the Cairo paper Al Akhbar reported today.

title: Whoopee Returns To Broadway Feb. 8
description: Whoopee, a musical comedy hit of half a century ago, will be revived at the ANTA Theater, beginning Feb. 8, with Charles Repole in the starring role originated by Eddie Cantor. The show was written in 1928 by William Anthony McGuire. Among its songs, created by Walter Donaldson and Gus Kahn for a cast that included Mr. Cantor and Ruth Etting, are Makin' Whoopee, Yes, Sir, That's My Baby and Love Me or Leave Me.

title: Undefeated Seton Hall Downs Princeton, 6765
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 6  The Sewn Hall Pirates extended their perfect season's start tonight with a 6765 victory over Princeton for their fourth triumph.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: A heavy slate of new corporate and municipal bonds came to market yesterday, and investors refrained from rushing to buy the major issues.

title: World Gold
description: WEDNESDAY, DEC. 6, 1978

title: Federal Trial on Fire Upheld
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 6 (UPI)  The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit ruled today that a Federal trial in a case involving the fire at the Beverly Hills Supper Club could start as scheduled in February.

title: New Spanish Constitution Gets Big Majority, But Abstentions Are Heavy
description: MADRID, Thursday, Dec. 7  In spite of rain and cold, Spaniards, voting in a momentous referendum, yesterday heavily approved a new, democratic constitution that marks the final, legal rupture with the dictatorial Franco era. But the turnout of voters appeared to be something of a disappointment to the Government.

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, DEC. 6, 1978

title: Opera: Juilliard's Ballo
description: Alarge audience was on hand to greet the opening of the Juilliard American Opera Center's season last night in the Juilliard Theater; Part of the interest was the opera, Verdi's Un Ballo in Maschera, and in the new vocal talent it might reveal. But part also was homage to Tito Gobbi, the famous Italian baritone, who directed the new production. About two years ago Mr. Gobbidirected the group in Verdi's Falstaff, which did not exactly draw rave reviews.

title: Malaysian Aide, in U.S., Defends Treatment of Vietnam Refugees
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  Officially, Malaysia's Education Minister, Musa bin Hitam, is in Washington to lead his country's delegation at a 27nation conference on Asian economic development.

title: Players to Weigh N.F.L. Wage Scale Aimed at Getting Fair Slice of Economic Pie
description: Professional football players are considering a radical new labor approach that would largely replace individual contract negotiations with collective bargaining for specific wage scales.

title: Shell in Gas Allocation
description: The Shell Oil Company announced last night that it was raising its gasoline allocation figure from 75 to 85 percent. That means Shell dealers and distributors can now, count on getting 85 percent of the gasoline they purchased in either December 1977 or December 1972, whichever was higher.

title: Ailey Dances Rainbow
description: DONALD McKAYLE's Rainbow 'Round My Shoulder is now 19 years old. On Tuesday, the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater performed the dance for the first time this season at the City Center. It was clear why Rainbow has survived, in its own quiet way, as a classic of American modern dance.

title: Justice Department May Modify Its Stand on Veteran Preferences
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) The Justice Department hinted today that it might soften its defense of maintaining veterans preferences in hiring and promotions for Government jobs.

title: Bank Data Subpoenaed by U.S. In Search for Guyana Cult Funds
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6  The Justice Department has begun issuing subpoenas for the records of banks in this country and abroad in which the People's Temple and its founder, the Rev. Jim Jones, had deposited more than $10 million.

title: New Lending Policy for InterAmerican Bank
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  After more than eight months of intense negotiations, major contributors to the InterAmerican Development Bank have reached a consensus on a major redirection of the bank's lending policy.

title: HARRISON G. HULL JR.
description: Harrison G. Hull Jr., assistant controller and plan administrator of the Westvaco Corporation's employeebenefit plans, died of a heart attack Saturday in Westport, Conn. He was 53 years old and lived in Westport. Mr. Hull, a graduate of New York University, joined Westvaco, a manufacturer of paper, packaging and chemicals, in 1952.

title: Trash Is Boon In Plan Before Estimate Unit
description: New York City's Board of Estimate, faced with a 1985 deadline for the closing of its landfills, will be asked today to approve a resource recovery proposal as part of a controversial plan by Mayor Koch for the disposal of garbage over the next decade.

title: Minerals to Supply Nuclear Fuels
description: The International Minerals and Chemical Corporation announced it had signed longterm contracts with four New England utilities to supply them with part of their nuclear fuel plant needs through 1992.

title: Bellmore Pupils Make Donation To the Neediest
description: A secondgrade class at the Charies A. Reinhard School in Bellmore, L.I., sent a $15 check to the 67th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, representing nickles and dimes the youngsters had earned doing household chores.

title: Lucile Koshland, at 80; Long in Voters' League
description: Lucile Koshland, a former president of the League of Women Voters of New York State and the wife of Daniel Koshland,the former president of Levi Strauss & Company, died Tuesday at her home in Hillsborough. Calif. She was 80 years old.

title: 2 Arraigned in Murder of Designer
description: Two teenage suspects in last Sunday's fatal stabbing of Irene Maxwell, the Scottish fashion designer, were arraigned yesterday in Manhattan Criminal Court on charges of seconddegree murder and attempted robbery. Judge Brenda Soloff remanded both youths to jail, without bail, pending a preliminary hearing this Friday.

title: Carey Campaign Cost Put at Over $5 Million
description: Governor Carey went deeply into debt in his campaigns for renomination and reelection, a postcampaign financial report showed yesterday.

title: Board of Education Prepares To Close Underused Schools
description: The Board of Education is preparing to close a significant number of underused New York City schools to meet budget cuts and to accommodate a declining student population, according to city officials and a recent memorandum by School Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola.

title: Rangers Trounce Blues, 74
description: How to succeed in the National Hockey League without really trying. That was the scenario for the Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night, thanks to the St. Louis Blues, whom the Rangers trounced, 74.

title: Q&A
description: Q. We have a slate tile floor in our bathroom that had been coated with a sealer before we bought the house. Last year, after following the instructions recommended for cleaning the floor, we put on a polyurethane sealer made for slate floors. However. when it dried we noticed some whitish areas near the base of the toilet, and the sealer did not seem to take on those areas. The manufacturer of the sealer told us to use fine steel wool. We did, but this only scratched the surface without removing any of the whitish stains. Can you tell me how to remove these whitish stains?  Mrs. L.R.. Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: Johnson Succeeds Bragan
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 6 (AP) Johnny Johnson, administrative officer for Commissioner Bowie Kuhn's office since 1970, was elected president of the National Association, baseball's minor league network, today.

title: The Troubled Presidency: II
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. The Nixon Administration witnessed a historic confrontation between two different forms of government: Presidential government and constitutional government. Given the widespread reaction against Presidential government that the confrontation produced, can a strong Presidency be preserved while phasing out an imperial one? Can America enjoy the benefits of both constitutionalism and presidentialism, while avoiding the risk of deadlock on the one hand and of arbitrary rule on the other?

title: A. C.L. U. Sues on Louisiana Law Requiring Itinerant Worker Cards
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 6  The American Civil Liberties Union filed suit today in Federal District Court in Louisiana attacking a new state law empowering seven parish governments to require fingerprinting and special identification cards for itinerant workers.

title: The End of a Dream: Illiteracy Invades The Middle Class
description: AS the evening began, I was suffused with an uncharacteristic sense of confidence that civilization, as civilized men and women understand the term, is flourishing in spite of (and, in part, because of) the disorienting cultural changes of the last 15 years. I had gone to visit an old high school friend on the day after Thanksgiving; she and her husband are restoring a farmhouse on a secluded piece of land just a half hour's drive from Lansing, the capital of Michigan.

title: The Region
description: TRENTON  New Jersey, which instituted a ban on the dumping of most chemical wastes a year ago, yesterday proposed regulations for the registration and operation of hazardouswaste dumps.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  What kind of political news will be made in 1979? To approach that question, let's look at the three levels of news in politics:

title: News Summary
description: Moscow seeks an arms limitation treaty speedily and expanded AmericanSoviet trade, Leonid I. Brezhnev told visiting delegations of United States officials and scores of business executives. The Soviet leader repeatedly stressed his desire for better ties with Washington, but warned that trade would continue to decline unless discriminatory legislation was repealed by Congress. [Page A1, Col.6.]

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.

title: Borough Park Crime Down in 78
description: Police statistics showed yesterday that the Borough Park section of Brooklyn reported crimes in categories involving seven major felonies went up 78 percent from 1973 through 1977, a rate of increase well above the 59 percent for all Brooklyn smith and 28 percent citywide. But for the first eight months this year, Borough Park's reported felonies were down 14.9 percent from last year's 4,416 to 3,756, against a citywide decrease of 8.6 percent.

title: Excerpts From Carter's Speech on Anniversary of Human Rights Declaration
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  Following are excerpts from the White House text of President Carter's speech today before a meeting commemorating the 30th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights:

title: For Christmas Decorations, Pine Cones and Wreaths
description: WITH all the beautiful holiday decorations filling the florist and department stores, deciding on the perfect ornament for your home is all the more challenging.

title: Flammable Fabrics Touch Off Quarrel
description: Washington IN the dawn hours of Nov. 12, a 22yearold woman and her two children died of smoke inhalation after a cigarette set their living room sofa afire in Waukesha, Wis. The sofa had been smoldering for two hours, the authorities estimated.

title: Inspecting Lori Paton's Mail
description: All15yearold Lori Paton wanted was a little information about the Socialist Labor Party for her social studies , course, but she ended up the subject of an F.B.I. investigation and file. Lori had the bad fortune to misdirect her letter to the Socialist Workirs Party when it was under mail cover surveillance because of its unorthodox views. Without opening the envelope, F.B.I. agents recorded her name and address and started an investigation that ran to checks with the local police,.a credit bureau and her school. It was that easy back in 1973, even for a high school student, to fall under Big Brother's scrutiny.

title: U.S. Steel Discloses Talks With China
description: The United States Steel Corporation has been actively negotiating for three months for a contract to build a billiondollar ironore processing complex for China, its president, David AT: Roderick, said yesterday.

title: Moynihan Meets British Aides
description: LONDON, Dec. 6 (Reuters)  Senator Daniel P. Moynihan, Democrat of New York, discussed the Northern Ireland situation at an hourlong meeting with Foreign Secretary David Owen of Britain today. Senator Moynihan, who is to visit Dublin on a private factfinding tour, also met with Roy Mason, the British minister responsible for Northein Ireland.

title: Egypt's Premier Will Meet Israelis In Europe Over Impasse on Treaty
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  Prime Minister Mustafa Khalil of Egypt will meet soon in Europe with Israel's Foreign Minister, Moshe Dayan, and Defense Mi,nister, Ezer Weizman, to discuss the impasse in peace treaty negotiations, diplomatic sources said today.

title: Issue for U.S.: Soviet's Intent
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 6  Recent Soviet involvement in such places as Ethiopia. Vietnam. Cuba and Afghanistan has raised new questions within the Carter Administration over Moscow's intentions. Are the Russians pressing for strategic advantages around the world at Western and Chinese expense or can the developments be explained as fairly harmless?

title: State Accuses 8 L.I. Doctors Of Conspiracy
description: Eight Long Island physicians were indicted yesterday on charges of conspiring to refuse to treat patients covered by the state's workers compensation program and those injured in automobile accidents covered by nofault insurance.

title: Gold Mine Stocks Shine While Market Pauses
description: The stock market paused for breath yesterday after registering substantial advances in three of the four preceding sessions. Prices moved up in the morning, down for most of the afternoon and then edged higher in late trading.

title: Kelly, Nominee as Hospitals Chief, Withdraws After a Critical Report
description: Eamon Kelly withdrew his name yesferday from nomination as New York City's hospital chief after Federal authorities said he had used poor judgment in arranging to have a politically influential Atlanta law firm represent a top labor union official who was under criminal investigation.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Carrier Corporation got a new lease on life as an independent company yesterday when a Federal appeals court in New York barred the United Technologies Corporation from purchasing any Carrier stock until at least Dec. 14.

title: Home Improvement
description: THERE are very few woodworking, painting or finishing projects that do not require at least some sanding in order to achieve a smooth finish. Regardless of whether the work is done by hand or with an electric sander, a familiarity with the various types of sandpaper and their characteristics will save time, effort and money.

title: G.M. Raises Engine Price
description: DETROIT, Dec. 6 (AP)  The General Motors Corporation has increased prices on optional V8 engines by as much as $105 in an effort to discourage motorists from buying the fuelhungry engines.

title: Music
description: JACOB DRUCKMAN's music has been turning up with increasing frequency in 1978. This may be due in part to the fact that he turned 50 this year, providing opportunities for celebrations; more likely it may just be the development that follows op the increasing maturity of a major creative artist.

title: Hers
description: ONE of the predictable reactions to the horror in Guyana was to blame the government. It was the classic American cry, There ought to be a law! These critics insisted that public authorities are too timid about investigating groups that label themselves religious. Their outcry was countered, just as predictably, by the arguments of constitutionalists.

title: Bosworth Expects Minor Guide Shifts
description: The director of the nation's program of wage and price guidelines came to Wall Street yesterday and told an audience of executives that their complaints had been heard: The Administration will announce minor changes in its voluntary guidelines program next week.

title: Amcena Purchase
description: The Amcena Corporation of New York, held by members of the Brenninkmeyer family, which owns Ohrbach's of New York, said it had acquired Maurices Inc. of Duluth. Minn. Maurices operates 175 specialty apparel stores under the names of Maurices, The Wardrobe, The Closet and Mr. Mark. Maurices stores are situated in 18 states throughout the Middle West and Pacific Northwest. The purchase price was not disclosed.

title: Bridge:
description: Representatives of Westchester County and New Jersey, in combination, have had an outstanding record in Grand National Team play recently. Two years ago they reached the national final, and this year the national semifinal, on both occasions after eliminating strong New York City squads.

title: City Collects Some Garbage
description: Fifty city sanitation trucks were diverted yesterday to pick up refuse normally handled by striking private sanitation workers as rotting piles of garbage began to pose mounting health and fire problems.

title: PICTURE FROM VENUS IS A DISAPPOINTMENT
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Dec. 6Pioneer Venus 1 returned its first image of Venus today. It was a lowcontrast picture of the cloudcovered planet with only a quarter of its disk illuminated by the sun.

title: Caring for a Live Christmas Tree
description: The basic rule for harboring a living Christmas tree to keep it short, wet and cool. A balled and burlapped Christmas evergreen is dormant, its light weight reduced to mere subsistance until spring's arrival, when it will once again stretch and grow. But if it mistakes the warm confines of your living room for spring, the tree will let loose early, and then its chance of survival outside following the holidays will be slim.

title: New Controls On Air Traffic
description: It is small consolation for the loss of 144 lives. But the midair collision of a jet airliner and a small private plane over San Diego on Sept. 25 appears to have brightened prospects for a range of airtrafficcontrol improvements that anxions safety experts have long been advocating.

title: Puerto Rico Company Plans Sale
description: The San Juan Racing Association, owner of 10 radio stations in this country and the $45 million El Comandante race track in Puerto Rico, said yesterday that it was negotiating the sale of the company for nearly $65 million  to be paid largely in cash.

title: ARABS IN WEST BANK ASSAIL DEMOLITIONS
description: RAMALLAH, IsraeliOccupied West Bank, Dec. 6  Several hundred high school students and other residents of this Christian Arab center north of Jerusalem paraded in the streets today to protest Israeli demolition of the nearby home of an alleged Palestinian terrorist.

title: The Little Boy in the Rose Deal
description: Sports of The Times

title: The Case of the Useful Carcinogen
description: Are there any circumstances under which substances known to cause cancer should deliberately be added to our food supply? For 20 years Congress has said,  No. But now that saccharin, the last remaining noncaloric sweetener, has been caught in the regulatory web and confirmed in tests with rats as a mild carcinogen, Congress is being forced to reconsider and must decide whether to revise inflexible food additive laws like the controversial Delaney Amendment. That reconsideration is welcome. The laws are two decades old and showing signs of wear.

title: Giants Give a Randolph a Tryout
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 6 Willie Randolph's brother, Terry, who is no baseball player, was given a tryout today by the Giants in hopes that he is a football player.

title: For Nigeria, a Jumbo Loan
description: LONDON, Dec. 6  Looking back, I think we just didn't realize the size of it or the complexities, one Of the key bankers said ruefully. And interest rates, margins and fees are not the be all and endall. There's also market sentiment and the sensibilities of the borrower.

title: Broadcast Expansion Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  The Federal Communications Commission said today that the nation should seek an expanded share of the world's broadcasting spectrum at a Geneva meeting next year, where keen competition is expected between industrial and developing nations.

title: 3 Acquitted in Assaults an Blacks
description: BOSTON, Dec. 6  Three white men were acquitted here today for a November 1977 attack an a group of black tourists near the Bunker Hill Monument in Charlestown. An allwhite jury reached the verdict after deliberating nine hours in Suffolk County Superior Court.

title: TV: James Stewart Gala
description: WELL .. . er ... it's sorta hard to say this, but have you ever had the .. . er . . suspicion that when he's offstage, James Stewart talks just like everyone else? This heretical thought occurred while watching the tribute to filmland's allAmerican grandfather that will be shown tonight from 10 to 11 o'clock on CBSTV.

title: Rose Sets Off Baseball Salary Ripple
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 6  Reaction to the Pete Rose signing left no question today that from now on players, beginning with Dave Parker of Pittsburgh, will look at their futures through Rosecolored glasses. They should, however, also look through glasses that have a tinge of Blue.

title: About Yonkers
description: YONKERS, Dec. 5  Slowly, like the morning's salt pretzels put to the light bulb in the snack bar, the Cross County Shopping Center warms up for another day in another season of Christmas sales. Shoppers are only moments from unsheathing their credit cards as two young men in blue set up a tripod for the familiar red donation kettle of the Salvation Army, inducing kind seasonal thoughts on the dangers of generalizing about cults and their devotions.

title: Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING

title: ALICE M. BROPHY, 68, ADVOCATE FOR AGED
description: Alice M. Brophy, New York City's first Commissioner for the Aging and a leading force for creating and improving programs for the elderly, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a heart attack. She was 68 years old and had undergone a coronary bypass operation last week.

title: U.S. Endorses Monetary Agreement
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  The United States today gave its endorsement to the monetary arrangement that European leaders agreed yesterday to put into effect on Jan. 1 as part of plans to eventually build a common currency.

title: Strike Delays British Trains
description: LONDON, Nov. 6 (Reuters)  A strike by British railroad engineers delayed ens of thousands of Londonbound cornmuters today as they tried to reach the city from the southwest. The engineers have threatened a, series of 24hour strikes until Christmas to press their drive for higher pay.

title: LEGISLATURE MEETS TODAY TO APPROVE NEW MORTGAGE BILL
description: ALBANY, Dec. 6  Mollified by a pledge of additional administrative controls against redlining, or geographic discrimination in mortgage lending, the Assembly's Democratic majority today accepted a bill to raise the maximum interest rate on home mortgages and attempt to thwart redlining as well.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: An effort to get China to limit textile exports to the United States has been undertaken by the Carter Administration. China is this country's sixthlargest foreign supplier of fabrics and its largest single source of cotton textile imports. The Administration's effort aimed at placating domestic producers. [Page D1.]

title: Backgammon:
description: In the last five years, the enormous growth in popularity of backgammon has resulted in many significant theoretical advances. Even though the game is thousands of years old, many fundamental concepts have only recently been discovered. A new generation of talented young players is spearheading this advance.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  Concern for human rights has been an explicit element in American foreign policy for nearly two years. We have learned in that time how difficult it is to apply the concept evenhandedly and effectively. But no one now can doubt the power of the idea.

title: Books of The Times
description: WHAT a character in a play he would have made, if we were still permitted to have characters in plays instead of big ideas. The poet, the dompteur, the lord of the South Sea, the Einstein of the new theatrical forms, comes out of the Black For est at the end of World War I wearing steelrimmed glasses and a leather cap, followed by his friends  the black panther, the tiger and other beasts  who are also wearing steelrimmed glasses and leather caps. The Weimar Republic is in trouble.

title: U.S. Alleges Two in Philadelphia Obstructed City Election Inquiry
