description: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 8, 1978

title: The Question of Health and Safety A Main Issue in Cyanamid Dispute
description: BOUND BROOK, N.J., Dec. 6  In an unusual step, 1,100 striking chemical and maintenance workers at the American Cyanamid Company here have made occupational health and safety a prime issue in contract bargaining.

title: DryGulched by Policy
description: NEW HAVEN The Federal Government, in carrying out its resourcehusbandry program on public lands. is making decisions in distant concrete warrens where Byzantine bureaucratic considerations obscure the biological and cultural issues being debated. Almost incidentally, these decisions, estranged from the temper of people and place, are squeezing the small rancher out of business. The cowboy may soon take a terminal ride into the sunset.

title: What's New in Human Rights
description: President Carter is sounding understandably defensive about his human rights campaign. Now that Richard Nixon, of all people, is presuming to instruct him in a better way to promote freedom  by secret diplomacy of course  Mr. Carter can be forgiven even some belligerence. He has too been effective, he says, and no force on earth is going to deter him.

title: Signs Go Off at the Stadium
description: New York City disclosed yesterday the latest chapter in the long, unhappy saga of Yankee Stadium. It announced that it had forced the Yankees to turn off three lighted signs outside the stadium  at a saving to the taxpayers of $10 a day.

description: The President is reviewing the Defense Department budget right now, a lieutenant in the Pentagon's press office said the other day.Until he makes his decisions, there's nothing I can tell you about what this budget will do for NATO.

title: Guadeloupe: Idyllic Site for Talks
description: President Carter and European leaders will gather for a January summit meeting at a Caribbean vacation spot that has lag been a favorite of Americans and others in search of splendid beaches, picturesque ports and curative hut springs.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: LAST week's Sesame Street Christmas special was on public television and was therefore limited to the show's regular performers. This week's is on a commercial network and is therefore dressed up with expensive guest stars. A Special Sesame Street Christmas, on CBS tonight at 8, mixes Big Bird and friends with Leslie Uggams, host for the occasion, Ethel Mennan, Anne Murray, Imogene Coca, Dick Smothers and, very briefly. Henry Fonda and Michael Jackson.

title: MentalPatient Cutbacks Planned
description: ALBANY, Dec. 7  The State Department of Mental Hygiene, which has sharply reduced its hospital population by releasing large numbers of mental patients to community facilities, announced a fiveyear plan today under which it hopes to achieve further cutbacks by making it harder for new patients to be admitted.

title: Art People
description: CALLING the new artreproduction business set up by Nelson A. Rockefeller a shameful venture, the Art Dealers Association of America has mounted a broadside attack on the booming trade in art knockoffs.

title: Army to Offer Bonuses For Joining the Reserves
description: WASHINGON. Dec. 7 (AP)  The Army announced today that it would offer $1,500 in cash bonuses or $2,000 in education aid to young people who enlist for six years in the Army Reserve or the National Guard, which have been steadily losing strength in recent years.

title: Auctions
description: ALL that glisters is not necessarily Cartier's gold in the auctions scheduled in New York and Los Angeles for next week, but a great deal of it, surprisingly. is. Leftovers from the stock of Cartier of Paris will be sold by Christie, Manson & Woods, Park Avenue at 59th Street, next Tuesday at 10:30 A.M. and from those from Cartier of New York by Sotheby Parke Bernet in Los Angeles next Monday and Tuesday evenings. The differences between the wares in the two sales begins with European taste versus American taste. A Continental clientele inspired the 203 lots at Christie's, pieces that were consigned by the Danziger Brothers, two Englishmen who owned Cartier's in France in the 1960's and sold it in 1972 to Robert Hocq, the present owner, a French industrialist. The Sotheby's sale is of jewelry made for the Kenton Corporation, a conglomerate that owned Cartier in New York from 1968 to 1976, when Mr. Hocq bought the New York branch, reuniting it with all the branches of Cartier under his full command. When he took over, the stock made to the orders of the previous owners, orders in this country and abroad were edited from inventories of the different stores. The range of selections is considerable at Christie's and includes stocking stuffers that are cuter than they are choice  jewelstudded birds, donkeys, dogs and cats that carry presale estimates of $80 to $1,000. The more serious items number a selection of clocks, watches and fine jewelry, expected to sell for $35,000 at the outside.

title: Despair in Sunset Park and Hope, Too
description: The old man who was thinking back to his youth, when there was singing and dancing on 49th Street in .the west Brooklyn neighborhood of Sunset Park, said that the world is upside down these days. He is afraid to go out of doors.

description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange,(A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Dowling 100, Brooklyn Coll. 92
description: Brooklyn College, behind by 3 points with two minutes to play, succumbed to a Dowling freeze that forced the Brooklynites into four consecutive fouls as the Long Island team won, 10092.

title: Publishing: Independent Turns Into Acquisition
description: FOR Donald I. Fine, sole owner and publisher of Arbor House, the acquisition of his independent, trade publishing house by the Hearst Corporation was not without its withdrawal symptoms. On the evening of the signing he felt, he said, a little like a mother who had just given away her newborn child. He found sleep hard to come by and realized he was downing more than his usual quota of spirituous beverages  without, he emphasized, any noticeable effect.

title: Japanese Executive Kidnapped By Four Gunmen in El Salvador
description: SAN SALVADOR, Dec. 7 (AP)  Four armed men kidnapped a Japanese executive of a textile firm whose general manager was abducted and killed by leftists earlier this year, a company spokesman said today.

title: St. John's Wins, 8382; McKoy: 31
description: St. John's Wayne McKoy pumped in a careerhigh 31 points and the Redmen withstood a Baylor rally in the final four minutes last night to achieve an 8382 victory before 3,439 fans at Alumni Hall in Queens.

title: 3Division Proposal for Major Leagues Facing Obstacles
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 7  One of the more sweeping changes in baseball history  splitting the major leagues into three divisions apiece  was formally recommended today to the owners of the 26 teams but the proposal ran into significant opposition.

title: World News Briefs
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 7 (AP)President Anastasio Somoza Debayle says he will lift martial law, free all political prisoners and end restrictions on radio news broadcasts to keep talks going with opposition leaders.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Screen: Brink's Job As Comic Caper:Dream Caper
description: EVERYBODY has his fantasy  the untended candy store, the pay-telephone that offers free calls to Paris, the breakaway bikini and, of course, easy access to the vault of your favorite bank. The seven men who successfully robbed the Brink's armored car company in Boston of more than $2.7 million in January 1950 realized their dream. And, to judge from the continued interest in the caper, they realized the dreams of a lot of other peopleFor one brief instant, the Brink's bandits  small-time hoods who lucked into what was called "the crime of the century"  wallowed in money, green-backs, the kind we carry in our wallets, nothing as esoteric as stocks or bonds or letters of credit. They were up to their ears in the real thing. After that, it was one long hangover. For most of them it wasn't much fun, but it was worth that moment of glorious, physical possession.This is the approach of William Friedkin's "The Brink's Job," which attempts to take a lighthearted view of the robbery, but is only involving when it plays these events more or less straight, something that the 1955 Tony Curtis film, "Six Bridges to Cross," failed to do."The Brink's Job," opening today at the Criterion and Gemini I Theaters, covers a lot more years than any caper movie has any right to do  from the late 1930's to the late 50's  in order to explain the backgrounds of the hoods involved. However, because the characters are so one-dimensional, it seems a waste of the movie's time and ours.It's the kind of movie in which each actor registers just about all he has to work with in any one scene. Essentially they are cartoon types. There is the leader of the gang, a sentimental petty thief named Tony Pino (Peter Falk), who loves his wife, Mary (Gena Rowlands), and pursues his dream to success only because he's too stupid to know better.The other gang members are played by Allen Goorwitz (whom we used to know as Allen Garfield), as Tony's almost fatally clumsy brother-in-law; Peter Boyle, as a short-tempered, mean-spirited Irishman; Paul Sorvino, as a bookie and the one member of the crew who seems capable of spelling his own name correctly; Warren Oates, as a battle-fatigued explosives expert who is not so expert when the chips are down, and Kevin O'Connor and Gerard Murphy as the soldiers of the company.The film, which was written by Walon Green, adapted from a novel by Noel Behn, is neither especially comic nor  and this is surprising, considering Mr. Friedkin's success with "The French Connection"  suspenseful. As in his last film, "Sorcerer," Mr. Friedkin seems bent on supplying us with more sociological information than is entirely necessary, whereas more information about the heist itself would have been welcome. For example, were the Brink's people really as casual about security as they are shown to be in this film?The movie looks very handsome and rather bigger and more expensive than the story actually warrants, except, of course, for the cash we see on screen. The performances are intelligent without being particularly believable or fun. One continually has the impression that Mr. Falk, Mr. Goorwitz and Miss Rowlands are playing down to roles that aren't good enough for them. Mr. Boyle's role is one that he could telephone in by this time. Mr. Sorvino plays it as it comes, which is without fuss but without tremendous conviction. Only Mr. Oates has anything to do as the probably psychologically disturbed war veteran, and he's not around very long."The Brink's Job" doesn't do justice to our fantasy, which is, I suppose, only a misdemeanor."The Brink's Job," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains some vulgar language but little real violence.

title: Operetta: Patience
description: FOR inure than 40 years the Village Light Opera Group has been entertaining itself and New Yorkers with performances of Gilbert and Sullivan operettas, and a number of their productions at the Fashion Institute Theater over the last several years have been of remarkably high quality. This achievement is particularly noteworthy for the reason that the group is a 100 percent volunteer organization.

title: For a Remarkable Judge, A Reluctant Retirement
description: The license plate on Judge Jane M. Bolin's light blue 1972 Dodge reads FCJ1. It stands for Family Court Judge1, and it is the latest in the series of firsts the 70yearold judge has achieved in her life.

title: Rubble of Commune Yields a Tape Of Cultists Dying, Jones Exhorting
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 7  A tape recording of part of the final night of madness at Jonestown has been found among the ruins of the jungle commune, American Government sources disclosed today.

title: 2 Held for Terrorizing Woman, 24
description: Two men kept a 24yearold Manhattan mother of two who had refused to prostitute for them in a state of terror for five months until their apprehension Wednesday night, the police said yesterday.

title: Sindona Aide Testifies
description: A few months before the collapse of the Franklin National Bank in October 1974, its chairman, Harold Gleason, told a member of the board of the bank's holding company that unless something were done about serious foreignexchange losses he would be ruined and forced to resign, the board member testified yesterday.

title: Police Questioning Fellow Officers In Inquiry on Borough Park Melee
description: Detective Stuart Michaels was interviewing witnesses yesterday, as he he had done countless times before. But this time he was asking what happened in his own station house and the people were his brother officers.

title: Lucchesi Tells in Court Of Punk Remark Context
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 7 (UPI)Frank Lucchesi, former manager of the Texas Rangers, testified today how he came to use the word punk four days before he was assaulted by Lenny Randle during soring training in 1977.

title: A Step Up For Duran At Garden
description: Boxing was as active as a threering circus yesterday and, like a threering circus, not everything smelled like cotton candy.

title: Britain Proposes a NATO Meeting With Warsaw Pact
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 7  Britain's Foreign Secretary, Dr. David Owen, proposed today that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization mark its 30th anniversary next spring by opening a political dialogue with the Warsaw Pact in the interests of dtente.

title: Deaths
description: ALEXANDERMae F. On December 6. Beloved wife of the late Herbert M. Dearest mother of Jean A. Marrow. Devoted grandmother of John A., Andrew R., & Pamela Lack. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave at 81 St. on Saturday 79PM. Service Sunder, BethEl Chapel of Temple EmanuEl Fifth Ave at 65 St at 2pm. Contributions may be sent to: New York Service for the Handicapped or Tribute Fund, Temple EmanuEl Women's Auxiliary. Interment private.

title: Disappointments on Two Fronts Trim Stock Prices
description: Mildly disappointing developments on two fronts  wildcat drilling in the Baltimore Canyon and a Government report on November wholesale prices  combined to send stock prices lower yesterday.

title: United Airlines Facing U.S. Sanctions Charges
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (Reuters)  The United States Government filed charges against America's largest airline, United, alleging it had violated sanctions against Rhodesia by training commercial air crews for that African country.

title: Radio
description: 78, WNCN. Lyric Suite, Notturno. Grieg; Fanfares. Mouret; Concerto for Winds, Vivaldi; Sonata in D, Schubert; Overture to an English Opera, Haydn.

title: Books: Free Spirit and Mother of the Arts
description: GIVEN the date of her birth (1875), the size of her fortune (prodigious) and the very dull company that she initially kept at Newport. R. I. and elsewhere. Gertrude Vanderbilt could well have led a perfectly pointless life. Nor did her marriage in 1896 to Harry Payne Whitney predispose her to go onward and upward with the arts. Harry Whitney loved life, and he was the best of companions of pologround and race course, but he was not the man to reassess the motivations of Michelangelo.

title: McEnroe Is at the Top of His Game As He Nears Top of Tennis World
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif., Dec. 7  After he beat Bjorn Borg in Stockholm, it was like a joke. Everywhere he went  shopping for boots in Milan or dancing in London  people pointed. A headline in an Italian paper one day read McEnroe Afraid of Red Brigade. The next day, the paper said he wasn't afraid. It was crazy, wild. And John McEnroe loved every minute of it.

title: Jersey Children Donate to Help Neediest Cases
description: Two New Jersey youngsters were among contributors yesterday to the 67th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. With their gifts they enclosed letters expressing their desire to assist others who are in need.

title: Business and the Law
description: JUST before Mahlon F. Perkins Jr., who had belonged to a large law firm, was sentenced to prison, his lawyer, Harold R. Tyler Jr., a former Federal judge who is currently practicing law at another big firm. addressed the court:

title: House Demoaatic Caucus Slows Down Reform Drive
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 7After caucusing for four days to draw up rules and procedures for the 96th Congress, which convenes Jan. 15, House Democrats headed back to their home districts today, leaving behind a series of decisions that were notable mainly for their restraint and caution.

title: Top Bluegrass Band Making Annual Visit
description: One of the most acclaimed bluegrass bands in the country, the Seldom Scene, will play its annual onenight stand in New York tomorrow night at the Loeb Student Center in Greenwich Villaee.

title: Sharon Says Israel Holds To Policy on Settlements
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 7  Ariel Sharon, Minister of Agriculture with special responsiblity for Israeli settlements, said today during a tour of Jordan Valley settlements that the Government was adhering to its plans to increase the Jewich population on the West Bank of the Jordan, and that this would include new settlements after the Dec. 17 expiration of a threemonth freeze.

title: Advertising
description: BERNARD A. Goldhirsh is a successful publisher of three magazines at the age of 38 because of his ability to perceive a need and then fill it. His fourth title is being started in April and, judging by his assurance of 70 pages of advertising an issue for the first year, he has another success.

title: The Challenge By Rumanians
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7  Rumanian, officials here and in Bucharest have been, telling American officials that Rumania's recent defiance of the Soviet Union, has been motivated mainly by a desire to maintain an independent foreign policy.

title: Bridge:
description: The biggest bridgerelated legal suit in history may be on its way to a disposition out of court within the next six months.

title: The Democratic Party Shelves Plan to Raise Funds by Credit Card
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 7  Stricken with sudden qualms about legality, Democratic Party leaders have quietly shelved their plan to raise political funds through promoting credit cards, which was to have been started at their midterm conference here.

description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, Bizet's Carnen, 1:30; Verdi's Luisa Miller, 8.

description: The trend toward three classes of air service seems in difficulty.

title: Edelman Resigns State Youth Post
description: Governor Carey's Office yesterday announced the resignation of Peter B. Edelman as director of the. State Division for Youth, effective Dec. 31. He becomes the first commissioner to leave the Carey Administration since the Governor's reelection last month.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on Page 28.

title: Suicide Among Students Alarms West Germans
description: BONN  This school year win end in death by suicide for more than 500 children in West Germany, if the statistics of previous years hold true. An estimated 19,000 schoolage youngsters will try to kill themselves and a shockingly high number of young children, one in every three under 16 years of age, will suffer serious symptoms of stress caused by what the Germans refer to as Schulangst  roughly, school anxiety.

title: Deaths

description: Mayor Koch announced yesterday the resignation of David W. Brown, his topmost Deputy Mayor, and a concurrent reorganization of his cabinet to divide the functions that Mr. Brown had performed.

description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday, Dec. 8,1978

title: Bridge:
description: In bridge, as in anything else, the short run is unpredictable. This accounts, in part, for the popularity of Swiss team contests. In a short match of seven or nine deals, four good players have a fair chance to defeat lour experts. In a long knockout match, a similar upset would be most unlikely.

title: Morgan Foresees Possible Recession
description: The Morgan Guaranty Survey, a monthly publication of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, issued a gloomy forecast yesterday on the nation's economy for the next six months, concluding that a recession may be hard to avoid.

title: Around the Nation
description: IDAHO FALLS, Idaho, Dec. 8 (AP) A cold snap has delayed the test of a nuclear reactor safety system until at least tomorrow afternoon, the Department of Energy announced after today's test was called off.

title: Letter: On UNESCO Press Code
description: To the Editor:

title: My Car Bungle Hurts
description: WILLSBORO, N.Y.My car carries no I Love N.Y. bumper sticker, but it one were available that said, My Sympathy. N.Y. I would paste it on.

title: Suns, Led by Westphal, Set Back Celtics, 124104
description: BOSTON, Dec. 8 (AP)  Paul Westphal, one of the National Basketball Association's leading scorers, pumped in 30 points tonight as the Phoenix Suns snapped the Boston Celtics' fourgame winning streak with a 124104 victory.

title: Newark School Board Will Discharge 1,73 And Eliminate Frills
description: NEWARK, Dec. 8  The Newark Board of Education, signalling a change in educational policy, voted today to dismiss nearly 2,000 school employees, almost onefourth of the 8,000 employees in the system.

title: Female Cadets In Jersey Police May Get Break
description: TRENTON, Dec. 8  John J. Degnan, New Jersey's Attorney General, said today that the physical requirements for female candidates for the state police might have to be modified to permit more of them to join the force.

title: Dr. Ralph S. Halford, Leader in Chemistry; At Columbia 32 Years
description: Dr. Ralph S. Halford, a dean, professor emeritus and vice president of Columbia University, died yesterday at his borne in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 64 Years old.

title: Vietnamese Advancing on a Key Cambodian Area
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 8  The Vietnamese forces in Cambodia are continuing their advance northeastward from the border and are reported to be within 25 miles of the Mekong River town of Kratie, the headquarters of Cambodia's northeastern region, a Western analyst said today.

title: Ensemble Studio Group Shows 3 OneAct Plays
description: Last spring, in an attempt to revive neglected theatrical form, Curt Dempster's Ensemble Studio Theater presented a marathon of 19 oneact plays. From that anthology the company has selected a trio of oneacts, linking them under the title Three. The plays have a number of points in common in addition to their brevity. They are by new writers. They offer small but choice roles. They all deal with games; two of them are about children at their games. Competition is a unifying theme.

title: Indexed Mortgage Called Aid to New York Market
description: With the enactment of a law providing indexed ceilings on homemortgage loans yesterday, New York State has at a stroke markedly strengthened its laggard position in the competition for mortgage funds. The longterm ramifications are significant not only for housing producers but also for sellers and buyers of existing homes.

description: Alexander, Mae

title: Jobless Rate Holds Firm at 5.8%; Employment in November Rises
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8  The unemployment rate held at 5.8 percent of the work force in November, even though the number of Americans holding jobs rose sharply.

title: Weeden Reports Deficit Of $23.7 Million for Year
description: The Weeden Holding Corporation reported yesterday that it lost $23.7 million in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30. compared with a deficit of $2.23 million in the previous fiscal year.

title: Deaths
description: ROUSEHelen Macdonald on December 5. 1978. dearly loved wife of Marshall J., devoted mother of Anne R. Harding and Ellen J. Rouse. loving grandmother of Lawrence M. end Elizabeth A., dear sister of the late Jessie. Florence and Kathleen. Loving motherinlaw and avid of Lawrence Herding and Dr. Thomas E. Lovell and family. Mass et Chrisflan Burial at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church. Saturday, December 9. at 9:30 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Memo Says Racism Split Jones Followers in California
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 8  A confidential document recovered from Jonestown reports that the San Francisco headquarters of the People's Temple, cult that had proclaimed itself an island of racial tranquillity, was riven with bitter dissension between blacks and whites.

title: INDICTMENTS HINTED IN INQUIRY ON LANCE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8  The Justice Department invited Bert Lance to testify before a Federal grand jury in Atlanta about a month ago, indicating that its investigation of his financial affairs is nearing conclusion and that indictments may be expected, according to sources familiar with the process.

title: Golda Meir: Peace and Arab Acceptance Were Goals of Her 5 Years as Premier
description: For five years Golda Meir was Prime Minister of Israel. Her oftenstated ambition was to see Israel accepted by its Arab neighbors and living in peace. With firmness and determination, she sought but failed to achieve those aims. We say peace and the echo comes back from the other side, war,  she once lamented. We don't want wars even when we win.

title: New York Energy Chief Skeptical of Oil Shortage
description: ALBANY, Dec. 8  New York State's Commissioner of Energy today charged the oil industry with exaggerating the threat of an oil shortage as part of a rather cynical publicrelations gamble designed to raise the price of fuel.

title: Close Vote Over P.S.A. Is Expected
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 On Sept. 25, a Pacific Southwest Airlines jet crashed at San Diego, killing 144 persons in America's worst air disaster and by coincidence Harold C. Simmons of Dallas quietly bought 29,500 shares of P.S.A.

title: Income Loss vs. Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8  There is no allowance for catching up for past years, Alfred E. Kahn, the chairman of the Council on Wage and Price Stability, told state legislators Monday in asking them to limit the salary increases they vote for themselves to conform to the Administration's pay guideline. If you always say that anybody who has fallen behind has a right to catch up, then you have built in a permanent engine of inflation, Mr. Kahn told a business audience later. Catchup equals inflation.

title: The City
description: With the assignment of additional agents to the investigation, the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration stepped up its inquiry yesterday into the theft of about 1,300 pounds of Colombian marijuana that had been stored by the Government in a leased warehouse in Brooklyn.

title: Alcoa Considers Projects in China
description: A group of engineers from the Aluminum Company of America left for southern China this week to look at possible sites for setting up mines, processing plants and smelters for aluminum.

title: Quarterback Giants Traded Away
description: In the furor over the flop of the New York Giants, perbaps the most familiar complaint is that they need a quarterback. But many people seem to have forgotten that the Giants had a quarterback. His name is Francis Asbury Tarkenton and at age 38 he has been the National Football League's best quarterback this season. He has completed record 304 passes for 2,921 yards and 21 touchdowns for the Minnesota Vikings, who play the Detroit Lions today. He has added to his career records that deserve to be chiseled onto

title: Rostropovich as Conductor
description: It seemed strange to find Mstislav Rostropovich making a debut with the New York Philharmonic on Thursday night. After all, as a cello soloist, the Russian musician had performed with the orchestra many times in the last 22 years. But this time he was was appearing as a conductor, a calling he turned to comparatively late in life, and so successfully that he is now music director of Washington's National Symphony.

title: Suit by Lucchesi Ends Amicably
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 8 (AP)  After three days of testimony, a damage suit filed by Frank Lucchesi, former manager of the Texas Rangers, stemming from a 1977 fight with Lenny Randle ended in handshakes and an amicable outofcourt settlement today. No terms were disclosed.

title: U.S. to Give Retailers Price Test
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8  The Council on Wage and Price Stability is devising a markup test for retailers, wholesalers and food processors as Hart of the guideline for price restraint.

title: Nets Beat Bullets By 108100
description: LANDOVER, Md., Dec. 8  The surprising New Jersey Nets completed their longest trip of the season by coolly controlling the league champion Washington Bullets tonight in a 108100 victory. The Nets triumph was secured by John Williamson's 40 points, a season high, andrieorge Johnson's shotblocking.

title: 5 Probes Are Reported on Target As They Plunge Toward Venus
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Dec. 8 The five instrumented probes of Pioneer Venus 2 raced in toward the planetary target tonight, their radios silent to conserve energy for returning data tomorrow during their plunge into the dense Venusian atmosphere.

title: Duran Stops Brooks in Eighth
description: When Roberto Duran fights, the boxing world pays attention, even when the man with the socalled hands of stone goes into the ring 12 pounds over the weight limit for the lightweight division he has ruled for seven years.

title: Bolles Slayer Draws 48 Years
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 7 (AP)  John Harvey Adamson, one of three men convicted in the slaying of a Phoenix reporter, Don Bolles, has been sentenced to 48 to 49 years in Prison We are still inveatigating an matters that came up with the name of Don Bolles, the prosecutor, William Schafer 3d, said today after the sentence was handed down by Pima County Superior Court Judge Ben Birdsall. I don't see a time when we win stop investigating. Mr. Adamson entered a guilty plea to a charge of seconddegree murder in January 1977 as his trial for the death of Mr. Bolles was about to begin.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Rubber Talks End in Geneva
description: GENEVA, Dec. 8  Leading producer and consumer countries of natural rubber ended tonight an inconclusive attempt to draft a pact to stabilize the price of the commodity by agreeing to resume the effort before next May.

title: Bomb Wrecks Soweto Building
description: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 8 (Reuters)A bomb exploded last night in the black township of Soweto, severely damaging the main administrative building, the police reported today.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 9, 1978

title: Golda
description: The miracle of Gold Meir was how one person could so perfectly embody the spirit of so many. A refugee from Russia, a dreamer in the United States and a leader of Israel, she embodied the hopes, fears, sentiment and obstinacy of Jews everywhere. And to all the rest of the world, she was their voice.

title: Singer, in His Nobel Lecture, Hails Yiddish
description: STOCKHOLM, Dec. 8  The sound of language from a world that hardly exists any more filled the assembly hall of the Swedish Academy today. Its master, Isaac Bashevis Singer, said in his Nobel Prize Lecture on Literature that in its way it is the language of us all, the idiom of frightened and hopeful humanity.

title: Encompass Theater Performs A Thread of Scarlet
description: One of the more sensational scandals of Brooklyn when the town across the river was known as the city of churches is the subject of A Thread of Scarlet, the current work being given by Encompass Theater on West 48th Street.

title: For Iranians, the Mullah's Orders Are Law
description: BABUL, Iran  A story is much repeated in this prosperous resort city on the Caspian Sea, 140 miles north of Teheran, about a hapless policeman who had the audacity to approach a mullah while he was exhorting a crowd on the street, and to tell him to move along. Without word, one of the faithful stepped forward, pulled a knife, disemboweled the soldier and then went back to listening to the mullah.

title: An Old Custom Helps to Enrich Fund for Needy
description: A custom that has existed for many years was recalled yesterday by Mrs. Morris Rotenberg of Forest Hills, Queens, as she sent her yearly contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. In hailing the 67th annual campaign, Mrs. Rotenberg wrote:

title: Prospects Looking Up For U.S. Downhill Squad
description: SCHLADMING, Austria, Dec. 8The United States men's downhill skiing team, which failed to win a World Cup point last season, showed sips of startling improvement here today in the final two training runs before the season opens this weekend.

title: Federal Grand Jury, Questions Cult Survivors in San Francisco
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8  A special Federal grand jury met here today to begin questioning 11 survivors of the People's Temple about the murder of Representative Leo J. Ryan.

title: Lyce Franais, a School Where French Is a Way of Life
description: The youngsters from East 95th Street, wearing blue and gray, seem at a glance no different from all the other privateschool students who emerge onto upper Fifth Avenue each afternoon. But behind the black doors of the Lvcee Francais de New York. where they spend the day, all of them whether they are American or French or Senegalese or German  become as French as the schoolchildren in Paris, taking the same lessons that thousands of pupils in France do.

title: China Is Said to Plan Trade Laws To Protect Foreign Investor Rights
description: TOKYO, Dec. 8  China has told Japanese executives it plans to enact an ambitious set of commercial laws early next year to guaranteethe rights of foreign investors in joint ventures and to protect their patents.

title: Dexter Stages Don Pasquale for Miss Sills at Met
description: Donizetti's Don Pasqualet never missing for a long time from any opera house, returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday night after an absence of a few years. It was a brandnew ,production, conceived by John Dexter, with sets and costumes by Desmond Heeley.

title: An Unchanged Storyteller
description: One day in the 1930's, the story goes, an editor at The Jewish Daily Forward, a Yiddish newspaper in New York, was giving some advice on writing to a new and very junior contributor when the new man flew into a rage. Don't try to teach me Yiddish! he cried. I know how to write Yiddish!

title: McEnroe Wins, Gottfried Loses Marathon in Davis Cup Openers
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif., Dec. 8 Trailing by two sets to love and about to be counted out at match point in the third, Buster Mottram mustered a stunning fiveset marathon victory over Brian Gottfried today and gave Britain a 11 standoff with the United States after the opening day of the Davis Cup final.

title: Preserving Our City's Wetlands
description: In and around the New Ydrk metropolitan area, from Orchard Beach in the northeast to the shores of the Raritan River in New Jersey, are natural areas of significant ecological and economic importance.

title: Against an Assistant Supreme Court
description: Is the Supreme Court dangerously overloaded? Three justices think so and have revived previously ignored proposals for new high courts to relieve the one we have. In a long dissent the other day, Justices White and Blackmun complained that worthy cases were not getting a hearing because petitions and appeals continue to pile up in record numbers. This gave Chief Justice Burger a cue to argue once more for some sort of auxiliary tribunal. The WhiteBlackmun opinion is new but the arguments are familiar. We agree with Justice Brennan that the need has not been proved.

title: A Great Day for Jewish Forward: Its Writer and Yiddish Honored
description: It took the entire 82 years since its founding, and finally The Jewish Daily Forward had a headline to warm even those Jewish hearts grown cold with disappointment and waiting: Isaac Basilevis Singer Begins His Nobel Lecture in Yiddish.

title: Blumenthal: '79 Growth Low as 2%
description: BONN, Dec. 8  Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal conceded today that real economic growth in the United States next year could be as low as 2 percent, but he continued to rule out the possibility of a recession.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Worldwide sales of Volkswagen AG, climbed 11 percent to about $10 billion in the first three quarters of this year, raising profits in the period by 36 percent, to about $196 million against $144 million from the comparable yearago period. Friedrich Thomee, the company's finance director, announced the results yesterday in Wolfsburg, West Germany, the company's headquarters.

title: EARNINGS
description: Esmark Inc. reported yesterday that its profits increased 13.7 percent in the fiscal fourth quarter and rose 7.2 percent in the full fiscal year ended Oct. 28. The company said the improvement largely reflected earnings gains by its Swift & Company meatpacking subsidiary.

title: About New York
description: Even before Walter C. McSherry moved to an apartment on West End Avenue near Lincoln Center, he figured he knew what urban sophistication was, because he was raised in McAllister, Okla. McAllister had the largest population  16,000  and the largest theater, the Busby, between Dallas and St. Louis.

title: Guyana Says It Belatedly Received Tape of the Jones Cultists Dying
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 8  A spokesman for the Government of Guyana said today that the Government was not giVen a copy of a tape recording of the death scene at Jonestown, found by the American authorities, until last Wednesday, nearly three weeks after the mass deaths at the People's Temple commune.

title: Newspaper Strike Negotiations In St. Louis Recess Until Monday
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 7 (UPI)  Negotiations to end the city's 10dayold strike of newspaper pressmen bogged down in a sixhour session today and were recessed until Monday.

title: How State Senafors Voted On the MortgageLoan Bill
description: ALBANY, Dec. 8  Following is the rollcall vote by which the State Senate voted early this morning to raise the state's mortgage interest ceiling and to prohibit banks from denying loans on the basis of geographic discrimination:

title: Carter's Inflation Plans Draw Fire As Democrats Convene at Midterm
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 8  Democrats from across the country assembled today for the party's first midterm conference on issues, quarreling over whether to honor President Carter or attack his antiinflation stands.

title: Post Office Sets SameDay Mail
description: The United States Postal Service has announced that its board of governors has tentatively accepted plans for a sameday intracity courier service.

title: RUMANIANS RECEIVE CARTER ASSURANCES
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, Dec. 8  The United States Secretary of the Treasury, W. Michael Blumenthal, arrived here tonight with a message from President Carter to President Nicolae Ceausescu expressing support of Rumania in its dispute with the Soviet Union.

title: A.A.U Penalizes 18 Swimmers
description: Five of the nation's outstanding swimmers have been barred from international competition for two years in a surprisingly strong crackdown by the Amateur Athletic Union over violations of its disciplinary code.

title: Ballet Puertorriqueo to Open
description: Ramon Segarra, a former member of the New York City Ballet and associate director and ballet master of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, has announced the opening of the debut season of the Ballet Puertorriqueo on Dec. 14 at the Riviera Theater in San Juan, P.R. The company, formerly known as the Ballet Teatro de San Juan, will present four performances.

title: Harvard Seeks Brustein And His Theater at Yale
description: An ambitious theatrical transfer that would bring to Harvard University Robert Brustein, the outgoing dean of the Yale Drama School, and the Yale Repertory Theater that he created and lifted to a position of some eminence in his 13 years at New Haven, will be proposed on Monday by Derek Bok, Harvard's president, and considered by the Cambridge institution's board of overseers.

title: Golda Meir, 80, Dies in Jerusalem; Israelis Acclaim Stalwart Lioness
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 8  Golda Meir, a onetime teacher in Milwaukee who became Prime Minister of Israel, died this afternoon at the age of 80.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 8 (AP)  Don January shot an eightunderpar 64 today and took a fivestroke lead after 36 holes in the Mexico Cup golf tournament.

title: Text of the Nobel Lecture by Isaac Bashevis Singer
description: STOCKHOLM, Dec. 8 (AP)  Following is the text of Isaac Bashevis Singer's Nobel lecture, delivered today before the Swedish Academy.

title: Arson Exhibits in Waldbaum Fire May Have Been Faked, Police Say
description: Distict Attorney Eugene Gold in Brooklyn is studying evidence submitted by police investigators that the Fire Department may have faked some exhibits in its inquiry into last August's Waldbaum supermarket fire to show possible arson.

title: MORTGAGERATE BILL IS SIGNED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, Dec. 8  Governor Carey signed into law today a bill raising the interest rate on home mortgages and making it illegal to redline, that is, deny mortgage loans in New York State on the basis ofgeographic discrimination.

title: OBSERVER
description: Texans must be enjoying the peevish whining with which New York has responded to the American Airlines snatch.

title: Occidental Petroleum's Internal Audit Discloses $30 Million in Payments
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8  The Occidental Petroleum Corporation, under questionable legal circumstances, has dispensed about $30 million since 1969, including secret payments to an Arab prince, a Nigerian diplomat and unidentified persons who may have been evading taxes and currency exchange laws in foreign countries, according to an internal corporate audit.

title: Judge Reinforces Rules On Construction Hiring
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP)  A Federal judge has put legal weight behind a set of Government regulations that require construction companies doing business with the Federal Government to hire more women.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: AIMS AND THE MAN The United States Constitution and its interpretations by the late Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, William O. Douglas, will dominate the stage of the Broadway Theater tomorrow night at 8 o'clock, as prominent figures in theater, politics and communications, led by Henry Fonda, give a twohour Reading of the Constitution. The reading will be interpolated with additional material from Supreme Court decisions and the writings of Justice Douglas, as arranged in a format by Robert B. McKay, former dean of the New York University Law School.

title: Carew Rejects Offer; Twins Get Koosman
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 8  Rod Carew said no to the San Francisco Giants, at least for now, but it was still go for Jerry Koosrnan today. The Mets sent the last of their World Series pitchers home to Minnesota for a minor league pitcher and a player to be named later.

title: Democrats in Memphis: Of Birds, Sorghum and Sincerity
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 8  Democratic advancemen, arriving early at their headquarters hotel, the Rivermont, attempted to have three myna birds removed from their cage in the bar, fearful that their squeaking would irritate the delegates.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Carter Administration may ask consumers to boycott businesses that violate its price guidelines, according to Alfred Kahn, chairman of the Council on Wage and Price Stability. He said the Government was considering the boycott request in order to put teeth into a largely voluntary program. He also said that the Administration was thinking about denying revenuesharing funds to state and local governments that exceed guidelines. [Page 1.]

title: New York State Rate Of Unemployed Off; Jobs at Record Total
description: The unemployment rate in New York State tell in November to its lowest point in four years, while a record number of nearly 7.5 million state residents held jobs, the United State Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Namibians Speak Out Against U.N.'s Election Plan
description: TSANDI, SouthWest Africa, Dec. 6At this remote tribal settlement in the semidesert of Ovamboland, where twothirds of the people are illiterate and all but a handful live in thatched huts, even goatherds have opinions about the United Nations.

title: U.S. Urges Renewal of Peace Effort To Honor the Memory of Mrs. Meir
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8  President Carter and Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance urged a rededication to Middle Eastern peace efforts in memory of Golda Meir, the former Prime Minister of Israel, who died today.

title: Jerome Greene, 73, an Executive With Helmsley Spear Since 1955
description: Jerome Greene, vice president of Helmsley Spear Inc., died Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 45 East End Avenue.

title: Two Student Suicides Stun Ridgewood
description: RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 8  Two high school juniors hanged themselves in this affluent suburban community this week, stunning and perplexing its uppermiddleclass population, stirring apprehension among school administrators that other despondent or emotionally upset teenagers might commit suicide, and prompting them to seek closer bonds between adults and youngsters.

title: Giants' Owners Assailed
description: While the Giants continued planning for next year by signing such stalwarts as Fred Besana and Randy Cottleld yesterday, some of their disgruntled fans were planning ahead, too.

title: Croats and Serbs in Chicago: Pride and Fear Over Growing Violence
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 7  Two Croats stand convicted in the recent armed takeover of the West German Consulate here. Six Serbs have just been indicted on charges that they plotted to kill Marshal Tito on his visit to Washington last March. A dozen Chicago businessmen of Croatian descent have complained of extortion threats from a purported nationalist band.

title: Jascalevich Hasn't Sought License, Medical Examiners Board Declares
description: Although the jury that acquitted Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich of murder has made an unusual demand that he be allowed to resume his profession as a surgeon, Dr. Jascalevich has not requested that his license be restored, the New Jersey Board of Medical Examiners said Yesterday.

title: Judge to Decide Becton Suit
description: A 15day trial that ended yesterday in Manhattan Federal Court sought to determine whether the Sun Company, Salomon Brothers and others illegally formed a secret purchasing group and then offered to buy big blocks of Becton, Dickinson & Company stock without public disclosure.

title: Deregulation Delay Is Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8  Two Congressional specialists in transportation today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to stop its efforts to relax its regulatory control of surface transportation until Congress acted to change legislation.

title: Governor of New Mexico Runs Into Trouble Here
description: Jerry Apodaca was jogging his daily 10 miles, when he missed some turns in Central Park and got lost. It was 5:30 in the evening, it had turned dark and he was in Harlem, with no taxi in sight.

title: Private Sanitationmen Dig Out as Strike Ends
description: A seemingly unending stream of trucks dumped their contents at the Gansevoort dump yesterday, as sanitation workers for private carting companies sought to clear the streets of a week's accumulation of garbage. Workers reached a new threeyear agreement on Thursday that would raise average salaries by $65 a week and provide sick pay..

title: Television
description: Morning

title: World News Briefs
description: HAVANA, Dec. 8 (AP)  A Cuban exile delegation meeting with President Fidel Castro reached agreement today for the release of some 3,000 political prisoners and for the reunification of families separated by political differences, a Miami banker announced.

title: U.S. Envoy in Iran Opposed Decision to Aid Dependents' Departures
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8  The White House decision to allow American military and civilian dependents to fly out of Iran at Government expense went against recommendations of the United States Ambassador in Teheran, Administration officials said today.

title: World Leaders and Friends Hail Extraordinary Woman
description: Golda Meir was mourned and praised yesterday by presidents and prime ministers, mayors and governors, Jews and nonJews.

title: The Elements Of Style, Soto Speak
description: The subject was Have Men Got It? and about 80 people  most of them women  showed up the other night at the Central Synagogue auditorium on East 55th Street to find out. The program was me nexttotast to the Hunter College Center for Lifelong Learning series entitled The Stylemakers, the aim of which, according to Dr. Richard M.Huber, the center's executive director, is to take a frivolous subject and treat it seriously.

title: Talking Straight to Hanoi
description: How can the United States best assure that its interests are not compromised by the new Indochina war, which pits Vietnam, backed by the Soviet Union, aeainst Cambodia, backed by China? Because Hanoi's ties to Moscow have been dramatically reinforced recent months, the United States cannot be indifferent to a result that might not only alter the regional balance of power but also affect the SinoSoviet rivalry. Yet Washington seems increasingly blind to a truth should have learned through its own bitter experience in Southeast Asia: Hanoi is an independent actor, not a mere Soviet proxy.

title: Benefit for Flood Draws Few Benefactors
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., Dec. 8  Dr. William A. Reishtein, a retired gynecologist and an earthy conversationalist, whose lofty life goals include (1) money, (2) power and (3) the amelioration of the human condition, was in a bit of a snit today. An untouched reuben sandwich lay before the doctor as he stared through the tines of his fork at a visitor.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Sagan's Sunrise ... Sunset Is Danced
description: As an artistic director of a Moderndance company, Alvin Ailey  more than anyone else  has made the repertory concept a working policy. Consistently, he has brought in choreogra. phers other than himself to stage their works or revive classics for his dancers.

title: Market Continues To Retreat
description: Stock prices continued to slide in slow trading yesterday as civil unrest in Iran and sobering comments on prospects for the United States economy in 1979 aroused concern among investors.

title: Sadat Terms Mrs. Meir Honest Foe, First Class
description: CAIRO, Dec.8 (UPI)  President Anwar elSadat said today that he had received with sorrow news of the death of former Prime Minister Golda Meir of Israel. He described her as a firstclass political leader and an honest foe.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Harry Winston, a World Leader In Diamond Trade, Is Dead at 82
description: Harry Winston, the Fifth Avenue jeweler who donated the Hope diamond to the Smithsonian Institution 20 years ago, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home in Manhattan. He was 82 years old.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, DEC. 8, 1978

title: Backlash Seen Harming Drive To Shield Press
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP)  A public backlash to the insistence of newsgathering organizations on more protection from government interference may lead to greater restrictions than there ought to be, a Yale law professor, Robert Bork, said today.

title: Pact Signed By Norway, Sweden
description: OSLO, Dec. 8 (Reuters)  Norway and Sweden decided today to enter into a farreaching industrial cooperation project that was expected to be sharply criticized in the Norwegian Parliament and possibly lead to a Government crisis.

title: Deaths
description: DOUGHERTYRev. Msgr. Denial M. on December 7, 1978 at Stowe, Vermont. Pastor Emeritus St. Patrick's Churdi. Vaplatok, N.Y. Devoted brother of Rev. Msgr. John C. Dougherty and SistaWary Daniel. Reposing at St. Patrick's School Hall. Verpland. front 2PM until SPM & 7PM until 10PM Saturday end 2PM until SPM Sunday. Mass of the Holy Eucharist at St. Patrick's Church ay Sunday, December, 10 at SPM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Patrick's Church on MOnday, December 11 at 10AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Insurance Rate Move Deferred
description: DETROIT, Dec. 8  By a unaminous vote today, the National Association of Insurance Commissioners deferral until June action on a studygroup recommendation that marital status and sex be dropped as criteria that automobile insurers may use in determining rates.

title: F.A.A. REVISES RULE CITED IN JET CRASH
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8  The Federal Aviation Administration disclosed yesterday that it had revamped an airtraffic procedure whose bearing on the Sept. 25 midair collision in San Diego has been a prime issue in the inquiry into the cause of the accident.

title: Tennis Stars to Bypass Masters
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif., Dec. 8 Bjorn Borg and Guillermo Vilas have decided to bypass the Grand Prix Masters tennis tournament Jan. 1014 at Madison Square Garden.

title: The Region
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  Justice Arthur M. Cromarty of State Supreme Court yesterday granted a request by the Suffolk County District Attorney to impanel a third grand jury next month to investigate the controversial $832 million Southwest Sewer District project.

title: Creatures Stirring In Holiday Windows
description: Freddie the Fox is up to all sorts of mischief in B. Altman's windows. At Lord & Taylor, the gang is coming home for Christmas by air, car, subway and even the Roosevelt Island tramway. There isn't a jewel in the delightful Christmas scenes at Tiffany, while Cartier's gingerbread houses are lavishly decorated with diamonds and rubies. Saks, which is fond of fantasy, is fantasizing about the 12 days of Christmas this year. And as for F.A.O. Schwarz, bless each and every one for the new animated figures replacing the clutter of past Yuletides.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE CULTURE OF NARCISSISM. By Christopher Lasch 268 pages. W.W. Norton. $11.95.

title: Hong Kong Stocks Sink Anew
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 8  For the second time in five years, the small investors and speculators in this crown colony's volatile stock market have sown the wind and reaped the whirlwind. Last month, punctured by a sharp runup in interest rates, the Hong Kong stock market broke and plunged 33 percent.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Gold futures commanded center stage in commodity trading yesterday after being upstaged earlier this week by other commodities such as soybeans.

title: Corporate Earnings Reported
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: SHAH, IN A RETREAT, AGREES TO LET FOES PARADE TOMORROW
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 8  The Iranian Government retreated tonight from a showdown with its religious and political foes by authorizing street processions on Sunday and Monday.

title: Council on Fitness Reorganized
description: President Carter has replaced virtually his entire Council on Physical Fitness and Sports and directed its new chairman to revitalize the program, which has been dormant for more than two years.

title: Slaying Suspects Set for Lineup
description: A business associate of Irene Maxwell, a young fashion designer from Scotland who was slain on a street in the Tribeca district of lower Manhattan last Sunday, will view a lineup in the Manhattan District Attorney's office next week that will include two teenagers charged in the murder. The associate, Stacy Albert, witnessed the killing and will be asked on Dec. 15 if she can identify the two suspects, Earvin Edwards, 17 years old, and Arnold Stokes. 15. as the assailants.

title: Chip Carter Is Working As Aide at Convention
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 8 (UPI)  President Carter's son, Chip, is working as a leg man for the Democratic National Committee at its midterm miniconvention.

title: A Final Gavel and a Last Bow Close Two Albany Careers
description: ALBANY, Dec. 8  Speaker Stanley Steingut, nothing less than a virtuoso at conducting the Assembly, waved his baton early yesterday morning for the last time. He was directing the performance of Assemblyman Clark Wemple, a Republican from Schenectady, who was wondering what had happened to his resolution condemning Governor Carey's plans to put a $60,000 bubble over his swimming pool.

title: Carter Congratulates Ohira
description: TOKYO, Dec. 8 (Reuters)  President Carter suggested today to the new Japanese Prime Minister, Masayoshi Ohira, that they try to meet before the conference on Jan. 5 and 6 on the island of Guadeloupe in the Caribbean of the leaders of the United States, France, West Germany and Britain. A Government spokesman said Mr. Carter made the suggestion during a congratulatory telephone call to Mr. Ohira, who was confirmed as Prime Minister by Parliament yesterday.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON Asignature verification system that was patented this week is regarded as potentially valuable in preventing forgeries and controlling confidential information, as well as access to restricted areas. When a signsture is written, its dynamic characteristics, including the acceleration and pressure with which the pen is used, are automatically compared with electrical records of the genuine one.

title: A Study Finds Birds and Dam Able to Coexist
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8  Completion of the Grayrocks dam in southeastern Wyoming would not threaten migrating whooping cranes so long as enough water was released from the darn to preserve the crane habitat along the Platte River.

title: Deaths
description: ALEXANDERMae. The Board & Staff of the New York Service for the Handicapped record with profound sorrow the death of Mae Alexander. As Board member, Treasurer & Chairman, her 45 years of service was an Inspiration to us all. Her concern for the disabled was unsurpassed. She chose be rather than pity & rejoiced In their success, whether at the Alexander School for disabled adults or Camp Oakhurst. Only months ago, she visited with the handicapped children at camp. Her love for them found expression in service. They will miss her concern. We will miss her warmth. To her devoted family go our sincere expression of sympathy.

title: 4 TeenAgers Killed And 22 Hurt in Texas In a School Bus Crash
description: ROBY, Tex., Dec. 8 (UPI)  A tractor trailer rammed a school bus at a rural intersection today, killing four junior high school basketball players and injuring 22 others.

title: Bonn's Growth Forecast
description: BONN, Dec. 8 (AP)  The West German Economics Minister, Otto Lambsdorff, and the economics ministers of the German states agreed today that real 1979 growth in West Gennany would be 3.5 to 4 percent, a spokesman for the Economics Ministry said. The forecast is the same as that made by a Government panel of economic experts in late November. The panel also predicted then that 1978 growth would be 3 percent.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: ELLIS L. HALL
description: HAMDEN, Conn., Dec. 8 (AP)  Ellis L. Hall, a founder of the school that became Quinnipiac College, died at his home here after a long illness.

title: Deaths
description: MEIRGolds. The American Section of the World Zionist Organization Executive expresses ifs profound sorrow over the Passing of Israel's Peremial Great Lady'. who in her own life exemplified the finest traditions and values of the Zionist movement. Singlerninded in her love for her people and in her devotion to the, Jewish State. she combined an Iron will with a basic sympathy and compassion: idealism and vision with downtoearth pragmatism. She had the common touch end throughout her long careeras kibbutznick in Merhavia. Histadrut leader, Ambassador to Moscow. Member of the Knesset, Foreign Minister or Prime Minister, she was always Gooda. not lust to the Israeli people and so the Jews of the Diespora, but to the worldatlarge. She displayed vision and acute political understanding as Acting Head of the Jewish Agency's Political Depasernent in Jerusalem. which served her well during her turn as Israel's first Ambassador to Moscow and then as Foreign Minis ter. Both political prescience and Dorsonal courage combined with her devotion to the concept of the Jewish State and her years of dedicated service to the Stateinthemaking earned her a place among the signers of Israel's Declaration of indepeedence. Even after her retirement as Prime Minister, she continued her involvenent in Israel's political life and remained a force to be reckoned with. Together with her children, Menachem and Sarah, the grandchildren, and the entire Jewish world, we mourn the passing of one of the great leaders of our generation. Her memory will be Inscribed forever In the history and the heart of her people.

title: Grumman Flying Many U.S. Dependents Out of Iran
description: The Grumman Aerospace Corporation announced yesterday that it had chartered three airliners to return to the United States any dependent of its employees in Iran who felt endangered by the disturbances there.

title: Carter Asks Party Support on Arms Pact and Inflation
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 8  Cataloguing the achievements of the first two years of his Administration, President Carter called on his fellow Democrats tonight to help him adopt a broad agenda for 1979, including the ratification of a strategic arms limitation agreement with the Soviet Union.

title: Otis and Parsons to Merge in July
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9  Otis Art Institute, the only professional fine arts school in metropolitan Los Angeles, will merge with Manhattan's Parsons School of Design next July 1.

title: Rhymes and Reasons
description: POETRY. Say the word and someone slips out the room. Start discussing your favorite poems and your near and dear will swiftly disappear. Perhaps because when they were children they were introduced to poetry as a language to be deciphered and revered. A little like ancient Aramaic. But word sounds, written and spoken rhythms, the neat exploding of rhymes are basic elements of simple poetry and natural food for small children. They are the great reciters, absorbing, remembering, overpronouncing, chewing syllables and savoring jumprope and advertising jingles, song lyrics, tonguetwisters and, if you'll keep some in the house, poems.

title: R.L. Klass To Wed Anne Leigh Stadler
description: Anne Leigh Stadler and Richard Loren Klass plan to be married at the Plaza on Jan. 6. Mr. and Mrs. Jack Stadler of Mamaroneck, N.Y., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mrs. Louis S. Klass of Columbus, Ohio, and the late Mr. Klass.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Long before the Mediterranean lands were overrun and conquered by the Romans the shores at the foot of Italy were settled by the Greeks. A new book: Art and Coinage in Magna Graecia, by R. Ross Holloway, gives us the story of the coinage in eleven coastal cities of southern Italy which began as early as the 6th century B.C.

title: Questions/Answers
description: I have a wax plant (Hoya) which is three or four years old. It grows in a west window, is ,watered when dry and fed with timerelease food every four months. It has not grown an inch in over a year. What am I doing wrong? S.R., Englewood, N.J.

title: Washingtons Man at Indian Point
description: BUCHANAN WITH his burly build, generously sized jaw and gravelly voice, Theodore A. Rebelowski, could be cast as a middleaged police sergeant. And policeman he is in a sense, as the Federal guardian of public health and safety at Indian Point. Mr. Rebelowski spends his days seeking clues to the safe or unsafe operation of the three nuclear reactors sitting in the populous suburbs along northern Westchester's Hudson shoreline. His world is one of specifications, tolerances, measurements, temperatures, pressures and flows.

title: DINING OUT
description: HARTFORD A BONUS of Hartford's recent rejuvenation is a number of new restaurants. One of these is The Brownstone, centrally situated across the street from the Hartford Civic Center in a restored 19th century mansion. The Brownstone, which has been operating as a restaurant for several years changed hands last year.

title: CHINA TESTS VOTING FOR MINOR LEADERS
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 9  China has begun experimenting with elections for lowlevel administrators in factories, villages and scientific institutes to supplant in part their appointment by the Communist Party.

title: Deaths
description: GILBERTRuth J. Beloved wife of Jules C., loving mother of Leslie Leventhal, Penny Gilbert, beloved sister of Dr Morris Katcher, Lee Hahn. Jean Herman, loving grandmother of Neil and Joshua. Services to be at Nassau North Chapel, Great Neck, Sunday 12 Noon.

title: Robert E. Cantwell, 70, A Journalist and Author
description: Robert Emmett Cantwell, a former editor at Time, Newsweek and Sports Illustrated magazines and the author of two highly praised novels In the 1930's, died Friday at St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 70 years old and lived at 520 West 114th Street.

title: An Expert Doubts Roman Coins Found in U.S. Are SeaLink Clue
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 9  Finds of Roman coins in the United States, including one in an Indian mound in Texas, are most likely lost souvenirs of World Wars I and II rather than proof of ancient transoceanic contact, an expert says.

title: BODIES OF CULTISTS LEAVING DOVER BASE
description: DOVER, Del., Dec, 9 (AP)  The bodies of victims of the mass suicidemurder at the People's Temple commune in Guyana began leaving Dover Air Force Base today.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 In the long and agonizing negotiations for some kind of peace agreement in the Middle East, we have now come down to a really critical point. President Carter is obviously irritated with both President Sadat of Egypt and Prime Minister Begin of Israel for fussing over what he regards as minor objections to the Camp David accords, which he worked so hard to achieve.

title: Robyn Lynne Sater Engaged To Leslie Stuart Trachtman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alan Venzer of Atlanta have announced the engagement of Mrs. Venzer's daughter, Robyn Lynne Sater, to Leslie Stuart Trachtman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Trachtman of Baldwin, L.I. Miss Sater also is a daughter of the late Stanley J. Sater, a cofounder and president of the Metro Management Corporation, Atlanta builders and realestate developers.

title: VANCE ASSURES NATO SOVIET ARMS ACCORD WILL HELP SECURITY
description: LONDON, Dec. 9  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance assured Western allies today that the projected strategic arms limitation agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union would enhance security, not diminish it as many in Europe once feared.

title: ART VIEW
description: What are we to make of the new wave of art reproductions tat are now coming on the market, usually through mailorder promotions, bearing fancy prices and the names of prestigious sponsors and claiming some sort of special status either as art objects or as financial investments or both? Some 500,000 copies of a slick, colorful catalogue advertising 96 items from The Nelson Rockefeller Collection have been in circulation since Labor Day, and two weeks ago a showroom was opened on 57th Street in New York to beefup the promotion of this socalled collection of reproductions.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: WHAT the publishers are offering young readers can be found elsewhere in this section. To find, however, what was being bought in the shops, this department paid a visit to Eeyore, the bookshop cozily nestled on the Upper West Side, a shop that caters only to children (ages 4 to 12) and the only such a one, says owner Joel Fram, on Manhattan Island.

title: I Dina Del Guercio Is Betrothed to Architect
description: The engagement of Dina Maria Del Guercio to Bradley Beachy Cruickshank has been announced by the prospective bride's brothers, Peter H. Del Guercio of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Kenneth Del Guercio of Landrum, S.C.

title: Deaths
description: SEWARODr Franklin A. of Brick. town, formerly of Rutherford, NJ on Dec 8, 1978, beloved husband of the late Helen (nee Dull), father of Franklin A., Jr., Mrs Jill Montgomery and the late James G., also survived by 12 grandchildren. Funeral services at the CollinsCalhoun Funeral Home, 19 Lincoln Ave. Rutherford, Monday at 1PM. Cremation private. Friends will be received Sunday, 2 to 4 and 7 to 9PM.

title: A Man of Flair, Not Fashion
description: The current craze for how to books and courses on dressing correctly and acquiring style gets a slightly padded cold shoulder from Richard Merkin. Mr. Merkin knows he has style. When he talks about clothes, which is frequently, he is apt to use words like spiritual, Apollonian calm and total order. Which is not at all surprising, since Mr. Merkin, whose avocation is his wardrobe, is by profession a painter.

title: 2 PLANNED CASINOS FACE NEW HURDLES
description: Highly placed state investigative aides said yesterday that New Jersey's Division of Gaming Enforcement would recommend denying casino licenses for Caesars World and the Bally Manufacturing Corporation unless the two companies could refute allegations of past criminal associations.

title: FIRE PERILS PERSIST IN COLLEGE HOUSING
description: In the year since 10 women died in a predawn fire on the top floor of a Providence College dormitory, fire codes have been more strictly enforced at colleges and universities around the United States.

title: Traders of Baseball Hit Florida Drought
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 9  I've been making trades in baseball for 35 years, said Gabe Paul, the president of the Cleveland Indians and a wheeler of the front rank, and it's never been harder to make a trade.

title: Mailbox: An Anthem Should Be Respected
description: I fully agree with Mark Rossman (Mailbox, Nov. 26) regarding the thoughtless interruption of the pregame national anthem by cheering and clapping by a few spectators in Madison Square Garden and Yankee Stadium.

title: The New Insurance FreeRade Zone
description: On July 20, 1978, Governor Hugh Carey signed into law a New York State bill that should have the longrange effect of helping to put this country's businessinsurance marketklace on an equal competitive footing with many foreign locations traditionally regarded as world centers of the industry.

title: Long Island Antique Show and Book Fair Also Provides a Treat for Collectible Fan
description: Simon Nottman used to practice medicine and run a bookstore in Covent Garden, but since moving to Long Island from England four years ago he has not yet got around to applying for his medical license, so his books take almost all of his attention.

title: A General Cracks Books Once Again
description: PRINCETON IT WILL have taken George Eggers 37 years to meet the requirements for a bachelor's degree from Princeton University when he graduates in June, 1980, but it's not because he is a slow learner. What occupied most of his time was a 33year stint in the United States Army.

title: A Call to Order For the General Assembly
description: THE time has come for the Connecticut General Assembly to put its own house in order. During the last four years, significant legislation has been passed that will reorganize the judicial system and the executive branch of government. Now it is our turn!

title: He Has Made Peace With Romanticism
description: According to a familiar sequence of musical affinities, interpreters of great music are expected to stir the turbid fumes of Wagner and Mahler before attaining the pure air of Mozart. But Colin Davis, the eminent English conductor who leads the Boston Symphony Wednesday and Thursday at Carnegie Hall, has come to Wagner and Mahler belatedly, and from the other direction.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING
description: SOME weeks ago, in answer to a New York Times poll, Fairfield County residents expressed the opinion that one of the things they feared most was the specter of increased urbanization.

title: Linda Eastman, Princeton Senior, to Be Wed
description: The engagement of Linda Kay Eastman to William Henry Hammond Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hammond of Riverside, Conn., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. James S. Eastman of Livingston. N.J. An August wedding in the Presbyterian Church of Livingston is planned.

title: Of This and That
description: TYRANNOSAURUS REX By Millicent Selsam. Illustrated. 41 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $5.95. (Ages 8 to 10)

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: TWO Democratic County Legislators, Ronald Tocci of New Rochelle and Richard Brodsky of Greenburgh, see the Lawrence Park Heat, Light and Power Company in Bromcville as posing in microcosm the legal and financial question posed by the proposed Consolidated Edison acquisition. They will therefore recommend tomorrow that the county consider taking it over, through purchase or condemnation.

title: Western Disco Group Is Rocking Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 9  There is a fourhour wait at the box office. Someone stole the four tickets reserved for the American Ambassador, Malcolm Toon. Scalpers are asking up to 150 rubles ($225) a seat and, some say, are getting what they ask.

title: THEATER Losing Something in Transition
description: IF two years can make a tradition, then we can count on a minimusical or an intimate revue call them what you will  from the Westchester Regional Theater each year as Christmas approaches. Last year they gave us Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris. This year it is Tuscaloosa's Calling Me ... But I'm Not Going! a little revue that had a successful offBroadway run three years ago.

title: Down and Up, But Mostly Down, On W. 92d St.
description: Last year, the name of the hotel was the Ridgefield. People who lived near the singleroom occupancy hotel, located at 255 West 92d Street, said it was a blight on the neighborhood, a haven for prostitutes and smalltime thugs.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: Traditionally, being the chairman of the National Broadcasting Company is like being Vice President of the United States  only without the hope. The real power lies with the network president, who's responsible for programming; for a network, the bottom line is the Neilsen ratings, and NBC's are currently in trouble.

title: Experts Testify for Releasing of Officer in Shooting
description: A series of state psychiatric experts have testified in a Brooklyn courtroom that Police Officer Robert Torsney, acquitted by reason of insanity of the murder of a 15yearold black youth, should now be released from custody at Creedmoor hospital.

title: Schmidt Cites the Danger
description: BRUSSELS  It is scarcely surprising that West Europe's ambitious new currency plans are off to a shaky start.

title: FOOD
description: THE emphasis this year in the cooking schools on the Island seems to be on bread baking, on using the food processor and on the cuisines of France and China. While most of the courses are being conducted as part of a series, there is an increasing trend to single sessions covering one particular aspect of cooking technique or a special presentation such as a holiday cooking or baking event.

title: T. & E.: Is the Act An Asset or Not?
description: The Public School Education Act of 1975  it was implemented two years ago  probably has been criticized more trap any other education law in New Jersey's history.

title: Carter Seeking Details From Koch on Impact Of Possible Cut in Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9  The White House, nearing the final stages in the preparation of President Carter's budget for the next fiscal year, has asked Mayor Koch's office to provide details of the effect of possible cutbacks in Federal aid to New York City.

title: Sports Today
description: Medgar Evers at Baruch, 7 P.M. (Radio WNYC,7 P.M.)

title: Deaths
description: LEDERNathan. The Board of Overseers of the Albert Einstein College, of Medicine of Yeshiva University expresses its heartfelt sorrow at the death of Nathan Leder, a Founder and dedicated supporter of the most sincere condolences are extended to his family.

title: Handbells Ring Out Season's Greetings
description: THE MAGIC resonance of English handbells filled the air of the First Presbyterian Church of Bedford with Christmas cheer on a recent morning, and it was a little like being inside a giant music box.

title: Delegates Are Quieter and Less Seasoned
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 9  The more than 1,600 delegates to the Democrats' midterm national party conference on the banks of the muddy Mississippi River are different from those of other years.

title: Spartans Also Cry
description: AMIA LIEBLICH is a Gestalt psychotherapist who teaches and practices in Jerusalem. Not the most suitable setting, one might think, for therapeutic technique that so prizes the willingness of clients to flow with their vulnerabilities and fears. It is, after all, long way from Big Sur, Calif.  the arcadian mecca of Gestalt therapy  to the spartan landscape of Israel, wnere au years of incessant warfare have conditioned people to paper over their collective sense of vulnerability, to function despite every imaginable trauma and grief.

title: CASUALTIES IN THE CLASSROOM
description: More than 60,900 teachers were physically attacked by students during the 197778 school year, the National Education Association (N.E.A.) found in its latest poll of members. School intruders and angry parents contributed a few thousand more assaults. The casualties add up to about 3 percent of the 2.1 million teachers in American public schools.

title: Cairo to Capetown
description: THE respect that the authors and illustrators of children's books now show for the richness and diversity of African culture makes it easy to forget that not long ago Africa was still disdained as the dark continent. This new respect reflects a healthy turnabout in Western thinking, even if the books that are the outgrowth of the rerooting of African folklore aren't always successful.

title: Loughery Is Ejected in 125120 Victory Over Clippers
description: PISCATAWAY, NJ., Dec. 9  John Williamson, working his way from under zone defenses, doubleteaming and even tripleteaming, led the New Jersey Nets to a 125120 victory tonight over the San Diego Clippers. He scored 48 points, a season high that topped last night's 40point performance in a victory over the Washington Bullets.

title: Realty News
description: Independent real estate brokers in suburban Connecticut, one of the most lucrative housing markets in the country, are protesting what they see as the intrusion of big business into their territory.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY HOUSING
