description: IN realestate circles, an invitation to an open house does not mean a wineandcheese or coffeeanddanish party. It is, rather, another merchandising tool used to help sell homes under certain circumstances.

title: Compassionate Classicist
description: IT was John Hall Wheelock, my first editor, who apprised me of the fact that human consciousness is dependent upon biological principles. As an aging and somewhat lagging poet, I had no idea of what might be involved in a statement of this sort. But, once embroiled in it, I knew it for what it was. I knew that my own work was taken in the mesh of the light of this biological idea:

title: DYING TOWN HOPES FOR SECOND CHANCE
description: PICKSTOWN, S.D., Dec. 9 (UPI) The village streets are quiet now, most of the houses are empty, and the 200 residents who remain must travel to nearby communities for everything except gasoline and groceries.

title: Sport Pitting Dog Against Dog Is Reported Spreading Secretly
description: BOSTON, Dec. 9 (AP)  Scunge is friendly, slightly mangy dog who will stick his head through the bars of his cage to be petted. He is also a killer, trained in the illegal sport of dog fighting.

title: GARDENING
description: IF you are an early bird, you will have already prepared your garden for winter; if you tend to procrastinate, you had better get started. However, don't feel bad if you haven't yet completed the task; much of what needs to be done to protect your plants is best done just before freezing weather anyway.

title: GARDENING
description: THERE are all sorts of ways to approach this business of weather predicting. There are earth signs, sky signs, nature signs and for a change of pace, calendar signs. The Old Farmer's Almanac has a calendar approach.

title: New Music Consort Sets Carnegie Series
description: Three concerts of contemporary European music will be performed by the New Music Consort in Carnegie Recital Hall, beginning on Jan. II with a French program. On that night, the 16member ensemble will present Boulez's Le Marteau sans Maitre, Debussy's Cello Sonata, Messiaen's Oiseaux Exotiques and the New York premiere of Gilbert Amy's Inventions for Flute, Harp, Piano and Percussion.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: WHATEVER happened out in, the meadows? The Hackensack Meadowlands acreage was to be, we were told not too long ago, the largest naturalbird and smallanimal preserve in the East. a sanctuary for muskrats and a network of nature trails on stilts meandering through the reeds and cattails.

title: SETTLING A SCORE WITH
description: In a workshop of the Foshan pottery factory, near Canton, its windows thrown open to let in the hot tropical air of South China, a group of women are skillfully applying the finishing touches to small clay figurines. Above them on a wall is an illustrated poster. In abbreviated language, it ticks off what are evidently the important accomplishments of the workers. Of the 156 people in the room, the poster boasts, 121 have bicycles or sewing machines, 84 have wristwatches, and 29 have radios or electric fans.

title: A Changed Synanon The Subject of Inquiry
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9  Synanon, the acclaimed drug rehabilitation program that evolved into a highly profitable organization, is now under state investigation on charges of violence and a wide range of illegal activities. And, with its founder hospitalized and under arrest, there are signs that several people are jockeying for control of the wealthy, controversial organization.

title: Behind the Violence in Brooklyn's Borough Park
description: Everybody's reading this backwards, said Lieut. George Illiano after his fellow officers had put the 66th Precinct station house back in order last week. These people are not antipolice, they're propolice.

title: New Life Looms for Newark Station
description: NEWARK ITS heavy doors under lock and key, the front of the old vacant station of the Central Railroad of New Jersey at 834 Broad Street is covered today with grime, tattered political posters and advertisements for rock concerts. But a movement is stirring that could transform the 109yearold structure into the center of new downtown shopping and dining area.

title: Even Witchcraft Qualifies for the Religious Exemption
description: Any threat to the traditionally broad tax exemption for religious groups is almost sure to produce measure of interfaith solidarity rarely achieved over more strictly spiritual matters. In such a mood of common resistance, dozens of representatives from Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish bodies joined forces last week at four days of public hearings in Washington to denounce a proposal by the Internal Revenue Service that would strip taxfree status from private schools that discriminate against minority groups according to standards set by the Service.

title: Georgetown Five Rallies To Beat St. John's, 7771
description: Craig Shelton scored 22 points and John Duren added 21 as unbeaten Georgetown rallied to defeat St. John's, 7771, Iast night before 4,394 fans at Alumni Hall.

title: A Leisurely Stroll In Old Strasbourg
description: The folksy charm of the Germanic countries now lies far beyond the pocketbook of most American tourists. But calorieladen streudel, picturesque halftimbered houses and oompah bands can still be found at a relatively reasonable price. Where? In France, of course. In Strasbourg.... carved, halftimbered houses and a great rosecolored cathedral.

title: MORE IRANIAN FUNDS SAID TO COME TO U.S.
description: For several years, international bankers have been reporting growing deposits from Iran, but the flow of Iranian money into the United.States is believed to have increased, substantially since the outbreak,of vast demonstrations against the Shah this fall.

title: Accountant Weds Susan Evans
description: The Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Susan Evans, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John A. Evans of New York and Shelter Island, L.I., to John Carman Sterling 3d,son of Mr. and Mrs. Sterling Jr. of West Hartford, Conn. Msgr. Thomas Keogh performed the ceremony, and the Rev. Ronald Woodruff, an Episcopal priest, assisted.

title: European Currency Plan Approved
description: The history of efforts to coordinate the monetary policies of Europe is a Sisyphean saga of repeated failure. Time and again the varying economic performances and differing domestic needs of the major European powers have blocked attempts to bind their currencies into a more stable union.

title: Group Homes: Now the Fight Is Structured
description: THIS week attorneys for the town of North Salem are to appear before the state's Commissioner of Mental Retardation Services to appeal the state's selection of a site for the town's first group home for the mentally retarded. The area of just over 4,000 residents is to become the first Westchester community to test the appeal provisions of a new state law that sought to give communities a greater, role in locating homes for retarded persons who had been housed at the Willowbrook state facility on Staten Island. An estimated 800 county residents were previously there.

title: SPORTS
description: MIDDLETOWN PEOPLE have always been fascinated by winning streaks from the caveman who first clubbed down nine mammoths in a row to Pete Rose, whose 44game hitting string last summer overshadowed baseball's pennant races.

title: A Sleeping Beauty From London
description: LONDON Madam is what everyone, everywhere, always, calls Dame Ninette de Valois. An interview with this great and formidable woman is an intimidating undertaking. You do not create, virtually singlehanded, a great ballet company, a national institution, without being formidable and becoming intimidating.

title: Illinois Officials Firm on Keeping Pay Rises Despite Public's Outcry
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Dec. 9  Although voters are threatening to turn them out of office and President Carter has denounced them for impeding his fight on inflation, Illinois state officials are determined to keep their pay increases, which range up to 40 percent.

title: Six Novels
description: THE FIRST TWO LIVES OF LUKASKASHA By Lloyd Alexander. 213 pp: New York: E. P. Dutton. $8.50. (Ages 9 to 12)

title: Golda Meir to Be Buried in Jerusalem Tuesday Near Zionist Founder
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 9  Israel's Cabinet, meeting in special session tonight, decided that former Prime Minister Golda Meir would be buried Tuesday on Mount Herzl, a hill on the southwestern outskirts of Jerusalem, near the tomb of Theodor Herzl, the founder of Zionism.

title: A Playboy Ad Divides Ivy Papers
description: BOSTON, Dec. 9 (AP)  Ivy League. journals are divided on the issue of whether to run a Playboy advertisement for women students willing to pose nude or seminude for the magazine.

title: The Critics Called Them Monsters Shaw Said They Were Real Women
description: At the age of 47, Bernard Shaw was still unknown to most of the British public. Those who had heard of him knew him as an amusing theater critic and as the author of a few moderately successful comedies, some of which had run for only a few nights. In that year  1903  the only Shaw play seen on the London stage was an Elizabethan pastiche called The Admirable Bashville, presented for two performances only: Shaw's only other appearance before the British public was with the publication of a play, Man and Superman, which was so long that no London manager would even consider it. In a postscript in a later edition, Shaw asserted: On the whole, the book has done very well. The strong critics are impressed; the weak intimidated. It was not true. Friendly critics  like G.K. Chesterton and Max Beerbohm said it was brilliant but not a play; the unfriendly ones said it was amusing but shallow. But no one paid all that much attention.

title: St. Francis Triumphs at Garden
description: In what Coach Lou Rossini of St. Francis College called a very spirited game, his Terriers rallied from a 10 point deficit early in the second half to down Long Island University, 8274, in the finale of a college basketball tripleheader at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

title: BRIDGE
description: The celebrated fable of James Thurber, in which a man rises early In the morning and sees a unicorn quietly munching in his garden, serves as a reminder that briElge also has its fabulous beasts, appearing late at night rather than early in the morning.

title: POLITICS
description: AT the moment, a meeting of the Tax Reduction Action Committee could be held in a closet. Yet the committee, known as TRAC, and spearheaded by two Nassau Democratic politicians who are widely suspected of using the group as a vehicle for their personal political ambitions, can claim to have had some impact on the current Republican squabbling over spending and taxes in Nassau County.

title: INVESTING
description: Everybody wins, nobody loses, the old carnival pitchman's cry, has become the slogan of the market for collectibles today. But reality can be quite the reverse for the many new investors seeking financing to acquire rare stamps. coins. books and art works.

title: And Now, From High Atop Bamberger's in Downtown Newark, Channel 1...
description: AS THE operating licenses of seven New York and four Philadelphia VHFTV stations, both commer public, approach their expiration dates, recent news aticles have borne the heartening information that the Federal Communications Commission has advised the owneroperators of these channels to establish instate studios and news bureaus and staff them with additional personnel whose primary function would be to improve coverage of New Jersey events.

title: Visconti Film Series At Lincoln Center
description: The American premiere of The Innocent, the last film by Luchino Visconti, will begin a sixday retrospective devoted to the late Italian director that will begin Jan. 8 at the Library of Lincon Center.

title: Blind Student at Harvard Using Tapes as Her Law School Texts
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 9 (AP)The room at the end of the fourthfloor corridor in Ames Hall dormitory resembles a disk jockey's booth at a radio station. But the Harvard Law School student who lives there has little time for music.

title: Ambrosia and Watercress
description: This season's juvenile cookbooks offer a diversity of approaches. You don't simply buy food, measure it by the cup and eat. Instead, you forage, measure In metrics and, in some cases, use the food for creative projects.

title: A Young Met Curator Walks Esthetic Tightrope
description: Working for one of the world's more prominent art museums, 29yearold Lowery Sims is walking an esthetic tightrope.

title: Good Looking
description: PICTURE books, like so many of the books produced for children these days, often express the fantasies and preoccupations of their adult authors more than those of their presumptive readers or auditors. Many of the picture books this season, for example, cannot be understood without a fairly elaborate adult sensibility. Looking at 19 of the most distinguished, let's proceed from failures to successes. I promise you the last few books are wonderful.

title: Good Move
description: Pundits should never acknowledge other pundits, but we must confess more than grudging admiration for our colleagues, the chess critics. What mastery, what economy! They can do more with one punctuation mark than most writers can do with a paragraph.

title: Food
description: Volumes could be written on recipes that at first sight seem foreign but are, in fact, distinctly American. One such recipe, remembered from a Southern childhood, is for an unusual pasta dish. Although it is made with pasta of Italian origin and marinated in French dressing, it is dubbed New Orleans style and was a specialty of a Memphis golf club. After being marinated overnight, the seasoned pasta is blended with mayonnaise and diced chicken. The dish is served cold, garnished with mushrooms a la grecque, avocado slices, artichoke hearts, black olives and cherry tomatoes. A dish guaranteed to pique the appetite.

title: Ohio Court Nears Decision on Plan to Permit TV Coverage of Trials
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 9Ohio could become the largest state in the nation to permit television coverage of its courts under a proposal the Ohio Supreme Court is expected to act on in the next few weeks.

title: Editors Choice
description: AMERICAN CAESAR: DOUGLAS MACARTHUR 1880.1964, by William Manchester. (Little, Brown & Co., $15.) Voluminous research; narrative sweep; judicious ambivalence.

title: Odyssey From Left to Right
description: WE are all the snakes and worms of history. Living or dead, we don't lie still. Reputations shrink and swell, shrink and swell, an endless act of chewing and burrowing under and above ground. Who can declare what another century will think of our heroes and villains, our own good and bad gods? Hitler, Stalin, Churchill, Virginia Woolf? Perhaps they will be forgotten, junked somewhere in pantheon of wax, removed from the pathologies, fits and sexual habits of specific women and men. What about the lesser gods, such as Max Eastman? Where does he belong? Once the Byron of the Left, the darling of radical letters, he ended up despised ignored by everyone. He has no wax museum to take him in. When he died in 1969, few people knew who he was, and fewer still remember him today.

title: Sculpture: A Listing
description: A MORRIS COUNTY librarian has compiled a 72page guide describing the sculpture and public monuments erected in the county over the last century.

title: HIGH SCHOOL PRESS GRILLS MACCHIAROLA
description: School Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola began a press conference with high school editors last week by asking that the group balance a hard question with an easy question. But the hard questions came one and after another, and by the end of the 50minute session there were still many hands in the air and questions left answered.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE Oriental options are increasing on the Island. Witness the Vietnamese food for the last year at Hee Hing in Patchogue. Hee Hing has a lengthy Chinese menu too, one of those archaic CantoneseAmerican egg roll and chow mein affairs with a house special steak you want to be fancy. According to the owner, 80 percent of his patrons order the Vietnamese dishes instead of the Chinese ones, and with good reason.

title: State's Banking Chief Cites Need for Aides On New Redline Law
description: New York State's Banking Superintendent, Muriel Siebert, said yesterday that, unless she recieved additional examiners, it would be impossible to enforce the state's new antiredlining law.

title: IN THE NATION
description: SOWETO, South Africa  Just beyond eyesight of Johannesburg, on a vast expanse of treeless, rolling hills, lies what probably is the largest black ghetto in the world, believed by some to be the third largest city in Africa.

title: ABCTV Keeping 900 Jobs in New York as Result of State Tax Deal
description: New York State's Commerce Department has arranged a multimilliondollar taxbenefit deal that persuaded ABCTV to sPend $27.5 million for new televisionproduction and office facilities in Manhattan, retaining 900 jobs and creating 100 new ones.

title: The World Biggest Coin Factory
description: Watching money being made is easier than earning it, and some 400,000 visitors who annually take the free tour of the United States Mint in Philadelphia will readily attest that nobody makes money faster than Uncle Sam. The mint, in fact, is the largest coin factory in the world.

title: Newark Unions Brace for Threatened YearEnd Layoffs
description: NEWARK MUNICIPAL labor unions here, faced with a layoff threat that could eventually affect more than 2,000 of the city's 13,000 government workers and school employees, have banded together to fight the dismissals. The first ones are scheduled to take effect Dec. 31.

title: City Ends Exemptions Of 7 New York Clubs; $174,650 in Tax Due
description: Propertytax exemptions on premises owned by seven private clubs have been revoked by the New York City Tax Cornmission on the ground that their activities are not primarily educational or charitable.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Knicks will have games at Madison Square Garden at 7:30 P.M. Tuesday against the San Diego Clippers and at 2 P.M. next Sunday against the Atlanta Hawks. The New Jersey Nets will play the Atlanta Hawks at 8 P.M. on Friday at the Rutgers Athletic Center in Piscataway, N.J.

title: State Delegates Stir Up an Issue To Goad Carter
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 9  Since the New York delegation arrived in this iceglazed city on the Mississippi for the Democratic Party's midterm conference, it has watched with some bemusement the Cunningham and Crangle show  two former New York state chairmen debating privately and publicly over what kind of majority that would be required to pass a party resolution.

title: Agency Officials Ask For Public Support
description: This is the season when we make plans to celebrate the traditional holidays with our friends and families. But we know there are other kinds of holidays  holidays that take place in the hearts of people.

title: Ice Blocks East German Roads
description: EAST BERLIN, Dec. 9 (Reuters) Snow and ice paralyzed East German roads and closed three major airports today. Highways were blocked by accidents, and traffic jams developed after rain had frozen on roads. East Berlin's Schnefeld Airport was also closed for more than five hours and provincia airports at Dresden and Erfurt remained closed.

title: Isaac M. Altaraz, Psychologist, Dies at 87 in a Fire at His Home
description: GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Dec. 9 (AP)  Dr. Isaac M. Altaraz, a prominent psychologist, died today at age 87 in a fire at his home, the authorities reported.

title: Australians Reach Final
description: SYDNEY, Dec. 9 (UPI)  Two Australian Federation Cup teammates, Kerry Reid and Dianne Fromholtz, will meet in tomorrow's final of a $75,000 tennis classic at White City. Miss Reid advanced today with a 46, 64, 64 upset victory over topseeded Virginia Wade of Britain and Miss Fromholtz gained her berth by beating secondseeded Wendy Turnbull, 63, 67, 62.

title: Jane Isaacs Fiance Of James W. Fox
description: The engagement of Jane S. Isaacs to James Warren Fox has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Abner H. Isaacs of Merrick, L.I., parents of the prospective bride. Mr. Fox is a son of Mr. and Mrs. George D. Fox of Sudbury, Mass.

title: A Gift for Hurt
description: Bad Connections surmounts some fairly heavy obstacles to become a fine novel of the alienated woman; at times an extraordinarily fine novel.

title: Compulsive Gambler Diagnosed: A Success Type With a Disease
description: LAS VEGAS, Dec. 9 (AP)  Doctors assembled in this city of gaming tables were told yesterday that compulsive gambling was a devastating illness that was ruining a million American lives.

title: Labor Dept. Aide Fights for Jobs Program
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9  Its a big corner office, big enough for a game of halfcourt basketball, and in the Washington pecking order a spacious suite ranks just behind a private bathroom and well ahead of a Xerox machine. In the waiting room, a magazine is open to a photograph of black children touring Disney World. A can of soda pop sitting on a desk displays a picture of a black ballplayer. The women answering the phones are both black. Inside the big corner office sits Ernest G. Green, and he's black, too.

title: Iran Regime and Foes Act to Avert Violence Today
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 9  The Government and its opponents pledged today that they would do everything possible to prevent bloodshed during protest marches tomorrow that may involve as many as a million people if the weather fair.

title: Holiday Mail Volume Brings Word of Advice
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP)  The volume of Christmas mail is building, and postal officials are urging Americans to mail their cards and parcels as soon as possible.

title: Article 5 -- No Title
description: STUDY MEDICINE (M.D.D.D.S.D.V.M.)

title: POLITICS
description: SAMUEL G. FREDMAN, Westchester's Democratic Party leader, says he hopes that Wilson G. Price, his Conservative counterpart, will get smart and con vince the Republicans they can't rely on him. Translated into political terms, that meant Mr. Fredman hoped the Conservatives would endorse more Democrats for elective office.

title: MORE GUNS SOUGHT BY GUYANESE POLICE
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 9 Some Guyanese police officials believe that members of the People's Temple may have had more guns than the 32 rifles, shotguns and pistols recovered by the authorities after the mass deaths in Jonestown last month, they said in interviews here.

title: L.B. Taft Jr., Mimi Shanley, Are Married
description: The marriage of Marcella Marie Shanley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Shanley of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, to Lloyd Bowers Taft Jr. took place at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Forest Hills Gardens yesterday afternoon. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Taft of New York and a greatgrandson of President William H. Taft. The Rev. M. Joseph Farley performed the ceremony.

title: Marital Crime and Punishment
description: ROSELLEN BROWN'S splendid first novel, The Autobiography of My Mother (1976), dramatized in meticulous detail, through the very nuances of speech, the tragic differences between an indefatigable civilrights attorney and her 29yearold withered flowerchild daughter. Miss Brown's skillful prose did not simply set out for us the innumerable heartbreaking reasons why Gerda and her daughter Renata would always be strangers; it allowed us to see, to hear, through the women's distinctive voices, the tragic depth of those differences. That they are tragic and not merely vexing becomes altogether too clear when, at the conclusion of that densely textured and extremely intelligent novel, Renata's small daughter dies as a consequence of foolish accident that both she and her mother might have easily prevented. The enmity between one generation and another leads to the destruction of the next.

title: Despite Inflation Toll, Carter Wants to Free Fuel Prices
description: The air was crackling last week with announcements and pronouncements from the Federal Government and its leaders, all speaking to the question of the hour, and the year: Can inflation be contained?

title: Lois Beth Wilner Is Married
description: Lois Beth Wilner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David J. Wilner of Edison, N.J., was married yesterday to Kenneth Nelson Clarke, son of Jean Clarke of Hollywood, Fla., and N.K. Clarke of Miami. Rabbi Alfred Landsberg of Edison performed the ceremony at the Hampshire House.

title: Christmas Is Corning, and So Are Turkeys
description: THANKSGIVING has come and gone, but not the turkey. For years now, the bird has been popular entree at Christmas and New Year's, too, and the upcoming holidays should be no exception.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computerprocessed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Today  Watchung Mountain Poodle Club specialty, Records Hall: Rutgers University, College Avenue, New. Brunswick, N.J. lays. 55 miniatures, 55 standards, 49 obedi ence: 9 A.M.

title: Man Dies in Police Car Scuffle
description: NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Dec. 9 (AP)  A state trooper is recovering today from stab wounds and a Springfield man is dead after the two struggled in a moving police cruiser. Brian R. Kynock, 29 years old, of Marlboro, was taking a drunken driving suspect to the Northampton state police barracks yesterday when the man attacked him with a linoleum knife, the police said, and the officer shot the suspect as the cruiser crashed.

title: Boston Center Offers 300 Subjects
description: BOSTON, Dec. 9 (AP)  The Boston Center for Adult Educatiqn tries to have something for everyone.

title: CRIME
description: There have been mercenary armies in Africa. Why not in the United States? That is the idea behind THE MONEY WAR by Terrence Lore Smith (Atheneum, $9.95). Suppose an experienced mercenary, one of those lean, charismatic military geniuses, decides to take over an American city. Could the local authorities cope?

title: A Seaman Recounts Past Glory
description: Steven S. survived many an adventure as a merchant seaman for 30 years. He began as a 16yearold stowaway in the 1930's, leaving his native Yugoslavia by hiding beneath ropes on the deck of a freighter. When the captain learned of his presence, he put Mr. S. to work and agreed to take him as far as Lisbon.

title: Judge Voids Strict Medicaid Rule
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP)  A Federal judge has thrown out a Government regulation that allowed 15 states to impose stricter Medicaid eligibility standards for nursinghome residents who had spouses living at home.

title: GARDENING
description: NEW JERSEY gardeners are grateful that their tasks are comparatively few and far between during this month of celebration.

title: Man Who Set Up Tor Sale Sign On L.I. Is Freed After Day in Jail
description: FREEPORT, L.I., Dec. 9  Douglas J. Moran, who chose to go to jail on Thursday rather than pay a $250 fine for violating a village ordinance by displaying a For Sale on his home without a permit, received a pleasant surprise yesterday when he was released after serving only one day of a fiveday sentence.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Two playwrights who began promising careers Off Broadway in the early 1960's have turned up with new pieces in recent weeks. Leonard Melfi's Porno Stars at Home opened in a hitherto unused playhouse called The Courtyard, just off Sheridan Square downtown, and the powderbox dimensions of The Courtyard brought us so close to the five performers that when any two of them raised their voices anger our ears were apt to flinch from the assault. Sam Shepard's Buried Child made its appearance in a makeshift auditorium so tiny that the author's devotees quickly used up the available seats and settled for hunchedup positions in the center aisle; as a result, it has now moved to the somewhat larger, though still intimate, Theater de Lys. Question. Why, approximately 15 years after their respective debuts and at a time when workshop productions often find it easy to move into ample theaters uptown, are both men still confined to the theatrical fringes?

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Beethoven's 208th birthday will be celebrated with all the trimmings Saturday in New Haven. Following the performance of his Fourth Symphony and the Violin Concerto by the Chamber Orchestra of New England in Sprague Hall at 8:30 P.M., a birthday cake will be cut onstage and dispensed to the audience. The premises will be decorated with Happy Birthday, Ludwig drawings by local children, and a cartoon of the wellknown. Beethoven expert, Schroeder, will be raffled off for the benefit of the orchestra's maintenance fund. The cartoon is signed by Schroeder's alter ego, Charles Schulz. Tickets are $7 at the door or phone 7770790.

title: U.S. Plans for Cyprus Encounter Objections Of Greeks and Turks
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus Dec. 9  The latest American proposal to break the Cyprus deadlock has run into serious snags on both sides of the barricades that divide this eastern island.

title: Dakota Dam's Road Is Traveling
description: PIERRE, S.D., Dec. 9 (AP)  The road across Oahe, the world's secondlargest rolled earth dam, has moved about five inches closer to Pierre since it was built 16 years ago, the Army Corps of Engineers has said.

title: Philippine Dancers Do 22 Works
description: The Philippine Dance Company, founded in 1943 by Bruna P. Seril, is serious about its folk material. On Friday at the Philippine Center's elegant Marcos Hall it presented 22 of the more than 200 traditional dances revived in the 1950's by Francesca Reyes Aquino, a pioneer researcher in the field, to whom the program was dedicated.

title: 15 Women Die in Dormitory Fire At School for Mentally Retarded
description: ELLISVILLE, Miss., Dec. 9  Fifteen women patients died after they were overcome by smoke and heat early today in a dormitory at the Ellisville State School for the mentally retarded. Gov. Cliff Finch called the fire the worst tranedv to ever hit our state.

title: Colts Lose in Snow
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 9  Pittsburgh's Terry Bradshaw buried the Baltimore secondary under an ava lanche of 240 yards and three touchdowns in a steady snowfall today, leading the Steelers to a 3513 triumph over the Colts.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Put up baffles or screens to protect valued evergreens from harsh winds... Last call to rake remaining leaves and debris from lawns. . . . If the ground is frozen, lightly mulch perennials and tender evergreens, especially dwarf rock garden species. . . . Winter is an excellent time to have shade trees pruned and thinned by professionals.

title: QuintHype
description: To a generation surrounded by worldwide depression, poverty and the rise of fascism, the birth of the Dionne quintuplets in May 1934 was less a curious diversion than a badly needed affirmation of the human spirit. From a farmhouse in northern Ontario, news of the birth of the five identical infants, each weighing little more than a pound, gradually spread worldwide to become the biggest story of the decade. Everyone within reach of newspapers, radio and movie newsreels knew of Oliva and Elzire Dionne; of Dr. Allan Roy Woe, who fulfilled the dream of Charlie Brown's [Anus by becoming a worldfamous humble country doctor; of every change of weight and strength.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Peer Pressure Is a Novel Theme
description: AFTER Ellen Rabinowich finished her youngadult novel, Toni's Crowd, about peer pressfire in a suburban high school, she sent the photographer illustrating the text to her old high school in East Meadow.

title: Other Ideas & Trends
description: In its 25yearhistory the Howard Hughes Medical Institute has been as closemouthed as its founder. Last week the institute broke its silence. Not that it told all. But a report in The New England Journal of Medicine said the institute is expanding its research, done at 12 top medical schools, in genetics, immunology and metabolismendocrinology. The institute's wealth rivals that of Rockefeller University, which has an endowment of $177 million. While most foundations are getting poorer because of inflation, the Hughes Institute is probably getting richer. Its money comes from the aftertax earnings of the Hughes Aircraft Company. Between 1963 and 1973, the institute's total take from the company was $21.6 million; last year, it was $18 million.

title: The Enigma of Morristown's Capitalistic Commune
description: MORRISTOWN GEORGE G. JURSCEK, the state's mostpublicized cultist, says that the Jonestown suicides in Guyana did not mystify him because they were a natural evolution of official oppression, and that he could be driven to taking his own life.

title: Article 6 -- No Title
description: Car need a paint job?

title: The Footwork Behind Ballroom
description: It was a time of tension, a time of trial. For one thing, Dorothy Loudon had walking pneumonia, an affliction which, while not devastating, was certainly discomfiting. Nonetheless, here was Miss Loudon on the day that Ballroom was having its first preview, still learning new songs. Besides, three new scenes had been added to Ballroom the night before. Miss Loudon had learned them, too. When would Ballroom be frozen? When would Michael Bennett say that enough is enough, and decide he was finished? Miss Loudon thought it might be the night before Ballroom opened. Then she could take the next day off.

title: The Floppy Disk Comes of Age
description: LOS ANGELES  The floppy disk and its associated drive, once ugly ducklings among computer technologies, have suddenly come into their own this year  and there are indications that a new version due out in 1979 may make the past mere prologue. Some analysts see the floppy as a candidate to be the cornerstone of the office of the future. Two signs of its rejuvenation: a new popularity in the consumer market and the entry of Xerox into the fold.

title: Michigan Laetrile Bill Advances
description: LANSING, Mich., Dec. 9 (UPI)  The Michigan House has approved legislation to legalize the manufacture and sale by prescription of laetrile, the purported cancerfighting drug. The bill was sent to the Senate, where action is not likely before year's end.

title: Many Questions of Gender
description: A PIONEER in the art of making female private life public, George Sand fascinated her contemporaries by weaning trousers, smoking cigarettes, conducting flamboyant and frequent love affairs (never two at once, she insisted, with dubious accuracy) as much as by her copious production of novels. Her latest biographer invites a 20thcentury audience to accept writing and conduct alike as aspects of a search for identity, a continuing struggle to understand herself as a woman and as a human being. Once George Sand exemplified Romantic dilemmas; now she exposes existential and feminist perplexities. Two centuries after her death, she still embodies fashionable issues, still demands attention.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON TAPPING his hornrimmed glasses on the table, he stared in reflection out the window of the Old Senate Office Building. He was searching for the words that would best summarize his almost quartercentury in the Senate.

title: Cancer Patients Face Long Delay In Federal Marijuana Shipments
description: SANTA FE, N.M., Dec. 9 (UPI) State health officials, who won a fivemonth battle to get Federal approval of a program using marijuana to ease pain and nausea in cancer patients receiving chemotherapy, now face a long delay in shipment of the drug.

title: Monique Knowlton Wed to W.S. Sterns 3d
description: Monique Graebener Knowlton and William S. Sterns 3d were married yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Carl B. Nelson.

title: THEATER
description: STAMFORD I CANNOT speak for other critics, but I know that I have often brought a different standard to reviewing productions by regional theaters from those I apply to Broadway productions. On Broadway, perfection is expected. At a regional theater, excuses are made.

title: Robert Pressman Weds Holly Pearl
description: Holly Meg Pearl, daughter of Lee Pearl of Stamford, Conn., and Joan Pearl of New York, was married last evening to Robert Lewis Pressman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Pressman of Harrison, N.Y.

title: Carter Weighs Cutback In Federal Pension Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP)  As part of its antiinflation program, the Carter Administration is considering a proposal to cut back automatic costofliving adjustments in military and Civil Service pensions.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: ENEMIES OF THE SYSTEM By Brian Aldiss. 119 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $7.95.

title: High Court Holds Brokerage Liable
description: The Supreme Court last week refused to review a decision that has the securities industry aroused. The decision, handed down by a Federal Appeals Court last January, held that a securities firm was liable for stock losses in a fraud case.

title: Charles Sullivan Leads 3 Jazzmen
description: At a time when jazz trumpeters tend to favor long fusillades of bright, brassy notes, Charles Sullivan goes his own way, showing his assimilation of such styles as the furious virtuosity of early Dizzy Gillespie and the carefully paced spotting of notes of the early Miles Davis, but using them as elements in a broad and varied attack that changes on almost every piece and is projected with flair and authority.

title: Miss Schlamp, Credit Analyst, Engaged to Vincent Cahill Jr.
description: Katherine Susan Schlamp of New York and Vincent Joseph Cahill Jr. of Lawrenceville, N.J., who work for the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in New York, plan to be married May 12.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  Asked to describe his Administration's strategy for nuclear arms, President Carter told reporters recently: Our nuclear policy basically is one of deterrence; to take actions that are wellknown by the American people and that are wellknown by the Soviets and other nations; that any attack on us would result in devastating destruction of the nation which launched an attack.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: ALTHOUGH rollers have made the painting of walls and ceilings easier, there are still tricks that can make roller painting easier and faster, and more likely to result in a smooth and uniform finish.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: Today  Middle Island, Middle Island Arena, Rocky Point Road, Middle Island, Children's and special working hunters, special jumpers, adult horsemanship, equitation. 9 A.M.

title: Carter's Dual Role in Memphis: A Politician as Well as President
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 9  Jimmy Carter divided his time here this morning between his twin roles as President and politician in a concentrated effort to rally support for his key policies and place his own stamp on the Democratic midterm conference.

title: Gilmore Is Standout as Chicago Takes 5th Straight
description: Artis Gilmore was too much for the Knicks to contend with last night. The 7footinch Gilmore, the highest paid center in the National Basketball Association at $650,000 a year, battered the Knicks with 28 points, 18 rebounds and six assists and led the Chicago Bulls to a 10196 victory before a crowd of 13.592 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Coalfield Jobs Being Eliminated In Wake of Strikes and Recession
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Dec. 9 (AP)In West Virginia's coalfields, the year that was supposed to bring riches is ending with more than 3,500 coal mining jobs eliminated, a spokesman for the West Virginia Coal Association said.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: HE writes about the closing of his old junior high school, about the heartless march of time.

title: WESTWAY EXPECTED TO INVIGORATE AREA
description: The construction of the Westway will generate enough new business activity to create anywhere from 13,900 to 129,600 permanent new jobs in the metropolitan region, possibly reversing the flight of businesses and jobs from the West Side of Manhattan, according to a study published today by the TriState Regional Planning Commission.

title: To the HouseSitter, a Contented Owner Means a Free Vacation
description: I had been housesitting about six months, at a mansion on a remote island off the Georgia coast when the honeymoon couple arrived. It was spring and days were filled with bright swatches of color as painted buntings darted about. The muted thunder of surf was heard across the island and nights were permeated by the rich sweet smell of magnolia. My friend and I spent days cleaning the house and putting flowers in every room. We planned to stay out of the way as much as possible that week so that the couple, who were staying there as guests of the absent owner, could have privacy.

title: ENROLLMENTS DOWN, COLLEGE STAFFS CUT
description: In the face of unexpected enrollment declines, the nine community colleges of the City University of New York have sent layoff notices, effective in September, to 125 to 150 nontenured professional staff members.

title: Robert L. Brush Jr. And Sandy Faison, Actress, Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Williams Faison of Brooklyn Heights have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sandra Faison, to Robert Lee Brush Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Brush of Ridgewood, N.J. A February wedding is planned.

title: Talmadge Collected Bulk of Overpayments After Aide Left Staff
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9  Senator Herman E. Talmadge, Democrat of Georgia. collected the bulk of his expense account overpayments from the Senate after his controversial aide, Daniel Minchew, had left his staff in October 1974.

title: Urban Decline and Fiscal Health
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 9 (AP)Declining urban areas may be saved by the city dwellers who desert them, according to Dr. David L. Birch, a researcher at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's architectural laboratory.

title: From Greenwich to Hartford, a Holiday Sampler
description: AS promised last Sunday, I am listing today some of the myriad holiday musical happenings, but firk here is a brief report on the preYuletide concert of the Greenwich Choral Society.

title: Revisiting the 1960's
description: RIDGEFIELD NORMALLY concerned with the present, the Aldrich Museum here is now glancing at the past with The Sixties Collection Revisited (through Dec. 17). This is a selection of 64 paintings and sculptures that represent about half the art owned by the museum's founder, Larry Aldrich.

title: BETTE MIDLER GOES HOLLYWOOD
description: Her hair is such a mad maze that when it recently caught fire in an encounter with a lighted candle, no one noticed the difference afterward. Her nose crooks at its tip like the prow of the Concorde. She stands little more than five feet tall, and her speaking voice, which sounds as if it swings on rusted hinges, can close on a vowel and place it on a frequency otherwise exclusive to the yapping of small dogs. She is Bette Midler, and she wants to become a legend.

title: Colonial Marine Park Sought for East End
description: THE Island  and New York State  may soon have its first and only Colonial Marine State Park, if the dreams of the Batchelor Society are realized.

title: Venus Probes Yield Mass of Data
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Dec. 9  A rain of science fell on Venus today.

title: Closings of Store and Plants Mark Decline in Akron
description: AKRON, Ohio  Polsky's, one of this city's two major downtown department stores, is staging one of those onceinalifetime sales again. This time the familiar pitch is especially appropriate.

title: Work on RailCorridor Project Pushed
description: The swing bridge on Amtrak's main line over the Hackensack River  the balky one in the Jersey Meadows that has way of getting stuck and tying up both Amtrak and Conrail passenger traffic  is scheduled for a $12.7 million rehabilitation job in 1979.

title: Trinidad Carnival: Awaiting Joovay, Playing Mas and Jumping Up
description: For almost a year, Vivian Paul Alexis told friends and relatives he would not take the time nor spend the money to travel to Trinidad for the island's annual preLenten carnival. No one believed him, and most of his close associates simply laughed. So they were hardly surprised last January when this 66yearold Trinidadborn electronics technician for Brooklyn's Downstate Medical Center piled himself, his family and a few friends into a luggageladen station wagon and headed for Kennedy International Airport to catch a plane to Trinidad.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: ART

title: Fools, Kings, Mice, Things
description: Richard Kennedy's Princess is so beautiful that to look at her is literally blinding. Like the sun, or Truth, it is only safe to view her through a glass darkly. To complicate matters, she herself is blind, but her blindness is kept secret.

title: Panel Members
description: Following are the members of the Connecticut School Finance Advisory Panel:

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: The international political balance turns increasingly on economic issues. And the mission to Moscow last week of Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal and Commerce Secretary Juanita Kreps represents an effort by the Carter Administration not only to put a more positive face on complex and strained United StatesSoviet relations but to help redress the yawning global gap in the United States balance of trade.

title: Deaths
description: Alexander, Mae

title: Four Novels
description: IN THE NAME OF THE FATHER By Tony Ardizzone. 208 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $7.95.

title: Micronesia Heads for a New Era As 3 SemiIndependent Nations
description: KOROR, Palau  Micronesia, the vast Pacific Island territory ruled by the United States for the last 33 years, is preparing for semiindependence as three separate countries instead of the unified nation envisaged, by the United Nations, with the concurrence of Washington, until recently.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Today  Long Island Sports Car Association 100mile T.S.D. rally; start at Howard Johnson's, Route 112 off Exit 64 of Long Island Expressway, Medford, L.I. Registration: 10 A.M.; first car off 11.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: This is a script we've played before. The title is Side Street Sabotage. A little suspenseanddisaster music, please. Somehow, this drama is always being performed on East 62d Street, between Fifth and Madison Avenues.

title: Updike In Africa
description: LIKE Evelyn Waugh and Paul Theroux and others before him, John Updike has betaken himself  imaginatively, at least  to Africa. The trip has done him good, for he has returned with one of his strongest novels  a book much superior the (relatively) disappointing A Month of Sundays and Marry Me; a book that stands with the two Rabbit novels and The Centaur as an example what this extraordinarily prolific novelist can do when his imagination, as well as his language, is strenuously engaged.

title: For Long Valley,
description: TO MOST of his neighbors, 66yearold Jack Borgenlcht is, as one of them put it, a wild, unpredictable and unbelievable guy who sports a shaved head, handlebar mustache, tattered denim jacket, matching patched jeans and an outdated automobile. He is, they say, an

title: Mail Agency Proposes SameDay Deliveries
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP)  The Postal Service would begin offering a sameday metropolitan delivery service in three urban areas early next year under a proposal to the Postal Rate Commission.

title: Generations on a Farm
description: THE place in A Woman's Place is an ancient farmhouse, part of it dating back to 1750. Across the rock that is its doorstone run the fossilized footprints of a tiny, threetoed creature last seen in prehistoric times. In fact, the passage of time is the most affecting event in this novel, chockfull of affecting events  one generation giving way to the next, whole family lines dying out only to be replaced by others.

title: Americans In England
description: THIS book is, in general, so suffused with optimism, so gracious in awarding the British the benefit of the doubt, so harsh on foreign critics, so praising of British manners and attitudes  indeed, so perverse in its generosity to this complex and often maddening country  that as soon as I finished it reached for the London telephone directory and looked for Bernard Nossiter's address. It was not my intention to send him a Valentine or a Guy Fawkes Day greeting, but merely to seek some clue to his sweet nature. Oh, Lord, I thought, I should have known. Mr. Nossiter lives on Eaton Place, and if any street the world may be said to be paved with gold, it Eaton Place.

title: Substitutes for Substitute Teachers
description: NORTHPORT ROBERT HILL, a Northport High School sophomore, had one of his classes canceled the other morning because the teacher was absent. So he headed for the guidance center to use the,department's computer. Barbara Holbrook, another Northport student, spent her free period watching a craft demonstration in the student commons, and Jim Hohenberger spent the 40minute break in his schedule in a darkened corner of the commons watching a reel of an Abbott and Costello movie.

title: Letters: How to Beat the System If Dining Out Alone
description: To the Editor:

title: Menswear Chic for Women
description: COLLEGE girls a silent generation ago knew that Brooks Brothers' buttondown shirts had more class than monogrammed blouses and that boys' jeans were more fun than slacks. But how many women realize that they can still expect to find some of their best sportswear buys in the men's department? There they can find free alterations, good quality and considerable savings. With a little imagination, a shopper can buy many of the season's chic items, from fashionably slouchy sweaters and slim trousers to the accessories needed for the Annie Hall look.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: APROPOSAL that would shift some Federal revenuesharing funds from urban townships to cities is half way through the State Legislature.

title: Now Asia Frets About Ugly Vietnamese
description: BANGKOK  The war to determine whether the three countries of Indochina would be Communist or not was won by the Communists three years ago. The struggle over whether Indochina should be in the Soviet or the Chinese camp continues.

title: Topics
description: A District of Columbia man suffering from glaucoma inadvertently discovered a few years ago that marijuana seemed to alleviate the disease. He grew his own supply, was arrested, produced expert testimony that he needed the illegal drug to save his sight, and at last browbeat Washington into supplying him with marijuana cigarettes. His battle underscored this irony: marijuana is used routinely by tens of millions of Americans yet its notoriety has hampered investigation of its therapeutic potential.

title: Northeast Corridor
description: WASHINGTON AMTRAK and the Federal Railroad Administration plan to spend $58.8 million next year as part of a project of converting the WashingtonBoston Northeast Rail Corridor into a reliable, highspeed passenger service for the 1980's.

title: Nursing Home Ordered to Repay Patient's Estate
description: A Manhattan nursing home has been ordered to repay the estate of a late patient funds transferred to the home when the patient was unable to speak, was paralyzed in both hands and was on the verge of death.

title: Anthony Korf Directs Parnassus
description: On three successive nights this week, Carnegie Recital Hall has been the home of concerts addressed primarily to 20thcentury music. The last of these, on Thursday night, was given by Parnassus, a chamber ensemble now in its fifth season. It is under the direction of Anthony Korf, and it includes players who turn up regularly in the service of contemporary music.

title: A Changing Tune For Passaic County
description: CLIFTON IN AN area of the state that is known better for its textile industries than for its cultural institutions, John Caprio is a pioneer.

title: Pig Pens
description: ONCE upon a time a friend of mine was invited to a small dinner for Isaac Bashevis Singer. The soup was served, and Singer instantly dipped in. The guests all turned to watch the great man. Singer looked up, put his spoon down and said, In the next life I will be a pig. Everyone laughed. And the other animals, he went on, will ask me what I was in the previous life. I will tell them I was a writer, and they will say. That's what all the pigs claim.

title: Florida A. and M. Wins
description: JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 9 (AP) Mike Solomon scored two touchdowns today to give Florida A. and M. a 1510 victory over Jackson State in a semifinal game of the National Collegiate Division 1AA playoffs.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Chicago had a big world premiere the other week. Nobody really knew how big until Hans Heinsheimer, the veteran music publisher, did a little digging. The Occasion was the world premiere at the Lyric Opera of Krzysztof Penderecki's Paradise Lost. Mr. Heinsheimer pointed out that not since 1921, when Prokofiev's The Love for Three Oranges had its world premiere in Chicago, had any major American opera house given birth to a major opera by a major European composer.

title: Why My Husband Went to Jail
description: MY husband came home from jail and finally, for me, the Levittown strike was over.

title: Judy E. Lavaty, Stewardess, Married to Jeffrey M. Strauss
description: Judy Ellen Lavaty, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Lavaty of Westport, Conn., was married there yesterday to Jeffrey Michael Strauss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Strauss, also of Westport. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride by Justice of the Peace Joseph Hanley.

title: REGAN, A NEUTRAL, WEIGHS THE FUTURE
description: Ask New York State's new Comptroller if he's running for Governor in 1982, and he'll give you an answer that reflects the position of someone who says he wants to be a nonpartisan Comptroller but also happens to be the only Republican who holds a statewide office.

title: Times Are Changing For College Soccer
description: TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 9  After being at the crossroads of popularity and acceptance for several years, college soccer made a wrong turn last year. But coaches with some new ideas have made suggestions that could change things againfor the better.

title: GOVERNORS SUGGEST A DEAL ON SPENDING
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9  The nation's governors and state legislatures are offering President Carter a trade: They will actively support his proposed cut in domestic spending if he in turn will push for consolidations and reforms in the maze of Federal grantinaid programs.

title: Janet Debra Epstein Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Epstein of York, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janet Debra Epstein, to Barry Mark Wolper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Wolper of Edison, N.J. The future bride, a 1977 alumna of the University of Pennsylvania, is an occupational therapist at All Saints Hospital in Philadelphia. Her fianc, a 1977 alumnus of the University of Virginia, is with Arthur Young & Company in New York. The wedding is planned for April.

title: Gloria Quigley Married to John Walton Winans, Broker
description: The marriage of Gloria Soderberg Quigley of Port Chester, N.Y., to John Walton Winans of Grosse Pointe, Mich., a stockbroker with Kidder Peabody & Company in Detroit, took place at the Rye (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Joseph Bishop performed the ceremony.

title: The Meadowlands' Roads Aren't Ready
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Last Sunday, when the Giants were playing the Rams in the new stadium here in the Hackensack Meadowlands, many of the 63,000 spectators started edging toward the exits before the game was threequarters over. That happens most football Sundays, even when the Giants aren't losing, as they were last week. The fans know what the score will be if they don't make quick getaway: They'll be trapped in endless lines of cars that take forever to` clear the parking lot.

title: A Parents' Guide to Children's Holiday Programming.;
description: At this time of year, youngsters are bombarded with a plethora of TV specials that have become the quasiofficial harbingers of Christmas. Thus, it seems a good time to evaluate these seasonal offerings, as well as to take stock of those children shows of particular merit that can be seen during regular programming schedules.

title: Internationalism Thrives at Manhattanville
description: PURCHASE BACK in the 90's, when a site for the United Nations was being sought, the land that Manhattanville College now occupies was under strong consideration. Although the U.N. settled along Manhattan's East River, many look at the international mood of the campus today and feel the fulfillment of some sort of destiny.

title: Cathy Lyn Morway Is Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Steven Deschat of Jericho, L.I., of the engagement of Mrs. Deschat's daughter, Cathy Lyn Morway, to Neil Seth Bloomberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Bloomberg of Manhasset Hills, L.I. A summer wedding is planned.

title: HIGH COURT TO HEAR CITY JOBBIAS CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 A test of the constitutionality of the New York City Transit Authority's refusal to hire methadone users reached the Supreme Court this week, in a case with potentially broad implications for many other types of employmentdiscrimination claims.

title: Miss Debevoise, Nurse, to Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Dickinson R. Debevoise of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Josephine Richards Debevoise, to Ralph N. Davies of Indianapolis. Mr. Davies is on the sales staff of the Ashland Chemical Company, a division of Ashland Oil.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE heroine of The African Queen is now fighting with Long Island Sound. Katharine Hepburn, who starred with Humphrey Bogart in the film classic set on a meandering African river, wants to stop the ocean from eroding the beach near her home in Fenwick, on the shore near the mouth of the Connecticut River.

title: Around the Nation
description: ROCKVILLE, Md., Dec. 9  Robert J. di Grazia, the controversial police chief who headed Boston's Police Department during that city's school desegregation disturbances, was dismissed on Thursday from his most recent post as chief of police in Montgomery County, Md., a wealthy suburb of Washington.

title: Article 7 -- No Title
description: MEDICAL, DENTAL and PODIATRIC SCHOOLS

title: The Government Party Was Thrown Out in Last Week's Election
description: CARACAS  From the doorways of their wooden shacks in the crowded hillside barrios, the slumdwellers of Caracas have an excellent view of executive jets landing at La Carlota airport.They can also see the new highrises where apartments cost $250,000, and hear the roundtheclock work on the city's new subway system. Right before their eyes, oil wealth is transforming Venezuela. Massive investment is taking place in industry, construction, mining, electricity, agriculture and public services. For the first time in memory Venezuelans are enjoying full employment in a booming economy.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 9 (AP)  Don January of Dallas bogeyed four holes today in the third round of the $210,000 Mexico Cup Golf Tournament but hung on to a threestroke lead over David Graham of Australia.

title: Births
description: BLACKSBURG

title: Sunday Observer
description: For the addict of Jackie books, very little sustenance has rolled off the presses this week. Despite its promising title, Jackie Oolala! turns out to be just another humdrum series of anecdotes by a Paris bellboy who carried Mrs. Onassis's luggage through the lobby of the CrilIon one day in 1969.

title: Now It's 'DialaBird'
description: BERNARDSVILLE NEW JERSEYANS now have a dialabird number to call for information on their feathered friends. By dialing (201) 7662661, the caller gets The Voice of New Jersey Audubon Bird Report, which is actually the voice of Richard Kane, a director of the state's Audubon Society. He delivers a weekly summary embodying rare birds, bird movements, birding conditions and good places to go birding in the state.

title: Families of Retarded Face New Burdens
description: NEW burdens are being imposed on hundreds of families of mentally retarded Westchester residents as a result of the Willowbrook consent decree of 1975, which mandated the return of more than 700 retarded residents of large institutions to their communities. Many of these former institutional inmates are being placed in supervised group homes or community residences, but retarded people who have been living with their families are being excluded.

title: Anomie Is the Issue
description: While waiting with more or less bated breath for the definitive crime novel to come tumbling off the presses  it will be the one about the sanitation department of a vast metropolis that holds the entire city for ransom  1 was led to contemplate the nature of the genre today. What with whodunits, whydunits and howdunits cheek by jowl on the booksellers shelves, it would appear that the only way to define it is to borrow heavily and apologetically from E. M.

title: Trains And Boats
description: THE clays of clipper ships will never come again  except, of course, in books. Which is why the books should be as trim and clean as the ships themselves. This one is. The clipper was built for speed. Her hull was long and thin, and her bow was shaped like a sharpcutting knife. That description, along with the picture alongside the title page, cleanly launches you on your voyage from New York to San Francisco. You will sail with 10yearold Jeremy Dow aboard the Golden Dragon. The year is 1850. The voyage will take more than 100 days. You will round the Horn in winter. You will put in at Valparaiso. And a day ahead of schedule you will drop anchor in San Francisco.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE Restaurant at the Inns of Court opened in midJune. In our eagerness to bring news of a promising dining spot, we went soon after the first announcement. The service was so gauche and the food so variable mat proper judgment could not be made. We set aside our notes for some monthsand returned for second visit recently. Since we waited nearly 15 minutes for our drink order to be served, it seemed at first as if nothing had changed. Actually, everything had changed, and for the better.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: I am not a native New Jerseyan; I lived on the eastern end of Long Island for most of my life. I thought of New Jersey as a place that I had to endure in order to get to some of the other states on the East Coast.

title: On Krypton, Superman Might Have Been a Plumber
description: Until the past several weeks, the moviegoing public probably hasn't come across the name Christopher Reeve. Soap opera buffs may have (he served two years on Love of Life), as may theater trivia connoisseurs (he did a stint with Katharine Hepburn in A Matter of Gravity), and Conceivably the name will ring a bell with aficionados of disaster films (few people other than relatives and close friends saw his minirole in the shortlived Gray Lady Down).

title: CALENDAR
description: Today: LockwoodMathews Mansion Antique Show. 295 West Ave., Norwalk. Take Exit 515 or N14 from Connecticut Turnpike.11 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title: The New York Choral Society Presents a Christmas Program
description: It is December, and the Christmas choral concerts have begun. As always, there will be performances of holiday pieces by composers of every stripe. The season's basic choral repertory, however, is ever the same: Handel's Messiah and Bach's Christmas Oratorio. Rather surprisingly, no other largescale Christmas works for chorus and orchestra are heard with any frequency.

title: Disco? How About SquareDancing?
description: AT LEAST twice a week, Vincent and Grace Saner don their squaredancing outfits and leave their Spotswood home to spend three hours at what looks like hard work. But to them, it is a respite in their otherwise busy lives.

title: Samuel I. Newhouse 3d Weds Carolyn L. Busch
description: Carolyn Leavey Busch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. M. Herbert Leavey of Harrisburg, Pa., was married yesterday to Samuel I. Newhouse 3d, son of Mrs. Kenneth Marks of New York and Samuel I. Newhouse Jr., chairman of Cond Nast Publications and grandson of Samuel I. Newhouse, owner of the Newhouse newspaper group. Rabbi Joseph H. Gelberman performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Newhouse Jr. in New York.

title: Discovery of Aztec Monolith in Mexico City Sparks a Major Excavation
description: MEXICO CITY  The accidental discovery of a beautifully carved Aztec monolith seven feet below a busy street in downtown Mexico City has sparked the most exciting archeological dig here in the last 65 years.

title: A. Cameron Mann, Former Head Of L.I. and Westchester Schools
description: A. Cameron Mann, a former headmaster of the Masters School in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., died Thursday at his home in Brattleboro, V.t. He was 74 years old.

title: Drastic Changes Planned in Newark School System
description: NEWARK, Dec., 9  The layoffs of school employees announced yesterday, eliminating about 1,000 teachers and aides and 700 substitute teachers, is merely: 'the first step in a complete restructuring of the school system here, the president of the School Board, Carl Sharif, said today

title: Detroit Is 54 Victor on Rookie's 2d Goal
description: DETROIT, Dec 9  Somebody should read the Rangers the tale of the tortoise and the hare. It may help the next time they race off to a big lead, as they did tonight against the Detroit Red Wings. The Wings, who obviously believe in fairy tales, kept plugging away at New York's 30 lead until they had crossed the finish line 54 victors.

title: Giants in Cellar Duel; Csonka's Last Year?
description: The Giants play the St. Louis Cardinals today at the Meadowlands with last place at stake. That's not quite the ending Larry Csonka had in mind.

title: President Visits Motel in Which King Was Slain
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 9 (UPI)  President Carter stood today on the motel balcony where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther KingJr. was killed and said that the world must always praise the goals for which the civil rights leader died.

title: HangersOn Are Coming Back
description: They're coming back. Hanging plants. For a time the hang by a hook near a window sort of greenery went through a everyone wants them craze. Then came a slump. People tired of the same old thing. Garden centers couldn't get rid of them and florists and supermarkets were letting them wilt on the vine, so to speak.

title: The Janet Soares Dance Troupe Specializes in Sinuous Movement
description: Janet Soares' choreography looks, best when it is most quiet and least manic.

title: JEWS IN CHICAGO AID SOVIET IMMIGRANTS
description: CHICAGO,, Dec. 9 (UPI)  You cannot understand how hard it is for us, Clementine , Khait said, a sorrowful expression lining her face. Our situation is very difficult. We have nothing.

title: Ministries Unit Opens
description: THE Smith Haven Ministries, an interdenominational social welfare agency, has made a major expansion move by opening a South Shore office in Bay Shore.

title: CAMERA
description: Although many people interested in photography do not realize it, the Division of Prints and Photographs of the Library of Congress in Washington offers a treasure house of photographs which anyone can order copies of for a nominal fee. Their vast collection of over 200 million photographs dates from the beginning of photography and covers every conceivable aspect of American life. Besides picturing the history and development of this country, many universally acknowledged and outstanding examples of photographic art are also included in this collection.

title: Port Chester Priest Recalls the Early Days of Pope John Paul
description: PORT CHESTER FATHER HENRY D'ANJOU was a seminary student in Wloclawek, a town in northern Poland, he recalled recently, when a young professor of theology would come from the Catholic University in Lublin to use the library and other facilities unavailable at his own school.

title: Danielson Stars
description: PONTIAC, Mich., Dec. 9  Gary Danielson and not Fran Tarkenton was the most conspicuous player at the Silverdome today as the Detroit Lions trounced the Minnesota Vikings, 4514, before a roaring crowd of 78,686 in the indoor stadium.

title: A Fable for Our Time
description: ALTHOUGH it has been a long time since most American children grew up on a farm or even near one, the myth continues that all youngsters have a natural rapport with and interest in animals. Urban babies are still shown alphabet cards with cows and ducks on them, though many may not see a cow until they are 40, or ever, except as translated by Walt Disney or McDonald's. For the child who grows up acquainted with cocker spaniels, alley cats, an occasional gerbil or cockroach and an annual visit to the zoo observe pythons and panthers in filthy captivity, the beast fable

title: Eileen Gail Berman Fiance of Student
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Berman of Allentown, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eileen Gail Berman, to Roberto Eugenio Fischmann, son of Imrich Fischmann of Guatemala City and the late Mrs. Fischmann.

title: THEATER MAILBAG
description: To the Editor:

title: Billy Joel Sings the Praises of New York
description: Atlanta Most adults have heard of Bob Dylan or the Rolling Stones. But unless they have teenaged children, chances are they haven't the vaguest notion of who Billy Joel is. Yet Mr. Joel, who's made a career as a touring musician tor eight years now, is presently the hottest male singer in the land. His last two albums, The Stranger and 52d Street, have sold some 6 million copies between them in this country in 1978 alone, with 52d Street firmly ensconced in the No. 1 spot on all the album sales charts for well over a month.

title: Now There's Money in the House
description: Early in the eighth round, Arthur Mercante parted Roberto Duran and Monroe Brooks when they were in a halfclinch. Brooks turned a questioning look on the referee as if to say: What for? We weren't tied up. Duran, who had been earnestly endeavoring to bat Brooks loose from his intellect spread his gloved hands, palms up, with a small shrug. Oh, well, his attitude seemed to say, that's a referee for You. Always inter fering, like the cops.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Exceptions Ranged From Serious to Frivolous
description: The report on New Jersey's $1 million, 18month investigation of Resorts International Inc. is 115 pages long and is backed by three volumes of documents, newspaper and magazine clippings, contracts and letters.

title: Kennedy Assails Carter on Budget At Midterm Meeting of Democrats
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 9  Senator Edward M. Kennedy today confronted President Carter over the spirit that should guide the Democratic Party, telling the party's midterm conference on issues that Democrats must sail against the wind of public opinion and reject drastic slashes in domestic spending.

title: On the Trail of a Steer, from Birth to Burger
description: Early on the evening of June 26, in the backyard of Robert and Susan Mandell's house in Montvale, N.J., the hamburgers were sizzling on the gasfueled barbecue grill. It was the final chapter of a saga that had begun twoandahalf years before on a farm in Missouri.

title: Fashion
description: When the temperature swoops downward and the winter winds whistle, it's nice to keep warm and still look good. It's even better if the outer layers add warmth without excessive weight. The coverups shown here do just that  for at least part of the anatomy. The rest of the body can be taken care of with the usual accouterments: tights, boots, scarves, mittens and caps.

title: THE MARKETS
description: For the second week in a row, movements in the stock market generated more heat than light. Prices fluctuated in a narrow range and the Dow Jones industrial average illustrated the lack of investor conviction.

title: Matrix Plays Jazz at Other. End
description: Matrix, a ninepiece jazz group from Wisconsin, is in town this weekend, playing at the Other End through tonight in support of (or being supported by) a new record called Wizard.

title: Bean Can Collapse Brings Suit
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 9 (AP)  A pyramid of bean cans that cascaded on a customer who picked a can from a grocery store display is the object of a $15,000 lawsuit. Janet Parks filed suit yesterday in Jackson County Circuit Court against the A.&P. food stores.

title: Bonjour Ennui
description: Franoise Sagan's 12th novel is set, like the other 11, among the rich, the glamorous, the cosmopolitan, the bored. This time her subject is the love affair of tempestuous Beatrice Valmont, the movie star, and Edouard Maligrasse, a struggling playwright on the verge of triumph. Beatrice is older, thoroughly Parisian, unfaithful with a blithe obliviousness that we are meant to see as elemental, intriguing. Edouward is almost too young for her (he's 36), still a bit of a provincial, much inclined to mope about in jealousy and despair. They fight, break up, start over any number of times, all of which is of immense interest, Miss Sagan assures us, to the Tout Paris, that at once brilliant and nauseating circle of gossipmongers and Beautiful People, who exchange glances in chic restaurants with imitationleather floors when Beatrice and Edouard show up, obviously fresh from bed, for an elegant lunch.

title: F.T.C. Says a New Agency Judge Will Hear Cereal Antitrust Case
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP)  The Federal Trade Commission has decided that a new administrative law judge will take over the Federal antitrust case against major breakfast cereal companies, 6 years into the legal fight.

title: The Olympics: Bigger Is Really Better
description: GIGANTISM is a feature of our day and age. Nuclear energy places gigantic resources at our disposal. The continual revolutions in science and technology lead to gigantic progress. We inhabit gigantic towns, we live in gigantic buildings, we travel at gigantic speeds, we are bombarded with a gigantic flow of information, we witness cosmic travel covering gigantic distances.

title: A Blow to Schmidt's Merger Dreams
description: Like many a regional brewer, the F. & M. Schaefer Corporation has had its financial problems. But the New York brewer of Schaefer and Piers apparently isn't ready to throw in the towel. Last week it won a preliminary injunction to block C. Schmidt & Sons from going ahead with plans to take it over.

title: Million Gallons of Gas Pumped Off Leaking Barge in Gravesend Bay
description: Workmen unloaded one million gallons of gasoline from a disabled barge anchored in Gravesend Bay off Coney Island yesterday after a tugboat rammed the barge late Friday night, spilling 50,000 gallons of gasoline into the bay.

title: Visions and Revisions
description: THE invisible poet was what Hugh Kenner in a book thus titled called him, meaning that the intelligence and feeling in and with language seemed to come at us off T.S. Eliot's page directly, not refracted through any discernible personality. But that was long ago, before the predictable posthumous revelations about Eliot's private life, and about how some of his most famous poems got to be written. Now, following Valerie Eliot's publication of the drafts and fragments that went to make The Waste Land, we have Helen Gardner's meticulous, not to say finicky, transcriptions of the drafts of Four Quartets, with full and very well arranged editorial apparatus listing variant readings, and with Professor Gardner's commentary.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The crystal balls that so many economists use to foresee the future are growing dark. Many say this is because the outlook is so grim. Others say it is because the devices are so unreliable they just aren't working any more, and there have been suggestions that the crystal ball industry will soon be stung by the announcement of a vast recall.

title: Kennedy Space Center To Get Spacelab Work
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI) The installation of all experiments in the space laboratory that will fly to and from orbit in the space shuttle will be performed at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida instead of Huntsville, Ala.

title: Tower of Trade, A Gem of 1921
description: In the last analysis, August Heckscher said not long after his new building at 730 Fifth Avenue opened 1921, whoever will not shop on Fifth Avenue and 57th Street will not shop anywhere.

title: Design
description: Once upon a time, thermos bottles were manufactured in the lofty space shown above. Then interior designer Andree Putman moved in on it, connected it to her 17thcentury Paris apartment and transformed it into elegant quarters for working and entertaining.

title: College Women and SelfEsteem
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 9 (AP) Women at six of the country's most prestigious colleges have lower selfesteem and lower aspirations than men, even though their grades are about the same, according to a recent study.

title: Housing Balance Still Up in the Air
description: ADEBATE over home rule and the concept of balanced housing is expected next year when the State Legislature takes up a bill designed to implement the controversial Mount Laurel decision.

title: Education Office Seeks Ideas on Adult Programs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP)  The Government is taking a look at adult education programs around the country and is seeking public comment on what needs to be done to improve them.

title: Why Does the Tut Show Draw Such Big Crowds?
description: It's the appeal of buried treasure, Richard Morsches, a Metropolitan Museum executive, said last week. It's curiosity about the past, said Dr. David Abrahamsen, the psychoanalyst and author. And Barbara Smith, a Bay Shore, LA., housewife, said, It's that fascinating story about the curse.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: 'Tis the season, and to help everyone to get into the proper spirit, communities throughout the Island have scheduled holiday treelighting parties. Today in Stony Brook, village residents and State University people will meet at 4:30 P.M. at the Village Green, light the first of two local trees  the other is at Woods Corner, where Nichols Road and Route 25A intersect  and then proceed to the campus, where at the End of the Bridge Restaurant in the Stony Brook Union there will be a party, complete with caroling, Santa and nibbling on such refreshments as the world's largest gingerbread man, a 10footlong, 100pound delicacy baked for the occasion.
