title: Elizabeth Seward Is Fianc Of Kienan Murphy, Physician
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry Seward of Rochester have made known the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Seward, to Dr. Kienan F. Murphy, son of Mr: and Mrs. James B. Murphy of Rye. N.Y.

title: New Murders Last Week in Europe's Worst Killing Ground
description: SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain  Eushadi Ta Ashatasuna. In the esoteric Basque language, those words mean Basque Homeland and Liberty, and the E.T.A. is the Basque underground organization. When Francisco Franco ran Spain, the group became a symbol of defiance and resistance to the dictatorship. In December 1973, one of its units changed the course of Spanish history by assassinating the dictator's chosen heir, Adm. Luis Carrero Blanco. In December 1978, the E.T.A. remains a symbol of defiance, this time to a democratic central Government, and the continuing random killings carried out by its youthful militants resemble the violence that pervades Northern Ireland.

title: Cost of 2 Casinos Put at $49 Million
description: THE most serious exception brought against Resorts International Inc. last week by the state's Division of Gaming Enforcement was that the state had not been given complete information about the money used by the company in getting established in the Bahamas and Atlantic City.

title: Soviet Prediction of Earthquake Proves Accurate in 2 of 3 Factors
description: A few hours before a severe earthquake on Nov. 2, Soviet scientists predicted both its magnitude and time, but they were less accurate in pinpointing its location.

title: Deaths
description: ALEXANDERMae. The Board & Staff of the New York Service for the Handicapped record with profound sorrow the death of Mae Alexander. As Board member, Treasurer & Chairman, her 45 years of service was an inspiration to us all. Her concern for the disabled was unsurpassed. She chose hope rather than pity & rejoiced in their success, wheCher at the Alexander School for disabled adults or Camp Oakhurst. Only months ago, she visited with the handicapped children at camp. Her love for them found expression in service. They will miss her concern. We will miss her warmth. To her devoted family go our sincere expression of sympathy.

title: Female Pros Make History
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 9  For everyone connected with the opening game of the Women's Professional Basketball League in the Milwaukee Arena today there was a sense of history being made.

title: Temporary Shelter for Indigents in Capital Is Shut
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9  A nineday peaceful takeover of part of the National Visitor Center for use as a makeshift overnight dormitory and soup kitchen ended today when Federal officials, frustrated with deteriorating health and safety conditions there, locked the doors.

title: POLITICS
description: DO you favor placing a limit on state spending? Sure, most state legislators will tell you these days. In the climate of Proposition 13, which forced a reduction in property taxes in California, that's like asking if a public official favors motherhood.

title: Chaka Khan Sings as a Solo Siren
description: Chaka Khan, who appeared at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday night, is a siren in more ways than one. Not only is she an allingoodfun seductress (during a sultry song dedicated to all the fellas, she reached out and playfully ran her fingers through the hair of a gentleman in the first row), but she also has a fiery wail of a voice. Also like a siren, her voice can become nagging, which is why her first solo concert in New York City (until now she has sung with the group Rufus, with whom she plans to continue singing in addition to performing on her own) was almost but not quite a triumph.

title: Greenwich Library
description: GREENWICH THEY line up outside for half an hour before the doors open at 1 P. M., then they make a dash for seats, otherwise they will have to read standing up. One would think that on a Sunday afternoon it would not be that crowded  after all, it isn't the 7:43 to New York, or the opening of a smash show or the baseball season  it's the Greenwich Library.

title: Half a Prize, Half a Treaty
description: Prime Minister Begin may reveal in Oslo today what value he attaches to half a Nobel Peace Prize. In this matter, at least, we prefer President Sadat's sense of the fitness of things: work first, reward later. The work still undone is the treaty of peace that they solemnly vowed at Camp David three months ago to sign by next Sunday. As President Carter has noted, a great deal depends on their holding to schedule.

title: Business Is Booming at Christmas Tree Farm in Vermont
description: CANAAN, Vi., Dec. 9 (UPI)  In the cold hills above the Connecticut River, Lorrainy Marchessault has spent 20 years battling insects, bad weather and doubting bankers to grow the perfect Christmas tree.

title: Learning From Others' Mistakes
description: WITH Connecticut riding the caboose rather than the engine of the national movement to reform the financial underpinnings of public education, the School Finance Advisory Panel had the advantage of other states hindsight in working out a strategy to meet the demand of the Supreme Court to eliminate the wide disparities in the spending levels of rich and poor school districts.

title: One Good Eye Is Enough
description: At practice all week, Wesley Walker hears the coaches shouting, Look the ball ... Look the ball into your hands ... Look the ball. But when he looks at a football spiraling toward him, he sees it mostly with only his right eye. He is legally blind in his left eye because of a cataract he has had since birth. But one good eye has been enough. As the New York Jets await today's game with the Browns in Cleveland, their 23 yearold wide receiver has caught 42 passes, scored eight touchdowns and leads the National Football League with 1,068 yards and an average gain of 25.4 yards. His sprinter's speed has helped. He has been timed at 40 yards in a blazing 4.35 seconds. But first he has to catch the football that he sees with only one good eye.

title: Marriage Announcement 6 -- No Title
description: Engagements

title: Baby Talk
description: MORE than any other people and more than at any other time, educated Americans in the 20th century have believed in the continuity of human development. For us, Wordsworth's childasfatheroftheman is at once principle and fact; what happens to children early in their lives defines their lives. Early experience is seen as crucial (even, implausibly, social exchange in the first hours of life) the family is assigned first responsibility for the mental health of children; personality is assumed to be early formed and relatively unchanging; and, most unfortunately, if the child is not performing well home and in school by the age of 6, it may be too late for remedy.

title: ChildMolesting Plea Entered
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9 (UPI)  The eighth of nine defendants to face trial for participating in an international child sex ring has pleaded guilty to two counts of molesting an 8yearold girl. Lester Henry, 91, a family counselor from Indianapolis, was ordered yesterday to return to court Feb. 13 for a hearing on whether he should be declared a mentally disordered sex offender: He faces an estimated five years in custody. He became the sixth of nine ment Indicted last summer to plead guilty to charges involving the operation of an international child prostitution and pornography ring.

title: The Best of the Pictures
description: The 10 books represented on these pages were selected from all the children's books published in 1978 by Steven Heller, art director of the Book Review, and George Woods, children's book editor. In this 27th annual award for the best illustrated children's books are three former winners  Alice and Martin Provensen, named six times before, and Tomi Ungerer, named three times before.

title: State Inquiry: 17 Objections to Casino's Future
description: RESERVATIONS about rogues with past ties to Resorts International Inc. and its predecessor, the Mary Carter Paint Company, added spice to an official state investigation of the gamblingcasino company.

title: Golda Meir: 18981978
description: She looked like everyone's idea of a Jewish grandmother: greying hair in a knot with a few wisps escaping, wearing oldfashioned tweed suits and orthopedic shoes. But Golda Meir, who died last week at 80, will be remembered as a builder and preserver of the state of Israel, a forceful Prime Minister and an extraordinary political figurenot to say woman of her time.

title: Daryl Isaacs, Physician, Fianc of Emily Hardy
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alan H. Hardy of Great Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Emily M. Hardy, to Dr. Daryl Isaacs, a resident in medicine at Peter Bent Brigham Affiliated I losoital Center in Boston. He is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Isaacs of Cape Town, where his mother, Dr. Maisie Isaacs, is a physician.

title: Events Today
description: Christmas Bazaar: Boutique, raffles, food; 10 A.M. to 3 P.M.; Administration Building, New York Military Academy, CornwallonHudson, N.Y.

title: City Votes Minor Fines For Liquor Violations
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Dec. 9 (UPI) The City Council in this community, the home of the University of Michigan, has unanimously approved an ordinance providing $5 fines for individuals who sell alcoholic beverages to people under the age of 21.

title: Radio
description: 7:308 A.M., WABC: Message of Israel. Two Generations in Perspective.

title: Watergate Was a Golden Age
description: WITTY, devilish, erudite  the characteristics that make William Satire perhaps the best political columnist at work today also make him the perfect political lexicographer. He takes to the lingo like a California Republican takes to dirty tricks.

title: GulliCavallo Duo in Recital
description: Franco Gulli, violinist, and Enrica Cavallo, pianist, have been performing as a husband and wife duo for over 30 years. Now instructors at the Indiana University School of Music, the Gullis gave a recital Friday night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Who's Watching the Wassailers?
description: HOLIDAYS are traditionally a time for drinking, but we must remember that children are watching. You may think that they don't see how much or what, where and with whom we drink, but they do. And we are the models for their future drinking patterns.

title: Former Band Member Is Sought In Slaying of Three in Kansas
description: WICHITA, Kan., Dec. 9 (UPI)  Sheriff's deputies today sought a disgruntled member of a local dance band in connection with the slaying of Norman Lee; the band leader, his wife and the band's publicist.

title: Some Questions About Financing The State's Schools
description: OVERALL, the effect of the recommendations of the state advisory panel on educational funding should be:

title: From Rabbi to Restaurateur
description: FIRST of all, Martin Soshtain wants to take back what he said about his mother and the vegetables. The last time he was interviewed, Mr. Soshtain accused his mother of boiling vegetables until they were dead, and added, And she wouldn't let us eat them unless she was sure they were dead.

title: Frieda Kahlo's Tragic Sense of Life
description: PURCHASE MOST artists draw liberally from their life's experiences to express themselves, but rarely does one single event influence them as much as one event influenced Mexican painter Frida Kahlo, whose works are on view at the Neuberger Museum. On Sept. 19, 1925, she was in a highway accident in Mexico City which left her with a broken foot, a spine fractured in several places and a smashed pelvis.

title: Staten Island OTB Office Robbed By 2 Men, Who Get $34,000 Cash
description: Two men armed with a shotgun and a handgun robbed an Offtrack Betting Corporation office on Staten Island of $34,000 in cash last night, according to the police, who said no shots were fired and no one was injured.

title: Bay State May Ease Student Curb
description: AMHERST, Mass., Dec. 9 (AP)  Unlike most state college administrators, the University of Massachusetts trustees have decided that outofstate students are an asset to the school's budget.

title: Moffetts' Jazz Trio at Ladies' Fort
description: A jazz trio consisting of an 11yearold bassist, a 16yearold drummer and a 19yearold saxophonist might not sound very promising, but Thursday night at the Ladies' Fort, 2 Bond Street, Charnett, Codaryl and Charles Moffett were more than promising. They had the audience cheering, and the audience included some exceptional musicians, among them Ornette Coleman, Phillip Wilson, Arthur Blythe, Prince Lawsha and the father of the trio, Charles Moffett Sr.

title: Brenda M. Donelan Engaged to Broker
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis X.J. Donelan of New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Brenda Mary Donelan, to John F. Wallace 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace of West Hempstead, L.I..

title: Holiday Music Fills the Air
description: THE sound of Handel's Messiah will be heard across the Island over the next few weeks as amateur and professional musicians and singers tune up for a heavy schedule of holiday concerts that could keep music lovers occupied right up to Christmas and beyond.

title: Judge Considers a Halt to Religious Singing in Schools
description: SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Dec. 9  A Federal district judge will accept written arguments Monday on whether to stop Christmas assemblies in the public schools here.

title: The Nation
description: Attempting the artistry of political compromise, President Carter is confronted by the need to paint by budget numbers. The result is a set of crude choices. While the President's political aides are privately marshaling behind the 3 percent target for military growth he pledged 18 months ago, his economic and social programmers are tightening ranks against the domestic cuts needed to hold the Federal deficit to the $30 billion he promised last fall. Mr. Carter's trouble is that there is sound politics on each side.

title: Paper Company and Union Agree To $750,000 Award in Bias Suit
description: MOBILE, Ala., Dec. 9 (UPI)  Scott Paper Company has announced that a $750,000 settlement has been reached with plantiffs in a 1971 suit charging the company and the paper workers union with discrimination against black workers.

title: FoodVendor Depots Found Filthy, With Laws Violated
description: Dirty water drips from ceilings, grime coats ancient refrigerators and refuse litters walls and floors, where pretzels, buns, chestnuts, soda cans and other food supplies lie exposed to the air and sometimes to rat and roach infestation.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: For film buffs who favor Westerns, the Thalia has turned over Tuesdays, for 12 weeks (through Feb. 20), to a review of the genre. The period covered runs from the late 1930's to the mid60's, including not only landmarks such as Red River and High Noon but a number of films rarely shown theatrically. This Tuesday has a program of the latter: Raoul Walsh's Distant Drums (1951), with Gary Cooper, and Mr. Walsh's Colorado Territory (1949), with Joel McCrea, Virginia Mayo and Dorothy Malone. (See Film)

title: Finance Plan Faces Political TugofWar
description: HARTFORD THE General Assembly's perception of school finance is not unlike that of the average citizen. Most state legislators know equalization of education is important and hope it will mean good things for their towns, but have only the fuzziest notion of the details involved.

title: Shortfall in State U.'s Enrollmen To Cut Its Revenue by $2 Million
description: The State University of New York has 5,000 fewer students this year than the 166,000 that had been anticipated, a gap that the vice chancellor for finance, Harry K. Spindler, called the biggest ever.

title: One Wodehouse, Two Hanleys, One Green
description: P.G. WODEHOUSE was the exponent of a form that no intelligent writer has been able to take seriously for several hundred years: the comic pastoral. You would have to go back to the enchanted forests of Shakespearean comedy to find even a fleeting analogy with his fiction  to the suspended green worlds of Arden and Illyria, where loveknots are festively disentangled, parentage mysteries advantageously resolved and fortunes miraculously accumulated, all without pain. And when we note that Wodehouse's green world tolerantly includes 20thcentury London and New York, as well as the forgiving lawns of rural England. we begin to see his true cloudlessness as an author.

title: 12th Body Is Reported Found in Newark Fire
description: Firemen sifting through the rubble of a fire that killed 11 persons in Newark Thursday morning found what appeared to be the partial remains of a 12th victim yesterday, according to an assistant medical examiner.

title: Notes: Diamond Jubilee of Flight
description: They have done it. They have done it. Damned if they ain't flew.

title: A Vietnam Veteran Emerges From a Lost Decade
description: RICHMOND, Va.  For six years, Douglas Schwinn relived in his dreams that terrible afternoon when North Vietnamese troops encircled his infantry company on a godforsaken hill near the Cambodian border.

title: World News Briefs
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 9 (UPI)  A Federal judge has ordered United Airlines to pay $50,000 in penalties for having violated American sanctions against Rhodesia.

title: What's Doing in BANGKOK
description: REAL AND UNREAL  The first Bangkok that takes hold of the visitor is not the real city typical of its people and its ways but a city built only for tourists. Few cities have created so much that has nothing to do with the life of its inhabitant's and that exists only to separate the foreigner from his money. Few make it so easy for hordes of travelers to pass through while seeing hardly anything that was not specifically created for the visitor.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Trading Small Talk
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 9  The conventioneers at baseball's annual winter meetings sold everything from players to official major league hair dryers this week. Most likely, more hair dryers were sold than players.

title: LETTER TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: Andree Brooks's story about old Stonington [Nov. 26] is really about the Borough of Stonington, a small part of the town of Stonington. Old Stonington used to include my town of North Stonington until 1807.

title: Tel Aviv Girl, Yiddish Fun At Diplomat
description: For those who savor the comic ups and the tearful downs of plot and the traditional tunesmithery of the Yiddish musical theater of bygone years, the type of theater that provided escapism for the Lower East Side, which always enjoyed tsoress on stage and had more than enough of its own waiting at the exit, The Girl From TelAviv should fill the bill.

title: Cynthia Gates, Student, Engaged to Bruce Baber
description: Cynthia Ann Gates, a senior at the Duke University School of Nursing, and Bruce William Baber, in his last year at the Duke University Law School, plan to be married May 27 in the Princeton University Chapel. Mr. Baber is a Princeton alumnus.

title: Company Appalled By State's Charges
description: OFFICALS of Resorts International Inc. said last week that the company will present complete defense against state charges of criminal associations and mismanagement with respect to its gambling casino in Atlantic City.

title: The Death of a Young Mother Leaves Her Family in Shock
description: The desolation of last winter seemed remote to John Ross. He and his wife were expecting their third child. They had been married for almost five years and were the parents of a fouryearold boy and a threeyearold girl.

title: WHY BUKHARIN'S GHOST STILL HAUNTS MOSCOW
description: A ghost has risen from the Stalinist past to challenge the rulers of the Soviet Union. It is the specter of a small, zestful man with boyish charm and puckish humor who, 40 years ago, stood in the dock in Moscow and confessed to an array of heinous  and patently false  charges against him.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Instant books. When an extraordinary event shakes the Western world, the residents of Publishers Row don't react merely with wonder or horror as do you and I. If they're paperbounders especially if they've worked for Bantam Books  they're apt to get out a special telling the full story within a fortnight. Bantam has produced some 64 such instant books since 1964; the most successful of these, Ninety Minutes at Entebbe, rated 1,100,000 copies in 1976.

title: A Look at Vision Therapy:
description: NEXT time you go to an optometrist, don't be surprised if instead of fitting you with glasses or recommending surgery for an eye disorder he prescribes a program of eye calisthenics. He may be one of a growing number of behavioral optometrists who treat with vision therapy.

title: A Threat to Social Programs Worries Some of the Democrats
description: MEMPHIS  This is our party. They can't take it away from us, shouted a dissident liberal Thursday night, complaining that the Carter Administration had railroaded through unfair rules for the Democratic Party's midterm convention here.

title: Senator Stevens Quits Hospital
description: ANCHORAGE, Dec. 9 (UPI)  The Senate minority whip, Ted Stevens, who was injured Monday in an air crash that killed five persons including his wife, was released from Providence Hospital today. Senator Stevens, 55 years old, suffered two cracked ribs, multiple bruises and a mild contusion on his head when a chartered jet carrying seven passengers crashed on landing at Anchorage International Airport.

title: CHESS
description: Gambits intensify the difficulty of making decisions about the comparative value of material as against nebulous attacking chances. That is their purpose  to force the defender out of routine schematic thinking into a realm where it's necessary to be original.

title: Donna Jean Dufek Plans a June Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank Dufek Jr. of Pittstown, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Donna Jean Dufek, to Dean Chapman Durling, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carlton C. Durling of Whitehouse and Mantoloking, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: ALLAMERICAN BOY ON TRIAL
description: From the beginning, there was a basic contradiction in the strange case of Ted Bundy. The moment he stepped into the courtroom in Utah three years ago to answer a charge of kidnapping, those who saw him for the first time agreed with those who had known him for all of his 28 years: There must have been some terrible mistake. Here was a young man who represented the best in America, not its worst. Here was this terrific looking man with light brown Some say that Ted Bundy is the most prolific mass murderer in American history; Bundy claims he is the tragic victim of a tangling web of circumstances. hair and blue eyes, looking rather Kennedyesque, dressed in a beige turtleneck and dark blue blazer, a smile turning the corners of his lean allAmerican face, walking almost jauntily before the judge, but free of any extravagant motion that could lead one to think a swaggering  even dangerous  personality existed beneath that casual, cool exterior.

title: Riverside Church Conference Seeks Arms Cutback
description: A religiousbased effort to slow down the arms buildup drew more than 550 members of the clergy and lay people to a conference lifit week at Riverside Church on a planned national education effort.

title: Presidential Item Veto Backed by 70% in Poll
description: Seventy percent of the American public favors giving the President power to veto specific items in a bill without having to veto the whole measure, according to the latest Gallup Poll. Nineteen percent oppose the idea and 11 percent have no opinion

title: Mixed Reactions
description: AS the implications of the proposed school finance system become more widely understood by local officials and the public, the disagreements already evident among members of the school finance panel will move into a wider arena of debate over how the plan may or may not affect each of the state's 169 cities and towns.

title: Music in Review
description: Samuel Mammel, who made his official New York recital debut Monday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, is currently a graduate student at the Juilliard School. His playing became more convincing as the evening progressed, and there were several possible reasons for that.

title: Westchester/ThisWeek
description: ELMSFORD The Music Man, Tuesday to Sunday (through Feb. 18). Opens 6:15 P.M., buffet at 7, show at 8:30; Sundays an hour earlier. $16 to $18. Reservations. An Evening. Dinner Theater, 11 Clearbrook Rd. 5922222.

title: Furriers Worry About Their Boom
description: I've just heard the most marvelous news  there's a blizzard in Chicago and it might be moving East.

title: Michaels Tempering Jets Like Clockwork
description: Walt Michaels will not discuss playoffs with his Jets even today, when they play the Browns at Cleveland.

title: With Hopes High as a Cathedral, Many Seek to Work on St. John's
description: Minutes after arriving at her desk last Tuesday morning, Odessa Elliott, the secretary to the dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, had a visitor who was looking for work. lie was a recent immigrant from Yugoslavia who, like many other in the neighborhood and the city, was responding to the news that construction on the cathedral would resume after a hiatus of 37 years.

title: PRESIDENT ASSAILED BY PARTY DELEGATES
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 9  President Carter met criticism today from delegates to the Democratic Party's midterm conference who were unhappy with his antiinflation program, his plans to increase defense spending while cutting domestic programs and his backing for an expensive mobile missile program.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, DECEMBER 10, 1978

title: Fish Banned in Canada Reportedly Sold in U.S.
description: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Dec. 9 (AP)Swordfish banned in Canada because of mercury content are being caught by Canadian fishermen and sold to Americans through United States fishermen, Canadian fisheries officials report.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: New Demonstrations
description: TEHERAN, Iran  The lull between the bloodshed last weekend, at the beginning of the holy month of Moharram, and the anticipated clashes this weekend, when the Iranian religious calendar comes to a climax in the holiday known as Ashura, gave everybody here an opportunity to think about a solution to the crisis that has threatened the reign of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.

title: Olympics in Sight
description: A VERY YOUNG GYMNAST By Jill Krementz. Illustrated. 128 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $8.95.

title: Safety Experts Bid Legislatures Raise Minimum Driver Age to 18
description: WARRENSBURG, Mo., Dec, 9 (AP) The National Safety Conference has recommended that state legislatures raise the minimum legal driving age to 18 to cut down on traffic accidents involving untrained young drivers.

title: TV VIEW
description: Pamela Hill, the executive producer of documentaries for ABC News, has rapidly found herself becoming the Peck's Bad Girl of broadcast journalism. She's generating enough national attention, some of it not very favorable, to challenge the print press's preoccupations with NBC's Fred Silverman. She's attempting to be experimental and is already embroiled in controversies. She is ignoring such traditional networknews practices as the almost airtight restrictions against presenting outside independent productions. She's openly sympathetic to different ideas about television. In general, she has become a provocative force for change, and without doubt elements of change are sorely needed in a number of areas within the broadcasting business.

title: Sadat Absence, Begin Presence Awkward for Oslo
description: OSLO, Dec. 9  The decision of Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel to accept his Nobel Peace Prize here tomorrow, while his colaureate, President Anwar elSadat of Egypt, remains in Calm, has created a mood of awkward discomfort among Norwegians. And they have had little success in masking it.

title: Wine
description: Does anyone shed a tear as I occasionally do for the old Ambassador? Talk about your great wine shops; there has never been a store to equal the Ambassador, on East 88th Street in Manhattan, for its collection of German wines. There were some bordeaux on the shelves, and a few burgundies, probably. But they were for convenience. The Ambassador, in the heart of what was New York's German section, was designed for the the connoisseur of German wines.

title: Aqueduct Faces Freeze
description: A second straight day of rain turned Aqueduct's racing surface into swamp yesterday and raised the threat of a maintenance crisis.

title: Miss Stewart, John Hollister Set June Bridal
description: Mrs. H. Christian Zweng and Ray S. Stewart of Atherton, Calif., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Sandra Jean Stewart, to John Hollister Stevenson, son of Anne Hollister Stevenson of New York and J.J. Stevenson Jr. of Cincinnati. A June wedding is planned.

title: EXCHANGE SCHOLARS FROM CHINA ARRIVE
description: Scholars from China have begun arriving at American universities, and the United States Government is preparing to announce the names of a dozen American students and professors who will go to China next month, marking the official start of an exchange that could bring 10,000 Chinese itudents to the West over the next several years.

title: Life in Townhouse Condos A Blend of Many Flavors
description: Some people buy suburban townhouse condominiums because they like apartment living, and others buy them because they like houses.

title: Strike in Britain Is Causing Cuts In 1,200 Papers
description: LONDON, Dec. 9 British newspaper readers are getting sparse fare this week.

title: Kennedy Presses for Health Plan
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 9  Senator Edward M. Kennedy issued a ringing challenge to the Carter Administration and Congress today to enact a comprehensive national health insurance program that would make health care a right for all our people now.

title: What's Cooking and Who's Teaching
description: THERE seems to be an increasing trend among Westchester's cooking instructors to tailor their courses to the interests and convenience of the students. Except in the larger organizations, such as adult education departments in which fixed schedules are set well in advance, teachers indicate that they plan to wait until a number of students have registered before determining the exact day, hour and, in some cases, the particular curriculum of the course.

title: EGYPT SEEKS SHIFTS IN 2 PARTS OF PACT
description: CAIRO, Dec. 9  On the eve of Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance's arrival here, Egypt is still seeking two changes in the American draft of a peace treaty endorsed by Israel, Egyptian officials said today.

title: Leonard Stops Muniz To Remain Undefeated
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Dec. 9 (UPI)  Sugar Ray Leonard won his 17th professional fight today by scoring a sixthround technical knockout of Armando Muniz in a nationally televised bout.

title: Deaths
description: BROD Anna. Devoted mother of Madelon Glassman and Charles Sachs. Adored grandmother of Fran, Donald, Amy, and Nancy. Greatgrandmother of Kenneth and Justin. Dear sister of Miriam, Flo, Helen, Selma and Herbert. Loving aunt and friend to all. Services were held.

title: Engagements
description: FOGGLECHNER

title: Sheryl H. Puchalsky Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Puchalsky of Franklin Square, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sheryl Helene Puchalsky, to Dr. Gary S. Berkowitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murry W. Berkowitz of Flushing, Queens. Miss Puchalsky graduated from the State University of New York at Buffalo. Her fianc, a dentist in New York, is an alumnus of Queens College and the New York University College of Dentistry.

title: I Am Not A Camera
description: WINSTONSALEM, N.C.Not long ago, members of the Board of Stewards of the Walnut Street Methodist Church checked into the Blueview Motel, just off the Parkway. They were not there to pray. They were there to learn Management by Objectives, a trend whose price is right. For onetenth of the entire church budget, the stewards hired Creative Management Consultants to teach them how to serve the Lord with gladness and come before His presence with a song.

title: Roar of the Sax and All That
description: BARS are good places to play because there's more communication with the audience, said Wes Houston, leader of Wes Houston and the AllStar Space Band, one of the Island's most enduring bar bands, because when you're so close to the people, you can't fool 'em if you're bad.

title: Cancer Research Unit Gets Local Support
description: WALKER Laboratory in Rye, a division of SloanKettering Institute, has acquired a new group of supporters, Women for Cancer Research. The group was recently formed by Westchester women who wanted to know more precisely how funds they had been raising for cancer programs were being spent.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Exhibitors take note: Everybody has a horror story about going to the movies the high cost of tickets, the rudeness of ushers, terrible projection, reels three and four shown instead of five and six, that sort of thing. Here is mine for the week. One recent Thursday, I attended the 11 A.M. showing of Death on the Nile at a theater on Broadway. The weather outside was clear and cold. The weather inside was dark and almost as cold, so chilly that it was necessary to wear one's overcoat for a bit of comfort. In addition, there was some sort of construction taking place in the theater. The fact that a film was in progress cut no ice with the carpenters and plumbers, who had their jobs to do and were doing them for the first hour. None of the handful of patrons registered a complaint. Like sheep in a rain storm we huddled in the same general area of the orchestra and attempted to lose ourselves in the opulence of the movie, whose hot, sunny Nubian locale only added to our feelings of discomfort.

title: Headliners Cold Turkey!
description: In California, nobody's perfect for long. Once upon a time, Charles Dederich, the founder of Synanon, was the brilliant begetter of a successful communal therapy for alcoholics and drug addicts whom nothing else had helped. Times changed. membership dropped, and people began saying Synanon looked like one more loony cult with a charismatic leader. Last week, Mr. Dederich was arrested in Arizona on a California warrant charging him with conspiracy to commit murder, in that he asked two Synanon members to place a live rattlesnake in the mailbox of a lawyer who had argued a successful damage suit against Synanon. Mr. Dederich was carried from his home, apparently drunk, and his extradition has been delayed until he can be released from the hospital.

title: High on the Hog: Southern Folkfood
description: I'm from the North Carolina hills: that's cornbread and buttermilk; turnip and mustard greens; ham hock, fatback and pot liquor. Folkfood, mythfood, mnemonic food. Unhaute cuisine  a living link with the alimentary past.

title: Excerpts From Text of Vance's Speech in London
description: LONDON. Dec. 9 (AP)  Following are excerpts from the text of a speech today by Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance to the Royal Institute of International Affairs in London.

title: LETTER TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: The article on the childcenteredness of the suburbs and interview with Kaye Greenleaf [Nov. 12] was not objective enough in pointing out the suburbs.for children. I am a 21yearold who has lived all my life in New York City, but many of my friends from college years are Long Islanders. I know from them that there are many more drawbacks to life in the suburbs than the one mentioned by Mrs. Greenleaf, namely the dependence on parents to drive them everywhere.

title: New Scale Speeding Checkups By Weighing Trucks in Motion
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 9 (UPI) A new scale has been devised to weigh trucks moving at speeds up to 30 miles an hour. And even truckers, who in general loathe police checks of their cargo weight, concede it has its good points.

title: AMERICANS' EXODUS FROM IRAN SPURRED BY CARTER DECISION
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 9 The American exodus from Iran increased today after the United States decided to fly military and civilian dependents out of this country at Government expense.

title: G.S.A. Hires First 50 Of 150 Investigators To Examine Scandals
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI)  Jay Solomon, head of the General Services Administration, has announced the hiring of 50 investigators, auditors and lawyers as part of an expanded investigation into the scandalplagued Federal agency.

title: Concerning Christmas
description: AUTHOR, artist and editor elves have been at it again  creating, cribbing and clicheing  to bring children books with themes that hinge on Christmas. Maybe there's something here to your liking  and mine  to help with the endless, impatient days ahead.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: In Support and Welfare: A Legal Maze [Opinion Page, Nov. 19], it was indicated that a woman who was divorced on the ground of living separately and apart under a written agreement is ineligible for alimony. That is not correct.

title: Phyllis Lugger Sets Nuptials
description: Mrs. Albert A. Lugger of St. Louis has announced the engagement of her daughter, Phyllis M. Lugger, to Haldan N. Cohn, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanton H. Cohn of Smithtown, L.I. The couple will be married Jan. 14 in St. Louis.

title: A SitIn Ends at Amherst College After Accord on Hispanic Center
description: AMHERST, Mass., Dec. 9  A sitin by 25 Hispanic students at Amherst College ended in its fourth day early today when the students accepted an offer from the college president that gave them a better location for their cultural center.

title: SHOP TALK
description: WHILE lining up in the earlymorning hours to await the opening of the annual ski and skate sale, many a parent has wondered if there was not some easier way to replace children's outgrown athletic equipment without going into debt.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: BLOOMFIELD  (Bloomfield College, Franklin and Fremont Streets)  A View From the Bridge, in an Actor's CafeTheater production. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. $3.50$5.50; students and the elderly, $2.5044.50. (201) 4297662.

title: Chamber Society Adds Series of 3 Vocal Programs
description: A series of three vocal chambermusic programs will be presented this season by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center in addition to its regular concerts at Alice Tully Hall.

title: MUSIC;Tonal DoubleHeader
description: I FOLLOWED my own advice last weekend, for a change, and dropped in on two of our major county orchestras, both of which are continuing to flourish with loyal and, it would seem, everlarger followings.

title: A World of Cooking Around the State
description: CONNECTICUT'S cooking schools are soon to begin another interesting round of classes. Chinese, French, bakin and foodprocessor techniques head the list. Some classes resume early in January, but March is the starting time for many other schools.

title: Vita's Mother
description: Lady Sackville was a most extraordinary woman. She led a most extraordinary life. But she is of no importance. Her history would never have been dug up without the present obsession with all things even faintly Bloomsbury. She was mother of Vita SackvilleWest, novelist poet, friend of Virginia Woolf and wife of Harold Nicolson (cf. Portrait of a Marriage). Vita actually wrote her story together with the story of her grandmother Pepita's in a wonderful book called Pepita. Mrs. Alsop has added to this cache of information Lady Sackville's very frank diary, her letters and The Book of Happy Reminiscences for My Old Age given to her by Vita's son, Nigel Nicolson. The result is a biography filled with more exclamation marks than any romantic novel. Yet Mrs. Alsop isn't altogether to blame. Lady Sackville's own favorite saying was Quel Roman est ma vie! It was no hyperbole.

title: INTERVIEW
description: WEST NEW YORK THERE would have been another referendum on the ballot on Election Day were it not for the efforts of Sydney Schlesinger, one of the principal opponents of retail sales on Sundays.

title: New Yonkers Police Boss Faces Tough Task
description: YONKERS HE'S a former cop who walked a beat in Nassau County for six years before making sergeant. He was graduated second in a class of 159 at Hofstra Law School but acknowledges that he went to college only because he thought it would make him a better policeman.

title: GARDENING;Signs of the Season
description: THERE are all sorts of ways to approach this business of weather predicting. There are earth signs, sky signs, nature signs and for a change of pace, calendar signs. The Old Farmer's Almanac has a calendar approach.

title: Joan Collins Merrick, Nurse, Fiance of C.R. Schneeweiss
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eldridge Gerry Merrick of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joan Collins Merrick, to Christopher R. Schneeweiss, son of Mrs. William J. Schneeweiss of Princeton and the late Mr. Schneeweiss.

title: Daniel Richard Brooks Jr. Will Wed Amy V. Stancs
description: Mr. and Mrs. Downey Stancs of Litchfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Virginia Stancs, to Daniel Richard Brooks Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Brooks of Denville, N.J. The couple plan to be married next May in the Duke University Chapel.

title: IN BRIEF
description: In just six years China has become the largest single supplier of cotton textiles to the United States. That kind of growth didn't escape the notice of domestic cotton growers, who cried foul, claiming that cheap imports hurt their business. To placate them, the Admitsistration has opened talks aimed with Peking aimed at curbing cotton exports. The talks will be carried out in liaison offices in Peking and Washington since the the two countries have no formal diplomatic relations.... A number of commercial enterprises involving China were announced last week: United States Steel said it was actively negotiating to build an plant to refine ironore pellets; Nippon Steel, the world's largest producer, said it would build a $2.3 billion steel plant near Shanghai; Bethlehem Steel signed an agreement to build a $100million ironore processing plant, and France and Peking signed a trade agreement worth $13.6 billion that will include the Chinese purchase of two nuclear reactors.

title: A Guide to Cooking Schools in the State
description: COOKING schools in New Jersey are as active as ever, with Chinese cuisine the overwhelming favorite. Few indeed are the schools that do not teach some aspect of Chinese cooking, from basic techniques to advanced and specialized subjects, such as banquets, noodle dishes and Chinese pastries.

title: Wild Turkeys Staging a Comeback
description: AVESTIGE of 19thcentury New Jersey wildlife  wild turkeys  has been restored to the northwest corner of the state, and the swift, graceful birds have adapted nicely to their new home.

title: Suffering From Suffolk Phobia
description: THE other night I had a bad dream, almost a nightmare. I was in Suffolk County and I was lost. I wanted to stop somebody and ask directions, but I was embarrassed at my inability to pronounce the town Hauppauge correctly.

title: Florence M. Thomas Bride of Louis P. Kelly
description: Florence Ann Mack Thomas and Louis Paul Kelly Jr. of New York were married yesterday afternoon in the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity by the Rev. F. Reid Isaac.

title: Women Guards Barred In Frisking Jailed Men
description: SALEM, Ore., Dec. 9 (AP) county judge has granted a permanent injunction prohibiting female guards from frisking male prisoners at Oreeon's two correctional institutions.

title: Court Bars Police Snooping
description: WASHINGTON AMAN'S home is his castle, but how about his garden? Or, more specifically, how about his marijuana garden?

title: Football Is Hardly Sugar Daddy
description: For what seems like forever, the National Collegiate Athletic Association has been arguing that the profitmaking ability of some athletic teams, primarily football, ought to be reason for exemption from Title IX, the Federal statute that bars sex bias in school programs. If equal percapita spending for male and female athletes is strictly applied, the argument goes, then the level of competition at the big time school will decline. This in turn will mean a reduction in spectator support and a drop in the earnings that help pay for not only the football team but also the rest of the college's athletic program. Such is the argument, which was made again last week on the Views of Sport page by Fred C. Davison, president of the University of Georgia. It's much ado about very little.

title: Egyptomania, 1850's Style
description: It's been a big year for Egypt: Sadat has made headlines, King Tut has drawn ticket lines, the Temple of Dendur has risen again (above Fifth Avenue) and moviegoers have fallen under the spell of Death on the Nile. This month, New Yorkers will have still more things Egyptian to admire. The gleaming treasures Tutankhamun will go on public view at the Metropolitan Museum on Dec. 20, along with a lighthearted display of Egypt's impact on everything from cemeteries to cigarette ads. And at the Prakapas Gallery, an impressive show of photographs taken in Egypt more than 100 years ago will open this week. These vintage pictures were a reflection of the Egyptomania that swept over Europe in waves after Napoleon's Egyptian campaign of 179899. Hard on the heels of his soldiers, artists arrived, eager to depict the monuments and exotic scenes of the land of the Pharaohs. By the 1840's daguerreotypists had moved in on the artists, and in 1849 Maxime Du Camp turned up with his camera and his friend the novelist Flaubert record the marvels of antiquity. Soon after Du Camp

title: Age Is No Barrier To Essex Swimmer
description: MONTCLAIR CLARENCE ROSS is 79 years old, but he looks far younger. Robust and athletic, he swims at least 2,000 yards five times week and holds 11 agegroup titles and at least the same number of records in current Amateur Athletic Union masters swimming competition.

title: Other World Events
description: Since the overthrow of Chile's President Salvador Allende Gossens in 1973, more than 600 Chileans, most of them Allende supporters, have simply vanished. Last week a clue to the fate of some of them seemed to have emerged as at least 25 bodies were found, buried deep in an abandoned mine near Santiago. Human rights advocates, led by a Roman Catholic bishop, reportedly were tipped off to the hidden tomb when a former secret service agent informed a priest during confession. The military Government of President Augusto Pinochet Ugarte promised to investigate.

title: Joan R. Eland Engaged to Scott W. Johnson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul Warren Ifland of Brussels have announced the engagement of Mr. Ifland's daughter, Joan Rewbridge Ifland, to Scott William Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Bedford Johnson of New York. The couple will be married Dec. 31 at the Old Parish Church in Weston, Vt.

title: In Toronto News Source Case, a Stalemate for Now
description: TORONTO, Dec. 9  The Globe and Mail of Toronto and an official commission investigating allegations of police abuses have reached at least a temporary stalemate in the commission's efforts to question one of the newspaper's reporters about sources for his articles.

title: U.S. Takes Doubles, Leads Britain by 21
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif., Dec. 9 There was no miracle in the desert today. Stan Smith and Bob Lutz, conducting business as usual, gave the United States a 21 lead over Britain in the Davis Cup tennis final with a 62, 62, 63 victory over Mark Cox and David Lloyd.

title: Army Private Crushed by Tanks
description: FORT CARSON, Colo., Dec. 9 (AP) A 19yearold private was crushed to death yesterday between two M60 tanks in a training accident at Fort Carson, Army officials said. The private was identified as John Wheelock of Hudsonville, Mich: The accident was being investigated.

title: Ecological Fears Postpone St. Lawrence WinterNavigation Project
description: ALBANY, Dec. 9  A controversial demonstration of the feasibility of winter navigation on the icebound St. Lawrence River has been put off for at least a year because of increasing concerns about possible danger to the environment, according to state and Federal officials.

title: Castro, Affirming Plan to Free Prisoners, Says U.S. Is Slow to React
description: HAVANA, Dec. 9  President Fidel Castro cleared the way today for a move that could lead to the most direct liberalization of Cuban society since the revolutionary Government took power in 1959.

title: Want to Start a Football Bowl Game? Guarantee Big Money
description: Fielding Yost's undefeated University of Michigan football team, known as the PointaMinute team, went to the first postseason bowl game on Jan. 1, 1902, and so humiliated the home favorite, ,Stanford, that it took the Rose Bowl folks 14 years to overcome the shock of Michi2an's 490 victory.

title: YALE BUYS INTEREST IN CORNING BUILDING
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 9 After a decade of disappointment in the stock market, Yale University has begun to shift a major portion of its resources into real estate.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Now that WNET/Channel 13 has opened its latest Dance in America series, the old discussion about dance and television can move forward into a new phase. These thoughts are prompted not only by the first Dance in America program this fall, Choreography by Balanchine, Part 3, but also by a Danish television film about Peter Martins, which had its first screening in New York during the same week under the auspices of the Danish Consulate General and Niels Matthiasen, the Danish Minister for Cultural Affairs. The WNET videotape and the Martins film are very different in approach and intent, but they do share Mr. Martins, currently a principal exponent of George Balanchine's choreography at the New York City Ballet. They even show the same pas de deux with Suzanne Farrell and Mr. Martins dancing in Mr. Balanchine's Chaconne.

title: Transit Agency Accused on Rent
description: The New York City Transit Authority ignored suggestions that it occupy, rentfree, vacant office space in a former Brooklyn College building and instead leased space in a building almost directly across the street at a cost of $13.8 million over 20 years, Borough President Andrew J. Stein of Manhattan has charged.

title: Alvin Ailey Dancers Offer Duet by Lar Lubovitch
description: It is dark. Suddenly a spotlight reveals a man and a woman in an embrace. He is wearing pajama bottoms and she is in a slip. That is how the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater opened a duet by Lar Lubovitch Friday night at the City Center. It ended exactly the way you think it did.

title: One Band Likes 10 to Play the Top 40
description: TOP40 bands ply their trade all over the Island, performing current hits and treasured. oldies for inveterate bar hoppers in search of the familiar. Most of these bands are small by economic necessity, usually consisting of no more than four or five members.

title: SPORTS
description: EAST RUTHERFORD IT IS 2,100 miles from Tempe, Ariz., to Giants Stadium, the last place one would expect to find team from the Valley of the Sun playing a football game in midDecember.

title: Harlem School Board Suspended Once More For Defying Directives
description: In a reprise of his action six months ago, School Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola yesterday indefinitely suspended members of School Board 5 in Central Harlem for what he said was their defiance, once again, of his directives.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: DANIEL P. GUIDO, who was replaced as Nassau County Police Commissioner after Francis T. Purcell was elected County Executive last year, says his life has come full circle now that he is the civilian Commissioner of Police in Yonkers. He assumed the job last Oct. 30.

title: PEOPLE
description: At a meeting of the Economic Club of Detroit last week, Transportation Secretary Brock Adams charged that the American auto industry has recently acquired a reputation for imitation, not innovation, and urged industry executives to join in an allout search for the engine of the future,  one not dependent on gasoline.

title: Retriever, Super Pet, Is Obedience Queen
description: America's obedience super dog is a golden retriever, O.T.Ch. Moreland's Golden Tonka. Owned and handled by Russell Klipple of Parker Ford, Pa., she gained her super dog title at the United States Dog Obedience Classic at the Convention Center in Minneapolis, Nov. 2526.

title: OftTold Tales
description: Hitler, once again. The market for biographical ephemera seems insatiable, but enough is enough. Not, to be sure, for careful work conveying fresh data or convincing interpretations of some episode previously unknown or misunderstood, some aspect of his policy or outlook that remains obscure say, his relations with big business, the reasons for declaring war on the United States, the opportunities apparently ignored in the Mediterranean in 1942.

title: School Plan Faces Legislative Hurdles
description: Lower figures show 197879 state aid per pupil. Upper figures are an estimate, based on the formula recommended by the School Finance Advisory Panel, of the effect of their plan when fully applied. Figures do not include aid for transportation or special education.

title: The World
description: Three months ago, when the Camp David talks seemed hopelessly bogged down in semantics, President Carter set a Sept. 17 deadline for the end of the discussions and got Anwar elSadat and Menachem Begin to agree on a framework for peace. Last week, he seemed to be trying the same tactic. Complaining about unwarranted delays and quibbling over language, he warned Egypt and Israel that if they did not sign a peace treaty by next Sunday  the goal agreed upon at Camp David they would be setting a precedent with farreaching, adverse effects.

title: Indonesian Editor at Home in Franklinville
description: LIKE the publishers and editors of many rural weekly newspapers throughout the United States, Johannes Girsang has no time to write fancy editorials. This is

title: JOHN UPDIKE BREAKS OUT OF SUBURBIA
description: For 20 years, the novelist has translated his life into a masterful chronicle of middleclass anxiety and infidelity. Now he has broadened his vision in a remarkable new book set in Africa.

title: Sweet 16 No More
description: Two years ago a novel called Diving for Roses was listed in these pages as one of the best children's books of the year. An accompanying annotation described the book, which was intended for Ages 14 and Up, as follows: A 17yearold girl, her disheveled. ravine mother, a forest lover, alcoholism and pregnancy are the ingredients in a fine, powerful and literate book. This recipe was too spicy for the editors of The New Yorker; they reprinted the item as newsbreak humor, followed by the stunned comment, Wait'll you hear what the grownups are reading these days!

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Ceding Eased on House Loan Rates
description: New York State's tough usury ceiling on mortgage loan rates is a thing of the past. In a special session, the Legislature voted to do away with the 8.5 percent ceiling, one of the lowest in the nation, and allow the rate to go to 9.5 percent, with further increases possible. Governor Carey signed the bill Friday.

title: Racers Gird for Boat Title.
description: Some call it the ultimate in motor competition. By any definition, though, offshore powerboat racing is a bonecrushing, musclepulling sport. And this week the crews of the top 21 boats from five continents are gathering in the Argentine coastal resort town of Mar del Plata to prepare for next Saturday's world title race.

title: Much Ado About Death Rays
description: Is the United States in danger of being zapped into submission by Soviet death rays? That alarming possibility is being raised again by some weaponswatchers who believe Russia holds a commanding lead in the development of directedenergy weapons. These include beams of atomic particles, similar to lightning, or of highenerav laser radiation. a form of light.

title: Moslem Revolt in Iran Stirs Fears for Future Of Minority Religions
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 9  The old man who looks after the Zoroastrian Temple on Stalin Avenue is very attentive to the fire. He watches over the big brass altar in this quiet little place, making sure there is always sandalwood to keep the eternal flame going. But nowadays, he says, hardly any worshipers come into the temple.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: ALTHOUGH rollers have made the painting of walls and ceilings easier, there are still tricks that can make roller painting easier and faster, and more likely to result in a smooth and uniform finish.

title: Rating Westchester In the Ivy League
description: HIGH SCHOOL seniors seeking entry into Ivy League colleges this winter may find themselves with a minor advantage or distinct disadvantage in the admissions process because they live in Westchester, depending on which admissions officers they choose to believe.

title: Museum's Motto
description: LINCROFT P LEASE Touch, say the guides at the new Junior Museum at the Monmouth Museum, and the youngsters do.

title: Blumenthal Sees Ceausescu in a Display of Support
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, Dec. 9 President Nicolae Ceausescu today assured President Carter's special envoy, Secretary of the Treasury W. Michael Blumenthal, that the Soviet Union had applied no perceptible pressure on Rumania since the start of the SovietRumanian confrontation two weeks ago.

title: The Essential Philip Rahv
description: PHILIP RAHV belonged to the company of radical intellectuals who stole Partisan Review from the Communist John Reed Club and in 1937 began it on a new basis as an independent journal of literature and politics. His literary essays were published in three earlier volumes; the present selection reprints the best known of these, adds a few later pieces (196972) and closes with a group of mostly uncollected political writings; this is not the Complete Rahv but it can serve for a while as the Essential Rahv. Yet the reader who wants to gain a vivid impression of Rahv's critical temperament could do worse than to let the essays wait, and spend a day un the library with back issues of Partisan Review. Rahv was a guiding spirit of the journal during the nearly three decades of its prime, and his truest criticism was implicit: We see it in what he chose to print or not to print. In his essays he exhibits the settled arrogance proper to an editor whom life, art and regular contributors all work hard to please.

title: Deaths
description: MEIR  Goida. The American Section of the World Zionist Organization Executive expresses its profound sorrow over the passing of Israel's Perennial Great Lady, who in her own life exemplified the finest traditions and values of the Zionist movement. Singleminded in her love for her people and in her devotion to the Jewish State, she combined an iron will with a basic sympathy and compassion; Idealism and vision with downtoearth pragmatism. She had the common touch and throughout her long careeras kibbutznick in Merhavia, Histadruf leader, Ambassador to Moscow, Member of the Knesset, Foreign Minister or Prime Minister, she was always Goida, not just to the Israeli people and to the Jews of the Diaspora, but to the worldatlarge. She displayed vision and acute political understanding as Acting Head of the Jewish Agency's Political Department In Jerusalem, which served her well during her turn as Israel's first Ambassador to Moscow and then as Foreign Minister. Both political prescience and personal courage combined with her devotion to the conceal of the Jewish State and her years of dedicated service to the Stateinthemaking earned her a place among the signers of itraet's Declaration of independence. Even after her retirement as Prime Minister, she continued her irwolvenent in Israel's political life and remained a force to be reckoned with. Together with her children, Menachem and Sarah, the grandchildren, and the entire Jewish world we mourn the passing of one of the great leaders of our generation. Her memory will be inscribed forever in the history and the heart of her people.

title: Where a Plainer Past Endures.
description: In the 18th century, New York was a small town of singlefamily homes, two and threestory business buildings, and open space clustered around the Battery and Wall Street. When New Yorker died, they were buried in their churchyards or nearby cemeteries.

title: Creative Spirit of a Collector
description: BROOKVILLE IN these days of specialization, even in the arts, a painter usually remains a painter and a photographer remains a photographer. If an artist changes his medium, he is not considered serious.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: In the opinion of four of the Justices of the United States Supreme Court, the other five last week gave the Fourth Amendment a beating. The amendment guarantees citizens against unreasonable searches and seizures, and one means of enforcing has been the courtmade exclusionary rule, under which evidence seized in violation of someone's Fourth Amendment rights cannot be used against him in a criminal case.

title: SHOP TALK
description: THE Smith Haven Mall has its fans and its detractors. Shoppers by the droves jam into its vast enclosed plaza, headed for Macy's, Sears or Abraham & Straus, while others are lured by the smaller specialty shops that line the mall.

title: WESTCHESTER HOUSING
description: WESTCHESTER has fewer children and more elderly persons and small families than it used to, a situation that has led several school districts to a new idea: Turn some of the schools into apartments.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: MUCH has been written about suburban living, and as a New Jersey suburbanite for 26 years I think I have experienced quite a bit of it.

title: Health
description: Do parents have the right to refuse medical treatment for their children? This provocative question is being raised by a case now wending its way through the courts in Massachusetts. On one side are Gerald and Diana Green, a young couple of Scituate, whose 2yearold son. Chad. has leukemia. The Greens do not want Chad to suffer the side effects of chemotherapy, and they say that they will take the case all the way to the Supreme Court of the United States. On the other side is a bastion of the medical establishment, Boston's prestigious Massachusetts General Hospital, a Harvard affiliate, which began the court action in order to force continuation of Chad's chemotherapy.

title: Buttons: $80 and Up
description: There's a woman in New York who has gold evening bag, gold as in the real McCoy. The bag is lined in suede and on that lining, spelled out in twinkling diamonds, is the woman's name. That's understatement.

title: Ready for Vietnam? A Talk With Michael Cimino
description: It was a Saturday night in New York. Francis Coppola, the director of the Godfather films and head of the newboy network that has moved into power in Hollywood, came to the hotel suite of Michael Cimino, a loner with only one released work (a 1974 caper film titled Thunderbolt and Lightfoot) to his credit.

title: ANTIQUES
description: HARTFORD ON the afternoon of Dec. 12, 1878, Mary Lydia Sheldon completed her Christmas shopping at an Asylum Street notions store, ordering the parcels delivered to 396 Main Street, where she lived with her sister and brotherinlaw, the Rev. and Mrs. John James McCook. As usual she had promised the McCooks she would not spoil their children with expensive Christmas presents. Old family diaries disclose, however, that compared with the amount budgeted for children's toys by most of her contemporaries, even indulgeit aunts, Miss Sheldon had as usual averspent.

title: On Isolated Plum Island,
description: PLUM ISLAND THE hundreds of animals that come onto this island every year never leave it. They are, in the jargon employed here, necropsied.

title: Assailed by New York's Leaders, Kibbee Impresses His Evaluators
description: A recent evaluation of Dr. Robert J. Kibbee, the chancellor of the City University of New York, by a panel of educators has given him credit for high academic standards and persistence in fighting for the university's welfare.

title: ANTIQUES
description: PAINTS and stains were widely, used by early Long Igland craftsmen to protect and decorate furniture and other household items. An understanding of how and why the surfaces of objects were treated is not only historically interesting, but also essential to appreciating both the original appearance of the piece of furniture and the intent of the maker.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: ALTHOUGH rollers have made the painting of walls and ceilings easier, there are still tricks that can make roller painting easier and faster, and more likely to result in a smooth and uniform finish.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: AMAGANSETT  East End Winter, works by local artists; 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Thursdays through Saturdays; 11 A.M. to 3 P.M. Sundays; through Jan. 20; Gallery East Hampton, Main St. Reception today 2 to 5 P.M.

title: The Region
description: When Governor Carey signed the new bill increasing the interest rates on home mortgages from 8 to 9 percent (the national average is 9.86 percent) last week, he was also striking a blow against redlining, or geographic discrimination in mortgage lending. But he was doing it when the definition of redlining itself was coming under increasing examination.

title: Playing Against the House (New Jersey)
description: I WOULD prefer an appeal to my finer instincts. Selfishness, avarice and greed are flaws, if not sins, that I own up to in weaker moments and repress in stronger ones.

title: A Prayer of Hope For Birds of Prey
description: The New Jersey Raptor Association is a private nonprofit organization dedicated to the wellbeing of birds of prey.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Pay Issue Dominates Police Board Race
description: PORT WASHINGTON VOTERS in this old North Shore residential community of lawyers., bankers, commuters, store owners and clam diggers are scheduled to choose a police commissioner this Tuesday from among three candidates: two investment analysts and a man who drives a taxi by night and a truck by day.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: Indiana, U.S.F. Gain Soccer Final
description: TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 9  Indiana University and the University of San Francisco, ranked No. 1 and No. 2, respectively, at the end of the regular season, will meet tomorrow afternoon for the National Collegiate soccer championship after winning their semifinal games today.

title: Bugling the Red, White and blue
description: WHAT is Daniel Patrick Moynihan? There are many answers in this important and provocative book: selfseeking exhibitionist, the fastest intellectual gun in the East, imaginative scholar adept at unconventional interpretations and prophet alternately bewailing our nation's loss of face and prodding us to reaffirmation  the bugler in chief of a red, white and blue ideological offensive.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: LOS ANGELESThese boat people recall others.

title: Webster's Disciplinary Action on BreakIns Cited as Argument for Clear Rules
description: WASHINGTON  When William H. Webster announced last week that he had decided not to discipline most of the Federal Bureau of Investigation agents involved in illegal breakins, mail openings and wiretaps in the New York area in the early 1970's, he added that if he had been weighing the matter as a judge, rather than as the bureau's director, he probably would have done the same thing. Citing what he called the climate of the times, the former Federal judge from St. Louis asserted that to punish agents who had acted in good faith would be both counterproductive and unfair.

title: ANTIQUES
description: MENHAM

title: DISPUTE WITH BONES SAID TO BE ON TAPE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9  In the last minutes before they died in Guyana, some of the followers of the Rev. Jim Jones tried to persuade him to keep promise to move their People's Temple commune to the Soviet Union rather than to end it in mass death by poison, according to a source familiar with a tape recording made at the time.

title: STAMPS
description: Gifts to help get someone started in philately, or for those already involved in collecting  without spending a fortune  are a timely consideration now with only 14 days left before Christmas.

title: Bloom and Friends
description: HUGH KENNER'S original and entertaining study of, chiefly, Ulysses fulfills in an exemplary manner the Quantum desideratum: a richness of detail and insight within about one hundred pages of print. Short enough to be read in an evening and significant enough to be a book. It is a reworking of lectures given at the University of Kent in Canterbury to honor the name of the other Saint Thomas. As I myself am due to deliver the Eliot lectures there in 1980, despair at being able to emulate Professor Kenner's erudite elegance clouds my admiration. Professor Kenner's own admiration for Eliot had, inauspiciously for the occasion, to be clouded by his need to reject a famous pronouncement by Eliot about the mythological method in Ulysses. The mythic element in that book, Professor Kenner says, rightly I believe, is not important. Imaginative writers deal in the particularities of putting sentences together, not with deliberately evoking vague and ancient and irrelevant entities. Ulysses is called what it is, but what if, like one of Stephen Dedalus's greenly green unwritten epiphanies, it had been called P? Would anyone have suspected that Homer was tapping his way along Grafton Street.

title: ANTIQUES
description: It is anything but a coincidence that during the weeks and months ahead when the Treasures of Tutankhamen is on view at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New Yorkers will have more opportunities than in many years to acquire what art dealers and auctioneers describe as everything from Egyptian temple treasures to tomb debris. Indeed, the opening next week of the longawaited exhibition has pushed the intensity of Tutmania among certain merchants and collectors to fever pitch. It may also raise a score of questions in the minds of serious if inexperienced collectors about how to judge the authenticity and quality of antiquities.

title: Deaths
description: MEIRGolda. The officers and staff of the National United Jewish Appeal express their profound sorrow at the death of GoIda Meir, whose towering strength was a deep and constant source of inspiration in the lifeline partnership between the American Jewish community and the people of Israel. Her warmth, wisdom, and passion for justice moved us to ever new heights of understanding and commitment in sustaining that lifeline. Her simple, eloquent truth cut through to the core of every issue and fortified our resolve and determination. Her life of ceaseless sacrifice taught us the meaning of true giving. A founder of the restored Jewish mitten, a kindier of the renewed light of Jewish life, a fighter for peace with justice for the people of Israel and for the mothers and children of all the nations of the Middle East, she was larger than life and her legacy to all Jews everywhere is larger than the death that has overtaken her. Those of us who have shared the embracing presence of GoIda Meir, experienced her love. friendship and concern and grasped the firm, guiding hand she reached out to us have had the rarest of privileges. She wasand in our hearts will always remainthe First Lady ofthe Jewish people.

title: The World
description: MOSCOW  Four hundred capitalistic American businessmen meeting in Moscow and Soviet Communist Party Chairman Leonid I. Brezhnev had one thing in common last week  they agreed that the United States Congress is now the biggest obstacle to broader AmericanSoviet trade. They want Congress to repeal the 1974 law denying favorable tariff rates and longterm credits to the Russians unless more Soviet Jews are allowed to emigrate. That seems unlikely, but last week two high officials of the Carter Administration told them that the President is in favor of increased trade anti nrnmised to untie some of the red tape holding it up.

title: Quakers Give Inmates Chance to Reflect
description: IN MAY 1977, word went out to various Friends (Quaker) meetings in Westchester and Fairfield Counties asking that concerned Friends consider adding their names to a list of Friends, to be approved by the Taconic Correctional Facility in Bedford Hills, to be included in the weekly Sunday worship service at the jail. After mulling it over, I gave my name to Louisa Baur from Croton Valley, one of the Friends most instrumental in helping make these worship services and our sharing possible and successful. Earlier, several prisoners who had participated in a Quaker Alternatives to Violence program, made a request to have a Friends service in the Taconic facility. Miss Baur undertook to carry through the formalities to start services.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The date of the funeral for Harry Winston, the jeweler, was reported incorrectly in yesterday's Times. A private service will be held today at 11:30 A.M.

title: SPORTS
description: THERE'S no big deal about 13th birthdays. Unless you're Jackie Cassello, who will celebrate hers eight days from now. After that, the petite gymnast from Rockville Centre will get her shot at being a worldbeater.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: When she was 15, Barbara Wertheim was ill for three months and had to remain at home. Her French governess, Mlle. Thouvenel, read Racine and Corneille aloud to her between drills in the conjugation of verbs. Thanks in part to those longago lessons, hundreds of thousands of Americans today are reading Barbara W. Tuchman's latest adventure in history, A Distant Mirror: The Calamitous 19th Century, a book requiring intensive research In French documents.

title: He Wants to Build a Soviet Plane in Ohio
description: WASHINGTON  Early next year, 1,200 unemployed steel workers in troubled Youngstown, Ohio, will be given a fresh opportunity and new careers in a venture made possible by means of Soviet technology, Federal funds, the deregulation of the American airline industry  and one man's dream.

title: Pacific10 Selects White Football PlayerofYear
description: SAN FRANCISCO (AP)  Charles White, Southern Californias tailback and the conferences leading career rusher, has been named football playeroftheyear in the Pacific10 Conference.

title: Elliott Carter: Out of the Desert And Into the Concert Hall
description: If someone ever decides to writp an opera on the great creative event in the life of an American composer in the manner of Hans Pfitzner's Palestrina, the incident he will choose will surely be Elliott Carter's flight into the desert in 1950. Then, Mr. Carter was the aging enfant terrible of New York, long (too long) the most promising of his generation. Now  tomorrow, in fact, with great birthday fanfares  Elliott Carter is an authority figure 70 years old, worldwide probably, one of the more performed and analyzed practitioners of his arcane profession.

title: Stanford University Raises Fees
description: STANFORD, Calif., Dec. 9 (UPI)Stanford University has approved increases in tuition and in fees for room and, board, effective next fall. General tuition is to rise6.1 percent, from $5,130 to $5,595 a year. Tuition at the medical school, however, will rise 27.6 percent, from $5,399 to $6,873. Fees for room and board on campus will increase 8.5 percent, from $2.169 to $2,354.

title: Births
description: TYTEL

title: ART
description: HEMPSTEAD MOST people old enough to remember the Depression retain few positive impressions of the period. Talk to an artist, however, and the story is very different. For painters and sculptors, the 1930's were a period of unprecedented opportunity for professional advancement, brought about by the establishment of Federal artpatronage programs as part of New Deal economic pumppriming.

title: ART
description: NEW BRUNSWICK ONE of the major faults of much contemporary art is that it is so painfully boring. Some obsessed artists tend to repeat themselves ad nauseum, while others, who are not overly innovative, merely simulate the work of others.

title: Collision on Bridge Kills Man
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 (UPI) Robert Deitch, 30 years old, of Sicklervine, N. J. was killed yesterday in a headon car collision on the Walt Whitman Bridge over the Delaware River. Theodore Packer, 34, of Bellmawr, N.J., was listed in serious condition at Methodist Hospital.

title: Judith Lynn Fox, Bernard C. Javelly To Be Wed in June
description: The engagement of Judith Lynn Fox to Bernard Christian Javelly has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Jay Fox of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I., parents of the future bride. Mr. Javelly is the son of Mrs. Pierre Javelly of Mexico City and the late Mr. Javelly.

title: WRITERS IN BRITAIN SEEK UNION STATUS
description: Britain's major authors are closely watching the trade union dispute at the shutdown Times of London because reviews of their books will not appear in the powerful Times Literary Supplement and, even more a subject of internal debate, because they recently applied for union status for themselves.

title: Englishmen in India
description: GRANTED it is unfashionable to think of history as offering a moral lesson to the present, it is almost impossible to read Christopher Hibbert's account of the Indian mutiny of 1857  when native troops in the British Army in India rose up against their British leaders  and not come to such conclusion. Mr. Hibbert himself, I hasten to point out, scrupulously refrains from drawing lessons or parallels, or even from analyzing or venturing a judgment on the wealth of materials he has so vividly set before us. He writes as the dispassionate observer, the reporter or recorder rather than the interpreter events, and if that is not necessarily the Ideal way writing history, it may result, as here, in a work with its own rewards and virtues.

title: Apostrophes to a Dead Lover
description: THE impressionistic novel is getting a new lease on life from Edmund White, whose dreamy Forgetting Elena had a success of esteem some years back, and who in his second novel has abandoned such concessions to the reader as linear storytelling.

title: Senator Haskell, Nina Totenberg To Marry Feb. 3
description: Senator Floyd K. Haskell, Democrat of Colorado, will marry Nina Totenberg on Feb. 3 in Washington.

title: NATURE WATCH
description: EVENING GROSBEAK

title: Colleen Kelly, Robert Lack Will Be Wed
