description: Mr. and Mrs. James Kelly of Snyder, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Colleen Phyllis Kelly, to Robert Joel Lack, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter A. Lack of Upper Montclair. N.J.

title: Deaths
description: DOUGHERTYRev. Msgr. Daniel M. on December 7, 1978 at Stowe, Vermont. Pastor Emeritus St. Patrick's Church, Verplanck, N.Y. Devoted brother of Rev. Msgr. John C. Dougherty and Sister Mary Daniel. Reposing at St. Patrick's School Hall, Verplanck, from 2PM until 5PM &, 7PM until 10PM Saturday and 2PM until 5PM Sunday. Mass of the Holy Eucharist at St. Patrick's Church on Sunday, December, 10 at 8PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Patrick's Church on Monday, December 11 at 10AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: CONTRACT SCANDAL SLOWS OHIO LOTTERY
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 9  Federal, state and county officials are investigating a web of Ohio lottery contracts as a result of a scandal that has depressed ticket sales and raised questions about the role of Robert E. Hughes, Cuyahoga County Republican Party Chairman.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS Continued Conservation
description: WASHINGTON  Warnings that vast sections of agricultural land in Africa and Asia are disappearing into the deserts, while the fertility of a fifth of the earth's cropland declines, are by now so familiar they no longer startle. But it was something else again to hear Bob Bergland, the Secretary of Agriculture, proclaim recently that soil erosion in the United States was at a record high, and that water supplies were being reduced at a reckless pace.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 10 A.M (Channel 9) The Prime Of Your Life: Representative S. William Green of Manhattan.

title: Dana Murphy Wed To Richard Wiehl
description: Dana Durrell Murphy, daughter of Edwin Serre Murphy Jr. of Fairfield, Conn., and the late Jane Evans Murphy, was married in Fairfield yesterday afternoon to Richard Vance Wiehl, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest A. Wiehl Jr., also of Fairfield. The Rev. Robert Bast performed the ceremony in St. Timothy's Episcopal Church in Greenfield Hill.

title: Vermont Bar Owners Seek a Narrower Law on Intoxication Liability
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Dec. 9  Faced with rising insurance rates, restaurant and bar owners in Vermont are drafting legislation to replace the state's law assessesing liability for harm caused by intoxicated persons.

title: The Thickets of Academe
description: WHEN I need intellectual stimulation on a weekday afternoon, I wheel out my gearless bicycle and make my way with unamplified torque to my son's school. My experiences there comprise a curriculum of such depth and variety that I owe it to the community to set them down. Here, then, is a record of my most recent visit, which began with an inquiry into the ontology of boots and shoes.

title: Angelo State 353 Victor
description: SAN ANGELO, Tex., Dec. 9 (Ap) Arthur Gutierrez ran for 111 yards and Wylie Turner intercepted three passes in leading Angelo State to a 353 triumph over Western State of Colorado today in a National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics Division I semifinal game. The victory puts Angelo State in the final next Saturday in McAllen, Tex., against Elon College of North Carolina.

title: A Vote by A.M.A. Policymakers Permits Chiropractors' Referrals
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 9 (UPI)  The American Medical Association's policymaking body has confirmed a decision allowing physicians to accept patients referred to them by chiropractors. Nevertheless, it is still warning that chiropractic medicine is a hazardous healing system.

title: Undefeated Streak Extended to 15
description: TORONTO, Dec. 9  The New York Islanders, who lost a 107 shooting battle in Maple Leaf Gardens earlier in the season, atoned for that setback by beating the Toronto Maple Leafs, 32, tonight before the usual sellout crowd of 16,485.

title: Rights Bill Pushed For Crime Victims
description: TREN I ON ABILL designed to protect the rights of crime victims from violations  not by criminals, but by policemen, prosecutors and the entire judicial system  has been introduced in the State Assembly. A similar measure will be sponsored in the Senate.

title: Farmers Irrigating to Avoid Risks
description: URBANA, Ill., Dec. 9 (UPI)  An increasing number of farmers are turning to irrigation to minimize the risks inherent in farming. A University of Illinois study has found that the number of irrigated acres in that state doubled in the last five years and tripled in the last 10.

title: Searching for Educational Equity
description: A CAREFULLY crafted plan that will be the basis for significant changes in the way Connecticut pays for and provides the education of, its 600,000 school children faces the first of many tests starting Tuesday night.

title: Quebec Separatists Leaning to Strong Federal Ties
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 9  Quebec's leaders appeared to be contemplating a strong degree of economic, diplomatic and defense integration with the rest of Canada in the event that they achieve their goal. of Political sovereignty.

title: Subterfuge, Debate and Plain Politics Are Part of the Process
description: WASHINGTON  Congress has been away since October, but last week the Capitol was filled with the most intense kind of lobbying, as the Office of Management and Budget heard appeals on the budget requests the President will send to Congress for the fiscal year starting Oct. 1. 1979

title: Vocal Arts Ensemble Focuses On Largely Ignored Repertory
description: The New York Vocal Arts Ensemble is a quartet of singers led by its pianist, Raymond Beegle, that explores a largely ignored repertory  music for solo singer or, more commonly, vocal auartet or other small vocal group. The heyday of such music was in the 19th century, when  like the now equally moribund pianoduet repertory  it served the needs of the home before the advent of the record player and the rise of what is now called popular music.

title: Letter
description: JEAN SCHLADERMUNDT

title: SMALLTOWN AMERICA: A PORTRAIT
description: From the overpass, it looks as though Brownsville, Tenn., hasn't changed much in four decades: the same towering oaks and familiar streets; shuttered mansions and stark white clapboards behind deep foliage; the town square on the hill with its squat courthouse looking toward Nashville on the east and Memphis on the west; the Confederate soldier high on his pedestal still at parade rest after a hundred years; Roy's Drug Store where teenage boys used to hang out on the sidewalk.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: After a grand jury in Brooklyn had accused the New York State Assembly Speaker, Stanley Steingut, and his son, Robert, of an election crime, the Brooklyn District Attorney was unable to prosecute. The courts ruled that since the alleged crime had occurred in Manhattan, the District Attorney there had jurisdiction.

title: Present Tense
description: President Carter did no favors for the Shah of Iran last week. At a moment when the Iranian ruler's staying power was facing fresh risks  just as the emotioncharged holy month of Moharram was nearing its climactic peak  Mr. Carter told reporters at breakfast that, frankly, he didn't know if the Shah would survive. The President then proceeded succinctly to review the monarch's human rights record (There have been abuses... the trend has been toward. . .democratic principles), and he reversed the Pentagon by granting: free trips out of Iran for American military dependents.

title: Cinemas Start Sale Of Doodads
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9  When Superman engulfs America's movie theaters next weekend, Tshirts, posters, pins and kryptonite rocks that glow in the dark will be on sale in 475 of the theaters playing the film.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: Photographs differ from paintings, or so we're often told, because they need captions to explain them. But is this really true?

title: HOME CLINIC
description: ALTHOUGH rollers have made the painting of walls and ceilings easier, there are still tricks that can make roller painting easier and faster, and more likely to result in a smooth and uniform finish.

title: 2 Officers and 911 Operator, Suspended in Nurse Killing, Quietly Go Back on Payroll
description: Two police officers and a civilian 911 operator have been quietly restored to the payroll after being suspended last month by Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire for allegedly failing to take proper action in connection with the slaying of Bonnie Anne Bush.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE SHADOW OF THE WINTER PALACE, by Edward Crankshaw. (Penguin, $3.95.) During the century preceding the outbreak of World War I, the Russian state ruthlessly pursued imperialist expansionism abroad and repression at home. This account by a superbly literate British historian who can squeeze out of the driest documents an understanding of the human dimension suggests parallels to the present.

title: Eileen Brodsky Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Milton Brodsky of Easton, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eileen Judith Brodsky, to Gerald S. Levitt, son of Mildred Levitt of Sherman Oaks, Calif., and the late Henry C. Levitt. The wedding is planned for May 26, The bride, a graduate of C.W. Post College, attended Drexel University. Her fiance is an alumnus of the Universities of Nevada and Southern California.

title: Embarrassing Moment for Senator Russo
description: STATE SENATOR JOHN F. RUSSO of Toms River, one of the most influential Democrats in the Legislature and a potential candidate for his party's nomination for Governor in 1981, has become embroiled in a local political. controversy that could damage his political career.

title: DINING OUT
description: WHEN Jacques Allembert created Le Chateau with his partner, Gerard Seybold, two years ago, he chose Tenafly because he loved New Jersey and hated New York. But he brought New York expertise with him, since his father owned and operated Le Bistro at Third Avenue and 50th Street.

title: Sona van Voorhees And W.W. Reese, Banker, Are Wed
description: The marriage of Sona Lawrence van Voorhees to William Willis Reese took place yesterday in the chapel at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (the Little Church Around the Corner). The Rev. Norman Catir performed the ceremony, which was followed by a reception at Doubles.

title: The Giant And the Runt
description: SID AND SOL is a wonder  a picture book that heralds a hopeful, healthy flicker of life in what is becoming a creatively exhausted genre. The magic rests in the seamless bond of Arthur Yorinks's and Richard Egielski's deft and exciting collaboration.

title: Other National Events
description: George S. Brown rose to the nation's highest military post, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, in part by virtue of his combat record (he was executive officer of the air group that executed the famous 1993 lowlevel bombing raid against the Ploesti oil refineries of Rumania). But General Brown, who died last week of cancer at the age of 60, will also be remembered for his offthecuff remarks suggesting that Jews have undue influence in America because they own the banks and the newspapers, and calling Israel a burden and Congress meddlesome and irresponsible.

title: Forging Backwards in Essex
description: WHILE some Connecticut companies, like Xerox and United Technologies Corporation, make millions by extending the scientific frontier, others prosper by resisting progress. One such business is Essex Forge Inc. As its catalogue and sign boldly say, it manufactures handwrought iron and tin.

title: Plans Under Way For New U.S. Court
description: WHITE PLAINS IT TOOK just three little words to win a battle fought for years by lawyers and officials in Westchester and other counties north of the Bronx line to get in this city a branch of the Federal Court for the Southern District of New York. But it will be months before it is actually functioning.

title: Susan Ellen Rousso Wed To Edward Tawil on L.I.
description: The marriage of Susan Ellen Rousso, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eli L. Rousso of Hewlett, L.I., to Edward Tawil, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Tawil of Brooklyn, took place yesterday in the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I. Rabbi Arnold B. Marans officiated.

title: 2 Iranian Groups Assail the Shah In Protest Near the White House
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10  Two Iranian groups held orderly demonstrations today against Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi in Lafayette Park across from the White House.

title: Islanders' Streak Ends
description: MONTREAT, Dec. 10  Shed no tears for the Montreal Canadiens. Despite a slow start this season, a few injuries and only the third best wonlost record in the National Hockey League, the Canadiens beat the New York Islanders tonight in the Forum, 43.

title: U.S. Sees Steel Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)  A strong year for the American steel industry is expected in 1979 with imports probably declining 20 percent because of higher prices, the Commerce Department said today in its annual forecast on steel.

title: Democrats Prod Congress to Act On Health Insurance Legislation
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 10  The Democrats midterm conference called on Congress today to put into effect the party's longstanding support of national health insurance by enacting legislation within the next two years.

title: 20 Caught in a Swiss Avalanche
description: BERN, Dec. 10 (Reuters)  Twenty skiers narrowly escaped injury or death today when an avalanche swept them away near St eghorn Mountain, according to the police. Most of the skiers were able to pull themselves clear, but one woman was trapped for two hours. She was nished to a hospital in serious condition.

title: Michele Wertheimer Is a Bride
description: Michele Lynn Wertheimer and Neil Allen Fredman, New York lawyers, were married yesterday at the Engineers Country Club in Roslyn, L.I. Rabbi Arnold S. Turetsky of Temple Israel in White Plains performed the ceremony.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Catholics Get Guideline on Jewish Ties
description: With a rabbi introducing him and a cantor singing several hymns, Bishop Francis J. Mugavero of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn yesterday issued new guidelines for Catholics to observe in their relations with Jews. The guidelines discourage proselytizing and encourage the study of Jewish history and traditions.

title: Two Restaurateur Families Serve Up a Wedding Cake
description: Mes amis, the judge began, looking solemn, if a bit impish, in his long black robes, nous sommes id pour celebrer une tr(s important ... . He paused.

title: Stage: British Gimme Shelter
description: IT is extraordinary. No sooner did Britain acquire a postwar society, some 30 years ago, than John Osborne and Kingsley Amis and the other Angry Young Men arrived and began hacking away at its stultification and weariness.

title: Conference Board Sees Slowdown
description: No matter that business indicators continue to suggest an economy still very much in high gear, there will be continued inflation and a slowdown next year.

title: Study Sees Cheating on Oil Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10  A Congressional staff memorandum released today asserted that major oil companies had overcharged American consumers nearly $2 billion during the last four years and that some officials in the Department of Energy had condoned the practice.

title: Pell Will Not Coach Clemson in Bowl
description: CLEMSON, S.C., Dec. 10 (UPI) Charley Pell, the Clemson football coach who was named to a similar job at Florida a week ago, withdrew his plans tonight to coach the Tigers against Ohio State in the upcoming Gator Bowl at Jacksonville, Fla., on Dec. 29.

title: Style--
description: Style

title: Chess:
description: The ninth annual North American open computer chess championship in Washington was wort by Belle, a program by Ken Thompson and Joe Condon of the Bell Telephone Laboratories. Belle, running on a DEC PDP 11. scored 40 in the fourround Swiss system tournament sponsored by the Association for Computing Machinery and held at the Sheraton Park Hotel.

title: Coffee n Cake Part of the Cost To Elect Carey
description: With $3.2 million spent on radio and television advertising, Governor Carey's campaign for reelection was a model of the modern media campaign, in which once standard field operations, storefronts and large campaign staffs are deemphasized. But there was still a generous share of oldfashioned politics in the total of $5,086,508 that the Governor spent for all re election efforts  particularly the large sums for vaguely identified Election Day expenses, as the official campaign financial report described it, or walking around money or coffee and cake money, as politicians more colorfully describe it.

title: Outdoors: A Study of Hunters and Antihunters
description: THERE are many, particularly in the urban centers, who feel that America has reached the stage at which hunting is no longer a valid pursuit of reasonable men. The brief annual parade of dead deer on automobiles, for example, is a distasteful sight to the antihunter, who argues that the pursuit of game is an anachronistic and morally wrong ritual in an age when open spaces are shrinking and when the need for food gathered by hunting is rarely a matter of survival.

title: Welcoming Youngsters to Fifth Avenue Mall
description: Polly Molloy, made up as a clown, near St. Patrick's Cathedral .yesterday. The avenue was closed to autos from 57th Street to 39th Street. An estimated 50,000 took advantage of the sunshine to stroll on the temporary mall. Some stores reported that ski caps were selling well in the freezing air, and parents, of course, had to try explaining to their children about the presence of all those Santa Clauses. Yesterday was the ninth Holiday Festival.

title: Recital: Marilyn Horne Makes Fisher Hall Debut
description: MARILYN HORNE gave her first recital at Avery Fisher Hall yesterday afternoon. The auditorium and the stage were filled with her admirers, and they cheered her more florid displays with devotional enthusiasm.

title: Price Day, Baltimore Sun Editor And a War Correspondent, Dies
description: Price Day, editorinchief of The Sun and Evening Sun newspapers in Baltimore for 15 years, died Saturday at Union Memorial Hospital in Baltimore after a brief illness. He was 71 years old.

title: Barbara Bascom Bride Of Russell W. Crocker
description: Barbara Anne Bascom, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Bascom of Woodbury, L. I., was married at noon yesterday to Russell Warren Crocker of New York and Lausanne, Switzerland. He is a son of Richard Crocker of Branford, Conn., and Arlene Crocker of St. Petersburg, Fla. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony at the Crest Hollow Country Club of Woodbury.

title: Cult's Surviving Leaders Look to Uncertain Future
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10  They have few possessions and no money. Most of their friends and some relatives died with the Rev. Jim Jones at Jonestown, Guyana, on Nov. 18. They are left with the problems of sweeping up the debris, of comforting one another other, of seeing it through.

title: Singer on Yiddish, Ghosts and Stories for Children
description: STOCKHOLM, Dec. 10 (AP)  Following is the text of the address by Isaac Bashevigl Singer, winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature, at the banquet in City Hall tonight following the award ceremony.

title: Amnesty in Nicaragua Expected to Speed Negotiations
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 10  The expected release of hundreds of political prisoners here this week could pave the way for direct negotiations between the Government and opposition on a United Statessponsored; plebiscite to determine whether Nicaragua's besieged dictator, Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle, should remain President.

title: Stern Symbol of Opposition to the Shah
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 10  Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini leads no political party, commands no army, has no foreign allies and has been exiled from his country for 15 years, currently living more than 3,000 miles away on the outskirts of Paris.

title: Kansas Coach Says Officials Cause Loss
description: Nobody ever said Ted Owens of Kansas and Digger Phelps of Notre Dame were easy basketball coaches to please. Both are outspoken, critical and highly emotional and drive their teams hard to success.

title: World News Briefs
description: PEKING, Dec 10 (Reuters)  A new poster urging President Carter to support human rights in China appeared here today but was quickly torn down by a man who said its author was a Soviet agent provocateur, witnesses said.

title: A Town in Austria Plays Substitute Host
description: SCHLADMING, AUSTRIA THE French ski village of Val d'Isere had everything arranged for the traditional opening of the World Cup skiing season there: a schedule of training and race times drawn up weeks in advance; a clutch of apres ski cocktail parties; a listing, checked and doublechecked, of where each skier, official and reporter was staying. All that Val d'Isere didn't have was snow.

title: Ship Runs Aground Off Florida
description: MIAMI, Dec. 10 (AP)  The 500foot drybulk carrier Karmalu ran aground today three miles off Key Largo, the Coast Guard reported. The Karmalu, a doublehulled British vessel, was carrying 80 tons of fuel but no cargo on a run from Spain to Texas, and was in no danger of leaking, the Coast Guard said.

title: The City
description: Most of New York City's financing problems have now been solved, but the municipal bugetary difficulties loom as large as ever, the outgoing chairman of the city's Municipal Assistance Corporation said.

title: Networks Seem to Be Reversing 20 Years of TV Sex and Violence
description: The 22 new television programs that make up the most extensive midseason renovation ever by ABC, CBS and NBC are notably devoid of hardaction formats that are dependent on murder and brutality and of formulas that dictate sexual innuendo and revealing dress.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Antelia, Italy's airline, has appointed Antonio Fileccia, former? general sales manager for the United States, Mexico and Central America, as director of the North American division.

title: $30,000 Is Top Salary For Beginning Lawyers
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) few New York law firms have broken the $30,000 barrier in starting salaries for law school graduates, according to a survey published in Student Lawyer magazine.

title: Patriots Clinch Division Title, 2624
description: It has been a long time between divisional championships for the New England Patriots  15 years, in fact, and a different league. But yesterday the Patriots clinched the American Conference's Eastern Division title with a 2624 triumph in the last seconds over the Buffalo Bills and guaranteed themselves a berth in the National Football League divisional playoffs on Dec. 30 and 31.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Is the day coming when your broker will recommend American Telephone, General Motors  and $10,000 of term insurance? Harry Jacobs, the new chairman and chief executive officer of Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc., is not about to go that far, but he is certainly going into the business of selling insurance.

title: Study Says Military Force guys Negotiation Time
description: United States armed forces were deployed in support of political objectives 215 times between 1946 and 1975, and national policy goals usually were achieved in the first six months after the use of force, according to a new analysis published in Washington.

title: The Message Of Memphis
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 10 If hard evidence was needed, ,the Memphis midterm confereiice demonstrated the obstacles President Carter faces in trying to lead the Democratic Party to the right to fight inflation and to slow the growth of Federal spending on social programs.

title: F.T.C. Asks Merger Data
description: The JohnsManville Corporation and Olinkraft Inc. announced that the Federal Trade Commission had requested each to supply additional information concerning the proposed merger of Olinkraft into a JohnsManville subsidiary.

title: Queens Congresswoman May Have Started Trend
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro is trying to get Bella S. Abzug's old seat on the Public Works Committee when the new House of Representatives parcels out freshman assignments.

title: How the N.F.L. Breaks Ties for Berths
description: The National Football League's formula for breaking ties in the standings is used in four ways: to determine qualification for the playoffs, to decide sites for playoff games, to determine the selection order in the college player draft, and to help determine the schedule for the following season.

title: Pilot Ejects Before Crash
description: ENGLAND AIR FORCE BASE, La.. Dec. 10 (AP)  A oneseat A7D jet fighter crashed after takeoff about 8 A.M. today and broke into pieces at the end of a runway here, but the pilot ejected safely, base officials said.

title: TaxCredit Plan Urged to Foster Civilian Patrols
description: As one Jewish group rallied in front of Brooklyn's 66th Precinct station house calling for a Jewish selfdefense force, the leader of another group yesterday proposed a New York State tax credit to aid civilian patrols augmenting the police in various city communities.

title: Oil Drilling Takes a Breather
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 10  After the most intense burst of domestic oil exploration and production in two decades, the pace of drilling in the United States is slowing from the breathless to the merely brisk.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON  My most important job in the White House was to go into the Oval Office before every Momentous Decision to proclaim: Mr. President  take the easy way! Do the popular thing! This would enable me to be truthful in drafting these lines in a speech: Some of my adyisors have told me to take the easy way, to do the popular thing. But I have rejected that advice....

title: TV SPORTS
description: TONIGHT

title: The Region
description: The state university system in New Jersey has failed in its efforts at affirmativeaction recruitment of faculty members, according to the State Chancellor of Higher Education, Dr. T. Edward Hollander.

title: Soccer: Dons Beat Indiana in Final
description: TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 10  The University of San Francisco captured its fourth National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer title today by defeating Indiana, 20, at Tampa Stadium.

title: The Police Term Knife Most Available Weapon
description: Police officials this week noted the easy availability of knives in assaying the two recent stabbing murders on city streets.

title: Pete Rose And the Ripple
description: JOHN GALBREATH was going to make Pete Rose a man of wealth and also breeding. To get in on that end of the horse business, said Rose, I thought you had to be a Farouk. The brood mares proffered by the Pirates owner would have been nice to have, as long as they didn't get independent and foal out their options, but the very suggestion of Charley Hustle's becoming a Farouk, or even something along the lines of a Galbreath, was unsettling.

title: Licensing of Jersey's Gambling Casinos
description: TRENTON  Until last week, what Resorts International has wanted, Resorts has got.

title: British Parliamentary Delegation Accuses El Salvador of Torture
description: LONDON, Dec. 10 (Reuters)  A British parliamentary delegation reported today that it had found evidence of torture and repression in the El Salvador.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Fight to Protect Mental Patients Applies Humor
description: Participants in the movement to protect the rights of mental patients educate the public about their side of the mental health problem with books, articles, poetry and plays.

title: Did Air Crash Kill Banker? A Fraud Indictment Says No
description: On Aug. 7, 1976, a small chartered jet plane slammed into the side of El Burro Mountain near Acapulco, Mexico, killing the three persons aboard. Among those listed as dead was David Graiver, an Argentine banker with large finalicial interests in New York.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Recital: Persky Plays Clarinet
description: STANLEY PERSKY's clarinet tecital Saturday afternoon at Carnegie Recital. Hall began auspiciously but trailed off from there. At the outset, Mr. Persky, who has played with numerous newmusic groups in town and who is on the faculty of the City College of New York, offered Stravinsky's Three Pieces for Clarinet Solo (1919) and Berg's Four Pieces (1913), with Fritz Jahoda at the piano. Both works received technically adept, interpretively insightful read. ings.

title: New Buildings Squeezing Into a Crowded Midtown
description: Midtown Manhattan may be booming, but it is not growing. Building in the center of the city, active again after years of hiatus, is following a strange pattern, altogether unlike that of development in previous booms.

title: Jonestown Fund Linked To a Reputed Hit List
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10 (AP)  A People's Temple aide says the Rev. Jim Jones planned to use the money found at Jonestown, Guyana, to pay for death contracts on his enemies, The San Francisco Examiner reported today.

title: Browns Spoil Jets' Comeback And Playoff Hopes in Overtime
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 10  The New York. Jets playoff hopes ended today when the Cleveland Browns overcame a stunning Jet comeback to score a 3734 overtime victory on a 22yard field goal by Don Cockroft. The Jets trailed, 2710, when they began their comeback and scored 24 points in the final 9 minutes 12 seconds of regulation play.

title: Oil Refineries May Face a Strike This Winter, an Executive Warns
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (Reuters) The head of Standard Oil of Indiana warned today that the petroleum refining industry may face a strike this winter that could seriously curtail supplies of gasoline and fuel oil.

title: Paper Surrenders Reporter's Notes in Murder Trial
description: TRAVERSE CITY, Mich., Dec. 10  A reporter's notes, subpoenaed by the prosecution in a murder trial here, have been turned over to the prosecutor as well as the defense after four months of court battles.

title: Text of Sadat Talk at Nobel Ceremony
description: OSLO, Dec. 10 (AP)  Following is the text of a speech by President Anwar elSadat of Egypt, delivered in English by his representative, Sayed Marei, in accepting Mr. Sadat's share of the Nobel Peace Prize here today.

title: Survey Spots U.S. Agencies Most Willing to Lend Ear to Complaints
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI) People filing consumer complaints with the Government probably have their best chance of: being heard at the Civil Aeronaut ics Board or the United States Postal Service.

title: McEnroe Hero in Cup Victory
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif., Dec. 10 John McEnroe brought the Davis Cup back to the United States today for the first time in six years, and few players ever did it better.

title: Russians Win In Gymnastics
description: SAO PAULO, Dec. 10 (AP)  Aleksandre Dijatin and Maria Filatova of the Soviet Union won individual gold medals last night in the World Cup gymnastics competition at the Ibirapuera Gymnasium.

title: A Second Tame Deer Killed In Pennsylvania
description: WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Dec. 10 (AP)  A deer in a pen as part of a Christmas display in this central Pennsylvania town was stabbed to death today with a hunting knife.

title: A Tart Controversy Grips the Apple World: Which Is the Best Granny?
description: In the world of apples, a green revolution is going on. It involves apples called Granny Smiths, and a minor controversy over whose Granny is the best.

title: Flyers Stop Rangers In Rough Battle, 40
description: The Rangers were manhandled, pummeled, speared and shut out last night by the Philadelphia Flyers, 40. It was a ragged hockey game at Madison Square Garden, matching the unruly behavior of the crowd.

title: Birch Society Celebrates Its 20th Birthday
description: DALLAS, Dec. 10  Twenty years to the day after the founding of the John Birch Society, about 800 members gathered yesterday for its annual council meeting, apparently convinced that the United States was catching up to what they'd been saying since the Eisenhower Administration.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Edward Kennedy got angry the other day: Steamingly, publicly angry. It was not a politician's anger, a performance for effect. He was sore and showed it, shouting in outrage. There may be a moral in the tale.

title: Peking's Fallen Angels: Some Stay in Pantheon for Years
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 10  First a history lesson. Many years ago, or so it seems in China, before the Cultural Revolution took place, disgraced Communistileaders were not purged. They just  well  faded away.

title: VANCE STARTS TALKS WITH SADAT ON PACT
description: CAIRO, Dec. 10  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance held a very good, full and constructive meeting with President Anwar elSadat tonight as he opened the American drive to overcome obstacles to an EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty.

title: Notes on People
description: Today is the 70th birthday of Elliott Carter, the composer, and, despite a dizzying schedule of celebratory concerts and rehearsals, he Will be at City Hall at 11 o'clock this morning to receive New York City's highest cultural award, the Handel Medallion, from Mayor Koch. Previous recipients include Marian Anderson, Arthur Rubenstein, Leonard Bernstein, Martha Graham, Marc Chagall, Eva LeGallienne and the late Pablo Casals. but City Hall sources say that, after a period when the medallion was given out several times a year, the policy was reexamined. This is the first presentation since Mr. Koch took office.

title: Newspaper Strike Hurt City Sales
description: According to sales data, the 88day newspaper strike apparently hurt bigstore retailing in New York City, interrupting a long pattern in which the city units of the major department stores had consistently outperformed their suburban branches. The strike cut the volume of mail and phone orders and deterred both highfashion and pricepromotion programs, leading retailers say.

title: Dividends
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: Secular Life Attracts More French Priests
description: PARIS, Dec. 10  Bernard has no regrets about leaving the priesthood none at all, he said in the booming voice he used to deliver sermons without a microphone.

title: Venus Data Show Higher Temperatures at Poles
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Dec. 10Infrared measurements of Venus indicate that the cloud tops over the planet's polar regions are warmer than at the equator, Pioneer Venus project scientists said today.

title: MiamiNotre Dame To Play in Tokyo
description: CORAL GABLES, Flu., Dec. 10 (AP)  The University of Miami announced today that it had completed an agreement with Notre Dame to playa football name Nov. 25 next year in Tokyo.

title: Music: Randolph's Messiah
description: OF the major annual Messiah productions in New York, David Randolph'' with his Masterwork Chorus and Orchestra, which began a series of six performances Saturday night at Carnegie Hall, is the most widely performed and heavily attended.

title: U.S. Backs Iran Envoy On Payment for Flights
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10The State Department denied yesterday that William H. Sullivan, the United States Ambassador in Iran, had opposed the use of public funds to pay travel costs for dependents of American officials who wished to leave that country.

title: STUDY FINDS RULES ON MICROWAVES LAG
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10  A Congressional study has concluded that Federal agencies have been lax in setting and enforcing standards to protect the public from the potential health hazards of microwave radiation; which at high levels has been shown to cause cataracts, sterility and birth defects.

title: New Unit Votes to Strike Giant Virginia Shipyard
description: HAMPTON, .Va., Dec. 10  Thousands of shipyard workers voted overwhelmingly tonight for a strike against the giant Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company  a strike that Federal officials in Washington said could be the biggest ever against a single employer in the South. No date was set for a walkout.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Inflation is expected to continue to rise in 1979 and the economy will slow down, according to the annual forecast by a Conference Board panel. The group expects the next year's growth to shrink 2.4 percent. [Page D1. ]

title: Mental Patients Seeking a Voice In Determining Their Therapies
description: Mental patients are challenging modern psychiatry, its heavy reliance on treatment with drugs and the whole traditional mental health system. Many even question whether mental illness exists. And their movement, psychiatrists concede, is having an effect.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, DECEMBER 11, 1978

title: Heart Attacks Claim Couple on Same Day
description: FORT WORTH, Dec. 10 (UPI)Diann Shepard will attend the funerals tomorrow of her parents, who died of heart attacks within minutes of each other.

title: In Military, Acronyms Go Marching Along
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10  Sir, on the cruise missiles, aren't we introducing an F.B.S. issue into SALT? After all, the GLCM/SLCM are essentially theater weapons, as the Europeans see them as forwardbased systems.

title: A New Judge In Cereal Case
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 The Federal Trade Commission has ordered a new administrative law judge to take over the antitrust case against three cereal companies  the Kellogg Company. General Mills Inc. and the General Foods Corporation. They are accused of inhibiting competition by issuing many cereals that are essentially alike and by causing stores to give little space to other companies' brands. General Foods Corporation. They are accused of inhibiting competition by issuing many cereals that are essentially alike and by causing stores to give little space to other companies' brands.

title: Arts Academy Elects I.M.Pei As Chancellor
Around the Nation
description: HOPKINSVILLE, Ky., Dec. 10 (AP) A military cargo plane crashed early today in a field short of a runway at Fort Campbell Army base in southwestern Kentucky, killing all five crew members aboard. a military spokesman said.

title: Those Upwardly Mobile Street Peddlers
description: Hey, getcher Saint Lawrent! Hey, getcher Crissyun Dieor!

title: Police in Israel Tighten Security To Prepare for Mrs. Meir's Rites
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 10  Israeli authorities stepped up security precautions today in view of the arrival of many foreign dignitaries for the state funeral on Tuesday of former Prime Minister Golda Meir.

title: Donors to Neediest Cases Fund Increase Gifts to Offset Inflation
description: Inflation and its special problems for the indigent were mentioned yesterday by two donors who increased their contributions to the 67th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Jonestown 3 Weeks Later: Outsiders Are Taking Over
description: JONESTOWN, Guyana, Dec. 10Only the muffled voices of policemen, the tread of their boots on the wooden walkways and the rustle of banana palms broke the quiet in this former jungle commune today.

title: San Francisco Comes to Grips With Murders
description: How does a city resurrect itself when its heart has been shot out, especially a city like San Francisco, whose residents adore it and exult in showing it to visitors, facet by beautiful facet, as if were a precious stone? Three weeks ago, San Franciscans.had some worries: the multimilliondollar deficit they may face next year as a result of the taxcutting Proposition 13, and new Federal legislation that may make the manpower programs of the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act virtually unavailable to the city government.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: JUST when you think you have finally gotten rid of the Old South, the mythic, violent, erotic, paranoid, biblical and deathobsessed South that used to be as important to the American imagination as the haunted houses of Hawthorne, the ghosts of dead whaling captains and the blood of Indians all over the frontier; just when you think this Old South is sealed over by the New, beneath, the Hyatt hotels booked full of peanut barons; just when it seems no longer necessary to grapple with the demons of a Faulkner or the peacocks of a Flannery O'Connor  along comes Harry Crews.

title: Instead of the Shah, an Islamic Republic
description: PARISIn recent weeks the Western press has written a great deal about the impasse between the Shah and his opposition. Western observers have suggested that his opponents should accept a compromise with the regime in order to break the deadlock and spare the country further bloodshed. Unfortunately, the Western press has never understood that a compromise along the lines proposed by the Shah and his American supporters will not free Iran from crisis.

title: TV SPORTS
description: TONIGHT

title: let Stars to Shine At Tucker Benefit
description: Luciano Pavarotti, tenor, and other Metropolitan Opera singers will take part in the third Richard Tucker Memorial Gala on Jan. 7 in Carnegie Hall. Am nong those scheduled to appear are ??egine Crespin, Marilyn Horne, Leona ??itchell and Rita Shane, sopranos; Al??edo Kraus, tenor; Robert Merrill and errill Milnes, baritones, and Bonaldo aiotti and Paul Plishka, basses. mes Levine will be the music direc tor, and Francis Robinson will be master of ceremonies.

title: Ruth Lindstrom Wed to L.C. Windsor Jr.
description: In the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan yesterday, Ruth Ester Lindstrom, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond W. Lindstrom of West Hartford, Cohn., became the bride of Laurence Charles Windsor Jr., son of Margaret Windsor of Hinsdale, III., and the late Mr. Windsor. The rector, the Rev. Alanson B. Houghton, performed the ceremony during the regular morning service.

title: Commodities
description: THERE were some uncommonly strange words buzzing about the gold market last week. The gold bulls spoke glowingly of crocuses and daffodils, while the bears complained about deceptions practiced by London bullion dealers.

title: Skiing: A First for Miss Fisher
description: PIANCAVALLO. Italy, Dec. 10 (AP)  Abbi Fisher, a diminutive skier from South Conway, N.H., scored her first victory in a World Cup special slalom ski race today.

title: A. Sumner Gambee, 77, ExPresident of Hospital
description: A. Sumner Gambee, a past president of Englewood (N.J.) Hospital, died at the hospital Saturday. He was 77 years old and lived at 220 Speer Avenue in Englewood.

title: RIGHTS TREATY MOVE AIMED AT LIBERALS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 10  In a move likely to please liberals, President Carter has taken another step to improve the United States embarrassing record of inaction on United Nations humanrights treaties and has urged speedy Senate ratification of the 30yearold genocide convention.

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON ARE credit controls coming? Probably, according to some economists, such as Alan Greenspan, former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers. No, according to Administration officials such as G. William Miller, the chairman of the Federal Reserve.

title: Dolphins in Playoffs; Raiders Out
description: MIAMI, Dec. 10.  The Miami Dolphins' world, so shaky in recent weeks, took on substance and shape today. The team came on strong during the second half against Oakland and defeated the Raiders, 236, in a game that proved decisive in determining the playoff teams in the American Football Conference. Miami is in, Oakland is out.

title: Witness Faces 5Year Term for 11 Murders
description: A major witness has testified in the Westchester Premier Theater trial that he participated in 11 murders, but will serve no more than five years in prison because he is telling What he knows about crime throughout the country.

title: BIG TEHEARAN CROWD MARCHES PEACEABLY AGAINST SHAR'H RULE
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 10  Hundreds of thousands of Iranians marched six miles through the heart of Teheran today in a powerful but entirely peaceful protest against the rule of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.

title: Fiedler in Boston Hospital Again
description: BOSTON, Dec. 10 (AP)  Arthur Fiedler, conductor of the Boston Pops Orchestra, was admitted again yesterday to a hospital here with undisclosed ailments. He was reported in satisfactory condition. Mr. Fiedler, who will be 84 years old in a week, reentered Tufts New England Medical Center Hospital for therapy. He was at the hospital from Nov. 29 to Dec. 1 and continued recuperation at his home in Brookline.

title: Williamson Leads Nets Upward
description: I'M Super John Williamson, said the rookie guard when he introduced himself to the Nets. That's me.

title: Chilean Police Seize 30 Staging Rights Protest
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 10 (Reuters)  Policemen using riot sticks arrested about 30 people today when humanrights demonstrators blocked traffic in Santiago.

title: Giants Get the Message, Defeat Cardinals by 170
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 10  On a day when Giants' fans took to the air to express their frustration, the Giants kept their cleats firmly on the icy ground and ended a sixgame losing streak by defeating the St. Louis Cardinals, 170.

title: The Missile We Don't Need.
description: The Pentagon's proposal to begin full development next year of a bigger, more accurate intercontinental ballistic missile, the MX, raises questions about a possible reversal of the 30year American strategy of deterrence. That strategy has relied on the threat of largescale retaliation against Soviet cities to discourage any thought of a nuclear attack against the United States. The MX, in contrast, would carry. three times the hydrogen bomb payload of existing Minuteman III missiles; its dozen multiple warheads could destroy most of the Soviet Union's silobased missile force in a firststrike attack. This power might increase Washington's temptation to wage a limited nuclear war in a crisis, something President Carter has rejected as inviting largescale nuclear war.

title: 88 in Congress Traveled Abroad in Last 6 Weeks
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)  More than onethird of the eligible senators and at least 59 House members have made overseas trips at taxpayers' expense since Congress adjourned in midOctober, State Department and Congressional records show.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The Government securities market drifted downward last week, with trading activity unusually light, as few dealers or investors seemed to have much conviction about the outlook. The thing to do, many seemed to agree, was to sit back and wait till the new year, when the trend of interest rates might become clearer.

title: A Nuclear Accident, Canceled Because of Bad Weather, Finally Proceeds at Lab in Idaho
description: MUD LAKE, Idaho, Dec. 10  The nuclear accident that happened here late last night did not quite go as planned. The United States Government had spent three years and about $10 million setting it up, but not even the Government could prevent the pipes from freezing.

title: TaxExempt Issues Top $1 Billion for 2d Week
description: For the second consecutive week, more than $1 billion of new taxexempt bond issues are scheduled for sale, and underwriters expect to be able to handle the heavy volume without pushing interest rates higher.

title: De Gustibus
description: Along about midsummer we received a letter from Saul Mallon of Morristown, N.J., stating that almost 40 years ago (good heavens, that man has a long memory!) a recipe for Pendennis Club eggnog was published shortly before Christmas on the food page of The New York Sun.

title: 3 Countries Gain In 1979 Cup Play
description: While the United States was winning this year's Davis Cup tennis final yesterday, advances in zone competition for the 1979 Cup were completed by Japan, Colombia and Argentina.

title: An Exauditor Troubles KLM
description: A bitter legal squabble between KLM Royal Dutch Airlines and a dismissed company auditor here has brought to light allegations of irregular payments and conflicts of interest by KLM officials, and of secret loans and hidden and improper control of other travel facilities by KLM itself.

title: Advertising
description: IT has been about a year since Fortune and Esquire went from monthly to fortnightly, and the publishers of both are prepared to say it was a good move.

title: King of Sweden Presents Nobel Awards to 9 Laureates
description: STOCKHOLM. Dec. 10 (UPI)  Prizes were awarded today to six Nobel laureates frolm the United States, one from the Soviet Onion, one from Britain and one from Switzerland .for their work bestowing the greatest benefit on mankind during 1978 in the fields of literature. science and economics.

title: Egypt and Israel Air Differences at Nobel Ceremony
description: OSLO, Dec. 10  President Anwar elSadat of Egypt and Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel pledged themselves in accepting the Nobel Peace Prize today to continued peace efforts, but the laureates clearly marked out the negotiating differences between them.

title: Nonprofit Agency Said to Spend U.S. Funds for Private Buildings
description: A nonprofit Brooklyn neighborhood preservation agency spent public funds on buildings owned by its board members or their families, according to a report issued yesterday by the City Council President, Carol Bellamy.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: PATIO PARADE The Salute to Great American Songwriters series at the Market atrium of the Citicorp Center is taking a breather until the day after Christmas, However, seasonal entertainment is moving right ahead, with free daily performances in the patio, entered on 53d or 54th Street east of Lexington Avenue. Many of the table sitters (early arrivals) bring in snacks and beverages from surrounding Market shops. ShOwtime is 6 to 8 P.M. on Monday through Friday, 4 to 6 P.M. on Saturday and 3 to 5 P.M. on Sunday.

title: Entertainment Events
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center. verdi'sAida. 8.

title: Sporting Gear
description: TableTop Hockey Game

title: PRIVATE ACADEMIES PROTEST TAX PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10  The Internal Revenue Service didn't know quite what it was getting into.

title: United Begins Wooing Women
description: The reason that one sees United Airlines advertising directed at the female business traveler is simple enough. She's part of the fastestgrowing category of airline passenger. And United has all sorts of research on her.

title: Mr. Meany Is Out of Step
description: George Meany and the A.F.L.C.I.O. have launched a major effort to undermine the President's embryonic wageprice guideline program. They charge that the program is biased in favor of business and that it comes down too hard on wages, too soft on prices. Instead of Mr. Carter's quasivoluntary effort, they want mandatory controls. Such criticism is premature and unfortunate. The President's price control proposal, with its threat of denying Government contracts; could turn out to be mandatory in all but name. Moreover, the workers Mr. Meany represents have much to gain from the success of the President's approach to wage moderation.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Are professional tennis players spoiled? Sentiment seems to mount that in some cases the answer is yes, and those who believe it can point to a couple of incidents last week involving a Swedish star, the Grand Prix Masters tournament and the ColgatePalmolive Company.

title: U.S. Team Loses
description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Dec. 10 (AP)  TrinidadTobago beat the United States juvenile soccer team by 31 today. The setback toppled the Americans from first place in the North, Central American and Caribbean juvenile soccer championship. The champion will represent the zone in the world championship in Tokyo next year.

title: Miller Expects Easing Of Credit Pressure Soon
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10  G. William Miller, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said that the rate of growth of the nation's money supply was slowing so rapidly that it was likely that pressures in credit markets wouldsoon abate and that interest rates will begin to drift downward on their own.

title: The Fans' Sign From the Sky
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. WITH more love than hate, as if rehearsing a polite scolding of an old relative, the members of the Giants Fans Committee passed out mimeographed sheets yesterday at Giants Stadium that announced: On or about 1:30 P.M. There will be a sign from the sky  We've Had Enough  if you feel we Giant Fans have Suffered long enough, pass this along the aisle to ether Die Hard Giant Fans and join in a unison chant of We've Had Enough. We have been the most supportive, loyal Fans in the world. Maybe if we all raise our voices, our message will reach management. We cannot wait another 15 years for a championship!

title: TV: A Woman Called Moses With Cicely Tyson
description: NEARLY five years ago, Cicely Tyson starred in The Autobiography of Miss Jane Pittman, the fictional saga of a black woman whose life spanned the end of slavery and the beginnings of civil rights protests in the 1960's. Tonight and tomorrow, on NBC at 9, Miss Tyson can be seen in A Woman Called Moses, a fictionalized account of the life of Harriet Ross Tubman.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 10 (AP) David Graham of Australia, down by three strokes at the start of the day, fired a fiveunderpar 67 and won the $210,000 Mexico Cup golf tournament today when Don January missed a fivefoot par putt on the 18th.

title: Hussein Plans Explanation Tour
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 10 (Reuters) King Hussein and his wife, Queen Noor, will begin tomorrow a tour of France, Italy, the Vatican and Britain. The King will explain the Jordanian position at last month's panArab summit conference in Baghdad; Iraq, at which the Camp David peace agreement between Egypt and Israel was condemned, Government sources said.

title: Demands Heard From Abductors Of a Businessman in El Salvador
description: SAN SALVADOR, Dec. 10 (Reuters) A leftwing guerrilla group has demanded the release of political prisoners in El Salvador as a condition for freeing a kidnapped Japanese businessman, diplomatic sources said today.

title: Bridge:
description: A favored horse that falls at the first fence in a steeplechase such as England's famed Grand National attracts public attention, surprise and sympathy. This happened in New York City Saturday in the Grand National, which on this side of the Atlantic is a rather slower bridge event that starts at club level and concludes eight months later with a national champion.

title: Aspin Says Navy Is Lax In CarrierPlane Crashes
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI)  Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, accused the Navy today of gross negligence in ignoring design flaws that he said caused at least six carrierlaunched planes to plunge into the sea over the last year.

title: Sports Today
description: Rams vs. Cincinnati Bengals, at Los Angeles. (Television  Channel 7. 9 P.M. Radio WCBS. 8:50 P.M.)

title: Kaunda, Zambia's Leader, Seeks New Term in Election Tomorrow
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 10 (AP) President Kenneth D. Kaunda, his popularity eroded by an economic crisis at home and the spillover of a guerrilla war in Rhodesia, will seek endorsement this week from Zambia's two million voters for another fiveyear term in office.

title: Democrats, Under Pressure, Vote To Praise Carter Bucket Priorities
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 10  President Carter won the unexpected battle of Memphis today when the Democratic Party, under intense and, organized Administration pressure, voted to praise his budget plans instead of demanding that he protect domestic social spending from reductions.

title: 4 Killed, 1 Hurt As Blaze Sweeps Brooklyn Home
description: Two adults and two children were killed yesterday and a third child was injured as fire swept through an apartment in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn.

title: Big Macs and Cokes: New Chinese Foods?
description: TOKYO, Dec. 10  The Big Mac in China? And CocaCola, too?

title: Downhill to Read
description: SCHLADMING, Austria, Dec. 10 Ken Read of Canada, a top finisher in training runs last week, showed that practice makes perfect as he won the first downhill race of the World Cup skiing season over a muddy course today.

title: Deaths
description: BARSHAYRobert, of 2965 Avenue Z. Brooklyn, husband of Beatrice, lather of Mark and Edward, grandfather of Cynthia and Sharon, Ethan and Ross, brother of Hyman Barshay and May. Funeral today. 11:30 AM, al Kirechenbaum Funeral Parlor, 1153 Corey Island Ave.

title: Suit Over a Hughes Will to Be Film
description: LOS ANGELES The bizarre story of Melvin Dummar, a Utah gas station attendant who tried to prove that Howard Hughes willed him a fortune in return for a lift, will be turned into a $4.5 million romantic comedy by Universal.

title: To Walt Frazier,
description: WALT FRAZIER used to own this city. He used to run the Knicks until 10, then roam the Mr. Goodbars until 4. He was so cool he never. even broke a sweat. He had a burgundy and antelope RollsRoyce, a fulllength mink coat and a mirror on the ceiling of his bedroom. But no act runs forever. He closed in New York last fall and had to take it on the road to Cleveland. He comes back only for moments. Last Thursday was one.

title: NFL Standings
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Radio
description: 8 A.M. WNCN. Andante with live Variations (K. 501), Mozart; ??ugue in A minor from Prelude ??nd Fugue, Bach; Danse Macabre, ??aintSaens; Lachrimae: 2 Al??ans, Dowland; Rigoletto Para??rase, Liszt; Adagio in G monor ??r Strings ans Organ, Albinoni

title: Three Women Killed in Car Crash On Icy Washington County Road
description: NORTH GRANVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 10 (UPI)  Three Whitehall women were. killed in a twocar collision on an icy road in Washington County yesterday.

title: Stage: Choices, Women's Anthology
description: UNDER a grant from the Ford Foundation, the American Place Theater has undertaken a project to encourage the developthent of women playwrights and directors. Because the American theater is burgeoning with new creative female talent, the program is potentially a significant one.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: How many Ivy League graduates have played in the National Football League this season, and how does this compare with 10 years ago?

title: Text of Begin Speech Accepting Prize
description: OSLO, Dec. 10 (AP)  Following is the text of the speech delivered in English by Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel when he accepted his share of the 1978 Nobel Peace Prize at Akershus Castle today.

title: A Little Help for Connecticut Schools
description: Connecticut, never noted for generosity toward its cities and. towns, is moving, under pressure and not very fast, to longoverdue reform of public school financing. In 1977, the state's Supreme Court declared unconstitutional Connecticut's heavy reliance on municipal property taxes and gave the state until next May to fashion a fairer method of ravine for schools. The state's preliminary reply, just issued by its School Finance Advisory Panel, may satisfy the court and placate apprehensive taxpayers. But financially beset cities like Hartford and poor rural towns like Sterling have little cause to rejoice.

title: That's the Law
description: Many nonhunters, distressed by the sight of dead deer on automobiles, do not realize that in many states the hunter is required by law to display them.

title: Seeking a Voice on Television
description: Should more people have a voice on TV? The question seems to answer itself. Who canobject to so desirable an objective as widening access to the airwaves? The harder question, evident in the debate now under way before the Federal Communications Commission, is how to go about it.

title: Chamber: Ars Nova Bow In New York
description: MOST symphony orchestras these days form splinter groups that give their members an opportunity to perform chamber music in addition to the regular symphonic repertory. The Buffalo Philharmonic established the Ars Nova Musicians for this purpose in 1974 and, under the direction of Marylouise Nanna, a first violinist with the parent orchestra, the ensemble presented its New York debut concert Saturday night in Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: Speculum Musicae Celebrates Elliott Carter at 70
description: ELLIOTT CARTER is 70 years old today and during the last few weeks musical organizations have been paying their respects to one of America's most renowned composers. Perhaps the most important birthday concert occurred last night in Tully Hall featuring members of Speculum Musicae.

title: Market Place
description: TWICE last week, John R. Kennedy Jr., president of the Federal Paper Board Company, felt obliged to issue a statement saying that the concern knew of no particular reason for unusual trading and advancing prices in its shares.

title: Strides in Arms Talks With Soviet Said to Bring Summit Session Near
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10  Administration officials said today that progress in the SovietAmerican negotiations to limit strategic arms had enabled the two sides to plan. a meeting between Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko designed to conclude the talks and pave the way for a summit conference between President Carter and Leonid 1. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, perhaps as early as January.

title: 2 Teenagers Charged With Bludgeon Death Of Bronx Woman, 83
description: Two Bronx teenagers were arrested early yesterday and charged in the murder hours earlier of an 83yearold woman whose West Bronx apartment was set afire, apparently by the assailants to cover up the crime, the police reported.

title: Opposing Stands Taken By Mondale and Kennedy
description: Following are excerpts from the speeches by Vice President Mondale yesterday and Senator Edward M. Kennedy Saturday night at the Democratic midterm conference.

title: Parts of Frankfort, Ky., Flooded; 1,000 Flee, State Capitol Cut Off
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., Dec. 10 (AP) Floodwater filled the streets of more than half of downtown Frankfort today, forcing 1,000 people from their homes, interrupting water, gas and phone service and cutting off the state Capitol.

title: Task Force Says Police Should Supervise Arson Cases
description: Asserting that the Police and Fire Departments frequently get in each other's way during arson investigations because of rivalry anti overlapping jurisdictions, the newly formed New York arson strike force has proposed a comprehensive streamlining of arsoninvestigation procedures.

title: World Gold
description: MONDAY, DEC. 11. 1978

title: RECESSION FORESEEN BY CONGRESS AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11  The Congressional Budget Office is projecting a decline in the nation's output of goods and services for the final two quarters of next year. This would meet the formal definition of a recession.

title: Designers, Even Dreamers, Peer Into Aviation's Future
description: SEVENTYFIVE years ago, on Dec. 17, 1903, a powered airplane built by the Wright brothers lurched into the air, heralding a technological revolution and an era as romantic as any in human history.

title: Uarco Sets Merger
description: Uarco Inc., which opposes a takeover bid of $48 a share from Dayl in Inc., said yesterday that it had reached a definitive merger agreement with the City Investing Company at $52 a share. There are 2.05 million outstanding Uarco shares, so the deal would cost City Investing as much as $107 million in cash.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTH ERN DISTRICT Monday, Dec. 11, 1978

title: TestTube Baby Clinic Planned
description: TWO Virginia doctors are preparing to open the first United States clinic that will use testtube baby procedures, thus lending a new urgency in this country to the ethical and medical issues that have been widely debated since Louise Brown was born in a British hospital last July.

title: Karl E. Mason; Taught Anatomy At the Rochester Medical Center
description: Karl E. Mason, professor emeritus at the University of Rochester Medical Center, died Friday in Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md., after suffering a heart attack at his home. He was 78 years old.

title: U.S. Is Drafting a LandUse Plan For the Scarred California Desert
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 11  More than 500 motorcyclists, in apparent defiance of a Federal court order, roared 155 miles across the desert from Barstow, Calif., to Las Vegas, Nev., late last month, churning up sand and leaving tire tracks that may last for decades.

title: JOHN M. YOUNG, 77, OF ORGAN STANLEY
description: John M. Young, a founder and, in recent years, an advisory director of the New York investment banking concern of Morgan Stanley & Company, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 77 years old and also lived in Katonah, N.Y.

title: Evansville Five Gets a Victory
description: MURRAY, Ky., Dec. 11 (AP)  The University of Evansville defeated Murray State, 5958, tonight and scored its first basketball victory in nearly a year since a plane crash killed 14 squad members and Coach Bob Watson.

title: China Leads Asian Games
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 11 (UPI)  The Japanese won 10 gold medals, three silver and four bronze today in the Asian Games; but could not pull even with the Chinese, who dominated gymnastics on strong performances by their women.

title: Jackson a Gasoline Critic
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11  Senator Henry M. Jackson, chairman of the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources, criticized the automobile industry today for failing to prevent the current rise in demand for expensive, highoctane, unleaded gasoline and the oil industry for failing to meet that demand.

title: Sylvia Johnson, Feminist Leader And State Official in New Jersey
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 11 (UPI)Sylvia Johnson, director of the State Division on Women since October 1977, died yesterday in the Princeton Medical Center. She was 54 years old.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 12,1978

title: Teachers to Ask Court in Newark To Halt Layoffs
description: NEWARK, Dec. 11 A legal challenge to the layoffs of about 1,000 school employees and elimination of slots for 700 substitute teachers will be initiated as soon as the first layoff notice is received, according to Carol A. Graves, president of the Newark Teachers Union.

title: A Second Dockworker Is Sought In Wounding of a Drug Informer
description: Thomas Esposito, a Brooklyn longshoreman who became an informer for the Government after his conviction on narcotics charges, was shot in the head and seriously wounded as he left for work last Thursday. Shortly afterward, agents of the Drug Enforcement Administration arrested Tomas Aviles, a fellow longshoreman who was said by the victim to have fired the bullet.

title: U.N. Human Rights Day Has Asperity and Nostalgia
description: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 11  From the moment that the President of the General Assembly, Indalecio Lievano Aguirre of Colombia, opened the 30th anniversary celebration of Human Rights Day until he rapped his gavel after dusk, it was difficult to distinguish the special session from any ordinary day of diplomatic business.

title: Shell Abandons Well
description: The Shell Oil Company, as operator for a group of 19 companies, announced yesterday that no oil or gas had been found in its second exploratory well in the Baltimore Canyon, off the Atlantic coast. The company said it would plug and abandon the well, which is about 87 miles east of Cape Henlopen, Del.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: TELEVISION is education's allpurpose scapegoat. Reports on any youth problem, from declining reading scores to juvenile violence, point accusing fingers at the boob tube  the very term indicative of the bias shared by many Intellectuals and most teachers. The implication is that, if only TV went away, all would once again be well with the world of learning.

title: Bias Case That May Rival Bakke's Accepted by High Court for Review
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11  The Supreme Court agreed today to decide a discrimination case that is potentially even more significant and divisive than last term's Bakke case.

title: U.S. Aide Suggests Two Papers In Cincinnati Be Operated Jointly
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP)  The Justice Department's antitrust division recommended today that The Cincinnati Enquirer be permitted to operate jointly with The Cincinnati Post.

title: Pontiff, on Rights Day, Condemns Violations
description: ROME, Dec. 11 (AP)  Pope John Paul II, in a message made public today, proclaimed himself saddened and dissatisfied over too many examples of human rights violations.

title: Fight Brews Among Rock Promoters
description: Although both sides insist that they wish to avoid it, a potential war is brewing in New York popularmusic concert promotion. The contestants are Ron Delsener, the city's leading concert promoter, vs. Alan Pepper and Stanley Snadowsky, owners of the nightclub the Bottom Line.

title: A High Chinese Military Leader, Pirged by Mao in 1959, Apparently Is Rehabilitated
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 11  Peng Tehhuai, who commanded China's forces in the Korean War and was one of the Communists greatest military figures before being purged in 1959, has apparently been rehabilitated.

title: Victim of an Attack Loses Round in Battle to Keep Her Assailant in Jail
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 11 Elaine C. Summers, a 27yearold lawyer who used an obscure law to see that the man she said had tried to rape her was punished, lost a legal round today when a judge ruled that he could get out of jail on $2,500 bond while the constitutionality of the law was determined.

title: New Hope in Nicaragua
description: Another round of civil war may now be averted in Nicaragua, thanks mainly to an interAmerican team of mediators, led by the United States. President. Somoza has agreed to resign if he loses a national plebiscite, and the leadership of the Broad Opposition Front has agreed to accept the President's rule pending the vote. But a peaceful outcome still depends on Mr. Somoza ; only he can guarantee a fair vote.

title: Poland Trims Hosiery Prices
description: WARSAW, Dec. 11 (Reuters)  Poland's price commission reduced the price of women's tights and stockings by 25 percent today to encourage the purchase of new ones rather than the mending of old pairs. A Warsaw daily, Zycie Warszawy, said that vast stockpiles had built up in factories.

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: THERE are times when tax legislation seems be nothing so much as an endless series of glosses and corrections on what went before. The newly minted Revenue Act of 1978 and its liberalized treatment of Individual Retirement Accounts no exception.

title: Notes on People
description: What kind of sparks might fly if you invited Susan Brownmiller and Norman Mailer to the same party? Yesterday, the New York Public Library found out when the feminist author of Against Their Wills, a study of rape, and the longtime Mr. Macho of the literary scene joined other writers at a buffetluncheon presentation of a $100,000 check to the research libraries from B. Dalton, the new booksellers in town.

title: JEWISH GROUPS DENY THEY MISLED PRESS
description: BOSTON, Dec. 11  American Jewish groups that played important roles in obtaining Soviet exit visas for Boris and Natalya Kats and their 14monthold daughter, Jessica, say they are not reponsible for the misapprehension that the child's life was still in danger when her medical problems began to be noticed in the American press last spring.

title: OBSERVER
description: The newest pastime on American campuses is called necking. Like dancing, necking requires two people, usually a male and a female, and a relatively private place with very little light. It is usually done by appointment. Let's get together tonight and neck, one student may say to another. Or, What do you say to a little necking Saturday night?

title: SouthWest Africa Counts Votes
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Africa, Dec. 11 (Reuters)  Counting of votes cast in last week's election for a constituent assembly. in SouthWest Africa started today, with the results expected to be known in a week. South Africa's administrator general in the territory, Judge Marthinus Steyn, has said 81 percent of the 412,000 registered voters cast ballots, although two major political parties boycotted the election.

title: Torture Continuing in Iran, Rights Group Charges
description: LONDON, Dec. 11 (AP)  Amnesty International accused the Iranian authorities today of continuing the systematic torture of political prisoners, contrary to frequent claims by Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi that torture had been stormed.

title: Rhodesia Again Raids Mozambique
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 11 (UPI)  Rhodesia said today that it had carried out new air raids over Mozambique and destroyed several weapons depots of black nationalist guerrillas. It rave only scanty details, but the Mozambique radio said that more than two dozen people had been killed.

title: BEGIN CALLS ISRAEL SET TO RENEW TALKS
description: OSLO, Dec. 11  Prime Minister Menathem Begin of Israel said today that Israel was ready to continue peace negotiations with Egypt even if the parties failed to meet the Dec. 17 deadline agreed to at the Camp David talks for signing a peace treaty.

title: .. After Big Weekend with Washington's Superstars
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11  For three days and nights over the past weekend, this city's politicians, both in office and out, mingled with the Kennedy clan, executives from Warner Communications, a slew of Hollywood stars and President and Mrs. Carter to aid the mentally and physically handicapped, and to publicize Superman, the superbudget movie that will open around the country on Friday.

title: Vietnam Cites Chinese Boat Fire
description: SINGAPORE, Dec. 11 (Reuters) Vietnam accused Chinese vessels today of having intruded into its waters and opened fire on Vietnamese fishermen. A Hanoi radio broadcast, monitored here, said that five Chinese boats had entered an area off Quang Ninh on Saturday and opened fire. There was no mention of casualties. Yesterday, the Chinese press agency charged that Vietnamese ships had attacked two Chinese boats with machinegun fire on Saturday, killing a fisherman and wounding two.

title: Justices Bar a Review Of the Marriage Tax
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11  Apparently accepting the Federal Government's argument that in an imperfect world there is no such thing as a perfect tax code, the Supreme Court today refused to hear a constitutional challenge to the socalled marriage tax  the higher Federal income tax paid by two working people who get married and file a joint return.

title: Superman Road Show for the Special Olympics Rolls Into New York
description: A glittering crowd of 1,300 turned out last night for Premiere No. 2 of the Superman road show, only 24 hours after the Man of Steel had wowed 'em in Washington.

title: Joseph. D. Croll, 79, Dies; Partner In Brokerage Firm Since 1925
description: Joseph D. Croll, a partner in Asiel and Company, a brokerage concern, died Saturday at New York Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 1021 Park Avenue.

title: Rights Policy: Uneven Stress
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11  President Carter's human rights policy, unveiled in the first weeks of his Presidency and publicly reaffirmed in the course of the current Human Rights Week ceremonies at the United Nations, has been plagued from the beginning by challenges to its consistency.

title: Bally Receives Permission to Raze Blenheim Rotunda
description: TRENTON, Dec. 11 The Bally Manufacturing Company today got final state permission to tear down the Blenheim Hotel's rotunda listed in the National Register of Historic Places  to make room for a $100 million casino and hotel complex in Atlantic City.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NO FANFARE Each Christmas season invariably brings a number of interestingsounding exhibitions accompanied by a minimum of publicity  displays that many New Yorkers like to investigate on their own.

title: Television
description: 6:00(4)Media (5)New Zoo Revue (13)Captioned ABC News (R)

title: Deaths
description: CROLLJoseph D. On December 9. 1978. The Twentyfive Year Club of Asiel & Co. mourns the loss of our longtime friend and partner. Constance M. Owsiany, Club President

title: Bridge:
description: Just how far to bid in a competitive auction when both sides have a good fit is always difficult to judge. If in doubt, the best pulicy, for mathematical reasons, is to bid one more. There is much more to gain than there is to lose, and there is a chance of pushing the opposition to a higher level.

title: Books of The Times
description: ONE must ask children and birds how cherries and strawberries taste, said Goethe to Eckermann. But the children and the birds around here are eating Grease this year, so the reviewer is left to his own tastes. Here then, in no particular order, are the children's illustrated books that tasted best in 1978:

title: F.B.I. and Secret Service Reevaluating Guard Role
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI)  The Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation told Congress today that the bureau was taking another look at how it relates to the Secret Service so that it will be better prepared to deal with, or pre. vent, assassinations of Presidents and other national leaders.

title: Frisbee Player Dies From Fall
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Dec. 11 (AP)  Death has claimed a 23yearold Worcester man who accidentally plunged off a 25foot balcony at the Springfield Civic Center. Robert Yiaski had been hospitalized with a fractured skull since the Nov. 29 fall, which occurred as he attempted to catch a Frisbee being tossed around before the start of a rock music concert featuring the group Foreigner. He died last night at Baystate Medical Center.

title: HARRY DIAMOND
description: Harry Diamond, president of the Elizabeth Iron Works of Elizabeth, N.J., died Sunday at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J. He was 94 years old.

title: The Homosexual in Uniform.
description: Until now, the operating policy of the armed forces toward homosexuals. seems to have been to tolerate them as long as they were in the closet or only half out, and to discharge them from service when publicity threatened. But as the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ruled last week, that is not legally satisfactory. The court told the services to rethink the policy.

title: John V. Naish, ExHead Of Convair Division, 71
description: John V. Naish, former vice president of the General Dynamics Corporation and president of that company's Convair Division, died Sunday of cancer at his home in La Jolla, Calif. He was 71 years old.

title: Fairfield 74, Montclair St. 59
