description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Dec. 11 (AP) Mark Young scored 19 points and hauled down 21 rebounds tonight to power Fairfield University to a 7459 college basketball victory over Montclair State. The Stags improved their wonlost record to 42. Montclair State slipped to 24.

title: Giants, for Present, Savor Their Victory
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 11 The future isn't now for the Giantsnot yet. There's one week to go, a week to get even for The Fumble, a week more to tolerate the rumors and wonder how many are true.

title: ISRAELIS IN TRIBUTE AT MRS. MEIR'S BIER
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 11  Tens of thousands of Israelis, many in tears, filed past the coffin of former Prime Minister Golda Meir today in the plaza outside the Parliament building.

title: Some in Cult Riceited Cyanide by Injection, Guyanese Sources Say
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 11At least 70 members of the People's Temple, most of them adults, were given injections of cyanide at Jonestown instead of drinking it, wellplaced Guyanese Government sources said today.

title: WORLD AROUND US
description: WHERE have all the flies gone? Or, for that matter, the mosquitoes, spiders, ants, bees and butterflies?

title: Indochina Refugee Parley Opens
description: GENEVA, Dec. 11  In the presence of a Vietnamese delegation, an international conference on the flow of refugees from Indochina opened here today.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a technical problem, a table in Business Day yesterday, headlined Last Week's Active Issues, actually carried information for the week ended Dec. 1.

title: TV: Place of Dreams Marks 75th Anniversary of Flight
description: UNLESS parents want to run the risk of being pestered for an immediate trip to Washington, they are advised to keep the youngsters away from the television set from 9 to 10 o'clock tonight, when Channel 13 is presenting A Place of Dreams.

title: Sam Houston Johnson, 64, Dies; Brother of the Former President
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 11 Sam Houston Johnson, younger brother of former President Lyndon B. Johnson, died of lung cancer today at Holy Cross Hospital. He was 64 years old.

title: Advertising
description: FOR more than a decade, the Johnnie Walker Black Label Scotch advertising has been a prime example of drinkmeyousnob genre of highpriced spirits advertising. But that's not what Smith/Greenland, Somerset Importer's agency had in mind, it says.

title: 450 Lawyers and Judges Studied For Sign of Legionnaires Disease
description: NEWARK, Dec. 11 (UPI)  Pennsylvania and New Jersey health officials said today that they were surveying 450 lawyers and judges who attended a conference in the Virgin Islands for symptoms of legionnaires disease.

title: OutofTowners Give to Neediest
description: They may be from Clearwater, Fla., Memphis, Term., Solana Beach, Calif., or Weston, Mass., but a steady stream of outoftown donors appear daily in the 67th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Oil Price Rise Put at 5%
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Dec. 11 (UPI)  Oil prices will rise about 5 percent next year, the Saudi newspaper Al Bilad predicted today.

title: British Pledge Currency Role
description: LONDON, Dec. 11 (AP)  Chancellor of the Exchequer Denis Healey has committed Britain to playing a full'role in further discussions on the development of the European Monetary System.

title: Pop: Nina Simone Back
description: AFTER an absence from New York of four and a half years, spent largely in Europe, Nina Simone returned to Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday evening and to an audience that welcomed her enthusiastically and adoringly. It was an ideal Simone audience, as perceptively responsive to her moods and her directions as was Al Shackman, the guitarist, who provided her only accompaniment, and it gave her the opportunity to play the role of high priestess to the hilt.

title: Michaels Forthright on Jet Loss
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 11  Although the temperature in Cleveland was 16 degrees above zero and a 15mileanhour wind was blowing, New York Jets Coach Walt Michaels doesn't think the weather was to blame for the Jets 3734 overtime defeat by the Browns yesterday following a miraculous 24point Jet finalperiod rally.

title: U.S. Plans a Nicaragua Plebiscite
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11  The United States plans to press for the establishment of an international commission to conduct a plebiscite in Nicaragua if it can persuade President Anastasio Somoza Debayle and an opposition coalition to accept the project, officials said today.

title: Dr. Vincent du Vigneaud, at 77; Won a Nobel Prize in Chemistry
description: Dr. Vincent du Vigneaud, a biochemist, who was awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1955 for his work in hormones, died yesterday at St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains at the age of 77. His home was in Scarsdale.

title: Trucking: Competition Looms
description: The open road is beckoning for Grand Union.

title: Borough Park Group Seeks 40 More Officers
description: The Borough Park Community Council in Brooklyn last night adopted a resolution calling upon Mayor Koch and Police. Commissioner Robert J. McGuire to assign 40 more police officers to the area permanently.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle under which it would acquire all of the outstanding capital stock of the Telenet Corporation through a merger of a G.T.E. subsidiary into Telenet. The deal is valued at $59 million.

title: Vance Sees Israelis After Reporting Good Progress at Meetings in Egypt
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 11  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance flew to Israel tonight after reporting that he and President Anwar elSadat of Egypt had made good progress in resolving the remaining issues in the EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty negotiations.

title: City Urges U.S. to House Aged in Concourse Plaza
description: The days of sumptuous banquets and baseball victory celebrations were long gone, but four years ago  amid hopes of revitalization for the West Bronx  the city purchased the Concourse Plaza Hotel for $2.6 million with plans to transform it into a residence for the elderly.

title: Museum Conditions Are Destroying Artifacts
description: THOUSANDS of irreplaceable examples of the art and technology of vanishing human cultUres, housed in many of the country's leading science museums, are slowly deteriorating for lack of funds to give them proper care.

title: The City
description: A Federal District Court judge in Brooklyn refused yesterday to grant a motion by a parents group to have the Board of Education submit within 45 days a plan for the desegregation of the virtually allminority Andrew Jackson High School in Cambria Heights, Queens.

title: Events
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, Donizettl's Don Pasquale, 8.

title: Companies Report Earnings
description: For periodi as shown. (N) indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Excha nix, (A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: 7 Masked Thug's Get More Than $3 Million In Holdup at Kennedy
description: Seven masked men, brandishing shotguns and automatic pistols, drove up to a Lufthansa cargo facility at Kennedy International Airport early yesterday, handcuffed nine employees and beat up another, disconnected an alarm and made off with a reported $3 million in cash and jewelry worth possibly $2 million.

title: Israel Replaces Minton as Head of Putnam's
description: G.P. Putnam's Sons, established in 1838, changed presidents yesterday. Peter Israel, an editor and novelist who has been managing director, succeeds Walter J. Minton, head of the company since 1955.

title: Adelphi 67, Boston Univ. 65
description: BOSTON, Dec. 11 (AP)  Gordie McCrae scored 30 points, including the game winner, tonight and led Adelphi to a 6765 victory over Boston University. Gene Jones, a freshman, was B.U.'s high scorer with 14. The victory improved Adelphi's season record to 52 and dropped B.U. to 24

title: MasseyFerguson Is Pruning
description: TORONTO, Dec. 11  Earlier in the fall, when Victor A. Rice was named president of MasseyFerguson Ltd., the financially troubled farm implements giant, the first thing he did was to hold his head in his hands.

title: Age of the Uphill Skateboard
description: Just when it appeared that the skateboard set was finally off the streets and inside the rollerdiscos, along comes a new street toy straight out of the Indianapolis 500.

title: Treasures of Tut Glitter in Daylight
description: How do you convey the darkness of King Tut's tomb in galleries drenched with daylight? That was the problem faced by Stuart Silver, chief designer of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, who has just finished installing the Tutankhamen show for its Dec. 20 opening in the new Sackler Exhibition Hall at the Met.

title: Bengals Upset Rams, 2019
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 11 (AP) Chris Bahr's 42yard field goal with three minutes left in the game capped a Cincinnati rally tonight and gave the Bengals a 2019 National Football League victory over the playoffbound Los Angeles Rams.

title: Missouri Fire Kills 4 in Family
description: ELVINS, Mo., Dec. 11 (AP)  An explosion and fire, possibly caused by a recently installed wood heater, ripped through an eastern Missouri home and killed a sleeping family of four, officials said. The victims were Terry Strickland 31 years old; his wife, Billy Joe, 28; and their two sons, Terry Jr., 8, and Dale, 6.

title: A Speech on Socks
description: One subject of perennial interest to all persons, probably all persons save a few barefoot hundreds on the entire planet, is the mystifying metamorphosis of socks in the wash. It must happen everywhere, on the shores of Lake Titicaca and of Lake Chad, in Thule and Tierra del Fuego, this infinitely combining, infinite and unmatched. series of socks, this miscegenation of socks, this protean transformation, this creatio ex nihilo, this vaporization, sublimation, abduction and shabby substitution of outright changeling socks.

title: 5 N.F.C. Teams Battling for Final 3 Playoff Spots
description: At last there is some light at the end of the. tunnel that leads to the pro football playoffs. With the 16game regularseason coming to a close this weekend, the American Conference's five playoff representatives  Denver, Houston, Miami, New England and Pittsburgh  have been decided. In the National Conference, Dallas and Los Angeles have clinched their positions and five other teams  Atlanta, Green Bay, Minnesota, Philadelphia and Washington  are in contention for the three remaining spots.

title: The Symbol of Charlotte Street
description: The South Bronx has become a national symbol the physical ruin that follows the sharp industrial decline of older American cities. No force may be sufficient to reverse it. Nevertheless, President Carter last year stood on Charlotte Street, in the heart of one of the Bronx's most desolate areas, and pledged that the Federal Government would intervene to salvage the area and its people.

title: Market Place
description: IN 1975, when financially troubled New York City was unable to redeem its shortterm notes, the Municipal Assistance Corporation was created to give holders of those securities an option.

title: First Big Decisions of Congress: Which Members Get Best Offices
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP)  Now is the time that senior and powerful members of Congress assert their authority and make the first important decisions of the Congress that will formally enter the Capitol in January.

title: Soweto Guerrilla Suspects Held
description: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 11 (Reuters)  Several former students from Soweto, who were suspected of being trained outside the country as guerrillas, were arrested when they returned to South Africa during the last two weeks, the police said today. The security officers shot to death one of the suspects, Kenneth Mkhawanazi, when he seized a hand grenade, the police said.

title: Special Classes Help Gifted in Ghettos
description: OUTSIDE, there is a burnedout tenement, a symbol of a devastated innercity neighborhood. Inside, a teacher is working on algebra problems with a class of gifted children, preparing them for entrance to specialized high schools.

title: Norway to Quit Currency Plan
description: OSLO, Dec. 11 (UPI)  Norway said today that it was pulling out of the European currency system known as the snake and for the time being not joining the new European Monetary System.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: This morning, Anthony Morton Solomon will reach yet another milestone in a diversified financial career. At 9 A.M. today, in Frankfurt, he will be presiding as interest rates are set on a series of United States Treasury notes available only to West German residents. The offering is this Government's first financing in a foreign credit market, and caps a long GermanAmerican effort to help bolster the dollar.

title: Deaths
description: MEIRGoida. Americans for Progressive IsraelHashomer Hatzair mourns with great sorrow the passing of Goida Meir. BERNARD HARKAVY, President.

title: $375 Million Jersey Sport Issue Set
description: The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, which operates the Meadowlands thoroughbred and harness race track and the stadium where the Giants football and Cosmos soccer teams play, is selling more than $375 million of bonds this week to refinance some outstanding securities and to pay for additional facilities.

title: Beech Aircraft
description: The Beech Aircraf Corporation, the nation's secondlargest seller of general aviation aircraft after the Cessna Aircraft Company, reported profit gains and growth in commercial, international and defense/aerospace sales in fiscal 1978.

title: Black Leaders Pleased by Carter Response at Meeting
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11  Nine black leaders met with President Carter today and emerged after 40 minutes saying they were far more optimistic than a eimilar eroun did last week. The nine were told that the fate of social programs in the 1980 budget had yet to be determined.

title: Dance: New Baryshinkov
description: ELYSE BORNE and Mikhail Baryshnikov made their debuts as Sugarplum Fairy and Cavalier in the New York City Ballet's production of The Nutcracker  Sunday evening at the New York State Theater.

title: South Africa's Impulsive but Flexible New Prime Minister
description: CAPE TOWN, Dec. 11  When he succeeded John Vorster this summer as Prime Minister of South Africa, P.W. Botha provoked sharp anxieties among opponents of apartheid. He was widely depicted as the James Cagney

title: American Investment Resuming in Northern Ireland
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 11 (AP)  After an eightyear lull, United States companies are again investing in Northern Ireland, raising hopes of British Government officials that an economic lift may help end the chronic strife there.

title: TV: California Reich Visits West Coast Nazis
description: THE CALIFORNIA REICH, on WNET/13 tonight at 10, is another of those controversial presentations that raise troubling questions about access and freedom of speech. In this case, the subject is American Nazism, specifically the National Socialists White People's Party as seen through the eyes of several of its members in three California communities.

title: Ferguson Ties a Record With 5th Cowboy Title
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Dec. 11 (UPI)Tom Ferguson of Oklahoma, tied a world record yesterday by capturing the AllRound Cowboy title at the National Rodeo finals for the fifth consecutive year.

title: Hyatt Regrets Comments on S.E.C.
description: The Hyatt Corporation, which operates hotels and motels, said it regretted certain statements made by or attributed to it last week in connection with the announcement of the settlement of a Securities and Exchange Commission administrative proceeding.

title: Ferment In China
description: WASHINGTONRecent wall posters and minidemonstrations in Peking have stimulated some naive speculation about whether China is moving toward Westernstyle democracy. It is not.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Prices of gold futures were battered in a sudden late flurry of sell orders yesterday. This converted earlier gains of as much as $4 an ounce into losses averaging $1.40 at the close of the Comex in New York.

title: Theodore Douglas,82, Executive Of the I.T.T. Federal Laboratories
description: Theodore Miller Douglas, former vice president of the I.T.T. Federal Laboratories in Clifton, N.J., died Sunday at the Mountainside Hospital in Glen Ridge, N.J., after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

title: A Fair Trial Is More Important Than a Free Press, Judge Says
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Dec. 11 (AP)  A leadingMassachusetts judge says the right of criminal defendants to a fair trial must take precedence over freedom of the press when the two constitutional guarantees collide.

title: Gussow of Times Gets Nathan Award
description: Mel Gussow, a drama critic for The New York Times, has won the 197778 George Jean Nathan Award for Dramatic Criticism.

title: Civil Rights Unit Presses For Rights Amendment
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP)  The United States Civil Rights Commission argued today for adoption of the proposed equal rights amendment, saying that the 14 states that have passed their own versions of it have made substantial strides toward equality of men and women.

title: Issue and Debate
description: One of the major campaign promises of Mayor Koch, a promise that he reiterated emphatically in a recent interview,was to require workers on the municipal payroll to live in New York Citt.

title: Stage: Living at Home, One Man's Test of Reality
description: JOHN BOGLE, the college dropout who lives at home in Living at Home, suffers a good deal. Reality evades him.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Corporate bond prices declined yesterday as underwriters offering $100 million of Houston Lighting and Power Company bonds since last Wednesday decided to let the unsold portion  estimated at $50 million  trade freely in the secondary market.

title: Supreme Court Roundup
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11  The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a member of Congress can be prosecuted, for taking bribes in exchange for sponsoring or voting for bills and, if so, what kind of evidente the prosecution can present

title: Murdoch Is Close To Rangers' Deal
description: Don Murdoch, the Ranger forward who is renegotiating his contract even though he has been banned from playing for at least half the season, said yesterday his lawyer would be in New York today to try to make a deal with the club.

title: Botha, Stung by Scandal, Vows Wider Press Curbs
description: CAPE TOWN, Dec. 11 Prime Minister P.W. Botha of South Africa, his Government's credibility damaged by a political scandal uncovered largely by the antiapartheid press, said today that gossip mongering of the kind that characterized much of the reporting on the scandal would be curbed by legislation next year.

title: Sales Down, Profits Up For Japanese Companies
description: TOKYO, Dec. 11  For the first time in postwar Japan, corporate profits are growing fatter on declining sales. It may be too early to tell, but business analysts see the healthier profit margins as part of a new, timely and very unJapanese effort to put profit growth ahead of expanding sales.

title: IN THE NATION
description: JOHANNESBURG  He was a white professor at an Afrikaner university, proud of his work, fretting at his low academic salary, a bit stiff with an inquisitive visitor. But over a good lunch and a bottle of excellent South African white wine, he began to unbend. He realized, he said, that things in South Africa could not be kept as they were. Change had to come, should come. In fact, he said, leaning forward earnestly, I'm ready for total. integration with the coloreds and the Asians right now.

title: Crane and F.T.C. Staff In Accord on Medusa
description: The Crane Company, which owns 44 percent of the Medusa Corporation and plans to seek the rest of the cement maker, said yesterday it had reached agreement with the Federal Trade Commission staff to keep both companies separate.

title: RapidAmerican Exchanges Expire
description: The RapidAmerican Corporation announced that the company's two exchange offers, which had been extended to Dec. 8, had expired. The cornpany said that in response to the exchange offer to the common stockholders, tenders of about 930,000 shares had been received for which it is issuing about $15.5 million of its 11 percent subordinated debentures due 2005 and about 465,000 redeemable warrants expiring 1994.

title: $280 Million in Australian Coal Sold Under Controls
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 11  A $280 million coal export contract signed by the Americanowned Utah Development Company is being hailed by the Australian Government as a first vindication of the controversial exportcontrols program under which companies must get Government approval on negotiating limits before beginning sales talks.

title: About New York
description: The security guard had fallen asleep in the lobby, so all the two gunmen had to do was take his weapon, wake him gently and then go over to the night, clerk, Robert Shanley, and begin a pistolwhipping that was to last for a half hour.

title: Concert: Serkin Plays Schubert
description: SCHUBERT'S music is seldom ever absent from Rudolf Serkin's repertory. It was present in the pianist's annual Carnegie Hall program last night, probably less because everyone is honoring the 150th anniversary of the composer's death this year than because Mr. Serkin has such a natural affinity for it. The music he chose to play, however, was not from the largescale sonatas but rather the set of Four Impromptus in Opus 192. This formed the central portion of the evening, and while Brahms's fairly monumental Handel Variations were yet to come, the Schubert proved to be the dominating performance.

title: Violent Storms Sweep Portugal
description: LISBON, Dec. 11 (Reuters)  Two people were killed today in violent storms. A man and his daughter died when a tree crashed on their house at Penafiel in northern Portugal. From Oporto, in the north, to Lisbon, in the south, the police reported winds up to 80 miles an hour.

title: Lights Top 230 Park Avenue
description: Harry B. Helmsley, above, center, president of HelmsleySpear, Inc., was cited by Governor Carey for contributions to New York last night, as renovated tower at Park Avenue and 46th Street was renamed the Helmsley Building. Structure was refurbished, its famous clock and ornaments were gilded in gold leaf  and its spire has been given lights reminiscent of those on Empire State Building, also installed by Mr. Helmsley.

title: World News Briefs
description: MINEHEAD, England, Dec. 11 (Reuters)  The case against Jeremy Thorpe, the British politician charged with plotting the murder of a man who said he was Mr. Thorpe's lover, has been based on evidence provided by a mental case, the defendant's lawyer contended in court today.

title: Guyanese Official Is Haunted by Idyllic Memories of Visit
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 11Like many prominent members of the Guyana Government, Margaret Ackman, member of Parliament and parliamentary secretary of the ruling People's National Congress Party, had received many invitations to visit Jonestown. Fora long time, she refused.

title: While Iranians Demonstrate, Americans in Teheran Have Quiet Day
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 11  It was the quietest day that Gail Borden had spent in Teheran since arriving here three years and three months ago.

title: 100 Demonstrate for Grace Paley
description: Susan Sontag, the writer; Joseph Chaikin, the director, and other prominent intellectuals were among the 100 persons who demonstrated opposite the Federal Court House yesterday to decry the arrest and trial of Grace Paley, the writer, and 10 others who protested in Washington against nuclear weapons and power.

title: Cosmetic Surgery's New Image: No Longer Only for the Rich
description: Cosmetic surgery, the kind of operation performed to improve the patient's image, has traditionally carried its own tenacious image. Like RollsRoyces, emeralds and private planes, it has long been considered the prerogative of celebrities, jet setters and tycoons, or more precisely, wives of tycoons

title: Nancy Lopez Gets Trophy
description: Nancy Lopez, who earned $161,235 in her rookie season on the Ladies' Professional Golf Association tour, with trophy awarded to her yesterday by the L.P.G.A in Manhattan.

title: Nobody Ever Loves a Zebra
description: The Philadelphia Eagles were on the march in New Orleans and Gordon McCarter, the referee, didn't hurt their cause a bit by stepping off twe 15yard penalties against the Saints, one for piling on and one for unrefined use of a forearm. This was in the early days of the franchise, before the Saints began to win either football games or friends. Nevertheless, they were the home team and those dirty interfering officials were doing them wrong. By the time the Eagles made first and goal on the 8yard line, the boos and whistles were deafening.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Mixed
description: Yields were mixed on Treasury bills in the weekly auction yesterday in both the 91day and 182day maturities.

title: Banker Initiates Drive For State Referendums
description: A millionaire investment banker and son of the founder of a major Wall Street brokerage firm began a statewide effort yesterday to give New York's voters the rights of initative and referendum.

title: A School for the Successful
description: Columbia University announced its newest academic fellowship program yesterday, but instead of people like professors, it may attract a Greek peddler, say, who's made good in the fish business.

title: Prices of Christmas Trees Are Up 10%
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11  That old Scrooge called economics is prevailing over the Spirit of Christmas, and as a result you will pay more this year for your Christmas tree.

title: Koch Budget Cut Likely to Cover Hospitals, Prisons and Education
description: As Mayor Koch begins deciding what to cut to balance the budget, New York City officials say that the most severe reductions are likely to involve hospitals, mental health, education, higher education, probation and corrections.

title: Eastern Air Seeks National
description: In one of the most striking developments since airline deregulation began in October, Eastern Air Lines yesterday joined the scramble to take over National Airlines, offering $425 million.

title: Steel Output Increases 2.2%
description: Steel production rose 2.2 percent last week to 2.71 million tons from the previous week's 2.7 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The industry used 88.9 percent of its production capacity last week, up from 88.7 percent.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Protesters in Israel Seize West Germans' Offices
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 11 (AP)  Three Israelis took over the West German cultural center here today and seized a woman hostage but later treed their captive and surrendered to the police.

title: Deaths
description: BRAUERJerome Edward. Of Ta macra, Florida and 117 Pershing Road, Englewood Cliffs, N.J. Beloved husband of Frances (Mai). Devoted father of Theodore Robert, and Fatherinlaw of Diane. Loving brother of Minerva Brauer, Myrtle Miltonberg and Matilda Reier. Adored grandfather of five grandchildren. Services will be held at GuttermanMusicantKreitzman, corner of Passaic and Park Streets, Hackensack, on Tuesday. December 12 at 12 noon. The period of mourning will be observed at the residence in Englewood Cliffs.

title: Miss Kinney Takes Final In Squash Racquets Play
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 11  Kris Kinney, a Princeton sophomore who was the thirdranked college player in the nation last season, defeated a teammate, Nancy Gengler, in the final of the Princeton Invitation women's squash racquets tournament yesterday. The score was 715, 1510, 715, 1513, 176.

title: Rail Rate Rise Held to 7%
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP)  The Interstate Commerce Commission today awarded the nation's railroads a 7 percent overall freight rate increase, a key victory for President Carter's antiinflation program.

title: Tokyo Expense Accounts
description: TOKYO, Dec. 11 (Reuters)  Despite the pinch of recession, Japanese businesses spent a record $1.26 billion in 1977 on expenseaccount entertainment, the national tax agency said today.

title: Glamour and BlueChip Issues Lead Market Rise
description: Glamour and bluechip issues led the stock market higher yesterday as in vestors ignored such potential negatives as higher gold prices and weakness in the American dollar in foreigncurrency dealings.

title: Diplomats Become Werblin's Soccer Project
description: When the Cosmos played in obscurity under the Triborough Bridge in New York three years ago, the Washington Diplomats were hardly known outside of Fairfax. Va.

title: Kennecott Told To Hold Election
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation was ordered in Federal court in Manhattan yesterday to hold a new election of officers on Jan. 29.

title: New Congressman Gets a Message: Integrity Is Important
description: MUSKOGEE, Okla.  Jean Englebrecht was pleased. She had watched Mike Synar grow up and win 4H ribbons and play basketball and go off to college. After law school, he came back to Muskogee and joined his father's real estate and ranching business, and last month the voters of northeastern Oklahoma elected him to Congress.

title: Parole Board Says Giles Case Shows Failure of Criminal Justice System
description: The New York State Division of Parole has concluded that the case of a convicted killer suspected of slaying three women while on parole may be proven to be a failure of the parole system and the entire criminal justice system in New York, according to a 14page Parole Division report issued yesterday.

title: The Region
description: HARTFORD (AP)  The State Board of Education will outline to the legislature next month a proposal to lengthen the school day to six hours of actual school work, an increase of two hours.

title: U.S.O.C. Approves L.A. Plan
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Dec. 11 (UPI)  The United States Olympic Committee executive board has unanimously approved the major points in an agreement with the private sector in Los Angeles for the establishment of the 1984 Olympic Games Organizing Committee.

title: Frontiers: Genetics
description: THE chimeras of ancient Greek myth were nightmare creatures combining the most vicious attributes of mammals, birds and reptiles. Today scientists are producing real crossspecies combinations far more important in fact, although much less spectacular in appearance.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Labor Lobbyist Finds It's Time To Quit the Hill
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11  When Andrew J. Biemiller became chief lobbyist for the American Federation of Labor a quarter of a century ago, he received some succinct advice from the federation's president, George Meany.

title: Deaths
description: EGGERSTEDTEthel W. on Decernber 10, 1978 of West Islip, Lt. Be. loved wife of Fred; devoted mother of Susan Eggerstedt, Mary Schuster. and Kathy DeMaio; also survived by 5 grandchildren. Reposing at the Fredrick J. Chapey West Islip Funeral Home, Montauk Highway, West Islip. Services and funeral private.

title: EARNINGS
description: The Carrier Corporation, the world's largest airconditioner producer, which is battling a takeover bid by the United Technologies Corporation, yesterday reported a 45 percent jump in profits for the fourth fiscal quarter ended Oct. 31 and a 67 percent jump for the full fiscal year.

title: McMillian Deal Set By Knicks, Blazers
description: After a day of crosscountry telephone negotiations, the Knicks and Portland agreed last night on the compensation for allowing Jim McMillian to sign with the Trail Blazers as a free agent. The Knicks will receive Portland's secondround choice in the 1979 draft.

title: Coal Company Plans 1,600 Homes In Virginia to Attract New Miners
description: GRUNDY, Va., Dec. 11  One of the nation's major coal companies announced here today that it would invest $25 million in a 1,600family new town project on a mountain to lessen, in one remote corner of the Appalachian coal fields, a critical shortage of housing that has deterred jobhunters.

title: WEST IS NOW UNEASY ABOUT ARMS IN IRAN
description: Anxiety is developing in the Defense Department and in the American arms industry over the security of the advanced weapons that the United States has sold to Iran. The concern is shared by officials in Britain, which has also delivered advanced weapons to Iran.

title: L.I.R.R. Breakdowns Stall 65,000
description: Sixtyfive thousand commuters were delayed for up to 90 minutes during yesterday morning's rush hour because equipment and switching problems delayed the arrival of 76 Long Island Rail Road trains into Penn Station.

title: Deaths
description: ANDREWSOr George Clinton on December 9, 1978 at Key Biscayne, Fla. Husband of Hazel. Father of George, Richard, Pauline and Barbara. Also survived by 15 grandchildren. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell. Madison Ave at 81 St, 10AM until 10PM Tuesday with services at 10AM Wednesday.

title: Radio
description: 8:159 A.M., WQXR. The Pines of Rome, Respighi.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Economy

title: Trailer Truck Split Open On Bridge at 59th Street
description: The container of a tractortrailer truck was ripped open during the morning rush hour yesterday when it struck one of the steel girders on the outside lane of the Queensborough Bridge, at 59th Street. A load of paper towels cascaded onto the bridge and a street below.

title: 3 Rescued Off L.I. by Helicopter
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Dec. 11 (AP)Three men were rescued from a raft by helicopter today after their fishing boat sank in the Atlantic Ocean south of Shinnecock Inlet, the Coast Guard reported. The helicopter, dispatched from Cape Cod, Mass., picked up the men at 10 A.M., 90 minutes after they messaged that their boat; the Snoopy, was sinking about 80 miles south of the inlet.

title: A Carter News Parley To Be Held at 11 A.M.
description: President Carter will hold a news conference at 11 A.M. today that will be telecast live by the three networks and their local stations  Channels 2, 4 and 7.

title: Concert: The Apple Hill Players Begin a ThreeProgram Series
description: THE Apple Hill Chamber Players, a group that has given several successful concerts in New York in past seasons, began a threeprogram series at Carnegie Recital Hall on Sunday night. For reasons that probably related mostly to unfamiliarity with this intimate hall's extraordinarily resonant acoustics, the opening concert did not go as well as it might have in a space the musicians were familiar with.

title: Police Seize 6 Pickets In Protest at Cleanup Of Niagara Falls Site
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Dec.11 (UPI)  Six persons were arrested today as angry residents stepped up the pace of their picketing at the Love Canal cleanup construction site.

title: Chamber: A First for Live Series
description: FOR many years the words chamber music seemed to mean to the American musical public nothing more or less than four string players  probably the Budapest Quartet  knitting their brows over late Beethoven. But there is a great wide world outside that one, and the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center has contributed immensely to making that common knowledge during the 10 seasons of its existence. Like many a program by the society, the one performed Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall over a national television network dealt entirely in works that the Budapest could not have played without help.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, DEC. 11, 1978

title: Talking Business
description: Almost three months ago, President Carter signed the International Banking Act of 1978, possibly one of the most significant pieces of banking legislation in decades. The act attempts to remove some of the competitive inequities that previously existed between American banks and branches in the United States of foreign banks.

title: New Datsun Unveiled
description: MARCO ISLAND, Fla., Dec. H (UPI)  Nissan U.S.A., distributor of Japanesebuilt Datsun vehicles, today unveiled its latest entry into the American car market  a frontwheeldrive, twodoor hatchback subcompact. Nissan executives said that the new model, called the Datsun 310, came in two body styles, a sedan and GX coupe. Suggested retail prices begin at $4,829 for the sedan and $5,369 for the coupe.

title: Pop: Trio From Toronto With Computer
description: FRIDAY night's performance at the Kitchen by Maple Sugar, a Torontobased collective of performance artists, began promisingly enough. David Rosenboom, using a computerassisted electronic music system, presented a new composition, In the Beginning, that was full of ravishing effects.

title: Obituary 8 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 354.3900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 TO 4'30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201)MARKET 34900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 94300; NASSAU CO. (516)747.0500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 660.1600; CONNECTICUT (203)148.7767.

title: High Court Backs Veto for Fed on New Bank Holding Companies
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11  The Supreme Court has upheld the right of the Federal Reserve Board to block the formation of a bank holding company on the ground that it would be financially unsound, even if the Comptroller of the Currency has previously approved the move.

title: N.L.R.B., in Reversal, Sets Aside Contested Union Vote on Coast
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI)  The National Labor Relations Board, relying on the swing vote of a Carter appointee, has overturned a decision certifying a union representation election that involved accusations of trickery.

title: PROTESTERS MARCH FOR 2D DAY IN IRAN; VIOLENCE IS LIMITED
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 11  Several million Iranians filled the major streets of this country's cities and towns today to demonstrate their opposition to the Shah for the second day as Shiite Moslems celebrated the emotional high point of a solemn month of mourning.

title: New York Telephone Seeking $240 Million In Increased Charges
description: The New York Telephone Company applied yesterday for a new round of rate increases of up to $240 million, the maximum allowed under President Carter's antiinflation guidelines. It also asked for an automatic passalong to its customers of future wage settlements and tax increases.

title: Koosman Finally Heads Home, Ending a Met Era
description: Jerry Koosman, the last of those strong young men who pitched the New York Mets from rags to riches a decade ago, conceded that an era of sorts had ended when he was traded to the Minnesota Twins the other day. lt grabs me, he said.

title: Bellow Leaves Viking, Switches to Harper & Row
description: In a surprising move, the novelist Saul Bellow has switched to Harper & Row after nine books and 30 years with Viking Press. The Chicagobased Nobel laureate in literature plans to bring out his first book with his new publisher in 1980.

title: U.S. Urges Rise in Aluminum Capacity
description: The aluminum industry, experiencing one its biggest years of shipments and profits, has been prodded by the Government to increase its production capacity after having been caught short, especially in meeting the demand for rolled products.

title: Mirror Reflects Dreams of Young Dancers
description: Youngsters at New York's High School of Performing Arts in rapt attention at performance by Soviet dancers of the Bolshoi and Stanislavski Ballet Theaters.

title: Accepting Economic Dirty Talk
description: We now have a President who predicts that the best hope for the economy next year is, in effect, a growth recession. How times have changed. Eight years ago, to say growth recession was to talk dirty. Herbert Stein, President Nixon's chief economist, was furious when scholars at the National Bureau of Economic Research coined the phrase in 1970 to describe a period when the economy continues to grow, but so slowly that unemployment rises, production weakens and income and sales suffer. Mr. Stein hoped that year to avoid the stigma of a real recession  meaning a period of plummeting economic activity  and he did not want to be blamed for some new form of trouble, either. As it turned out, Mr. Stein was disappointed on both scores. The nation began that year in a growth recession and ended it in a genuine recession.

title: Agency Assails A.M.A. On School Accreditation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP)  The staff of the Federal Trade Commission today continued its attack on the American Medical Association, asserting that the organization had too great an influence over accreditation for medical schools.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI)  The Air Force today grounded its entire fleemore than 700 C130 Hercules transpor planes after a crash in which five crewmen were killed. Dozens of other coon tries that fly the planes were also notified.

title: Deaths
description: Andrews, George

title: Science Watch
description: Soviet anthropologists have discovered the remains of four interconnected dwellings that were built of animal skins stretched over mammoth bones more than 40,000 years ago by hunting and gathering peoples.

title: Fiedler Reported Fair After Limited Surgery
description: BOSTON, Dec. 11 (AP)  Arthur Fiedler, the Boston Pops conductor, was in fair condition after undergoing surgery tonight to correct problems that had been affecting his mobility and gait. a hospital spokesman said.

title: Religious Ferment in Iran: A Long History
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 11  On the 10th day of the Moslem month of Muharram in the year 680, one of the grandsons of Mohammed, Hussein, was killed at Karbala in the Iraqi dessert along with 90 relatives, children and friends.

title: TwoPart Symphony in a Debut
description: FROM time to time in every country and in every era, attempts are made to form musical groups whose reason for existence is to perform the music of contemporary composers. New York has seen many such brave ventures, but few have been more ambitious or more solidly backed than the American Composers Orchestra, which began its second season last night at Alice Tully Hall. No fewer than a dozen angels corporations, foundations and governmental agencies  were listed in the program book, and funds had even been secured to allow recording of the two newer works, Barney Childs's Concerto for Clarinet and Orchestra and Charles Wuorinen's TwoPart Symphony.

title: Bucknell 80. Cornell 65
description: LEWISBURG, Pa., Dec. 11 (AP) Al Leslie scored 22 points and Bob Barry added 20 to pace Bucknell to a 8065 victory over Cornell tonight.

title: State Payments to Private Schools for Cost of Required Testing Is Upheld
description: A special threejudge Federal court ruled in Manhattan yesterday that it was constitutional for New York State to reimburse private schools for the costs of required testing and recordkeeping.

title: Police Official Is Favored By Koch for Hospitals Job
description: Mayor Koch is expected to propose Joseph C. Hoffman, the first deputy police commissioner, to be the city's next hospitals chief at a special meeting this evening of the board of directors of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation.

title: Money
description: MONDAY. DEC. 11, 1978

title: New Jobs for Tune and Nichols
description: THE GRAND TOUR, the new musical trying out in San Francisco on its way to New York, has just added an extra passenger, the directorchoreographer Tommy Tune. According to one of the producers, he was brought aboard by his friend Joel Grey, the production's star, because the show needs some work.

title: Alexander Wetmore, ExSmithsonian Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  Dr. Alexander Wetmore, secretary of the Smithsonian Institution from 1995 to 1952 and an avian evolution specialist, died Thursday at his home in suburban Maryland. He was 92 years old.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: IT has been noted before that when it comes to the nomenclature of certain dishes in French cookery, things are, to borrow a line from Gilbert and Sullivan, seldom what they seem. An omelette norvegienne, or Norwegian omelet, is not an omelet but a baked Alaska ; a longue de chat, or cat's tongue, is a sweet pastry, and so are tuiles, or tiles.

title: Reverie in Memphis
description: An air of unreality hung over the Democratic Party meeting in Memphis last weekend. The midterm convention was a time for some to daydream that Senator Edward Kennedy was really Bobby, that Vice President Mondale was cast as Hubert Humphrey and that Jimmy Carter, despite protestations to the contrary, was Jerry Ford and would be drummed out of the party before the 1980 election.

title: Deaths
description: Adelsberg, Mark

title: Bulls 99, Warriors 94
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (AA)  Art's Gilmore sank four free throws in the final 48 seconds and Chicago's defense held tight to clinch the Bulls sixth consecutive victory, a 9994 decision over the Golden State Warriors tonight.

title: Carter Namibia Remarks Clarified
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  President Carter said today that South Africa had accepted the United Nations plan for SouthWest Africa, and that the next step was to find out whether the SouthWest Africa People's Organization would also accept it. Soon after he spoke, the White House and the State Department pointed out that the situation was quite different.

title: Transcript of President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: Following is a transcript of President Carter's news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:

title: Chess:
description: The difference between the way a computer plays the game and the way a human goes about it is considerable  a machine works primarily by quantitative processes, while a human uses qualitative, directed thinking.

title: Deaths
description: ADELSBERGMark. The passing of Mark, beloved husband, father, son and brother, is deeply grieved. Ser. vices Wed, Dec 13, 11:30AM, Park West Memorial Chapel, 115 W 79 St.

title: N.Y.R.A. Pursuing Nevada TV Hookup
description: Horseracing fanciers in Nevada gambling halls will be able to watch live telecasts from New York's thoroughbred tracks as they make legal bets, according to a plan being negotiated by the New York Racing Association.

title: Ashkenazy to Help Du Pr Fund
description: Vladimir Ashkenazy will give a piano recital in Carnegie Hall on Feb. 21 that will begin a series of concerts to support the Jacqueline du Pr Research Fund of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society in the United States.

title: Policeman Slain in San Juan
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Dec. 12 (UPI)  A militant proindependence group known as the Macheteros (Machete Wielders) has taken responsiblity for slaying a Puerto Rican policeman.

title: Consumer Spending Climbs 2%
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP)  Consumer spending rose 2 percent in November as shoppers spent more money at department stores, grocery stores and drug stores, the Commerce Department said today.

title: The Region
description: HARTFORD (AP)  The Connecticut Supreme Court has ruled that part of a statue of King George III, broken by Colonial patriots and thrown into swamp, belongs to the swamp's owner, not the man who found it.

title: Entertainment Events
description: DOSSIER $1 (French with English subtitles), directed by Michel Devilie, at the 8th Street Playhouse and Cinema Studio 1, Broadway and 66th Street.

title: 3 Rare Kitchens, Well Done
description: JULIA CHILD likes to walk around her kitchen  I don't care about time and motion and all of that, and I get my exercise crossing back and forth all the time.  while George Lang keeps steps to a minimum by having everything neatly compartmentalized into storage, food preparation, paperwork and eating areas. Pierre Franey likes hard quarry tile on the kitchen floor because it doesn't show dropped pieces of food; Julia Child finds that it hurts her feet. George Lane likes lots of stainless steel; Pierre Franey thinks it is too slick.

title: Profile of a Hockey Coach
description: The coach and general manager of the New York Rangers plays the violin, boxed for 10 years, loves Guy Lombardo's music, took a correspondence course in law, seldom drinks anything stronger than beer and thinks that as a player he probably was the first member of the Rangers to hold a card in the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and 92d Street.

title: For Thousands in Cairo, Homes ls a Tomb With the Dead
description: CAIRO, Dec. 12  For the last 29 years, Mohammed Mabrouk has coexisted with the dead in rentfree accommodations that many other Cairenes would envy. He and his wife have four rooms with electricity and an outside water faucet  and half a dozen eaves on the cool premises.

title: Carter Backs Playing The National Anthem
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  The national anthem stirs President Carter's feelings of patriotism and gives him a realization of what our nation stands for, he said at his news conference.

title: A Union Head Assails Meany for Attacks on Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP)  In a rare public display of division within the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, the head of a major union has assailed the federation's chief, George Meany, for his attacks on President Carter's antiinflation program.

title: Deaths
description: HOWARDChester, M.D. The staff of the Department of Medicine of the Beekman Downtown Hospital note with deep regret the passing of their colleague, Dr. Chester Howard. We extend to Dr. Howard's family our sincerest sympathies.

title: Opening the Door to Homeowning
description: The yearlong deadlock in Albany over interest rates is broken and mortgage money should soon be flowing again to aspiring homebuyers. The New York Assembly has raised the interest ceiling to 9 percent and authorized further periodic increases if rates on U.S. Treasury notes should climb. Foes of redlining also profited from the special session, gaining a stiff new ban against geographical discrimination by banks. Governor Carey and the Assembly leadership deserve credit for braving demagogic talk about the perils of higher interest rates and acting to revive the state's housing industry.

title: Companies Report Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange,(A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Carter's Clash With Kennedy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  In October 1976, Senator Edward M. Kennedy brought down the house at Boston College with a pitch for national health insurance in introducing Jimmy Carter, then the Democratic nominee for President. It was so compelling that the usually composed Mr. Carter, in thanking Senator Kennedy, called him the next Preside  , stopping just before finishing the word.

title: Norman Raeben, 77; Last Surviving Son Of Sholom Aleichem
description: Norman Raeben, last surviving son of Sholom Aleichem, the Yiddish writer, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home. He was 77 years old and lived at 444 Central Park West.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Deaths
description: BONDEREFSKYLouis. The Board of Directors of the New York State Credit Union League, District Pres. idents, League staff and credit union leaders throughout New York State mourn the passing of Louis Bonderefsky on Sunday, December 10. 1978. He is survived by his wife Annabelle. As an Honorary Director. Past League President and Managing Director of the League, Mr. Bonderefsky over the years always showed a deep compassion for his fellow man. His presence will be missed. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 100 W. 76 St, New York City at 2PM on Wednesday December 13th.

title: Bruins 7, Canucks 3
description: BOSTON, Dec. 12 (AP)  John Wensink enjoyed the first threegoal game of his N.H.L. career tonight to help the Boston Bruins score a 73 victory over the Vancouver Canucks.

title: Obituary 7 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 3:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. A.M. TO 4: 30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERM NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: World News Briefs
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, Dec. 13  President Park Chung Hee's political supporters appeared to be leading by a narrow margin today over opposition candidates in the first elections for the South Korean National Assembly held in six years.

title: Stress Tests: SelfReferrals
description: Your physician is likely to know where to refer you for an exercise stress test. In New York City, the following stress testing centers accept selfreferrals:

title: ChryslerFrance Prices Up
description: PARIS, Dec. 12 (AP)  ChryslerFrance, the French subsidiary of the Chrysler Corporation of the United States, said today that it would increase the prices of all its cars except the Itagheera model by an average of 3.3 percent, effective immediately.,, Citroen raised its prices by an average of 3 percent earlier this month and Peugeot by an average of 2.8 percent in November. The sale of the Chrysler subsidiary to PeugeotCitroen has been announced but is awaiting final Government approval.

title: Koch Gains Pledge on Water Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  Mayor Koch won a commitment today from a Presidential task force to insure that New York City and other urban areas get consideration in the distribution of Federal funds for watersupply systems.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: HAVING known and worked with Isaac Bashevis Singer, writes Eli Stolpner, I called to offer him my congratulations on winning the Nobel Prize.We got to talking about many things. Suddenly he inquired about my age. I gave him my age and I also told him I was a grandfather. Isn't it funny, he said, all the yinglach [kids] I know are all zaydes [grandfathers].

title: Officials Disagree on Effect of Restrictions on Secret Service Mission
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UPI)  The head of the Secret Service told Congress today that recent restrictions on domestic surveillance had hampered his agency's ability to protect the President's life, but a top Justice Department official disagreed.

title: GEORGE H. SALTZMAN
description: George H. Saltzman, honorary president of the Garment Center Synagogue, at 205 West 40th Street, died Monday at his home in Manhattan at the age of 89.

title: Rockies 4, Capitals 3
description: LANDOVER, Md., Dec. 12 (AP) Randy Pierce scored an unassisted breakaway goal at 12:04 of the third period, giving Colorado a 43 victory over the Washington Capitals tonight while ending the Rockies fivegame losing streak.

title: RAPE CASE APPEAL ARGUED IN ALABAMA
description: CULLMAN, Ala., Dec. 12  The Alabama Court of Criminal Appeals will be asked tomorrow to untangle a dispute by three national civil rights organizations over which should handle the appeal of a mentally retarded black man convicted of raping a white woman.

title: A Correction
description: In the Nov. 29 edition of The Living Section, a recipe for preserved quince with ginger gave an incorrect quantity of water. The correct amount is five cups.

title: 105 Shops Revitalizing San Francisco Pier
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12  East of Fishermart's Wharf on the northern waterfront here is a new complex of 105 shops and 23 food outlets that is revitalizing that area, providing thousands of jobs for local residents and creating new payroll and property tax revenue for the city.

title: DONORS TO NEEDIEST SAY IT'S JOY TO GIVE
description: The message was as cheery as the letterhead on which it was printed. Morgan C. Mitchell and his wife, Elizabeth P., of the East Side sent a gift of $100 to the 67th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. They wrote.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Treasury borrowed up to $1.5 billion worth of marks in an offering of bonds to investors in West Germany. Proceeds of the issue, the Treasury's first in a foreign currency, are to be used to buy unwanted dollars whenever the American currency comes under heavy selling pressure in foreignexchange markets. The issue consists of threeyear notes yielding 5.95 percent and fouryear notes yielding 6.20 percent. [Page A1.]

title: Economic Scene
description: THE internecine battle in Memphis among Democrats over President Carter's proposed inflationary budget for the 1980 fiscal year has undoubted political importance in disclosing the split within the party between the conservative and the liberal wings. But the economic significance of the battle of the budget in the war against inflation during the coming year is slight.

title: Ford Lifts Its Prices Of Big Cars
description: DETROIT, Dec. 12 (AP)  Faced with Federal fuel standards it says it can barely meet, the Ford Motor Company today increased prices of its big cars to hold down demand.

title: Toys Made in Jonestown on Sale
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 12 Christmas shoppers at one of Guyana's big department stores are being offered colorful stuffed animal toys for children made months ago for the bollday season by the residents of Jonestown.

title: Portuguese Parliament Approves New Cabinet
description: LISBON, Dec. 12 (AP)  The National Assembly voted approval today of Portugal's third Government this year, turning down a bid by the Communist Party to reject it.

title: Navy to Close Base on Barbados After Year of Talks Prove Futile
description: BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, Dec. 12 (Reuters)  The United States will close its naval facility in Barbados after 22 years of operation.

title: Kentucky Called a Disaster Area
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (Reuters)President Carter declared Kentucky a major disaster area today because of severe storms and flooding last week. The declaration permits the use of Federal funds in relief and recovery efforts.

title: Personal Health
description: ORDINARILY, the idea of being on a treadmill implies a highly undesirable way of living, but today growing thousands of Americans are choosing to spend a brief time on a medical treadmill as a way of testing the strength and resilience of their hearts.

title: Late Islander Goals Deadlock Kings, 55
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Dec.12  Improbably, with a desperation forced on them by a gritty Los Angeles team, the Islanders salvaged a 55 tie tonight by stroking home two goals in the final three minutes after blowing a 30 lead.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Dolls in Touch With Reality

title: Soviet Assails Mock U.N. Session
description: GENEVA, Dec. 12  A student version of the United Nations General Assembly was barred from the Palais des Nations here today after its opening session yesterday led to a Soviet protest.

title: Bucks Turn Back Suns; Johnson Gets 40 Points
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 12 (AP) Marques Johnson scored a careerhigh 40 points tonight as the Milwaukee Bucks, snapping a fourgame losing streak, defeated the Phoenix Suns, 120114.

title: President Cites Good Progress In Arms Parley
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  President Carter said today that good progreis had been made in talks with Moscow on a new agreement limiting strategic arms, but that additional negotiating problems had to be resolved before a meeting with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, could be scheduled.

title: Columbia's Late Charge Downs St. John's, 9077; Byrd Scores 26
description: Buddy Mahar of Columbia and Lou Carnesecca of St. John's were at the opposite ends of the Lions basketball court last night. Emotionally, they were also at the opposite ends.

title: Reading Iran's Next Chapter
description: TEHERAN. Iran, Dec. 12  In the last 10 days, the opponents of Shah Mohammed Rita Pahlevi have demonstrated that even the edicts of a military Government, backed by sophisticated weapons from the factories of Britain and the United States and the Soviet Union. cannot halt the Momentum of their protests.

title: Felec Gets Contracts
description: Felec Services, a subsidiary of the Federal Electric Corporation, said had been awarded two threeyear contracts valued at a total of $273 million for the operation, maintenance and logistical support of earlywarning systems in the Far North. Federal Electric is a unit of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

title: Reich Music Foundation To Aid Other Composers
description: The Reich Music Foundation, heretofore known for its presentations of the music of Steve Reich, has branched out into the production of concerts by other avantgarde composers, many of them associated with Mr. Reich's ensemble of musicians.

title: People's Temple Lives On In Villa in Guyana's Capital
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 12 Except for the huge aluminum antenna sprouting from its roof, the pale yellow yilla on the eastern edge of town looks no different from its neighbors.

title: Kenya's Political Detainees Freed
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 12  President Daniel arap Moi announced today the release of all political detainees in Kenya, a group of 16 persons that includes three former members of Parliament and the country's best known novelist.

title: Best Buys
description: IF an American, through some act of magic, could shop for food in different countries instead of simply in different neighborhood stores, he would surely stay away from Tokyo. Last month, a pound of sirloin there cost $15.87 and a pound of butter $3.39.

title: Carter Deplores Agitation Against Shah From Outside
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  President Carter called today for an end to the uncontrolled statements made from foreign nations that he said had encouraged the violence in Iran.

title: Deaths
description: EVANSAnne Woodrow. Of Princeton New Jersey, age 10, on Monday December 11, 1978. Mother of Raymond J. Woodrow of Princeton & Richard H. Woodrow, deceased. Service & interment private.

title: Bolshbi to Dance in U.S.
description: The Bolshoi Ballet will appear at the New York State Theater for four weeks beginning next Aug. 1. The engagement was announced yesterday by representatives of Columbia Artists Management and Nederlander Productions, which will copresent the company.

title: Ad Agency Head Charged
description: The hoard chairman of a Manhattan advertising concern was indicted yesterday in connection with a Federal inquiry into embezzlements from REA Express Inc. He is the 13th person charged since the carrier went bankrupt in 1975.

title: Indiana Group In Merger Pact
description: The National Distillers and Chemical Corporation and Indiana Group Inc. said they had reached a definitve agreement to merge. They had previously announced a similar agreement in principle.

title: Big Coast Ranch Sale
description: The Newhall Land and Farming Company has disclosed that it has entered into a preliminary agreement for the sale of its 14,700acre Gill Ranch in the San Joaquin Valley in California for $22.5 million in cash before the end of its fiscal year on Feb. 28. James F. Dickason, president, and chief executive officer, said the sale, if consummated, would net Newhall $10.8 million, or $2.39 a share. He said the prospective buyer was the Foxdune Corporation of New York and that a subsidiary of the Getty Oil Company planned to subsequently acquire the Gill Ranch property from Foxdune in an arrangement whereby Foxdune would acquire a Getty property in New York City. Newhall is one of California's largest landresources companies.

title: Drop Is Forecast In Senior Classes At High Schools
description: A draft report by the State Educhtion Department projects a 28 percent decline in the numberof students who will graduate from New York City, high schools in the next decade. The report also predicts that black students will soon reptace white students as the majority members of the graduating classes.

title: Rutgers Wins in Overtime
description: Rutgers survived a late Manhattan College rally and beat the Jaspers, 6260, in overtime in a New JerseyNew York Met 7 basketball game at the loser's court last night.

title: Quebec Leashing a Hydro Giant
description: JAMES BAY, Quebec  The water has already begun to gather in the first reservoir. By this time next year, the dikes will be in place, the dams ready, the rivers in new beds. And then the power  an enormous outpouring of hydro power  should start surging south to Montreal. and even to New York, 1,300 miles away.

title: Topics
description: While attention is focused this week on the Metropolitan Museum's opening of the Treasures of Tutankhamun  an event of as much interest to students of crowd phenomena as to Egyptologists  we offer a ,continuing report on Cleopatra's Needle, Central Park's resident 3,500yearold Egyptian artifact that stands just behind the museum: It has been melting away since its arrival from Alexandria in 1883, but New York's polluted air is not entirely to blame.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows of the past week (Monday. Dec. 4, to Sunday. Dec. 10). listed according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets.

title: Elizabeth's Iran Visit in Doubt
description: LONDON, Dec. 12 (Reuters)  Queen Elizabeth will not make a planned visit to Iran in February unless the situation there improves, Prime Minister James Callaghan said today in Parliament. A stop in Iran had been scheduled as part of a threeweek Mideast tour.

title: Advertising
description: ALL you jingle fans out there who have come to know and love When you go places, the showplaces are Sheraton are out of luck. The song is being replaced.

title: Around the Nation
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 12  Dr. Peter Bourne, President Carter's former chief adviser on drug abuse, met for two hours today with members of the Georgia Composite Board of Medical Examiners here, answering questions about the disclosure that he wrote a prescription to a fictitious person in July.

title: World Gold
description: TUESDAY, DEC. 12, 1978

title: Minaki's 2 Time Zones
description: Hajime Minaki has been elected president and a director of Nomura Securities International Inc., the United States subsidiary of the Nomura Securities Company, which has been described as the Merrill Lynch of Japan. Nomura has 102 branches in Japan, 23 branches around the world and $1.4 billion in equity capital.

title: $3 Million in Counterfeit Bills Seized in Attic
description: Police in North Haven, Conn., working with the Secret Service, seized about $3 million in counterfeit $20 bills yesterday at the home of Joseph Willis, an yearold man who, authorities said, passed the bills at local fastfood establishments. Mr. Willis was arrested Monday at a Burger King in Ansonia, Conn., and the bogus notes, plus plates for making $20, $50 and $100 dollar bills, were recovered later. A search is continuing for possible accomplices.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 13, 1978

title: Tut Tickets Advertised By Scalpers
description: An executive of the Metropolitan Museum of Art said yesterday that improper scalping of tickets to the Met's Tutankhamen exhibition had been going on for two months and that there were reports of tickets, originally available for as little as 60 cents, being resold for $15 or more.

title: Pioneer Will Raise Funds for Met Again
description: Pioneer High Fidelity, a leading marketer of audio components, will repeat next year its 1977 fundraising campaign in behalf of the Metropolitan Opera. In the earlier drive, Pioneer enlisted the help of its employees and of newspapers and periodicals in getting contributions for the Met from the public. This amounted to approximately $70,000, which was then matched by Pioneer and further enlarged by a special grant from the National Endowment for the Arts. More than $275,000 was finally turned over to the Met as a result.

title: U.S. Borrows West German Marks In New Move to Bolster the Dollar
description: BONN, Dec. 12  The United States; borrowed West German marks today for use in currency markets to support the international value of the dollar.

title: Affirmed by a Nose As Best Horse of '78
description: Unable to catch Seattle Slew on the race track, Affirmed defeated him at the ballot box yesterday in the annual Eclipse Award voting for horse of the year.

title: Saturnalia: A Feast Fit for a Roman God
description: CATULLUS described the Saturnalia as the merriest festival of the year, and Seneca reported that all Rome seemed to go mad on this holiday. The Saturnalia, named for Saturnus, an ancient agricultural deity, began on Dec. 17. It is almost certain that the holiday was started to commemorate the end of the autumn sowing season in southern Italy.

title: Miss Hearst Feels No Blame For Her Actions With the S.L.A.
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Dec. 12 (AP)Patricia Hearst, drawing a distinction between herself and her actions as the radical Tapia, says she feels no responsibility for her conduct after her kidnapping by the Symbionese Liberation Army.

title: Don't Count on Metrics
description: IF you've been waiting with dread as the metric system marches inexorably toward a total invasion of the nation, relax. It may not be marching so relentlessly after all.

title: NEW STRIFE SWEEPS IRAN'S SECOND CITY
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 12  Opponents of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi attacked on two fronts today with bloody demonstrations in Isfahan, Iran's secondlargest city, and a big strike in the southern oilfields that reduced production to a nearrecord low for the year.

title: Bridge:
description: The American Contract Bridge League. which governs the duplicate game in North America, has a fulltime professional staff headed by an executive director, Richard Goldberg, and based in Memphis. Policy decisions, however, are made by a 25member board of directors, which annually elects one of its number as president.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  Senator Edward Kennedy of Massachusetts continues to impress and even to haunt the Democratic Party, hot only because he is a Kennedy but because he has developed into one of the few really eloquent public speakers in American political life today.

title: Tending A Garden Of Herbs
description: BUCKDEN, ENGLAND AN herb garden, formally arranged on traditional Elizabethan lines, has opened in the middle of rural England. It is called the Hoo, an AngloSaxon word meaning simply a piece of ground, and is attached to a modest manor house in the Cambridgeshire village of ,Buckden, close to the main LondontoScotland Al Highway.

title: A Criticized Assistant In Labor Dept. Quits But Another Remains
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall announced today the resignation of a highranking assistant whose performance had been criticized by the White House but gave a vote of confidence to another top aide who had been similarly criticized.

title: Enrollment Drop's Fallout
description: Educators who have learned in recent years how to live with cutbacks in their budgets now find themselves wrestling with a shortage of another kind: students.

title: TV: Jane Alexander Back In Biography of Teacher
description: AS an actress, Jane Alexander is seemingly incapable of making a wrong move or hitting a false note. In the area of television alone, going from Eleanor Roosevelt in Eleanor and Franklin to a teacher of special children in A Circle of Children to a lesbian mother in the recent  A Question of Love, her career has encompassed unusual variety and a distinctive element of dignified assurance.

title: 21 Passengers Hurt in Derailment On IND at Columbus Circle Station
description: Twentyone subway riders were injured last night when a southbound Eighth Avenue local carrying 100 passengers jumped the tracks just south of the Columbus Circle59th Street station and slammed into the tunnel wall, ripping open two of the train's eight cars.

title: Rudel Ready to Leave Top City Opera Post; Miss Sills Will Step In
description: Julius Rudel, director of the New York City opera since 1957, is expected to announce his resignation at a meeting of the city opera board this morning. His duties will terminate June 20, 1979, and on July 1, the celebrated soprano Beverly Sills will take over as director.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HOME SWEET ROW It seems only right that one of the Big Apple's most cherished blocks should festively shine for Christmas.

title: INQUIRY ON DEATHS STARTING IN GUYANA
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 12 A coroner's jury, sitting at the remote northwest community of Matthews Ridge, will begin an investigation tomorrow to determine whether any of the 909 deaths at Jonestown on Nov. 18 constitute murder under Guyanese law.

title: Hong Kong Gets a Carnival
description: HONG KONG Some guests came to the haunted Gothic castle overlooking the South China Sea in their RollsRoyces. Some came on a boat. But the host and hostess for the masquerade extravaganza arrived in a rainbowcolored hotair balloon flown in from Australia.

title: Simpsons Bid Raised
description: TORONTO, Dec. 12  The bitter struggle for control of the Simpsons department store chain heated up again today when corporatecousin SimpsonsSears Ltd. sweetened its earlier takeover offer for Simpsons to match a competing bid from its archrival, the Hudson's Bay Company.

title: Piano: Blackshaw Debut
description: CHRISTIAN BLACKSHAW'S piano recital Monday night was not really typical of the debuts at Carnegie Recital Hall. For one thing, Mr. Blackshaw had better credentials and gave a better recital than the majority of such debutants. For another, his appearance attracted a more sophisticated crowd of piano fanciers than the customary friends and relatives of the artists who fill up the hall on such occasions.

title: Beaumont Theater Will Reopen With a 5Member Directorate
description: Lincoln Center is planning to reopen the Vivian Beaumont Theater late next year or early in 1980 under a new fivemember directorate consisting of Woody Allen, Sarah Caldwell, Liviu Ciulei, Robin Phillips and Ellis Rabb, with Edward Albee as company playwright. Each of the direct6rs will stage at least one play every two seasons. Both the 1,100seat Beaumont and the 299seat Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater have been dark since August 1977, after Joseph Papp and his New York Shakespeare Festival withdrew from being the theatrical constituent at Lincoln Center.

title: The City
description: Justice Hortense Gabel of State Supreme Court, rejecting a challenge by the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, has ruled that recent amendments to the Financial Emergency Act are constitutional.

title: Food Talk: Smart Gadgets And Wok News
description: The popup toaster made obsolete by the toaster oven. The electric coffee pot superseded by the automatic drip machine. Cooking turned into processing by the microwave oven. And now the blender, that old standby so recently pushed aside by the food processor, has been oneupped again. The new version has gone space age, been computerized, turned into a blender with a brain.

title: Santa, You Forgot Handcuffs
description: DOWNERS GROVE, Ill.Shopping for toys is'a depressing experience for many parents. Each Christmas season offers more of the same: toys the parents have to assemble, toys the parents have to fix, toys the parents have to play with and toys the parents have to pick up.

title: Cancer Society Names FundDrive Chairman
description: The New York City division of the American Cancer Society has named William S. Cook. president of the Union Pacific Railroad Company, as chairman of its 1979 fundraising campaign.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Trading on the Chicago Board of Trade moved at a leisurely pace yesterday, with few notable trends.

title: Many Will Be Shifted in 911 ShakeUp
description: One hundred and twentyone civilian employees of the New York City Police Department's 911 operation  a fourth of the unit's total nonuniformed personnel  will be transferred out in a Major new effort to improve the performance of the problemplagued emergency telephone number system.

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY, DEC. 12, 1978

title: Choosing a Game People Will Play.
description: AFAMOUS English aphorism on the subject of education, Boys are always reasonable. teachers sometimes, parents never, can be applied in a modified form to the subject of Christmas games. The boys, or girls, or adults young in spirit, who between them constatute the consuming market, are always reasonable: If by their standards a game is worth playing repeatedly, they will persevere and it may be added to the small store of perennial favorites. If it has some transient appeal it will while away a few Christmas hours. And many a trivial box selected by some wellmeaning relative will never emerge from the closet.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch of The Associated Press, printed in The Times yesterday, erroneously described King Hussein of Jordan as a member of the Shiite branch of Islam. King Hussein is a Sunni Moslem. The two branches differ as to the legitimate line of succession to the Prophet Mohammed.

title: Warner Cable Bid
description: The Warner Cable Corporation, a subsidiary of Warner Communications Inc., has entered an agreement to acquire the cable television system of Coaxial Communications, and other companies related to the system in the Columbus, Ohio, area, Gustave M. Hauser, chairman and chief executive officer, announced. Mr. Hauser said that the transaction included a payment by Warner of cash and notes. About 32,000 subscribers are served by the Coaxial system. Hauser, chairman and chief executive officer, announced. Mr. Hauser said that the transaction included a payment by Warner of cash and notes. About 32,000 subscribers are served by the Coaxial system.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Gay Power Here
description: Harvey Milk was shot and killed in San Francisco on Nov. 27 by Dan White. Mr. White also shot and killed Mayor George Moscone. Mr. Moscone wasn't homosexual. Harvey Milk was. He was the first openly acknowledged homosexual ever to be elected to the San Francisco Board of Supervisors, in a city with a homosexual population that is large but not so large as New York's.

title: HighGrade State Bonds Sell Slowly
description: Highestgrade state bonds were offered for sale yesterday at the most generous taxfree yields available to investors since last July, but the securities did not sell rapidly. The performance seemed to indicate that interest rates are headed still higher.

title: Dr. Edith Jacobson, 81 Years Old, A Psychoanalyst and Professor
