description: Dr. Edith Jacobson, a psychoanalyst, died Dec. 8 in Rochester. She was 81 years old.

title: Chamber: SiYo Series
description: THE SiYo chamber concerts have been a fixture at the Schimmel Center for the Arts at Pace University for a number of years, but Monday night, the SiYo musicians traveled uptown to the Beacon Theater for the first in a projected series of three concerts. The move proved to be a notaltogetherhappy one.

title: Washington Plans Paris Festival
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  The Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, in conjunction with the French Government, announced today a French festival for the spring.

title: Market Place
description: THE Masonite Corporation, long in the stock market doldrums, appears to be getting more attention as investors speculate on the value of the company's substantial timberlands.

title: Goldin Accuses Transit Agency On Bus Repairs
description: The maintenance of New York City buses is so bad that on some days more than onethird of the 4,500bus fleet is out of service, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin charged yesterday after an audit of the bus systems.

title: Can't Meet 7% Target, Japan Says
description: TOKYO, Dec. 12 (UPI)  Japan acknowledged today that it could not meet the 7 percent economic growth target pledged by former Prime Minister Takeo Fukuda at the economic summit meeting of the nonCommunist industrialized nations last July.

title: Castro Prisoners Arrive As a Split in Exiles Rises
description: MIAMI, Dec. 12  A group of 70 freed Cuban political prisoners with 107 relatives arrived here today, the latest beneficiaries of a CubanAmerican dialogue that has caused a bitter split in this city's Cuban exile community and is stirring grim memories of the Castro revolution.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PIANCAVALLO, Italy, Dec. 12 (AP)  Hanni Wenzel of Liechtenstein survived a melting track, rain and fog to win the first World Cup women's giant slalom race of the season today.

title: Notes on People
description: To many he is the epitome of oldline, AngloSaxon New York, but let others be perplexed if they wish. title: Air France Sees Concorde Loss
description: PARIS, Dec. 12 (AP)  Air France, the French national airline, said today that it expected operation of its Concorde supersonic airliners to show a loss of 86 million francs ($19.3 million) in 1978, up from an earlier forecast of 32 million francs ($7.19 million).

title: Deaths
description: SALTZMAN  George. The Officers and members of The Sisterhood mourn the Passing of the Honorary and Past President of the Garment Center Congregation. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. He was a cherished and devoted member. His faith, loyalty and love of all aspects of our Congregation was an inspiration to all. In lieu of flowers contributions, to the Garment Center Congregation in his memory will be appreciated. Services at the Garment Center Congregation, 205 W 40 St, Wed, Dec 13, at 12 Noon. May Weisman, President Victoria Solitar, Vice President

title: Survey Indicates the German SelfImage Is More Wish Than Reality
description: BONN  Everyone knows that the Germans are reliable, efficient and clean. They say so themselves.

title: Private Lives
description: FOOD has almost never done for Dmitri what it did for Marcel in Swarm's Way, He has a past, of course, but it seems not to be associated with taste and smell, with batches of cookies and cups of tea. It is more like a bunch of traffic tickets in the glove compartment of the Eigenwelt, waiting to remind him of the places he has parked. A bar of music, an old poem, a woman's shoulder are his usual keys to this compartment. And so what happened the other day was a surprise.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: CAMBRIDGE, MASS.Big guns are firing at the Carter Administration's policy in Southern Africa. We are being told that it embraces radical farces instead of creating moderate alternatives and that it plays into the hands of the Russians and Cubans, who are arming the radicals. The Administration, the critics say, foments war between blacks and whites and fails to stand up to the Reds.

description: BASKETBALL

description: 1 rrecipe for sponge for rye bread (see ecipe)

title: Chrysler Plans Plant Closings
description: DETROIT, Dec. 12 (UPI)  The Chrysler Corporation, moving to reverse a financial decline and trim stockpiles of slowselling cars, saysit will temporarily shut down three assembly plants next month and lay off 15,700 workers, some indefinitely.

title: Lafleur and Dryden Star As Canadiens Rout Blues
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 12 (AP)  Guy Lafleur, the National Hockey League's scoring leader, scored three goals for the 10th time in his career to support Ken Dryden in his 39th shutout as the Montreal Canadiens defeated the St. Louis Blues. 60. tonight.

title: VANCE WINS BACKING OF SADAT ON MOVES TO BREAK DEADLOCK
description: CAIRO, Dec. 12  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance obtained tentative approval tonight from President Anwar elSadat for a new formula to resolve the remaining issues in the EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty.

title: Free Helps Clippers Beat Knicks, 105103
description: San Diego is a long way from Howard Park, the Brownsville Recreation Center and P.S. 32 in Brooklyn, where the 360degree spindunk shot is often a way of life. Lloyd Free grew up in that neighborhood and proclaimed himself AllWorld.

title: Mrs. Belmont, Arts Patron, Celebrating 100th Birthday
description: Today 101 red roses will be delivered to the home of Eleanor Robson Belmont, a gift from the personnel of the Metropolitan Opera. It is Mrs. Belmont's 100th birthday  the extra rose is for her next year.

title: ExConsul in Guyana Cleared of Sect Charge
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (Reuters) The State Department said today that its former consul at the United States Embassy in Guyana had been cleared of charges that he had been sexually compromised by members of the People's Temple cult.

title: Brooks Brothers Plans Stores in Japan
description: Brooks Brothers, the oldestablished New York retail chain, which despite fashion ups and downs continues to offer American males naturalshoulder clothing and buttondown shirts, is going overseas for the first time, with a plan to open a series of Brooks Brothers stores in Japan in a joint venture with a Japanese company.

title: ManEating Tiger Killed in India
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 12 (AP)  A tiger reported to have eaten six men and woman in northern India has been killed, a newspaper says. The Statesman reported a wildlife warden tracked the animal and killed it recently near Gala village about 560 miles east of here.

title: ANGOLA SAID TO AIM FOR LINK WITH WEST
description: LUANDA, Angola, Dec. 12  Signs of movement by Angola's Marxist regime in its search for openings to the West are accumulating, gradually and unevenly but with a fairly clear direction, European diplomats here said today. The latest was a welcome for Senator George McGovern, who arrived late last night and was to be received tomorrow by President Agostinho Nieto.

title: Movie: 'Dossier 51,' Study in Infiltration:Invasion of Privacy
description: MICHEL DEVILLE's new French film, "Dossier 51," is the sort of movie that's more interesting to talk about than to sit through. Its method is more intellectual than emotional or dramatic, which is not to say that it's as profound as it is arid. The movie, which was shown at this year's New York Film Festival, opens today at the 8th Street Playhouse and the newly partitioned Cinema Studio 1."Dossier 51" is an adaptation by Mr. Deville and Gilles Perrault of Mr. Perrault's novel about the activities of an unidentified intelligence agency as it seeks a possible candidate to infiltrate an international trade organization. The agency, which could be the Central Intelligence Agency or some, such group, picks on a young French diplomat and then, with the help of just about every surveillance device developed by man, studies its fellow to find ways in which he might possibly be blackmailed. He is followed, as is his wife, and his wife's lover; his apartment is bugged, as is his wife's lover's apartment; his activities are filmed whenever feasible; his friends, family and servants are questioned, and sometimes sexually seduced; his childhood is examined and analyzed for character defects until, at last, the agency gets the goods on the poor man.In an attempt to dramatize this terrifying invasion of privacy, Mr. Deville has sought out a cinematic equivalent to the method of Mr. Perrault's novel, which told the story through official reports and memorandums that kept the subject of the investigation at several removes from the reader. Mr. Deville does more or less the same thing, composing the movie entirely of secret films, tape recordings, written and oral reports of agents who write and talk in the jargon of their trade.The idea is more sound in theory than in practice, because it's virtually impossible to see any difference between what are supposed to be secret films and the visualized verbal reports that are presented to us. Mr. Deville's intention that this method will somehow implicate all of us in the audience as voyeurs overlooks the fact that all movies effectively implicate the members of the audience as voyeurs. It's one of the ways in which fiction works."Dossier 51" thus is more cinematically tricky than psychologically shocking. It's not only that we're all fairly well aware of the awful possibilities of electronic surveillance and the uses to which it may be put  Francis Ford Coppola's "The Conversation" dramatized this nightmare far more eerily  but that Mr. Deville's agents (unseen except in mirrors or films-within-the-film) are so clever and resourceful that there's never any suspense in the movie. It's a butterfly hunt. We don't especially care about the victim, about the agents, or even about their methods, which, unfortunately, no longer have the power to astonish.There are further technical problems. Actors playing directly to the subjective camera tend to become extremely self-conscious. The method of the movie never allows us or them to forget the camera. There is a single dramatic scene in the entire film, when an undercover agent interview's 51's (code name for the victim) mother and she spills the beans about her son's true parentage and some sad details about her own life. Franoise Lugagne, who plays the mother, creates the one living character in the film, but Mr. Deville, apparently knowing that he had a good thing going here, allows the scene to go on so long that it finally undercuts not only Miss Lugagne, but everything else in the picture.The movie takes a small boy's delight in the jargon and syntax of the spy trade. People, things and operations are all called by their code names (Jupiter, Minerva, 51, 52, 52B, Zephyr, Dead Leaves, etc.) to such an extent that one wishes one had been equipped with a lexicon on entering the theater. Much of the film is in French with English subtitles, but the soundtrack narration and the conversation of the unseen agents are presented in an English that sounds as if it had been written and recorded by Martians.

title: Vietnam Denies It Is Fostering Exodus
description: GENEVA, Dec. 12  Vietnam denied today, that it was fostering an exodus of its citizens in fishing boats in return for payments. The allegation, based on refugee accounts, had been made by Australia and Britain at a conference on Indochinese refugees held here under United Nations auspices: The. twoday meeting ended inconclusively today.

title: Casino Suspends Executive
description: Resorts International yesterday suspended Seymour Alter, its director of realestate operations, who had been charged with trying to bribe a judge and with procuring paid female companions for public officials.

title: CARTER SAYS PARTY HAS NOT BEEN SPLIT BY KENNEDY'S VIEWS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  President Carter asserted today that his differences with Senator Edward M. Kennedy did notsignal a widening schism within the Democratic Party and told a news conference that his belttightening fiscal policies had the support of a majority of Democrats.

title: Staubach to Sit Out Jets Game on Sunday
description: The Dallas Cowboys play the Jets at Shea Stadium Sunday and Coach Tom Landry is going to let his star quarterback. Roger Staubach. skip the game. Staubach. who has a jammed toe and sprained foot, is resting in bed with the leg elevated and Landry said yesterday. Danny White will play the whole game or at least most of it.

title: Golda Meir Is Buried in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 12  Golda Meir was buried today in a plain pine coffin at Mount Heal National Cemetery.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Jersey's High Court Admits Cameras and TV as a Test
description: TRENTON, Dec. 12  There was more, light than usual in the New Jersey Supreme Court today. Even the normally colorless drapes appeared bright red as, for the first time, the proceedings were recorded for television and, for the first time since 1936, still photographs were taken during a trial in a New Jersey courtroom.

title: Real Estate
description: IN 1973, the Panasonic Corporation moved out of an industrial building in Woodside, Queens, into consolidated quarters in the New Jersey Meadowlands. The loss was a blow to New York City. which lost 1,500 jobs. The city tried to get Panasonic to build on cityowned land near the Kennedy International Airport, but at the time the city's inducements could not equal New Jersey's.

title: Q&A
description: Q. What are albondigas?

title: Television
description: Morning

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: When Pan American makes a bid for National Airlines, it is one company going after another. When Eastern Air Lines makes a bid, it is Frank Borman at the controls. Everyone knows Frank Borman: astronaut and authentic hero, the tough decent guy who moved into the top job at Eastern Air Lines.

title: Cavaliers 127, Pistons 110
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, Dec. 12 (AP) Cleveland's shooting corps of Austin Carr, Campy Russell, Terry Furlow and Mike Mitchell each scored 20 points or more as the Cavaliers stopped the Detroit Pistons, 127110, tonight.

title: Dr. Domingo GomezGirneranez, Cardiovascular Researcher, Dead
description: Dr. Domingo Mauricio GomezGimeranez, a cardiovascular researcher at the Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine at New York University, died of heart failure at his home in Manhattan on Sunday. He was 75 years old.

title: La Dolce Vinegar, Rich and Robust
description: Bologna is considered by many to be the gastronomic capital of northern Italy, but Modena, a town in its shadow about 25 miles north, has its specialties, too, and one of them has shown up in New York.

title: Dr. Ely Mencher, at 64, Chairman Of Earth Sciences at City College
description: Prof. Ely Mencher, chairman of City College's Department of Earth and Planetary Sciences, died Monday at White Plains Hospital. He was 64 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE charge that can be leveled against books for the older child, say for the 10yearold and up, is that they do not celebrate life, the good life. There is an absence of joy and hope. Universals are seldom held up for scrutiny and affirmed. Instead, there is a reflection of the tortured adult world, the contemplation of little sorrows and great griefs. The seamy, the slightly tawdry, predominate. Picking at random this year you can find lesbians being raped, homosexuals committing suicide, stepdaughters being molested, retarded children being victimized. The Wicked Witch has become the alcoholic mother, Little Women is Little Strumpets, the teenage novel a literary Jonestown.

title: Jazz 109, Pacers 103
description: NEW ORLEANS. Dec. 12 (AP) Pete Maravich and Truck Robinson combined for 63 points tonight to lead the New Orleans Jazz to a 109103 victory over the Indiana Pacers.

title: Stock Market Retreats on a Pessimistic Forecast
description: A pessimistic forecast for the economy next year by Salomon Brothers, a leading investment banking and brokerage firm, yesterday sent the stock market moderately lower in slow trading.

title: Louise Nevelson Dedicates Her Sculpture at Trade Center
description: The sculptor Louise Nevelson joined the Port Authority chairman, Alan Sagner, for a noonhour dedication yesterday of her wall sculpture Sky Gate New York, specially commissioned for the World Trade Center.

title: City Hospitals' Directors Accept Hoffman as Corporation's Chief
description: Mayor Koch nominated Joseph C. Hoffman to be the $65,000ayear president of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation last night. The corporation's board of directors accepted the man the Mayor has selected to carry out his plans to dismantle part of the city's hospital system.

title: Wine Talk
description: WINE drinking is, Unfortunately, one of those pastimes that attract fanatics. They are the people who take what should be a pleasant diversion and transform it into a pedantic ritual. Their specialty may be wine but they share a common trait with all'kinds of fanatics: They have no sense of humor when it comes to their passion of the moment.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Making its 13th and final bond sale of 1978 yesterday, the Bell System marketed $150 million of debentures that underwriters priced to yield 9.27 percent  the highest rate of return on tripleA telephone company securities in three years.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, a subsidiary of the Walter E. Heller Corporation, has elected Michael E. Tobin chairman. He succeeds Allen P. Stults, who is retiring but who continues as a director and chairman of the executive committee. Also announced was the election of Keene H. Addington as president.

title: Privacy and the Passenger
description: The Supreme Court ruled last week that a person who enters a friend's automobile as a passenger surrenders a legitimate expectation of privacy. If the police should stop and search the car without good reason, they violate the owner's Fourth Amendment rights but not the passenger's. Under this narrow definition of privacy, even a search conducted solely as harassment would leave the passenger  and by logical extension a guest in a home  without legal redress. The decision is a throwback to a time when a person's right to be left alone depended on property ownership.

title: Checking Your Coat: Here Are Some Tips
description: EVERYBODY has questions about money these days, and with cold weather upon us certainly one of the touchier is how much of a tip does one leave for checking a coat?

title: TV: New Twist on Heidi
description: FOR the generations of children who read Heidi in overheated, overstuffed living rooms over cocoa and cookies, the little heroine's affection' for her humble cottage high in the Alps, her hard work and few comforts, may have seemed a bit odd.

title: EARNINGS
description: Gulf & Western Industries Inc. reported yesterday that profits in its first fiscal quarter ended Oct. 31 climbed 54.5 percent over the corresponding three months last year.

title: Checker To Sell for $49 Million
description: The Checker Motors Corporation, maker of Checker taxicabs, said yesterday it had agreed to sell all of its assets for about $49 million to Oppenheimer & Company, the Wall Street investment organization.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Tuesday, Dec. 12, 1971

title: Careers
description: THE stock market may be down and the economy may have bearish overtones, but there is a bull market for graduates who have majored in engineering.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: ONE bright summer morning, Diane and Martin Ackerman were sitting at breakfast in the villa they had rented on the Cote d'Azur. The sun sparkled on the perfectly appointed table, the crisp croissants, the fresh fruit. It was a picture from a travel brochure, but there was this box of AllBran on the table. Mon Dieu.

title: Rockets 112, Celtics 105
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 12 (AP)  Moses Malone scored a game high 28 points and pulled down 20 rebounds to pace the Houston Rockets to a 112105 triumph over the Boston Celtics tonight.

title: Technology
description: WAKEFIELD, VA. SINCE February this sleepy eastern Virginia town of Wakefieldonce described as the kind of place you would like to live in on a Sunday has been playing host to a steady stream of curious visitors from telephone companies in such distant places as Sunburst, Mont., Clinton, Ark., the Bahamas and even Hong Kong.

title: Reynolds Hires 6 New Lawyers
description: What is the first thing many people do when they're in trouble? Hire a lawyer. R.J. Reynolds Industries WinstonSalem, N.C., created six new associate general counsels yesterday. But the company announcement makes no mention of any increased legal troubles:

title: France Adamant On Duties
description: PARIS, Dec. 12  France today again insisted that European nations must not make a final trade agreement with the United States unless the next Congress removes the threat of penalty duties on $500 million of European food exports to the United States, according to officials attending a meeting in Brussels.

title: Money
description: TUESDAY, DEC, 12, 1978

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP)  A replacement was announced today for a new soft drink that was criticized as baby beer that would condition children to drink beer.

title: Composite Drawings Assembled for Two Suspects in Robbery at Kennedy
description: Investigators of Monday's multimilliondollar robbery in Lufthansa's cargo area at Kennedy International Airport have put together composite drawings of two of the six or seven bandits who got away with a reported $3 million in cash and $2 million in jewelry.

title: Study Bids Nation Use More Solar Energy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  A highlevel interagency report sent to President Carter says that solar energy can provide 20 percent of the nation's energy needs by the end of the century and recommends a major Federal effort to reach that goal.

title: 3 Men Take $100,000 In Diamonds and Gold
description: Three men, two of them armed, invaded a jewelry manufacturing company at 83 Canal Street last night, herded a number of employees into side room and escaped with an estimated $100,000 worth of diamonds and gold, according to the police.

title: Agency Acts Fast to Halt Dumping Of Oil Wastes on a S.I. Marshland
description: Quick action by the New York State's Department of Environmental Conservation appears to have contained an oily sludge spill on Staten Island that ruined an acre of marshland on a creek emptying into the Arthur Kill. The spill, the agency's regional director said, is the worst one we know about.

title: Kahn: Impolitic But Learning
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  Twice last week, Alfred E. Kahn, the Carter Administration's antiinflation chief, suggested  tentatively, but unmistakably  that consumers might boycott companies that are found to be in violation of the Administration's, voluntary guidelines for prices and wages.

title: Coach Knight Ousts 3 Players, Places 5 on Probation at Indiana
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Dec. 12 (AP) Three Indiana University basketball players have been dismissed from the team and five others, including the leading scorer, Ray Tolbert, placed on indefinite probation, Coach Bobby Knight said today.

title: Italy Moves Toward Money Bloc
description: ROME, Dec. 12  Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti, in a bold political gamble, announced today that he wanted to bring Italy into the new French and West Germansponsored European Monetary System despite the opposition of the Communists and Socialists, on whose support his minority Government depends.

title: Chinese Stews: A Savory Development
description: For the most part we think of Chinese cooking as consisting mainly of stirfried, steamed or roasted dishes. Yet there is also a whole, savory collection of keng cooking  soupstews usually based on meat but sometimes on fish and seafood, in which the combinations are simmered on top of the stove in clay casseroles, traditionally bound with wire. Lovers of exotic cookware will find these handsome, roughtextured, tannishgray unglazed vessels more than enough reason to take up this type of Chinese cooking.

title: President Bars Idea Of Boycotts
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  President Carter declared today his opposition to organized consumer boycotts of companies that do not comply with the Administration's wageprice guidelines.

title: Gibson May Call Guard in a Strike
description: NEWARK, Dec. 12  Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson said today that he would call in outside help, including the National Guard, it the 13,000 municipal employees called a general strike.

title: CLEVELAND'S MAYOR OFFERS RESCUE PLAN
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 12  In his final pitch to save this city from fiscal default, Mayor Dennis J. Kucinich outlined a sweeping fiscal rescue proposal to local bankers late today calling for an income tax increase and multimilliondollar bond issue.

title: Seven Killed in Chicago Fire
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (AP)  Seven persons, including two small children, were killed today when fire ravaged a fourstory apartment building on the Southwest Side. fire officials said. The dead children were identified as Jimmy Cruz, 2 years otd, and his sister, Amelia, 4. Three of the adults were identified by the Red Cross as Edmundo Reveles, 32; Antonio Rodriquez, 56, and Raymond Solis, 51. Two other men, about 51 and 35, remained unidentified.

title: Screen: Rain and Shine
description: RAIN AND SHINE, Ferenc Andras's Hungarian film that opens today at the new Cinema Studio 2, recalls the humanist comedies that, briefly, came out of Czechoslovakia in the late 60's, before Soviet intervention effectively ended the Prague Spring. I empharsize that Rain and Shine only recalls those films, including the comedies of Milos Forman and Ivan Passer; it doesn't equal either their artistry or their vision, which transcended social and political concerns.

title: A Master Makes Bread An Art
description: BLOOMINGTON, IND. IF ever a man followed that bit of biblical advice, Ask, and it shall be given you; seek, and ye shall find, it was Bernard Clayton Jr., a writer in this university town who, about four years ago, set off on a 7,000mile journey around France to seek the formulas and breadmaking techniques of that nation's legendary boulangers.

title: Salomon Bearish on 1979
description: It is too glib to talk of a twoquarter recession and a slight contraction in economic activity, said Henry Kaufman, general partner at Salomon Brothers, yesterday in one of the more bearish forecasts for the American economy now being circulated.

title: U.N. Unit's Aid Vote Angers U.S.
description: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 12  A General Assembly committee tonight approved an economicaid resolution that the United States, in protest, said was designed to enhance the political standing of the Palestine Liberation Organization and could lead to a cutoff of major American financial support for United Nations assistance projects.

title: Two Versions of Report Released In Voting Machine Investigation
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 (AP)  A complete lack of maintenance and unqualified mechanics were responsible for voting machine breakdowns and balloting delays here in the November general election, according to the unedited version of a report commissioned for a Federal grand jury investigating the problems.

title: Swiss Men Are 1,2 In Cup Slalom Upset
description: MADONNA DI CAMPIGLIO, Italy, Dec. 13 (AP)  Unheralded Martial Donnet and Peter Luescher scored a stunning 1, 2 triumph today, giving the Swiss men's team its first World Cup victory in the special slalom in nine years.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: In the old movies, Pat O'Brien became head of the airline because he had flown through more storms and landed in more cornfields than anyone else. That era ended with Eddie Rickenbacker, whose career was more colorful than anything Hollywood could devise. The Rickenbackers were followed by the faceless bankers and Wall Street lawyers who knew how to avoid getting lost in the labyrinthine ways of Washington bureaucracy.

title: Letters
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Reynolds Sued on Bid
description: SAN FRANCISCO. Dec. 13  The States Steamship Company has filed suit here in an effort to prevent the agreed acquisition of Del Monte Corporation by R.J. Reynolds Industries for an estimated $620 million.

title: U.S. Judge Postpones Inquiry by Grand Jury Into Murder of Ryan
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13  A Federal judge here today postponed a grand jury investigation into the assassination of Representative Leo J. Ryan until Federal Bureau of Investigation reports are made available to People's Temple survivors who have been called to testify.

title: Amnesty's Odd Man In
description: Can a Communist find happiness as research director of Amnesty International, the celebrated champion of human rights throughout the world? The man in question is Derek Roebuck, dean of law at the University of Tasmania and a member of the Australian Communist Party. As Amnesty International's research director, a job he is to begin next month, Professor Roebuck will supervise 70 staff members who gather information about the treatment of prisoners of conscience wherever they may be. In the words of an advertisement for the position, his duty will be to insure the highest standards of accuracy, impartiality and judgment.

title: Navy and Air Force Face Big Exodus of Pilots Lured to Commercial Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  The Air Force and the Navy, which spend at least $200,000 to train a pilot, are facing a major exodus of pilots to lucrative airline jobs.

title: Data General Wary on Pay Lid
description: While most of corporate America has pledged support to the Carter Administration's wageprice guidelines, Edson D. de Castro expresses grave doubts that his company can comply with them.

title: Canadiens 3, North Stars 2
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Dec. 13 (AP)  Mario Tremblay scored at 7:32 of the third period tonight to lift the Montreal Canadiens to a 32 victory over Minnesota, snapping the North Stars' fivegame unbeaten string.

title: Market Place
description: WHEN Henry and Richard Bloch started small bookkeeping business in Kansas City, Mo., in 1946, no one dreamed that their company would become the nation's leading preparer incometax returns.

title: Amtrak chief Proposes U.S. Contract for Rail Service
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  The president of Amtrak called today for a new national policy toward the rail passenger service and a longterm commitment from Congress that would help stabilize the system and improve service.

title: H. F. JOHNSON DIES; LED WAX COMPANY
description: Herbert Fisk Johnson, the retired chairman of the Johnson Wax Company, who was a philanthopist and an art patron, died yesterday at his home in Racine, Wis. He was 79 years old.

title: Einstein Sculpture Approaching Last Stage
description: ORIENT, L.I.  The old man sat at a table and scribbled on a pad while the young man tried to capture his image in a lump of clay.

title: U.S.EGYPTIAN PLANS TO RESOLVE TREATY REJECTED BY ISRAEL
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 13  The Israeli Government raised objections today to new ideas that had been worked out for concluding an EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty, and Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance announced plans to return to Washington.

title: 200 Schools Under Study For Students' Problems
description: ALBANY, Dec. 13  The State Education Department has singled out for special attention 200 representative schools around the state that have such problems as poor test scores and attendance rates and high pupilturnover rates.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Heatedly Defends Herself in Parliament
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 13  Indira Gandhi deliyered a spirited and emotional defense today against attempts to expel her from Parliament on a charge that she harassed officials in 1975, when she was PrimdMinister.

title: Plan for Beaumont: Curtain Still Rising
description: ASIDE from easing the parking problems of opera and ballet patrons, there was very little good to say about the enforced idleness of Lincoln Center's Vivian Beaumont Theater over the last 16 months. It has been a blight on the cen ter; and beyond that, on the civility of city that finds itself in possession of theatrical monument it cannot find use for.

title: 30 Families Routed by Acid
description: TELLICO, Tenn, Dec. 13 .(AP)  Thirteen cars of a Louisville & Nashville Railroad freight train derailed today, spilling thousands of gallons of sulfuric acid into a drainage ditch and forcing the evacuation of 30 families from their homes. No injuries were reported, and the cause of the accident was under investigation, according to Phil Hooper, the railroad's resident vice president for Tennessee.

title: Detectives Among 84 Assigned to 911 Duty;
description: Eightyfour police officers and detectives will be taken off their regular duties, including undercover investigations, and assigned to the problemplagued 911 emergency number system beginning Monday to replace civilian employees being transferred out because they were found unqualified.

title: Diplomat's $10 A Drop to Aid Neediest Cases
description: Yuan TaoFeng of Brooklyn, a retired diplomat and college professor, is a constant reader and also a contributor to the 67th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. He has written on Chinese diplomatic history and, with his $10 donation to the campaign, he referred to his gift as just a drop in the bucket. Mr. Yuan added:

title: Hers
description: NEXT month will mark the beginning of the 10th year that I have been what is now called a displaced homemaker  that is, a woman whose primary role for 25 years was that of wife and mother, and who had that life abruptly ended. What have I been doing these 10 years? I see that question in the eyes of oldtime friends and people I meet for the first time. What have I learned, I ask myself, that is helpful to other women?

title: The Region
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn. (AP)The Connecticut Gaming Commission threatened to cancel its contract with a private contractor, American Totalisator of Hunt Valley, Md., to run the state's Daily Numbers lottery game because the company had failed to file required financial statements with the commission.

title: TV: Rockette, Tribute To Aid the Music Hall
description: ROCKETTE, on NBC tonight at 9 o'clock, is heralded as a tribute but really is more of a plea. And as the cause is a personal favorite, it should be conceded right here that this review is likely to be prejudiced.

title: Fotiu: A Lion, A Lamb
description: There was Nick Fotiu, the Rangers enforcer, at the club's Christmas party, cradling his blond 10monthold daughter in the crook of his elbow, and skating with her to the penalty box.

title: Callaghan Loses, Calls Vote Today
description: LONDON, Dec. 13  The Government's pay policy was dealt a severe blow tonight when the House of Commons voted 285 to 279 against the use of economic sanctions to enforce its antiinflation policy. Prime Minister James Callaghan promptly called for a vote of confidence.

title: A $150 MILLION TRIM IN HOSPITALS IS SEEN
description: High New York City health officials said yesterday that they were prepared to cut the municipal hospital budget of $1.2 billion by at least 10 percent, or $150 million.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In some editions of The Times yesterday, the transcript of President Carter's news conference erroneously quoted him as having said, regarding the situation in SouthWest Africa, that the South Africans have not accepted the terms set up for that region by the Secretary General of the United Nations. The President said the South Africans have now accepted the Secretary General's terms, a statement that was later clarified by the State Department.

title: Deaths
description: GREENBERGHyman. Beloved husband of Anna, father of Janet Kram and Barbara Meranze and loving grandfather. Funeral services Friday, December 15. 12:33 Pm at Riverside Chapel. 180 W. 76 St. Manhattan.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: It is a First Amendment bill, not just a press bill.

title: Corporate Earnings Reported
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange,(A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Bay State Bonds Sell Slowly
description: Massachusetts sold another large issue of taxexempt bonds yesterday and investors again were not eager to buy the securities. The performance convinced some underwriters that interest rates in this sector of the credit markets should rise.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Carter Administration revised its guidelines for wage and price increases and added a limit of 6.5 percent for increases in the average fees of physicians and other professionals. The key changes were a modification of the pay standard with respect to fringe benefits and a tightening of the profit margin aspect of the price standard. [Pages A1, D11.) Meanwhile, the teamsters union and the trucking industry are scheduled to open talks whose outcome may determine the success or failure of the antiinflation program. [A1.]

title: EARNINGS
description: The Supermarkets General Corporation yesterday reported profit increases of 77.1 percent for the third fiscal quarter ended Oct. 28 and 47.7 percent for the nine months.

title: On the Ropes in Iran
description: President Carter keeps wobbling on the tightrope of Iran. He favors the Shah, but he must also think beyond the Shah. To show interest in the opposition may seal the Shah's fate; to be too much for the Shah may cause American influence to disappear if he does not survive. Although vital American interests are at risk in the crisis, it is fundamentally a domestic upheaval and American control over events is slight. So what can a President do?

title: Backgammon:
description: The second Las Vegas backgammon tournament sponsored by American Backgammon Championships was completed here last weekend. This recordbreaking event drew more than 700 players competing in three sections for $400,000 in prize money. The amateur section was won by David Leibowitz, who defeated Jack Barney in the finals. Third place went to Mike Campbell and fourth to J. Bysinski.

title: New Breed of Arkansas Officials Taking Race Out Politics
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  Two noteworthy political events happened in Arkansas this year. Bill Clinton was, elected Governor, and Marlin Hawkins retired.

title: Q & A
description: Q. In every corner inside our house the walls get wet with condensation. We have washed these areas with bleach, then painted them with shellac and semigloss paint, but we still have the problem with sweating. We have put vents in the outside siding and have replaced the storm windows, but the sweating continues  including on the inside of the windows. We know there is some insulation in the walls.. Can you help us?  A.R., Palmer, Mass.

title: Life of a Trucker Has Changed Over the Decades
description: CARLSTADT. N.J.  In the vintage film They Drive By Night, Humphrey Bogart plays a tough truck driver trying to survive in the chaotic, corrupt, violent trucking world of 1940.

title: Bullets 134, Clippers 117
description: LANDOVER, Md., Dec. 13 (AP) Elvin Hayes scored 36 points while becoming the 10th player in National Basketball Association history to reach the 20,000point plateau and led the Washington Bullets to a 134117 victory over the San Diego Clippers tonight.

title: Inflation Guideline a Main Issue As Teamster Talks Begin Today
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  Tomorrow at 9 A.M., in a nondescript meeting room at the Shoreham Americana Hotel here, representatives of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and the trucking companies open three months of negotiations whose outcome may determine the success or failure of the Carter Administration's antiinflation effort.

title: Troy to Ask for a Closed Hearing On Jan. 8 in Embezzlement Case
description: The lawyer for former City Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr. will argue in State Supreme Court next Monday that the press and public should be barred from a pretrial hearing on embezzlement charges against Mr. Troy.

title: EDWIN S. WILKINS JR.
description: Edwin S. Wilkins Jr., vice president and general counsel of the Canada Dry Corporation, 100 Park Avenue, died Tuesday in Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 49 years old and a resident of Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: Chicago City Council Agrees to Cut Salary Increases From 60% to 20%
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 13  In what may be the first victory for President Carter's 7 percent wage and price guidelines, the Chicago City Council agreed today to roll back a proposed 60 percent aldermanic salary increase in the face of vigorous public protest and criticism from Administration officials.

title: Clout, WomenWise
description: LOS ANGELESI am a political groupie. The seat of power excites me. I must be near it. Not on it. Access to it will do. When I was a teenager (Truman vs. Dewey), I was a gofer (coffee, etc.). Now that I am a woman, I contribute. I purchase political access and it is reasonably priced. Yet, not many women are buying. Why not?

title: Cries of Long Live the Shah!
description: ISFAHAN, Iran, Dec.13 For the first time in months, cries of Javid Shah! Long Live the Shah!  rang through the streets of a major Iranian city today as troops here led a violent counterdemonstration against opponents of the Government.

title: NEW & USEFUL
description: This is surely a time when something that makes parties and dinners both easier and more festive is welcome. A new serving aid serves a dual purpose. For the first part of the meal, when white wine is served, the bottle rests in a Lucite wine bucket on its own threelegged Lucite stand. For the salad course, the bucket is removed and the stand Is turned upside down so a Lucite salad bowl fits on it. After dinner, the stand folds flat and may be stored with the bowl and bucket. Not only is it neat, it's also attractive, because the frosty ice cubes and the leafy greens show through the clear plastic. The whole package, complete with stand, bucket, bowl and salad servers, sells for $110 on the fourth floor at Bergdorf Goodman.

title: Subway Riders Delayed by Cleanup After Derailment
description: Thousands of subway riders were delayed yesterday as repair crews struggled to clear the wreckage of a southbound Eighth Avenue CC local that jumped the tracks late Tuesday afternoon just south of the 59th Street station and crashed into the tunnel wall, injuring 16 of the train's 100 riders.

title: Airport Cash Loot Was $5 Million; Bandits' Van Is Found in Canarsie
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said last night that the bandits who robbed the Lufthansa cargo facility at Kennedy International Airport on Monday got away with more than $5 million in United States currency, not $3 million as originally believed, and a stillundetermined amount of foreign currency and gems. The F.B.I. said it was the largest cash robbery in history.

title: Country Chairs: The Work Pays Off
description: AT flea markets and antiques shows, among the number of chairs that are often sitting around  most of them seatless  there are usually a few attractive turnofthecentury side chairs, backed With three slats, that have a country look. The seats are either splint or rush and are usually in a sorry State. (These chairs should not be confused with chairs that have been caned and are not constructed to take a woven seat.) The country chairs are reasonably priced, and if one is prepared to invest a modest outlay of cash, time and effort in restoring them, they will be an attractive addition to any but the most formal room.

title: The City
description: Donald Hotchkiss, one of four youths accused of assaulting and seriously injuring six men in the Ramble in Central Park last July, has pleaded guilty to three counts of assault and one count of robbery growing out of the case.

title: EVIDENCE IS FOUND OF GRAVITY WAVES
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Dec. 13 The first experimental evidence of gravitational waves has been reported by a team of radio astronomers at the University of Massachusetts in Amherst.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made, payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249, or to any of the following organizations:

title: New $1 Coin Honoring Susan B. Anthony Is Pressed in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13  The first coins to bear the face of a woman were pressed here today at the United States Mint.

title: The Winter of Their (The Birds') Discontent
description: THINKING snow. Last night my husband whispered sweetly in my ear, It's time to winterize the estate, darling. He was referring of course, to our pocketsize city back yard. But soft ... it thinks it's a garden.

title: Disks: As the Russians Play Gershwin
description: HERE'S an amusing oddity, and at a budget price, too. It might be said to be worth having for the cover alone, which, against a solid red background, prints the seals of the United States and the Soviet Union and underneath, the relevant information about the pieces and the performers in each country's language and alphabet.

title: Moment Of Truth
description: An angered President Carter has publicly called it quibbling over insignificant language differences. In private, some of his closest advisers have called it something worse than that, including breach of faith.

title: Freeze Brings Call For Artificial Snow
description: Winter, in the form of persistent subfreezing temperatures, finally has arrived in the ski country, and snowmaking has been ordered on a roundtheclock basis.

title: Kiki Dee at Bottom Line
description: EVERY singer dreams of assembling the perfect band, and Kiki Dee, who appeared at the Bottom Line on Monday and Tuesday night, has very nearly put one together. But such a dream can turn into a disappointment when the singer lacks the strength of voice and personality to predominate. Miss Dee's set Tuesday evening was rousing, but her own performance left a fuzzy impression.

title: Sales of U.S. Cars Up 24% for 10 Days
description: DETROIT, Dec. 13  Sales of Americanmade passenger cars jumped by more than 24 percent for the first 10 days of December, over the same period last year, with the Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation sales accounting for the gain.

title: 11 Protesters Are Convicted
description: WASHINGTON (AP) Dec. 13 Complaining that the Government considers stepping on the lawn of the Executive Mansion of more concern than war preparations, 11 protesters have been convicted on a misdemeanor charge of refusing to leave the White House grounds.

title: Knicks Are Annihilated by Spurs, 139109
description: SAN ANTONIO, Dec. 13  Coach Red Holzman of the New York Knicks would have savored an eightminute game with the San Antonio Spurs tonight. Unfortunately, the rules stipulate 48 minutes and it was the extra 40 that killed the New Yorkers.

title: CULT VICTIM SLAIN, GUYANA JURY TOLD
description: MATTHEWS RIDGE, Guyana, Dec. 13 The first official report that murder had been committed in the mass deaths at the People's Temple sect in Jonestown emerged today, as a coroner's jury began a formal inquiry into the matter.

title: Deaths
description: RUBINSara, beloved wife of Harry, loving mother of Bernard and grandmother. Sister of Dorothy W,. gor, Ann Block. Sylvia Greenspan Services held December 13th.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday, Dec. 13. 1971

title: Dr. Spock Leads Demonstrators To Tulsa Nuclear Plant Hearing
description: TULSA, Okla., Dec. 13 (AP)  Dr. Benjamin Spock led more than 60 placardwaving demonstrators to Federal hearings on Oklahoma's first proposed nuclear power plant today.

title: 10 Signposts: New IDirections In Decorating
description: OUT with the old and in with the new. That's what stores and designer showrooms are up to, as the latest collections of home furnishings arrive. Changes in furniture and accessories are rarely as startling as those in fashion, but still, there is some innovative thinking going on these days.

title: Argentina and Chile Break Off Talks Over Islands
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 13  The foreign ministers of Chile and Argentina have been unable to agree on a mediator in their dispute over the possession of islands at the southern tip of the continent, increasing the possibility of an armed conflict.

title: Burning Wood: Do's and Don'ts
description: WASHINGTON Higher energy costs are causing many Americans to consider the benefits of burning wood, which, besides heat, can provide a cheerful, crackling blaze on a cold evening. But before stoking up the fire there are a few things to remember.

title: Yonkers Delays Canceling 3% Tax
description: YONKERS, Dec. 13The City Council here delayed action last night on rescinding the recently imposed 3 percent utility tax. It voted instead to send the proposed local law amending the tax to the Rules Committee for further study.

title: Duke Five Routs U.S.C, 7965
description: DURHAM, N.C. Dec. 13 (AP) Mike Gminski fired in 25 points and led a strong inside game to pace topranked Duke to a 7965 victory over 12thranked and previously undefeated Southern California tonight.

title: City Hospitals Trace Origins To 1736 Ward
description: New York City's beleaguered municipal hospital system traces its origin to 1736 when the immediate forerunner of Bellevue Hospital was established as a sixbed ward in the public almshouse and house of corrections on the Commons site now occupied by City Hall.

title: Christmas Gift Ideas That Are Made for Comfort
description: NESTFEATHERING takes on special significance Christmas because luxurious purchases are much easier to rationalize. It's a time to spoil yourself, family, friends and usually your budget as well. During a ride on the rushhour subway, for example, a commuter might impulsively decide to give himself a crushed velvet chaise for Christmas. Or a real, oldfashioned porch rocker, or a hassock for tired feet. A blanket on one's Christmas list could, by the same turn of mind, become a silken comforter under the tree. Here are some gifts that were chosen for their comfort quotient, for pure indulgence's sake.

title: Church Leaders in San Francisco Ask Courts to Help Bury Cultists
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13 (AP)  A group of local religious leaders urged the courts today to take $1 million of the People's Temple's assets to pay for burial of those who died in the suicides and killings at the cult's commune in Guyana last month.

title: New U.S. Arms Control Director Sees Need to Update Weapons
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  George M. Seignious 2d, the new director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, told reporters today that even if a new strategic arms accord is reached soon, the United States would still have to modernize its nuclear arsenal.

title: About Newark
description: NEWARK, Dec. 12  The Jonestown cult with all its death and mystery is such a compelling part of the life of Dr. Hardat A. S. Sukhdeo that even his dreams are filled with it now that he has returned to the middleclass routine of Upper Montclair.

title: Boeing Seeks Japanese
description: TOKYO, Dec. 13 (AP)  The Boeing Company, the world's largest aircraft manufacturer, is looking for about 100 Japanese technicians to help handle increasing orders for its 797's and 727's, spokesman for the aircraft industry nere reported today. He said he thought the company would get about a third of the number it wanted. The spokesman, of the Society of Japanese Aerospace Companies, said 29 technicians had been selected for final review before making a trip to Boeing's headquarters in Seattle. The technicians were chosen from Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Kawasaki Heavy Industries and other jet aircraft companies.

title: Pitney Bowes Sells 3 Units
description: Pitney Bowes Inc., the nation's largest maker of postal meters and mailing equipment, said yesterday that it had completed the sale and leaseback of three properties for $8.5 million to Pately Associates of West Hartford. Conn. The three properties are the Pitney Bowes assembly plant and office facility and its national service center, both in Stamford, and its national distribution center, in Newtown, Conn. The leaseback from Pately is for an initial 25year period with an option for renewal

title: Rock: Feelies and Cools
description: THERE were two interesting occurrences on the newwave rock front Tuesday night  the first appearance of the Feelies with their new drummer at Hurrah's, and the United States debut at Max's Kansas City of the Cools, billed as Japan's No. 1 rockabilly band.

title: $20 Tut Tickets Prompt Museum To Move Against Jersey Agency
description: An undetermined number of tickets to the Tutankhamen exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art are in the hands of a ticket agency in Union City, N.J., and have been advertised for sale at $20 each.

title: Schoolgirl Is Testing State Eligibility Rule
description: Sectional officials of the state Public High School Athletic Association will allow 15yearold Valerie Robin of Horace Greeley High School in Chappaqua, N.Y., to play girls junior varsity basketball this season, even though she became ineligible to play high school athletics by practicing with a men's college soccer team this fall.

title: Calendar: Poinsettias Grow in Brooklyn
description: Poinsettia Flower Show, Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING

title: Murder Plot Laid to MotherinLaw
description: A Manhattan lawyer has charged that his motherinlaw conspired to have him murdered following his announcement that he was divorcing her daughter after 18 years of marriage. The lawyer, Norman Himmelein, made the charge Tuesday after District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan said that a 55yearold Queens man had been indicted for conspiring with Mr. Himmelein's fatherinlaw to have Mr. Himmelein murdered.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
description: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1978

title: Jeannette Seidman, 91; ExHead of Ad Agency
description: Jeannette S. Seidman, former president of the InterRacial Press of America, a foreignlanguage advertising agency, died yesterday in a New Rochelle nursing home. She was 91 years old and, until two years ago, was a resident of Tudor City in Manhattan.

title: Thorpe to Stand Trial on Charge He Conspired to Kill His Accuser
description: LONDON, Dec. 13  Jeremy Thorpe, former leader of Britain's Liberal Party, was ordered today to stand trial at the Old Bailey on charges of conspiring to murder Norman Scott, a model who claimed to have had a homosexual relationship with him.

title: Town in Florida Votes Against Its Abolition
description: PORT RICHEY, Fla., Dec. 13 (AP)  Despite their complaints about high taxes and poor services, the mostly elderly residents of Port Richey voted today not to abolish their town.

title: Home Beat
description: HE spent a month and a half on his bicycle looking for it he says. At 19 Christopher Street, he finally found it. And ho would prefer that you not think of it as a shop. He sees it, rather, as a studio.

title: Evolution Exhibit Is Upheld
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP)  In a modern version of the Scopes monkey trial, a Federal judge has decided that the Smithsonian Institution does not have to publicize the Bible alongside its exhibit on evolution.

title: U.S. Embassy Is Bolstered
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 13  The staff of the United States Embassy here has been bolstered by dozens of specialists flown in to back an effort to help the Shah against a growing challenge to his rule, according to embassy sources.

title: Text of Adams Letters on Westway Project Delays
description: Following are the texts of letters from Brock Adams, the Federal Secretary of Transportation, to Charles E. Warren, chairman of the Council on Environmental Quality, and Douglas M. Costle, head of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency:

title: Rangers Beat Kings In a Shootout by 87
description: Was that the National Hockey League represented last night in Madison Square Garden?

title: Carter Warns Talk Can Start Recession
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 President Carter warned tonight that predictions of a recession can become a selffulfilling Prophecy.

title: Rudel Resigns as City Opera Director
description: Julius Rudel, director of the New York City Opera for the last 21 years, announced his resignation yesterday. It will become effective June 30, 1979, and he will be succeeded by Beverly Sills, the noted soprano. Mr. Rudel will stay on with the company as principal conductor, a newly created post.

title: Judy Kaye's Club Debut
description: JUDY KAYE, who plays Lily Garland in the musical On the Twentieth Century, is making her nightclub debut at Reno Sweeney this week (she is appearing at 11:30 P.M. through Saturday only) with an act that is so well constructed and executed that one would think she were an old hand instead of a neophyte at nightclubs. A source of much of the polish of her performance is undoubtedly the long list of touring companies that she lists as the preparation for her overnight success after she replaced Madeline Kahn in On the Twentieth Century last April.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Ski Reports
description: (All ski areas are ccerating on very limited terrain. Figures in parentheses show total trails and number open at each area.)

title: Koch's Shuffling Of Cabinet Puts Toia in Key Job
description: Mayor Koch's reshuffling of his cabinet last week will leave Deputy Mayor Philip L. Toia in a position to become the Mayor's key aide, City Hall aides agree, although everyone concedes that no one will have the influence of the departing David W. Brown.

title: GUIDELINE ON WAGES RELAXED BY CARTER; PRICE RULE TIGHTER
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  With one eye apparently on the, negotiations of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters that start tomorrow, the Carter Administration revised its voluntary pay and price standards today.

title: Carter Steps Up Drive to Win Support for Arms Treaty
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  Administration officials are stepping up efforts to win Congressional and grassroots support for a new treaty with the Soviet Union on the limitation of strategic arms.

title: Peterson Now PHH
description: Peterson, Howell & Heather Inc. said its shareholders had approved a management proposal to change the holding company's name to PHH Group Inc., effectively immediately. The company also said that it expected trading of its stock to begin on the New York Stock Exchange on Dec. 18. The stock is currently traded over the counter. The company provides specialized services to corporations, including car and truck leasing.

title: Modifications Issued on Standards
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  Following is a fact sheet describing modifications in the wage and price standards that was distributed today by the Council on Wage and Price Stability:

title: From Police Force to Medical Management
description: Naturally the issue always comes up: What is a cop doing managing hospital?

title: Notes on People
description: Although nearly blind and unable to play ball himself, Irving M. Sells organized the boys on his block in Brooklyn's Williamsburg section into the Unicorn Athletic Club. From 1931 to 1955, he and his wife, Sara, were wellknown to Greenwich Villagers for their energetic operation of the big newsstand at Sheridan Square. Mr. Selis had helped organize the Blind Newsdealers Association in 1928, and 10 years later thetouple were leaders in a group that, insisting the blind must lead the blind, set up the Associated Blind.

title: U.S. Lines Plans Move From New York in '79
description: United States Lines Inc. has decided to move its headquarters from 1 Broadway in Manhattan to Cranford, N.J., in mid1979, Jack Watson, vice president for administration, disclosed yesterday.

title: Cult Member Is Said to Accept Blame for 5 Slayings at Airstrip
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 13 (AP)  A member of the People's Temple, charged with five counts of murder in the slayings of Representative Leo J. Ryan and four other persons, has told the police that he accepts full responsibility for the deaths and for injuries to other persons at the scene, informed sources said today.

title: Questions and Answers on Wage and Price council's Guidelines
description: Following are excerpts from questions and answers prepared by the Council on Wage and Price Stability on tlik guidelines:

title: Glittering Stores For Sheiks, Stars
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  For a lot of people's money  a great deal of money, in fact  Rodeo Drive is fast becoming the world's most prestigious shopping area.

title: Sadat Wants Signing on Mt. Sinai
description: CAIRO, Dec. 13 President Anwar elSadat insisted today that any treaty with Israel must be signed on Mount Sinai.

title: World News Briefs
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 13  A Quebec couple involved in acts of terrorism that led to the creation of a state of emergency in Canada In 1970 ended eight years of exile today.

title: Park Party Trails in Korea Voting
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 13  The governing Democratic Republican Party received fewer votes in parliamentary elections held yesterday than the opposition but President Park Chung Hee retained control of the National Assembly.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: DETROIT. Dec. 13 (AP) Mickey Stanley was liven h. unconditional release today by the Detroit Tigers.

title: Advertising
description: THE GAF Corporation, which got a new head of advertising and marketing last May, now has two new ad agencies. Not an unusual sequence of events.

title: Critic's Notebook: 2 Hit Films Without Gimmicks
description: WHY are Midnight Express and Bread and Chocolate, two movies without stars or gimmicks or other obvious selling points, among this season's most durable hits? Both of these films depict the plights of characters stranded in hostile surroundings, and each reduces the situation to simple, almost storybook terms. Each presents disturbing problems in a manner that is ultimately soothing, alarmingly so. Each depends heavily upon crudely drawn racial or national stereotypei for its dramatic impetus. Too often, each approaches its audience the way someone wielding an electtic prod might approach a steer.

title: Deaths
description: ATKINSONThanas H.. Jr. December 13. 1976. Of 59 Cavalry Rd. Weston. Connecticut. Husband of Jean Robb Atkinson. Memorial services will be held Friday at 11am at Christ & Holy Trinity Church. Westport, Cf. In lieu of flowers contributions to The American Cancer Soda, ty would be greatly appreciated.

title: Hussein Won't See Khomeini
description: PARIS, Dec. 13 (AP)  King Hussein of Jordan said here today that he would net meet with the Ayatollah Khomeini and had never planned such a meeting.

title: Israeli Winery Floods Streets
description: RISHON LE ZION, Israel, Dec. 13 (UPI)  Nearly 15,000 gallons of red burgundy wine today flooded the streets of Rishon Le Zion, a winemaking center. The CarmelMizrachi winery each year pours about 10 percent of its output down the drain to qualify for a kosher designation, according to rabbinical rules. This year the sewage system was clogged and the wine flooded the streets.

title: Rhodesia Said to Get U.S. Copters
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  The State and Commerce Departments are investigating reports that 11 Americandesigned helicopters were delivered recently to Rhodesia despite international arms and economic embargoes, a spokesman said tonight.

title: Peking Hints It Might Rehabilitate ExChief of State
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 13  Chinese authorities have published a threedecadesold letter from Mao Tsetung to a son of the disgraced former chief of state, Liu Shaochi, in what may be a first step in Mr. Liu's rehabilitation.

title: Lonesome Billy Assesses Reggie
description: The logo on the window has a I inside a sixpointed sheriff's star, surrounded by the words, Billy Martin's Western Wear, Inc. Inside the door of the small store on East 69th Street near Madison Avenue, the pungent aroma of leather flows from expensive boots, belts, leather goods and cowboy hats. On the brown, leather walls were stuffed trophies of a Rocky Mountain bighorn sheep and an antelope, along with some Frederic Remington sketches of cowboys. On shelves were framed photos of Billy. Martin with

title: Home Improvement
description: NATIONWIDE statistics indicate that a fire occurs in about 1,500 homes each day, and, in addition to the millions of dollars worth of property damage, more than 6,000 people die in these fires each year. To combat this increasing trend, much attention has been given to such protective devices as smoke alarms and fireextinguishers. But attention must also bepaid to fire prevention.

title: Deaths
description: CROZIEREleanor. On December 13M. 1978. Of Montclair. formerly of Passaic. Sister of Mrs. Ann Brown of Montclair. Also survived by a niece and a nephew. Funeral from the Hugh M. Moriarty Funeral Home, 76 Park Street. Montclair, NJ on Saturday at 9AM. Then to SI. John's Episcopal Church at the corner of Montclair Avenue and Chestnut St, Montclair where at 10AM a funeral service will be held. Interment East Ridgetenen Cemetery. Clifton. Visiting hours 79PM Thursday. 24 and 79 Friday. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society or the charity of your choice.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Toyota, Nissan Outputs Drop
description: TOKYO, Dec. 13 (AP)  Japan's two largest automobile manufacturers today reported production declines in November.

title: Look Out, Midas and Puma  Here Come Motorized Legs
description: HYDE PARK, N.Y., Dec. 11 Burt Shulman gently touched the throttle of the little machine strapped to his back. Suddenly he wasn't Burt Shulman at all, but Mercuryabouttobecomelams, a quiet mechanical engineer who was now the match of Captain Marvel or may be even Wonder Woman.

title: lolani Luahine, at 63; Called Last Exponent Of Sacred Hula Dance
description: Iolani Luahine, a dancer regarded as Hawaii's last great exponent of the sacred hula ceremony, died Monday on the island of Hawaii. She was 63 years old.

title: Music: Colin Davis Leads Boston Symphony
description: MOST of last night's Boston Symphony program, in Carnegie Hall, was devoted to one long work that consisted of 12 relatively short numbers. Colin Davis conducted Mahler's Des Knaben Wunderhorn. His singers were Jessye Norman and John ShirleyQuirk. The only other work on the program was Mozart's Symphony in C (K. 338), one of the youthful and. hence, short symphonies (Mr. Davis brought it in at around 20 minutes). Thus, in a way, the concert was a progression of passing moods.

title: Bridge:
description: The only bridge term borrowed from the boxing ring is the uppercut, an attempt to deliver a knockout punch from below. In bridge, the operation always concerns the trump suit, and the idea is to improve partner's prospects of trump tricks by forcing an overruff.

title: 3 Top U.S. Directors In Yale Dean's Race
description: Three prominent American stage directors  Lloyd Richards, Zelda Fi. chandler and Gordon Davidson  are among the possible candidates to succeed Robert Brustein as dean of the Yale Drama School. A search commit. tee, formed to assist A. Bartlett Giametti, president of Yale University, his choice of a new dean, has apparently narrowed an original list of 20 recommended candidates to four or five preferred contenders, including Mr. Richards, Mrs. Fichandler and Mr. Davidson.

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, DEC. 13, 1978

title: Sound
description: FOLLOWING a rather fulminant sermon against the folly of excess power last week, let us reverse the coin and argue the importance of having enough power and suggest ways to determine how much power is enough.

title: Deaths
description: Allkinson, Thomas

title: FISCAL PLAN SPLITS CLEVELAND COUNCIL
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 13  A straw vote by the City Council today indicated that Mayor Dennis J. Kucinich was far short of the votes he needed to win approval of the broad fiscal rescue plan he has proposed to save the city from default on Friday.

title: Talking Business
description: Dour reports about consumer spending and predictions of continuing inflation are sounding a sore note at a point when the nation's shoppers are diong their annual holiday buying. One prime indicator of public buying preferences is toys, especially during the Christmas shopping season, which normally accounts for half of the year's toy business.

title: Where to Find The Tree Farms
description: Vincent Abel, North Clove Road (mile and a half east of Verbank); (914) 6776395. Open daily.

title: Paper Plant May Shut
description: The International Paper Company has said that it will shut down its Panama City, Fla., plant by the end of January unless the facility is sold by that time. The company announced three months ago that it was trying to sell the mill and the 345,000 acres of surrounding woodlands. It said discussions were being held with several prospective buyers whodhave expressed an interest in the property. Annual capacity of the mill is 280,000 tons of linerboard and 240,000 tons of bleached market pulp. Shutdown of the Panama City plant would mean the loss of 950 jobs, the company said.

title: French Austerity Cuts Jobs, Welfare
description: PARIS, Dec. 13  France received another bitter taste of its Government's new austerity policies as the stateowned steel companies announced plans this week to lay off more than 21,000 workers during the next two years. In addition, the Cabinet announced a $3 billion increase in social security taxes today and tightened the rules for unemployment compensation.

title: Dance: Miss Gonzalez
description: ANNABELLA GONZALEZ seems fascinated by objects. The stranger the objects are, the better she seems to like them. Certainly, Monday's performance by the Annabella Gonzalez Dance Theater at the Theater of the Open Eye was most interestine when there were bizarre objects on stage that could be manipulated in an equally bizarre manner.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NEW KEY There's always advance interest in a new theater project of the unpredictable Arthur Kopit, whose Wings is winging in toward Broadway after its downtown success at the Public Theater.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1978

title: Article 2 -- No Title
description: DO NOT FORGET THE NEEDIEST!

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Deaths
description: duVIGNEAUD  Vincent . The trustees. faculty, Matt and students of The Rockefeller University, note with great sorrow the death of Dr. Vincent duVigneaud. Trustee Emeritus of the University, and ex. tends deepest sympathy to his family. Patrick E. Haggerty, Chairmen of the Board Joshua Lederberg. President

title: F.B.I. Investigating Amtrak
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP)  The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it was investigating charges fraud involving Amtrak. The bureau said the investigation began a couple of months ago and deals primarily with Amtrak's $1.8 billion improvement project of the Northeast corridor.

title: Coal Town Hangs On, Finds It's Booming
description: GRUNDY, Va., Dec. 13  At the side of U.S. Highw'ay 460 near here, Steven Osborne sells house trailers in the air.

title: Jet Teammates Vote Walker the M.V.P.
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 13  When Wesley Walker is excited, he speaks almost as rapidly as he runs. So the secondyear wide receiver, who has been clocked at 4.35 seconds for the 40yard dash, was far from speechless today after having been voted the Jets' most valuable player by his teammates.

title: Fay Compton, British Actress, 84.
description: Fay Compton, a British actress whose career on stage and in films spanned 70 years, died Tuesday at the age of 84.

title: Additions to Staff Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  Administration officials confirmed today that the staff of the United States Embassy in Teheran had been bolstered in recent days. But the officials denied that the new arrivals were military or internal security experts.

title: McGovern Sees Angolan Leader And Discusses Pullout of Cubans
description: LUANDA, Angola, Dec. 13  President Agostinho Neto of Angola told Senator George McGovern, today that he would have no further need for Cuban troops if incursions and threats from South Africa were ended.

title: Trust Fund Set For Food Fair
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge authorized yesterday the establishment of a 125 million trust fund to foster extension of credit to financially ailing Food Fair lnc.

title: Haitian Account of Resorts Bribery Is Unsubstantiated, Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  New Jersey authorities, who are counting on a former Haitian businessman to link their state's only casino operator to alleged bribe attempts in Haiti a few years ago, may be disappointed, law enforcement sources said here today.

title: Chinese Protest Strongly to Hanoi on New Clashes
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 13 Saying that its patience was limited, the Chinese Government issued a strong protest to Vietnam today over further clashes on their border and in the Gulf of Tonkin.

title: Amy Carter to Ski in Colorado
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 13 (AP)  Amy Carter will spend part of her Christmas vacation skiing at Crested Butte, Colo., the White House said today. President Carter's 11yearold daughter will travel to Colorado for the second year in a row with the family of Jim Bishop of St. Simon's Island, Ga. Mr. Bishop is a friend of Mr. Carter.

title: Carter Calls Cairo Very Generous
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UPI) President Carter said tonight that President Anwar elSadat of Egypt had been very generous in accepting a timetable for future Middle East talks initially proposed by Israeli negotiators, but that Israel was now reluctant to accept it.

title: Flames 5, Wings 5
description: DETROIT, Dec. 13 (AP)  Guy Chouinard's second goal of the game, with one second to play, capped a furious Atlanta rally tonight as the Flames erased a 53 deficit and salvaged a 55 National Hockey League tie with the Detroit Red Wings.

title: B52 Launches Missile
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 13 (AP)  An unarmed shortrange attack missile was successfully launched from an Air Force B52 aircraft over the Atlantic Ocean this morning. The missile is 14 feet long and 18 inches in diameter. For the test, it carried a dummy warhead. In operation, it would carry a nuclear one.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Entertainment Events
description: BALLROOM, a musical. Book by Jerome Kass. based on Queen of the Stardust Ballroom; music by Billy Goldenberg; lyrics by Alan and Marilyn Bergman; directed and choreographed by Michael Bennett; starring Dorothy Loudon and Vincent Gardenia. At the Maiestic Theater. 245 West 44th Street. at 6:45.

title: EGYPTIANS ACCLAIM CARTER PEACE ROLE
description: CAIRO, Dec. 13Some prematurely battered buses that hurry along the shady roads of the Nile Delta, courtesy of the United States aid program, have been dubbed Carter buses by villagers.

title: COMMODITIES
description: The wheat futures market collapsed yesterday in what one analyst called a gigantic break when prices dropped more than 11 cents a bushel at one point during the trading session. That equals about a 3 percent drop in price  a large decline in one day.

title: CARTER OPENS DRIVE ON FEDERAL WASTE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  President Carter outlined a campaign today aimed at increasing efficiency in the Government by attacking fraud more diligently and streamlining regulations dealing with social welfare programs.

title: Koch Lights Christmas Tree
description: Mayor Koch, with help from a group of youngsters, last night lit the city's official Christmas tree, a 53foot balsam fir. This is the darkest month of the year, but in all other ways this is the brightest season of the year, he told a gathering outside City Hall after, the 75member Talent Unlimited High School Chorus had sung Christmas carols.

title: Letter: On New York City's Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: Cowens: 2 Paths to Showers
description: Dave Cowens, the Boston Celtics' playingcoach, was involved in a National Basketball Association rarity Tuesday night in Houston when fouled out of the game as a player and was ejected as the coach.

title: Jury Ponders Verdict in Jockeys' Trial
description: MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Dec. 13 The jury in the trial of six jockeys and three trainers accused of fixing horse races at Garden State Park deliberated for more than three hours here this afternoon without reaching a verdict.

title: Electronic Trading Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  The Cincinnati Stock Exchange, the nation's first allelectronic system of securities trading, won another year's lease on life today as the Securities and Exchange Commission unanimously approved a 12month extension of the exchange's controversial pilot program.

title: U.S.T.A. Serving Indoors
description: In the face of a decline in the demand for indoor tennis courts in the metropolitan area, the National Tennis Center has just opened a ninecourt indoor facilty in twin buildings at Flushing MeadowCorona Park near Shea Stadium in Queens.

title: Ford Says That Congress Hobbles President by Foreign Policy Action
description: WASHNGTON, Dec. 13  Former President Gerald R. Ford said today that Congress had seriously weakened the Presidency by interfering in the conduct of foreign policy.

title: Carter Aide Apologizes for Letter Critical of South Bronx Planning Effort
description: A letter from a White House aide that implied criticism of New York City's planning efforts in the South Bronx  and that seemed to threaten a cutoff of additional Federal funds for the area until there was good, solid planning by the city  touched off anger in City Hall yesterday and brought clarifications from the White House.

title: Financial Woes Force A College in Vermont To Close by Weekend
description: PUTNEY, Vt., Dec. 13 (AP)  Windham College officials announced today that the school was closing. They told jeering students that they would not receive refunds on their tuitions and that they should be off the campus by Saturday.

title: Italian Deputies Vote Money Bloc Entry
description: ROME, Dec. 13 The Italian Parliament today endorsed Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti's decision to enter the European Monetary System. Italy therefore will become a member of the system, led by France and West Germany, at its inception Jan. 1.

title: Oil Price Fears Push. Dow Lower
