description: Takeover tituations provided the stock market with its best gainers yesterday as most issues moved lower in moderate trading. Investor sentiment generally was dampened by fears of record interest rates in 1979 and by prospects of an increase in world oil prices.

title: Record Gasoline Output
description: The nation's gasoline refiners, trying to alleviate a tight supply situation, produced a record amount of the fuel last week, the American Petroleum Institute said yesterday. According to the A.P.I., 7.81 million barrels of gasoline were produced daily, up from 7.77 million barrels a week earlier. Before last week,the record total had been 7.69 million barrels set the week of July 14. The steppedup production combined with lower consumption, as winter weather curtailed driving, to increase the nation's gasoline inventories to. 228.8 million barrels, from 223.6 million barrels the week before.

title: Carey Pushes Forward On Realigning Cabinet
description: ALBANY, Dec. 13The director of the State Division of Alcoholism and Alcohol Abuse reportedly was dismissed yesterday and the director of the Division of Drug and Substance Abuse Services resigned as Governor Carey continued to reshuffle his cabinet.

title: GARDENING
description: BOOKS are as much a part of a good gardener's collection of tools as trowels, hoes and mowers. They supply that extra expertise and often make the difference between success and failure.

title: An Amateur Survives Without a Contractor
description: THE general advice on apartment renovation is that whenever you want major work done, hire a contractor and pray. Contrac ors are notorious for doubling or even tripling the cost of a project, and stories of inferior work, shoddy material and unmet deadlines are an accepted part of the mythology of apartment renovation.

title: Stern, Lauer Dissolving
description: Stern, Lauer & Company, a relatively small, oldline brokerage firm, said yesterday it would dissolve effective Dec. 21 and that some of its partners and employees would become associated with Bear. Stearns & Company.

title: McHargue and Barrera Honored in Horse Racing
description: Darrel McHargue was named jockey of the year and Laz Barrera. won his third straight Eclipse Award as top trainer in thoroughbred racing's annual balloting yesterday.

title: U.S. to Keep up Diplomatic Fight Against a P.L.O. Role In U.N. Aid
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 13 The United States, defeated in a campaign it waged to deny the Palestine Liberation Organization any voice in controlling United Nations economic assistance, said in Washington today that it would continue to oppose any move to channel aid through the guerrilla organization.

title: Administration Urges Newsroom Raid Ban
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  The Carter Administration urged Congress today to prohibit the police from conducting surprise raids on newsrooms or other places in search of notes, photographs or other documents intended for publication.

title: Maheu Announces Plans
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 13  Robert A. Maheu, former chief executive of the Howard Hughes gambling empire in Nevada, announced plans today for a multimilliondollar casino hotel here.

title: Paul Michael Barth Marries Marcia de Revere Rainaud
description: Marcia de Revere Rainaud, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Edward Rainaud of Wilmington, Vt., was married yesterday morning to Paul Michael Barth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Allan Barth of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Len Leggett of the First United Presbyterian Church of Pompano Beach, Fla., performed the ceremony at the Sea Garden Beach Club in Pompano Beach.

title: Controversies Still Pursue Departing State Youth Head
description: It is an indication of the fractiousness of the three and a half years Peter B. Edelman has served as director of New York State's Division for Youth that even his resignation will provoke some controversy.

title: Park Contract To Be Ended
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  The National Park Service announced today that it was moving to terminate its contract with the Yellowstone Park Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of the General Host Corporation of Stamford, Conn.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: TORONTO, Dec. 14  The merger investigation branch of the Canadian Government today dropped its inquiry of a proposal by Winnipegbased Hudson's Bay Company to take over Torontobased Simpsons Ltd., both major retail chains.

title: One Glass Show, Two Techniques
description: THE twoman show of John Nygren and Herb Babcock at the Contemporary Art Glass Gallery offers an excellent illustration of contrasting approaches to contempory glassmaking. Both men are products of the booming 16yearold Studio Glass movement and both are well represented in museums for contemporary glass. But there the similarities end.

title: Mona Barry Bride Of Count de Sayve
description: The marriage of Mona Barry of New York to Count Christian de Sayve, an international investment banker with Credit Agricola in Paris, took place yesterday afternoon in St. Edward's Roman Catholic Church in Palm Beach, Fla. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Walter Hartnett and was followed by a reception at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Downey, stepfather and mother of the bride.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec.13  A liberal friend called to say that he had undergone the Great Awakening  a belated realization that heavy Federal spending habits in good times lead directly to hard times  but complained of suffering from a political identity crisis. As a new conservalib, he wanted to know what to read that would cure his cognitive dissonance, making him less of a stranger in a strange, conservative land.

title: Festival of Rumanian Music Starts
description: THE singing was remarkably fine at the Rumanian Festival concert Tuesday night at the Beacon Theater, but under such disorienting circumstances that it wasn't really. very rewarding to listen to.

title: Borrowing Of Marks Is Big Success
description: BONN, Dec. 13  The United States Government's first public offering of bonds denominated in a foreign currency is a huge success. The $1.5 billion issue has been oversubscribed by almost $3 billion.

title: TV: Series On Cancer Of Breast
description: I WAS in the bathtub one night, and I found this little lump. So my immediate reaction was, No, no, no  it's nothing. It's no lump. So for two weeks I waited.

title: Jazz: Barbara Carroll at the Piano
description: BARBARA CARROLL, who has settled into the Bemelmans Bar at the Hotel Carlyle, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, as resident pianist (a situation Marian McPartland filled for several years), has been one of the elect among jazz pianists for more than 20 years. But now she has shaped and polished her approach and technique to a particularly fine degree.

title: Money
description: WEDNESDAY. DEC. 13, 1978

title: Rules to Curb Abuses By Vocational Schools Are Issued by F.T.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP)  The Government today issued regulations intended to protect students against fraud and deception by private vocational schools. Leaders in the industry warned that the new rules could raise tuition costs by 50 percent.

title: 3 Concerns In Private Placements
description: Three corporations disclosed yesterday that they were raising a total of $260 million by selling fixedincome securities directly to institutional investors. The financings pointed up the usual increase in private placements completed each December, but they also may have marked the beginning of more activity in this part of the capital markets.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Financial Corporation, a Cincinnatibased diversified financial holding company, has elected to its board of directors Charles E. Woodruff, retired vice chairman and director of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, and Bart A. Brown Jr., a principal in the law firm of the Brown & Gardner Company, Cincinnati.

title: 21Year Sentence in Rape Case
description: Nickola Lekutanag, a 31yearold resident of the Bronx, Was sentenced yesterday to 21 years in prison for raping a visitor from St. Louis three hours after she arrived in New York City. Justice Joseph D. Quinn Jr. ruled in State Supreme Court that Mr. Lekutanag must serve at least seven years before becoming eligible for parole. Mr. Lekutanag was convicted Nov. 3 for the November 1977 crime.

title: 2 Triple Satellites Are Launched In 3Way Communication Effort
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 13 (AP)  Twin Triple 7 satellites were launched tonight as part of a secret communications network for United States, British and North Atlantic Treaty Organization armed forces.

title: Designing A New Home for The Big Mac
description: OAK BROOK, ILL. THIS is just a house, but it is subversive  it is trying to tell us that McDonald's has taken over the entire culture, said Stanley Tigerman, the Chicago architect, as he looked at a postersize sketch of a clapboard farmhouse with a big front porch, propped up in the conference room of the headquarters of McDonald's, the hugefastfood company, in this Chicago suburb.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) 7470600; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: Philip Morris Plans Tower At 42d Street
description: Philip Morris Inc., which has grown from a midsized tobacco company in the 1950's to an international conglomerate expecting revenues of $6 billion this year, will build a new headquarters at the southwest corner of Park Avenue and 42d Street, opposite Grand Central Terminal.

title: IRAN'S EXILE LEADER WARNS WEST ON OIL
description: PARIS, Dec. 13  In a warning aimed at President Carter's support for the Shah, the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini said today that the United States and other countries risked being cut off from Iranian oil if the religiousled opposition movement reached power.

title: DELAYS ON WESTWAY ASSAILED BY ADAMS IN CALL FOR ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  Transportation Secretary Brock Adams, seeking to break an impasse that has held up approval of the Westway highway project in New York City, has assailed as appalling the actions of a Federal enviromental official in New York City who is opposing the project.

title: Controllers and 2 Pilots Blamed For Aerial Collision Fatal to Six
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP)  Air traffic controllers and the pilots aboard the planes were to blame for the aerial collision of two aircraft near the Memphis airport last spring in which six people were killed, the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

title: Bond Prices Recover After Loss
description: The credit markets recovered partially late yesterday afternoon from an early price decline as traders apparently were cheered by news that the Treasury is going to do less financing this month than they had supposed.

title: New Jersey's RentControl Muddle
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court has provided some badly needed guidance for the state's crazy quilt of rentcontrol laws. In a case challenging Fort Lee's ordinance, the court ruled that owners and landlords are entitled to a fair return on their investments. Moreover, the court sensibly said that volunteerrun rent leveling boards, like the one in Fort Lee, cannot adequately do their job without a professional staff.

title: Rehearsal Club Weighs Closing
description: Officials of the 65yearold Rehearsal Club, a residence for women seeking to establish performingarts careers, are studying whether to close or to undertake a costly appeal of a ruling last week by the tax commission that it should no longer be exempt from payinst realestate taxes.

title: A NoNonsense Envoy Counsels the U.S. from Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 13  When the United States Ambassador to Moscow, Malcolm Toon, accompanied a group of senators to a meeting in the Kremlin last month, Prime Minister Aleksei N. Kosygin shook the envoy's hand, grinned and said, So you've come with the senators  what's the matter, don't you trust them alone?

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UPI)  The National Conference of Catholic Bishops announced today that Roman Catholics in America would be allowed to take both bread and wine at communion at ordinary masses, at the option of each diocese's bishop.

title: Home VideoDisk Unit Offered
description: After nearly a decade of promises and false starts, a videodisk homeplayback system that attaches to a television set and plays prerecorded movies and other programs is finally coming to market.

title: Reserve Units on Alert in Israel
description: JERUSALEM, Dec.13  Selected reserve units of the Israeli defense forces were called up today as part of a mobilization exercise.

title: Ohio River Is Still on the Rise; Flood Deaths Are Put at Three
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 13 (UPI)  Ohio River floodwaters churned downstream today and headed for a crest nine feet above flood stage at Louisville, Ky., after peaking six feet above the flood line at Cincinnati.

title: 2 Suspects in Stabbing Of Scottish Designer Not Picked in Lineups
description: The partner of a Scottish fashion designer stabbed to death in an apparent robbery attempt by two youths in the Tribeca section of Lower Manhattan last week did not identify either of the suspects charged with the crime in two separate lineups at the Manhattan District Attorney's office yesterday.

title: Soviet Election Set for March 4
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 13, Reuter  Elections to the Supreme Soviet, the nominal parliament, will be held March 4, it was announced today. Voters in Soviet elections approve a single list of 1,517 candidates drawn up by the authorities and drop the ballots into a box.

title: The Joy of Cutting Your Own Tree
description: IN 1851, it is said, a man named Mark Carr started the first commercial Christmas tree operation in New York City when he brought two horsedrawn sleds laden with pines into Manhattan during the holiday season.

title: Poland to Cut Manager Ranks
description: WARSAW, Dec. 13 (Reuters)  About 30,000 Polish office administrators will be transferred to other work next year in a move to get rid of superfluous bureaucrats, a Warsaw newspaper reported today. Various directors, deputy directors, chiefs and managers are springing up like the proverbial mushrooms after rain, said the daily Slowo Powszechne. We even have the nonsensical situation of offices and institutions in which the managers outnumber the managed.

title: Nastase Wins, 65, 64, In Challenge Cup Match
description: MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, Dec. 14 (UPI)  Ilie Nastase evened his record at one victory and one loss today in the World Championship of Tennis challenge cup competition with a 65, 64 victory over Dick Stockton.

title: Growth in Money Supply Continues to Slow Down
description: The credibility of the Federal Reserve's effort to fight inflation was reinforced yesterday as the. central bank reported a continuing slowdown in the rate of growth of the nation's money supply.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Film Studio To Consent To Offer
description: Columbia Pictures Industries said yesterday that it would consent to a proposed offer by Kirk Kerkorian, the movie executive, to buy a 20 percent interest in the company for $42 million in cash.

title: Ford Bids U.S. Rescind Fuel Rules
description: DETROIT, Dec. 19  The Ford Motor Company, arguing that existing auto fuel economy rules may kill the sixpassenger family car by the mid1980's, today called on the Government to roll back rules on the books for the period through 1985, and to postpone indefinitely any new longerterm standards.

title: U.S. Urged to Push Iran Coalitions
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14  George W. Ball has presented the Carter Administration with several options for easing the current crisis in Iran, including a broadbased coalition government that would include Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, Administration sources said tonight.

title: Hearst Buys Texas Papers
description: The Hearst Corporation has announced it has entered into agreements to purchase for an undisclosed amount two Texas daily newspapers  The Midland ReporterTelegram and The Plainview Daily Herald. 13oth newspapers are published afternoons and Sundays. The Midland ReporterHerald has circulations of 21,000 daily and 23,000 Sunday, while The Plainview Daily Herald is a 10,000 daily and Sunday newspaper.

title: Screen: 2 at the Thalia
description: BETWEEN the time when Lamont Johnson directed the brilliantly economical "The Last American Hero" and then moved on to direct Margaux Hemingway and Farrah Fawcett-Majors in their screen debuts ("Lipstick" and "Somebody Killed Her Husband," respectively), he made an interesting departure: "Visit to a Chief's Son," a 1974 adventure film set in Africa, among the Masai tribe. Previously unreleased, it opens today at the Thalia on a double bill with "Homebodies," another unreleased film from 1974."Visit to a Chief's Son" is based on the experiences of Robert Halmi, who journeyed to Africa as a photographer for Life magazine, wrote a book about his trip, then went on to produce a film about it.Accordingly, one might suppose the character based on Mr. Halmi would be an attractive and sympathetic one. But no: The anthropologist named Robert who visits Kenya with his adolescent son has surprisingly little respect for or understanding of the natives, and when he and the boy retreat to their own camp they take American-style showers and drink Coca-Cola. Indeed, when the son makes friends with a Masai boy his own age, the first thing young Kevin teaches young Kodoyno is how to shake up a soda bottle and douse somebody with the spray.With the notable exception of Johnny Sekka, who plays the chief of the title with a welcome cynicism and a winning smile, the non-Masai actors barely hold the screen. But they are upstaged by some remarkable scene-stealers: baby hippos, baby elephants, exotic birds and a lake that seems covered with flamingos, from shore to shore. The rest of the film plays like a relatively transparent pretext for the wildlife footage, but the animal shots are spectacular, and there are a great many of them  more than enough to be worth the price of admission.The most appealing thing about "Homebodies" is its premise. A band of old people in Cincinnati decide they don't like young people, especially the young people who are trying to evict them from their condemned apartment building, which is being torn down to make room for more skyscrapers.So they begin defending themselves, disposing of an ill-tempered social worker and a greedy builder and anyone else who gets in their way. Eventually, they declare war on one another, and at this juncture the film loses its quotient of dotty charm. Without their sense of common purpose, they're not a particularly appealing bunch, and in any case Larry Yust, the director, isn't able to hold these two halves of the film together."Homebodies" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It contains some fairly routine violence, plus a scene involving the amputation of a dead man's foot.

title: Kaunda Assured of Victory in Zambian Vote
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 14 (Reuters)  Kenneth D. Kaunda was assured today of a fourth term as Zambia's President, maintaining the dominant position he has held in the nation's political life since independence from Britain 14 years ago.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Killer Bee Honey Is Latest Novelty Counter Nectar
description: Like many architects of entrepreneurial schemes, the plotters of this venture are convinced they have a sweet idea. And they are certain that many New Yorkers, with their penchant for the latest novelty, will swarm to buy it.

title: Lawyer Questions Mental Stability Of Cultist Accused of Killing Ryan
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 14 The lawyer for Larry Layton, the People's Temple member accused of murdering Representative Leo J. Ryan, Democrat of California, raised questions today about his client's mental stability seemingly taking the first step in attempting to establish a defense on the ground of insanity.

title: Deaths
description: KOSMANSamuel. The officers and directors of the American Technion Society are deeply grieved by the death of an esteemed colleague and friend. A member of the National Board of Directors and President of the Greater Miami Chapter of the American Technion Society, Mr. Kosman played a signal role in support of higher education as a bulwarts of Israel's viability and secur ity. We extend our heartfelt cot dolences to his family.

title: Store Owner Sought in Killing
description: A bench warrant was issued yesterday for the arrest of a 24yearold Bronx store owner who jumped $15,000 in bail after being charged with fatally shooting a teenager who had thrown a snowball at his store, at 169 East 205th Street. The warrant was issued after the defendant, Dede Nikollaj, failed to make a routine appearance in court.

title: S.E.C. Cites Bank Over Disclosure
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14  In a civil complaint filed today in Federal court, the Securities and Exchange Commission said that bank holding companies must disclose to shareholders significant violations of banking law or unsafe and unsound practices cited In traditionally secret bank examination reports.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: OTB to Show Gulfstream Races
description: New York City's Offtrack Betting Corporation picked up a few lengths yesterday in the race to put horse racing on closedcircuit television.

title: Merger of Simpsons In Canada Approved
description: TORONTO, Dec. 14  The struggle for supremacy among Canadian department stores appears to have been won by Simpsons Ltd. and its corporate cousin, SimpsonsSears Ltd. Their proposed merger was approved today by the Canadian Government.

title: Tandberg of Norway Declared to Be Bankrupt
description: OSLO, Dec. 14 (AP)  After only nine months of state ownership, Tandberg Radio and Television of Norway, once the flagship of the country's electronics industry, has been declared bankrupt and was placed under court administration today.

title: Fed Report On Trade Zone
description: The Federal Reserve Board, in its first public pronouncement on the proposed banking free trade zone in New York, issued yesterday a statement discussing the issues raised by the proposal.

title: Christmas Events This Weekend
description: 1. West Village Chorale and Chamber Singers at St. Luke's Chapel, 487 Hudson Street. Sunday at 4 P.M.

title: Events and Openings
description: Friday

title: Kennedy HealthInsurance Hearing Is Held in Queens
description: Connie Jackson had Blue Cross and Blue Shield and major medical insurance, but the medicals bills for her daughter's asthma were so costly that she filed for bankruptcy.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Musick's Handmaid, Four Pieces, Purcell; Chanson Triste for Double Bass and Piano, Koussevitzky; Motet, Jubilate Deo omniS terra, Morales; Legende, Wieniawski.

title: Connecticut Plant to Move
description: PUTNAM, Conn., Dec. 14 (AP) The American Optical Corporation said yesterday that it would move its 400employee safetyproducts operation in Putnam to its main plant in Southbridge, Mass. The company, which has had plant in Putnam for 37 years, said 95 percent of its employees here would be offered jobs in Southbridge.

title: City Must Close Some Hospitals, Koch Aide Says.
description: Philip L. Toia, the Deputy Mayor for Financial Management, said yesterday that some municipal hospital closings are inevitable if New York is to survive its current fiscal crisis.

title: Colleges Mystified by Title IX Fund Rules
description: Officials of both men's and women's college athletic programs remained confused about Title IX regulations a week after the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare attempted to clarify the issue by announcing prooposed guidelines for compliance with the Federal law banning sex discrimination in intercollegiate athletics.

title: Shortages Of Jet Fuel Are Feared
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14  A threat of spot shortages in fuel for jet aircraft has developed because of, rising demand from airlines that are opening new routes, according to officials of the airlines, the oil industry and the Department of Energy.

title: Charge Filed in Dodge Trust Case
description: The former wife of an heir to the Dodge Motor Company fortune was indicted in Manhattan yesterday on charges of looting $390,000 from her 24yearold son's trust fund.

title: Egorov Bows at Carnegie
description: If Van Cliburn became music's most celebrated competition winner 20 years ago, Youri Egorov, the Russianborn pianist who makes his Carnegie Hall debut at 8 P.M. tomorrow night, may well have become its most celebrated loser.

title: Business and the Law
description: JOEL DOLKART was a prosperous Wall Street lawyer when he was accused of stealing more than $2.5 million from two firms. He was spared a substantial taste of prison life last year because he cooperated with the Manhattan district attorney's office and other law enforcement authorities investigating Gulf & Western Industries, the conglomerate where he had served as director and general counsel.

title: Space Probe Supports Venus Greenhouse Theory
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Dec. 14Measurements taken by spacecraft in the atmosphere of Venus support the theory that a runaway greenhouse effect could account for the planet's searing surface heat, Pioneer Venus project scientists reported today.

title: Another College For South Bronx Is Voted by State
description: ALBANY, Dec. 14  Over the objections of Hostos Community College, the. Board of Regents today approved the esbranch campus fora suburban college.

title: Deaths
description: BISHOPSidney H. Beloved husband of Sophie. Loving father of Steve and Harold. Cherished grandfather of Ira, Eileen, Laura and David Brother of Ruth David. Service. Friday, 9:45 AM, at Temple Ema nuEl, Ross Plaza, Lynbrook, N.Y.

title: Romance, Fantasy and Violence Arrive on Local Screens
5 jockeys Guilty in Race Fix
description: MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Dec. 14 Five jockeys and two trainers accused of fixing horse races at Garden State Park four years ago were found guilty tonight after a 10week trial based largely on testimony supplied by Anthony (Big Tony) Ciulla. Two other defendants, a jockey and a trainer, were acquitted by a Burlington County jury in State Superior Court.

title: Fingerprints Are Found in Lufthansa Robbery Van
description: Fingerprints were found yesterday on the van used by armed bandits to carry off $5 million in cash and $850,000 in jewelry from the Lufthansa cargo area at Kennedy International Airport early Monday morning.

title: Chile May Take Dispute to O.A.S.
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 14  Chile is preparing to accuse Argentina before the Organization of American States of threatening regional peace with its military buildup and hostile statements over disputed islands at the tip of the continent, diplomatic sources say.

title: Coroner's Jury and a Cult Survivor Visit the Death Scene at Jonestown
description: JONESTOWN, Guyana, Dec. 14  The coroner's inquest into the deaths of more than 900 members of the People's Temple shifted to the scene of the Nov. 18 killings today, and for the most Dart it was a tour.

title: Burger Suggests an Aide for Administrative Relief
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14  Chief Justice Warren E. Burger suggested today that a new Supreme Court position, that of circuit justice for administration, be created to relieve him of administrative duties that he described as increasingly burdensome.

title: Fordham Beaten by Princeton
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 14  John Lewis, a senior guard, scored 10 points in the second half, including four free throws in the final minute, as Princeton rallied from a 13point deficit and defeated Fordham, 3837. tonight.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, DEC. 14, 1978

title: Absentees' Ballots Were Altered In '76 Primary, Jersey Panel Told
description: TRENTON, Dec. 14  Democratic officials from North Bergen told the State Commission of Investigation today that absentee ballots in a close Congressional primary in 1976 were steamed open and corrected in the local party chairman's kitchen.

title: 2 Arenas Compete for Boxing Fans
description: According to Gil Clancy, the Madison Square Garden matchmaker, Gerald Cooney is the best young heavyweight prospect in the world. Clancy based his assessment on the fact that the managers of at least 22 other heavyweights turned down an eightround match against Cooney.

title: Dance: Littler & Littler
description: PROGRAM notes can make difference. Anyone who saw Liz Pasquale's Littler and Littler without reading the program notes might have been mystified by what went on. For this work, performed Wednesday night at the Third Street Music School by the Amazing Shrinking Dance Company, looked like nothing more than a miscellaneous collection of scenes.

title: Rumanian, Daring Abroad, Is Repressive at Home
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, Dec. 11 Bread shortages have caused lines to form in front of bake shops of late for the first time in years, and taxi drivers are being restricted to four gallons of gasoline a day.

title: U.S. Says It Sends Iran Only Few Extra Aides
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14  The State and Defense Departments both said today that they had sent only a Sinail number of extra people to Iran to assist American or Iranian officials with problems related to the crisis there.

title: Bridge:
description: For New York bridge enthusiasts add many further afield, the 1978 tournament year reaches its climax at the New York Hilton Hotel with the Winter Regional Championships beginning today.

title: Panel Is Sifting Charges Of Brink's Job Payoffs
description: BOSTON, Dec. 14  A Federal grand jury is investigating allegations of payoffs to reputed figures in organized crime connected with the making of the movie The Brink's Job, according to Gerald McDowell, head of the New England Organized Crime Task Force.

title: Cites Commitment
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14  Amid mounting Congressional skepticism over the Carter Administration's spending plans for the coming fiscal year, the Presildent said tonight that he would stand by his commitment to raise the defense budget by approximately 3 percent.

title: Design in Light and Shadow
description: Lower Manhattan's lively juxtaposition of architectural styles is made especially clear in this view, looking southwest down Park Row in Chinatown.

title: N.F.L.Statistics
description: AMERICAN CONFERENCE RUSHING

title: Cleveland at the Brink Of Default as Lender Objects to Fiscal Plan
description: CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 14  This oncethriving industrial city moved to the brink of fiscal default today. City officials failed to reach a consensus on how to pay off $15.5 million in shortterm loans due by the close of business tomorrow, and major lender notified the city late today of its objections to the Mayor's proposals to prevent default.

title: Market Place
description: Aprinting press concern. R. Hoe & Company, which was forced into receivership by its creditors in 1969, finally emerged from bankruptcy last spring  as a manufacturer of saw blades.

title: I. R. S. Raids Studio 54; 5 Ounces of Cocaine Seized
description: Armed with a search warrant obtained by a strike force against organized crime, agents of the Internal Revenue Service raided the highly popular Studio 54 discothque yesterday, carting off books, records and filing cabinets.

title: At the Movies
description: THE audience told me what it wanted in The Brink's Job,  William Friedkin, the director, was saying the other day.I know because I previewed it. That's something I didn't do with The Exorcist or The French Connection or any other picture I've made.

title: TaxFree Bond Yields Rebound
description: The taxexempt bond market, emerging from its steepest decline in four months, appeared to stabilize yesterday as Pennsylvania and Rhode Island sold major bond issues that carried yields high enough to attract investors.

title: Research Ship Missing After Sailing to Hawaii
description: HONOLULU, Dec, 14 (UPI)  Rescue planes searched the Pacific Ocean south of Hawaii today for a University of Hawaii research vessel with nine men aboard that disappeared in rough weather on a trip between two Hawaiian islands.

title: Ski Reports
description: (All ski areas are operating on very limited terrain. Figures in parentheses show total trails and number open at each area.)

title: Traffic in New York Can Drive Some People Crazy
description: The lights flash red and green near Herald Square. Some are Christmas decorations, some are traffic lights. They ,seem to have an equal effect on the cars weaving and shooting through the intersection.

title: Blumenthal Defends High Rates
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14  The Carter Administration, underlining an informal understanding with the independent Federal Reserve System, said today that monetary policy had to dovetail with tight fiscal policy and served notice that interest rates must be kept high until inflation has been brought under control.

title: Opera: Electric Tosca
description: IT promised to be a big night at the Metropolitan Opera. Shirley Verrett was singing the title part in Tosca on Wednesday night with Luciano Pavarotti as Cavaradossi, both of them trying on those roles for the first time in that house. Moreover, it was the season's first performance of Puccini's tale of spies, sex and violence in occupied Rome, A.D. 1800, and the production had been restaged by Tito Gobbi, before whom all Rome really did tremble when he used to portray the villainous Scarpia in this opera.

title: CARTER SAYS TREATY IS UP TO ISRAEL NOW; U.S. MAY CURB ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14  Expressing acute frustration over the latest snag in IsraeliEgyptian peace negotiations, President Carter said today that it now was up to Israel to accept or reject the projected treaty.

title: Art: A Poet's Spirit Graces the Whitney
description: THE exhibition that opened this week at the Whitney Museum of American Art under the title, William Carlos Williams and the American Scene, 19201940, is an unusual event. It is an art exhibition based on the career of a writer. On its walls, therefore, are almost as many words to read as there are pictures to look at. Fortunately, the words are mostly those of a highly accomplished poet.

title: Restaurants
description: SMALL, intimate and atmospheric restaurants have long been a Greenwich Village specialty, and in recent months the roster of snug, inviting dining places has been increased by at least half a dozen. Two of the more charming and interesting newcomers are practically around the corner from each other, just a little, west of Hudson Street. The Black Sheep on West 11th Street is the quintessentially romantic, Bohemian restaurant the kind that those of us who grew up in the Village used to search out and cherish. Its roughfinished brick walls, candlelight, casual flower arrangements, hanging bunches of dried herbs, old kitchen stove  on Which desserts are displayed  and its wildly decorative paintings of fruits and vegetables all promise casual hardy cooking at moderate prices. That is just what this informal, unpretentious place delivers.

title: Rent a Pen Money Aids Neediest
description: Students in the seventhgrade social studies classes of the Lawrence Junior High School on Long Island began a rent a pen service in 1970, through which forgetful students can borrow pens for a penny per classroom period. As a result, contributions of $813.64 have been received by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Rhodesian Bombers Humiliate Zambia
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 14  When Rhodesia first bombed guerrilla camps deep in Zambia, the pilot of a Rhodesian fighter plane circled the Lusaka airport for half an hour. Calling himself Green Leader and speaking in a tone that white Rhodesians use in giving orders to their servants, he broadcast warnings to the control tower to keep Zambian aircraft grounded.

title: The Region
description: Three youths who pleaded guilty to charges of robbing an elderly couple in their Hempstead, L. I., home last October were sentenced by Judge Edward A. Baker in Nassau County Court.

title: Screen: It's a Bird, It's a Plane, It's a Movie
description: IN a season in which our motion-picture comic strips have been either heavily mythic ("The Lord of the Rings") or simply pretentious ("Watership Down"), "Superman" is good, clean, simple-minded fun, though it's a movie whose limited appeal is built in. There isn't a thought in this film's head that would be out of place on the side of a box of Wheaties. But to describe as good, clean, simple-minded fun a film on which so much effort, time and talent have been expended is to sound a muted warning.To enjoy this movie as much as one has a right to expect, one has either to be a Superman nut, the sort of trivia expert who has absorbed all there is to know about the planet Krypton, or to check one's wits at the door, which may be more than a lot of people are prepared to do for longer than two hours.The Superman comic strip has been carefully, elaborately, sometimes wittily blown up for the big-theater screen, which, though busy, often seems sort of empty. In Christopher Reeve, a young New York stage and television actor who plays Superman and Clark Kent, the mild-mannered newspaper reporter who is Superman's cover, the producers and Richard Donner, the director, have a performer who manages to be both funny and comic-strip heroic without making a fool of himself. Mr. Reeve even looks like something drawn on an easel, being composed entirely of firm lines without a bit of shading. Margot Kidder is also most charming, revealing (is this for the first time?) that Lois Lane is the sort of newspaper reporter who puts two p's in rapist.The supporting cast is of a caliber one might otherwise expect to see only at fund-raising events for American Indians, the American Film Institute or the March of Dimes. Marlon Brando turns up early in the saga as Superman's dad, Jor-El, who looks rather like George Washington with chrome finish on his hair. Glenn Ford has two scenes as Superman's adopted earth-father.Gene Hackman, Ned Beatty and Valerie Perrine play the members of the evil trio whose attempts to destroy California (by activating the San Andreas fault) form what might be called the plot. Jackie Cooper plays the harried editor of The Daily Planet, and a number of other major actors, including Terence Stamp, Susannah York, Harry Andrews, Trevor Howard and Maria Schell, play roles so small the actors should wear numbers for immediate identification.This kind of casting is prodigal but it is an essential element in a film in which extravagance is the dominant style.The screenplay appears to have been composed by a unisex basketball team  Mario Puzo, who is credited with the original story; David Newman, Leslie Newman (who is the wife of David) and Robert Benton, who in 1966 wrote a Broadway musical about Superman with Mr. Newman. Tom Mankiewicz receives credit as creative consultant, but, because he is a writer, I assume he might also have written a line or two.There have been a number of published statements by people connected with the film to the effect that the Superman legend has been treated without condescension, not as camp, which is more or less true, though the movie's brightest moments are those very broad ones supplied by Mr. Hackman, Mr. Beatty and Miss Perrine, whose bosom submits to her bodice only with a fight. Their comic moments recall the best of the old Batman television series.For all intents and purposes Mr. Brando plays it straight, applying to Krypton's most brilliant scientist a neo-English accent and a mock gravity that are funny because he's the actor he is.The movie does nothing lightly or quickly. After opening credits that are so portentous they could be announcing the discovery of a new mouthwash, the film spends what seems to be an interminable amount of time (approximately an hour) on Krypton explaining the planet's domestic problems (worse than but not as complicated as Iran's) and Superman's heritage, a sequence climaxed by the destruction of Krypton. The rest of the movie proceeds at the panel-by-panel pace of a comic strip, with Superman/Clark Kent's courting of Lois Lane and fighting for "truth, justice and the American way."The special effects are mostly very good, especially the montages in which we see Superman flying faster than a speeding bullet, saving trains, buses, airplanes (Air Force One) from untimely crashes, or just taking Lois Lane for an evening's spin over New York."Superman," which opens today at Loews Astor Plaza and other theaters, doesn't transcend its origins, as "Star Wars" did, but it never means to. For me it's as if somebody had constructed a building as tall as the World Trade Center in the color and shape of a carrot. Rabbits might admire it. They might even write learned critiques about it and find it both an inspiration and a reward, while the rest of us would see nothing but an alarmingly large, imitation carrot."Superman," which has been rated PG ("parental guidance suggested"), contains two (according to my count) harmless double-entendres.

title: Around the Nation
description: GOLDEN, Colo., Dec. 14 (AP)  Unofficial returns tonight showed that production and maintenance workers at the Adolph Coors Company voted to end 42 years of union representation at the brewery, which makes Coors beer.

title: Article 5 -- No Title
description: REMEMBER THE NEEDIESTI

title: Vance Makes Brief Visit to a West Bank Area
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 14  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance made a brief visit to Bethlehem in the occupied West Bank before leaving for Egypt today.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: HENRY B. LUST

title: For Children
description: YOUNG PEOPLE'S CONCERT, by the Hudson Valley Symphony, conducted by Louis F. Simon, on Sunday at 2 P.M., with soloist Stella Han, pianist and winner of the symphony's 1970 Youth Concerto Contest, at Sleepy Hollow High School, North Broadway, North Tarrytown. Admission, $1.50. Information: (914) 7694935 or (914) RO 10152.

title: English Music at Hunter
description: Twentiethcentury British chamber music, including works by Elizabeth Maconchy, William Allwyn, John Ireland and John Addison, will be performed tonight at 8 P.M. in the Hunter College Playhouse, East 68th Street, between Park and Lexington Avenues. The musicians are the Boehm Wind Quintette, the Franklin String Quartet, Nancy Allen, harpist, Peter Gordon, horn player, and Stephen Erdody, cellist. Tickets are $5 ($3 for students and the elderly). Information: 6287000.

title: U.N. Assembly Urges Ban on Arms to Israel
description: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 14 (Reuters) The General Assembly called on the Security Council today to impose a mandatory arms embargo against Israel and to establish machinery to insure that all states carry it out.

title: Superior Oil Soars 5 Points
description: Superior Oil jumped 5 points yesterday and reached its loftiest price in five years, while the general stock market continued cautiously to mark time.

title: Messiah and Other Oratorios
description: Today

title: Advertising
description: AN Englishlanguage version of Realites, the French monthly review, will reappear again today with a young Belgian marketing man as publisher, a Belfast Irishman as ad director and a bankroll from the Pennsylvania publisher of a magazine for nurses.

title: Topics
description: If we may borrow a little something from astrology, this is the time of year when Money finds itself in the House of Christmas, Greed is on the cusp of Grasp, and Giving is in close conjunction with Taking. Herewith, then, a few starcrossed incidents from around town.

title: Americans in Isfahan Enduring Suspicion of Their Iranian Neighbors
description: ISFAHAN, Iran, Dec. 14  For the Americans in Isfahan, the challenge to the Shah has meant three months of threats, firebombs and constant apprehension about what effect policy changes in Washington might have on the mistrustful Iranians among whom they live and work.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 15, 1978

title: To Washington: Priorities, Please
description: TEL AVIVThe fate of Western society depends to a considerable degree on the United States' alertness and on its defense posture.

title: U.S. Steel Accused By Scrap Tin Buyer
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 19  The United States Steel Corporation has been charged with antitrust violations by a California manufacturer of metal ends for fiber motoroil cans. Merit Ends Inc. charges that U.S. Steel has employed its superior economic power and leverage to unreasonably restrain trade and substantially lessen competition.

title: A Tree Comes to Harlem
description: A National Guard truck bearing a 60foot black spruce on its way to the State Office Building on 125th Street between Lenox and Seventh Avenues. Residents in Harlem contributed 67,922 quarters to purchase the Christmas tree, Walking before the tree were Jean Williams Booker, head of the tree committee, and members, David N. Dinkins, center, City Clerk, and Charles McGregor, the author and actor. This week, Christmas trees were lighted all over the city, among them 29 set up by the Parks Department. Page B3.

title: New York Guide To the Best In Holiday Music
description: F all the Christmas lists that men, women and children have devised over the centuries, none, surely, has been more wildly and wondrously varied than that immortalized in The 12 Days of Christmas. That lively carol documents a beguiling mix of the practical and the useless, the simple and the lavish, the lovely and the absurd  geese alaying, swans aswimming, maids amilking, five gold rings, ladies dancing, lords aleaping and a partridge in a pear tree!

title: Industry Wary on Vows To Obey the Guidelines
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14  For M.O. Lee, chairman of the VF Corporation, a women's wear manufacturer in Reading, Pa., the opportunity was too good to resist. President Carter had written to him and the other heads of the nation's 500 top industrial companies asking them to pledge to comply with the Administration's voluntary price and pay standards.

title: Bruins, Led by Wensink, Set Back Capitals, 5 to 2
description: BOSTON, Dec. 19 (AP)  John Wensink scored his 18th and 19th goals tonight to power the Boston Bruins to a 52 victory over the Washington Capitals.

title: Aides in Suffolk Report a Flaw In Sewer Pipe
description: Suffolk County officials reported yesterday that they had new evidence of structural flaws so serious that they might require replacing the main pipe to the treatment plant of the county's controversial Southwest Sewer District system.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: Below 42d Street

title: Putting a Stop to Surprise Searches
description: The Carter Administration has taken a welcome first step toward shoring up some First Amendment freedoms that suffered severe blows from the Supreme Court last May. In a case involving the Stanford University newspaper, the Court then held that police may conduct surprise searches of newspaper offices for evidence of crime even when the occupants are not themselves suspected of wrongdoing.

title: U.S.Australia Air Fares to Drop
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 14American and Australian negotiators have agreed to let Continental Air Lines fly between the West Coast of the United States and Australia. They have also agreed to cut some fares sharply.

title: Quebec to Seize Mining Company.
description: QUEBEC, Dec. 14  The Quebec government announced tonight that it would expropriate control of Asbestos Corporation from the General Dynamics Corporation of St. Louis.

title: OPEC Action: Effect on U.S.
description: Just about every oil analyst expects the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to raise prices, though not by much, at its meeting, which begins tomorrow in Abu Dhabi.

title: Doctors Hail Reduction In Kidney Surgery Peril
description: BOSTON, Dec. 14 (AP)  New techniques have so dramatically reduced the danger of fatal infection in kidney transplants that the surgery is now an attractive alternative to treatment by dialysis, doctors say.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times Dec. 5 on an Ohio case involving a defendant with 10 distinct personalities erroneously identified the author of the book Sybil as Cornelia B. Wilbur. The book was written by Flora Rheta Schreiber.

title: Press Critic Asks Curb On Papers' Ownership By Large Companies
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP)  Ben H. Bagdikian, a writer and frequent press critic, proposed today that a limit be placed on the ownership of newspapers by large corporations to restrict their control over the industry.

title: New Rule Asked For Controlling Unsafe Wastes
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14  The Environmental Protection Agency proposed today farreaching new rules that for the first time would require pioducers of hazardous waste materials that pose a threat to human health to dispose of them in a safe and approved manner.

title: Massachusetts Mortgage Guide
description: The Massachusetts Banking Department announced yesterday that it was putting out the first shoppers' guide to residential mortgage rates by a state banking agency, adding that its study showed mortgage rates in Massachusetts ranged from 9 to 12.5 percent.

title: Bank Board Clears Use Of Graduated Mortgages
description: WASHINGTON (AP)  The Government today authorized widespread use of a graduated monthly home loan paydent plan that permits lower mortgage payments during the first few years a home buyer owns a house.

title: Frustrations For President
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 14  The Egyptians and Israelis are so close to a peace treaty, and the few remaining issues seem so minor in comparison with the possible benefits, that outsiders express astonishment that a deadlock could develop.

title: Stalled Water Tunnel To Receive Some Work
description: Mayor Koch yesterday awarded $25.6 million contract for 1979 construction work and maintenance on the Third Water Tunnel, the $420 million project that has been virtually halted since 1975 in a dispute on costs.

title: Real Country Dancing Allemandes Right Into Town
description: St. George will slay the Dragon tomorrow night, and in the fray some innocent bystander.may perish. But by the end of the evening, the dead will be revived (though not the Dragon), and everyone will dance in celebration before calling it a night.

title: Wrong Way on Westway
description: The debate over Westway, the highway and development project proposed for a threemile stretch of landfill along the Hudson, has recently taken a nasty turn. Governor Carey, irked by repeated environmental challenges, has called Eckardt Beck, the regional environmental administrator, a lunkhead and urged Washington to muscle Mr. Beck into line  or, perhaps, out of office. Transportation Secretary Brock Adams has obliged by terming Mr. Beck's actions appalling. Mr. Beck, meanwhile, protests that hd must carry out environmental laws and would rather be a lunkhead than a convict. And Mr. Beck's Congressional supporters call the Governor a bully who wants Federal officials to break the law so that dubious project can proceed. This could all be dismissed as posturing for political advantage were it not that both the Governor and Mr. Beck risk overstepping the bounds of authority.

title: 2 Offshore Oil Concerns Fined for Rigging Prices
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 14 (AP)Two giants in the offshore oil industry and six of their top executives were indicted by a Federal grand jury today, accused of conspiring to rig prices and discourage competition.

title: Responsibility Clause
description: An advisory committee of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants asked for public comment yesterday on a proposal that would require corporate management to describe explicitly in annual reports its responsibility as the source of the financial information in all such documents. The proposal follows a recommendation by a study group that found that many stockholders did not understand the separate responsibilities of independent auditors andmanage ment.

title: Salesman Is Guilty in Hijack Plot
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 14 (UPI)  A Federal court jury tonight found Edward J. Mendenhall guilty of wire fraud in a scheme to swindle front money for a plot to hijack a nuclear submarine from its base in New London, Conn.

title: Arab Oil Chiefs Plan to Increase Price by Monday
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates, Dec. 14  Arab oil ministers, arriving here for a meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, said today that the group's 18month freeze on oil Prices would end shortly.

title: Islanders Beat Red Wings, 41; Bossy Streak Ended at 8 Games
description: UNIONDALE, L.I. Dec. 14  Feeling virtually unknown west of the QueensMidtown Tunnel, the team.with hockey's best record, the New York Islanders, showed tonight why no one has beaten them at home this season.

title: Business Council Sees 1979 Growth
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) The Business Council's economic consultants expect real economic growth next year of 2 to 3 percent with an inflation rate of 7.5 to 8 percent.

title: Trainer Nerud Packs It In
description: Dr. Fager was an extraordinary race horse who, at the age of 4, brought off an unprecedented sweep. He was the first in American racing to win four national championships in a single year  horse of the year, handicap champion, sprint champion, grass champion. You may brine your trainer, read the invitation to the awards dinner that the Thoroughbred Racing Association sent to William L. McKnight, Dr. Fager's owner. To McKnight and John Nerud, the trainer, it read like, You may bring your dog.

title: JERSEY JUDGES DUE FOR AN EVALUATION
description: The performance of New Jersey judges will be formally rated under a report card system that is expected to start in the next few months.

title: Striking Pressmen in St. Louis Delay Contract Ratification Vote
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 14 (UPI)  Striking pressmen delayed a ratification vote today on a tentative contract agreement with The St. Louis PostDisnatch.

title: French Art Thieves Seize Painting by Bosch
description: PARIS, Dec. 19  One of the finest paintings by Hieronymus Bosch, The Conjurer, was stolen by two armed men yesterday from the museum of suburban St.GermainenLaye.

title: How to Wish a Million New Yorkers Season's Best
description: Joshua Sapan decided to get his Christmas cards out early this year since he wanted to reach one million New Yorkers and not pay a penny in postage.

title: Salvador de Madariaga Is Dead; Spanish Author in Exile Was 92
description: MADRID, Dec. 14 (Reuters) MADRID, Dec. 14  Salvador de Madariaga, the Spanish author and diplomat, died of a heart disease today in Locarno, Switzerland, a spokesman for the Royal Household here said. Mr. de Madariaga, who was ambassador in Washington in 1931, was 92 years old.

title: Paperworkers Challenge On Pay Plan Countered
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14  The Department of Justice maintained today that a small West Coast union had no legal right to challenge President Carter's antiinflation program of voluntary wage and price guidelines.

title: Television
description: 6:00(4)Media

title: Union Camp Veneer Mill
description: The Union Camp Corporation said yesterday that it planned to build a $13.5 million mill near Thorsby, Ala., to produce 70 million square feet of veneer annually from southern pine. The new mill will have 65,000 square feet of floor space and will occupy a 50acre site. Completion is scheduled for the spring of 1980. Thorsby is about 50 miles north of Montgomery.

title: American Motors Cuts Price of Spirit
description: DETROIT, Dec. 14 (AP)  The American Motors Corporation, whose new Spirit subcompact has failed to halt the company's sales slump, said today that it would cut prices on all three Spirit models by $200, as much as 5.1 percent.

title: Deaths
description: STEINBERGBessie, beloved wife of the late Jackdevoted mother of Ruth Israel, Florin Cohen and Jean Seltzer. Loving grandmother and great grandmother. Sister of Louis and Harry Levitis and the late Gussie Tilow. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, December 17, at 11:15 AM Schwartz Bros  Forest Park Chapels Queens Blvd and 76th Road, Forest Hills NY.

title: Auctions
description: THREE records for antiquities were established yesterday at Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue and 76th Street, in an auction of 19 lots froth the Boston Museum of Fine Arts. An Egyptian limestone figure of a robust man from the Fine Arts pushed the record for antiquities at auction from $260.000 to $280,000. The 31inchtall sculpture from the late Fifth Dynasty (23502290 B.C.) was purchased by a European collector. Stanley Moss, a New York dealer, raised the level for Roman art at auction to $90,000, when he bought a Roman bronze head of a woman, cast in the second century. And Walter Randel, the New York dealer, paid the highest price at auction for ancient gold, when he bid $70,000 for a Sarmatian gold finial, hemispherical in shape, aswirl with inlaid turquoise decoration and about 2,000 years old.

title: U.S. Attorney Said to Have Made Job Offer to Jim Jones Supporter
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 19 (UPI)United States Attorney William Hunter, in charge of the Government's investigation of the People's Temple, once asked Timothy Stoen, then a member of the temple, to become his assistant, The San Francisco Examiner reported today.

title: Oil Companies' Costs Upheld
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14  A Federal court here has upheld the right of oil companies to pass along to their customers more increases in company costs than had previously been allowed.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Meet Red Grooms. That's what the Rockland Center for the Arts in West Nyack is inviting you to do tonight at 9. The artist will be there to show his film Ruckus Manhattan, a visual record of the construction of his environmental sculpture of the same name. The sculpture, which was praised by critics when it was exhibited in New York two years ago, is a threedimensional recreation of Manhattan Island  complete with buildings, subway cars, boat's and people  from Wall Street to Rockefeller Center. Admission is a $2 donation. From New York City; cross the George Washington Bridge and take the Palisades Parkway to Exit 5; go north on Route 303 to Route 59,. east in Nyack and turn right onto Greenbush Road. Information: (914) 3580877.

title: The Pop Life
description: MOST people who were watching the Saturday Night Live television program last week4nd must have been nonplussed by the musical guest, Kate Bush. The musical slot on this show has become perhaps the most soughtafter, prestigious showcase in the nation, and here was a young woman whom hardly anybody in America could have heard of, let alone heard.

title: Airline Beats Valhi in Vote
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 14  Pacific Southwest Airlines won the first round in a proxy fight with Dallasbased Valhi Inc. The dispute is over adoption of corporate amendments proposed by the management of Pacific Southwest. The amendments are designed to make the nation's 12thlargest airline less vulnerable as a takeover target.

title: Concert An AllRussian Evening
description: AS a cello soloist and, more recently, as a conductor, Mstislav Rostropovich has proved abundantly that he speaks the language of late Romanticism. And, since there are no artists more representative of all that the 19th century cherished than Byron and Tchaikovsky, what work could seem more in Mr. Rostropovich's line than Manfred, the symphonic work that the Russian based on the Englishman's epic poem? It was Manfred, one of Tchaikovsky's least often performed largescale pieces, tha,t capped off Mr. Rostropovich's concert last night with the New York Philharmonic.

title: Tension in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 It was an increasingly common scene in this capital as the high drama of the budget unfolded. Ranged around a conferente table, grimfaced as they talked to reporters they had summoned, were the heads of nine major higher education organizations.

title: Music: Some Moderns
description: THERE have been complaints that there is no such thing as good contemporary piano music. And. indeed, it is hard to think of works after Rrokoviev and Poulenc that have entered the repertory. Goodness knows that there is a great deal of piano music composed these days, and the postWebern style was brought to a head by the Second Piano Sonata of Pierre Boulez. But that can scarcely be regarded as a repertory piece. Most of the material for piano written these days is academic stuff  contemporary or conservative as the case may be.

title: Music for the Christmas Season in Churches and Halls
description: Following is a list of some of the special musical presentations and other events planned for the Christmas season at churches and concert halls in the metropolitan area

title: Art: Native Sons At Kennedy Gallery
description: ANY exhibition that calls itself The American View : Art from 1770 to 1978 and has a catalogue that cost $10 has a lot to live up to. What we actually get at the Kennedy Galleries, 90 West 57th Street, through Jan. 6 is a selection from the gallery's stock that is quite acceptable at this stage of the season but might have been more modestly titled (or not titled at all). There are some very good paintings in it, along with others of whom nothing complinientary.,can be said; but neither in terms of consistent quality nor of inspired pertinence does it come up to the implications of its name.

title: Carey Set to Urge Carter To Oust Westway Critic
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14  Governor Carey will ask the White House to remove the Federal Environmental Protection Administration's regional director for New York City because of the director's opposition to the Westway, Mr. Carey's chief of staff said today.

title: 2 Quebec Exiles Reserving Pleas On Kidnapping Charge From '70
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 14  Two former members of an underground group known as the Quebec Liberation Front, who have voluntarily ended an eightyear exile, reserved their plea today after being formally charged with the kidnapping of a British official in October 1970.

title: Jazz: Ron Carter's Cellos
description: WHEN Ron Carter organized a quartet a year and a half ago, it was an unusual group in that half the instrumentation was made up of basses. Mr. Carter, normally a doublebassist, played piccolo bass, a smaller version of the bass that allowed him to assume a predominantly solo role as leader of the group, backed by Kenny Barron. piano, Buster Williams, doublebass, and Ben Riley, drums.

title: The City
description: Two Brooklyn youths accused of murdering a 31yearold fashion designer were indicted on seconddegree murder charges yesterday by a Manhattan grand jury.

title: A National Approach to Saving, Say, a Gabled House
description: Architecture is called the inescapable art, but many of our proudest old buildings do escape from us each year, making way for routine office buildings, rectilinear condominiums or, worse, parking lots.

title: A Little Night Feasting
description: Romance is coming back, Barbara Tober said happily as Jerry Kravat and the Waldorf Astoria orchestra struck up a Strauss waltz. Then Mrs. Tober delightedly added, Ball dresses are coming back! Debutante parties are coming back! Proms are coming back! We're going into a very romantic era. Discos may be popular, but the thrust is definitely toward romance.

title: From Halston, Easy Elegance
description: The shadow of Balenciaga hovers over the Halston collection. Halston denies it, of course. Maybe in the big dresses, he admits grudgingly, referring to, among other things, a perfectly proportioned halterneck black style, its full skirt elevated in front and dipping to the floor at back.

title: TV Weekend
description: ALTHOUGH the weekend schedule is crowded with specials, tonight's outstanding presentation is a standard madefortelevision movie. On ABC at 9, Long Journey Back is inspired by the true story of a highschool girl who loses a leg and her memory in a schoolbus accident and how her family handles her recovery.

title: Israeli Cabinet Meets On Peace Snag Today
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 14  Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that he had called a special Cabinet meeting to discuss the stalemate in negotiations for a peace treaty with Egypt.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: WE are in trouble as early as page 14, when Emir Rodriguez Monegal, a Yale professor of contemporary LatinAmerican literature, tells us:

title: Amherst Group In China Pact
description: HONG KONG. Dec.14 (AP)  A New Yorkbased shipping and finance organization announced here today that it had arrived at an agreement with China to help set up a national communications and dataprocessing system and had proposed tiuildlng hotels in five Chinese cities and in Tibet.

title: Academic Credit for Mormon Classes Is Struck Down
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 14  Mormon Church links to the Utah public school system were dealt a blow today when Federal District Judge Clarence Brimmer of Wyoming upheld several cornplaints Iodged by the American Civil Liberties Union in a suit against the Logan Board of Education and the Utah State Board of Education, among others.

title: Art People
description: IN an enlightened world, public disgrace normally brings stardom with a cluster of media contracts, speaking engagements and the like. But to Bernard Reis, a defendant in the Rothko trial, it brought only ruin of the oldfashioned kind, with bankruptcy and the loss of many friends. And, when the 83yearold accountant died, he was characterized in the obituaries simply as a former executor of the Rothko estate, his passing reported perfunctorily.

title: About Real Estate Rent Collection a Problem At Rehabilitation Projects
description: why would anyone try to do essential rehabilitation on an apartment house when he is unable to collect rents from the tenants who would benefit? Is it sensible to let publicly subsidized rehabilitation costs drift upward because of rent withholding or rent reductions while the rehabilitation is going on?

title: Dubious Foreign Outlays Are Laid to McDonnell
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14  The Securities and Exchange Commission today accused the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the nation's leading defense contractor, of having made $15.6 million in secret payments to promote its foreign sales.

title: 2 New Communication Satellites For Military in Orbit on Schedule
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 14 (UPI)  Air Force scientists got signals from space today showing that a pair of 777 military communications satellites had separated and gone into orbit on schedule 6 hours after liftoff.

title: Plays, Pageantry, Puppetry
description: Today

title: Former Houston Police Chief Is Convicted and 2 ExOfficers Are Indicted
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 14  In the latest of a series of scandals and other troubles involving the Houston Police Department, a former chief was convicted today of extortion and two former policemen were indicted in connection with the shooting death of an 18yearold.

title: Business Records
description: BANKPUPTCY PPOCEEDINGS SOUTHE RNDISTRICT

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Like latterday Marco Polos, the bankers and businessmen continue to wend their way to China, seeking the modern equivalents of spaghetti and gunpowder. One caravan to the Middle Kingdom is headed by Willard C. Butcher, president of the Chase Manhattan Bank. He was in Peking yesterday, meeting with Li Hsiennlen, Chinese Vice Prime Minister, to explore possibilities for future commercial and trade exchanges between China and the United States.

title: Sadat Is Confident About a Treaty Sooner or Later
description: CAIRO, Dec. 14  President Anwar elSadat said tonight that he was still confident that a peace treaty with Israel would be signed.

title: Hand Bells Ring The Season In
description: WITH a bell raised in each whitegloved hand, 10 young people stood at a long table, intent on the musical scores before them. Coordinating their efforts with the help of a conductor, they rang out an elaborate finale of Jingle Bells. The performers, rehearsing at Brick Presbyterian Church for a program on Sunday, were playing hand bells  instruments use for centuries but popular now as never before in the United States.

title: Corporate Earnings Reported
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange,(A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Dance: Sally Gross
description: SALLY GROSS performs infrequently. On Wednesday at Hunter College Studio Theater she presented six new and old solos. They were, on the whole, well worth the wait.

title: Public in AbramsSuccessor Hunt
description: Under pressure from Mayor Koch and other political figures, Bronx Democrats have decided to open up the process of selecting an interim successor to Borough President Robert Abrams, who is to be sworn in as State Attorney General on Jan. 1.

title: 75 Students Stranded as a College in Vermont Closes
description: PUTNEY, Vt., Dec 14  Tiny Windham College began closing its doors here today. It was the latest in a growing list of small liberal arts schools unable to survive in an era of declining college enrollments.

title: Screen: 'The Deer Hunter'
description: MICHAEL CIMINO'S "The Deer Hunter" is a big, awkward, crazily ambitious, sometimes breathtaking motion picture that comes as close to being a popular epic as any movie about this country since "The Godfather." Though he has written a number of screenplays, Mr. Cimino has only directed one other movie (the 1974 box-office hit, "Thunderbolt and Lightfoot"), which makes his present achievement even more impressive. Maybe he just didn't know enough to stop. Instead, he's tried to create a film that is nothing less than an appraisal of American life in the second half of the 20th century.I don't mean to make "The Deer Hunter" sound like "War and Peace" or even "Gone With the Wind." Its view is limited and its narrative at times sketchy. It's about three young men who have been raised together in a Pennsylvania steel town, work together in its mill, drink, bowl and raise hell together, and then, for no better reason than that the war is there, they go off to fight in Vietnam."The Deer Hunter," which opens today at the Coronet, is an update on the national dream, long after World War II when America's self-confidence peaked, after the Marshall Plan, after Korea, dealing with people who've grown up in the television age and matured in the decade of assassinations and disbelief.The three friends, all of Russian extraction, are Mike (Robert DeNiro), Nick (Christopher Walken) and Steve (John Savage). Mike is the one who calls the tune for his friends. To the extent that any one of them has an interior life, it is Mike, a man who makes a big thing about hunting, about bringing down a deer with one shot. More than one shot apparently isn't fair. As codes go this one is not great, but it is his own.Nick goes along with Mike, sometimes suspecting that Mike is eccentric, but respecting his eccentricities. Steve is the conventional one, whose marriage (a Russian Orthodox ceremony, followed by a huge, hysterical reception) occupies most of the film's first hour and sets out in rich detail what I take to be one of the movie's principal concerns  what happens to Americans when their rituals have become only quaint reminders of the past rather than life-ordering rules of the present.Mr. Cimino has described his treatment of the three friends' war experiences as surreal, which is another way of saying that a lot of recent history is elipsized or shaped to fit the needs of the film. What is not surreal is the brutality of the war and its brutalizing effects, scenes that haunt "The Deer Hunter" and give point to the film even as it slips into the wildest sort of melodrama, which Mr. Cimino plays out against the background of the collapse of Saigon and the American withdrawal from Southeast Asia. It's Armageddon with helicopters.Most particular and most savage is the film's use of Russian roulette as a metaphor for war's waste. It's introduced when the three friends, prisoners of war of the North Vietnamese, are forced by their captors to play Russian roulette with one another. The game crops up again in Saigon where, according to this film, it was played in back-street arenas rather like cock-fighting pits, for high-dollar stakes. These sequences are as explicitly bloody as anything you're likely to see in a commercial film. They are so rough, in fact, that they raise the question of whether such vivid portrayals don't become dehumanizing themselves.More terrifying than the violence  certainly more provocative and moving  is the way each of the soldiers reacts to his war experiences. Not once does anyone question the war or his participation in it. This passivity may be the real horror at the center of American life, and more significant than any number of hope-filled tales about raised political consciousnesses. What are these veterans left with? Feelings of contained befuddlement, a desire to make do and, perhaps, a more profound appreciation for love, friendship and community. The big answers elude them, as do the big questions.Deric Washburn's screenplay, which takes its time in the way of a big novel, provides fine roles for Mr. DeNiro, Mr. Walken and Mr. Savage, each of whom does some of his best work to date. Meryl Streep, who has long been recognized for her fine performances on the New York stage, gives a smashing film performance as the young woman, who, by tacit agreement among the friends, becomes Nick's girl but who stays around long enough to assert herself. In the splendid supporting cast are George Dzundza, Chuck Aspegren, Shirley Stoler and Rutanya Alda. The late John Cazale makes his last film appearance a memorable one as the kind of barroom neurotic who might at any moment go seriously off his rocker.The film has been stunningly photographed by Vilmos Zsigmond, who provides visually a continuity that is sometimes lacking in the rest of the movie. "The Deer Hunter" is both deeply troubling and troublesome (for the manner in which Mr. Cimino manipulates the narrative), but its feelings for time, place and blue-collar people are genuine, and its vision is that of an original, major new film maker.

title: Chamberlain, at 42, Eyes N.B.A. Return
description: Wilt Chamberlain, the 7foot2inch center who retired five years ago as the careerscoring leader in the National Basketball Association, says he wants to play basketball again at the age of 42.

title: IN THE NATION
description: PRETORIA, South Africa  South Africa's Minister of Justice is a round, jovial man with roached hair and gleaming spectacles who looks more like a Rotarian or a druggist than the official who presides over this country's detention and banning laws, its prisons and police  including those responsible for the death in custody of Steven Biko.

title: East Side Festival Is Celebrating Families
description: Family Jam '78, a 10day festival for the entire family, with drama, dance, music, magic and mime, will begin today at the Entermedia Theater, 189 Second Avenue (12th Street).

title: Callaghan Government Wins Test in Commons
description: LONDON, Dec. 14  Prime Minister James Callaghan's Government survived a vote of confidence tonight and staved off a winter election.

title: Film: A Horse's World
description: "JUST CRAZY ABOUT HORSES" is, as its title implies, less about horses than obsessive horse worship. The documentary, which opens today at the Guild Theater, is a jaundiced valentine from a young film maker to the horse set in which he was raised. It is an absorbing  and horrific  excursion into a world that is unfamiliar to most, whether devoted Central Park canterer or racetrack habitue. Money, breeding and a certain casual arrogance are required. The horses endure.Tim Lovejoy, who wrote and produced "Just Crazy" with Joe Wemple, has created an episodic collage of events and personalities in this, his first film. Buyers at a thoroughbred auction are urged to ponder the "residual values" in one mare's ovaries and, later, jockeys ride out onto the course to well-bred, almost languid rooting from the stands. The camera sidles into the middle of a crowd of steeplechase groupies, fur coats slung carelessly into car trunks and faces avid with gossip. We stroll into a pre-hunt party at one lavish "place"  for houses are "places" here and dogs are "hounds" who "speak" rather than bark  that was bought, as its owner laughingly recalls, as a "hedge against F.D.R."There are wonderful comic moments. An inarticulate jockey slips into equine body language. A very graphic breeding scene opens with a shot of a stallion teaser, a horse of dubious lineage who is fated only to test a mare's readiness for breeding, and closes with the mated mare being lead away covered delicately in a white sheet. A butler wanders onto a rolling green field to serve a bloody mary to his master and an exquisitely bored dressage rider reveals that "racing in Bombay especially was very popular." A Hepburn sound-alike drawls that she's rooting for a rider because "she's a nice person without masses of money."We watch an operation performed on a knock-kneed colt, then the camera cuts to a woman confined to a wheelchair after a riding accident, a horse breeder who strapped her crippled body to her horse for one last ride. We meet an equestrian who lives by candlelight in an attempt to re-create the 18th century in his splendid mansion. And the wounded rejects of the horse set are also introduced and their fantasy worlds explored with gentle good taste.It all becomes a little numbing but there are sudden compensations: A stallion canters free across a green meadow, a foal totters to its feet a few moments after birth and a tiny would-be rider urges a woolly sheep to a trot. In the film's most affecting scene, a stableman and mare exchange a look of haunting pain as her first foal is delivered stillborn.Peter Stein's grainy photography at first seems only to attest to the film's low-budget status but its softened edges and blurred colors become seductive, a good match for Sam Waymon's easy-going score and Tammy Grimes's amusingly smudge-voiced delivery of the rather breathless script."Just Crazy About Horses" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested") because of scenes of mare breeding and foals being born. Squeamish adults also take note.

title: Conference Board Projects 11% '79 Pay Rise
