description: Wage and benefit gains of about 11 percent can be expected next year, according to a Conference Board panel on the labor outlook. President Carter's voluntary wage guideline calls for 7 percent.

title: Steelers and Broncos Matchup Heads TV Double Tomorrow
description: There will be a pro football doubleheader on television tomorrow, with the second game matching two playoff teams, Pittsburgh and Denver (Channel 4, 4 P.M.).

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The freeze on oil prices will end shortly, said Arab oil ministers arriving in Abu Dhabi for an OPEC meeting, and price increases may take place in phases throughout 1979. The ministers differed on the extent of any price increases and on whether to continue using the dollar as the pricing unit for oil. [Page Al.] Leading economic forecasters say that oil price increases totaling around 8 percent next year would have a noticeable impact on the American economy, which many say is already on the verge of a downturn. [D1.]

title: Giants Lose Games But Win Voters
description: For a team that did not do very well on the field, the Giants came out all right in the voting for the Pro Bowl squads with three nominees. Brad Van Pelt and Harry Carson, linebackers, plus Dave Jennings, the punter, were named yesterday to the 40player squad of the National Football Conference.

title: Soviet Ballet Dancers Do a Good Turn
description: It was a week or so before initial rumblings along the dance Community's enthusiastic but inexact grapevine became a certainty. The Russians were coming. Today, a group billed as Stars of the Bolshoi and Stanislayski Ballet Theater, will be seen at Town Hall in a benefit for New York's Black Theater Alliance.

title: Teamsters' Talks Opened; Pay Demands Are Deferred
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 14  The International Brotherhood of Teamsters formally opened its pivotal contract negotiations with the nation's trucking companies today without making any specific monetary deinands.

title: Notes on People
description: The Earl of Snowdon, married from 1960 until this year to Britain's Princess Margaret, will make Lucy LindsayHogg his countess today in London. Antony ArmstrongJones, you may recall,, was court photographer at the time of his royal marriage and elevation to the title. Now he is marrying 37yearold television production assistant, who is the former Lucy Davies, daughter of the Irish fashion designer Donald Davies. After a childless fouryear marriage she was divorced in 1971 from Michael LindsayHogg, television and movie director and son of the actress. Geraldine Fitzgerald.

title: Deaths
description: Bishop, Sidney

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  The latest official reports from Iran are increasing anxiety within the Carter Administration and adding to divisions here about how Washington should respond to the crisis. According to these reports:

title: Deaths
description: GRINTHALLouis H. The Towi League sorrowfully records the passing of the beloved husband Elaine and devoted soninlaw Etta Seltzer, Honorary Trustee.

title: Deaths
description: DAVIESDiane on December 12, 1978. Sister of Melanie Haab, William and Edward Davies. Service at St. Bartholomew's Chapel, Park Ave and 51 St., Friday 2 PM.

title: Foe Nears Key Cambodian Road
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 14  Vietnamese forces have moved as far as 70 miles into southern Cambodia, putting them in position to cut Highway 4, linking Phnom Penh to its main port, Western analysts said today.

title: Torrijos Yields Reins in Panama and Drops Out of Sight
description: PANAMA, Dec. 11 After having ruled Panama singlehandedly for the last decade, Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera has abruptly handed over the Government to a team of young technocrats and virtually disappeared from public view.

title: Words and Music at Jazzmania
description: Jazzmania, the fourth floor walkup at 14 East 23d Street that offers jazz in a livingroom.atmosphre, is celebrating its fourth anniversary by adding new dimension to the jam sessions that have been the basis of its presentations since it opened its doors in 1974.

title: Roots Plagiarism Suit Is Settled
description: Alex Haley settled a lawsuit yesterday by acknowledging that his worldrenowned book Roots contained some material from a relatively unknown novel about slavery that was published nine years earlier.

title: General Dynamics Fights Quebec Move
description: The General Dynamics Corporation said that threats by Quebec provincial officials to expropriate the assets of its Canadian subsidiary, the Asbestos Corporation, was an attempt to pressure the shareholders of the Asbestos Corporation to sell their stock at an unrealistic low price.

title: In Rhodesia, Both Sides Need Help of U.S.
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia  One of the few things on which each group in Rhodesia's spreading guerrilla war agrees is that the United States could and shOuld bring a quick settlement  by helping its side win.

title: NEW STRIFE ERUPTS IN ANY IRAN CITIES; SHAH PRESSES TALKS
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 14  Violent. demonstrations erupted in a dozen cities today while Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi began another effort to end the bloodshed by trying to persuade opposition leaders to join a coalition government.

title: ImageMaking in South Africa
description: The patriarchs of South Africa's ruling National Party have a habit of drawing the wrong lessons from their mistakes. One such mistake was the creation of a secret Government propaganda fund, meant to buy South Africa a better name in an unfriendly world.

title: World News Briefs
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 14 (UPI)  President Anastasio Somoza Debayle said today that he had temporarily closed the border with Costa Rica because of fighting in the area, and he accused nationalist guerrillas of trying to sabotage his amnesty decree.

title: Stage: Bennett's Ballroom Arrives
description: FOR a while, as Ballroom introduces its characters, its situation, an initial pair of songs and a few dances, it keeps to an oddly subdued tempo, interesting in its unexpectedness. Nothing very exciting or witty or beautiful happens in the first half hour of this musical about old people finding love at a goldenage ballroom; but it is tasteful and unforced.

title: Koch to Hold Briefing on Civil Service Plan
description: In an effort to marshal support for sweeping proposals to alter the Civil Service, Mayor Koch has invited 60 mayors from all parts of New York State to a briefing at City Hall this afternoon.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 14 (AP)  Lou Holtz, the University of Arkansas football coach, said today that two Razorback players who were suspended from school yesterday pending investigation of a college woman's rape complaint were innocent until proven guilty.

title: Economic Scene
description: THE turmoil in Iran, posing a serious threat to the oil supplies of the United States and other Western countries, is likely to be only the first of a series of upheavals with revolutionary potential in the oilproducing countries in the decade ahead.

title: Jersey Agency Agrees To Give Back Tickets For the Tut Exhibition
description: The Colony Ticket Service of Union City, N.J., has agreed to turn over to the Metropolitan Museum of Art all the tickets to the Treasures of Tutankhamen exhibition it has and not to distribute any tickets to the exhibition.

title: EARNINGS
description: Dresser Industries, a leading capital goods producer that is also prominent in the oilfield service business, reported yesterday that profits were up 7.5 percent in the three months ended Oct. 31.

title: Publishing: ShelfHelp
description: WHEN B. Dalton, the giant book chain opened its Fifth Avenue store last month, it pledged its first day's proceeds to the New York Public Library. Last Monday Dalton made good its pledge to the tune of $15,189.93. But the book merchandiser went much, much further. It alsb presented the library through the Dayton Hudson Foundation With an annnional CheCK of $100,000. Since the library has just received a matching grant of $1.6 million from the National Endowment for the Humanties  it has to raise two dollars for every one in the grant  it means that Dalton has contributed more than $170,000 to the library's drive.

title: Screen: After 'Love Story'
description: WHO can forget about a 25-year-old girl who died? Not Oliver Barrett 4th, that's for sure. At the beginning of "Oliver's Story," which opens today at Loews State, the Trans-Lux East and Walter Reade 34th Street East, Oliver is sitting in a graveyard mourning his lost Jenny; at the end of the film, he's sitting by the banks of the Charles River doing much the same thing.The ads for "Oliver's Story" feature a prettily windswept photo of Ryan O'Neal (as Oliver) and Candice Bergen (as Marcie, the new woman in his life), plus the slogan "It takes someone very special to help you forget someone very special." But if you imagine that that indicates the film is about Oliver's falling for Marcie and starting life anew, well, you probably think love means never having to say you're sorry.In fact, the message of "Oliver's Story" is a decidedly gloomy one: You get just one shot at young love, and after that you're over the hill. The happy-go-lucky Oliver of "Love Story" is gone, replaced by a prematurely middle-aged fellow who grinds away at his job, worries about his family responsibilities and spends some excruciatingly dull sessions with his psychotherapist. ("Nothing happens magically, Oliver," the doctor says on a particularly dreary day. "But just being aware of a problem is beginning to solve it.")When Oliver and Marcie take a whirlwind tour of Hong Kong, they're actually there on a business trip and hardly even enjoying themselves. Over dinner they talk about where they first learned to use chopsticks and how many rolls of film Oliver has used up while touring the city.At least "Love Story" had a romantic and moderately rebellious world-view, being opposed to parental authority and in favor of angels in the snow. "Oliver's Story" is stodgy through and through, with a hero and heroine who have one good time together jogging through Central Park and never again match the thrill of that moment. Perhaps their detachment and their weary soul-searching and their willingness to get up at 6 A.M. for a good game of tennis are signs of the times. That doesn't make their saga the stuff of which dreams are made.The screenplay manages to take every possible edge off Erich Segal's novel, even though finding the edges can't have been easy. As written by Mr. Segal and John Korty, who directed it, the script teams Oliver with a WASP department-store heiress whose take-charge attitude eventually gets on his nerves.In Mr. Segal's book, this was supposed to contrast sharply with the memory of Jenny, with her unaffected, lower-class ways, and to remind Oliver of his aristocratic parents, whom he never much liked. In the film, Miss Bergen is only a slight departure from Ali MacGraw, who never seemed all that economically deprived in the first place, so the point is lost. A scene of Mr. Segal's, in which Marcie met Oliver's parents and  unlike Jenny  was a big hit, has been dropped from the movie, as has every other useful parallel with "Love Story."In fact, all that remains of the first film are Francis Lai's theme song and a little photo of Miss MacGraw on Mr. O'Neal's nighttable, right next to the Excedrin. This is not to suggest that Mr. Korty has moved on in any imaginative way, or that he is above falling back on "Love Story" every time new inspiration eludes him. After Oliver has a fight with Marcie, for instance, Mr. Korty has him drive all the way to Cambridge, just so he can trot briefly and wordlessly past the other film's Harvard Yard settings.Jenny's father is still around (this time played by Edward Binns instead of John Marley), but he has conveniently forgotten all about his daughter and keeps urging Oliver to go out and have a good time. The Barrett parental estate serves a similarly perfunctory purpose. These evocations are so cold and clumsy that they effectively dispel all vestiges of the first film's highly marketable mood.Mr. Korty has the reputation of a fine independent film maker; his documentary about the DeBolt family, to be shown on television this weekend, won an Academy Award last year. But his direction of "Oliver's Story" is too unsure one moment, too insistent the next, and he has no eye for the glamour that might have been this film's last chance.Mr. O'Neal is certainly equal to the material, but Mr. Korty doesn't seem to trust him with it; too many montages seem devised to keep the actor from having to talk. Miss Bergen always looks spectacular in close-ups, so why, then, are there so many unflattering long shots of her in unbecoming costumes? And what use has been made of the (highly exploitable) memory of Jenny? The first sequence shows Mr. O'Neal watching her coffin being lowered into the ground, inch by tearjerking inch. But after that, for all his funk, he doesn't often think of her again. Perhaps it's just as well. This is the kind of sequel that could have her turning over in her grave."Oliver's Story" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), because it contains one brief bedroom scene and because Marcie has inherited much of Jenny's smart-alecky vocabulary.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Traders at the Chicago Board of Trade kept a careful eye on the wheat pit yesterday, following Wednesday's sharp price decline. There was some more selling early yesterday morning, but then holders of short positions began to buy to take profits. Even so, prices were down again at the close, indicating availability of heavy supplies.

title: Broadway
description: WOULD you believe a new Cole Porter musical with a book, more or less, by Phillip Barry? Of course not; but it exists, at least in the mind's eye, and it will go into rehearsal at the Stratford Festival in Ontario in March. It is called Happy New Year, and it has been adapted as a musical by Burt Shevelove, who took it from Mr. Barry's play Holiday. Obviously, the 16 Cole Porter songs in the show  14 of them unpublished, two only lightly used  were not written for Happy New Year, and instead have been added to it. But when you hear.the songs, Leonard Soloway insists, you swear they were written for the show.

title: Cabaret: De Shields Solo
description: THE interchange between Broadway and New York's cabaret circuit is a fruitful one; so fruitful, in fact, that it's hard to believe that cabaret could exist here on its present scale without a restless pool of Broadway actors with solo ambitions to feed it.

title: T.V.A. Agrees to Spend $1 Billion To Clean Up Air at Power Plants
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14  The Tennesseee Valley authority, in what was hailed as a landmark public health settlement, agreed today to invest well over $1 billion to clean up air pollution at 10 of its power plants in the Southeast.

title: Pro Bowl Rosters
description: Wide Receivers  Lynn Swann, Pittsburgh; Wesley Walker, Jets: John Jefferson, San Diego; Steve Largent, Seattle.

title: World News Briefs
description: ROME, Dec. 15  Terrorists killed two policemen outside the Turin prison at dawn today, and this afternoon terrorists shot and wounded a bank executive in Venice and a magistrate in Florence.

title: Racers Fold; W.H.A. Down To Six Teams
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 15 (UPI) The Indianapolis Racers bowed out of the World Hockey Association tonight, reducing the league to six teams.

title: Miller Says Dollar Fund Is Not Gone
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15  G. William Miller, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, acted today to quash rumors that the United States had used up practically its entire $30 billion war chest to support the dollar since Nov. 1.

title: ChainReaction Crash Kills Five
description: KETTLEMAN CITY, Calif., Dec. 15 (UPI)  At least five motorists were killed today in a chainreaction crash in. volving several semitrucktrailer rigs and more than a dozen cars on fogshrouded 15, the California Highway Patrol said.

title: Entertainment Events
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center. Verdi'sAlta, Tosco. 8.

title: Rock Tour by Billy Joel
description: Billy Joel came home Thursday night, and it was a triumphal occasion for him. Not only was it his debut at Madison Square Garden, but it was also the first of three shows there that had sold out almost as soon as they went on sale. Sometimes the scalpers milling about on Seventh Avenue before big rock concerts get burned, but Thursday was definitely a seller's market.

title: Pravda Calls EgyptIsrael Treaty Betrayal of All the Arab Peoples
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 15 (Reuters) Pravda, the Communist Party newspaper, said today that the draft of the EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty was a betrayal of all the Arab peoples and that the parties concerned were trying to find a way to make the conspiracy more respectable.

title: Harold Hansen, at 59; A Packaging Executive
description: Harold Hansen, marketing executive and inventor, died Dec. 13 at the Veterans Administration Hospital in WilkesBarre. Pa., of complications following a stroke. He was 59 years old and lived in Newton.

title: Miss Fugate in Nutcracker
description: Dance Marie in The Nutcracker, so ballet lore goes, and you're fated not to dance much after that. The child's role of the little girl around whom the ballet revolves is considered both a plum and a curse. But at Thursday's performance of the holiday classic at the New York State Theater, Judith Fugate, one of the first Maries to be accepted as an adult professional into the New York City Ballet, danced the Sugar Plum Fairy  the ballet's plum for grownup dancers  with the cool assurance of a lady who'd never heard of hexes.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON TWO of the 1,000 inventions patented this week are aimed at improving the health and safety of babies. One is an alarm belt to monitor an infant's condition and reduce crib fatalities. The other, offered by a grandmother, is a collapsible outdoor shelter called a gazebo that can be carried in a shoulder bag.

title: Xavier 75, So. Calif. 68 Tennessee 100. Niagara 80
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 15 (UPI)  Nick Daniels sank seven free throws in the last three minutes tonight to lead Xavier (Ohio) to a 7568 upset of 13thranked Southern California in the Volunteer Classic.

title: Letters
description: Reduced unemployment. Increased time for creative and leisure activities. Reduced Social Security costs. These results could occur if the country would adopt a major social program which I am proposing to the Congress.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 16, 1978

title: Greenwich AT A GLANCE
description: Geography

title: Taiwan's President Protests to U.S. Over Decision on Ties With Peking
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Saturday, Dec. 16 President Chiang Chingkuo protested bitterly today against the United States decision to establish diplomatic relations with Peking and sever ties, including the mutual defense treaty, with the Chinese Nationalist Government here.

title: Kennecott And Curtiss End Fight
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation agreed today to a compromise with the CurtissWright Corporation to end their protracted proxy fight, which began last spring.

title: Carey Gets List Of Seven Names For Chief Judge
description: Governor Carey was given a list of seven names yesterday from which he must choose New York State's next Chief Judge.

title: Stranded Mining Town Awaits Bridge
description: VULCAN, W. Va., Dec. 13  On one side of this town is the Tug River and beyond the river is the state of Kentucky. On the other side is a steep and rocky hill; its spine visible in winter through naked trees.

title: Foes Schedule Day of Mourning Monday to Test Shah's Strength
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 15  The religious and secular opposition to Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi served notice today that it intends to step up its war of economic attrition in the hope of driving him from power.

title: U.S. Pressing Shah to Compromise And Set Up Civilian Regime in Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15  The United States has assumed the delicate role of a mediator among the contending factions in the crisis in Iran, with the Carter Administration pressing Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi to replace his military Government with a broadbased civilian coalition.

title: Sam Houston Johnson Is Buried Near Brother on Family's Ranch
description: STONEWALL, Tex., Dec. 15 (AP) Sam Houston Johnson was buried yesterday 12 feet from his onceestranged brother. Lyndon Baines Johnson

title: Deadline Is Unmet on Trade Talk
description: GENEVA, Dec. 15  The major industrialized nations failed today to meet the deadline they had set for successfully concluding their negotiations to lower trade barriers. However, the United States said it was ready to close out with a balanced result this year.

title: Fine Line Separates Giants' Negatives
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 15  In two days another losing Giants'season will be over, and Doug Van Horn was wondering aloud today: Why does everybody take a negative attitude toward us?

title: Fledgling Right to Life Party Unseats Liberals as No. 4
description: The new Right to Life Party outpotled the Liberal Party in last month's New York State gubernatorial election and thus captured the fourth position on the voting machine for the next four years, the official state canvass of the vote confirmed yesterday. The party will be listed after the Democratic, Republican and Conservative Parties.

title: Your Money
description: THE magic number for yieldoriented shortterm investors these days is 10 percent. You can get 10 percent on the 26week savings certificates being offered by many thrift institutions: you can get 10 percent on such Federal agency securities as Banks for Cooperatives bonds. No one appreciates the promotional allure of that nice round number more than money market fund managers.

title: Carter's Recognition Step Draws Applause and Anger
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15The political reaction tonight to President Carter's announcement that the United States would establish diplomatic relations with Peking and break the security treaty with Taiwan ranged from applause to anger.

title: Quartet Led By Moondoc
description: Ensemble Muntu, a jazz quartet led by the alto saxophonist Jemeel Moondoc, has been toiling in New York's lofts and small clubs for several years now without much critical notice. The group'does not fit comfortably into any avantgarde niche. Rather than drawing inspiration from the stylistic breakthroughs of the Art Ensemble of Chicago and related groups, as so many younger players are doing, the musicians in Ensemble Muntu are at work perfecting the kind of group interplay one heard in Ornette Coleman's quartets of the early 1960's.

title: Kings, Paced by Ford, Defeat Celtics, 105 to 101
description: BOSTON, Dec. 15 (UPI) Phil Ford scored 19 points and paced a fourthquarter rally that gave the Kansas City Kings a 105101 victory over the Boston Celtics tonight.

title: Postal Workers Parade for Dismissed Comrades
description: New York postal workers, protesting the dismissal of some of their number during wildcat strikes earlier this year, gathered at the General Post Office, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, for a rally and march through midtown Manhattan yesterday. About 100 workers demanded amnesty for 200 coworkers discharged during a wildcat job action last July 21 in a Jersey City facility and in California. After the job action, 2,500 more workers were suspended or otherwise disciplined. The New York Metro Postal Workers Union is supporting dismissed workers.

title: Oil Storage Tank Ruptures
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Dec. 15 (AP)  A storage tank at the plant of the Commonwealth Oil Refining Company on Puerto Rico's south coast ruptured last night, spilling 250,000 barrels of fuel oil, the United States Coast Guard reported. A Coast Guard spokesman said that 90 percent of the oil had been held behind a retaining wall surrounding the tank but that an undetermined amount had flowed into a drainage canal.

title: She's Got Her Act Together Again
description: She was married in 1958, divorced in 1969. And one of the things that Gretchen Cryer remembers best about her 11year marriage was that she had to talk baby talk to her husband whenever she wanted him to help around the house.

title: China Move Reflects Carter's Aim To Protect Arms Pact and Taiwan
description: WASINGTON Dec. 15 Administration officials said tonight that President Carter's announcement of American plans to establish diplomatic relations with China reflected a belief that such ties would not jeopardize a new arms agreement with the Soviet Union or expose Taiwan to an attack from the mainland.

title: Israel's Prices Up 6.2% in November
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 15  The Government reported today that Israel's retail price index had increased 6.2 percent in November, the highest rise this year.

title: Hawks Turn Back Rested Nets, 121104
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Dec. 15  An erratic league schedule that had sent the New Jersey Nets on a 15day trip subsequently gave them a fiveday layoff this week, and the rest proved soporific. The Atlanta Hawks amassed a huge early lead tonight and beat the Nets, 121104, before 4,121 spectators in the Rutgers Athletic Center.

title: Newton Drury, Conservationist Who Led Redwood Drive, Dies
description: Newton Bishop Drury, one of the nation's leading conservationists for more than half a century and the prime mover in thecampaign for the preservation of redwood trees, died Thursday at the Alta Bates Hospital in Berkeley, Calif., where he resided. He was 89 years old.

title: Corporate Earnings Reported
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicafes stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the Americas Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Carey's Bubbles Plan Shelved for Time Being
description: Plans to put allweather bubble enclosures over the swimming pool and tennis court at the Executive Mansion in Albany are on the back burner, a spokesman for Governor Carey said yesterday.

title: Jets' Long Sets Aim At 1,000
description: Kevin Long has no chance to become the first New York Jet to run for more than 1,000 yards. That has already been done by John Riggins, who rushed for 1,005 in 1975. But, thanks to the expanded National Football League schedule, however, Long has a chance to become the second Jet player to gain a thousand yards, and it comes up in tomorrow's season finale against the Dallas Cowboys in Shea Stadium.

title: Henry Quiller's Sheep
description: My Uncle Joe L. Williams taught me how to guess, close enough, the weight of a twoyearold steer, the number of bushels per acre a field of standing wheat might yield, and how to recognize an anticline, a hump or fold in sedimentary rock strata where oil and gas sometimes accumulate. But mostly he told me stories, each of which had a moral. He urged me to pay special attention to the one about Henry Quiller because, Joe said, it taught me how to get rich and how never to worry about money.

title: Security Pacific Deal
description: The Security Pacific Corporation disclosed that it had completed the acquisition of American Finance System for about $65 million in cash and stock. American Finance operates 369 consumer finance offices is 22 states. Security Pacific is n bank holdingg cornpany with assets of more than $20 billion

title: Learning From Cruelty
description: I saw a dead cat ldst night. Nothing unusual about that around New York. One sees them  cats and dogs squeezedout. mudspattered corpses, hitandrun victims along the highways of the city. Only the cat I saw wasn't on the highway. It was hanging from a lamppost, from a clothesline noose that had probably choked it to death rather than broken its neck.

title: O'Toole and Cook Star In Washington Vanya
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15  Some big changes were made in the Canadian production of Uncle Vanya when it opened at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performine Arts.

title: Deaths
description: Anchan, Nathan

title: Price Rise Set For MercedesBenz
description: DaimlerBenz AG, the West German car maker, said it was raising prices 1.9 percent on its MercedesBenz cars effective Monday. The company said the higher prices would apply on cars sold domestically and abroad.

title: Dr. Jacob Lifton, at 81; Orthodonture Specialist
description: Dr. Jacob C. Lifton, a specialist in dental surgery and an honorary staff member of the New York Hospital for Special Surgery, which he served for more than 30 years, died Tuesday at New York Hospital, following a long illness. He was 81 years old.

title: Pretoria's Ally Is Namibia Victor
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Africa, Dec. 15 (Reuters)  The Democratic Turnhalle Alliance, with 82 percent of the vote, was declared the winner today of last week's election in SouthWest Africa, also known as Namibia.

title: A Mickey Mouse Clock That Roars
description: Mickey Mouse's time has come literally, and in a big way. At the ripe age of 50, the rambunctious rodent has been celebrated by parties, several books and countless commercial copies of the cartoon character's classic toys and timepieces.

title: An Exxon Staff Sends Donation To the Neediest
description: Employees in the investorrelations division of the Exxon Corporation have given up the exchange of Christmas cards with people we see each day and instead have adopted the practice of contributing to the yearly campaign of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Saudis Ask Moderation On Oil Price
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates, Dec. 15  On the eve of the formal start here of the conference of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, Saudi Arabia's influential oil minister called today for moderation in determining the new price of oil.

title: The City
description: The lawyers for co David R. Berkowitz, who was convicted as the .44caliber killer, have lost a motion to be compensated for his defense as courtappointed counsel.

title: Trail Blazers 116, Nuggets 113
description: DENVER, Dec. 15 (AP)  Portland's rookie, Mychal Thompson, hit a free throw with five seconds to play to clinch the Trail Blazers 116113 victory over the Denver Nuggets tonight.

title: Knicks Defeat Bulls As Knight Scores 43
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 15  Toby Knight scored a careerhigh 43 points tonight in Chicago Stadium in leading the New York Knicks to a 11894 rout of the Chicago Bulls.

title: Research Lag Is Laid to Management
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15  A study by the National Science Foundation has determined that the major cause for the decadelong decline in basic exploratory research carried out by America's industries is that research has come under the control of top management.

title: Providence Tops California On Scott Shots
description: PROVIDENCE, RI., Dec. 15 (AP) Jerry Scott made two free throws with one second remaining tonight to give Providence a 5958 victory over the University of California in the Industrial National college basketball tournament.

title: Radio
description: 6 A.M., WNYCAM. Ich Freu Mich Des, Schutz; Ricercare Per Sonar Risonanza di Echo, Gabrieli ; L'Olica Canzon Per Sonar, Da corregio; Non Dispregiate I Miserelli Amanti, Parabosco; Padre del Ciel, Padovano.

title: Letter: On Fire Academy Sites
description: To the Editor:

title: Text of President's Statement on Ties With China
description: Good evening. I would like to read joint communiqu which is being simultaneously issued in Peking at this very moment by the leaders of the People's Republic of China:

title: Light Opera Sings FullScale Babes in Toyland Muntu Jazz
description: Victor Herbert's Babes in Toyland used to be a popular and inevitable event at Christmastime until the composer's operettas went out of fashion about 50 years ago. In fact, the current revival by the Light Opera of Manhatan, which continues at the Eastside Playhouse through Jan. 14, is apparontly the first fullscale production New York has seen since 1930.

title: Changing Brazil
description: To those who expect Brazil to look like the military dictatorship it is, the November elections were a strange phenomenon. Almost 46 million people went to the polls and, in a reasonably free and reasonably honest contest for parliamentary seats at the national and state levels, voted for the candidates of their choice. Much to the surprise of more people within Government circles than would care to admit it, the regime's party retained majorities in both houses of the National Congress in Brasilia.

title: Miss Mussman Directs Room/Raum
description: Room/Raum, which Linda Mussman calls an abstract play, is the newest production of the experimental theater directed by Miss Mussman, the Time and Space Limited Theater Company at 139 West 22d Street. It is a fascinating and largely successful experiment in the idea of shared forms.

title: Antitrust Reform Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15  A Presidential commission has recommended that Congress repeal the insurance industry's exemption froM antitrust laws and the immunity that lets truckers and railroads jointly fix uniform freight rates.

title: China: The Long Wait
description: HONG KONG, Saturday, Dec. 16 President Carter's announcement last night that the United States and the People's Republic of China are finally normalizing diplomatic relations comes nearly seven years after Richard M. Nixon pledged in the Shanghai Communiqu of February 1972 to work toward that goal.

title: Three TV Programs Tied to Tut Show
description: King Tut's agent. if he had one. is long gone these thousands of years, but should he turn up like the King's own funerary relics, the agent would have field day with television.

title: Edward Auer, Pianist, Appears
description: Edward Auer, who was heard Thursday night at the Metropolitan Museum, is a 37yearold pianist who deserves to be better known. His musical instincts are absolutely patrician, and he has the technical equipment to implement them with meticulous clarity.

title: Bridge:
description: When experts are playing against each other, they naturally assume that everyone is playing expertly. Once in a while this assumption is unjustified, and the effect may be both irritating and ironic.

title: Dennis John Kucinich
description: After he was elected Mayor of Cleve, land in November 1976 at the age of 31, Dennis J. Kucinich said he did not want to be known as the youngest mayor of a major American city: I want to be the best, he said. Almost since the begin ning of his tenure, however, there has been considerable debate over whether Mr. Kucinich has been even an adequate mayor.

title: State. Dept. Says Cult Withdrew Authorization for Visit by Ryan
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15  The People's Temple withdrew permission it had given Representative Leo J. Ryan to visit its Jonestown settlement in Guyana when it learned that reporters and relatives of members of the cult would accompany him on his investigation of the cult last month, the State Department said today.

title: Brando Sues on Superman Film
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 15 (AP) Marlon Brando and his production company have filed a $50 million lawsuit against producers and distributors of the movie Superman for allegedly violating terms of an agreement for the actor's services in the film.

title: Hua Rose as Protg of Mao
description: The decision to make Hua Kuofeng acting Prime Minister after the death of Chou Enlai early in 1976 came as surprise. Even in China, his name was hardly a household word, and scanty accounts of his life were given to the Chinese only in the months after Mr. Hua succeeded Mao Tsetung as Communist Party Chairman in October of that year.

title: Retail Prices Up in Britain
description: LONDON, Dec. 15 (AP)  Britain's retail price index rose 0.7 percent in November from the previous month and was up 8.1 percent from the year earlier, the Government said today.

title: Chronology of USChina Ties Since 1949
description: The achievement of normal relations between the United States and China proved elusive for nearly three decades after the Communists came to power in Peking in 1949.

title: Teng, a Deputy Premier, Is Strongest Leader
description: Twice purged as a capitalistroader, Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping has become China's most forceful leader since he surfaced from exile once again early last year.

title: Store Sales Surge 10% in Week
description: It looks like we're going to have a Christmas after all  and a good one.

title: LINK TO TAIWAN ENDS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15  President Carter announced a historic agreement tonight under which the United States and China will establish diplomatic relations on Jan. 1.

title: M.T.A. Issues ExpenseAccount Guide
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which has been the subject of investigations into allegations of irregularities in the expense accounts of its executives, yesterday issued guidelines intended to prevent its executives from submitting improper expense accounts and prevent them from diverting official cars to personal use.

title: Japan's Trade Surplus Goes Down
description: TOKYO, Dec. 15  Japan's trade surplus sank in November to the lowest level in six months, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: Borg, Ramirez Advance In Montego Bay Tourney
description: today to the the semifinals of the $320,000 World Championship of Tennis Challenge Cup.

title: Train Passenger Shot to Death
description: HUTCHINSON, Kan., Dec. 15 (AP) A passenger aboard an Amtrak train wa?? shot to death by the police today after h?? fired two shots aboard the train and the?? shot at policemen at the station here, th?? authorities said. The victim was identi fied as Howard Smith, 65 years old, bu his hometown was not known.

title: China Reports Accord With U.S. to Establish Diplomatic Relations
description: PEKING, Saturday, Dec. 16 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Hua Kuofeng announced today the resumption of full diplomatic relations with the United States, after a break of nearly three decades.

title: Callaghan Asks Study of Breaches of Oil Sanctions Against Rhodesia
description: LONDON, Dec. 15  Prime Minister James Callaghan asked Parliament today to set up a highlevel parliamentary commission to inquire further into violations of oil sanctions against Rhodesia.

title: To People of Abu Dhabi, Oil Parley Is a Dull Show
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates, Dec. 15  The war of words between hardliners and moderates of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries continued here today, with both sides pressing for their positions on the projected increase in the price of oil.

title: Disaster Areas in West Virginia
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., Dec. 15 (UPI)  President Carter has declared five West Virginia counties a major disaster area as a result of serious flooding earlier this month, Gov. John D. Rockefeller 4th announced today. Under the declaration, residents of Cabe11, Wayne, Mingo, Jackson and Lincoln counties will be eligible for Federal aid.

title: Koch Expected To Increase Pay Of 2,100 by 4%
description: Mayor Koch is expected to hand out on Jan. I increases up to 4 percent to 2,100 managerial employees not covered by Civil Service, plus a lump sum of $750, each for costofliving increases, City Hall sources said yesterday. The total cost to the city will be $871,750.

title: Javits to Quit Key Job On Unit That Handles New York Legislation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15  Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, said today that he would seek the position of ranking Republican on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and relinquish his longtime post as ranking Republican on the Human Resources Committee.

title: Television
description: 6:00(4)Agriculture U.S.A.

title: Ford Attacks Carter on Inflation, Iran and Defense
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15  Former President Gerald R. Ford, saying he had not had the time to consider running for President again, criticized President Carter today on inflation, Iran and defense spending, and carefully reserved judgment on strategic arms talks.

title: America's Duty to the Boat People
description: The photographs of Vietnamese refugees jammed on the decks of unseaworthy craft as Malay peasants block their way to shore continue to tear at the conscience. So, too, do the camps across Southeast Asia overflowing with other Vietnamese, overseas Chinese, Cambodians and Laotians. There is a pressing need for the United States, and other Western countries, not only to give haven to increasing numbers of the refugees but to make refugee policy more rational and practical. Working on the basis of legislatiotitliat Senator Edward Kennedy has sought for years, the White House and Congressional experts have nearly reached consensus on a new law.

title: Katharine Brigham Married to Lawyer
description: Katharine Brigham of New York and Brewster, Mass., daughter of Mrs. Lawrence V. Roth of Hamilton, N. Y., and Brewster, and the late Mr. Roth, was married yesterday afternoon to Gardner A. Callanen, a widower of Waterville, N. Y. He is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Gardner A. Callanen of Waterville.

title: New Pesticides Halt Superbug Attacking Lettuce
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 15  An insect infestation that threatened to ruin much of the nation's winter lettuce crop has been halted by emergency spraying of new pesticides, according to California agricultural experts.

title: Chock Full Net Drops 82%
description: The Chock Full O'Nuts Corporation, which operates 59 urban counterservice restaurants, reported yesterday an 82.4 percent drop in profits for its first fiscal quarter ended Oct. 31. Revenues of the company, which also processes and sells coffee, were,down 7.8 percent.

title: CITY OF CLEVELAND DEFAULTS ON LOANS
description: CLEVELAND, Saturday, Dec. 16 Fiscal default befell this city last night, when its government failed to repay some $15.5 million in loans to a group of local banks and the city treasury.

title: The Region
description: WHITE PLAINS (AP)  Yonkers Councilmen Arthur Freddolino and Michael Cipriani, who 'said they had been offered bribes, were reprimanded by a Westchester County grand jury, which said they should have disclosed this to law enforcement officials rather than in radio broadcasts.

title: 76ers 91, Rockets 84
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 (AP) Caldwell Jones scored 16 points, and Maurice Cheeks had 15 as the Philadelphia 76ers stopped a late surge by the Houston Rockets and won, 9184, tonight.

title: Market Declines Broadly
description: The stock market, confronted with an array of impending news developments, retreated yesterday across a broad front.

title: Reports Conflict on Status Of Jones Cult's Finances
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15  A Government official said today that a bank in Zurich had informed the Justice Department that the People's Temple assets, sometimes estimated to total as much as $8 million, had been removed. The name of the bank could not be learned.

title: Studio 54 Inquiry Termed FarRanging
description: Federal officials said last night that their investigation of Studio 54 had been sparked by reports that organized crime may have been the source of initial capital for the fashionable Manhattan discothque.

title: Mays Heads Fame Ballot
description: Willie Mays, whose play for the Giants and the Mets electrified baseball fans for 21 seasons, heads a list of 54 players eligible for election to the Baseball Hall of Fame on ballots that have been mailed to veteran members of the Baseball Writers Association of America.

title: Panel Proposes a Rail Settlement
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP)  A Presidential emergency board proposed a settlement of a long and bitter railroad contract dispute today in an effort to prevent resumption of a nationwide rail strike on Jan. 15.

title: Insuring the Aged Against Fraud
description: Insurance agents around the country are pressuring the elderly to buy medical policies that cost too much for the coverage they offer. So charges the Huse Committee on Aging, whose investigators found instances of fraud and unethical practices in nine states, including New York, California and Illinois. But the most unscrupulous practices they uncovered were those of the Intercontinental Insurance Company in Elizabeth, N. J.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Soviet Edgy Over Future U.S.China Military Deals
description: MOSCOW, Saturday, Dec. 16  Despite the Soviet Union's rift with China, the Kremlin has long regarded the normalization of relations between Washington and Peking as legitimate, as one wellplaced official put it.

title: Sun Devil Coach From the Mines
description: If his players are Sun Devils, he is their Luciferor at least that's his reputation as the Arizona State football coach. Mention his cruel, harsh image to him and he says,I would never kick a kid. I've slapped em on the helmet with my hand, but that hurts my hand more than it does them. But whatever he does or does not do, Frank Kush gets results. Of the active college football coaches, only Paul (Bear) Bryant of Alabama and Woody Hayes of Ohio State have more victories. In his 21 seasons out in the Arizona desert where the Sun Devils play in Tempe, a Phoenix suburb, Frank Kush has a record of 172 victories against only 53 losses and I tie going into the inaugural Garden State Bowl against Rutgers at Giants Stadium today. Frank Kush has not been back East much lately, but he remembers it when he was a tough, hard kid, one of 15 children of a coal miner who died too young with the soot in his lungs from Mine 35 in Windber, Pa., near Johnstown.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Aggressive buying of wheat futures contracts helped reverse the recent downtrend in wheat prices. At the close on the Chicago Board of Trade, December wheat was quoted at $3.60 a bushel, up 11 cents from the Thursday close. The more distant contracts gained much less  from 2 to 4 cents a bushel  an indication that the rebound was technical in nature.

title: Quebec Moves to Seize Large Asbestos Concern
description: QUEBEC, Dec. 15  The Quebec government introduced a bill today to expropriate most of the assets of the Asbestos Corporation but kept the door open to a lastminute purchkse agreement with its majority shareholder, the General Dynamics Corporation of St. Louis.

title: Mike Spinks Stops Phillips in 4th at Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec 15  Michael Spinks was wearing a Muhammad All Tshirt under his fulllength rabbit fur coat when he went to the gym yesterday to train for his lightheavyweight fight against Eddie Phillips.

title: Another Pearl in The Pros
description: Debbie (the Pearl) Mason nearly became an anachronism at the age of 26 this week in the fastchanging world of women's basketball. The 5foot5inch, 100pound guard, the best player, some say, Queens College ever produced, was cut from the New York Stars of the new Women's Basketball League 10 days ago. The coach said he doubted that Miss Mason could survive in the game now that it had swung so dramatically to dominance by big women.

title: Ski Reports
description: (All ski areas are operating on very limited terrain. Figures in parentheses show total trails and number open at each area.)

title: U.S. Offers a Plan to Reopen Lands in West to Competitive Coal Leasing
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15  A new program that could reopen Federal lands in the West to competitive coal leasing by mid1980 was described today by Interior Secretary Cecil D. Andrus.

title: Anthony LaGiglia Dancers Feature Series of Solos
description: One of tne most remarkable things about the Anthony LaGiglia Dance Theater's Thursday night concert at the American Theater Laboratory was the dancers' concentration. Performed halfheartedly, Mr. LaGiglia's pieces might have looked merely peculiar. Instead, the dancers made them magical because they obviously believed in them.

title: Vance Reports to President
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15  The Carter Administration accused Israel today of deliberately distorting the nature of new peace proposals taken to Jerusalem this week by Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance in his effort to complete an EgyptianIsraeli treaty.

title: Books of The Times
description: Kings and crooks, millionaires and refugees, big game hunters and smugglers, prima donnas and courtesans traveled on it; tycoons and financiers clinched their deals across its sumptuous dining tables; diplomats, spies and revolutionaries on board the train moved secretively to their moments of history.

title: Silver Cornet Band Makes New York Debut Dec. 18
description: Mr. Jack Daniel's Silver Cornet Band, a recreation of a smalltown band of the late 19th century, will make its New York debut Monday night in Avery Fisher Hall at 8:30. The ensemble has its historical model in a band formed in Lynchburg, Tenn., in the 1890's by Jack Daniel, who ordered the instruments from a Sears catalogue. The current group was organized by Dave Fulmer, but its authentic silver cornets had to be purchased in Europe since they are no longer made in this country.

title: Greenwich Struggling to Save an Ideal
description: GREENWICH, Conn.  Scaffolding is up now around the Greenwich Lodge, a stately, halfcenturyold apartment building just off the Post Road, signaling yet another change to worry some of the residents and officials of this genteel town. They feel Greenwich has changed too much already.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 15 (AP)  The Aluminum Company of America said today that it was raising prices on primary aluminum ingot by 2 cents a pound, to 55 cents, effective immediately on new orders and on all shipments Jan. 2, 1979.

title: Cabinet Backs Begin Stand
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 15  The Israeli Cabinet decided today to reject the latest proposals by Egypt for a peace treaty as well as the attitude and interpretation of the United States regarding the proposals.

title: Koch Gets 3 Billion School Budget; Smaller Classes Among Objectives
description: The New York City School Chancellor, Frank J. Macchiarola, sbmitted a $3 billion expense budget to Mayor Koch yesterday that calls for smaller classes, intensified remedial instruction and additional personnel to combat truancy, vandalism and internal mismanagement.

title: McDonnell Douglas Lists Details Of $15.7 Million in Payments Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15  The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the nation's leading defense contractor, provided details today regarding $15.7 million in payments made by the company to foreign airline and government officials since 1969 to promote sales in at least 17 countries.tinued into 1977 and 1978, after the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act took effect. That law makes it a crime to bribe a foreign government official.

title: Autopsies Are Performed on Jones and 6 Followers
description: Military pathologists performed autopsies yesterday on the Rev. Jim Jones and six of his followers who died in Guyana four weeks ago.

title: U.S. Output Climbs 0.7% For Month
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP)  The nation's industries increased their output by a solid 0.7 percent in November, indicating that the economy is continuing to grow at a strong, steady pace, the Government said today.

title: Three Empty Places
description: New York has recently lost three outstanding members of the generation of municipal reformers who began their work before World War I.

title: Expansion of U.S. Advisory Panel on Gene Research Raises Concern on Effectivenc
description: The makeup of an important Federal advisory committee has become the subject of serious concern among scientists, who fear a move to expand and alter its membership may be making it ineffective to cope with important new technical problems arising in recombinant DNA research.

title: Clarence A. Hill, 82, an Executive Of 20th CenturyFox Since 1926
description: Clarence A. Hill, a retired executive of 20th CenturyFox, died Tuesday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 82 years old.

title: A SummerJob Hoax
description: The most disturbing political phenomenon of the late 1970's is the precipitous decline of the American public's confidence in government. Unfortunately, the view of government as wasteful and incompetent is too often justified. A vivid example of carelessness in Government undertakings is the Summer Program for Economically Disadvantaged Youth, funded under the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act (CETA).

description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 15 (UPI)  The Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested Gov. Ray Blanton's bodyguard and his legal aide today for selling paroles for convicted felons and said Governor Blanton himself might have been involved.

description: TRENTON, Dec. 15  High school graduates from urban areas, even graduates of private high schools, generally fared worse in basic reading, writing or mathematics than their suburban counterparts, according to a report released here today by the Basic Skills Council of the Department of Higher Education.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: COME ON DOWN The place is the Music School at 46 Barrow Street, midblock southwest of Sheridan Square. The event is a holiday celebration sponsored by the BedfordBarrowCommerce Block Association. Doors will open to the public at 8 o'clock, with a $2 entry fee requested (no charge for children under 6 years), for the spread of homeprepared foods and seasonal beverages, Christmas music and Hanukkah melodies by neighborhood groups, and a puppet performance by the Bil Baird figures from the troupe showcase across the street. There's also a preparty caroling session at 7:30 in front of the school, with visitors invited to participate.

description: WEST POINT, N.Y. Dec. 15 (AP) Matt Brown scored 26 points and moved into seventh place on the Army career scoring list, leading the Cadets to a 6444 rout of Lafayette tonight.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec 15 (Reuters)Roy Jenkins, president of the European Common Market Commission, was quoted here today as saying he expected an international trade agreement, on the negotiators level only, to De conducted by the end of the year.

Devoted uncle of Judith Schecter, Doris Klein. Francine Stern. Adrienne Lesof. Laurie Horn. Sonya Schultz and Arthur Amchan. Dear greatuncle to Jay, Allison & Rachel Schecter, Nancy. title: South Africans Fear That Iran Crisis Might Cut Oil Supply
description: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 15  Amid a sea of troubles, South Africa suddenly has a new worry that transcends all others in immediate importance  a threat to its oil supplies posed by the turmoil in Iran.

title: CHARLES B. M'LAUGHLIN
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Dec. 15 (AP)  Bishop Charles B. McLaughlin died ye sterday of a heart attack. He was 65 yearsold and was the first Roman Catholic Bishop of St. Petersburg.

title: Bonds Down, Interest Up; Some Rates at Peaks
description: Bond prices declined and interest rates climbed yesterday  some to their highest levels on record  as uncertainty spread through the discouraged credit markets and investors worried about oil prices, the dollar and inflation.

title: Irish Move Welcomed
description: PARIS, Dec. 15  Ireland's decision to join the new European Monetary System Jan. 1 was welcomed in Europe today as giving new credibility to the attempt by Common Market countries to foster economic recovery by stabilizing their exchange rates and reducing their dependence on the United States dollar  the key goals of the currency bloc.

title: Holdup on L.I.

The Nassau County police said that James Webster, manager of the branch of the Long island Bank, was handcuffed for more than 30 minutes to a metal box that appeared to have dynamite in it before he could be freed. The box turned out not to be a bomb.

title: Youth Is Held in Murder of Teacher
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 15  A 17yearold youth who tells people what he did after just before he does it was captured tonight by the police as the suspected gunman whb killed a teacher yesterday at Wilbur Cross High School here.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16Two months before Adm. Hyman G. Rickover, the head of the Navy's nuclear submarine program, testified that there were no radiation problems at the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard in New Hampshire, the admiral privately informed the Navy that there were serious radiation hazards at the yard, a Ralph Nader organization said today.

title: GARDENING
description: PLANTS go through cycles of popularity along with so many other fads and trends. Remember the terrarium craze of a few years back when everyone tried to see how many tiny plants they could drop through the neck of a tall green bottle to make a woodland garden?

title: Upsets Prove N.F.L. Point
description: The National Football League, always looking to improve its product, was successful this year in making structural changes to achieve more equitable scheduling, adding two more wildcard teams to the playoffs, making a total of 10. The teams seemed to be closer than ever before and the upset has become commonplace  the latest example being last Monday night's game when Cincinnati, which had lost 12 times, beat Los Angeles, which had won 11 times.

description: JUDITH HOPE of East Hampton has been somewhat of a trailblazer for the last three years. She was the first woman in a post that hardly fits the female image  Governor Carey's appointments officer, the official charged with dealing with primarily male county leaders and other politicians over patronage appointments to the state ad ministration.

title: The Associated Press And Employee Guild Speed Up Pact Talks
description: The Associated Press and the Wire Service Guild intensified their efforts last week to negotiate a new agreement covering 1,240 employees in the 120 national bureaus of the news organization.

title: Watcher of Austria Is Downhill Winner
description: SANTA CRISTINA, Italy, Dec. 16 (AP)  Josef Watcher of Austria, the defending World Cup downhill champion, overcame a strong showing by the Swiss and a track slowed by fresh snow to score the first Austrian victory of the season today in a World Cup men's downhill race.

title: Patricia M. Olvany, Teacher, Wed to Robert Peter Hodson
description: Patricia Mary Olvany, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Link Olvany of Garden City, LI., was married there yesterday in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church to Robert Peter Hodson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert George Hodson of Manhasset, L.I. Msgr. Stanley Matthews of White Plains, performed the ceremony.

title: TANKER LOSSES RISE BUT SEAS ARE SAFER
description: BOSTON, Dec. 16 (AP)  At dawn on Dec. 15, 1976, the aging 30,000ton tanker Argo Merchant ran aground on Fishing. Rip Shaol off Nantucket. She foundered eight days, then sank, leaving behind long oil, slicks and nagging questions about maritime safety.

title: Steelers Conquer Broncos
description: DENVER, Dec. 16  Norris Weese, the chunky, cocky Denver quarterback who feels that he does not get to play enough, put in a wakeup call for the rest of the Broncos during the second half today against the Pittsburgh Steelers, and all sorts of fireworks exploded.

title: Burt Young 'Uncle Joe Shannon,' Film of Trumpeter on Skid Row:The Cast
description: "Uncle Joe Shannon" is about a once-famous jazz musician now lurching through skid row, his trumpet in one hand and a kid with cancer hanging on the other. Uncle Joe does not sell his trumpet to pay for the operation. But that is the film's only surprise. "Uncle Joe Shannon," which opens today at the Festival Theater, leaves no heart-string untugged.The film was conceived and written by Burt Young, its star, and it is an obvious labor of love. Nominated in 1976 for an Academy Award for his performance as Paulie the butcher in "Rocky," Mr. Young has a deserved reputation as one of the best character actors in films today. He is also the author of a number of television screenplays. But someone else should have taken this one in hand. Mr. Young sinks even himself into a morass of sentimentality."Uncle Joe" tells the story of a star trumpet player who takes off on a long, fast slide into sell lestruction after his wife and young son die in a fire. In the process, he acquires a youthful side-kick who is also on the run from life, and together they whip each other back into shape as Christmas rolls inevitably around the corner.The film is full of odd improbabilities. Uncle Joe keeps his worn possessions, including his son's charred trumpet, in his unlocked room in a fleabag hotel. His trumpet remains at his side, intact, through binges and suicide attempts. A hospital and orphanage are broken into with surprising ease. And, scorned by a group of jazz-club barflys when he is unable to get through a trumpet solo, Uncle Joe has them jiving in the aisles when he swings into a syncopated version of "Jingle Bells."Mr. Young's own performance stays on a single, beery note throughout, pain registering in his face and trumpet solos (dubbed by Maynard Ferguson) alone. But, in his directorial debut, Joseph C. Hanwright has gotten good performances from Madge Sinclair and Jason Bernard, as Joe's long-suffering friends; from Martin Beck as the wryly wasted hotel proprietor and, in particular, from a remarkable, pudgy little 12-year-old actor named Doug McKeon, who has a welcome, sardonic way with his lines. Bill Butler's cameras capture the slick night surfaces and ruined faces of the street people of Los Angeles so that, clichs in themselves, they have the impact of sudden revelation.For no reason apparent to this viewer, this film was rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested").

title: A Checkers Move
description: The Checker Motors Corporation, producer of what longlegged New Yorkers consider the only comfortable taxicab made in the United States, is being sold, with the proceeds to be used to set up an investment company under a new name.

title: Denise Young Wed To Robert Teicher
description: In Agudath Shalom Synagogue in Stamford, Conn., yesterday evening, Denise I. Young, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Young of Stamford, became the bride of Robert Lloyd Teicher, son of Dr. and Mrs. Marvin R. Teicher of New Rochelle, N. Y. Rabbis Joseph E. Ehrankrantz and David Golovensky officiated.

title: Unexpectedly, A New and Normal Era Begins
description: In Shanghai in 1972, when President Nixon and Prime Minister Chou Enlai issued their communiqu, nobody thought it would take nearly seven years to establish diplomatic relations between the world's most powerful nation and the world's most populous nation. Yet when the announcement finally came last week, it was dramatically sudden. Relations will be established on Jan. 1, and ambassadors exchanged in March. In recognizing that the People's Republic of China is the single Government of China President Carter told the nation from the White House, we are recognizing simple reality. In Peking's Great Hall, Prime Minister Hua Kuofeng, China's nominal leader, was saying much the same thing.

title: The Nation
description: LOS ANGELES  In California, the word water means more than the word money on Wall Street. Most people in the nation's most populous state live in the south. Most of the precipitation falls on the north.

title: Design/Dancing
description: With discothques enjoying a resurgence all across the nation, people everywhere are dancing again and discovering how much they've missed it. But, for many of them, it's not enough to dance only on special occasions. They are the people whose enthusiasm has been rekindled to the extent that they are setting up their own disco facilities at home.

title: U.S. Gives $10 Million in Grants For Prevention of Child Abuse
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UPI)  The Government has awarded $10 million in grants to community agencies, juvenile court programs and other projects aimed at prevention and treatment of child abuse and neglect.

description: ALBERTSON  Serigraphs and paintings by Sheltie Schneider; through Dec. 31; Shelter Rock Library, 165 Searingtown Rd. For hours, CH 87363.

title: Resorts Defends Bahamas Gift Policy
description: ATLANTIC CITY OFFICIALS of Resorts International Inc. say there is nothing illegal or unethical about giving gifts to those public figures in the Bahamas with whom they deal. The hotel operates two casinos in the Bahamas and one here.

title: Nancy Park Plans Wedding In March to Stephen McGlinn
description: Mr. and Mrs. John W. Park of Upper Montclair, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Lynn Park, to Stephen McGlinn, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. McGlinn of Vail, Colo. A March wedding in Upper Montclair is planned.

title: Psychiatrist Says Holiday Travel CanLead to Stress and Hostility
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 16 (UPI)  .The description of jolly holiday travel in Jingle Bells  Oh, what fun it is to ride in onehorse open sleigh  just does not apply in this day and age, a psychiatrist says.

title: Paloma: A Picasso Original In Her Own Right
description: PARIS  When Paloma Picasso arrives in New York this week she will bring some weighty baggage. There is, of course, what she always carries: her name, her fortune, and her position in the art world. The latter is charged with the future of her father's vast legacy, the birthright for which, as a child born out of wedlock, she fought for six years in the French courts.

title: Jewish Groups Charge Carter Has Abandoned Role of Mediator
description: Echoing the Israeli contention that Washington was no longer evenhanded in the dispute between Egypt and Israel, representatives of major American Jewish organizations charged yesterday that President Carter had abandoned the role of mediator in the Middle East peace negotiations and had become an advocate of the Egyptian position.

title: U.S. Plans To Fix Moriches Inlet
description: THE United States Army Corps of Engineers has announced plans to rebuild the channel in Moriches Inlet. But for boatmen who use the hazardous waterway, help may not come in time.

description: Someday, I often thought, we must take the children to Washington. This spring, the time was right: at 9 and 7, Jessica and Sarah were eager to see the Smithsonian, the White House and the Houses of Congress.

title: WASHINGTON

By his recognition of Communist China, he has guaranteed himself the most formidable assortment of political opponents at home and abroad since Franklin Roosevelt.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP)  Antidiabetes pills may be responsible for thousands of deaths a year and should not be taken by overweight diabetics, according to a consumer group.

Within a few months, T.I.A. had company, as Pan American World Airways offered to buy National, bidding VII a share. And last week, Eastern Air Lines joined the throng.

title: NEW JERSEY HOUSING
description: WE WANTED a share of the American Dream before it disappears. Ask Joseph and Gwen Komyati why they decided to purchase a home now at Holly Oaks, a development under way in Manchester Township, Ocean County, and that is what they will tell you.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: The Roman Catholic Church's notorious Index Librorum Prohibitorum, which lasted from 1559 to 1966 and included on its list writers such as Descartes, Cervantes, Pascal, Swift, Stendhal and hundreds of others, is only one form of suppression described in this book, which is now in its fourth edition. It contains more than 300 cases of literary censorship. Shakespeare was both banned and bowdlerized. Some writers are banned by keeping their work out of the country: Daniel Defoe's Moll Flanders was kept out of this country by the Customs Service until 1930, and Voltaire's Candide was seized by that same body in 1929, on its way to a Harvard class in French literature.

title: Freeholders Turning to Common Goals
description: MORRISTOWN COUNTY Boards of Chosen Freeholders in New Jersey, long known for taking independent positions on issues confronting their communities, appear to be preparing to work together next year on common goals.

A consignment store there, the Good as New Tack Shop, is full of bargains in riding apparel, gear and even stocking stuffers. Situated upstairs about a block past the railroad station at 35 Adams Street, this place makes riding habits, if not the riding habit, affordable.

title: ART VIEW
description: Egyptomania has been with us for a very long time. Homer had it. The Greek historian Herodotus had it, in the 5th century B.C. Shakespeare had it, flaknboyantly. Napoleon had it. Giuseppe Verdi had it, though initially he didn't fancy, writing Aida. C.G. Jung had it, and most memorably did it slake his craving for magic and myth.

However, she is now relentlessly closing off as much space as possible, hoping she can reduce the house to the size of a small apartment.

title: Rutgers Loses, 3418, in Bowl
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 16  Rutgers' first venture in a postseason football bowl was an unexpected success today  for 30 minutes.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: LettersT O T H E E D I T O R
description: Once again, Betty Friedan's insight has provided us with the essence of our own experience, our own past (The E.R.A.  Does It Play in Peoria? Nov. 19). Her portrait of Peoria High School is impressive just because it is not unique. It is the picture of high schools of the 30's in middleclass America everywhere. It was an era of accepted double standards for girls and boys: home economics vs. shop, class secretary vs. class president and sexual chastity vs. sowing the wild oats. However, there was equality in the classroom, and girls were expected to make the honor roll as well as the boys. A good education was considered great preparation for a secretarial job or for the role of an ambitious husband's wife.

title: Man Stabbed in Kennedy Melee
description: A 21yearold man was stabbed during a melee early yesterday in the American Airlines Terminal at Kennedy International Airport. The police said two men were arrested after the altercation, which involved several people. George Perez, 23 years old, of the Bronx, was charged with assault and obstructing governmental administration, according to the police. The second man would not give his name, but was charged with menacing and possession of a weapon, a 32caliber revolver. The injured man, identified as Pedro Rodriguez, underwent surgery at Jamaica Hospital for a stab wound in the side.

title: Prints for Giving
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR CERTAINLY one thing to look forward to in the art world during the Christmas season is the annual print show at the Harbor Gallery. It is a show that glows with an variety of selections of fine quality.

title: Outlaws Rock Band at Palladium
description: On Friday night the Palladium was rocked by the sounds of boogie and heavy metal. Boogie, which is the forte of Outlaws, the headlining act, has danceable spring in its step, while heavy metal, played by the opening band, the Pat Travers Group, treads with a dull thud.

title: FRANCE'S COALITION IS SPLIT BY DISSENT
description: PARIS, Dec. 16  Nine months after President Valery Giscard d'Estaing's centerright coalition narrowly defeated an alliance of Socialists and Communists in elections for Parliament, both groups are being torn by dissension.

title: Triple Crowns and Stings
description: Horse racing's balance sheet for 1978 showed another season of extraordinary new assets and disturbing old liabilities.

title: Con Edison Wins Ruling On Damage in Blackout
description: A New York State appeals court has ruled that the Consolidated Edison Company is not required to compensate seven businesses that sued for damages suffered in the July 1977 power blackout.

title: At Nudist Clubs in Wintertime, Only the Heartiest Few Disrobe
description: CROWNSVILLE, Md., Dec. 16 (UPI) Bonnie's father sipped wine quietly in the small, crowded cabin, never batting an eye as his 27yearold daughter and his neighbor's wife disrobed in front of a dozen men, women and children.

title: Heard on the N.F.L. Grapevine: Giants Are Looking for a Coach
description: Listened to the grapevine: Joe Paterno. Heard it through the grapevine: Dan Reeves.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 11:30 A.M. (Channel 4) Here and Now: Edward Ostrowski, president of Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association.

title: Author's Query
description: For a novel about the Vietnam War, I would appreciate pertinent letters, diaries, snapshots of and by veterans.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Some plays are written to be played, and some plays are written to be played with. William Douglas Home's The Kingfisher belongs in the latter category  you'd know Mr. Home was himself an actor, even if you didn't sneak a look at his Playbill biography  and now that I've seen two sets of sparring partners dancing out the idle arabesques of the piece, I'm content that such theatrical toys should exist. It was Ralph Richardson and Celia Johnson who were doing the honors in London a year or so ago; it's Rex Harrison and Claudette Colbert who are now nursing the evening to a glow here, and the essential point; I guess, is simple enough. Mr. Home hadn't committed this doodle, would the performers aforementioned be working this season at all? And if the piece weren't a junglegym composed of practically nothing but holes, would they have so many empty spaces to fill with their impertinent, infinitely polished, presences? It's odd how often it takes a thin play to let the actors wax fat.

title: Deaths
description: HOCHBERGJoseph L. The officers directors and members of the New York Public Adjusters Association mourn the untimely passing of their esteemed colleague, founder, officer, and director, on December 15, 1978. He played a prominent and decisive role in the establishment and advancement of the Public Insurance Adjusting profession both locally and nationally. He was a man of courage. thoughtfulness and cornpassion. His dedicated services spanning a period of over 50 years as a Public Adjuster leaves an indelible Imprint on all those with whom he came in contact. So long Joe we shall not forget you. To his be, loved wife Sue, his daughter Phyllis and son Ed and his bereaved family we extend our sincere and heartfelt sympattry.

title: Kathryn Kavazanjian Engaged to Daniel Joseph Leonard
description: Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Kavazanjian of Garden City, L.I., and Orient, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathryn Dorothy Kavazanjian, to Daniel Joseph Leonard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Leoanrd of Pittsburgh. The couple plan to be married July 14.

title: Mexicana in Middletown
description: MIDDLETOWN IT CAME as a pleasant surprise recently to find a modest establishment  La Boca  on the main street of Middletown, serving Mexican food a notch above that we have found to date elsewhere in Connecticut. Admittedly, that is tempered praise. While Mexico has one of the world's more interesting cuisines, it tends to lose considerably in its translation  or its journey  to the northeastern part of the United States.

title: Beauty/Dancing
description: Disco dancing first appeared to be simply a Saturday night fever. But now it's become much more  a national nightly pastime. Though it's chiefly done for fun, it can become an easy way of keeping fit.

title: Pleasant Memories
description: WILLIE MORRIS has allotted himself a tough task in setting down his impressions of James Jones. Jones was a mythic figure to those who served in World War II, to those who reached maturity during that era and to those like myself, who in the 1950's hid from adolescence in books. Those of us who were touched by From Here to Eternity all thought we had a handle on him. He was a hybrid of the practical Milt Warden and the romantic idealist, Prewitt. Hollywood compounded this into Burt Lancaster's manliness and Montgomery Clift's brooding sensitivity.

title: Breaking Loose
description: ONE school lesson most Americans remember is the importance of our Revolution: it was our beginning as a nation. Beyond that elementary fact, however, even the better informed among us seem not to have an adequate conception of the event. As adults we still think of it as an episode, such as Washington Crossing the Delaware, in some misty operetta or pageant. Why is our memory of the Revolution so faint? The distance in time is negligible, the documentary record is rich, and historians in each subsequent generation have labored to bring the story to life. And yet, if the Bicentennial is any indication, its hollowness and remoteness are irremediable. Why has the inner meaning of the Revolution eluded us?

title: R.H. Hartje Fianc Of Anne S. Phillips
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Lloyd Wayman of Birmingham, Ala., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Wayman's daughter, Anne Sturgis Phillips, to Richard Harlow Hartje, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Everett Hartje of Martinsville, N.J., and Fort Myers Beach, Fla. Miss Phillips also is a daughter of the late Dr. Carey William Phillips Jr., a pediatrician.

title: THE MARKETS
description: My clients read all the threatening news about the economy and the stock market, a Wall Street broker lamented last week, and that just keeps them holding onto their cash all the tighter.

title: Now Here Are the Toys I Want for Christmas
description: FOR children, Christmas is a joyous holiday meant only for getting toys, basically. Toys which are going to be (1) thrown away, (2) completely forgotten. Usually, a child will start a Christmas spirit in early November by making a Christmas list of things that appear on television or that his best friend has. I believe that a child will see something on TV, picture himself using the product and add it to his list.

title: Montreal: Stanley's Best Friend
description: It was Montreal's year. Again. That fact didn't change in the National Hockey League.

title: Driver Arrested on Three Counts
description: A Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., man has been arrested on charges of driving a taxi with a forged New York City medallion and with possession of a small quantity of narcotics and a loaded 32caliber revolver. The police said the suspect, Elliot Koppleson, 31 years old, was arrested Friday while driving at the intersection of Broadway and the Henry Hudson Parkway in the Bronx.

title: Limn Dance Company Appoints Carla Maxwell
description: Carla Maxwell, acting director of the Jos Limn Dance Company since June 1977, has been named permanent artistic director of the 18member moderndance troupe. The 33yearold dancer. who has been a member of the company since 1965, is the fourth artistic director of the company since its inception 31 years ago. Past directors were Doris Humphrey, who Joined Mr. Limn's newly created company in 1946 and remained until her death in 1958, when Jos Limn assumed the directorship himself, and Ruth Currier, who was named to the post in 1973 and remained until June 1977.

title: Tomlin and Travolta Update the Romantic Film
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Caution Urged on Holiday Lights
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP)  The Consumer Product Safety Commission reports that 440 persons were treated in hospital emergency rooms last year for injuries associated with Christmas tree lights.

title: A Correction
