description: Lao Lee, one of the restaurants mentioned in a Dec. 3 article about Chinese restaurants throughout New Jersey, is no longer open. The owner and chef, Tony Lee, has moved to Berkeley Heights, in Union County, and opened the Great Wall Restaurant at 408 Springfield Avenue. The telephone number is (201) 6651331.

title: Winners of Individual and Team Championships During 1978
description: Archery

title: Mondales Sending Out 5.000 Christmas Cards
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP)  Vice President Mondale and his wife, Joan, are mailing 5,000 holiday greeting cards depicting a snowy scene of the Vice President's official residence.

title: A Christmas Appeal: Give to The Neediest Cases Fund
description: As she talked, Anna F. peered at herself in a shattered mirror, torn long ago from a cosmetic compact. When she looked up, a cherubic smile enlivened her thin, frail face, framed by swirls of graying hair.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: With the 20th anniversary celebration of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater this season, it has been easy to look back nostalgically at the good old bad days. Two decades ago the Ailey Company shared the mystique of commitment common to modern dance. It was the dedication of a small young troupe involved in the exploration of an evolving esthetic and a dance style. That commitment obviously cannot be reproduced by a company that is now established on a unique wave of popularity and by dancers who. rather than collaborate at creating the whole cloth of a new dance style, now put on that style as if it were a readymade suit. Such progresssionfrom struggle to accomplishment, from search to consolidation  is the path followed by all major dance companies in the last 20 years and it is not surprising that the Ailey troupe has gone the same way.

title: New Rules Would Offer Needy Indians a Choice
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP)  Needy Indian families living on reservations would be given a choice of whether to receive federally donated commodities or food stamps to use at grocery stores, under regulations that have been proposed by the Agriculture Department.

title: Other Ideas & Trends
description: More than 50 years after the Scopes trial, teaching evolution is still a live issue for some people. In Washington, D.C., two religious groups and a former missionary with five children sued the Smithsonian Institution because it plans a $463,200 exhibit on evolution. Dale Crowley Jr. said the institution should forget the exhibit or spend an equal sum to present the biblical theory of man's origin. To go into such a powerful medium of education and be indoctrinated in evolution is offensive, Mr. Crowley said. But Judge Barrington D. Parker of Federal District Court ruled that the Smithsonian wasn't violating anyone's constitutional right to religious freedom. The plaintiffs can carry their beliefs into the museum with them, he said, though they risk seeing science exhibits contrary to that faith.

title: NEW GUIDES ISSUED ON GENE RESEARCH
description: New national guidelines for the conduct of research on recombinant DNA and proposals to make them binding on virtually all scientists, including those in industry, were made public yesterday by the Government.

title: GARDENING
description: PLANTS go through cycles of popularity along with so many other fads and trends. Remember the terrarium craze of a few years back when everyone tried to see how many tiny plants they could drop through the neck of tall green bottle to make a woodland garden?

title: Deaths
description: RADETSKYDr. Charles Howard. Sutton Place SYnoOogue expresses its heartfelt sympathy to our devoted member, Esther RadetskY, on the loss of her beloved husband. Services today, 12:30PM, Riverside, 76th St & Amsterdam Ave. Warren Alpert, President Sylvia Kattensteln, Sisterhood President

title: Getting Together
description: INTEGRAL to the Western system of tastes and prejudices that Edward W. Said (in a book so entitled) has recently characterized as Orientalism, is the belief that China, like other Asian civilizations, never changes and thus essentially has no history. This of course is nonsense. Far from being uniquely ancient  another canard  China was latecomer among the Old World civilizations; to hold the lead in technical and economic innovation, as it did throughout the European period of late Antiquity and the Middle Ages, it had to change much and quickly. During these centuries, China, like the other agrarian civilizations, suffered invasion by nomad horsemen the Huns, Avars, Turks and Mongols were visitors to both East and West  and by the international mass religions: Manichaeism and Christianity as well as Islam and Buddhism. China had her political ups and downs: ages of unity and division, of freedom and of control by foreigners. Only twice have the Chinese themselves ruled international empires: under the Ch'in and Han dynasties (21 B.C.A.D. 219) and under the Sui and T'ang (A. D. 581906). Before, after and between these empires came periods of disunion. The ups as well as the downs of this history sometimes came with extraordinary rapidity.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, DECEMBER 17, 1978

title: Food
description: We have noted before that for most home cooks each of the four seasons begins and ends with a holiday. Equinoxes and solstices are for savants. For many people, Labor Day uncompromisingly marks not only the end of summer but the end of cold, light food. Similarly, winter, with its festive holidays, is the time for warm, hearty fare. Yet there are some dishes that can successfully span the seasons.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Nobody has yet spelled out any hard and fast rules relating to fiction's obligations to historical truth and, I trust, no one ever will. Fiction isn't seamanship, which can be governed by internationally observed rulesoftheroad. All fiction of any merit absorbs history  sometimes with grand selfconsciousness, as in War and Peace, sometimes to create a kind of metahistory, as in Tom Stoppard's Travesties. and sometimes simply by having been written when it was. Pride and Prejudice is hardly a historical novel, but it's as much a record of human events and affairs of the past as is Gibbon's Decline and Fall.

title: By M.T.A. From Kennedy: A Bus in Blue, A Subway Train With Luggage Racks
description: Visitors were coming and I desperately wanted them to be able to get around the city by themselves. I asked a subway clerk for a map. Instead I got literature, a blue leaflet from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority: I could be whisked to and from Kennedy! Although this is not the thing I wanted, I filed it in my cerebral index.

title: The Folks Behind the Plush Toys
description: AS the site of Santa's workshop, the dingy whitishgray building at the dead end of Port Chester's Highland Street is, at best, improbable. Four long, confusing flights of concrete and metal stairs are not the architectural creation of a man used to gracefully gliding down chimneys.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: The Carter Administration, performing an aboutface, last week urged that reporters get statutory protection for a right not spelled out in the First Amendment  the right, under certain circumstances, to shield the confidentiality of their sources.

title: SHOP TALK
description: STAMFORD CHRISTMAS is traditionally the most rewarding time of year for retailers. But for Lyla Ward of Party Place at 856 High Ridge Rd. in Stamford, it's only a buildup for New Year's Eve.

title: The Predicament Of a Gifted Genre Singer
description: DUBLIN

title: Egypt Content To Let U.S. Act On Treaty Rift
description: CAIRO, Dec. 16  Egyptian officials indicated today that Cairo was content to remain on the sidelines during the rift between Israel and the United States, confident that the Carter Administration would undertake some new initiative early next year.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: To us today, all 19thcentury photographs have the charm of a distant past. This is certainly true the photographs of Egypt on view at the Prakapas Gallery, 19 East 71st Street, to Jan. 20, 1979. The foursquare integrity with which they record the ruins of ancient Egypt, their faded tones of sepia, pink and straw, and the solitude that surrounds their subjects take us back to another, more leisurely era. These pictures may include one or two figures in Arab dress to give scale to the ancient temples and tombs, but the crowds camel drivers, hawkers, tour guides and tourists that spoil all but the most remote sites today are nowhere to be seen.

title: A Psychiatrist as Novelist
description: THE fictional literature of psychiatry  such as One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest and I Never Promised You a Rose Garden  has been almost as extensive, and much more readable, than psychiatric tracts. Now, Frederic Neuman, a New Rochelle resident who the chief psychiatrist of the Westchester Community Health Plan, has united both forms.

title: Grand Prix Sailing Is in a Critical Stage
description: In offshore yacht racing, this was the year of the rules. New handicap rules were bandied about, old rules succumbed  anything to breathe life into the circuit. And at least one prescription worked: Performance handicap yacht racing succeeded in drawing nearly 700 yachts to starting lines in Long Island Sound during its first season.

title: 2 More in S.B.A. Office Are Transferred in Inquiry
description: Two people have been transferred out of the Small Business Admimistration's New York district office in connections with an inquiry into alleged fund misuse and potential fraud involving at least $3.5 million in a minoritybusinessloan program in the region, according to an official of the agency in Washington.

title: Decisions Split Boxing
description: Muhammad Ali and Roberto Duran, two of the biggest attractions in boxing, may have reached their limits in 1978.

title: Zukerman And Chamber Society
description: Like so many instrumentalists nowadays, Pinchas Zukerman likes to conduct as much as play the violin. On Friday night at Alice Tully Hall, he combined both functions with the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, performing the Brahms Violin Sonata No. 2 with the society's musical director, Charles Wadsworth, at the piano, and conducting Mozart's Serenade for 12 winds and doublebass.

title: Once Again, It's Time to Count Birds
description: NOT quite a sports event, not merely a scientific study and not exactly a social gathering, the79th annual Christmas Bird Count of the National Audubon Society is now in progress.

title: Patience, and Trust, in the Mideast
description: Egypt and Israel have lost an intangible part of their historic peace by failing to sign a treaty before today, as they agreed at Camp David to try to do. Their hitherto patient broker, President Carter, is justly annoyed. Unjustly, he blames only Israel.

title: Ballet Dancers, Opera Singers From Moscow at Town Hall
description: So many Soviet arts ensembles seen here have been designed by both the senders and their box officewise hosts as prestige blockbusters, that it is refreshing to see the odd group, even an uneven one, slip through the net of official SovietAmerican cultural exchange.

title: Can Greenburgh Avoid Its 31% Tax Hike?
description: THE Greenburgh town administration, under the leadership of Supervisor Anthony Veteran, has consistently juggled to cause debt and rising costs, and these officials have now evoked a fierce outcry of protest against a projected 31 percent tax increase that appears contrived to compensate for waste and excesses in the proposed 1979 budget.

title: Teresa Lynn Via Is Married
description: Teresa Lynn Via, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen F. Via of Charlottesville, Va., and William Stein, son of Mr. and Mrs. David N. Stein of Forest Hills, Queens, were married yesterday. The Rev. James Hodges Parker Jr. performed the ceremony in the New Covenant Church in Hampton, Va. The bride is a registered nurse at the JohnstonWillis Hospital in Richmond, where her husband is a foam compounder with Allen Industries.

title: Schools in a Class by Themselves
description: WHEN I need intellectual stimulation on a weekday afternoon, I wheel out my gearless bicycle and make my way with unamplified torque to my son's school. My experiences there comprise a curriculum of such depth and variety that I owe it to the community to set them down. Here, then, is a record of my most recent visit, which began with an inquiry into the ontology of boots and shoes.

title: Teevens of Dartmouth Wins Ivy's Bushnell Cup
description: HANOVER, N.H. (AP)  Eugene (Buddy) Teevens, the quarterback who led Dartmouth to the Ivy League football championship, has won the Ma S. Bushnell Cup as the league's player of the year.

title: KnickHawk Sellout Today (It's Ball Day)
description: For years the sports promotional gimmickry of Bat Day, Ball Day, Picture Day, Jacket Day and the like have done wonders to swell gate receipts. But since the Knicks moved into the new Madison Square Garden in 1968, they had been gimmickfree  until today.

title: Caemmerer Holding A Key to Westway
description: ALBANY LAST April, Governor Carey offered Mayor Koch an $800 million deal to win his support for the Westway, the controversial project designed to replace the crumbling West Side Highway in Manhattan.

title: Deaths
description: ELLSWORTHRobert Eugene, beloved husband of Mary Louise, adored father of Mrs. Richard Herrmann of Pittsburgh, Pa and Judith Louise. Dear brother of Irvin H. of Cincinnati, Ohio. Suddenly on December 14. Illustrious Commander in Chief of the Ancient Accepted Scottish Rite Bodies of New York City. A distinguished and beloved brother whose devotion, warm smile and friendly grip will be missed by all. Our deepest sympathies and condolences to the family.

title: 11 Inmates and 2Jail Employees Are Injured in an Upstate Blaze
description: WATERTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 16 (UPI)Eleven Jefferson County jail inmates and two jail workers were injured early today in a jail cell fire set by an inmate, deputies said.

title: Survivor Says He Heard Cheers And Gunshots After Cult Deaths
description: MATTHEWS RIDGE, Guyana, Dec. 16  Thirty to 45 minutes after the revolutionary suicide seemed to have ended and silence had fallen on Jonestown, a survivor hiding in the bush heard what he says sounded like a chorus of cheers from within the commune.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Coach Walt Michaels of the Jets, on the dubious value of statistics in pro football: I've always said statistics are like loose women; once you get them you can do anything you want with them.

title: Deaths
description: TAYLOR  Rina M. Retired T&T. Dear sistereg of Mary Sauter. Also survived by nieces and nephews. Reposing at Louis DeLuca & Sons Mayflower Funeral Home, 6022 Bay Parkway, Brooklyn. Mass of the Resurrection, Tuesday 9:45 AM, St. Athanasitts R.C. Church. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery.

title: What Teams Saw: 2,120 Starlings, Plus
description: Last year, birdwatchers taking part in the annual Christmas count in Boonton recorded a total of 16,781 birds. They were divided into 106 species, as follows:.

title: Wanted: A Home For TV Commercials
description: ENGLEWOOD FOR 15 years, Rita Gerson has scouted homes, both inside and out, to use for selling everything from toothpaste to soft drinks on television and in the printed media.

title: NEW PRO IN THE WHITE HOUSE
description: Suddenly, they're not laughing at Jimmy Carter anymore. Stories about Fort Fumble no longer circulate in Capitol cloakrooms. Congressional complaints about White House ineptitude have been replaced by complaints about White House steamrollers. There isn't much talk of a oneterm Presidency at Washington dinner parties these days. about White House steamrollers. There isn't much talk of a oneterm Presidency at Washington dinner parties these days.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: The Sometimes Bumpy Road From Stage to Screen
description: The premiere last month of Same Time, Next Year and the opening, on Friday, of California Suite represent yet another swing in the long relationship between stage and screen. As soon as Hollywood discovered talkies, it seems, it also discovered Broadway. But in recent years the filming of dramatic and comedy plays, as opposed to hit musicals, has diminished.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Auction mania. One million nine. Two million five fifty. The figures sound like bids for the services of a star pitcher. But no, they're the sums being paid nowadays for paperback reprint rights to hot literary properties at auctions so frenzied that they make headlines and feature stories in publications that usually pay little attention to the world of books.

title: Government Offers Solar Index For Watchers of Weather Data
description: Many weather buffs across the country Who keep records of meteorological data Will soon have a new toy to play with.

title: Train Subsidies Off the Track
description: Every year the economic rationale for subsidizing longdistance intercity passenger trains grows weaker. Yet every year More tax dollars are voted for Amtrak  lest rail service be discontinued in one Congiessional district or another. Now, however, things may be different. The President is determined to hold down spending without crippling essential Federal programs. And Congress is running out of patience with the sprawling 27,000mile passenger rail system.

title: Heroine as Victim;
description: PRAXIS, the British writer Fay Weldon tells us, is Greek for action, turning point, and orgasm, and Praxis Duveen's long life includes a generous supply of all those things. At present old, poor, barely able to hobble about her basement apartment and to scribble these memoirs, Praxis has been at various times Willie the student's commonlaw drudge, a prostitute, Ivor the businessman's suburban dollwife, Philip the film maker's glamorous working wife, mother of two, stepmother of three, a highly paid copywriter of ads glorifying the stayathome wife and a famous feminist leader. She has committed adultery, incest and infanticide, for which last she spent two years in jail. She has been raped. As a child she was the horrified witness of her father's violence, her mother's madness. In fact, into these 251 pages Fay Weldon has managed to cram at least one instance of just about every kind of manipulation and aggression that men use to get women where they want them, and just about every nuance of guilt and passivity that keeps women there.

title: Levitt, Citing Overcharges, Terms M.A.C. Lax on Printing Contracts
description: State Comptroller Arthur Levitt charged yesterday that the Municipal Assistance Corporation had been lax in controlling and scrutinizing contracts for printing work.

title: Kentucky's Burden
description: Before Kentucky defeated Duke for the National Collegiate championship, Joe B. Hall, the Kentucky coach, had called it a season without celebration. Throughout the season, Kentucky lived with the burden of being No.1 in the wireservice polls.

title: Robinanne Turiel, a Student, Engaged to Todd Rubinstein
description: Robinanne Joy Turiel and Todd Rubinstein, who expect to receive their degrees in June from the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law of Yeshiva University, plan to be married next year.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: When Inge Dorenwald was 6 years old, she wrote her first story. WEN, THE DEVILL, IZ, NOT, HOME, IN, HELL, HE, COMS, TO, VIENNA, TO VIZZIT. She was thinking of the folktale about St. Stephen's Cathedral witn its one rower, the other one never completed because the builder broke a pact with the devil and in retaliation, the devil hurled tower and builder both to the ground.

title: HARVARD'S NOZICK: PHILOSOPHER OF THE NEW RIGHT
description: Robert Nozick was not there when I arrived at his Emerson Hall office at Harvard. His secretary explained that he would be bicycling over shortly. Sitting alone in his office, facing that familiar edict Thank you for not smoking, I mused about the complexities of libertarianism  the defense of individual right that Professor Nozick has become celebrated for expounding in his widely acclaimed book Anarchy, State and Utopia. Since its publication in 1974, Nozick has become a darling of the right, and something of an enigma to his own profession.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: IN REPLY to accusations that like my dog better than I like the human members of my family, I'd like to point out the following facts:

title: Rutgers Five Beats Princeton by 5451
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Dec. 16 (AP) Depite poor foul shooting and only points from James Bailey, Rutgers held on to defeat Princeton, 5451, at the Athletic Center tonight.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: BRIDGEPORT  Holiday art collection reasonably priced, benefit Easter Seal Rehabilitation Center, through Jan. 5, weekdays 8:30 to 5, 226 Mill Hill Ave. Information 3667551.

title: IRAN: MAKING OF A REVOLUTION
description: You must be careful, the 21yearold college senior warns as she knocks on the door of the apartment. Do not shake hands with the women or look directly into their eyes when you speak to them.

title: Small Sale at Gate Disappoints Promoters of Garden State Bowl
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 16  Aubrey Lewis, a member of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, was leaving a meeting at Woolworth's in New Yorkyesterday when he stopped to chat with three other company vice presidents.

title: BOOB ENDS
description: BOOKBUYERS, combing through the lavishly illustrated art books for that one ideal Christmas gift, may be noticing a new imprint on the title page: The Vendome Press. It is in fact a new name, and it is the creation of Alexis Gregory, who has been active in publishing in Europe, though he has also packaged books for American publishers including Harper & Row, McGrawHill and Harry N. Abrams.

title: Life in the Fast Lane
description: THE flip side of Elizabeth Ashley's brassiness is the droll candor that lets her tell this story: In 1962, when she was an ingenue hit in Takz Her, She's Mine and very busy climbing onto her high horse, there were a number of famous visitors to her dressing room. One was Lucille Ball, who praised her performance and wondered if this Broadway neophyte would want to do any television work later on. Miss Ashley airily replied that she would never want to do any such thing. The words just fell out of my mouth, she recalls. Only when I thought about it later did I realize how insufferably snotty they were. I said that to Lucille Ball? My God!

title: A Series Of Sojourns
description: THERE is something about the Jewish past that draws people to attempt onevolume histories of the Jews. One would think that 4,000 years of civilization  with all the transformations and dispersions, the names and the documents, not to mention the problems of interpretation  would discourage the most determined synthesizer. Yet recent memory yields the names of many, both scholars and nonscholars, who did not desist: Max Margolis and Alexander Marx, Cecil Roth, Solomon Grayzel, Max Dimont, Abba Eban and many before them.

title: Jane Mary Sheehan Sets May Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Connolly of Brooklyn and Brightwaters, L.I., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Connolly's daughter, Jane Mary Sheehan, to Matthew W. Murphy of Philadelphia, a vice president of the Chicago Corporation on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange.

title: Places At No. 20, The Dowager Of 44th St.
description: Some streets of New York derive their personality from a single dominant building, while others are an amalgam of less distinguished structures that together create a general ambience. Not all blocks of the city, of course, are so fortunate.

title: Most Residents Of Chinatown Pleased at Ties
description: It's so great, Paul Lee was saying, an enormous smile spreading over his face as he stood in the door of his Pell Street gift shop yesterday savoring the news of full diplomatic recognition of China. I feel good. I feel so good I could float.

title: The Charm of Mistletoe Is Rooted in Its Mystery
description: WASHINGTON (UPI)  The white berried mistletoe may inspire Christmas kisses and fond embraces, but to the hardwood trees in which it lives, it is a parasitic killer.

title: Redskins Defeated And Miss Playoffs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) Steve Schubert returned a punt 73 yards for a touchdown today to lead the Chicago Bears to a 1410 victory over Washington and kill the last chance the Redskins had of making the National Football League playoffs.

title: B.C. Perkins Weds Tracy A. Trencher
description: Tracy Anne Trencher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Trencher of Glen Cove, L.I., and Bruce Coleman Perkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Howard Perkins of Washington, and North Haven, Me., were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed by State Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Suozzi at the Pierre.

title: Miss Hearst's Clemency Plea Gains Wide Support
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 16 (UPI)  An application from Patricia Hearst for executive clemency, filed with the Justice Department on Sept. 25, is supported by 48 members of the House of Representatives, both of California's United States Senators and a nationwide organization called the Committee for the Release of Patty Hearst.

title: Dead in His Prime
description: IT matters little that I do not entirely share John Lahr's enthusiasm for his playwright hero Joe Orton. His biography Prick Up Your Ears is excellent and, in several respects, an important one. IT helps us understand not only Orton himself but much about the English theater since 1956 and a little bit about our own.

title: Army Upholds Its Curb On Unauthorized Hats
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UPI) The Green Berets may continue to wear green berets and two battalions of Rangers may wear black berets, but all other Army personnel are forbidden to wear unauthorized hats of any kind after Jan. 1.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: CAIROThe United States has become  to use the current jargon  a full partner in Middle Eastern affairs. This goes for matters of war, peace and economics. It goes for Arab, Israeli and Iranian matters. This is America's moment in the Middle East. It is a role that the United States has coveted and that it now must live with.

title: Homicide
description: In May 1950, The Writer magazine listed as markets for Fact Detective Stories no fewer than 33 magazines ranging from Best True Fact Detective Cases to True Cases of Women in Crime, all of which published stories about real crimes, many of them written by journeymen writers who were often police reporters. In 1966, with the publication of In Cold Blood, Truman Capote bestowed upon the genre immediate respectability, thereby opening the floodgates for a torrent of nonfiction novels based on reallife murder cases. Only a handful of these have warranted more than the space they might have been allotted in those magazines of old, with their lurid covers depicting ladies in scanties threatened by hulking brutes with 5 o'clock shadows.

title: Martha Ann Gollup Affianced
description: Shirley Higgins of Syosset, L.I., and Abraham Gollup of Fort Lee, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha Ann Gollup, to Howard Gary Polin of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Polin of Freeport, L.I. The wedding is planned for Jan. 27. The prospective bride is national sales lease manager at Films Inc., Chicagobased film company, with which her fianc is a division manager.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: A musical salute to the holiday season will be offered by the Jersey City State College Choir at 2:30 P.M. Selections will include The Alleluia Chorus from Handel's Messiah and a group of Renaissance madrigals, Hebrew folk songs and Negro spirituals.

title: INTERVIEW
description: NEARLY onethird of the 27 speakers who addressed a budget hearing last Monday night focused on a subject that may have seemed oddly special or foreign to the majority who packed the eighthfloor chamber of tne tsoaro of Legislators. They were calling, in most cases, for retention of the Pretrial Services Institute of Westchester as a separate and independent agency.

title: Air Force Starts Drive to Retain Its Young Doctors and Dentists
description: OFFUTT AIR FORCE BASE, Neb., Dec. 16 (AP)  The Air Force, like the other services, used to be assured of medical officers by the draft. Now a shortage is forcing changes in the way it treats young doctors and dentists.

title: New International Order Seen
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16White HOUSE officials said today that the establishment of full diplomatic relations with China should lead to a fundamental realignment of global politics.

title: Prospects for Detroit's AlsoRans
description: DETROIT  There were glad tidings for the automotive industry last week  well, for part of the industry at least. Sales of Americanmade passenger cars during the first fortnight of December soared 24.4 percent compared to the same period last year. But the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company were the only winners. The Chrysler Corporation was down 8.1 percent, and the American Motors Corporation fell 20.7 percent. Detroit's alsorans were running true to form.

title: Adoption of Tree for Christmas Recommended by Ecology Group
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UPI)  City dwellers have an alternative to buying a cut Christmas tree, according to an envil ronmental group. They can, adopt one in. stead in a nearby park.

title: Seoul Hopes. U.S. Shift on China Will Lead to New Talks for Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 16  South Korean officials said today that they hoped the Carter Administration would use its new relations with China to ,help reopen the talks between.South and North Korea.

title: Deborah Johansen Wed to C. Fredric Hobbs
description: Deborah Johansen, daughter of Mary Lee Johansen and John MacLane Johansen, both of New York, was married yesterday afternoon to C. Fredric Hobbs of Los Altos Hills, Calif., son of Mrs. Mark Hinton of Los Altos Hills and Robert F. Hobbs Jr. of Bryn Mawr, Pa. The Rev. David S. Hill performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin in San Francisco.

title: Businesses, in a Survey, Are Optimistic on 1979
description: EVANSTON, III., Dec. 16 (UPI) Businesses do not appear to be anticipating a recession next year and will hire more than 26,000 college graduates, with engineering graduates most in demand, a survey by Northwestern University reports.

title: Mary Sweet Bride Of Martin Jacobson
description: Mary Azzara Sweet, daughter of Mrs. Charles J. Azzara of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Azzara, was married yesterday afternoon to Martin Douglas Jacobson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Jacobson of Jamestown, N. Y. The Rev. Henry Fehrenbacher, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the Tillman Chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: IT ALL depends on what questions are asked. That seemed to be the message last week in the continuing controversy surrounding the proposed takeover of Consolidated Edison's electricity network by the county. The issue will reach another flashpoint tomorrow when the Board of Legislators decides whether the concept will be put before voters in a March referendum.

title: Deaths
description: Amchan, Nathan

title: Argentina Reigns in Soccer
description: This was the year of the World Cup, and Argentina, the host team, earned soccer's most important victory in Buenos Aires in June. And as occurred in Munich four years earlier against West Germany, the Netherlands had to settle for second best.

title: Nonrunners of the World Unite! Tip a Bartender
description: The nonrunners' counterrevolution has finally begun.

title: Study Finds Decrease In the Use of Seat Belts
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UPI) Federal traffic safety officials say it now appears that only a minority of the nation's motorists are using seat belts.

title: Beyond Taiwan
description: Since history's most celebrated PingPong match eight years ago, there has been only one way for the United States and China to navigate around Taiwan, the only obstacle to their full relations. President Nixon and Henry Kissinger charted the course with Mao setung and Chou Enlai; President Ford held to it; President Carter and Teng Hsiaoping have now reached port together.

title: Birth
description: Births

title: Esposito Fumes as Rangers Bow, 41
description: BOSTON, Dec. 16  The odds seemed stacked against the New York Rangers this afternoon at Boston Garden. The Bruins had proved virtually unbeatable at home, losing only twice in 15 contests and going unbeaten in their previous eight.

title: The Lives and Works
description: MORE than 20 years after his death, Bertolt Brecht remains a peculiar case, an unsettled question. He was an exception, a man nothing like our conventional notions of the artisthero, and therefore an impediment to any clear, orderly intellectual history of his times. As Klaus Vlker emphasizes in this new biography, no important writer of the century was more public than Brecht, more intricately and aggressively involved in the gritty details of social and political actuality; none was more pragmatic in his conception of the artist's role. I am a teacher of behavior, he once said, and meant by that a practical guide, not a seer or master. Practical ity seemed to be everything to him: would a play do what he wanted of it, would an action in the realm of art have the right effect in the realm of politics?

title: Inman, 69212, Leads Golf
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Dec. 16 (AP)  Joe Inman carded a twounderpar 69 to take a fiveshot lead today after the third round of the $100,000 Central and South American open.

title: Clevelanders Have No Trouble Fixing Blame for Default
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 16  in the wee hours this morning, as the deadline for Cleveland to come up with $15.5 million to pay off its debts passed, the Mayor's press secretary was asked if Cleveland had, indeed, become, the first major rite in generations to default.

title: Yale Raises a Record $306 Million
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 14  Yale University's fourandahalfyear fundraising campaign has reached $306 million, the university announced, calling the total the largest ever reached in a private fundraising effort. Stanford University ended its fiveyear effort in April 1977 with $304 million.

title: Upton Sinclair: Recalling a Muckraker
description: MARTINSVILLE UPTON SINCLAIR, muckraker extraordinaire and the author of more than 100 books, died in Bridgewater Township on Nov. 25. 1968. at the age of 90.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstaiu.k, canety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computerprocessed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United Slates.

title: Court Says Jailed Man Should Get Jobless Pay
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Dec. 16 (UPI)  The Vermont Supreme Court has ruled that a man who lost his job when he was jailed for breaking and entering is entitled to unemployment compensation.

title: Becoming Good
description: THIS is Iris Murdoch's 19th novel, unusual I'm sure for a serious writer today. Her work keeps its interest, I think, because of its intelligence, a philosophically educated, uninfatuated English moral intelligence with nothing flashy about it. Yet her novels have a lot of flash  thanks to her quite remarkable powers of invention. Her stories, including this one, are marked by an uncommon variety and complication of incident; the reader is continually surprised and shocked by the abrupt appearances, disappearances and reappearances of characters, unexpected couplings and uncouplings, sudden shifts into bizarrerie, epiphanies of the spiritual and invasions of the demonic. (The demons are manmade: We are all potentially demons to each other, writes Charles Arrowby, the narrator of The Sea, the Sea, after 495 pages of haunting and being haunted.)

title: AT HOME
description: WHENEVER I need intellectual stimulation on a weekday afternoon, I wheel out my gearless bicycle and make my way to my son's school. My experiences there comprise a curriculum of such depth and variety that I owe it to the community to set them down.

title: To Stand on Its Own English Feet
description: BY November 1823, seven months after he had begun his long poem Eugene Onegin, and eight years before he finished it, Alexander Pushkin termed it a special sort of novel: I'm now working not on a novel but on a novel in verse  one hell of a difference. Eugene Onegin separates the moralistic 18thcentury novel  an imitative expression of some generally accepted essence  from the critical realism of the 19th century. Tatyana and Onegin's affair fails, as does that of her sister Olga with Lensky, but the story of their loves is an innovative success, Pushkin's triumphant courtship of the Muse leading to a new statement about man's nature. Onegin grows beyond the epigrams of salons, Pushkin beyond the vocabulary of the 1789 Academy dictionary, which excluded all foreign words unnecessarily introduced into Russian. As Tomashevsky pointed out, Pushkin wrote a book that, unlike the neoclassical and sentimental romanticism of his time, introduced new forms, new style, fresh language, and directly reflected life itself.

title: And Then A Home
description: IN its report on Palestine in 1937, the Peel Commission of Inquiry stated, No other problem of our time is rooted so deeply in the past. Now, when the problem affects all of us, a marvelous number Americans. especially the young and opinionated, know nothing of how onehalf the problem, that is say the Jews, reestablished their claim, how and when they came back, how they gained the foothold that became a state. That long, slow, inchbyinch return stretching over nearly one hundred years is, two of its aspects, the subject of the two books under review. Each brings new material to the surface, and together they would do much to dispel the prevailing ignorance if they were written for the general reader, which unfortunately they are not.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: ATLANTIC CITY (Resorts International HotelCasino)  Joey Bishop, comedian. Thursday through Saturday, 7:30 and 10:30 P.M. $19$21, including dinner at 6:30 and 9 P.M., respectively. Show alone: $15$17. Reservations suggested. (609) 3406169.

title: Cleveland AT A GLANCE
description: Ohio's largest city. Cleveland occupies 77 square miles on the southeastern shore of Lake Erie.

title: Pilot Hopes to Match the Wright Brothers
description: KILL DEVIL HILLS, N.C., Dec. 16 Ken Kellett knows just how Wilbur and Orville Wright must have felt on those bitterly cold days 75 years ago.

title: CAMERA
description: Through the years a change has taken place in the field of photo books and, as with all evolutionary procedures, something has been lost as well as gained. Gone is the book featuring pictures for their own sake, generally loosely grouped into themes such as family, sports or news.

title: PEOPLE
description: At a crowded hearing last week on Capitol Hill, the issue of gasoline price controls  as well as the conflict between cleanair standards and the need for economical fuel  was hotly debated by the likes of John F. O'Leary, the Deputy Secretary of Energy, who favors removing price controls  and Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, who wants to retain them.

title: Medicine
description: On Friday, four weeks after more than 900 members the People's Temple died in Jonestown, Guyana, United States military doctors began autopsies on the Rev. Jim Jones and six of his followers. To many experts, it was a belated and inadequate attempt to try to determine what caused their deaths.

title: Lyle Acquitted of Murder In Death of Former Aide
description: GOLDEN, Colo. Dec. 16 (UPI)  A Jefferson County district court jury acquitted Ron Lyle, the heavyweight fighter, today of seconddegree murder charges in the shooting death of his former aide, Vernon (Rip) Clark, last Dec. 31.

title: Drs. Linda Barzelay, D.B. Carpenter Marry
description: Dr. Linda Barzelay, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur R. Barzelay of Oradell, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Duncan Breckenridge Carpenter, son of Dr. and Mrs. Malcolm B. Carpenter of Rockville, Md., and Hershey, Pa. Tne Kev. Dr. Thomas F. Pike, rector of the Episcopal Parish of Calvary, Holy Communion, and St. George's in New York, performed the ceremony at the Pauline Hartford Memorial Chapel of the Presbyterian Hospital.

title: Rono Runs Wild
description: For much of 1978, track and field was a fourletter word  Rono.

title: LIVELY ARTS These Isotopes Hit High Dixieland Note
description: PETER MEYERS, with three soundless beats of his clarinet, brings the sevenmember band called the Isotope Stompers to life and, moments later, the audience is keeping time to the Dixieland lau.

title: Ruling on SchoolHater Assailed
description: CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 16 (AP)  The New Hampshire Board of Education says a 9yearold girl who hates school must be taught there rather than in her home. But the girl's mother said she would challenge the ruling.

title: ANTIQUES
description: OLDWICK THERE is some controversy over whether it was Betsy Ross who made the American flag, but there is no doubt that it was aldece of patchwork.

title: Job Satisfaction Found Waning, Notably Among MoreEducated
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UPI)  Many Americans have become less satisfied with their jobs in recent years, according to a Governmentfinanced survey, released today by the Labor Department.

title: EAST GERMANS RAISE MILITARY SPENDING
description: EAST BERLIN, Dec. 16 Despite economic setbacks and shortages in domestic energy supplies, East Germany has announced a 5 percent increase in arms spending next year to strengthen the Warsaw Pact military alliance.

title: Liverpool Is Upset in Soccer, 10; Everton Gains a Tie With Leeds
description: LONDON, Dec. 16 (AP)  Bristol City upset Liverpool today, 10, sending the English League leaders to their third defeat in two weeks. Joe Boyle scored the goal in the game at Ashton Gate.

title: Jet Plan: Finish With a Flourish
description: All week long, Walt Michaels, the New York Jets' coach, has been inoculating his team against a case of the blahs. He has been hoping that the Jets will not let down for today's season finale because they're out of the playoffs. The Dallas Cowboys, the defending Super Bowl champion, are in Shea Stadium for the 1 o'clock game.

title: 30TH YEAR MARKED BY PACE UNIVERSITY
description: Not long ago, Pace University seriously considered holding midnight classes, and school officials who conducted a survey on the subject say the responses were encouraging.

title: THE PERILS OF GUARDING KING TUT'S TREASURES
description: In the opinion of some leading security experts, the Treasures of Tutankhamun exhibition which opens Wednesday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (the nexttolast stop on its sevencity haul around the United States) has been guarded by unusually vuinerable and at times lax and unprofessional safety measures. Had Murph the Surf been on the prowl, these experts believe, the fabulous collection might never had made it thus far intact. Such a conclusion is ironic, to say the least, not just because of the priceless nature of the 55 objects in the show, but also because the American mu seum world now has at its disposal a security technology so sophisticated it might well raise an admiring eyebrow from the officials in charge of Fort Knox. Yet  whether through ignorance, false economy, smugness or sheer folly  these resources have not been tapped, until the past few weeks, to safeguard King Tut's legacy of burnished gold.

title: Margaret Frazier Plans Wedding to K. T. Plodzik
description: Margaret Ann Frazier of Lexington, Mass., an assistant professor of nursing at the Boston University School of Nursing, plans to be married in July to Kevin Thomas Plodzik of Middle Village, Queens, a Spanish teacher at the Great Neck (L.I.) South Junior High School.

title: Where to Jog When the Snow Starts Falling
description: AFEW years ago, 9 out of 10 suburbanites greeted the onset of winter with questions like when should the car be winterized? How soon can the storm windows be installed? Does my ski parka still look O.K.? Today, however, the list is likely to include another minor dilemma  where will I go jogging?

title: U.S. Strategy in Nicaragua Keeps the Time Bomb Ticking
description: MANAGUA, NicaraguaAfter a combined nationwide strike and popular insurrection in Nicaragua in September failed to oust President Anastasio Somoza Debayle, opposition groups turned almost in despair to Washington for help. The United States sent a mediation team (with Guatemalan and Dominican participation) that promised to succeed where businessmen and guerrillas had failed. But 10 weeks later, hope has given way to disappointment and anger. General Somoza is still in power, and the State Department's proposals are unacceptable to all but the most conservative of his foes.

title: So Are the Choices. Can All the Sick Be Served?; Rx for Health Care: The Cost Is Staggering
description: WASHINGTON  Missing from the last week's rhetorical skirmish between President Carter and Senator Edward M. Kennedy over national health insurance was mention of its cost. That is probably because Mr. Carter wishes the issue would go away, while Mr. Kennedy knows that the estimates would stagger even his own supporters.

title: Music in Review
description: The Borealis Wind Quintet, a twoyearold group composed of former and current Juilliard graduate students, was heard last Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. All five members they are Meta Orear. flutist; Tamar Beach, oboist; Kathryn Taylor, clarinetist; Philip Gottling, bassonist, and Richard Price, horn player  are accomplished instrumentalists, and they play well together. If Mr. Price seems worth singling out, it is because his tricky instrument is sometimes a weak link even in superior wind groups. Mr. Price's playing, however, was expressive and reliable throughout the evening.

title: Hoping to Keep the Theater's Lights Burning
description: TARRYTOWN THERE have been rosier days, to put it mildly, in the brief but inglorious history of the Westchester Premier Theater, and no one is more aware of the contrasts than Gerald T. Donnellan.

title: SPORTS
description: NEW CANAAN ANYONE for a museum? Attention all hamlets, townships and cities! NAMOS is looking for a permanent home, and right now it is focusing on Connecticut. It wants to settle down like any responsible institution.

title: Role of Electronic Mail Is Studied
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16  President Carter has set in motion an interagency study of the role of electronic communications in future postal systems.

title: Yanks, Rose Stun Baseball
description: I guess, Carl Yastrzemski said, sounding like the designated spoke& man for all baseball in 1978, I'm just numb.

title: J.A. Mattes Fianc Of Amy R. Becker
description: Amy Rozanne Becker of Washington, a candidate there for a doctorate in clinical psychology at George Washington University, and Dr. Jeffrey Alan Mattes, a psychiatrist in Forest Hills, Queens, plan to be married July 1.

title: And Now a Flag Count By Capitol Architect
description: WASHINGTON (AP)  There were 10,471 United States flags. flown from the roof of the Capitol on July 4, 1976, the nation's 200th birthday.

title: IN BRIEF
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries sent warnings to the Western industrialized nations that the freeze on oil prices will end in 1979. Oil ministers of the 13nation cartel, arriving in Abu Dhabi for their semiannual pricing meeting that began yesterday, said that the increase may take place in increments through the coming year.

title: Parley Discusses the Practical Side of Nuclear War
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16  It was an unlikely encounter. Paul Newman, the motion picture star, cornered two retired admirals and asked them whether it was really necessary for the United States to continue building up its nuclear arsenal.

title: Epics and Errors
description: RESPONSIBILITY, justice, courage and moderation these are the Confucian virtues that Charlton Heston represents, a newspaperman in Taiwan told the actor not long ago, seeking to explain the phenomenal popularity of his movies in the Far East. Confucian they may be, but these virtues are at the core of Mr. Heston's film persona to all moviegoers, East or West; and, from the evidence he offers in The Actor's Life: Journals 19561976, they may be at the core of his entire existence.

title: Specialty Shops for Hanukkah Gifts
description: HANUKKAH is just about upon you, you have not bought any gifts and you are frantic. Where can you find a copy of an ancient oillamp menorah, a jigsaw puzzle depicting momentous events in modern Jewish history or a plastic shopping bag imprinted with the word schlep all for sale under one roof?

title: Buffalo Abortion Law Requiring Counseling Blocked by U.S. Judge
description: A judge in Federal District Court in Buffalo has barred the enforcement of a new Niagara County antiabortion ordinance under which women were required to look at photographs of fetuses before they could obtain abortions.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: DON'T tell me you're going to go on and on about leaves again, my wife said with despair that was far from mock as I sat down to catch the spirit of the Island, to mirror its infinite moods and reflect on the many ways of life that are perpetuated from the craggy spit of Montauk to the lushly shoppingcentered plains of Mineola. Whenever you start a grand sweep of the Island, it always comes down to leaves, sweeping leaves.

title: The Puzzling Case Of the Stolen Silver
description: NEW LONDON ON the night of Aug. 3, at precisely 10 o'clock, thieves smashed in the heavy plateglass door of the Lyman Allyn Museum, broke open a display case and, in less than three minutes, made their getaway with 13 pieces of virtually irreplaceable American silver. In the four and a half months since that night, no trace of the thieves has been found; no rumors concerning the rare, marked silver have surfaced among collectors, dealers or auction houses.

title: An Amateur's Luck Leads to a New Line Of Hybrid Hollies
description: Alittle knowledge goes a long way in horticulture. At least, that's what Kathleen K. Meserve insists. And since the Nissequogue; L.I., woman over the past 15 years has developed six popular hybrid hollies known as the Blue Hollies even professionals would think twice about arguing her point.

title: Budget Cuts Peril Transit Run by Counties
description: HAUPPAUGE THE drive for fiscal restraint in government claimed some more victims last week as the Suffolk County Legislature refused to reverse its decision not to finance a county bus system and not to continue the BrentwoodCentral Islip bus program known as DialARide.

title: A.M.C. has high hopes for a French connection.
description: Sales of American Motors passenger car have been rolling toward oblivion. When the final results for 1978 are tallied, the company will be lucky to have 2 percent of the newcar market.

title: F.C.C. Rebuffs Student Battle To Save Station
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16  A studentoperated radio station at the University of Pennsylvania, WXPNFM, lost a round yesterday in its appeal to the Federal Communications Commission to be allowed to stay on the air.

title: OPEC Nations Meet to Consider a New Price Rise
description: PARIS  Few people beyond petroleum experts had heard of OPEC before the fall of 1973. Now the acronym appears commonly in crossword puzzles, clued as powerful Middle East cartel or Arab oil group. It conjures images of fabulously wealthy sheiks wielding a lethal weapon in the shape of a faucet to force an oilthirsty world to their bidding.

title: Miss Spencer, Peter Adams Will Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hollister Spencer of Rochester have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Weed Spencer, to Peter Sayles Adams of Arlington, Va., an economist with the Department of Commerce.

title: Sergiu Luca:
description: Whenever I set out on a concert tour, I take along a double violin case containing two violins and four to six bows. That in itself is not so unusual  many violinists take along a spare. Except that in my case there are no spares. Big A (my 1669 Nicolo Amati violin on which I play, music before 1800) and Big B (my 1733 Carlo Bergonzi on which I perform music written after 1800) were both made in Cremona, Italy, and left their respective makers' shops within 70 years of each other looking and sounding very much the same.

title: U.S. to Continue to Sell Some Arms to Nationalists
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16  The United States will continue selling arms to Taiwan on a selected basis so that the Nationalists can keep their Americanequipped army, air force and navy in shape, a senior Defense Department official said today.

title: Fashion/Dancing
description: These are the evening slippers to wear when the emphasis is on glamour  and the focus is on beautiful legs and feet. Slim, sexy shapes, high, high heels, and all the shine and glitter needed to match the pulseracing beat of disco dancing.

title: Accident Victim Refuses to Quit
description: Nearly three years ago Matilda W., a 36yearold domestic worker with two children, stood on a cold, windy street corner in Brooklyn waiting for a streetlight to change. Suddenly a car swerved, hitting Mrs. W., who was rushed to Kings County Hospital in critical condition.

title: Patricia Vanacore Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Vanacore of Mendham, N.J. and Long Lake, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Eleanor Vanacore, to Frank W. Dufford Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Dufford of Middle Valley, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: More Stringent Rules Are Urged To Curb California Pesticide Use
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 16 (AP) Use of pesticides in California, the country's No. 1 producer of 48 crops, is under growing attack from groups that say the, regulations are not strict enough.

title: Notes: Will the U.S. Flag Make a HighSeas Comeback?
description: There are signs that the United States flag may once again fly from the stern of an oceangoing passenger liner. Others have tried and failed to return grand old ships to their former glory in American waters, so a note of skepticism may be in order, but should present plans succeed, the United States, the world's fastest transAtlantic liner, will sail again  as a cruise ship out of Honolulu.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Many collectors who have long used the the book entitled SoCalled Dollars as a reference guide will be happy to hear that the volume has been brought up to date, after 15 years, by a priced supplement called Current Valuations.

title: If You're Afraid . . .
description: ... to fly, and want to enroll in this program, write to Fearful Flyers, Room 4523, Pan Am Building, New York 10017. Your name will be kept on file, and you will be notified of the time and place of the next seminar.C.L.

title: Apartments for Blind Under Way
description: Construction began last week on the city's first apartment building designed for the exclusive use of the blind.

title: Net Final Reached By Evert
description: TOKYO, Dec. 16 (AP)  Chris Evert and Martina Navratilova won semifinal matches today and will meet in the final of a $200,000 women's tennis tournament tomorrow.

title: Editors' Choice
description: THE COUP, by John Updike. (Knopf, $8.95.) Rich, surprising, often funny novel set in a mythical African country.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
description: DO NOT FORGET THE NEEDIESTI

title: Antismoking Rules Turned Voluntary
description: WHITE PLAINS THE smoking ordinance forwarded to Albany last week by the county's Board of Health differs significantly from the original draft, which would have prohibited smoking in restaurants, theaters, hospitals and offices except in designated areas.

title: TV: Popularity of 60 Minutes Based on WideRanging Reports
description: CBSTV's 60 Minutes, the network's news magazine program, celebrated its 10th anniversary in September. The program of Nov. 26 did something that had been thought impossible for a news program  it topped the week's Nielsen audiencepopularity ratings with a 29.6 and an extraordinary 45 percent share of sets in use.

title: Sports Books of the Year: Cauthen, Cannon, Curry
description: A Standard Guide to PureBred Dogs compiled and edited by Harry Glover (McGrawHill, $24.95). Descriptions, standards, photographs and drawings of 350 breeds.

title: Indoor Soccer League Kicks Off
description: Shep Messing, the player, and Pete Rose, the owner, are the names most frequently mentioned in the selling of the Major Indoor Soccer League, which will kick off its initial season Friday night.

title: Answers by Gnter Grass
description: HEN Morris Dickstein reviewed Gunter Grass's The Flounder last month he described it as a gargantuan fable . . . Grass's first major novel in 15 years and one of the most exuberantly inventive works in recent European fiction. Since then, Richard Plant, a specialist in 20thcentury Germarrliteralure, interviewed Mr. Grass in the New York offices of Mr. Grass's publisher, Harcourt Brace Jovanovich.

title: Zambia May Ask for Soviet Arms
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 16  In dire need of bolstering its defenses, Zambia is prepared to turn to the Eastern bloc for arms to fend off further raids from Rhodesia and South Africa, according to President Kenneth D. Kaunda, who was sworn in yesterday for a fourth fiveyear term.

title: Newark Schools At Epidemic Stage
description: NEWARK CARL SHARIF, president of the Board of Education here and the moving force behind the announcement that more than 1,000 school employees would be laid off in an economy move, has warned that additional drastic changes will be needed to assure a proper education for the city's 67,000 students. The school district here is the largest one in the state.

title: Minorities Eye the Job Path
description: AN organization called the Long Island Minority Planning Institute, designed to prepare youths for participation in the economic development of the Island, was established last week as an outgrowth of a symposium of 125 representatives of minority organizations in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

title: A Sharp Increase in Retirements Is Viewed as a Cause for Concern
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP)  The number of men who are retiring between the ages of 60 and 64 has increased sharply in the last 20 years because of improved retirement plans, and the trend is creating strains on Social Security and private pension plans.

title: Democrats Unlikely to Oust Byrd
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UPI)  Senator Harry F. Byrd Jr., the Virginia renegade, appears in almost no danger of being forced out into the cold by Senate Democrats.

title: FOOD
description: FOR only about three of his 84 years can Oliver Wright remember a Christmas without Christmas pudding. That was when I was away in the Army, he explained.

title: Daphne Warburg Plans Nuptials
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. M. Warburg of Westport, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Daphne Warburg, to Michael Ramon Langhorne Astor, son of Sir John J. Astor and Ma Inez Astor of London.

title: U.S. TRADE OPTIONS IN PEKING ASSESSED
description: Several Factors Could Delay Rise in China's Business to Match Nationalists or Japan'sWASHINGTON, Dec. 16  After President Carter announced that the United States would establish diplomatic relations with China, he walked into the White House press room and told reporters, among other things, that his decision would open a new vista of trade relations with the almost one billion people of China.

title: CHESS
description: After a long period of doldrums, Grandmaster Lubomir Kavalek of Reston, Va., soared through the last six months in a blaze of glory. First he defeated the Swedish grandmaster Ulf Andersson in the Volvo match in Washington by a score of 63. Then he won the United States championship in Pasadena in very convincing style.. And, playing first board for the United States in the World Chess Olympiad in Buenos Aires, he turned in a strong 74 score.

title: John Maturo 3d Is Fianc Of Cheryl Corso, Teacher
description: Mr. and Mrs. David J. Corso of Hamden, Conn., have, announced the engagement of their daughter, Cheryl Ann Corso, to John E. Maturo 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maturo Jr. of Bloomfield Hills and Shelby, Mich.

title: Height of Kings Point's Flagpole Is Proving a Puzzler to Guinness
description: The Guinness Book of Records, which yearly records the superlatives about virtually everything, recently adivised the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L.I., that we now have a large query regarding the tallest unsupported flag staff.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Mime With a Message

title: Deaths
description: CULVERFlorence P. Aged 83. On December 15, 1979. At her residence East Quogue. N.Y. Survived by a daughter Mrs. Fred G. Palmer Jr., of Manlius. N.Y., 2 sons Harry P. of Roseland, N.J. and John F. of McMurray. Pa., a brother Dr. Joseph H. Phillips of Manhasset, N.Y, and 13 grandchildren. Reposing at Follett Funeral Home. Westhampton Beach. N.Y. Sun 24 and 7.9 PM. Funeral Mon Dec 10 at 11 AM at the East Quogue United Methodist Church. Interment Westhampton Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributtons maybe made to the Memorial Fund of the East Quogue United Methodist Church.

title: What Are the Rules For Baked Alaska?
description: WHEN did you last order freshfruit cocktail in a restaurant and have it arrive with segments of canned oranges or grapefruit in it? And how often has the Roquefort dressing tasted suspiciously like blue cheese? And how about the homebaked pies and breads that so obviously aren't? Or the bay scallops that are really the less expensive sea scallops or cookiecuttered red snapper in disguise?

title: A Smoldering Battle Over Rolling Paper Technology
description: A courtroom battle over the patent rights to a piece of wire is roiling the rolling paper world, threatening to turn the multimilliondollar paraphernalia business upside down. And it's happening at a moment when the industry which supplies tools for the ingesting and preparing of illicit drugs  has been hit by a serious sales slump, caused in part by a decline in marijuana supply.

title: Thomas Zara to Wed Mary Borie
description: Mr. and Mrs. David B. Borie of Greenwich, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Mary Washington Borie, to Thomas Dewees Zara of New York. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Zara of Santa Ma, Costa Rica. A June wedding is planned.

title: The Region
description: Industrial waste, it sometimes seems, is oozing out all over the region. Last week, there was an unneeded reminder of that fact; New York authorities reported that nearly an acre of Staten Island marshland had been covered by an oily sludge that may or may not have been spilled deliberately. The controversy over New York's Love Canal and the matter of who will pay for massive damage claims could have a longer life than the buried chemicals that made the Niagara Falls dump a poisoner of those who lived around it. Eventually, under proposed Federal standards announced last week by the Environmental Protection Agency, lethal waste will have to be disposed of with care. But authorities and the industries involved are concerned about the cost of the expensive improvements mandated by Federal and state agencies and about what's to be done about other Love Canals yet to be discovered. The following is a statebystate report on the pollution situation in the region.

title: Open Policy Is Asked On Charity Solicitation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UPI) Policies that allow United Way programs to monopolize charitable solid. cation at employees' places of work should be repealed and opened to all nonprofit, taxexempt organizations, according to a report by the National Commission on Neighborhoods.

title: Borg, Nastase Advance
description: MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, Dec. 16 (UPI)  Bjorn Borg of Sweden, Raul Ramirez of Mexico, Ilie Nastase of Rumania and Peter Fleming of New Jersey advanced yesterday to the the semifinals of the $320,000 World Championship of Tennis Challenge Cup.

title: ART
description: MONTCLAIR THERE are those in the art world who believe that Abstract Expressionism has run its course since its heyday in the 1950's.

title: Wise Philip Rallies. To Win Gallant Fox
description: The Argentinebred Mister Brea, whose credentials seemed outstanding, finally made his racing debut on American soil yesterday but disappointed after being sent to the post as strong second choice in the $53,750 Gallant Fox Handicap.

title: Highland Park: Site of State's First Eruv
description: HIGHLAND PARK WHEN Mrs. Irwin Asher moved to nearby Edison a little more than a year ago, she found it difficult to make friends.

title: Other World Events
description: British Prime Minister James Callaghan has been using the threat of economic sanctions to enforce his Government's unpopular antiinflation limit on wage increases. Last week he lost that weapon when the House of Commons voted to ban such sanctions when companies give pay increases that exceed 5 percent.

title: What a Lawyer Owes His Client
description: Lawyers should be held to the highest ethical standards; they should go to the board if they are uncomfortable with corporate activities, says Art Mathews, a partner of Wilmer Cutler & Pickering, the prestigious Washington law firm. But a lawyer can't be schizophrenic: To say the client's own lawyer whom he pays to represent him should blow the whistle on him is really going too far.

title: For the Shah, Mixed Echoes Of 1953 Revolt Sound in 1978
description: TEHERAN, Iran  The crisis that threatens to push Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi off the Peacock Throne of Iran erupted just 25 years after another crisis in which he was driven into exile, only to return in triumph.

title: Most Jonestown Deaths Not Suicide, Doctor Says
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 16 (AP)  The Guyana Government's top pathologist says he believes murder, not suicide, claimed more than 700 of the 911 persons who died at the People's Temple commune at Jonestown, Guyana.

title: Year in Sports: The Rivalries, The Fumble
description: FOURTEEN games off the pace in July, the New York Yankees won the baseball championship of North America in October after losing the first two World Series games. It was a great year to be a Yankee fan, a Yankee fan said of 1978.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: PERHAPS they're peculiar to the New Jersey suburbs. Perhaps they're typical of the suburbs in general. But, since I'm an urbanite transplanted into suburbia, people who devote a lot of their time to leaves  thinking about them or being disturbed by them  strike me as, well, different.

title: Corning Down From the Vivaldi Craze
description: It was about 25 years ago that the Vivaldi craze hit the classical music world. Virtually ignored for over two centuries after his death in 1741, Vivaldi suddenly became the most fashionable composer of the moment. College students crammed for exams with The Four Seasons grinding away on their hifi sets; the concerti erossi were required accompaniment for all cocktail parties; chamber groups arose from nowhere to play concert after concert of music by Vivaldi and his contemporaries Albinoni, Manfredini, Geminiani and the others; and of course recordings appeared by the dozens. somehow the motoric rhythms, diamondhard textures, cleanlined melodies and the cool, slightly anonymous cast of the music seemed the perfect musical background for those crewcut Eisenhower years.

title: Fabiola Bleiberg and a Lawyer Are Married
description: Fabiola Bleiberg and Stephen Schlessinger were married yesterday at the Lotos Dr. Patrick Sullivan, dean of the faculty of Vassar College, performed the ceremony.

title: Homeside Movies When You Want Them
description: It's been a long time in the making, but after a decade of false starts, the videodisk homeplayback system that attaches to a television set and plays prerecorded movies and other programs is finally coming to market.

title: Marriage Announcement 1 -- No Title
description: Engagements

title: Another Train of Thought on Commuting
description: DECEMBER is only just past its halfway point, but Conrail's North Jersey Coast line is already in midseason form, what with delays an almost daily occurrence.

title: Deaths
description: CAPLANLouis. The American Jewish Committee records with heartfelt sorrcw the passing of cur revered and beloved former President and current Honorary President. A distinguished community leader, his was a lifetime of dedication in the service of his country, his community, and his coreligionists. He provided extraordinary vision and sensitive leadership to the task of broadening the vistas of understanding among peoples, and in explacing new means of overcoming bigotry and hatred. To commemorate his leadership in civic life, AJC established the Louis Caplan Center for Community Services. Last year, through the generosity of the Maurice Falk Medical Fond, we created the Louis Caplan Center on Group Identity and Mental Health to further research in this vital area, with which he was closely identified. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Richard Maass, President Bertram H. Gold, Exec Vice Pres John Slawsce, Exec Vice Pres Emeritus

title: Letters: What to Do If You Run Out of Cash Overseas
description: To the Editor:

title: The Region
description: New York City had a new head of its unwieldy municipal hospital system last week and, although he said, I don't want to come in as an efficiency expert, he added quickly. but there's certainly room for that. What Joseph C. Hoffman, the excop turned hospitals adminstrator, meant was brutally plain. He might have to take out $150 million from the 17hospital, $1.2 billion budget in his first year in office. The new president of the Health and Hospitals Corporation speaks softly but carries a big ax  unlike his three predecessors.

title: GARDENING
description: IT'S that time of year, when visions of giftladen stockings hanging from the mantelpiece and children's shining faces beside the Christmas tree seem somewhat blurred in our minds as we fight traffic jams in shopping malls and elbow our way through crowded stores in a lastminute search for gifts.

title: ART
description: STONY BROOK PHOTOGRAPHY is often in the equivocal position of serving the purposes of art and history at the same time, partly because documentary and socalled art Photography have evolved simultaneously, and also because of the esthetic qualities that may be achieved  deliberately or unconsciously  when the camera is used as a recording device. Thus it is all too easy to impute to the charming holiday snapshot or the study of slum life some higher intent in terms of the photograph itself and of its integrity as a composition divorced from its content  an intent of which the photographer is often innocent.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: COURTS ARE CAUSING CONFUSION ON RENTS
description: The legal rents in several hundred thousand New York City apartments have been thrown into uncertainty because of recent court rulings.

title: Realty News
description: Brentano's and Gucci are expanding their retail outlets on Fifth Avenue.

title: UMass Toppled in Bowl, 3528
description: WICHITA FALLS, Tex., Dec. 16 (AP)  Mike Solomon, a sophomore fullback, sprinted 65, 28 and 20 yards for touchdowns in a wild second half today as Florida A. & M. captured the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division 1AA title with a 3528 victory over the University of Massachusetts in the Pioneer Bowl.

title: List of Deaths of Outstanding Figures in Sports During 1978
description: DelRoy, Frank, 65, of Indianapolis, chief inspector of cars at. Indianapolis 500, and seven other racing officials in crash of a private plane.

title: A Question of Justice in New Canaan
description: NEW CANAAN CHARGE of police brutality has brought uncharacteristic public divisiveness and oncern to this quiet, prosperous commuteroriented town that contendedly describes itself as the next station to heaven.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: THE widespread use of Christmas and other festive lights at this time of year often means a greater reliance on extra extension cords.

title: POINTS OF VIEW
description: At first blush, Government imposition of socially desirable requirements on business through the regulatory process, such as standards for cleaner air and safer products, seems to be an inexpensive and desirable way of achieving national objectives.

title: 1776 Fragment Put to Final Rest
description: WILTON, Conn., Dec. 14  Although Connecticut's highest court has ruled that finders are not always keepers, the Museum of the City of New York apparently will be able to keep a fragment of a historic sculpture that was found in a swamp.

title: Pennsylvania Fire Kills 6 Children Firemen's Response Is Slowed
description: MASONTOWN, Pa., Dec. 16 (UPI) Six children were killed in a fire at their home today in a rural area near this southwestern Pennsylvania community.

title: Barbara J. Lewis, James F. Harrison Wed in Short Hills
description: St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills, N.J., was the Setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Barbara Jean Lewis, daughter of Mrs. Albert M. Slaght Jr. of Short Hills and Normandy Beach, N.J., and the late Donald E. Lewis, to James Frey Harrison, son of Mrs. C. William Drake of Mendham, N.J., and Ridgely W. Harrison Jr. of New York and Quoque, L.I. The ceremony was performed by Auxiliary Bishop John J. Dougherty of the Archdiocese of Newark, who was assisted by Msgr. Harold A. Murray.

title: Michael Berzon to Wed Elyse J. Kosan in March
description: The engagement of Elyse Joy Kosan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving S. Kosan of Great Neck, LI., to Michael Berzon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Berzon of Purchase, N.Y., has been announced by the prospective bride's pareats. The couple will be married next March.

title: Koch Assailed on a Racial Assault
description: The National Association for the Ad. vancement of Colored People and Brooklyn Assemblyman say that Mayor Koch conducted a whitewash in his handling of an attack last August against four young black and Hispanic city workers and a black mailman and charged that it was part of a systematic policy of neglect of blacks and Hispanic people.

title: Blues Tie Islanders on Late Unger Goal, 22
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 16  Garry Unger, the iron man of the St. Louis Blues, scored the tying goal 53 seconds from the end of the game tonight to give the home club a 22 tie with the New York Islanders.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: CITY officials are making an unusual effort to replace the Xrated movies at the Penthouse Theater in South Norwalk.

title: For Children: A Host of Holiday Activities
description: AFTER visions of sugarplums have finished racing through their heads, the children will be home from school for a week on holiday. And while they can always spend their vacation glued to the television set or curled up with a good book, there are enough activities available from one end of the Island to the other to keep them  and their parents  constantly on the go.

title: Events Today
description: Poinsettia Flower Show; Formal garden with a variety of poinsettias; 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.; Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Texts of Statements From U.S., China and Taiwan
description: As of Jan. 1,1979, the United States of America recognizes the People's Republic of China as the sole legal Government of China. On the same date, the People's Republic of China accords similar recognition to the United States of America. The United States thereby establishes diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China.

title: Another Champion In the Family?
description: GLEN COVE HE'S sturdy, about 5 feet tall and 90 pounds, with blond hair and blue eyes. As he walks onto the tennis court at the Cove Racquet Club, wearing blue shorts and a yellow shirt, there doesn't seem to be anything extraordinary about him. But spectators start crowding for a closer look.

title: Most Iranian Stores Remain Shut
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 16  A backtowork movement that the Government had hoped for did not take place today.

title: ART VIEW
description: BUFFALO We have learned, writes Linda L. Cathcart, we are willing to be tolerant of almost anything in our art. Nothing could be more characteristic of the art world of the 1970's than this statement. To be open to almost anything  what Miss Cathcart further describes as our quickness to accept is the attitude of the moment. To construct hierarchies, draw up criteria, to be seen to exercise a certain taste  indeed, to write the kind of art history or criticism that requires hard and fast judgments  seems unnatural and niggling, a bit churlish perhaps, and maybe even dull. The current view is, who needs it? The past being so abundantly littered with mistakes, why even attempt it?

title: Sharp Quake Hits Iran; 42 Are Reported Killed
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 16 (UPI)  A sharp earthquake struck southwestern Iran yesterday, killing at least 42 people and injuring 10, Radio Iran said today. At least 17 villages were destroyed or severely damaged.

title: CLEVELAND'S MAYOR PLANS WIDE LAYOFFS IN WAKE OF DEFAULT
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 16  Mayor Dennis J. Kucinich and members of his staff began preparing plans today to lay off 3,000 to 5,000 city employees, beginning Monday, to conserve the city's limited suoolv of cash.

title: Statistics for Hispanics In Work Force Due Soon
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP)  The Labor Department will provide work force statistics on the Spanishorigin population next month as the Government begins to collect more data on Hispanics, according to Representative Edward R. Roybal, Democrat of California.

title: Mr. Begin May Have Been the Toughest Bargainer
description: WASHINGTON  In the midst of the euphoria that enveloped this city after the surprising success of Camp David, a few uneasy voices raised the warning that it was a flawed and incomplete package that sidestepped a critical issue. How was an IsraeliEgyptian peace treaty to be related to the establishment of Palestinian autonomy on the West Bank?

title: Huskies To Row On Nile
description: CAIRO, Dec. 16  On the same day that New Yorkers get their first glimpse of the treasures of King Tutankhamen's burial chambers, oarsmen from around the world will gather next Wednesday in Luxor, the site of the discovery of the ancient Pharoah's relics, to prepare for a reenactment of the competitive aspect of King Tut's burial ceremony.
