title: Fred Buzhardt Jr., Nixon's Counsel in Watergate, Dies
description: Joseph Fred Buzhardt Jr. was a Southern lawyer, courtly and courteous. He was able and a prodigious worker. He was at times open, at other times evasive  but he was at all times a loyalist for President Nixon, and a fighter who yielded legal ground only after intense resistance.

title: Councilmen Say Raise Is Not Worth the Effort
description: STARBUCK, Wash., Dec. 16 (AP) City Council members here have decided not to increase their pay. They say that it is not worth the trouble to follow President Carter's 7 percent guidelines because they earn only $2 a month.

title: Carey to Seek Funds To Foster Prevention OF Crime by Juveniles
description: Governor Carey intends to ask the Legislature for up to $50 million to finance a new crimeprevention program aimed at juveniles, which would supplement the tough new laws enacted earlier this year to punish young people who commit serious crimes.

title: Mideast Deadline Comes and Goes
description: The United States has done everything but hold the pen for Egypt and Israel but it cannot make them sign. Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance came home from a mediation journey to the Middle East last week with their differences apparently more entrenched and today's deadline for reaching a treaty  set at Camp David  impossible to fulfill. No one was saying exactly when or how the negotiations could resume. Moreover, the United States and Israel seemed to be slipping into another slough of mutual recriminations, with Washington putting most of the blame on Israel for the failure and Jerusalem crying foul.

title: Luxury Languishes in Era of Cost Cutting
description: Barbara F., who just moved into a new apartment building, has a kitchen the size pantry's once were. A gap between the parquet floors and the marble foyer had been filled with a caulking material. On the ceiling is a sprayon finish that looks like stucco and that flakes, she said, when touched. The rest of the apartment was painted with a waterbased (rather than the more expensive oilbased) paint which, she feels, is simply tacky.

title: INTERVIEW
description: STATE Commissioner of Education Mark R. Shedd was an attentive but unpersuaded listener during two evenings of public hearings last week during which a stream of speakers generally attacked the proposed new school finance plan. The critics said the plan was financially conservative and could mean a radical takeover of local education by the state.

title: LIFE IN TEXAS HARD TO MIGRANT WORKER
description: HIDALGO, Tex., Dec. 16 (UPI) Macario Flores sprawled on the ground, his greenstained fingers automatically loosening the dirt around the bushy bell pepper plant.

title: British Open Increases Total Purses to $310,000
description: LONDON (AP)  Prizes for the British Open golf championship have been increased by more than 20 percent. The total purse at Royal Lytham and St Annes in July will be $310,000, an increase of $60,000.

title: Headliners
description: Not long after Easter, Jeremy Thorpe, who was once the leader of Britain's Liberal Party and who still represents a Devonshire constituency in Parliament, will stand trial in Old Bailey. A ruling that a trial was justified came last week from three magistrates who had for 16 days heard a fully detailed presentation  one fully covered by the press  of evidence that Mr Thorpe and three codefendants had been involved in a conspiracy to kill Norman Scott, a model. Mr. Scott has claimed that he once had a homosexual relationship with Mr. Thorpe. Mr. Thorpe, who has denied that relationship and insisted that he never plotted with anyone to have Mr. Scott put to death, declared he would vigorously defend this matter.

title: Three Against Residency Law
description: JUST four months after the Board of Legislators enacted legislation requiring new employees of the county government to live Westchester, three board members are trying to repeal it. United in this battle are two Democrats, Steven A. Galef and Carolyn Whittle, along with Edward M. Gibbs. Republican.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Thorny Side of Rose Deal
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Jury Irregularities Charged in the CarterArtis Case
description: A Federal court in New Jersey has been asked to review charges of possible misconduct by jurors who two years ago convicted Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis of a triple murder in Paterson.

title: College Seniors Getting Directory of Pro Agents
description: WASHINGTON (AP)  The first directory of sports agents, produced by the Association of Representatives of Professional Athletes, is being distributed to college seniors who are thinking about a pro sports career.

title: Bond Sale in Bonn
description: Take stock in America  buy U.S. savings bonds.

title: Deaths
description: AMCHANNathan, On December 11, 1978 in Israel. Beloved brother of Morris. Rose, Ida, Anne FeInman of West Palm Beach, and Sylvia Sitborberg of New Hyde Park. Devoted uncle of Judith Schecter, Doris Klein, Francine Stern, Adrienne Lesof, Laurie Horn, Sonya Schutt: and Arthur Amchan. Dear greatuncle to Jay, Allison & Rachel Schecter, Nancy, Steven Shawn & Elyssa Klein, Alexandra & Eva Stern, Jonathan, Benjamin & Joseph Schultz. and Stephen Amchan, all of whom he loved and Inspired in his own special way. Graduate of NYU WSC 1928, Law 1930, ASTP University of Alabama & Pittsburg. Veteran of 95th Infantry Division ETO. Burial was in Hill of Saul, Tel Aviv on Tuesday, Dec 12. Memorial service will be held at a later date. ShivSoutha at the home of Morris Amthan, 1600 South Eads, Arlington, Virginia, 22202.

title: Medical Tapes System Relocated In Dispute in Massachusetts City
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Dec. 16 (AP)  Mayor Theodore E. Dimauro, who drew sharp criticism by confiscating six tapes on abortion and birth control from a telephone medical information system, has announced that the system will be removed from city property.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: The 150th anniversary of the death of Franz Schubert has, of course, been getting all the play this year, as well it should. But there are other musical anniversaries too, and before the year is out let's talk about the 200th anniversary of the birth of Johann Nepomuk Hummel.

title: Followers Say Jim Jones Directed Voting Frauds
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 16  Determined to help elect politicians friendly toward his People's Temple, the Rev. Jim Jones ordered what former temple members say was an organized campaign of fraudulent voting practices that included importing busloads of illegal voters to cast their ballots in this city's 1975 municipal elections.

title: State Attorney General: Man in the Middle
description: TRENTON JOHN J. DEGNAN, the State Attorney General, is facing increased pressure these days because of the different ways he has handled the results of two background investigations required by the Casino Control Law.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: THE widespread use of Christmas and other festive lights at this time of year often means a greater reliance on extra extension cords.

title: R. O. Blechman Puts His Sly Mark on Christmas
description: An animated Christmas special that is not relentlessly upbeat, prankish or even made with children especially in mind will be shown this evening at 8 on Channel 13. The novel hour, Simple Gifts: Six Episodes for Christmas, was conceived, produced and directed by R.O. Blechman, a New York car toonist and graphic designer. His quavery, sly lines seem to be everywhere these days: on covers for The New Yorker magazine, on The New York Times's Op Ed page and in its Sunday Magazine, on posters for Conran's, in illustrations for an Italian edition of Voltaire's Candide and in TV commercials ranging from a Christmas greeting from CBS to an award-winning one depicting a man arguing with his stomach for Alka Seltzer. But tonight's program, which uses not only his own talents but those of a halfdozen other artists, is the first animated film he has produced of such scope.

title: Penn State No. 1 at Last
description: It was Penn State's year and Billy Sims's Heisman Trophy.

title: ART
description: THERE are artists who cannot make the transition from one medium to another with ease; painting might be appropriate for their sensibilities though sculpture might not. But one artist who easily made the switch from one medium to another  specifically, from weaving to printmaking  is Anni Albers.

title: Officer Indicted As Gang Coach For a Robbery
description: An alleged sevenmember Brooklyn robbery ring that reportedly used a police officer as a tactical adviser has been indicted for the $38,000 holdup last Oct. 30 of toysRus, a supermarketsized toy store at 2875 Flatbush Avenue.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: ELMSFORD  The Music . Tonight and Tuesday to next Sunday (through Feb. 18). Opens 6:15 P.M., buffet at 7 P.M., show at 8:30 P.M. Sundays one hour earlier. $16 to $18. Christmas Show. Tomorrow, matinee and evening. Doors open 10:45 A.M. and 6:15 P.M. $17. Reservations. An Evening Dinner Theater, 1Theater, ii Clearbrook Rd. 5922222.

title: Geneva Meeting Yields Few Pledges of Aid for Indochinese Refugees
description: PARIS, Dec. 16  The Geneva conference of 38 nations, called to seek a solution to the problem of the continuing exodus of refugees from Indochina, has left concerned officials with a sense of gloom.

title: TV VIEW
description: As 1978 flickers to a close, intrepid students of the absurd can once again look back on a year's worth, of glittering promises and claims unleashed from executive suites of the television business. In terms of new series failing and being canceled, the current fall season has probably been the most disastrous on record, but that awkward fact hasn't slowed the industry's flow of drivel about responsibility and selfless guests for excellence. Meanwhile, because the film Animal House was a big boxoffice hit this year, the TV schedule for early 1979 will feature no fewer than three spinoff excursions into similar sophomoric humor, one for each network. Television originality marches on in lockstep.

title: Woman, 25, Arrested at Macy's After Alleged Threat to Kill Self
description: A Brooklyn woman threatened to kill herself last night at Macy's after she and another woman allegedly picked the pocket of a customer in the department store, the police said.

title: San Diego Crash Inquiry Provokes a Fresh Dispute
description: Appearing before a HouseSenate committee shortly after the Sept. Z5 collision of two airplanes over San Diego, the head of the Federal Aviation Administration came forth with what he hoped would be reassuring statistics.

title: For Cleveland, the Agony of Default
description: Cleveland sank Friday night as Captain Dennis Kucinich and his mutinous City Council argued over how to plug the leak. The city became the first of any importance to default on its debts since 1933, when Detroit went under, and Mayor Kucinich said it would mean layoffs and six months of chaos.

title: Point Up Deficiencies in College Freshmen
description: The results indicate that these students would need a great deal of help in reading and mathematics.

title: Joanne G. Linowes Planning Wedding
description: Prof. and Mrs. David F. Linowes of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Urbana, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joanne Gail Linowes, to Lee David Alinsky. The bride's father, Boeschenstein Professor of Political Economy and Public Policy at the University of Illinois, recently served as chairman of the Privacy Protection Commission in Washington.

title: SHOWDOWN NEARING ON JAYCEE SEX RULE
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 16  The struggle over women's membership in the Jaycees, an organization described by its national leadership as sort of grassroots America. has moved into the showdown phase.

title: INTERVIEW
description: TRENTON ONE of New Jersey's leading feminists believes that a woman will be chosen to run the United States Government within the next five Presidential elections.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: How do you write a Helen MacInnes novel of international intrigue?

title: Antipoverty Agency Losing, Contracts Following Audit
description: The New York City Human Resources Administration has notified an ItalianAmerican antipoverty organization, the Congress of ItalianAmerican Organizations, that it will be stripped of its $1.2 million in socialservices contracts as of Jan. 1.

title: Law School at Penn Abolishes Minority Admissions Committee
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16 (AP) The University of Pennsylvania Law School has abolished its special admissions committee, a move that critics say will.cut back opportunities for minoritygroup applicants.

title: IT'S STILL HARD TO GROW UP ITALIAN
description: A while ago, when I was at a body shop to pick up my car, I started talking with the owner, a middleaged ItalianAmerican. When he asked me what I did, I told him that I was a writer, adding that I was doing an article on ItalianAmericans. He looked at me incredulously and asked, Why in the world do you want to do that? There's so much pain there.

title: The War on 138th Street
description: It was already after 10 o'clock when Benny Escobar returned home from his meeting with the detective on the evening of Nov. 18, 1976. But minutes later he left the apartment to search the South Bronx streets for an open bodega because his baby was crying and there was no milk.

title: Deferred AnnuitiesFor Those Who Can Afford to Wait
description: Q/PLAN, Guarantor II and The Accumulator  they're not the Pentagon's latest defense strategies, but the names of some of the hottest financial instruments offered by Big Board member firms.

title: Hospital Confirms Layoffs
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16 (AP) Hahnemann Medical College and Hospital officials have confirmed reports of extensive layoffs, but they say no numbers will be decided for eight to 10 days. Hospital workers reacted angrily yesterday to reports that Hahnemann, facing huge financial losses, plans to lay off 200 to 300 employees in the next few weeks.

title: GARDENING
description: ONE or more of the plants traditionally associated with the coming holidays will bedeck almost every hall in New Jersey within the week. Favorites include Christmas kalanchoe (kalanKOee), Christmas cactus, Christmas begonia and the poinsettia, which is called Flor de la Buena Noche in its native Mexico.

title: Court Bars West Side LowIncome Project
description: Construction of a lowincome housing project near the Trinity School on the Upper West Side of Manhattan has been barred by a Federal appeals court that said the project would thwart plans for racial and economic integration in the area.

title: U.S. Expected to Seek Indictments Of Aides to Governor of Tennessee
description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 16  The Federal Government is expected to seek indictments against three aides to Governor Ray Blanton of Tennessee and perhaps several other state officials on charges of accepting bribes in exchange for promises to release convicts on parole or through executive clemency. There were indications that the Governor might have been aware of what was happening.

title: Malaysia Lifting Ban on the Use Of Its Airspace by the Concorde
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Dec. 15 (Reuters)  Tiansport Minister Tan Sri Manickavasagam said today that Malaysia has decided to lift its ban on flights through its airspace by the supersonic Concorde.

title: IN THE NATION
description: SOWETO, South Africa  The American Chamber of Commirce in South Africa, in consultation with some of the country's black leaders, is planning to establish a commercial high school here in Soweto, the vast, regimented black city in which most of Johannesburg's blacks are forced by law to live.

title: Rise in Consumer Prices May Hit 8%, Miller Says
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP)  Con sumer prices could increase at least 8 percent next year, significantly higher than the Administration is predicting, according to G. William Miller, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Cracking Down
description: NEW HAVEN LAST February, William Lewis, 20 years old, forced his way into the home of a 59yearold New Haven housewife, tied her hands with an electric cord and tried to rape her. Mr. Lewis had what three Superior Court judges called a horrendous prior record involving crimes of violence and sexual assault, including an attack on a 19yearold housewife accompanied by threats of suffocation of her fivemonthold baby.

title: A New Look At Key Questions Of Redlining
description: Neighborhoods differ, and one of the less visible but more important ways is in the measure of confidence they inspire among financial institutions.

title: ANTIQUES
description: The bull market in Art Nouveau wares  especially Louis Comfort Tiffany lamps  has produced two predictable results: escalating prices and a proliferation of forgeries, fakes and reproductions that some mistake for the originals. These problems have intensified recently at auctions, in antiques shows and in shops to such a degree that dealers and auctioneers have begun to protest publicly if not about skyrocketing prices, then at least about the ersatz works that some are saying have created an alarming situation in the decorative arts market.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: MINNEAPOLIS  When Irwin L. Jacobs was 18 years old, he attended a United States Customs Department auction, bidding $13 a pair for a case of 55 pairs of skis.

title: Wendy Doubleday Is Betrothed
description: The engagement of Wendy Bostwick Doubleday to T. Van Wyck Cushny Jr. has been announced by Mrs. McKim Doubleday of Mill Neck, L.I., and Nelson Doubleday of Locust Valley, L.I., parents of the future bride. Her fianc, who is known as Van, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodorus Van Wyck Cushny, of Glen Head. L.I.

title: Winners of Individual and Team Championships Dring 1978.
description: Women's SingletRobbie Coleman, Memphis.

title: Miss Austin And Geologist Have Nuptials
description: Ghislaine van Goethem Austin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Victor Austin of Mount Kisco, N.Y., was married in Bedford, N.Y., yesterday to Gustavus Warfield Hobbs 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hobbs 3d of Stonington, Conn., and Manasota Key, Fla. The Rev. Daniel F. Miner performed the ceremony in St. Matthew's Episcopal Church.

title: 100,000 Refugees Reported to Have Fled Eritrea
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Helped by its new Soviet and Cuban allies, Ethiopia has reversed the tide in Eritrea, once again securing effective control over its rebellious and strategic northern province. Last week, 100,000 Eritreans were reported to be fleeing into the mountains after Ethiopian forces recaptured Keren, an ancient city and once the center of Ethiopia's Monophysite Christianity. Keren was the site of the Eritrean rebels' first important victory 17 months ago and had functioned as their shadow capital.

title: To Carver, Wood Is a Living Thing
description: METUCHEN T0 THE people who pulled it out of Raritan Bay, the old dock piling looked like good firewood. But to Jim Gray, it was an Indian.

title: Inmate Sets Sights On Boxing Title
description: WOODBRIDGE AREVISED version of Rocky is being plotted by an inmate at Rahway State Prison, but with a lot less reticence and humility than shown by the hero of the movie.

title: Con Ed Asks State's Permission To Take On New Gas Customers
description: The Consolidated Edison Company anflounced yesterday that it had asked the New York State Public Service Commission to allow it to accept new gas customers, for the first time since December 1974.

title: Women Still on Strike InBank Sex Bias Case
description: WILLMAR, Minn., Dec. 16 (UPI) Seven women, bundled in parkas, snowmobile suits, mittens and boots, still stroll with picket signs in front of the Citizens National Bank here one year after they went on strike over charges of sex discrimination.

title: Indiana Nips Kentucky, 6867, in Overtime
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Dec. 16 (AP)  Mike Woodson scored 27 points as undermanned Indiana upset sixthranked Kentucky, 6867, in overtime today.

title: Fare at Blanche's: Food and News
description: JACKMAN, Me., Dec. 16 (AP) Holden LaBrie, a 19thcentury drifter, fur trader and sometime stagecoach driver, built himself a little cabin in what is now the center of town. Six years later he met an untimely, unexplained death.

title: Linda LaMagna Will Be Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Sam A. LaMagna of Locust Valley, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Linda Jeanne LaMagna, toMichael Jude Scotto, son of Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore J. Scotto of Commack, L.I. Miss LaMagna is a student at C.W. Post College and her fianc is a senior at Hofstra University.

title: Radio
description: Today: Leading Events

title: Rule Requiring SolarHeat Units Seen as Pioneer Effort on Coast
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 16  A pioneering solar energy regulation, enacted this week over objections from the construction industry, will require that solar waterheating units be installed in up to third of new homes in this area of southern California.

title: City to Seei $200 Million in Loans
description: New York City officials, expecting a cash shortage next month, are preparing to ask municipal pension funds and major commercial tanks for a loan of between $200 million and $250 million before the end of December, accotding to Eugene J. Keilin, executive director of the Municipal Assistance Corporation.

title: U.S. Plans to Issue Regulations For Packaging Toxic Pesticides
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UPI)  The Government will issue regulations by early next year to require childresistant packaging for the most toxic pesticides found in American homes, according to an Environmental Protection Agency official.

title: Penelope Douglas Becomes a Bride
description: Penelope Alice Douglas, an executive recruiter for E. J. Lance Management, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Hamilton Salzman, an associate with Morgan Stanley & Company, the investment firm. The Rev. Gary P. Fertig performed the ceremony in St. Thomas Episcopal Church.

title: Coast Power Company Plagued Since 1958 by Earthquake Faults
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 16  With an imposing brigade of lawyers and countless volumes of engineering and scientific research findings, one of the nation's largest power companies is trying to exorcise a jinx that has dogged it through two full decades of the age of atomic energy.

title: Fear of Flying: How to Get Over Airborne Phobias
description: Some people were clutching the arm of the seat. Others were clutching the arm of a person. Bob, a Long Island dentist suffering from claustrophobia, was huddled in a seat next to the front door. Mary, a New Yorker who fears heights, was sitting on the aisle so she could not see out the window. I would have preferred a seat in the rear, which is where I have sat for years, ever since reading that passengers in the tail section have the best chance of surviving crash. But this time I was up against the nose, strapped into a seat behind the pilot in the cockpit. The engines began to roar, and Pan Am's flight 222 was starting its takeoff.

title: The Evolving Limon Company
description: When Jos Limn died in 1972 everyone assumed that the Jos Limon Dance Company would die with him, for modern dance troupes usually cannot exist without some charismatic choreographer to guide them. Some of Limon's dancers, however, decided that they wanted to go on dancing together. Defying pessimists, they struggled to keep their company alive. And they succeeded. On Tuesday the Jose Limon Dance Company, the first moderndance group to survive the death of its founder, opens a week's engagement at the City Center.

title: Economy Class Nov Comes in Two Classes
description: Selma Edelstein is troubled. In a recent letter to Albert V. Casey, president of American Airlines, she said she was beginning to have doubts that the Super Saver ticket I bought to take me to the West Coast will entitle me to anything more than getting on the plane.

title: DINING OUT
description: ACCORDING to the menu, the dcor of the Golden Tower is a blend of elegant Chinese architectural styles. I'm not so sure about elegant, but blend is certainly the word for both the architectural and food styling at this Cedar Grove restaurant and bland is the word for the taste. The food specialties are a form of SinoAmerican surf & turf, offering fish and meat cubed or in chunks, sauted or deepfried and sauced very mildly.

title: The Twain Meet
description: If everything had gone Jimmy Carter's way, two diplomatic rabbits would have been pulled from his hat this weekend. The first would have been a peace treaty between Egypt and Israel. The second; as a kind of encore for an already enthralled audience, would have ended another diplomatic impassse of almost 30 years: that between the United States and China.

title: Regulating The Gamblers
description: BEIRG a member of the Commission on Special Revenue carries with it a great responsibility to both the state and to those we regulate. If problems arise, they must be dealt with in a just, and expeditious manner. The recent unsubstantiated charge by some members of the General Assembly that legalized gambling in Connecticut has brought an increase in the involvement of organized crime to the state is not only unfair, but is totally irresponsible.

title: PEKING CONCESSION ON ARMS TO TAIPEI LED TO U.S. ACCORD
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 16  Western dip lomats here said today that Peking ap peared to have made a key concessiar that ended years of impasse on the Tai wan issue and paved the way for normali zation of relations between China and the United States.

title: Andretti Firmly in Driver Seat
description: Had it not been for Mario Andretti, the 1978 autoracing season would have belonged to Cale Yarborough, Al Unser, Bobby Allison, Tom Sneva or maybe someone else.

title: More Than Meets the Eye
description: SEEING THROUGH CLOTHES is a complex, difficult, often rewarding study of the relationship of fashion to art that is both fascinating and frustrating. Anne Hollander's perceptive wit and fine intelligence, her scholarly background, her willingness to take risks by proposing original interpretations of the role of costume in Western culture make her book exciting and provocative. Unfortunately, she never articulates her thesis in one convenient place: it lies in fragments in disconnected sections of the text. This is immensely annoying to the reader, who is forced to reconstruct the author's fundamental premises.

title: The Hodgepodge of Society, the Forgotten
description: WHITE PLAINS LOREM BLOOMER, an 18yearold, unmarried maid in a sumptuous Mamaroneck mansion at the turn of the century, is entry No. 9459 in a dusty, old ledger Whose binhling bears the simple legend Inmates, No. 3. A closer look at the volume, stacked on shelves with 22 similar books in a storage room of the County Office Building here, shows that Miss Bloomer was among the county's poor and destitute in 1904 and orie of many who wound up at what is today the Ruth Taylor Institute. Then, it was called the Westchester County Almshouse.

title: Roncesvalles: 778 and All That;
description: Brashly, I interrupted the reveries of an elderly Spanish priest, taking his ease in the sunshine of a pleasant Pyrennean summer afternoon. He amiably admitted to knowing no English and, sine my own Spanish was almost as deficient, we settled on French as our medium of exchange and fumbled along, happily if a bit incoherently, in language foreign to both of us.

title: Mitchell Again Given A Christmas Furlough
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UPI) John N. Mitchell, the former Attorney General who is soon to be the last Watergate conspirator left in prison, has been granted a Christmas furlough again this year.

title: STAMPS
description: Once again, as it has been at this time of year for centuries, the thoughts of the more fortunate turn to the less fortunate  children, the old, the lame, the fimily in need, the worker without workand at this time stamps appear in. keeping with the seasonal spirit of helping those in need.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: THE widespread use of Christmas and other festive lights at this time of year often means a greater reliance on extra extension cords.

title: Miss Lopez on Star Course
description: Move over, Jack Nicklaus and Tom Watson. Make room for Nancy Lopez.

title: 15 Subway Token Booths, Shut To Save Money, Reopen Dec. 26
description: Two years ago during New York City's fiscal crisis, the Transit Authority was able to reduce spending somewhat by closing many subway change booths at stations throughout the city. The result was, in many instances, long lines at the booths that remained open at those stations.

title: Supreme Court Agrees to Rule on Kaiser Affirmative Action Programs
description: The Supreme Court has agreed to rule on a major new reverse discrimination suit that could have an impact more significant than last summer's Bakke decision. This one, once again calling into question affirmative action programs, involves millions of workers.

title: Authors' Queries
description: For a Selected Letters of Frank O'Hara, I would appreciate any letters or information not already lent to Donald Allen or Maureen GranvilleSmith, executrix of the estate of Frank O'Hara.

title: LETTER TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Political thinkers have always said that the good character of a democratic constitution and way of life depends on the way democratic people educate their young. The news last month for democratic education was not good.

title: Corrections: Does System Need Correcting?
description: THE Appellate Division of the State Superior Court has courageously ruled that the $100 million Public Buildings bond issue is clearly and unequivocally unconstitutional.

title: 2 Lawyers for Son of Sam Killer Are Denied City Funds for Costs
description: The lawyers who represented David R. Berkowitz, the convicted Son of Sam killer, have been denied public funds to cover their costs.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: Author's Query
description: For a book on the problems of American schools with particular emphasis on the urban, I would appreciate receiving brief accounts, anecdotes or comments of the experiences of school personnel in dealing with students, slow learners, disrupters, the violent ones and the degree of cooperation received from parents, supervisorsi administrators and others in the process. Confidentiality is assured.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: It wasn't the punishment 13 men expected after their arrest last month in Lansing, Midi., by policewomen posing as prostitutes. The men, who included business executives and college students, all pleaded guilty to soliciting. They were fined an average of $200 apiece. Then District Judge Charles Felice ordered them to write essays on how the arrest had affected their lives.

title: Pamela Fraser Sets Nuptials for March
description: The engagement of Pamela Lundbeck Fraser to Craig McAllister has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John Morrison Fraser Jr. of New York, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth McAllister of Hilton Head, S.C.

title: Health/Dancing
description: It would be hard for me to say, even now, why went to Jack Wiener. My wife, who is a dancer, had spoken of him as someone who had changed her in some fundamental sense and several of her dancer friends described him in equally rapturous terms. He had not only changed and improved the way they moved, he had also altered the way they felt themselves to exist. I was interested in what they said, but only peripherally. Every art form has its peculiar shop talk.

title: DINING OUT
description: THERE is a stunning restaurant formula emerging on the Island, and one of its latest exponents is Fontana's in Roslyn. The basic ingredients are walls of rosy old brick, preferably interrupted by archways: the bare simplfcity of polished wood, gleaming metal and the subtly elegant contrast provided by deep, muted paint and fabric. Plants, fresh flowers and snowily clad tables are the other requirements of this look, which is not yet a clich.

title: Bidding Urged for Medicare Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP)  An internal study by a Federal agency has recommended that the Government switch to competitive bidding on all Medicare contracts and that it streamline the program so the elderly can send their hospital and doctor bills to the same place.

title: The Commissioner Looks Ahead After His First Year in Office
description: The New York City Police Departmeht last week struggled to cope with complaints about its 911 telephone system and continuing controversy over the recent riot at its Borough Park station house in Brooklyn. Against this background, two reporters from the metropolitan staff of The New York Times, Leonard Buder and Selwyn Raab, and two editors from The Week in Review, Michael Wright and Alvin Davis, interviewed Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire on those and other police matters.

title: FOOD
description: ONE is not apt to think of New Jersey, or even Trenton, when one thinks of truffles, but the state's, capital supplies truffles to the entire Western Hemisphere.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: The Island's top figure skaters get a chance to show why they are the Island's top figure skaters today in an allday competition at Nassau County Arena. Sanctioned by the Ice Skating Institute of America, the event which is free to spectators  will feature the skaters in compulsory and freestyle competition. Everything gets under way at 12:95 P.M. at the arena, Magnolia Boulevard, Long Beach.

title: A Miniature Recalls Pharmacies of Old
description: PARAMUS IT TAKES only a bit of imagination to believe that the year is 1890 and that the Lilliputiansized pharmacy is real.

title: Pentagon Cloaks Cult Cost Figure
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16The Defense Department compiled a tentative estimate of $3.5 million for the total cost of operations associated with the People's Temple in Guyana but withdrew the document for legal reasons before it was made public, Carter Administration officials said today.

title: What's Doing in PRAGUE
description: LIVING MUSEUM  For centuries, Prague has gloried in its status as one of the great centers of the Hapsburg dynasty. Today, scarred by 30 years of Communist control and 10 years of Soviet domination since the invasion of 1968, some of the heart has gone out of the capital of Czechoslovakia. But the soul remains. Prague is considered by many the best preserved Medieval, Baroque and Byzantine capital in Europe. The sun glints across the curves of the Vltava River, reflecting on the bridges that King Charles's men built, the medieval towers where alchemists tried to turn lead into gold and the Parliament House, into which Soviet paratroopers 10 years ago, cutting short the brief period of liberalization known as the Prague Spring.

title: The High Cost Of a Takeover
description: THE board of directors of the Westchester County Board of Realtors, representing 2,800 member Realtors and Realtor associates, has unanimously adopted a resolution opposing the county's plan to replace Consoldiated Edison with a countyrun utility.

title: Around the Nation
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 16 (AP) A tractortrailer truck slammed into car and a pickup truck pulling a trailer today, burst into flames and killed at least four people, the state police said.

title: McEnroe Arrives; Evert Endures.
description: It was a year of parrying among the young champions of tennis. For most of the year Bjorn Borg battled Jimmy Connors for top ranking, but by year's end, Arthur Ashe was calling John McEnroe, the 10yearold from Douglaston, Queens, the best tennis player in the world right now.

title: Work by Barnes at Juilliard
description: Two seasons ago as a 19yearold composition student at the Juilliard School, Edward Barnes drew attention with the exceptional talent shown in the performance of his Home Again, Home Again in one of the school's concerts. That work was no flash in the pan, as demonstrated on Friday night, when his In the Garden was given its New York premiere at the Juilliard Theater in the school's 20thCentury Music Series.

title: Basic Skills Tests
description: TRENTON STATE education officials have found that, despite four years of highschool instruction in English and three years in mathe maties, almost half of the freshmen entering statefinanced colleges last fall were deficient in these basic skills and would need remedial help if they were to complete collegelevel courses successfully.

title: State Finds City's Raises Not Net by Productivity
description: Costofliving increases for municipal employees in the last two years were supposed to have been paid for by increased productivity, but nearly twothirds of the money that the workers received came from other sources, the state's special deputy comptroller reported yesterday.

title: A plea for a new kind of realism.
description: Critics say that the costs of Government environmental, health and safety regulation result in increased inflation, lost productivity and a diversion of research and development dollars from innovative activity. What the critics neglect to mention is that the alternative  not regulating the environment, workplace and consumer products  is also costly.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: EFFORTS to ban the smoking of tobacco in public places have run into trouble again. And it is now beginning to appear that nonsmokers will have to wait until next Sentember to eet some relief, if any.

title: Regents' Aid Formula Would Hurt Suburbia And Assist New York
description: ALBANY. Dec. 15  New York City would gain $1.5 million in Federal money for vocational education programs while suburban counties would lose funds under a new formula adopted Thursday by the State Board of Regents.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Some Hollywood hype artists came around not long ago. Slick fellows in purple sunglasses and $20 aftershave. Seems they're making this movie about Superman and as part of the hype they want to write me up, all about the fellow who hired Superman onto The Daily Planet, whether Superman could type with all 10 fingers or was just a huntandpeck man  that sort of thing.

title: President Adjusts Guidelines Machinery, Tilts Toward Labor
description: In its tussle with the forces of inflation, the Carter Administration is still defining and redefining its battle plan. Last week, the President announced some revisions of the wage and price guidelines he first unveiled Oct. 24 kind of fine tuning of the antiinflation machinery  and it was clearly a bow in the direction of labor.

title: Utility Says Snags in Financing Threaten Seabrook Power Plant
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., Dec. 13  Construction of the controversial nuclear power plant in nearby Seabrook is again in serious jeopardy, this time because of uneasiness in the nation's financial community.

title: Coast Crash Took a Toll of Living
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 16 (AP)  On Christmas it will be three months since a peaceful San Diego neighborhood was jarred by the nation's deadliest air crash. Alan Davidson is still picking up the pieces.

title: If You Go . . .
description: ... to Washington, and want to meet your Senators and Representatives, write for appointments at least six weeks in advance. Your chances are probably best during the school holidays, when most legislators set aside time to meet visiting constituents. Some congressional staffs also arrange tours of the Capitol Buildings for visitors during school holidays.

title: Tanya Tucker Moves Into Rock
description: According to her biographies, at least, Tanya Tucker turned 20 years old just last Oct. 10, but she has been a popmusic veteran since 1972, when Delta Dawn was released. More precisely, Miss Tucker has been a countrymusic veteran. Now she's made a decisive move toward rock, and the result is a new album, TNT, and a new stage image and show to support it, which arrived Wednesday night at the Bottom Line.

title: A Song of Success From Niantic Prison
description: ONE difference between Luckii Rucker and other talented, aspiring young pop singers is that Miss Rucker is serving a 10year sentence in the Niantic Correctional Institution. Oddly enough, her misfortune may be the making of her career.

title: OPEC Likely to Back Oil Price Rise Today
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates, Dec. 16  Oil ministers from the 13nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, ended the first day of their pricesetting conference here without a firm agreement.

title: THEATER
description: THE MUSIC MAN was the surprise smash musical of Broadway in 1957. And it is absolutely no surprise that it is a hit all over again in 1978 in a presentation by the An Evening Dinner Theater in Elmsford. The show has not aged a bit, because it was never of its time.

title: Miss Abrams Wed in Jersey
description: Elizabeth Jane Abrams, daughter of Linda Given of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., and Jerome Abrams of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married at her mother's home yesterday to Richard Martin Holden Thompson. Mayor John Parisi performed the ceremony.

title: Uneasiness Over Some New Neighbors
description: PENWOOD, is has been said, was the greatest of all the estates in the Bedford area. Assembled by the late Carll and Marcia Brady Tucker from 1913 to 1930, the stone structures, on the several hundred acres were designed in a number of styles, among them Tudor, Norman and Gothic. So when John R. Spann and Luis Antonio Fragelli told a Chappaqua real estate agent that they were looking for a goodsized building in Tudor, Norman or Gothic style, he showed them the Tucker house.

title: Officials of Agencies Cite Strained Resources
description: For 125 years, the Children's Aid Society has been caring, comforting and helping thousands of the city's children and their families. In good times and in bad, our doors have always remained open, our hands outstretched to those who turn to us out of need and desperation  children and families who have been shunted aside, lost in the backwash of the city's foment and change.

title: BRIDGE
description: Abridge player's attitude toward garbage depends on the, kind of game he is playing. By garbage we do not mean the kitchen variety, which the real enthusiast, especially if male, deems beneath his notice, but worthless hands containing two or three highcard points at most. The rubberbridge player finds it hard to escape from the thought that garbage is costing him money, even if the stake is a trivial one. But a tournament player may even welcome the sight of garbage. He can relax comfortably, reasonably confident that for one deal at any rate he will have little thinking to do and if anything goes wrong, it will be partner's fault.

title: Gathering the Fairfield Clan
description: FOR Connecticut children, there is not much to be merry about in the School Finance Advisory Panel's plan for public education. It will take workshops full of elves toiling away in the General Assembly to turn the plan into tidings of joy for the state's 600,000 schoolchildren.

title: Buses That Travel Off Island Are Growing in Popularity
description: SMITHTOWN Adrive to the station, a late train to Pennsylvania Station and then a subway or taxi to the Port Authority Bus Terminal  that was the obstacle course Islanders had to run, ride and wade through in order to leave New York City by public transportation. Now, the Island has a growing Greyhound bus service, reaching as far west as Smithtown and Bay Shore.

title: Concessionaires Form a Group To Deal With City Regulations
description: Concessionaires licensed by New York City have formed an association to deal with what they call the unfair and arbitrary actions of the city in regulating their businesses.

title: The Cities Are Changing, but Experts Disagree Whether It's for Better or Worse
description: WASHINGTON  With the default last week of the once proud industrial giant on the crooked Cuyahoga called Cleveland, the old bugaboo urban crisis is back again just when it looked as though things were finally getting better.

title: HOME CLINIC Extension Cords: An Invitation to Danger
description: THE widespread use of Christmas and other festive lights at this time of year often means greater reliance on extra extension cords.

title: Theater Trial With Flair for Drama
description: TESTIMONY about top entertainers, crime bosses and skimmedoff money has filled a Manhattan Federal courtroom for almost two months in a trial focusing attention on the Westchester Premier Theater.

title: All Atwirl In IceDancing
description: ABOUT two years ago, at an age when most talented young ice skaters have their dreams firmly fixed on winning a world or Olympic title, Great Neck's Deborah Page gave up competition, then turned professional and threw in her lot with a bunch of pioneers who are trying to create a new art form.

title: Taiwan Leaders Respond To U.S. Move With Calm
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 16  After brief spasm of anger and outrage, the Government of Taiwan responded with studied moderation today to President Carter's announcement that the United States would sever diplomatic relations with Nationalist China and normalize relations with Peking.

title: Miss Winters Bride Of Dr. P.D Kligfield
description: Mary Susan Winters, daughter of Barbara E. Winters of New York and Willard Page Winters of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Dr. Paul D. Kligfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Kligfield of Whitestone, Queens.

title: Jewelry That Gives A Signal
description: MINNEAPOLIS (UPI) You've heard of computer dating? Now there's blinking electronic jewelry to intrigue the date you got through the computer.

title: Too Many Teachers, Too Few Jobs
description: WHEN Donna Darr, a physicaleducation teacher from Delaware, learned that she would be moving to the Hartford area because of her husband's job change, she thought she would easily find work.

title: Pearson Is standout In Loughlin Games
description: The theory that the mild winter weather has given schoolboy track athletes the opportunity to train was verified yesterday at the 25th annual Bishop Loughlin Games at the 102d Engineers Armory. Good performances abounded in the opening meet of the major indoor season for more than 3,500 athletes from 187 schools.

title: LANE DENIES SEEKING CULT'S SECRET FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16  Mark Lane, the lawyer whose client was the Rev. Jim Jones of the People's Temple sect in Jonestown, Guyana, said today that he had not made any effort to seek access to the sect's secret assets in Swiss banks.

title: The Thickets of Academe
description: WHEN I need intellectual stimulation on a weekday afternoon, I wheel out my gearless bicycle and make my way with unamplified torque to my son's school. My experiences there comprise a curriculum of such depth and variety that I owe it to the community to set them down. Here, then, is a record of my most recent visit, which began with an inquiry into the ontology of boots and shoes.

title: LETTER TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Unfortunately, memories can be very short  when there is good reason to forget ['Service Roads Irk Homeowners Near Route 110, Nov. 26]. As a former builder in the Dix Hills area, I can attest to the fact that most of the homes that were built directly abutting the Long Island Expressway were sold at large discounts. In fact, with one small exception, all of the parcels built backing to the expressway in Huntington were among the last to be developed, because of the concern of builders and buyers alike; i.e., the builders were concerned about the ability to market such lots, and buyers were equally apprehensive.

title: The World
description: I can't say we have reached agreement on a new strategic arms treaty, President Carter told a news conference last week. But judging from the steady stream of optimistic leaks, and a mounting Administration campaign to gain Senate support for a treaty, agreement seems at hand. Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance plans to meet his Soviet counterpart, Andrei A. Gromyko, in Geneva Thursday. If their talks are successful, President Carter and Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev could meet to sign a treaty as early as next month.

title: Kjicinich Made a LastMinute Plea to White House
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 One of the lastditch attempts to stave off default in Cleveland was a call from Mayor Dennis J. Kucinich to the White House yesterday, asking for an, advance on the city's revenuesharing funds.

title: U.S. Investors Are Taking to Gold
description: Fifty straining, hoarsevoiced men press their bellies against the octagonal oak ring in the goldtrading pit of the Commodity Exchange in New York's World Trade Center. Seventy for 30 Feb! one yells. He wants 30 contracts for February delivery of 100ounce gold bars, and he'll pay $205.70 an ounce. Sell you five! yells one of the brokers. Sell you 101 shouts another. Done! says the trader. Somewhere, another American has just invested in gold.

title: Best Sellers
description: NONFICTION

title: Harvard Fears Its High Tuition Bars the MiddleClass Applicant
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 16 (AP)Harvard is worried that its high tuition might price students from middleincome families right out of its ivycovered walls, leaving only the very rich and the poor, who would be on scholarships.

title: Behavioral Study Indicates Many Parents Don't Tell Children of Erotic Aspects of Sex
description: Although the vast majority of parents questioned in a recent survey said that preadolescent children should know about the erotic aspects of sex, fewer than 15 percent of the mothers and 8 percent of the fathers said they had ever talked to their children about sexual intercourse. Even fewer had told their children about contraception or venereal diseases.

title: James C. Crimmins Weds Miss Leahy, Flight Attendant
description: Jennifer Leahy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Leahy of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to James C. Crimmins, son of Mrs. C. Sterling Bunnell of Cornwall, Conn., and the late Edward C. Crimmins. The Rev. A. Whisler performed the ceremony in St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan, Conn.

title: Home Sweet Home for the Holidays
description: NEW MILFORD THERE IS still time to make your own gingerbread house to display for the holidays, and to nibble on for weeks thereafter. Last. weekend at The Silo in New Milford, Leo Silverman; a pastry instructor from the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y., taught a small group how it was done.

title: MAILBAG
description: To The Editor:

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Volcanoes May Emit Chemicals Believed to Harm Ozone Layer
description: VOLCANOES NATIONAL PARK, Hawaii, Dec. 16 (AP)  Studies show that the active volcanoes of this park may emit halocarbons, members of a chemical group that includes fluorocarbons, which are suspected of being harmful to the atmosohere's ozone layer.

title: World News Briefs
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 16 (Reuters)The Rhodesian military command acknowledged for the first time today that its forces had attacked Mozambique army bases. It said the air raids occurred between Nov. 30 and Dec. 11.

title: Correction
description: In my column on these pages last week I made reference m an edition of WNYC's All About TV, on which Perry Wolff, an executive producer with CBS News, was critical of the ABC documentary Terror in the Promised Land. I quoted Mr. Wolff as having said that the ABC documentary was bestowing legitimacy on the Palestinian Liberation organization cause. In fact, that phrase was used by Steven H. Scheuer, the moderator of the program, and not by Mr. Wolff. The inadvertent attribution does not alter my major point about new documentary forms; however, I do regret any embarrassment the misattribution may have caused Mr. Wolff.

title: State Braces for Winter Disruption
description: AT THE first hint of severe weather this winter, officials at the stormmobilization headquarters of many of the state's utilities and highway systems will be looking for word on what to expect from a source 200 miles to the north: the Weather Services Corporation in Bedford, Mass.

title: Young People of Iran, Rejecting Modernism, Revive Islamic Values
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 16  Afsaneh, a 21yearold senior at the University of Teheran, is prepared to die for the cause. She says that three of her friends have already been killed while demonstrating. If you call my home and my parents tell you I'm not at home any more, then you'll know I've been killed too. she said.

title: St. John's Five Tops B.Y.U.; 39 for Carter
description: He needed a game like this and so did the team, said Coach Lou Carriesecca of St. John's last night after Reggie Carter scored 39 points to lead the Redmen to a 9083 triumph over Brigham Young University before a crowd of 3,480 at Alumni Hall in Queens.

title: State Cracks Down On Cult Exemptions
description: TRENTON NEW JERSEY has joined a growing list of states in which offbeat churches are finding it harder to get tax exemptions for religious purposes.

title: Chrysler's looking to salesman Iacocca.
description: Back in 1975, when the Chrysler Corporation suffered a major drop in sales in the wake of the Arab oil embargo, Chairman Lynn Townsend was the target of verbal brickbats tossed by angry shareholders. He ended up resigning his post, after a decade in the job, following a $260 million company loss for the year.

title: Army Dogs Will Wear Nylon Boots for Snow
description: NATICK, Mass., Dec. 16 (AP) Working dogs that have to slog through Ice and snow on the job may no longer have to worry about getting their feet wet.

title: American Poetry Restored
description: WHEN did we start to tick off our cultural life by tens? First came the 1920's of scabrous high living, followed by the 30's of hardbitten social responsibility. After an interlude for world war came the 50's with their backyard irony, the 60's of hair and revolt, the 70's of exhausted privacy. What began as a rough rule of thumb seems, by Whitehead's principle of the misplaced concreteness, to have become a law of cultural time, and the resultant oversimplification has turned struggles of taste and values into a marching order for textbooks.

title: Fire Kills 3 Children and Sitter
description: STOCKTON. Calif.. Dec. 16 (CPI) A fire that started near the family Christmas tree last night killed three chiidrer of a Vietnamese refugee family and their babysitter and left another child in extremely critical condition. Fire officials said the fire apparently started near the family Christmas tree and burned quickly through the house.

title: Mary E. Hendrickson, a Credit Analyst, To Be Wed to Brian McLaughlin in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Manville F. Hendrickson of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Elizabeth Hendrickson, to Brian Hamilton McLaughlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald H. McLaughlin Jr. of East Harwich, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: The standard forecast for 1979  the consensus of the nation's business and academic economists  is moving down. But it still calls for only a moderate recession or an advance so sluggish as to be called a growth recession  one in which unemployment will rise despite a small gain in real output.

title: The Shah Seeks A Way Out
description: In Iran last week, Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi began to seek new solutions to the crisis paralyzing his country  solutions that would cost him some power but might save him the throne. In a significant shift from his previous reliance on martial law imposed by the military Government of Prime Minister Gholam Riza Azhari, he met with one after another of the secular opposition leaders seeking a basis for a coalition government. So far, all efforts have shattered on the same rock: the Shah's refusal to give up control of the military, the only source of power he can still be sure of.

title: Reality On China
description: MADISON, Wis.The deeper reasons for The rapprochement between the United States and China do not lie in any sudden, recent or superificial switches. Already in the late 1940's Mao Tsetung sought especially good relations with America.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: EASTWARD HA! by S. J. Perelman. (Simon & Schuster/Touchstone, $3.95.) The inspired curmudgeon who chronicled his experiences circumnavigating the globe 30 years ago in the nowclassic Westward Her has done it again, from Scotland through Europe, Russia, the Middle East and Asia to that most primitive place of all, Hollywood. Though not S. Perelman't best, it will more than do.

title: Women in British Poll Prefer a Man Paunchy
description: LONDON (AP)  Fat is attractive., up to a paunch.

title: 2 Soviet Officials See Danger in U.S.China Relations
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 16  Two wellplaced officials of the Communist Party's Central Committee expressed extreme concern today over the possibility of ChineseUnited States economic and military cooperation aimed at bringing pressure on the Soviet Union.

title: A Gold Chain Letter Has Come Full Circle, With Trail of Victims
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 16 (UPI) The Circle of Gold chain letter, which started out in the San Francisco Bay area two months ago, has now completed its own circle around the country, making a few people richer in the process but leaving thousands of people $100 poorer.

title: West Bank Arabs Stone Israelis Over Seizures of Land
description: BETHLEHEM, IsraeliOccupied West Bank, Dec. 16  Young Palestinians threw stones today at Israeli patrols here and in a town to the south to protest a recent takeover of Arab land by Israel's military administration.

title: ART
description: ALL that the artists of the 16th century could do about the New World was to show it as a tropical paradise where the natives were turned out as if for a Renaissance fancydress ball. Nor, at first, were their successors in the Far West much better. Encompassing the totally new evidently requires not just talent and vision, but also the efforts of many observers building on each other's ac complishments. Perhaps more important than anything is that vague entity known as the spirit of the age, which permits, or does not permit, the passage of an idea.

title: The Nation
description: President Carter won a bout last weekend against Democratic liberals who find his budget proposals socially unacceptable, but he quickly had a new fight on his hands with those who find them a little fishy.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Be practical about using salt for icy walks, drives and steps; fertilizer or sand is better because salt seeps down into the soil and damages roots of lawns, trees and shrubs .... The cut Christmas tree will last longer if kept outdoors as long as possible before setting it up inside to trim .... Dig the hole for the live Christmas tree; mulch the soil mound and cover with burlap.

title: Topics
description: The recent history of personality cults has given the phenomenon a bad name, but a Florida evangelist seems nevertheless determined to be a cult unto himself. The Rev. Eugene Jerome Dupuis, a bornagain Christian, is such a staunch follower of himself that he has named his six children the most recent a daughter  after himself. His only gesture toward avoiding household chaos has been to give each child a number. I love me, Mr. Dupuis says. We wonder whether he realizes what such nominal cloning has done not only to his children's chances but to his own chance to live in history. His cult of self has insured that he will always be just a member of a chorus. Wouldn't he have been better off remaining singular?

title: Coal Commission Gets Extra Time To Study IndustryUnion Turmoil
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16  Ten weeks after a special Presidential. commission began hearings in its search for the causes of nearly a century of labormanagement problems in the coal mines, it has requested and received more time to diagnose this nation's most persistent case of industrial malaise.

title: Expert on Environmental Perils Is Named Health Chief by Carey
description: Governor Carey yesterday announced the appointment of Dr. David Axelrod, an authority on environmental toxicology, as Commissioner of the recently restructured State Health Department. Dr Axelrod will replace Dr. Robert P. Whalen, who resigned earlier this month.

title: F.T.C. Looks at Concentration in Book Industry
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15  After a year of behindthescenes interviews in Manhattan's publishing towers, the Federal Trade Commission, which has been investigating takeovers and mergers in the American book industry, sponsored a symposium today on concentration and conglomeration in book publishing. By doing so, the F.T.C.'s Bureau of Competition alerted the industry  which had nearly $5 billion in sales this year  that book mergers were being studied for possible violations.

title: CRIME
description: Helen MacInnes is one of the more popular practitioners of the espionage novel. Early along, she developed a formula that mixes spies, the good guys (us), the bad guys (the Communists) and the inspired amateur who fights the forces of evil in a manner that surprises both him and the enemy. Generally there also is a romance. All of these ingredients are present in the new, 18th, Maclnnes book, PRELUDE TO TERROR (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $10). But for once the mixture is flat and the author has not risen to the occasion.

title: JUNIOR PROFESSORS FIND TENURE ELUSIVE
description: NEW HAVENThe students in Carlos Hortas's Spanish classes think he is one of thp best professors at Yale University, and those he counsels as dean of one of Yale's residential colleges say they cannot imagine survivng a semester without him.

title: Miranda Jackson, Travel Adviser, Is Married to Thomas W. Hook
description: Miranda Dabney Jackson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William. Eldred Jackson of New York and Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., and a greatgranddaughter of President Theodore Roosevelt, was married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity to Thomas White Hook, son of James W. Hook Jr. of Albuquerque, N.M., and Mrs. Samuel G. Taylor of Padanaram, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Reed Isaac and was followed by a reception at the River Club.

title: Deaths
description: KOSMANSamuel. We mourn the loss of our Actuarial Consultant who combined the highest professional skills with a keen sense of personal dedication. His counsel was invaluable in guiding the Fund along constructive channel, thus helping tens of thousands ofs men and women. To the bereaved family, our profound condolences.

title: POLITICS
description: CONGRESS has its Black Caucus and its New England Caucus. It has the Democratic Study Group, an organization of moderatetoliberal Democratic members of the House. The Texas delegation gets together for breakfast about once a week to pool its influence for Texas. And even the New York Representatives in Washington will occasionally put aside their bickering long enough to eat lunch together.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING
description: SINCE Michael Sharpe, a 26yearold former legal aide and housing rehabilitation specialist, first took over the newlycreated post of State Housing Advocate last September, the phone has not stopped ringing at his downtown Hartford offices. In November he had to arrange to have two extra lines installed so people could still get through.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: JULIO SANTOS likes his job so much that he travels by car and boat 100 miles to get there in the morning and another 100 miles to get home in the evening.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Knicks have a 2 o'clock game against the Atlanta Hawks today and a 7:30 P.M. game against the Indiana Pacers Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden. The New Jersey Nets meet the Houston Rockets at 8 P.M. Wednesday at the Rutgers University Center in Piscataway, N.J.

title: The More It Costs, the More It Sells
description: For those to whom life was very, very good this year, Cartier's has the perfect Christmas gift  a 24carat gold nugget, almost one pound of pure gold, to grace the neck of one's beloved for a mere $9.500.

title: Old China Debate Flares
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16  China policy, a flashpoint of American politics in the 1950's and 1960's, ignited again today, as conservatives denounced President Carter's decision to sever the defense treaty with Taiwan and moderates attacked the President for having acted on relations with Peking without consulting Congress.

title: Bess Truman Leaves Hospital
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 17 (Reuters)  Bess Truman. the 93yearold widow of President Truman, left Research Medical Center here yesterday after a month of treatment for high blood pressure and abdominal stress. She returned to the family home at Independence, Mo.

title: Terry G. Gwyn Is Bride Of Benjamin Warthen
description: Jerry Geneen Gwyn and Benjamin Pollard Alsop Warthen were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Robert W Gustafson in the First and Central Presbyterian Church in Wilmington. Del.

title: BERLE TO LOSE POST, STATE OFFICIALS SAY
description: Peter A. A. Berle, whose outspoken stands against some of Governor Carey's policies angered the administration, will be asked to resign as New York State Environmental Conservation Commissioner, highranking Carey aides said yesterday.

title: Man and Superman at Circle in the Square
description: UNCUT, George Bernard Shaw's Man and Superman runs close to five hours. Shaw made no apologies; what with its length and its discursiveness, it was intended, he said, for a pitful of philosophers.

title: Koch Undaunted on Oil
description: The announced rise in international petroleum prices apparently failed to faze some leaders. New York's own Mayor Edward I. Koch said yesterday he was going to fight it on the greenery front. I'm going to try to use less oil in my salad, he said lightheartedly as he strolled among thousands of people on Fifth Avenue, which was transformed into a Yuletide holiday mall for the afternoon.

title: Miss Proell Takes Downhill
description: VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 17 Annemarie Proell Moser of Austria easily won the World Cup downhill race here today, her second victory in two downhill events this season, by skiing what she described as a perfect race no mistakes, no trouble.

title: CLEVELAND RUMORED TO BE FACING STRIKE
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 17  Speculation persisted here this evening that the major labor unions in this tinancially distressed city would call a general strike if Mayor Dennis J. Kucinich Went through with his plans to reduce the city's work force by 30 to 50 percent to conserve money.

title: U.S. Supporters of Taiwan Meet To Set Campaign on China Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UPI)  Opponents of the decision to cut United States diplomatic ties with Taiwan met today in an effort to set up a coalition to fight the Carter Administration's China policy.

title: Band: Sirone, With New Concept
description: SOON after the Revolutionary Ensemble disbanded in 1977, two of its three members, the violinist, Leroy Jenkins, and the drummer, Jerome Cooper, were performing on their own, Mr. Jenkins as the leader of a new band and Mr. Cooper as a remarkable solo percussionist. But the Revolutionary Ensembles bassist, Sirone, was not heard from until Saturday night, when he introduced his new group concept in a concert at New York University.

title: Imitator of the Wrights Takes a Very Short Hop
description: KILL DEVIL HILLS, N.C., Dec. 17 Ken Kellett proved no competition for the Wright brothers today as his reproduction of their airplane lifted only three feet into the air for a few seconds.

title: The Iadone Consort Plays Early Music
description: ALTHOUGH Friday night's appearance by the ladone Consort at the Metropolitan Museum was called a New York debut, four of the group's five members are more than familiar. The lutenist, Joseph Ladone the soprano. Jean Hakes and the recorder player, Morns Newman. were all part of the New York Pro Musica back in the days of Noah Greenberg Fortunato Arico is one of the best know gambists around Only Susan Ladone (Joseph's wife), who performed on a variety of viols, is a relative newcomer to early music circles here.

title: Deaths
description: PANDELMortimer A Sr., on Dec 15. 1978 of valley Stream. L.I., beloved father of Dorothy Ft Biliouest, Mortimer A, Jr. and William F., also survived by 6 grandchildren and 8 greatgrandchildren. Reccsire at Moore Funeral Horne. 54 west Jamaica Ave, Valley Stream, L I Religious services Monday, 8 PM followed by Masonic services. Funeral Tuesday. 10AM. Interment Maple Grove Cemetery. Yew Gar. dens. NY. In lieu of flowers. donations 10 the masonic Home, Utica, NY would be areareciated. Family will receive friends Sunday and Monday, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM.

title: A Police Chief in Illinois Is Ordained as Minister
description: BUFFALO GROVE, Ill., Dec. 17 (AP)  Harry Walsh has been ordained as a priest in the Episcopal Church, but he says he plans to keep his position as chief of the Buffalo Grove Police Department, despite a possible conflict in that he will continue to hear confessions.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The credit markets sagged last week as investors accepted the widespread view that interest rates are still headed higher and decided it didn't make much sense to buy bonds just yet. A weeklong search among fixedincome traders, investment bankers and portfolio managers turned up nobody who thought interest rates had already peaked and would not continue to climb.

title: Rail Merger Ban Extended
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP)  The Interstate Commerce Commission last week extended until March 16 a ban on the purchase of Seaboard Coast Line Industries stock by the Southern Pacific Company. The I.C.C. also told Seaboard to report by Feb. 20 what its annual meeting does about a plan to merge Seaboard with the Chessie System. A merger of Seaboard with either company would create the largest railway system in the United States.

title: Pakistan Lifts Curb on 8 Papers
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 17 (Reuters)  The Government has lifted censorship imposed on six daily newspapers and two weekhes in Sind Province two months ago, according to an offical spokesman. During censorship, the newspapers often appeared with blank spaces on some pages.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BANGKOK. Thailand, Dec. 17 (UPI)  With 62 golds, 49 silver and 33 bronze. Japan was the leader in the overall medal standing as the swimming events of the eighth Asian Games wound up today.

title: Notes on People
description: When he becomes a free man on Wednesday, H. R. Haldeman has some thinking to do about his future, but his immediate plan is to talk some more about his past. His book on his days as White House chief of staff, The Ends of Power, was updated in paperback this month to include a reply to some controversial points raised by Richard M. Nixon in his memoir. Television also lies ahead, starting with a taping on Jan. 17 with Phil Donahue, the talkshow host.

title: Thomas Bolles, Rowing Coach And Athletic Head at Harvard
description: Thomas Bolles, a rowing coach and former athletic director at Harvard University, died yesterday of a heart attack in Raleigh, N.C. He was 76 years old and maintained homes in Raleigh and in Clearwater, Fla.

title: Evidence Questioned in White Factory Worker's JobDiscrimination Suit
description: GRAMERCY, La. Dec. 14  Parties close to a discrimination suit involving a Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation factory say that evidence not on the record in the case may undercut the contentions of a white worker whose lawsuit has cast him in the role of a bluecollar Allan P. Bakke.

title: South Bronx College Center Reverses Usual Trend
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 15  A small liberal arts college in this prosperous suburban community, recognizing the need to serve workingclass adults better, has decided to expand its programs. But, unlike many similar schools, expanding outward from the city, the College of New Rochelle is opening its new facilities in the center of the South Bronx.

title: Assassinations Study May Be Inconclusive
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP)  After a $5.8 million investigation, the House Select Committee on Assassinations is considering a conclusion that conspiracies can neither be proved nor ruled out in the assassinations of John F. Kennedy and Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Clamping Down on Prison Terms
description: The New York State Parole Board, under pressure for being soft, recently adopted tough new standards to increase the time criminals must serve before being paroled. A mugger convicted of serious assault with weapon, whose minimum sentence would once have been between 21 and 36 months, now faces 32 to 60 months. The new policy is on the right track, at least for violent. criminals. But in striving to preserve its shaky place in the criminal justice system, the Parole Board has ventured into a realm of corrections policy which, because of political and fiscal factors, belongs to the Legislatore.

title: Chess:
description: Boris Spassky has not succeeded in mounting a challenge for the world championship since Bobby Fischer captured his title in their match in Reykjavik in 1972, but in tournament play you can go broke betting he won't take the first prize. He did it once again in the Torneo del Vino in Montilla, Spain, with a 62 score.

title: Complex Negotiations Ahead
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 17 Despite President Carter's announcement yesterday that the United States and China will finally normalize relations on Jan. 1, there still are a number of problems that must be negotiated before America's relations with Peking will be resolved.

title: 126 Safe in Crash of Indian Jet
description: NEW DELHI, Dec, 17 (UPI)  All 126 persons aboard an Indian Airlines jet escaped through emergency exits after the plane caught fire within seconds of takeoff from Hyderabad Airport today and crashlanded on the runway. A passenger and an air attendant sustained minor burns, a Civil Aviation Ministry spokesman man said. The Press Trust of India News Agency reported that two persons who had been mowing grass along the runway died after being struck by the plane as it crashlanded.

title: Dorsett and Cowboys Crush Jets in Shea Winds, 307
description: With winds gusting from 25 to 45 miles per hour at Shea Stadium yesterday, a passing attack almost was impossible for the Jets and the Dallas Cowboys. And because Dallas was operating without Roger Staubach, its injured quarterback, the obvious tactic was to run the ball.

title: H.R.A. Assailed On Restitutions By Relief Cheats
description: New York State's Welfare Inspector General said yesterday that althougt courts had issued orders last year for repayment of $1.16 million by New York City welfare clients who had hidden their assets or resources, through last May the city had collected only $59,587, or 5 cents on the dollar.

title: 21 Persons Injured in Jerusalem as Bomb Explodes on Crowded Bus
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 17  A bomb went off in a crowded bus here late this afternoon, injuring 21 persons, one seriously.

title: Starred in Yiddish Theater Before Doing Sancho in Hit Musical
description: Irving Jacobson, an actor whose talents were legendary in the Yiddish theater before his fame was established on Broadway as Don Quixote's comic sidekick, Sancho, in Man of La Mancha, died yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was SO years old and lived at 420 East 23d Street.

title: Things Are Looking Up on West Eighth St.
description: A fastfood operation is out and a bookstore is coming in on West Eighth Street  to the delight of many of the street's shopkeepers, apartment dwellers, Village leaders and the local police.

title: Home Rooms and Home Addresses
description: The New York City Board of Education has a real problem. Since it is difficult to integrate the pupils, an integrated teaching staff is eminently desirable, not mention that it is required by the Federal Government. But many predominantly black schools are served by mostly black teachers, predominantly white schools mainly by white teachers.

title: American Describes Police Siege In Terrified Small Iranian Town
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 17  Ralph Schoenman, a political activist from New Jersey, described today several days of terror in the small Iranian town of Nejafabad, during which soldiers and the police killed the opponents of the Government and damaged their homes.

title: Midshipman Killed, Another Hurt In Auto Accident at Annapolis
description: ANNAPOLIS, Dec. 17 (UPI)  One senior midshipman was killed and another slightly injured early today when their car plunged into the Severn River adjacent to the Naval Academy grounds, an academy spokesman said.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: BOSTON, Dec. 17  The news from Israel and Egypt is serious but not desperate. One who has been involved in the tortuous efforts to negotiate a treaty sums it up as follows:

title: New Offer For Simpsons
description: TORONTO, Dec. 17  The increasingly bitter struggle for control of Simpson Ltd. continued as the Hudson's Bay Company of Winnipeg made a revised offer last week to shareholders of the Torontobased department store chain.

title: Oil Output Rises as Iran Braces for a Day of Mourning
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 17 Oil production rose 80 percent today while troops in most of the country's major cities braced for a day of mourning that was called by religious leaders for tomorrow in memory of demonstrators slain in clashes with security forces.

title: Dance: Ailey Stages Langage
description: IT is surprising that Alvin Ailey's Masekela Langage has never quite become a popular Ailey standard. The piece reappeared in the repertory on Saturday evening at the City Center, where the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater has just finished the anniversary of its 20th season. The mystery remains.

title: Takeover Bid Delayed
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit has continued a stay that temporarily blocks the United Technologies Corporation of Hartford from proceeding with its bid to take over the Carrier Corporation of Syracuse. The stay will remain effective pending a decision by the appeals judges on motions to overturn a Syracuse Federal judge's refusal to issue a preliminary injunction to block the United Technologies tender offer.

title: Ruth Marie Peters, at 65; Editor And Writer on Raising of Flowers
description: Ruth Marie Peters, managing editor of Under Glass, a quarterly trade magazine, and a writer on horticulture, died Saturday of congest we heart failure at Englewood Hospital in Englewood, N.J. Miss Peters was 65 years old and lived in Ridgefield, N.J.

title: Military Gains for China Seen in U.S. Ties
