description: China will achieve two Mali military advantages from normalization of its relations with the United States that will enable the Chinese Army to prepare a more formidable opposition to the recently reinforced Soviet forces along the northern frontier.

title: Redlining Ban Called Hard to Enforce
description: State banking officials, bankers and critics of banks say they are uncertain about how and when new legislation outlawing redlining will be enforced, and disagreement has also arisen over a section of the bill raising the mortgageinterest ceiling from 8, to 9 percent.

title: Louis Caplan, ExHead Of Jewish Committee
description: PITTSBURGH. Dec. 17  Louis Caplan, who in 1961 was installed in New York as the 11th national president of the American Jewish Committee, died here yesterday. He was 92 years old.

title: Around the Nation
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 17  State's Attorney William J. Scott has filed a lawsuit seeking permanent closing of a nuclear waste disposal site near Sheffield, Ill., charging that the state's lease of the dump to a private wastedisposal concern is unconsttutional.

title: AN AVERAGE OF 10%
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates, Dec. 17  The world's leading oii exporters today decided to raise the price of petroleum by 14.5 percent'in stages by the end of next year, thus ending an 18month price freeze.

title: Stage: Tesich's Comic Touching Bottom
description: STEVE TESICH's Touching Bottom, which opened last night at the American Place Theater, is an evening of three oneact, twocharacter plays about eternal hope, tacling memory and the difficulty of communication. Each play wears the influence of Samuel Beckett, but they are enrobed in Mr. Tesich's own brand of comic ingenuity.

title: Whitehorn Appointed Chairman Of Cancer Society in New York
description: Nathaniel Whitehorn, a lawyer in New York City, has been named chairman of the board of the American Cancer Society's New York division, officials of the organization announced yesterday.

title: Mrs. Reid Victor
description: ADELAIDE, Australia, Dec. 17 (UPI)  Kerry Reid of Australia. seeded No. 1, defeated Beth Norton of the United States, 75, 67, 6.1, today and won an $11,400 tennis tournament.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ROUNDUP TIME Fans of Jerry Herman have a free treat in store starting this afternoon in the theater of the Library of the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center. At 4 o'clock today, tomorrow and Wednesday, there will be a tribute to the composer and lyricist in the form of a new twoact revue titled Tune the Grand Up! including Herman songs from such shows as Manic, Hello, Dolly! Mack and Mabel and Milk and Honey. Add preview sampling of Grand Tour, the Herman show due on Broadway this month.

title: Is There a Right Price for Oil?
description: Imagine two Gnomes of Zurich, those prototypical international financiers, in starched white shirts and rimless glasses. trying to decide whether to sell gold and buy dollars. What do they now want the United States to do about oil prices? One might be rooting for the price to go up. That would force Americans to use it more sparingly, import less and thus strengthen the dollar. The other, just as calculating, might be rooting for a lower, or at least stable, oil price. That would help the Carter Administration retard inflation  and thus strengthen the dollar.

title: 3aGallon Rise Expected For Petroleum Products in '79
description: The price of gasoline, heating oil and just about every other petroleum product that Americans buy will rise a penny a gallon or so early next year because of the price increases announced yesterday by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, industry experts said.

title: Brown Said to Propose Overhaul to Cut Costs Of Military Pensions
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17  Defense Secretary Harold Brown, in a move that has upset the military, has proposed a major overhaul of the military pension system that would reduce the amount of money paid to those who leave the service after 20 years, according to Defense Department sources.

title: Peekskill Is Likely to Be Chosen for Recycling Plant
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 14  Peekskill has become the likely site of Westchester County's longdelayed garbage recycling plant.

title: McAdoo's 41 Pace Knicks' Triumph
description: Bob McAdoo returned to the Knicks' lineup yesterday afternoon after a month of nursing an injured toe.

title: Coffee Exchange Accord
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP)  The Justice Department has agreed to settle a yearold civil antitrust suit against the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Friday's settlement is subject to approval by a Federal judge in New York City.

title: Music: Gerald Busby Plays Beethoven and Busby
description: GERALD BUSBY celebrated the birthdays of two composerpianists on Saturday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall  his own and Beethoven's. The program was, appropriately enough, an all BusbyBeethoven one, and what might have seemed presumptuous on paper turned out to be a pleasant occasion, thanks to Mr. Busby's unpretentious manner, obvious talent and the audi ence's friendly attitude toward both composers.

title: Nastase Wins In Usual Style
description: MONTEGO BAY. Jamaica, Dec. 17 (UPI)  Ilie Nastase, cursing and waving his racquet, surged back from a twoset deficit today against Peter Fleming to capture the final of the World Championship Tennis Challenge Cup. 26. 56. 62. 64. 64.

title: Bridge:
description: The big news at the Winter Regional Championships played during the weekend at the New York Hilton Hotel was quite unobtrusive and escaped the attention of all but a handful of concerned officials of the Greater New York Bridge Association.

title: Relaxed Raiders Beat Vikings
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 17  The Oakland Raiders beat the Minnesota Vikings, 2720, today but the Vikings beat the system. The system was the National Football League's qualification procedures for its playoffs and while the Vikings went through another sloppy contest, their competition for a berth in the playoffs, Green Bay, was also losing. The Rams trounced the Packers, 3114, in Los Angeles.

title: Chinese Missions Flock to Japan
description: TOKYO  China is bombarding Japan with economic, industrial and goodwill missions in the wake of a historic treaty of peace and friendship ratified by the two countries in October.

title: Israel Adds Dollar Barriers
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 17  The Israeli Government, alarmed by a rising inflation rate, acted today to stem an increasing flow of dollar loans into Israel. In effect, it reinstated some of the Government controls that were abandoned with fanfare last year as Israel made a determined effort to become a freemarket economy.

title: The 60's Generation
description: NEWARK, N.J.In the final days of the 10th anniversary of 1968, I reflect upon reflections upon the children of the 1960's. I think about reports that we have left the political stage, returned to the land, become attached to assorted gurus and turned inward. At best, it is said that we have descended (matured) from rebellion to marginal reform. We are no longer the left  we are progressive.

He retrieved the bail and threw to first, to where the batter was running.The runner on first, meanwhile, advanced to second. Shouldn't Ferguson have thrown to seccod? Why was it ruled a wild pitch?

It was embarrassing but unimportant because Willie's team, the New York Mets, had a lead of 64 over Oakland and needed only three putouts to, square the World Series. This was the second game in 1973.

description: UNITED NATIONS. N.Y.. Dec. 17 For two weeks. Andrew Young, sounding like the Georgia politician he once was. has roved around Africa, offering worried African leaders his analysis of postelection trends in the United States.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17  Supreme Court decisions in several pending cases are expected to have a longlasting impact on the nation's securities laws and the ability of the Securities and Exchange Commission to enforce them.

title: KENT STATE RETRIAL GETTING UNDER WAY
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 17  Jurors will begin hearing arguments and testimony here tomorrow in the retrial of a $46 million civil suit involving the fatal antiwar demonstration at Kent State University on May 4, 1970. The defendants include Gov. James Allen Rhodes and officials and members of the Ohio National Guard who were involved in the incident.

title: Two Slain in Shootout Over Food
description: A Queens man, thrown out of a restaurant after an argument over a piece of paper in his food, returned with a rifle and killed an employee who had ejected him, the police said. As he was leaving. the patron was fatally shot by a police sergeant, whose partner had been wounded in a brief gunfight.

title: Bill Bailey, 66, the Tap Dancer And Older Brother of Pearl Bailey
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17 (AP) Funeral services are scheduled tomorrow for Bill Bailey, the older brother of Pearl Bailey and once a wellknown tap dancer. He was 66 years old.

description: Morning

title: Success and a Bit of Controversy, at $100 an Ounce
description: What's in a name? A bundle of money, bit of controversy, a pack of temptation, twinge of conscience, when the name Opium and it's on a $100anounce Yves Saint Laurent fragrance.

title: TREATY TERMINATION MAY SPUR SENATORS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17  President Carter's announcement that he was unilaterally terminating the 1954 mutual defense treaty with Taiwan appeared likely today to provoke a retaliatory effort in the Senate to give that body authority to block such Presidential moves.

title: Satellite Spurs Growth of Cable TV
description: A shower of programming from the sky promises a boon to cable television that some experts believe will elevate it to a fullfledged mass medium, attractive to advertisers, within the next two or three years.

title: Grim Chilean Puzzle: 14 Skeletons
description: LONQUEN, Chile, Dec. 17  The peasants who live near an abandoned lime kiln here where at least 14 bodies were unearthed remember shots in the night and the coming and going of vehicles after curfew about 1974.

title: A Reasonable Raise for Legislators
description: Notwithstanding the President's 7 percent guideline limit on wage increases, local legislators all over the nation appear to believe this is the tine to vote themselves raises of much more than that. The Illinois Legislature, for example, granted its members a 40 percent increase. The Chicago City Council outdid that with a 60 percent increase, only to back down later. But legislatures in Rhode Island, Ohio and the state of Washington have so far stood by measures that break the guideline. The New York Legislature is said to be considering big raises for future members  the state constitution banning anything more selfservimg.

title: Simplicity To Acquire Bottler
description: The Simplicity Pattern Company Inc., long rumored as a takeover candidate itself, announced yesterday that it would acquire the James E. Crass Group of CocaCola bottling companies based in Richmond.

title: Texas Millionaire Ending Defense in Murder Trial
description: HOUSTON. Dec. 17  Defense attorneys in the trial of T. Cullen Davis, the Fort Worth millionaire, are expected to rest their case early this week. In an attempt to prove that their wealthy client was the victim of a frame engineered by his estranged wife, the defense has produced witnesses who have suggested that Mrs. Davis and Mr. Davis's chief accuser, Charles David McCrory, tried to hire hit men to kill Mr. Davis.

title: Vance Says U.S. Does Not Expect China to Use Force To Regain Taiwan but That Peking Gave No Pledge
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 17 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that the decision to establish diplomatic relations with Peking was made with the expectation, but no commitment, that China would refrain from military force to unite Taiwan with the mainland.

title: Detection of Glow Hints a Departure in Nature of Universe's Birth
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Dec. 17 Observations of the residual glow from the explosion in which the universe is believed to have been born have disclosed an unexpected component whose origin is unknown.

title: Big Week for U.S. Issues
description: The Government securities market will be active this week with two sales of bills, two sales of notes and an offering of Farm Credit System bonds.

title: Complex OPEC Pricing
description: The new Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries pricing schedule is the most complex in the cartel's history. It also appears to embody some very exacting  and politically telling mathematics.

title: Joseph Orleans, Charter Member Of Washington High School Staff
description: Joseph B. Orleans, former chairman of the mathematics department at George Washington High School and the last surviving member of its original faculty. died Saturday of arteriosclerosis in a nursing home in Pikesville, Md. He was 80 years old and had been a resident of New York City most of his life.

title: Screen: In the Pursuit Of a Wife's Happiness:Boyish Adventures
description: I HAVE trouble looking at the light side of Bertrand Blier's "Get Out Your Handkerchiefs," a comedy with a heroine who isn't altogether funny. Here is a woman who barely speaks, never thinks, spends most of her time scrubbing and knitting, is completely available (and indifferent) to any man who wants her, and will be happy only when she is at last made pregnant. She has so little will of her own that a 13-year-old boy can persuade her to have sex with him by pointing out that he'll "have to wait five, six years for another chance like this." Arguably, she is an object of mystery. But by the same argument, so is a seashell or a goldfish or an ashtray.Here, as with his earlier "Going Places," Mr. Blier stops me dead. I never had a clear or reasonable response to that film; I tuned out during a sequence in which two young men petulantly shot a female hairdresser with whom they were both involved, wounding her in the leg, and the woman was such a compliant dimwit that she didn't mind. Compared to that, the scene that showed Jeanne Moreau committing suicide by shooting herself in the genitals was a positive picnic.Mr. Blier's penchant for depicting behavior like this is certainly daring, but whether it amounts to anything truly provocative is another matter. Genuinely challenging an audience is one thing, and simply upsetting it is something else. At least in my case, Mr. Blier at his most outrageous doesn't elicit much more than fleeting, if heartfelt, indignation.In fairness, in "Get Out Your Handkerchiefs" he also elicits a great many laughs, and that's certainly more than could be said for "Going Places." This time, the same two actors (Grard Depardieu and Patrick Dewaere) play the same kind of oversized, irrepressible children, floundering around a woman whose true nature eludes them. She (Carol Laure) is the wife of one of them (Mr. Depardieu) but she's been depressed and uncommunicative for a while. Marriage being whatever it is today, her husband decides she needs another man to cheer her up, and recruits Mr. Dewaere in a restaurant.Their ostensible pursuit of the wife's happiness launches the two men on a series of adventures that makes them seem ever more boyish, until they encounter an adolescent (Riton) who is infinitely wiser and manlier than they. Ever more overshadowed by him, they find their high spirits and their connection with the wife both waning.Until it takes this fairly solemn turn, the film is an exuberant and highly inventive comedy, filled with the very funny quirks of these characters' lives. The Dewaere character has a collection of every Pocket Book ever printed, and can recite any title if he's given the serial number. The wife quietly knits matching sweaters for half the men in the movie. When Mr. Depardieu first strikes a bargain with Mr. Dewaere, he promises that if Mr Dewaere accepts the wife as a gift he will become Mr. Depardieu's pal, "and when a man is my pal he can ask for anything." Without the wife, though, "there wouldn't be much to ask me for."Both of these actors are at once knowing and funny, and their camaraderie can be wonderful to watch; Mr. Depardieu in particular projects an innocence so strenuous it takes on a demonic edge. Miss Laure does an amusing enough deadpan, but she's so opaque her charm eventually wears thin.Riton, the child actor, does a fine job, but there's something disconcerting about his prematurely mournful expression. Mr. Blier's device of setting his boyish adults in opposition to an adult boy has a certain cleverness. But his casting such a dolorous child merely calls too much attention to the patness of this part of the scenario, and to its pretension.Similarly, a late-night dormitory scene involving a number of small boys is shot with such overweening poignancy that it's out of sync with most of the film's airier mood. Mr. Blier has a habit of strong-arming his audience in one scene, and letting his characters drift aimiably in the next. That halting quality was effective enough in "Going Places," but "Get Out Your Handkerchiefs" is a much more substantial and sophisticated effort, in which even the slightest technical clumsiness is notably out of place.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: I try to stay tuned into the news. said Arthur Hailey , the author of superbestsellers such as Hotel. Airport and The Money Changers  I'm a newsaholic.

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON PRESIDENT Carter has now added professional fees to the growing list of items subject to the voluntary antiinflation guidelines, but the professionals say the rules aren't needed and some economists say they won't work.

title: City Population Is at Its Lowest Since the 1930's
description: The decline in New York City's population accelerated from mid1976 to mid1977, according to the latest estimates of the Census Bureau, which put the city's population at 7,312,181 as of mid1977, the lowest level since the 1930's.

title: NURSE EULOGIZED JONES AND TEMPLE
description: MATTHEWS RIDGE, Guyana, Dec. 17  The note from Ann Elizabeth Moore, the personal nurse of Jim Jones, was written in a spiral stenographer's pad in blue ballpoint ink, with the exception of the last line. That was scrawled in red.

title: Market Place
description: The KeoghPlus retirement plans, under which selfemployed individuals can set aside, on a taxtheltered basis, much more than the traditional 15 percent of earned income to a limit $7,500 a year, are expected to be quite popular this year  with those who happen to know about them.

title: Jersey Gems Lose in Debut
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 17 Women's professional basketball made its debut in the metropolitan area tonight as the Chicago Hustle defeated the New Jersey Gems, 123120, in Thomas Dunn Center at Elizabeth High School. It was the Hustle's third straight victory. They have played five games, including two exhibitions, but was the first trial for the Gems. There were 1,924 fans on hand in a gym that holds twice that number.

title: Letters
description: It is difficult to understand the Mayor's view that public assistance recipients who fail to pay rent are stealing.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Bob Hope, institution, was in town to do a 12minute segment on The Associated Press AllAmerica football team for his Christmas television special. He is energetic, enthusiastic and friendly and enjoys clowning with huge uniformed players who seem to feel posing with Hope for a snapshot is halt of the honor, like being pictured at the edge of the Grand Canyon or at the base of the Eiffel Tower. The 75yearold comedian seems at home with the players, giving them tips during rehearsals on haw to deliver a line or to react to his quips.

title: Autumn's Skyscape Over Manhattan
description: The view down the Harlem River yesterday from the windy heights of the Bronx. In the foreground is the Alexander Hamilton Bridge over which passes traffic to and from the George Washington Bridge. In the background is High Bridge, and the striking skyscape of a crisp autumn day in New York, with temperatures in upper 30's.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON  We now know that the Camp David summit  that preelection public relations extravaganza that halted for a time the cnimbling of confidence in Mr. Carter's competence  produced no genuine agreement at all.

title: World News Briefs
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 17 (AP) Opposition parties made minor gains against the ruling coalition in elections today for a Parliament that will give Belgium a new constitution and federal form of government.

title: Con Ed Warns of Rate Rise
description: The Consolidated Edison Company, commenting on the announced oil price increase, said that if and when the rise becomes effective, it would be forced to pass on the added costs to consumers by raising rates for heat and electricity.

title: Boat Refugees Find Adjusting To U.S. Another Hard Journey
description: I came here for freedom, said the patriarch of a family of eight Vietnamese boat people resettling in Philadelphia.

description: The intricate calculations that determine who will be in the National Football League. playoffs were completed yesterday. But the answers to where and when must wait until tonight. The 10 teams  two more than last season  emerged and five were returnees from last season's postseason struggle to the Super Bowl.

title: Transfer of Operators at 911 Called Only First Step
description: The transfer of more than 100 civilian employees out of the controversial, problemridden 911 emergencynumber operation  affecting more than onesixth of the operation's civilian work force  is only a stopgap to counter adverse public reaction, according to the new supervisor of the operation.

title: Jockeys Halt Suffolk
description: BOSTON, Dec. 17 (UPI)  Jockeys at Suffolk Downs walked off the job after the first race today, saying that the sloppy track was too dangerous to ride on. Track officials canceled the rest of the program and said racing would resume tomorrow.

title: Taiwan's Regime Appears Uncertain How to Deal With New Status
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 17  The Chinese Nationalist Government appeared today to be at a loss to know how to deal with the new diplomatic situation that prevails here in the wake of the United States decision to sever relations with Taiwan at the end of the year and to establish relations with China.

description: New York City's new Director of Labor Relations will be Bruce MacIver, replacing Anthony C. Russo, who announced his retirement last week. description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17  The Carter Administration called upon the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries today to reconsider its 19.5 percent increase in crude oil prices, declaring that the rise would endanger world economic recovery and impede efforts to slow inflation

title: Cleveland and New York City: Divergent Paths of Fiscal Crisis
description: Like New York City, Cleveland faces the deepseated urban problems of declining revenues and the rising cost of services. And like New York City, Cleveland has now fallen into a fiscal crisis after engaging in years of questionable bookkeeping practices that covered over an accumulation of operating deficits.

title: 32 From U.S., Including 11 Women, Awarded Rhodes Scholarships
description: Eleven women were among this year's 32 winners of Rhodes scholarships named yesterday from across the United States. It was only the third time that women took part in the annual competition for two or three years of study at Oxford University.

title: U.S. Citizens in Taiwan Warned to Stay Indoors
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 17 (AP)  The United States Embassy warned Americans today to stay off the streets to avoid confrontations with crowds of angry Taiwanese protesting President Carter's decision to normalize relations with China.

title: Rock: England's Pirates Are Back
description: ENGLISH rock musicians have been speaking reverently about Mick Green since the mid1960's. title: Cult Leader Capitalized on Political Gains Made in Using Followers as Volunteers

title: Indiana Meets Test With Upset
description: Coach Bobby Knight did not learn the whole truth about the use of marijuana by some of his Indiana University basketball players until eight days ago when four of his players made a Sunday night visit to the coach's home to give the details, according to a source close to the team.

description: The seven detectives of T am C were assembled in the palegreen second floor squad room of the 43d Precinct station house, at Story and Ftelcy Avenues. It was still dark on the morning, of Nov. 26, 1976, but the men were more anxious than sleepy.

title: 16thFloor Balcony Collapses
description: Yesterday's high winds, preceded by heavy rain. apparently caused the collapse of a balcony from the 16th floor of an apartment building at 75 East End Avenue, the police reported. They said the collapse yesterday afternoon sent debris crashing onto the sidewalk between 82d and 83d Streets, some of it falling on a car. No injuries were reported.

description: John B. description: TRENTON Dec. 15  The management of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, New Jersey's largest utility, has decided to scrap controversial plans for four floating nuclear generators off Atlantic City.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17  The Carter Administration intends to keep in force all agreements with Taiwan except the mutual security treaty after diplomatic relations are severed on Jan. 1, a top official said today. The defense accord will be ended at the close of 1979.

title: Liberal Group Perceives Move to Right in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP)  The Senate edged noticeably toward the conservative side this year, with the greatest shift occurring in the votes of Northern Democrats, the liberal organization Americans for Democratic Action, said today.

title: Playing the Percentages
description: WELL, if nobody else is going to work out any anti inflation guidelines for sports, I guess it is up to me. Not all the detail work; I prefer more of a broad policy role. But in an area where the cost of a superstar has shot up some 800 percent in the last 10 years, and superstars intrinsically have not improved, somebody has to start figuring out how to impose some standards.

title: Interest in Prussia Reviving
description: WEST BERLIN, Dec. 17  Prussia, a state that the victorious allies dissolved after World War II, has emerged ghostlike of late as a center of attention in both Germanys.

title: Marriage Announcement 1 -- No Title
description: Nancy L. Feldman Is Married

title: No Excusses, No Escape
description: EVER since The Fumble, John McVay has been treading water while everyone else has been standing around waiting to find out when he would go under. He's been like a man with h head in the noose and someone's about to hit the horse, says Joe Danelo. And he's acting just like nothing's happening.

title: Soviet Was Reportedly Bequeathed $7 Million in Jonestown Messages
description: MATTHEWS RIDGE, Guyana, Dec. 17  Letters bequeathing more than $7 million to the Communist Party of the Soviet Union were carried out of the People's Temple commune at Jonestown in a suitcase full of money on Nov. 18, the day more than 900 cult members died, a top Guyanese police investigator said today.

title: Brooklyn Philharmonia Offers Sibelius Program Led by Foss
description: LUKAS FOSS, music director of the Brooklyn Philharmonia, is something of a Sibelius champion, and for this past weekend's concerts with the orchestra, he offered an allSibelius program  the Four Legends from the Kalevala (Op. 22) and the Violin Concerto (Op. 47). The latter worked better than the former, and there were several reasons for that.

title: Bond Report
description: For week ended December 15,1978

title: Joseph Cardinal Frings Dies at 91; Defied Nazis as Prelate of Cologne
description: Joseph Cardinal Frings. the outspoken Archbishop of Cologne from 1942 to 1969 who defied the Nazis in World War II. led the progressive wing at the Second Vatican Council and became one of West Germany's most popular churchmen died of heart disease ailure yesterday in Cologne. He was 91 years old.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: IT was fun but essentially unserious when writers like Robert Ardrey and Desmond Morris informed us that people obey the same behavioral laws as animals. Mr. Ardrey and Mr. Morris are popularizers, after all; the serious ethologists were sticking to their geese, their bees and their sticklebacks. But now comes Edward O. Wilson bearing heavy credentials: he is Frank B. Baird Jr. Professor of Science and Curator of Entomology at the Museum of Comparative Zoology, Harvard University. And in his new book, On Human Nature, the third volume in a trilogy of which The Insect Societies (1971) and Sociobiology: The New Synthesis (1975) formed the first two parts, Professor Wilson is assuming more or less the same thing that the ethological popularizers did. The question of interest, he writes, is no longer whether human social behavior is genetically determined; it is to what extent. The accumulated evidence for a large hereditary component is more detailed and compelling than most persons, including even geneticists, realize. I will go further: it alrealy is decisive.

title: Jackson Mathews, PoetScholar; Translated Works of Paul Valry
description: Jackson Mathews, a Poet, author and scholar best known for his awardwinning translation of works by the late French writer, Paul Valry, died Friday in Westminster, Md. He was 71 yers old.

title: Coast Woman, Citing a Motto, Helps Neediest
description: Ruth M. Lender of Bend, Ore., noted that the motto of her community's humane society was Kindness to all living creatures. Mrs. Lender, in contributing $25 yesterday to the 67th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, wrote:

title: Stephan Klein, at 71; Helped Start Barton's, The Candy Company
description: Stephen Klein, the founder and board chairman of Barton's Candy Corporation, died yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at SO Central Park West.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249, or to any of the following organizations:

title: Fire Kills Five in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 17 (UPI)  A 26yearold woman and her four children, aged 7 months to 10 years, died early this morning in a fire that destroyed their home in southcentral Los Angeles. Fire department officials said the cause of the fire was being investigated.

title: THREAT TO DETENTE SEEN IN CHINA LINKS
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 17  In establishing diplomatic ties with China, the United States has embarked on a course that will require precise steering to avoid provoking the deep antagonism of the Soviet Union and thereby damaging detente, in the view of Western diplomats here.

title: The Names of the Jonestown Dead
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 17 (UPI)  The following two lists of victims of the Jonestown mass suicide and murder were released by the State Department yesterday. The first list is of those positively identified whose next of kin or friends have not been notified.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Southern Africa's Fear for Future
description: PARIS, Dec. 17  Visas fur Rhodesia have to be obtained on arrival at Salisbury airport. There are no consulates abroad since Rhodesia is not recognized by any other nation. The forms are distributed on the plane. In addition to the usual questions, there is One that asks one's race.

title: Sporting Gear
description: If you have not heard of or tried Gore Tex clothing, YOU must still be sweating or feeling generally uncomfortable in your regular rain gear. GoreTex is a waterproof material that breathes, thus eliminating interior condensation, and the clammy feeling that results, from trapped body moisture. One leading manufacturer, Ascente of 1766 North Helm Avenue, Fresno, Calif. 93727, (2O9) 2322887, produces lightweight equipment perfect for campers, climbers and sportsmen. Slicker suits ($116.50). downfilled jackets ($100). shells ($85). windbreakers (hooded, $54: unhooded $48.50), gaiters ($25.50) and sleepingbag sacks ($72) are featured.

title: Dance: Sally Bowden Voyages
description: SOME people when they travel don't really care whether they get anywhere. Simply to be on the go is pleasure enough for them. Judging from Voyages, her new work for eight women, Sally Bowden must be a choreographic traveler of that kind.

title: Device to End Shoplifting Sets Off a Health Dispute
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Dec, 14  Laura Smythe, a 32yearold shopper, was leaving a women's apparel store in the Roosevelt Field Shopping Center here with a Christmas present she had just bought for her mother when bells started ringing.

title: Bomb Blasts Injure 10 in British Cities
description: LONDON, Monday, Dec. 18 (AP) Three bombs exploded in central London early today injuring four persons, the police said.

title: Scarcity of Cobalt Spurs Conservation
description: The scarcity of cobalt is continuing to ruse prices to record levels and has brought a new regard for the metal as a precious resource, setting off more conservation. recycling and a search for substitutes among users.

description: Two views of hockey: The rock music is brassy and loud and it echoes off the walls in the Rangers locker room in Madison Square Garden. Some of the young players are singing along as they slip into their designer jeans and namelabel shirts, getting ready for another night on the town.

description: TOKYO, Dec. 17 (AP)  Chris Evert. playing aggressively and employing all her tennis skill, defeated Martina Navratilova. 75, 62, today in the final of an invitation tournament before a crowd 5,500.

title: Carter Organizing a Task Force To Shepherd Budget in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UPI) President Carter has organized a White House task force to monitor his 1980 budget proposal as it moves through Congress, his aides say, in an effort to keep it from ballooning along the way.

title: Thinking About Jews
description: The one thing that 1 have never doubted or found it necessary to prove or explain is the fact of Jewish existence through the ages. A creative remnant has survived always, despite the woes of persecution or the blandishments of other cultures and values. That remnant has recreated itself in angular, sui generis ways in every society to this day.

title: Advertising
description: THE latest tool created by the newspaper industry to increase readership, and therefore the medium's attractiveness to advertisers, is a 27minute film that is intended to raise the public's consciousness of the daily paper.

title: Piano: Egorov Performs A Selection of Fantasies
description: YOURI EGOROV's Carnegie Hall debut Saturday night did not fill the house. But it did attract a full herd of piano buffs, and the response from the audience suggested that the next time Mr. Egorov plays here the seats should be filled to overflowing.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Oil prices will be raised 14.5 percent in four quarterly stages starting with a 5 percent increase Jan. 1, for an average increase of 10 percent in 1979. Officials of importing nations fear the new staggered price system may institutionalize periodic increases in fuel costs. [Page A1.] President Carter, terming the increase a danger to world economic recovery and to American efforts to slow inflation, said OPEC should reconsider its decision. [Al.] The initial impact on American prices from the OPEC move would be at least a cent a gallon increase on oil product prices, with the full 1979 rise put at 3 centsa gallon, according to industry analysts. [D6.]

title: The City
description: Strong gusts of wind were blamed for causing heavy pieces of debris to tumble down yesterday from a Fifth Avenue building under construction across the street from the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: 7th Ave. Designers Are Taking Tucks In Their Silhouettes
description: Calvin Klein, a fashion designer who might not be expected to pick up anything heavier than a pin, bounded into his sleek new gymnasium the other day and began pumping iron: It was a relief when he finally put down the barbell.

title: LOS ANGELES FINDS POPULATION DECLINE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17  The great growth of population in the Sun Belt and citrus states, especially in Florida, Texas and California, is continuing, but with a twist of lemon, so to speak, according to a new summary of the nation's metropolitan areas by the Census Bureau.

title: Music: Katherine Ciesinski Sings Argento's Virginia Woolf Diary
description: KATHERINE CIESINSKI is a young mezzosoprano who has been gathering a number of awards and a great deal of praise lately, most recently for her appearances in Samuel Barber's Vanessa at last spring's Spoletto Festival in Charleston, S.C. Her recital Saturday night at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. was another major step in a fastmoving career.

description: WHEN Christmas greetings on the networks aren't limited to still another rerun of an animated children's special, they are likely to take the form of musical gatherings, such as tonight's The Carpenters  A Christmas Portrait on ABC at 9. or a sentimental drama, such as tomorrow's A Christmas to Remember on CBS at 9.

description: BUFFALO, Dec. 18 (AP)  Billy Inglis, who was named coach of the Buffalo Sabres earlier this month on gamebygame basis, was given the job today for the rest of the 197879 National Hockey League season.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18The price increase set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries widens the risk of a recession in the American economy next year and will probably result in somewhat slower growth abroad, according to Government and private economists.

description: MONDAY, DEC. 18, 1978

description: MANILA, Dec.18  Four Filipinos, including a pregnant woman, have testified at a court martial here that they were subjected to electric shocks and other forms of torture when in detention in the headquarters compound of the Philippine armed forces in Manila.

description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 18  Behindthe. scenes negotiations aimed at producing an outofcourt settlement in the civil lawsuit stemming from the Kent State University shootings in 1970 apparently failed today, setting the stage for opening arguments to begin tomorrow morning.

title: About New York
description: There is a style of young love in this city that has a couple set itself apart in a crowda tactile, evecontact kind of love indulged as the world glances past on the larger business of society. A case of this could be observed last Thursday in the waiting room of an abortion clinic on Queens Boulevard.

title: News Summary
description: President Carter faces a legal challenge. Administration officials said they expected a contest, perhaps going to the Supreme Court, to determine whether he has the authority to bypass Congress and terminate the 13yearold mutual defense treaty with Taiwan. Senator Barry Goldwater has said that he plans to test the constitutionality of the move. [Page A1, Column 5.]

title: The War on 138th Street
description: Jaime Vila was caught by the police with a 38caliber revolver tucked in his waistband after he knocked on the door of an apartment that contained a suitcase holding three pounds of pure heroin. Yet, to his surprise, all the arresting officer was questioning him about that afternoon in November 1976 was the solid gold amulet hanging from his neck.

title: Bronx Hospital Cut Protested
description: About 60 staff members of the Bronx Municipal Hospital Center, joined by local residents, demonstrated at City Hall yesterday to protest a $100,000 cut in funds for mentalhealth services. Dr. Joel Kovel, director of psychiatry at the center, said an additional $300,000 cut was expected soon.

title: SENATE INQUIRY SET ON TALMADGE FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18  The Senate Select Committee on Ethics voted tonight to subject Senator Herman E. Talmadge to a triallike hearing to determine whether the Georgia Democrat misused office and campaign funds.

title: Dictaphone Sought for $120 Million
description: The Dictaphone Corporation announced yesterday that it had received an offer from PitneyBowes Inc. to acquire Dictaphone for $120 million in cash and stock.

title: COMPANY NEW
description: TORONTO, Dec. 18  The Hudson's Bay Company appears to have won by default  the bitter struggle for control of the Simpsons department store chain.

title: Christmas Plan Bring a Warning
description: HOMES from coast to coast are sprouting greenery and red berries now in line with traditions that are older than Christmas itself. But their magic is for the eve alone.

title: IN THE NATION
description: District Six is a hillside area of old houses and winding, sunlit streets near the center of Cape Town, South Africa, where traditionally the city's coloreds (persons of mixed black and white heredity) lived and operated small businesses. Those who knew the neighborhood years ago recall beautiful old Victorian houses that used to attract painters and photographers; many say District Six in those days provided much of Cape Town's color and life.

title: Stage: Halloween Bandit  A Comedy of Menace
description: THE characters in Mark Medoff's plays terrorize one another, testing to see how far someone can be pushed before he or she breaks  and responds with fear. In When You Comin' Back, Red Ryder?, The Wager and the current The Halloween Bandit, an apparently placid situation is suddenly jarred by threats of violence. But even before guns are drawn or knives unsheathed, there have been undercurrents of emotional turbulence lovers competing, friendships cooling. At his best, Mr. Medoff is an American cousin of Harold Pinter  writing chilling comedies of menace.

title: 2 Unions Representing Actors Who Make Commercials Strike
description: Two unions representing actors involved in making television and radio commericals went on strike at 12:01 A.M. today after negotiations with representatives of advertisers and advertising agencies broke off.

title: A Brother of Kucinich Held in Bank Robbery
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 18 (AP)  Just hours before Mayor Dennis J. Kocinich announced layoffs to ease the city's fiscal problems today, his youngest brother was arrested and charged with bank robbery, a spokesman for the Mayor said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Avis Inc. has appointed James F. Calvano executive vice president.

title: Japan Fears the Effects of Increases
description: TOKYO. Dec. 18  Japan, which must import 99 percent of its oil, is seriously concerned over the decision of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to raise its oil prices 14.5 percent by next Oct. 1

title: DelBello Proposal Revised After a Lengthy Debate  Executive Praised
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 18  Westchester's Board of Legislators voted today to cut almost a quarter of a million dollars from the $419.3 million 1979 budget submitted by County Executive Alfred B. DelBello.

title: Yields on Bills Climb Sharply
description: Yields on threemonth and sixmonth Treasury bills climbed sharply yesterday, rising to their highest levels since Aug. 26, 1974, when these rates touched their highest peaks on record.

title: Film: 'Last Wave,' Storm of Occultism:Mysticism Down Under
description: THE sky is cloudless and brilliantly blue, though one hears ominous thunderclaps in the distance. A few seconds later, hailstones the size of baseballs begin crashing onto the hot, arid, still sunlit landscape. The hail shatters windows, and a small boy, watching the display outside, is brutally slashed.Far away, the life of a great city is almost brought to a halt by rains that will not stop. Day and night the rains go on. In the middle of the night, David Burton (Richard Chamberlain), a Sydney lawyer, walks into his suburban garden to find that the ground is alive with movement. There are frogs everywhere  all sizes and shapes. Frogs in such number can threaten.One evening when Burton is driving home in the rain, the speaker of his car radio suddenly erupts with a cascade of water  sound magically given substance. It's as if primeval forces were reasserting their dominion over a world heretofore assumed to be civilized, comprehensible, under reason's control.Thus does Peter Weir, the young Australian director, vividly set the scene for "The Last Wave," an Australian film about matters occult  mental telepathy, thought transference, the reality of dream life.The film, which opens today at the Beekman and Paramount Theaters, begins so brilliantly and with such promise that it's no real surprise that the closer it gets to its apocalypse, the less effective it becomes. The film's payoff is decidedly small, recalling nothing more esoteric than the discovery of the elephants' graveyard in one of the early Tarzan movies. Yet until we arrive at this breathless anticlimax, "The Last Wave" is a movingly moody shock-film, composed entirely of the kind of variations on mundane behavior and events that are most scary and disorienting because they so closely parallel the normal.The movie, written by Mr. Weir, Tony Morphett and Peter Popescu, is about the curious chain of events that starts when Burton, a liberal-thinking lawyer whose experience has been exclusively in corporation law, finds himself defending five aborigines accused of murdering a sixth in a Sydney alley. The circumstances are unusual. The slain man could have drowned (there's a small amount of water in his lungs and he was found near a mud puddle) or he could have had a heart attack. The coroner isn't sure.Making matters more difficult for the lawyer is the aborigines' complete indifference to their defense. Only one of them, Chris Lee (Gulpilil), a slight, dark fellow with an impassively cheerful moon-face, will talk to Burton, but this is more unnerving than enlightening since Lee, the lawyer realizes, has for some time been visiting him in his dreams.The plot that follows makes a great deal of the aborigines' tribal traditions and beliefs, particularly what they call "dreamtime," a nonstop spirit-life that is for the believers more real than the ordinary world.Though the inspiration of Mr. Weir and his associates runs out before the end, "The Last Wave" is an impressive work from a director new to American audiences. He's a man whose ability to find the eerie in the commonplace might please Hitchcock. Mr. Weir got very nice performances from his cast, especially from Mr. Chamberlain, who knows that an actor's obligation in such a film is to play it as small and ordinary as possible, and from Gulpilil. This actor, a full-blooded aborigine, creates a fascinating, self-contained character, the sort of person who has been shown all the mysteries. As a result, he can no longer be surprised or hurt by anything, only mildly amused or disappointed.

title: Behavior Is Shaped Largely By Culture
description: SOME say that men and women have the same mental abilities, that under the same circumstances there is no difference in the way they behave.

title: Findings in Jones Autopsy Called Consistent With Murder or Suicide
description: The Rev. Jim Jones and Anne Elizabeth Moore, a nurse in his cult in Guyana. died of gunshot wounds to the head, and their deaths could be consistent with either suicide or murder, a forensic pathologist who was a member of the autopsy team said yesterday.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Martin Kleinbard, Lawyer, at 59; Headed Unit Aiding Immigrants
description: Martin Kleinbard, a partner in the law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, died Saturday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness. He was 59 years old and lived at 16 Woodland Drive, Rye, N.Y.

title: No Big Business Impact Expected in OPEC Move
description: Representatives of key industries said yesterday that for the most part they expected no immediate big impact on their operations or prices following the 14.5 percent rise in international oil prices announced Sunday.

title: High Court Backs Bank Over Rate
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18  The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that a national bank situated in one state was not subject to the usury laws of other states where it solicits customers for its bank credit card.

title: Attacks Against Police in Japan Are Laid to Foes of New Airport
description: TOKYO, Dec. 18 (Reuters)  Radicals opposed to Tokyo's new international airport at Narita were believed responsible today for a series of arson attacks on police facilities in various parts of Japan.

title: Dance: The Renaissance
description: THE Court Dance Company's Sunday afternoon performance at the Synod House of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine was indicative of the interest that has developed in Renaissance music and dancing. Once, some concertgoers seemed willing to leave stylistic authenticity to the scholars. Today, many people who are neither musicologists nor dance historians find reconstructions of canaries, branles and galliards fascinating.

title: With Optimistic Future, Jets Bid Fond Farewells
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 18  It was no surprise that everyone showed up for the last day of the New York Jets' training camp at Hufstra University today except for the injured quarterback, Richard Todd, who was excused to go home yesterday. Attendance was mandatory. What was unusual ware the long goodbyes.

title: World News Briefs
description: LONDON. Dec. 18  Two bombs exploded and a third was defused here today, but there were no serious injuries. The provisional Irish Republican Army took responsibility for the attacks in an anonymous telephone call from Belfast, Northern Ireland, to The Irish Times, a Dublin newspaper.

title: 4 Food Establishments Are Cited As Violators of City Health Code
description: The New York City Health Department released yesterday the names of three restaurants and one fish wholesaler that it said had violated the Health Code. The establishments are:

title: School Told to Stop Use Of Physical Punishments
description: A private school that cares for retarded and emotionally disturbed New York State children is using physical punishment as part of its treatment, state investigators have discovered, and the State Education Department has ordered the practice stopped.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Howard J. Poduska will retire as president of the Bank of New York Company, holding company for the Bank of New York, on March 16 to pursue personal interests, it was announced yesterday. It will be an early retirement for Mr. Poduska even though he has spent 41 years with the bank. Now 58 years old, he joined the Bank of New York as a page in 1938 when he was 17.

title: Pan Am Asking U.S. Permission To Offer First Flights to Peking
description: Pan American World Airways, seeing the possibility that airline service to China could start as early as February, plans to ask the Civil Aeronautics Board today for permission to start operations without delay between San Francisco and Peking.

title: Output of Steel Increases 0.3%
description: Steel production for the week ended Saturday rose by threetenths of 1 percent, to 2.712 million tons from the 2.705 million produced the week before, the American Iron and Steel institute reported yesterday.

title: 31 Dissidents in Soviet Assail Times Editorial In Jessica Kats Affair
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 18  Soviet dissident attacked The New York Times today for a Dec. 6 editorial apologizing to the Russians over the case of Jessica Kats, an infant who was denied an exit visa when she was seriously ill earlier this year.

title: Jacobs Quits as President Of European American
description: Klaus Jacobs, the German banker who took over the presidency of the European American Bank three and a half years ago, unexpectedly resigned yesterday because of internal policy differences.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP)  The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today that it had abandoned plans to try to save the unmanned Skylab space station and would let the huge vehicle plunge to a fiery death in the atmosphere sometime between mid1979 and mid1980.

title: Byrne Pressing A State Inquiry On Life Insurer
description: TRENTON, Dec. 18  Governor Byrne said today that he had directed the state's Attorney General and its Insurance Commissioner to investigate problems that have been brought to public attention regarding a life insurance company he helped organize.

title: Topics
description: As director of New York State's Division for Youth, Peter Edelman has been an easy target for cheap criticism. Violent crimes by juveniles have, in fact, been diminishing. But as individual, brutal crimes are committed by ever younger perpetrators, public concern has been growing.

title: Peking Appears to Seek Conciliation With Taipei
description: HONG KONG. Dec. 18  Peking appeared today to be making a coordwated effort to be conciliatory toward Taiwan and avoid the provocative threats of the past about armed liberation of the island.

title: Science Watch
description: The noises made by human knees are being studied by a medical research team in Ohio seeking clues to better diagnosis of problems that arise in that crucial leg joint. A note in the Journal of the American Medical Association says the scientists at the University of Akron are trying to develop a computerprogrammed catalogue of all the known patterns of noise produced in movements of the knee, citing the health significance of each such cluster of sounds. Computer printouts give diagrams of each noise pattern, which look somewhat like a map of a mountain range. Eventually, the research workers hope to be able to use the computer signatures for diagnosis of knee problems.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: THE GOLDEN DAYS More then 20 rare German and Austrian posters made for classic American and German movies can be seen today through Feb. 3 at the ReinholdBrown Gallery (RE 47999) at 26 East 78th Street. Among the titles represented are Wings, City Lights, Grand Hotel, Blonde Venus, The Jazz Singer, Sergei Eisenstein's Strike, King Kong and Ben Hur. Gallery hours are 10:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesdays through Saturdays.

title: Carborundum Acquires Edlon
description: NIAGARA FALLS. N.Y., Dec. 18 (AP)  The Carborundum Company has announced the acquisition of Edlon Plastics Inc., a Newtown, Pa., company that makes plastic products for the chemical industry.

title: Terror And Death
description: Dear Friends, You doubtless are familiar with the current events in our country: We live under the sign of terror and death .. .. Besides the murder of the people by bombings, besides the destruction of the cities, besides the merciless persecution of the youth who are tortured and castrated in the basest manner, besides the atmosphere of fear and insecurity, besides the sleepless nights and constant worries, there was added for my family the arrest of a [member] who has since been missing.

title: Movie: Miss Monk Films Her 1976 Dance, Quarry
description: BECAUSE her choreographic works consist of montages of theatrical images, Meredith Monk's style has been called cinematic. Although cinematic theater is not the same as cinema itself, Miss Monk has risked filming her Quarry, first staged in 1976, and the movie is being shown through Saturday at the Harold Clurman Theater.

title: New Salem Man Killed After Holding Hostages
description: NEW SALEM. N.Y., Dec. 18 (AP)  A man was shot and killed by the state police last night after he refused to let his wife and daughter out of his house and wounded two troopers who came in to get him, officials said.

title: Adults' Toy Store Sells the Costly Exotic
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  There is a saying that anyone can make money here if what they sell is unusual and expensive and they sell it to the people on the A list  those who can afford to place style, comfort and pleasure before cost.

title: Lenox Quartet In New Debut
description: THE LENOX QUARTET was founded just 20 years ago at the Tanglewood Festival, but the group's concert at Alice Tully Hall Sunday night was really a debut. The quartet disbanded during the 197778 season and has only just been reformed by its founding member, the first violinist, Peter Marsh, with three new musicians: Warwick Lister, violinist; Patricia McCarty, violist, and Einar Holm, cellist. The ensemble is in residence at Ithaca College.

title: Complex Process Delineates Sex
description: WHAT makes one person male, another female? Increasingly sophisticated studies indicate that the answer lies in a complex chain of events that determines one's genital anatomy, reproductive potential and, perhaps, one's sexual identity and behavior as well.

title: Inflation Jitters Send Prices of Bonds Skidding
description: The credit markets dropped sharply in price yesterday, pushing interest rates substantially higher  some to record levels  as investors and traders concluded that the unexpectedly large increase in oil prices would weaken the dollar and make inflation worse.

title: Donald Nixon Apparently Linked By Lefkowitz to a Diamond Fraud
description: Donald A. Nixon. the nephew of former President Richard M. Nixon, apparently participated in the fraudulent sale of diamonds in New York State and in return received options on leases for unexplored diamond mines in Central Africa, according to papers filed by State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Afrikaner Tale of 2 Provinces: Transvaal and Cape
description: STELLENBOSCH, South Africa, Dec. 13  A few months ago, one of the most powerful figures in the ruling National Party spent an evening with a group of professors at the university here discussing the reforms necessary to achieve lasting racial peace.

title: 6 Seeking Abrams Post to Testify
description: Although a spate of potential candidates is expected, only six announced candidates have asked to testify today before the City Council's nineman Bronx delegation, which will select a Brorix Borough President to succeed Robert Abrams, who becomes the State Attorney General on Jan. 1.

title: Algeria Turns Anger on Morocco
description: ALGIERS, Dec. 18  President Houari Boumediene's medical condition was reported to have sharply worsened today, and as it did, Algerian authorities stepped up accusations against neighboring Morocco, which they have charged with dropping three tons of light arms and explosives on the coast east of here.

title: CHINA TO CONSIDER U.S. TRADE ACCORD, PEKING OFFICER SAYS
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 18  China will consider a longterm trade agreement with the United States now that relations between the two countries are to be normalized, Li Chiang, China's Foreign Trade Minister, said here today. It also plans to accept direct foreign investment from overseas. Mr. Li said.

title: Giants '6178: The Fumble And the Glory
description: 1961  Allie Sherman succeeds Jim Lee Howell as head coach. Giants get Y.A. Tittle from San Francisco in trade for Lou Cordileone, a rookie lineman. (Cordileone: Me for Tittle? Just me?).

title: Tennessee Governor Subpoenaed; 2 Aides Resign
description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 18 (AP)  Gov. Ray Blanton was subpoenaed today to testify before a Federal grand jury investigating allegations that state officials sold paroles to Tennessee prison inmates.

title: 11 City Council Insurgents Hold Unofficial BudgetGap Hearings
description: They were not asked to meet by anyone, these 11 City Council members who held their own hearings on the city's budget gap yesterday. They did not even hire a stenographer, and met three miles north of City Hall. And they are not likely to have any major say in the way the budget finally comes out.

title: Gibson Seeks Major Reorganization
description: NEWARK. Dec. 18  Faced with dwindling fiscal resources that have already led to the sending of layoff notices to 441 city workers, Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson will ask the City Council to approve major reorganization of city government, a spokesman for the Mayor said today.

title: The Stone Carvers
description: When the Episcopal Diocese of New York announced recently that it intended to renew construction of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, we felt a stirring of memory and of loss for the stone carvers of the 19th and first part of the 20th centuries  men as little known and mysterious as their medieval predecessors. They carved all the ornaments on all the monumental architecture from New York to California.

title: Iranians Observe Day of Mourning for Dead in Revolt
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 18  Iranians today observed a day of mourning for more than 1,600 demonstrators killed in the revolt against the Shah this year. The capital was calm, but violent demonstrations were reported from two other cities.

title: Arkansas Football Players Are Charged With Rape
description: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Dec. 18 (AP)  Firstdegree rape charges were filed today against Donny Hobo and Michael Forrest, University of Arkansas football players, according to the office of Prosecutor Mahlon Gibson of Fayetteville.

title: New Task for Equal Job Office
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP)  Responsibility for enforcing Federal laws on equal pay and forbidding discrimination because of age will be transferred next July I from the Labor Department to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, the two agencies announced today.

title: Lawyers for Former F.B.I. Aides Say U.S. Veils Sensitive Papers
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 18 (AP)  Lawyers for three former officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who are accused of conducting illegal surveillance against the leftist Weather Underground said today that the Government was making it difficult to conduct a defense by withholding and censoring sensitive government documents.

title: London Play May Cancel Broadway Engagement
description: Once a Catholic, a comedy from London scheduled to open at the Brooks Atkinson Theater in midFebruary, may cancel its Broadway production because its producers have been refused permission to bring in two of the original British players by Actors Equity.

title: Recital: Pianism By Domna Candido
description: DOMNA CANDIDO played an invigorating program of pianistic staples late Sunday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall. A young musician from Connecticut with a master's degree from Juilliard, Miss Candido significantly reinforced the favorable impression she made at her New York debut last season.

title: Vietnam Aide Skeptical On ChineseU.S. Accord
description: TOKYO, Dec. 18  The Foreign Minister of Vietnam, Nguyen Duy Trinh, said today that Peking's policy toward the Soviet Union and Vietnam would end in failure if the aim was to strengthen China's diplomatic position against those two countries through normalizing relations with the United States.

title: Chicago Signs Gilmore To a Lifetime Contract
description: CHICAGO. Dec. 18 (AP)  The Chicago Bulls signed Artis Gilmore, their center, to a new contract today that was termed lifetime by Arthur M. Wirtz, chairman of the Bulls' executive committee.

title: Errol W. Doebler, at 86, Former Lilco Chairman
description: Errol W. Doebler, former chairman of the board for Long Island Lighting Company (Lilco) died Saturday at his home in Southold, L.I. He was 86 years old.

title: Papp Workshop Production
description: Stage Directions, a new Joseph Papp production, is being readied for presentation at the Public Theater. The play is Part 3 of Israel Horowitz's Quannapowi Quartet, whose first two segments  Hopscotch and The 75th  were given in workshop last season at the Public. Rehearsals are now under way, and free performances are scheduled from Friday through Dec. 31.

title: Law Center Gives Deaf a Voice in Court
description: LOS ANGELES A San Bernardino couple who are deaf and cannot speak lost custody of their only child last year because a court decided that the daughter. who could hear, would be better off in a foster home.

title: Study Finds More Care Over Currency Risks
description: Senior executives are now more aware of the importance of protecting themselves against foreign currency risks but there is still some uncertainty whether this increased attention is producing significant results, a yearlong study showed yesterday.

title: A Soviet Diplomat Says Russians Want No Part of Cult's Bequest
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 18 The Soviet Embassy here sent out its lowestranking diplomat this morning to fend off reporters questions about the more than $7 million that members of the People's Temple bequeathed to the Communist Party of the Soviet Union in their final hours at Jonestown.

title: Algerians See Conflicting Choices After Boumediene Dies
description: MEDEA, Algeria, Dec. 13  Beer is not served in the Htel du Commerce, a Europeanstyle building facing the tidy main square, which has preserved its creamcolored bandstand built by the French in what they called the Place d'Armes before Algeria's independence in 1962.

title: U.S. to Seek Part of Cult's Funds
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 18  The State and Justice departments said today that they would make every possible legal effort to obtain funds from People's Temple bank accounts to reimburse the United States Government for expenses related to the tragedy in Guyana.

title: Issue and Debate
description: No one knows how much money is bet illegally each year, on sports events. Various studies have placed the amount wagered nationally at $40 billion or more, but those figures are projections made usually from data seized in police raids and by wiretaps.

title: Help Is Too Late As Death Rides Slow BMT Train
description: While a 65yearold passenger lay dying of an apparent heart attack on a BMT Brighton local yesterday morning, a crowd of angry passengers pounded on the moto an's booth, demanding that he stop the ttrrain. They argued with him when he said he was following radioed instructions to continue to a station where transit policemen could meet the train.

title: These Paper Plates Have a Pedigree
description: Anyone, almost, can get inside the door at the 21 Club, but unless one is known, meeting someone known, or there are, simultaneously, a blizzard and a blackout, the progress after that is usually backward or upward. The backward merely means that the place is full. The upward means that one looks O.K., but not O.K. enough for the inner sanctum, otherwise known as the bar section. That leaves the upstairs dining room.

title: Red Tape Snarls The Rebuilding Of South Bronx
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18  Of the $70 million earmarked by President Carter for rehabilitation in the South Bronx this year, only $23 million has been committed by New York City for expenditure, record that has brought disappointment and frustration to White House aides eager to get the program off the ground.

title: Broadcasters Strike in Spain
description: MADRID, Dec. 18 (AP)  Hundreds of television and radio employees demanding a new contract struck today in the first walkout ever against Spain's staterun broadcast industry. Strike leaders said they planned to stay out 72 hours. The Government, which must address more than 5,000 contracts affecting four million union members by Jan. 1, said supervisory personnel would maintain normal programming.

title: Bridge:
description: A quintet that has dominated New York team play for the last two years added to its victory string at the New York Hilton Hotel Sunday, at the conclusion of the Greater New York Bridge Association's Winter Regional Championships. Alan Greenberg, Peter Weichsel, Alan Sontag, Jim Cayne and Matt Granovetter took the title in a field of 100 teams, although they appeared to have little chance at the start of the final round.

title: Books of The Times
description: THOSE of us who were not charmed by Alexandr Solzhenitsyn's impersonation of Oswald Spengler at Harvard last June will find in Andrei Sakharov someone more agreeable, more Western, more nuanced and every bit as courageous. There is nothing about the father of the Soviet hydrogen bomb and the winner of the 1975 Nobel Prize for Peace that consorts with panSlavic mysticism. He is a man of the Enlightenment, however much harassed by the authorities in Moscow. He is clear on this point:

title: Frith on Guitar
description: THERE'S nothing like British progressiverock guitarists to attract big audiences to the Kitchen. Not that that worthy center for new music doesn't sometimes draw overflow crowds for its other experimental events. But a few months ago Robert Fripp offered a solo concert that brought out crazed British artrock fans from miles around. And Sunday afternoon Fred Frith, whose following is narrower but just as intense, drew another soldout house to another solo electric guitar event.

title: Building on East Side Accused of a Violation In Collapse of Balcony
description: New York City's Buildings Department filed a violation yesterday against the owners of the apartment building at 75 East End Avenue, from which a 60footlong portion of a balcony fell Sunday. The owners will be required to have architects or engineers inspect the building.

title: Don Ellis, Trumpeter, Composer And a Bandleader, Is Dead at 44
description: Don Ellis, bandleader, trumpeter and composer, died Sunday night in his home in North Hollywood, Calif., apparently of a heart attack. He was 44 years old and had recently resumed his career after having recuperated from a heart attack suffered in 1975.

title: Why Cleveland Is Different
description: After nearly four years of financial turmoil in which default on city obligations was hardly more than a whisker away, New York is still erect while Cleveland is now floundering, miserably, in the wake of its default on $15 million in notes. The differences between the two cities are substantial; the similarities are basic.

title: Ruhr Steel Strike Talks Off
description: DUSSELDORF, West Germany, Dec. 18 (AP)  Mediation talks to re. solve the 21dayold Ruhr district steel strike broke off today after the metal workers union rejected a wage and workweek compromise offer. About 80,000 workers at 16 plants have been idled in a strike and lockout that began Nov. 28 over the issues of higher pay and a shorter workweek. It is the region's first steel strike in 50 years.

title: Europeans Discount Effect of Oil Rise
description: LONDON, Dec. 18  Western Europe, which has been paying less and less for its oil imports as the United States dollar has declined in value, should be able to absorb without undue strain the 14.5 percent increase in the price of oil set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, economists and government officials said today.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The risk of recession in the American economy has grown, said Government and private economists in reaction to the oil price creases announced by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. A monetary reaction could come as early as today, when the Federal Reserve's policymaking Open Market Committee meets to consider whether to push shortterm interest rates higher part of the effort to curtail inflation. [Page Al.]

title: Inquest Leaves Many Questions on Jonestown Unresolved
description: MATTHEWS RIDGE, Guyana, Dec. 17  In days to come there will be Congressional hearings, grand jury inquiries and perhaps even trials in the United States that will overshadow the coroner's inquest completed today in this small mining village. Nevertheless, the inquest and the criminal trials of Lawrence Layton and Charles Beikman in Georgetown will constitute the repositories of much of the first sworn testimony about what happened at the Jonestown commune of the People's Temple on Nov. 18.

title: Market Place
description: INVESTORS who may be wondering which of the many life insurance companies will be the next to be acquired may find clues in the techniques used by the U.S. Life Corporation in its takeover program.

title: Rangers Recall Rookies
description: The New York Rangers recalled yesterday a pair of rookies, Dan Clark, a defenseman, and Mike McDougal, a left wing, from the New Haven Nighthawks of the American Hockey League. At ?? H??, Clark 31 years

title: Westway Panic Button
description: Gov. Hugh L. Carey has now pushed the panic button on Westway.

title: CRISIS IN CLEVELAND HELD CITY PROBLEM
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 18  The Cleveland financial crisis is a problem of the city's making that cannot be placed in the Federal Government's hands. Administration officials said today.

title: Star Pancoast Bride Of Yves B.J.Eonnet
description: Star Pancoast, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Walthall Pancoast Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., was married there yesterday in Christ Episcopal Church to Yves Bernard Jacques Eonnet, son of Dr. and Mrs. Mrs. Bernard Eonnet of Montigny lesCormeilles France.

title: NAT DEBIN
description: Nat Debin, director of programing for Music Fair Enterprises, a buyer of live entertainment, died Friday of a heart attack near his home in Midville, L.I. He was 67 years old. Mr. Debin was road manager for Lena Horne early in his theatrical career.

title: 2 Held in a Plot to Bomb Egyptian Office on 5th Ave.
description: Acting on an informer's tip, Federal agents early yesterday morning arrested two men, both allegedly Jewish militants, and charged them with plotting to bomb the Egyptian Government Tourist Office on Fifth Avenue.

title: New Starts In Housing Stay Strong
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 18 (AP)  Despite near recordhigh interest rates, the nation's housing industry continues to enjoy one of the best years ever with new housing starts at an annual rate of 2.1 million in November, the Government said today.

title: Nov. 7 Vote Turnout Was 37.9%, Lowest Since '42
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18  The turnout in November's elections dropped to the lowest point since World War II, with only 37.9 percent of votingage Americans voting in statewide contests, according to a report released today by the Committee for the Study of the American Electorate.

title: But No Quick Gains Expected
description: They have been gearing up for it since former President Richard M. Nixon's first visit, but the communiqus from Peking and Washington last week removed most of the doubts. American companies and the international banks that finance them see trade with China becoming as big as their business with Japan and the leading countries of Eurcope.

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: IT'S a little too early to tell how business is going react to the employee education plans contemplated by the new tax laws, but they are being talked up by some accountants as a potentially significant fringe benefit.

title: Frontiers: Medicine
description: TWO new developments have revived hope that science will succeed in wiping out malaria, a scourge that came back strongly after it was thought to have been defeated in the 1960's.

title: Balls of Human Hair Used to Repel Deer
description: HAIR  the crowning glory of many women and of some men, the protector of the skull from heat and cold, rain and wind  has been put to a new use by scientists at the Cary Arboretum in Millbrook, N.Y.

title: Pop: The Stiff Tour '78 Opens at the Bottom Line
description: WHEN you call your label Stiff Records, you deliberately invite all sorts of wordplays. Most of these gags have been appropriated by this leading British newwave label itself for its own slogans. But unfortunately, if things don't go well, some weakminded souls may be tempted to explore the negative side of things. Like, for instance, The Stiff Tour 78 was a stiff. Or, The Stiff Tour 78 bored me stiff.

title: Taiwan's President Bars Negotiation With China
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 18 (Reuters) President Chiang Chingkuo today made a stinging attack on the United States and angrily declared he would not negotiate with the Chinese Communists after Peking and Washington open diplomatic relations on Jan. 1.

title: Shah's Army Is Showing Stresses
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 18  The Iranian armed forces, which have been largely responsible for keeping Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi in power through a year of turmoil, are beginning to show signs of stress.

title: Talking Business
description: How do the Carter Administration's wage and price guidelines affect executive pay? The Administration is seeking to have companies hold overall wage increases to an average of 7 percent  or more precisely, 7.2 percent, as recently amended to allow for the increased cost of existing benefits. Although a great many questions remain unanswered, the effect on salaried employees and wage earners is relatively clear and has drawn the spotlight.

title: New England Coach Sought ReleaseClub Loses, 233
description: BOSTON, Dec. 18 (UPI)  Chuck Fairbanks, the former Oklahoma coach who took the New England Patriots from alsorans to Super Bowl contenders, was suspended today for acccepting a job as head coach at the University of Colorado.

title: Kucinich Plans to Lay Off 2,000; Cleveland Unions Pledge Walkout
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 18  Mayor Dennis J. Kucinich announced today that he would lay off 20 percent of Cleveland's work force on Jan. 2 to conserve cash needed to get the city out of default. Unions representing the police, firemen and laborers promptly said that they would call a general walkout if even one union member were laid off.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Blanche Calloway, Entertainer, 76
description: Blanche Calloway, singer dancer, bandleader, disk jockey, businesswoman and the older sister of Cab Calloway, died Saturday at the Deaton Medical Center in Baltimore. She was 76 years old and lived in Baltimore.

title: Bond Rating Downgraded
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation downgraded slightly from A to A minus its rating for Cleveland water revenue bonds yesterday. saying it seems unlikely that the city will be able to repay $17 million in city notes held by the water system construction fund.

title: About Education
description: To cram or not to cram  that is no question at all for most of the millions of students who annually take standardized tests for admission to college, law school, medical school and a host of other selective education programs. The majority of these anxious candidates cram, and they are convinced that it helps.

title: Survey Was Conducted After Carter's Speech
description: The latest survey by The New York Times and CBS News was conducted Dec. 1617 after President Carter's speech announcing the establishment of diplomatic relations with China. It is based on telephone interviews with 1.011 adult men and women.

title: West German Girl Gains Cup Giant Slalom Upset
description: VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 18 Christa Kinshofer, a 17yearold West German whose best previous finish in World Cup skiing competition was 15th last season, won the giant slalom today with two unexpectedly fine runs.

title: Seaway Idea Reportedly Rejected
