description: TORONTO, Dec. 18 (AP)  A study by the Canadian Government has rejected the idea of opening the St. Lawrence Seaway to winter navigation because it concluded that Canada would pay the bills and the United States would reap the beefits, it was learned today.

title: Advertising
description: YOUNG & RUBICAM U.S.A. will leap from $500 million in billings to $625 million Jan. 1 as Y. & R. National is merged into it. At the same time, all domestic operations will be divided into four regions, all of which will report to Alexander Kroll, president of Y.& R. U.S.A.

title: Japan's Premier Unhurt in Attack
description: TOKYO, Dec. 18 (AP)  A young man who reportedly was seeking a better quality of life for Japan lunged at Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira with a fiveinch knife today, but security men tackled him before he could stab the 68yearold head of government, police officials reported.

title: Vietnam Veteran's Family Vows to Continue His Fight
description: PEEKSKILL. N. Y., Dec. 18  Ten years ago in Vietnam. Paul Reutershan was the crew chief on an Army helicop ter. Frequently, he would fly through what he called the fog of agent Orange  a powerful chemical sprayed by Air Force planes above him to defoliate the land and make guerrilla warfare more difficult for the Vietcong.

title: 4 Trapped in Elevator 20 Hours; Rochester Orders Investigation
description: ROCHESTER, Dec. 18 (AP)  An investigation was begun today to determine why Diane Hall, 19; her son David, 4 months, and her cousins Martha Smith, 31, and Sandra Smith, 21, were trapped for about 20 hours in an elevator in freezing weather at a downtown municipal parking garage.

title: Woman on Chicago El Train Hit By Bullet Fired From Apartment
description: CHICAGO. Dec. 18 (UPI) A sniper in a highrise housing project today shot and wounded a woman passenger in a Loopbound C.T.A. train during the morning rush hour.

title: Pollution Study Cites Coal's Radioactivity
description: FOUR scientists at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory in Tennessee have concluded that the radioactive pollutants emitted by coalfired generating plants represent a slightly greater public health problem than those emitted by nuclear generating plants, but that neither is of major concern.

title: U.S. Won't Curb Visits By Citizens of Taiwan
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18  A State Department spokesman said today that residents of Taiwan now in the United States or planning to travel here would be treated no differently after Jan. 1 when official diplomatic relations with Taiwan are to be ended.

title: OPEC Rise Drops Stocks On Wide Front
description: The announcement of a 14.5 percent rise in the price of imported oil by the end of next year sent stocks tumbling in disarray yesterday and touched off a drop of 17.84 points in the Dow Jones industrial average. The trading pace picked up sharply.

title: OBSERVER Funky, Punky, Junky
description: In New York the silly people go to Studio 54 and dance all night and have their pictures taken wearing silly hair and then the pictures are published in silly magazines and silly new spapers. It's silly.

title: Gas Pipeline Plan Rejected
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) Federal energy officials rejected today a proposed $5 billion pipeline that would have been used to import Algerian natural gas into the Eastern United States via Canada. The officials said that they found the gas unnecessary.

title: William tenBrink, Chief Of Atlantic City's Police
description: William tenBrink, the police chief of Atlantic City, died Thursday night after suffering a heart attack. He was 40 years old.

title: Notes on People
description: Like all of us, Young Joe is getting older. That's Joseph P. Kennedy 3d, whose engagement to 29yearold Sheila Brewster Rauch was announced by her parents yesterday in the Main Line suburb of Villanova, Pa. The wedding date will be announced later. Miss Rauch, employed as a housing specialist for the City of Boston, graduated from Wheaton College, the women's school in Norton, Mass., and has a master's degree in urban planning from Harvard. Her father, R. Stewart Rauch Jr., a lawyer turned banker (chairman of the Philadelphia Savings Fund Society), was a director of the Penn Central Company at the time of the railroad's bankruptcy in 1970, and resigned the following

title: Earnings
description: General Mills Inc., which has added restaurants, toys, retailing, dairy operations and furniture to its packagedfoods business, reported an increase of 3.5 percent in profits for the second fiscal quarter ended Nov. 26 on a sales rise of 17.9 percent.

title: COMMODITIES FoodFuture Prices Rise; Precious Metals Also Up
description: There were two words used by traders to explain the surge in prices yesterday for precious metals and basic foodstuff commodity futures: oil and China.

title: Oil Bill in State to Rise 650 Million
description: A key economic analyst for Governor Carey estimated yesterday that the 19.5 percent increase in the world price of crude oil could cost New York State's residents $650 million to $700 million a year, or about $144 for a family of four. The Governor had already warned that a 10 percent increase would have disastrous effects.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW. Dec. 20

title: Job Safety Changes Are Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18  President Carter's Interagency Task Force on Workplace Safety and Health called today for broad new financial penalties and rewards to induce employers to protect their workers.

title: Taiwan Plants: Little Worry
description: A mood of business as usual seemed to prevail among American executives whose companies have operations in Taiwan, despite the impending break in diplomatic relations with the island nation and the complete withdrawal of all United States defense forces.

title: Cecil B. Day, at 44; Georgian Who Began Days Inn Motel Chain
description: Cecil B. Day, an Atlanta real estate man who founded Days Inns of America and developed the organization into the nation's eighth largest motel chain in just eight years, died of cancer on Friday at Atlanta's Northside Hospital. He was 44 years old and had been ill for a year.

title: Nets' King Is Arrested on Driving and Drug Counts
description: Bernard King, the New Jersey Net basketball star, was arrested early yesterday morning and charged with drunken driving, driving without a license and the possession of a small amount of cocame.

title: Trenton Aides Said to Get Raises
description: TRENTON, Dec. 18 (AP)  Despite belttightening to cover a projected deficit in the state budget, the administration of Governor Byrne has granted pay raises to 54 executive employees, including seven aides to the Governor, according to The StarLedger of Newark.

title: Japan Has Low Trade Surplus
description: TOKYO, Dec. 18  Japan's balance of trade on current account in November was far below the year's monthly average, but up considerably from the October level, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: EDUCATION
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn. LOUISE THOMAN leaned over a table in the Bachelder Learning Center here one recent day with an 8yearold boy at each elbow. In front of her was a brightly decorated coffee can full of red, white and blue poker chips.

title: MASS TRANSIT GAINS 6TH YEAR IN A ROW
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18  For the sixth consecutive year, the number of passengers carried by mass transit systems in the United States has increased, with urban centers of 500,000 or more accounting for the bulk of the gains.

title: Thousands Pack White House in Holidays
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18  The Christmas crush is in full swing at the White House.

title: Letting OPEC Make Energy Policy
description: The official communiqu spoke of eroding revenues and world inflation. But the real message underlying OPEC's decision to raise oil prices by more than 14 percent next year was quite different: The United States cannot depend on its special relationship with Saudi Arabia to hold down its oil import bills. The Saudis may send their young people to school at Southern Cal and their king to the Cleveland Clinic for heart surgery, but they won't allow such ties to interfere with the serious business of keeping the oil dollars flowing. As long as Congress does not offer Americans incentives for energy conservation, the oil exporters will be happy to provide financial incentives of their own.

title: Staff Attorney Bids P.S.C. Reject Telephone Company's Rate Rise
description: ALBANY, Dec. 18 (AP)  The New York Telephone Company's latest $160 million a year rate increase request should be rejected, a Public Service Commission lawyer said today.

title: 2 in Cabinet Set China Trip
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI) President Carter is to send Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal and Commerce Secretary Juanita M. Kreps to China in February to explore trade and investment prospects. Officials said the two Cabinet members would discuss business possibilities with highlevel Government figures in Peking.

title: Even the Affluent Gasp at Prices
description: Ever since Bob Cratchit fretted about how to buy his family a suitably fat and juicy goose on Scrooge's wages, Christmas shopping has brought money worries as well as Yuletide cheer to the lessthanaffluent.

title: The City
description: Three members of a family were found dead yesterday afternoon, apparently overcome by carbon monoxide fumes, at their home in the Throgs Neck section of the Bronx.

title: AMERICANS UNMOVED BY NEW PEKING TIES
description: No major groundswell of American opinion favors closer ties with China, despite the Carter Administration's decision last week to recognize Peking, but Americans are not enthusiastic about supporting Taiwan either, according to a poll by The New York Times and CBS News.

title: Giants to Pursue Joe Paterno
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 18  With the resignation of Andy Robustelli as director of operations and the dismissal of John McVay as coach, the Giants have opened the door for Joe Paterno to walk in. Look for the Giants to call the Penn state coach after the Sugar Bowl on Jan. 1 in New Orleans, where the Nittany Lions can win their first national championship. Until then Joe Paterno understandably would not want to be distracted by any obvious or secret negotiations. But after the Sugar Bowl game, it will be up to Welling

title: Goldwater Seeks U.S. Court Case On Taiwan Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18  Carter Administration officials said today that they expected a legal contest, perhaps going to the Supreme Court, to decide whether the President has the authority to bypass Congress and terminate the 23yearold mutual defense treaty with Taiwan.

title: The Region
description: The head of the gravediggers union said members were voting overwhelmingly to authorize a strike at the end of the year if new agreements were not reached by then.

title: Vilas Leads Net Advance In Australia Tournament
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 18 (AP)Guillermo Vilas of Argentina, seeded first, downed Cliff Letcher of Australia, 62, 63, today in the first round of the $175,000 New South Wales open tennis championship.

title: His Proposal Was A Piece of Cake
description: As his bridetobe dabbed happily at her misty eyes, and diners at neighboring tables in the crowded Chinese restaurant looked up to see what the cheerful cornmotion was all about, Jesse Slome informed his 14 guests that the heart shaped ice cream cake with Dotty. I love you! Will you marry me? inscribed in red had been the most tender and least flamboyant way he had thought of to propose to Dotty Grant.

title: Soccer League Raises Franchise Fee
description: The American Soccer League announced yesterday that it was setting higher standards for its franchises. In the past, a number of teams had operated with low budgets.

title: Stage: Spalding Gray's Youth
description: PROUST wrote some celebrated pages about a Madeleine, but his subject was memory, not pastry. In his trilogy of plays, Three Places in Rhode Island, Spalding Gray deals with autobiography, but again, his real subject is memory, not documentation.

title: Mortgage Sale Skipped
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation decided yesterday not to hold its regular weekly sale of mortgage participation certificates  its principal source of money to buy home mortgages  because of unstable conditions in the financial market brought about by the oilexporting cartel's unexpectedly large price increase.

title: Indiana, Led by Woodson, Routs Davidson, 101 to 64
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Dec. 18 (AP)  Mike Woodson of Indiana scored 23 points tonight as the Hoosiers stormed to a 24point halftime lead and buried Davidson, 10164, in the first round of the fifth Indiana Classic college basketball tournament.

title: Mannesmann Offer For Tally Extended
description: Mannesmann Precision Instruments Inc., an indirect wholly owned subsidiary of Mannesmann A.G. of West Germany, said it had extended until Jan.12 its offer to buy all common shares of the Tally Corporation for $14 a share in cash.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: High Court Voids Barriers of States to Extradition
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 18  The Supreme Court held unanimously today that one state may not ordinarily block another state's request for extradition of a fugitive by conducting its own investigation into the basis for the request.

title: Argon Level on Venus Stirs Debate
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. GLEEKS! That old expression from his graduateschool days punctuated Dr. John H. Hoffman's excitrent as he examined the first scientific data from the Pioneer probes into and beneath the clouds of Venus.

title: 141 Contribute $23,057 to Fund To Help Needy
description: Patrick Crowe, a New York real estate investor, said that, for more than five years, I have followed the progress of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. He said that he had always wanted to give but that business troubles had prevented him from doing so.

title: Music: Sergiu Luca Plays Conventional Violin Bill
description: SERGIU LUCA is a young violinist who is known for his lively interest in Baroque music and in the 19thcentury virtuoso literature as well as for the fascinating variety of instruments and bows that he brings to works from both periods. Sunday night at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A., however, Mr. Luca apparently wanted to avoid being typecast as a specialist. His program was entirely conventional  Stravinsky's Suite Italienne, Bartok's First Rhapsody, and sonatas for violin and piano by Brahms (No. 3 in D minor) and Beethoven (No. 4 in A minor).

title: Bhutto Makes Appeal for Justice And Calls His Treatment Harsh
description: ISLAMABAD. Pakistan, Dec. 18 (AP)  Zulfikar All Bhutto, the deposed Prime Minister, pleaded for justice today from the Supreme Court and said he had been treated harshly in prison.

title: Paterno Considered Leading Prospect to Take Over
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 18  On the first day after the fifth losing season of his fiveyear rebuilding program, Andy Robustelli said today he would resign as director of operations for the Giants effective Dec. 31 and said John McVay would not be rehired as head coach.

title: Fear on U.S. Inflation Hurts Currency
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 18  The American dollar tumbled in value on the world's money markets today after the decision by oilproducing countries to raise prices 14.5 percent by the end of next year.

title: Jones's Son, in a Mocking Tone, Tells Court He Slew 4 in Family
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 18Stephan Jones, 19yearold son of the late People's Temple leader, Jim Jones, startled a courtroom today with an angry and apparently mocking confession to the murder of a mother and her three children, a crime for which another man has been charged.

title: Meningitis Kills Florida Convict
description: AVON PARK. Fla., Dec. 18 (UPI)  A prison guard and two inma?? were in isolation at a Winter Haven ?? pi?? today as offical investigated the death of a convict from mening??s at the Avon Park Correctional Institute ThomasManning. 26 years old, the inmate, died Friday night of m??ning??, two days after being admitted to the hospital

title: Police Are Ordered to Turn Over Synanon Tapes to Court on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES. Dec. 18  A Superior Court Judge today ordered the Los Angeles police to surrender tape recordings of conversations between members of the Synanon organization for possible use as evidence in one of several civil lawsuits brought against the controversial group.

title: U.S., Japanese Agree On Trade Measures
description: GENEVA, Dec. 18  The United States and Japan announced today that they had successfully completed a package of tradeliberalization measures at the world trade talks here.

title: Celestial Paradox: 4 Objects Seem to Exceed Light's Speed
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Dec. 19  A basic rule in nature is believed to be the one that forbids anything to move faster than light. Yet at least four celestial objects have been observed that apparently exceed that speed limit by large margins.

title: Philip Morris Plans Big 7Up Promotion
description: In the early 1960's Philip Morris Inc. took an alsoran cigarette brand, Marlboro, and with a rugged cowboy for its advertising image turned it into the No. 1 brand.

title: Flyers' Rally Gains 44 Tie With Capitals
description: LANDOVER, Md., Dec. 19 (AP) The Philadelphia Flyers came from behind three times tonight, forged a 44 tie on thirdperiod goals by Don Saleski and Barry Dean and maintained their record of never having lost to the Washington Capitals in National Hockey League play.

title: NEW SOVIET CENSUS GETTING UNDER WAY
description: MOSCOW (AP)  The first of an army of a million censustakers are hiking into remote areas of the Soviet Union to begin a headcount that may make ethnic Russians a minority among this nation's more than a hundred ethnic groups.

title: The New Jerusalem
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  In January 1534, two preachers arrived at the German city of Miinster and began proclaiming a powerful new vision of salvation. The arrival of the Messiah. to be followed by a new millenium for the righteous, was fast approaching. But rather than wait for the glory that was to come, the faithful had to promote God's plan by taking up the sword against unbelievers.

title: Maude Brogan, Directed Rockefeller Music Fund
description: Maude E. Brogan. director of the Martha Baird Rockeller Fund for Music, died of cancer Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 51 years old.

title: The Region
description: ATLANTIC CITY  Ramada Inns, which has 700 hotels and inns around the world, but no casinos, announced yesterday that it had formed a company to convert the historic Ambassador Hotel into a casino hotel. William J. Moran Jr., vice president of Ramada, said at a news conference that Jess W. Hinkle, former president of the Del Webb Hotels in the West, including four, casino hotels in Nevada, had been named president of Adamar of New Jersey Inc.  Ramada spelled backward  as a subsidiary to run the casino.

title: LAST CALL FOR '78 TAX SHELTER SEMINAR
description: Viable new investment product using tax dollars for potential profits

title: John McVay and the Sacrificial Ax
description: Anybody laboring under the delusion that human sacrifice is out of style should consider the case of John McVay and the Giants. On the day after the National Football League regular season ended, the ax that had beheaded Allie Sherman, Alex Webster and Bill Arnsparger in less than eight years fell again and separated McVay from his job. Because he was a poor coach? No. Because management needed a scapegoat.

title: Taiwanese and Farmers to Hold Plains Weekend Protest Rallies
description: PLAINS, Ga., Dec. 19 (UPI)  Mayor A.L. Blanton said yesterday that a permit had been granted to 400 Taiwanese in the Southeast for a protest rally in Plains Saturday when President Carter is home for the Christmas holidays.

title: Confession Prompts Four Charges Of Murder Against Jim Jones's Son
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 19Stephan Jones, the 19yearold son of the leader of the People's Temple, was arrested today and charged with murder and attempted murder.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Herb Golden, once a Bankers Trust man, is becoming a Bankers Trust man again.

title: 25 Books Nominated for Critics' Prize
description: The first major awards for the outstanding books of 1978 will be announced on Jan. 15 by the National Book Critics Circle. The professional organization that is made up of 200 critics and book review editors from around the country has just nominated 25 titles in fiction, poetry, general nonfiction and criticism.

title: King to Play Tonight as Nets Bar Any Penalty Now
description: The New Jersey Nets plan no disciplinary action at this time against Bernard King, their leading scorer, who was arrested Monday in Brooklyn on charges of drunken driving and possession of a small amount of cocaine.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station. New York. N.Y. 10249, or to any of the following organizations:

title: Rhodes to Head Magazine Group
description: As most of the smart set thought it would, the board of the Magazine Publishers Association yesterday elected Kent Rhodes, a 66yearold magazine veteran with important Washington connections, as the association's fulltime paid president. When he takes office Jan. 15, he will be filling the slot created by the death of Stephen E. Kelly last April.

title: 260 Boat People From Malaysia Accepted by Swiss, Caritas Says
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Dec. 19 (Reuters)  Switzerland has accepted for resettlement 260 Vietnamese boat people from Malaysia, a Swiss refugee official said today.

title: Notes on People
description: One thing a heart transplanter has to have is hearts, and. Dr. Christiaan Barnard was threatening yesterday to abandon his whole program for lack of donors. The 56yearold surgeon's Cape Town clinic has done 41 heart transplants since he performed the world's first in 1967. Last year he said doctors were not referring enough of their patients to him as potential donors, leaving a big team of heart specialists on permanent standby.

title: Kimberly to Lift Pensions
description: The KimberlyClark Corporation said yesterday that it was increasing its monthly pension payments to about 4,000 retired employees and survivors to help offset the rising cost of living. The increases range from 7 percent for those who retired in 1976 to 25 percent for those who retired in 1958 or earlier. The newsprint and paper manufacturer estimates that over the years the cost of providing this latest supplement will total more than $17 million.

title: Cremation of Jim Jones's Body Is Reported in Southern Jersey
description: CLARKSBORO, N.J., Dec. 19 (UPI)The body of the Rev. Jim Jones, the leader of the People's Temple, was cremated today in southern New Jersey, the manager of the crematory said.

title: Wine Talk
description: ZINFANDEL nuevo, vino nuovo, harvest red, beaujolais nouveau, gamay beaujolais nouveau  what's going on here, anyway? It's very simple; everyone wants to get in on the success of new beaujolais. Beaujolais nouveau, in case you hadn't heard, is the biggest thing in wine since cold duck. It is wine bottled within weeks after the harvest and sold right away. The custom started in Beaujolais years ago, but then the new wine was consumed locally, from the barrel. No one ever thought of bottling it. fact, it is only in recent years that any kind of beaujolais was bottled.

title: Knicks Win, 130102, As Cleamons Excels
description: Jim Cleamons's roles have varied in his more than one season with the Knicks. He arrived from the Cleveland Cavaliers, in the deal for Walt Frazier, to direct the offense. But that role didn't last long. Instead, he was asked at vanous times to De a shooter and a substitute as well. During the last offseason he was even on the trading block, but there were no takers.

title: Schools Draft Racial Balance Program
description: School Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola said yesterday that teachers would be assigned on the basis of residency only after voluntary efforts to achieve a racial balance among teachers in the New York City schools were exhausted.

title: South Africa Shoppers Share in Robbers Loot
description: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 19 (Reuters)  Thousands of dollars worth of bills and coins tumbled at the feet of Christmas shoppers here yesterday, and they scrambled with the robbers to help clean it up.

title: Deaths
description: ADLERManuel L., D.D.S. on December 18th. Son of the late Dr. & Mrs. Charles Adler of Smithtowm, New York. Brother of Clara Hoffroan. Edna Van Veen. Helen Fis??er. Funeral service Wednesday 11:30AM Overton Funeral Home, 1??2 Main Street, ?? New York.

title: Parliament Vote Jails Mrs. Gandhi For Harassing Officials as Premier
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 19  Parliament expelled Indira Gandhi today and sent her to jail for the rest of the current session, which is only a matter of days, as punishment for having harassed officials in 1975 while Prime Minister.

title: Bridge:
description: Recent indications not withstanding, the biggest lawsuit in the history of bridge and its predecessors is headed for a showdown in the courts. It will take its place in legal history alongside the 1837 case in which the senior baron of England, Earl de Ros, lost a libel suit after he had been accused of cheating at whist by manipulating the deal and using marked cards.

title: More Prices Of Coffee Cut
description: WHITE PLAINS. Dec. 19 (Reuters)  The General Foods Corporation, the nation's largest coffee roaster, joined other leading makers today in reducing the wholesale price of its ground coffees 10 cents, to $2.53 a pound.

title: Head of Detroit U. Retires
description: DETROIT, Dec. 19 (UPI)  The Rev. Malcolm Carron, 61 years old, president of the University of Detroit since 1966, has announced his retirement. He will step down as soon as a successor is named by the Jesuit university, which will create the position of chancellor for him.

title: Apparel Merger Deal
description: Palm Beach Inc., an apparel manufacturer, announced an agreement in principle to acquire the B.W. Harris Company for an undisclosed amount of cash and notes. B.W. Harris is a leading maker of men's topcoats, sportswear and outerwear.

title: BLANTON DEFENDED IN PARDON DISPUTE
description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 19  Charges of pardonselling that have ensnared Gov. Ray Blanton of Tennessee in state and Federal judicial proceedings resulted in the State Attorney General's going into court today to defend Mr. Blanton against allegations that he might empty the prisons of Tennessee overnight unless restrained.

title: The City
description: The city's transit police union said yesterday that its investigation had found nothing improper in the conduct of transit police officers who missed a BMT train carrying a dying man as it passed their stations in Brooklyn Monday morning.

title: Power Blackout Spreads Disruption Across France
description: PARIS, Dec. 19  A vast electricpower blackout struck France today, depriving most areas of electricity for at least two hours.

title: Music: By James Tenney
description: STEVE REICH'S Reich Music Foundation offered the first of a round of performances by composers other than Mr. Reich Sunday and Monday nights, with two largely different programs of the music of James Tenney.

title: E.D.S. Cancels Iranian Contract
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation said it had canceled its contract with the Ministry of Health and Social Welfare of Iran because the Ministry was $5 million behind on its contract payment schedule

title: Cleveland Bank Seen as Having A Key Role in City's Fiscal Crisis
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 19  There is takeoff here on the punch line of a commercial promoting the E.F. Hutton Company Inc., a brokerage house. The local version goes, When Cleveland Trust sneaks, everybody listens.

title: Party's Chief Indicates Carter Will Run Again
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  John C. White, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, strongly indicated today that President Carter would seek reelection in 1980.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The Federal Reserve appeared yesterday to be starting another round of increases for shortterm interest rates. Its action indicated that commercial banks may soon raise their prime rates and that other interest rates will also climb.

title: Firestone Radial Recall Brings $127 Million Loss
description: AKRON, Ohio, Dec. 19  The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company reported yesterday that the nationwide recall of its steelbelted radial 500 tires had caused it to lose $127.2 million in its fourth fiscal quarter and $148.3 million for the full year.

title: Deaths
description: KLEIMANMalvina. Wife of no late George. Devoted mother of Family Bud and Lowell. Dear sister of Ann Roth and Carl Sperber . Loving, grandmother of Tale. Erin, Paige and Shane. Services today 1PM at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd. Manhasset, L.I.

title: 4 American Jewish Leaders Tell Vance of Anguish
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  The Carter Administration had no immediate comment tonight on a vote in the Israeli Parliament accusing it of being one sided and unjust in supporting Egypt's position in peace treaty negotiations.

title: L.I. Man Is Accused of Fake Billings
description: We don't want to be taken by a Yan kee, the city attorney in Richland Hills Tex., said, so he complained to authorities on Long Island about a man he said had billed the city for goods that it had paid for although it had never ordered them. Even worse, he said, the city never received anything.

title: World News Briefs
description: TOKYO, Dec. 19 (UPI)  Vietnam's Foreign Minister said today that Hanoi wanted diplomatic relations with the United States, but he accused Washington of stalling.

title: WATCH SALES REPRESENTATIVES
description: An important opportunity now exists for watch sales representatives in the New York area.

title: Massey Reports Net Loss
description: MasseyFerguson Ltd., a Canadian farmmachinery manufacturer, reported yesterday a loss of $257 million (United States currency) in its fiscal year ended Oct. 31. The company's new president, Victor A. Rice, indicated last week that the loss might exceed $250 million.

title: ISRAELI PARLIAMENT BACKS BEGIN'S STAND AND CRITICIZES U.S
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 19  The Israeli Parliament endorsed Prime Minister Menachem Begin's peacetreaty stand today and declared that the American criticism of it is onesided, unjust and does not contribute to the advancement of peace.

title: EARNINGS
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company reported yesterday net earnings of $1.5 million in its third fiscal quarter ended Nov. 25, its first profit since the final quarter of the 1977 fiscal year. The latest net, equal to 6 cents a share, contrasts with a restated loss of $6 million incurred in the November quarter a year ago.

title: 3 Proposed Midtown Towers to Get Nearly $30 Million in Abatements
description: Nearly $30 million in realestate tax abatements have been granted to three proposed office towers in midtown Manhattan, including those planned by the Philip Morris Corporation, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and Fisher Brothers.

title: Careers
description: Paramedic, Paralegal Training

title: Best Buys
description: WITH more and more money buying less and less food, meshing concerns for economy with good nutritition becomes an everfrustrating task. But one can remain wellnourished while easing the pinch on the food budget. It just takes some motivation and perhaps a few changes in eating patterns and shopping habits.

title: At the Smithsonian, 2 Holidays
description: WASHINGTON CHIRISTMAS and Hanukkah are bursting out all over at the Smithsonian Institution's Museum of History and Technology. Since Christmas and the first day of Hanukkah fall on the same day this year, the celebration, which begins next Tuesday, will reflect both holidays.

title: Harold D. Lasswell, Dead at 76; Was Top U.S. Political Scientist
description: Harold D. Lasswell. one of this country's leading political scientists, died Monday at Roosevelt Hospital in New York at the age of 76. He lived in New Haven and Manhattan.

title: COMMODITIES
description: The Treasury doubled the size of its monthly auction of gold to a record 1.5 million ounces yesterday to discourage dollar holders from exchanging the paper for bullion. But the bidding at the sale produced a sharp rise in futures prices.

title: Giant Bronze Eagle Hoisted to Downtown Perch
description: A sculptured bronze American bald eagle, weighing one and a half tons, being eased up to the cornice of the American Bureau of Shipping at 65 Broadway. Created by Greg Wyatt and cast in 30 pieces by the Modern Art Foundry of Astoria, Queens, the statue is 9 feet high and has a 10foot wingspan.

title: Gunmen on S.I. Steal $1 Million In Fargo Truck
description: Gunmen stole more than $1 million from a Wells Fargo truck yesterday afternoon after surprising two guards who had stopped for lunch at a sandwich shop on Staten Island.

title: TV: Ishi, a Chronicle Of the Yahi Indian Tribe
description: ISHI: The Last of His Tribe, on NBCTV tonight at 9, is based on the true story of a Yahi Indian who was found in hiding in a California barn in 1911. Brought to the University of California at Berkeley, he began to chronicle the history of his tribe, which was destroyed by encroaching gold prospectors and settlers. He died in 1916.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: APERFECTLY cooked whole fish is one of the finest offerings ever devised in the kitchen. The trouble is that such a fish is best cooked in a fish cooker, and this is a deterrent in most kitchens that are not somewhat elaborately equipped. There is one happy solution. A poached fish dish of remarkably similar quality can be obtained by using boneless, unskinned fish fillets and baking them briefly in the oven. As most fish cookery, the cooking time must be strictly limited or the flesh will become dry.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Wearing a Grin

title: U.S. Conceding Inflation in '79 Will Exceed 7%
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  Even before the Carter Administration's antiinflation program has had time to take hold, top Government economists are now conceding that next year's inflation rate will exceed 7 percent.

title: Private Lives
description: THE idea is a nice one, and not very complicated. The teacher asks her seventh graders to go to the Frick. At the Frick they compare a Duccio and a Bellini. That is, they are going to pass from medieval to Renaissance art. They have been told what to look for in the Duccio; in their pockets are lists of symbolic images. They have not been told what to look for in the Bellini, which is the one where St. Francis receives his stigmata, but if they are lucky they will spot the rabbit. They are merely encouraged to see, to think and to report back.

title: Carter Leads in Week's TV Ratings
description: President Carter had last week's largest television audience, and also very nearly the smallest one, for his two television broadcasts, which came on successive nights.

title: Companies Report Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York stock E xchange. (A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) Overthecounter.

title: Holiday Epidemic: Credit Abuse
description: ICAN'T handle a credit card, confessed Otto N., a 30yearold outofwork art teacher (I went to school too long and became something that doesn't pay). He had come in to the Budget and Credit Counseling Service of the Community Service Society for help in coping with an onerous burden of debt. Already long overdue on $15,000 in student loans, he had succumbed to a Visa card and charged up $1,200 worth of new debts. Now, he wanted to know, should he pay a private lawyer $600 to file for bankruptcy?

title: Tutankhamen Show In New York at Last
description: MORE than two years after its American premiere at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, the Treasures of Tutankhamen show opens today to a soldout house at the Metrovolitan Museum of Art.

title: Cowboys 1310 To Go All Way
description: RENO, Nev., Dec. 19 (AP) Harrah's Reno Race & Sports Book released the following odds today on the National Football League playoff teams' winning the Super Bowl on Jan. 21:

title: I.B.M. Is Star as Stocks Gain
description: International Business Machines was the star of Wall Street yesterday as the nation's favorite glamour stock jumped 12 points to 282 on the strength of a dividend increase and plans for a surprise 4for1 split.

title: CHRISTOPHER FREMANTLE
description: Christopher Fremantle, editor, painter and translator, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan at the age of 72. Mr. Fremantle had been for many years art editor of Fabrics magazine, a trade journal.

title: Returning to the Sunny State of Paradox
description: MALIBU, CALIF. IT was a beach house in Malibu, and the surf was swirling in just outside the window. Dozens of candles lighted up the room where we were sitting on puffy floor cushions. I turned to an old friend, a successful writer, and told her about our adventure the evening before. We had gone swimming nude in a Jacuzzi, a hot whirlpool bath.

title: Economic Scene
description: INFLATION feeds on wars and revolutions. The 1974 oilprice explosion was touched off by the ArabIsraeli War of October 1973  and the Arab embargo on oil shipments to the West. And this week's decision of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to increase the price of crude oil 14.5 percent by next Oct. 1 has been set off by the revolutionary upheaval in Iran.

title: Haldeman Leaving Prison; Mitchell Will Be Last to Go
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 19 (AP)  H. R. Haldeman will walk out of a prison camp at Lompoc, Calif., into freedom tomorrow, leaving John N. Mitchell as the last man serving time for Watergate crimes.

title: B.M.W. Raises Car Prices
description: DETROIT, Dec. 19 (AP)  The price of Bavarian Motor Works cars has increased an average of $731, or 3.8 percent, B.M.W. of North America Inc. has announced. The importer of the West Germanbuilt cars said that the dollar had not rebounded in relation to the German mark as much as the company expected when it set 1979 model prices in October. The suggested retail price on the least costly B.M.W. model, the 3201, goes up $430 to $10,165. The topoftheline 7331 jumps $1,105 to $27,875.

title: Upstate Republic for Troubled Youths
description: FREEVILLE. N.Y.  At 14, Andy Rosenschein ran with a gang and fought in smallscale race wars in the streets of Westchester County. At 16. he is a privileged citizen  the chief magistrate  of what might as well be another country.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Carey Names 3 to Drug Panel
description: Governor Carey completed a major shakeup in the administration of New York's programs on alcoholism and drug abuse yesterday by naming three new members to the commission charged with overseeing them.

title: The Pleasure Of Your Company
description: Over the years, I have had occasion to ponder what might conceivably have been served to Samuel Johnson to have prompted his remark: That was a good enough dinner, to be sure, but it was not a dinner to as a man to.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Tuesday, Dec. 19, 1978

title: Simpsons In Rift With Sears
description: TORONTO, Dec. 20  The sudden collapse of the proposed merger of Simpsons Ltd. and SimpsonsSears Ltd., both of Toronto, appears to have opened a breach in the relationship between Simpsons and Sears, Roebuck & Company, which controls 50 percent of SimpsonsSears.

title: Boeing Gets 3Jet Order From China
description: China has signed a contract for the purchase of three Boeing 747SP jumbo jet airliners that will cost a total of about $156 million, the Boeing Company announced yesterday.

title: F.C.C. OFFERS A PLAN TO ADD 125 STATIONS TO AM RADIO BANDS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19The Federal Communications Commission gave preliminary approval today to. a plan to create up to 125 new AM radio stations by ending its longstanding policy of maintaining clearchannel superstations at night.

title: New York City Makes Bid to G.O.P.
description: With lunch served around a Big Apple centerpiece and a pitch that started with a film of New York. New York sung by Liza MineIli, New York City sought yesterday to sell itself as the site of the 1980 Republican convention.

title: For Dieting PartyGoers
description: How do weight loss authorities watch their own weight when they're out at a dietetically perilous party? Here are a few of the maneuvers practiced by physicians and other specialists:

title: Gas Rebuff Astonishes Algerians
description: ALGIERS, Dec. 19  The announcement in Washington yesterday that the Department of Energy had rejected a huge contract for importing Algerian natural gas was greeted today with astonishment and some concern in Gov ernment and Western diplomatic guarters.

title: Supreme Court in Utah Stays Execution of Two
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 19 (AP)  The Utah Supreme Court stayed the executions of two convicted murderers today, blocking the last of five firingsquad deaths that had been scheduled to take place in Utah within a month.

title: Topics Pride and Punishment
description: The jailing of Indira Gandhi, decreed yesterday by the majority in India's Parliament, is intended as a symbolic act. Though Mrs. Gandhi is likely to spend only a few days behind bars, Prime Minister Morarji Desai proposed the resolution against her to demonstrate that No one can claim to be above the law. Parliament found that she had abused her parliamentary privileges when she attempted to block an investigation of her son Sanjay in 1975. Mrs. Gandhi was also stripped of the parliamentary seat she won last month.

title: Walter D. Seeman, 57, Executive In Sales for BalletWear Concern
description: Walter D. Seeman, marketing and saves vice president of Capezio Ballet Makers, of New York, manufacturers of dance shoes and dance wear, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Bronxville. N.Y. He was 57 years old.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: SEATED way back in the second ring at City Center, writes Jay Heyman, Bonnie and I were waiting for the start of the opening work that evening  the Joffrey Ballet performance of Moves. It is subtitled A Ballet in Silence, and is performed without any musical accompaniment.

title: 7 Puddings Gone Before Their Time
description: It's a short story and a sad story and just goes to show  don't plan ahead! The Fielding Christmas puddings are justly famous, at least among the Fieldings.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Greece Warns E.E.C.
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 19  In a confidential letter to Western European heads of government earlier this month, Greece's Prime Minister, Constantine Caramanlis, has warned of a dangerous increase in antiWestern spirit in his country if the European Economic Community does not open its doors to Greece by the end of this year as planned.

title: Chinese Card: How to Play It
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  President Carter's decision to normalize relations with China has fulfilled a goal set nearly seven years ago by Peking and Washington, but the question of how the United States should exploit the development in its future global policy is far from being resolved.

title: U.S. Acting to Secure Temple's $10 Million In 3 Banks in Panama
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 19  The Justice Department hat located more than $10 million in funds deposited by the People's Temple in banks in Panama and has taken steps to freeze the money, a Government source said today.

title: Giants: No Rush On Coach
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 19  The waiting continues. For 15 years, the Giants have waited in vain to return to the National Football League playoffs. They will wait at least three weeks'' before they choose the coach they hope will take them there.

title: WildCard Playoffs Offer Christmas Eve Contrast;
description: They are both Christmas Eve playoff games  the Philadelphia Eagles against the Atlanta Falcons at Atlanta and the Houston Oilers against the Miami Dolphins at Miami  but to professional football watchers, they appear to be distinctly different. The PhiladelphiaAtlanta game, first up at 1 P.M. on Sunday, looks like an average regularseason game. The HoustonMiami game at 4 P.M. appears to be much more interesting.

title: Screen: Clint Eastwood Stars With an Orangutan:Monkey Business
description: THE bright new star of "Every Which Way but Loose" is an orangutan named Clyde, and he has quite a repertory. He can kiss human actors, smile bashfully and make obscene hand gestures. He can fling up his arms and fall over in a faint, in a game of bang-bang-you're-dead. He can steal scenes even when they aren't worth stealing.Clyde's many talents notwithstanding, it's alarming to find Clint Eastwood co-starring with an ape. Mr. Eastwood's career since "Dirty Harry" has constituted one long argument for the studio system, for the days before established actors acquired so much control over their own movies that they could work on the flimsiest, most aimless projects with impurity. It's been a long time since Mr. Eastwood made a movie designed for a star.Some of his directorial efforts have been impressive, and his choice of Michael Cimino to direct "Thunderbolt and Lightfoot" certainly indicates that his taste in protgs is shrewd. But his last couple of films have been so lackadaisically plotted, and so haphazardly put together, that they come close to resembling loose strings of blackout sketches with no particular end in sight.Mr. Eastwood doesn't have the kind of comic agility that would make these episodes individually bright, nor does he tie them together with consistent, tightly coiled characterizations anymore. Far from showing off Mr. Eastwood to flattering advantage, this kind of format virtually eclipses his talents."Every Which Way but Loose," which opens today at Flagship theaters, is the slackest and most harebrained of Mr. Eastwood's recent movies. It is overlong and virtually uneventful, even though there are half a dozen cute characters and woolly subplots competing for the viewer's attentions. Ruth Gordon plays Mr. Eastwood's mother, and the cute thing about her is that she curses and owns a shotgun and can't pass her driving test. Sondra Locke plays a country singer with whom Mr. Eastwood is smitten, and it there's anything cute about her at all, it's the fact that she absolutely can't sing.As for the subplots, one has to do with a couple of cops who feel slighted by Mr. Eastwood in a barroom encounter and decide to chase him. Another involves a ne'er-do-well gang of motorcycle hoods who also tangle with Mr. Eastwood and follow him around. A third involves a love affair between Mr. Eastwood's brother and a woman he meets at a fruit stand. A fourth involves Mr. Eastwood's picking fights that his brother can bet on from time to time. No wonder Clyde is the man of the hour.If "Every Which Way but Loose" gets anywhere at all, it will be on the strength of Mr. Eastwood's considerable charisma, and on the fact that he and Miss Locke work well together even when there's nothing to work on. In "The Enforcer," in which they also co-starred, Mr. Eastwood played a slow-witted cop whom Miss Locke was forever outsmarting, and the departure from his usual tough-guy cynicism was reasonably intriguing. Here, though, the only clearly defined role is Clyde's. The others merely muddle through."Every Which Way but Loose," which is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains a certain amount of rough language, mostly from Miss Gordon, and a little libidinous activity, mostly from Clyde.

title: Technology
description: THE NCR Corporation's recent announcement that its new line of large business computers would use 64,000bit randomaccess memory chips signaled the crossing of a threshold in mainframe computer memory technology, a fact that probably causes the eyes of most noncomputer laymen to glaze over.

title: Widow of Gen. Marshall Dies
description: LEESBURG, Va., Dec. 19 (AP) Katherine Tupper Marshall, the widow of Gen. George C. Marshall, died yesterday at a hospital here. She was 96 years old. Mrs. Marshall was born in Harrodsburg, Ky. She attended Vassar College and graduated from Hollins College in 1902, after which she became an actress in England. She retired from the stage and was married in 1911 to Clifton Stevenson Brown, a Baltimore lawyer, who died in 1928. She married General Marshall in 1930. The general died in 1959.

title: Q&A
description: A. It is a small, edible wild bird that may or may not exist in the United States. It is also called figeater and garden warbler. In France it is known as a becfigue and in Italy, a beccafico. It is said that BrillatSavarin admired the taste of figpeckers or garden warblers more than any other bird. Despite its name, the bird does not live on a diet of figs but, rather, on the insects that swarm around figs when they are overripe. The most common method of cooking the bird is to sprinkle it with salt and pepper and to cook it quickly over charcoal.

title: U.S. May Offer Proposal to Protect Third Parties From Police Searches
description: WASHINGTON Dec. 19  President Carter has asked the Justice Department to study the possibility of proposing legislation that would protect third parties from surprise searches by law enforcement officials looking for evidence relating to a crime.

title: A Diet Doctor Comes to Dinner
description: DR. HOWARD SHAPIRO was asked by a stranger seated next to him at a recent buffet dinner what he did professionally. When he told her that he specialized in helping obese patients lose weight, she looked at the size of the serving before her and explained apologetically, This plate is for me and my husband.

title: Peak Rate On 2Year U.S. Notes
description: The Treasury sold $2.5 billion of twoyear notes yesterday at an average yield of 9.99 percent  the highest rate in history for an issue of Government securities with a maturity longer than one year.

title: I.B.M., in Surprise, Splits 4 for 1
description: In a move that left Wall Street analysts electrified, the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday announced it planned a 4for1 stock split and raised its dividend by $2.24 a year.

title: Stage: In Splendid Error, on Abolition
description: THE New Federal Theater is reaching back almost a quarter century with its presentation of William Branch's In Splendid Error as the third in a series of best black plays of the 1940's and 50's at the Pilgrim Theater, 240 East Third Street.

title: Deaths
description: SANDELCera. Devoted wife of the late Joseph, beloved mother of Leonard and Lenore Sandel and Marion and Judge Samuel Doan. Cherished sister of Gus Maurer and Dora Bendit. Revered Grandmother and greatgreadacther. Services Wednesday 12 Noon at Gutterman's Nassau Memorial Chapel, Long Beach Road at Greystore, Rockville Centre. L.I.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Scotty Bowman, the coach who led the Montreal Canadiens to four Stanley Cup titles, was named yesterday to coach the National Hockey League AllStars in their threegame series against the Soviet National team in February. The games will be played Feb. 8, 10 and 11 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Feud in Administration Said to Endanger Talks on Arms Sales Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  A Soviet proposal that would limit American arms exports to South Korea, Iran and China has set off a serious dispute in the Carter Administration. Government officials say the argument has dealt a serious blow to efforts by Washington and Moscow to reach an accord limiting the sale of weapons to the third world.

title: Blackout Strikes Mayo Clinic
description: ROCHESTER. Minn., Dec. 19 (AP) An explosion and fire in an electrical breaker blacked out power to about half this community of 50,000 persons today. The Mayo Clinic had what officials said was the first power failure in its history.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Avco Corporation, with interests in the consumer finance, aerospace, insurance, motion picture and land development fields, has elected Dr. Charles J. Merdinger to its board of directors.

title: PAPER CALLS JONES COMMUNIST IN 1950'S
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 17 Jim Jones, whose People's Temple settlement here espoused more socialism than religion, was a Communist from the early 1950's on, according to a rambling, disjointed personal history found among his effects and published by the Governmentowned newspaper here.

title: Corpse Identified as Drug Figure
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 11  A man whose body was found on the New York State Thruway in Yonkers early this morning was identified by Federal and city law enforcement officials as William Terrell, an associate of Leroy (Nicky) Barnes, the convicted narcotics dealer, and a contender for a slice of New York City's narcotics trade.

title: Defendant Asks Judge To Halt Times Articles
description: The lawyer for a Bronx man accused of murder has asked a judge to prohibit The New York Times from completing the publication of a series of articles on a drug war in the South Bronx until his, client's trial is over.

title: Why $30 Billion or Bust?
description: Senator Muskie, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, warns quite correctly that the President's plan for trimming the Federal deficit to $30 billion is in danger of being oversold. In recent weeks, $30 billion has become a magic number, a symbol of Mr. Carter's antiinflation earnestness. To meet that goal, he has pledged to cut away the fat  and if necessary some lean, too  in the 1980 budget now being completed.

title: Film: Gypsy Kings And Their Subjects:A Matter of Succession
description: THE gypsies should sue. True, it would be something of a con job, since "King of the Gypsies" isn't the worst film of the year. Yet I think the ancient, Romany-speaking tribes could whomp up a good case for their having been maligned by a movie that presents them as an endangered species without once making their plight emotionally arresting or anthropologically important. They've been ripped off. The gypsies themselves would call it a boojo.Taking as his source material Peter Maas's extensively researched book, which was based on interviews and personal observations and experiences, Frank Pierson has written and directed a melodrama about three generations of gypsies that is all color and no substance. Instead of defining the ways in which their heritage is unique, the movie wants us to believe that gypsies are like every other ethnic group that's been seen in popular movies.Perhaps they are a bit noisier and more peripatetic, but essentially they are just folks who have their antisocial whims and ways as they drink, dance, celebrate family reunions, love each other one minute and fight to the death the next.This may be Mr. Pierson's way of dramatizing their humanity, but the effect is mostly the opposite, to trivialize them. "King of the Gypsies" is "The Godfather" played in storefronts.The movie, which opens today at New York theaters, even sounds like "The Godfather," as when one gypsy accuses another of not having respect. Like a "Godfather" clone, it's also about a war of succession, when the old king of the gypsies, played by Sterling Hayden, his fair skin lathered with make-up, skips the obvious heir to pass his scepter on to a younger, supposedly more capable man.At the center of the problem, though, is the movie's lack of a point of view toward its subject. Dave, the young gypsy who becomes king when the old king dies, is first introduced as a fellow who wants to escape the gypsy heritage. In his almost tongue-tied way he has asked his grandfather, "Where are the gypsy surgeons? Where are the gypsy astronauts?" From what we see, Dave has a point. We seem to be on the verge of something seminal  the first movie about gypsy liberation!Yet watching this movie, one never has a clear idea whether total integration is something to be wished, so that these mostly illiterate, swindling gypsies might vanish into a homogenized America, or an impulse to be resisted, so that an ancient culture might be preserved. When, at the end, the gypsy king finds himself ruling as before, he's not been trapped by his heritage, but by an act that seems completely uncharacteristic.From what Mr. Pierson shows us, gypsies and the world in general probably would be better off if integration were successful, but I can't believe we are meant to be quite so cool. Part of the confusion, I suspect, is because the film fails so utterly to make these people's problems at all moving or urgent. Because we don't feel for them, they become minor freaks of time.As much as the movie exploits gypsies, it also exploits the actors, all of whom have been seen to better advantage in other films. In addition to Mr. Hayden, who acts all over the place and never gets out of the paper bag that is the movie, the cast includes a subdued, very fat Shelley Winters as the old queen of the gypsies; Judd Hirsch as Mr. Hayden's psychotic son who covets the crown and would kill his son for it; Susan Sarandon as the daughter-in-law, a role that permits her the one breast-feeding scene that's become her quota in recent pictures; Brooke Shields as a sweet gypsy girl who looks as if she should wash her face and go back to school at Brearley, and Annette O'Toole as the red-haired WASP whom the young king loves and loses.Eric Roberts, a handsome young man new to films, plays the gypsy heir and may be a good actor, though here he behaves as if he had studied the cinema of Richard Gere ("Blood Brothers," "Days of Heaven") to perfect a kind-mannered inarticulateness.The movie has a couple of scenes of blood-letting, which are surprising, since I'd always thought gypsies preferred to get their revenge in ways that didn't leave fingerprints. Sven Nykvist, best known as Ingmar Bergman's cameraman, makes the movie look very pretty even when prettiness is beside the point. As might be expected, the gypsy music never stops, but with Stephane Grappelli on violin, who cares?

title: Dance: Limn Company
description: THE Jos Limn Dance Company opened last night at the City Center55th Street Dance Theater with as unusual a program as any moderndance company has presented recently. The bill included a revival of Psalm, by the company's late founder; Kurt Jooss's The Green Table, and the New York premiere of a delightful, stylish piece by Murray Louis called Figura, with a score by the Paul Winter Consort.

title: Sports Today
description: New Orleans at Princeton, 8 P.M. (Television Channel 50, 8 P.M.)

title: Soviet Hockey Team Routs Canadians, 93
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 19 (AP)  Helmut Balderis and Boris Mikhailov scored two goals each as the Soviet national team routed a team of Canadian professional players, 93, tonight in the Izvestia international hockey tournament.

title: Fairbanks Incident Now TugofWar
description: Charles (Chuck) Sullivan, a lawyer and the son of the team's owner, Bill Sullivan, was attempting yesterday to negotiate with Charles (Chuck) Fairbanks so that Fairbanks might continue as coach of the New England Patriots, who are in the National Football League playoffs.

title: Deaths
description: GOLDWASSERJune. Beloved wife of Nathan, cherithed daughter of Minnie Limmers Kopp. devoted mother of Jill Shartstein Lisa Goldwasser. adored grandmother of Ann Miriam Shortsrein. Services Wed nesday December 20th. 10:30 A.M. 'The Riverside 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to National Council of Jewish Women, Brooklyn Chapter.

title: Cardinal Finds an Ad Personally Indigestible
description: It had been a nice, eleemosynary party with Terence Cardinal Cooke lighting Luchow's 45foot Christmas tree Nov. 22 in the presence of 500 oldsters from Catholic Charities and assorted celebrities.

title: Democrat Wins Dakota Recount
description: SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Dec. 19 Thomas A. Daschle, a Democrat, became the last new member of the forthcoming 96th Congress today after a threeweeklong vote recount gave him an unofficial victory in South Dakota's First Congressional District. The unofficial recount showed Mr. Daschle with a 105vote edge over Leo K. Thorsness, a Republican.

title: Added Layoffs Feared by Purcell
description: MINEOLA, Dec.19  Nassau County Executive Francis T. Purcell warned today that more layoffs of county employees might be necessary if revenues anticipated by the Board of Supervisors in its budget for next year did not come up to expectations.

title: State Tries to Get Child Facility To Limit Physical Punishments
description: Dr. Matthew Israel, whose childcare institute in Providence, R.I., was ordered by New York State to stop using physical punishment on the mentally disturbed and retarded New York children it cares for, met with state officials in Albany yesterday in an attempt to agree on limits that would allow the program to continue.

title: 33 U.S. Jews, in.Letter to Carter, Assail Washington Over Mideast
description: A group of 33 American Jews who joined last April in implicit criticism of the Israeli Government by lauding an Israeli peace group said yesterday that the position of the United States on the Egyptian peace talks was unacceptable.

title: Martinez Views Albany Post
description: Julio Antonio Martinez, the former heroin addict Governor Carey yesterday named director of the State's Drug and Substance Abuse Services, said that when he took his new post on Jan. 2 he would spend onethird of his time in Albany, onethird at his agency's office in the World Trade Center, and onethird in the streets.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Shah Said to Rule Out Regency as Solution to Crisis
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 19  Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi has ruled out a regency or any similar device as a solution to Iran's political crisis, Government and Western diplomatic sources reported today.

title: Fearing Kidnapping, Member of Moon Sect Spurns a Court Order
description: A 25yearold woman member of the Unification Church  whose father says was kidnapped 10 days ago from a deprogramming center in WilkesBarre, Pa.refused to appear in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday because she said she was afraid her father would abduct her from the church again.

title: A Surprising Holiday Feast in Denmark
description: Of all the Christmas dinners I have ever had, whether as child or parent, guest or hostess, the one I remember with the greatest affection was celebrated not on a frosty December night in New York, but rather on a June evening in Denmark. This peculiar combination of time, place and purpose was a surprise, well planned by Danish friends outstanding for their hospitality even in a land where that characteristic is an archetypal national trait.

title: Books of The Times
description: NEAR the end of Larry McMurtry's new novel, Somebody's Darling, Jill Peel, Joe Percy and a pair of Texas good ole boys are driving through West Texas in a pink Cadillac with a couple of cans of film in the trunk that they have stolen from a Hollywood studio with the vague intention of winning back control of the film's editing for Jill, who directed it. But the film no longer matters to them; in fact, Jill has decided to mail it back when they get to the next town.

title: Unwavering Environmental Aide Eckardt Christian Beck
description: Eckardt C. Beck. whom Governor Carey will reportedly ask President Carter tomorrow to remove as regional administrator for the Environmental Protection Agency. is described by his staff as a kamikaze pilot. not only intelligent and knowledgeable but also forthright and determined, willing to. suffer the consequences of a mission he believes in.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: A plan to create up to 125 new AM radio stations was approved by the Federal Communications Commission. The F.C.C. proposed to end its longstanding policy of maintaining clear channels for certain stations at night. The new policy, if given final approval, would end the predominance of such powerful broadcasting giants as WABC. WCBS, WNBC and 22 other 50,000watt stations familiar latenight listeners across the nation. Under the F.C.C. proposal, the broadcast areas of clearchannel stations would be protected only within a certain radius. (Page A1.]

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: PAGES FOR THE AGES. The new exhibition at the scholarly Grolier Club highlights the craft of fine printing, in a selective showing of books and printing equipment characteristic of the press book, a term used by printers and collectors to indicate noncommercial production. Typifying press book work of the last decade are handmade paper, classic and innovative typography and illustration and hand bookbinding.

title: They Cook the Whole Goose in Prigord
description: CHAVAGNAC, France As Christmas approaches, the golden goose so prized in Perigord becomes the focus of activity for the dozens of farms and tiny villages that dot this green and rolling region in southwest France.

title: Stiffer Peddler Curbs Expected Soon, Mayor Says
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that enforcement of regulations for street peddiers had been ineffective and he made a number of new recommendations that would include a requirement that they give receipts for all sales.

title: U.S. Payments Deficit Widens In Quarter
description: WASHINGTON Dec. 19 (AP)  The deficit in the United Slates bedance of payments on current account, a major cause of the dollar's weakness, widened by $700 million in the third quarter to $3.8 billion, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Absolutely the Last Possible Word on Tut
description: The following remarks are excerpted from Labels, a collection of travel essays by the late English satirist Evelyn Waugh. They were first published in 1929.

title: Personal Health
description: DON'T go out like that, or you'll get pneumonia, the concerned mother shouted to her teenaged daughter who was leaving for school one cold December morning with her coat unbuttoned and her hair wet. The basis for the mother's concern turns out to be an old wives tale. Although many things increase one's susceptibility to pneumonia, wet hair, open coats and cold winds are not among them.

title: Kitchen Equipment
description: WHEN the wire whisk came along, it revolutionized cooking. It could blend and beat better than an army of wooden spoons. Of course, the whisk, as with any innovation, was resisted by some people, my grandmother among them. She would sit in her small kitchen in Burgundy, a bowl of mayonnaise between her knees, stirring laboriously with her favorite spoon for hours, when she could have been working for mere minutes.

title: Letters
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Soviet Wary of U.S. Pledge on China
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 19  In its first comcmentaq on the establishment of ChineseAmerican,diploma tic relations, the Communist Party daily Pravda expressed skepticism about President Carter's pledge not to use the new relationship against the Soviet Union.

title: Shooting Breaks Out in Lebanon Between Syrians and Christians
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 19 (UPI) Shooting broke out today between Syrian troops serving in the Arab League's peacekeeping forces and Lebanese Christian militia units, disrupting the Government's of forts to restore security.

title: Plates on the lap just won't do.
description: In any event, he and his wife had incited Mr. Bemelmans to dinner, and the question was, of course, what to serve a man who had spent a quarter century and more dining on the likes of truffles, caviar, foie gras and pheasants' tongues.

title: London Couple Make Donation To the Neediest
description: An airmail letter came from London yesterday in response to the 67th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. It had been sent by two former New Yorkers who said they had not forgotten our responsibilities to our fellow New Yorkers.

title: Japan's Interchange Office May Be Model for U.S. to Keep Taiwan Door Open
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 19  They call me Excellency, Mr. Ambassador or Mr. Director,  said Akira Nishiyama. Japan's former Ambassador to Canada and now head of a disguised but vital Japanese diplomatic entity here.

title: Preserving a Goose: Worth the Effort
description: You don't have to be in Prigord to preserve a goose. Slightly different but equally delicious confit, rillettes and stuffed neck can be made with unfattened United States geese  or with Lone Island ducks.

title: Company Pays for Cab For Intoxicated People
description: MINNETONKA, Minn., Dec. 19 (UPI)  If an employee at a Minnetonka company becomes intoxicated at a party in the Christmas and New Year's holiday season, he can take a cab home and bill the company for it.

title: Article 4 -- No Title
description: New York Stock Exchange Issues

title: 8 Presumed Dead as Severe Flooding Afflicts Arizona
description: PHOENIX, Dec. 19 (AP)  Arizona rivers surged over their banks today, washing away bridges, inundating highways and forcing 8,000 people to flee their homes. Eight persons were presumed to have drowned.

title: Messages to President Oppose Move on China
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP)  The White House said today that the public reaction it had received on President Carter's decision to recognize China was running 4 to 1 against it.

title: Fordham Coach Ejected In Forfeit to Holy Cross
description: In a bizarre game shortened by a forfeit and laden with technical fouls, Holy Cross defeated Fordham, 8154, at the Rose Hill gymnasium in the Bronx last night.

title: G.A.O. Urges Frequent Deposits To Social Security Trust Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP)  The Social Security Trust Funds could earn more money each year if they required states to turn over their contributions semimonthly, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: The Silver Cornet Band Provides a Nostalgic Beat
description: AS he settled into a rocking chair on the stage of Avery Fisher Hall on Monday night. Dave Fulmer, the leader of Mr. Jack Daniel's Original Silver Cornet Band, placed a brass spittoon at his feet. There it sat all evening, but not once did Mr. Fulmer spit.

title: Koch Defends Ending Water Tax Exemption
description: Mayor Koch met with religious leaders yesterday and defended the city's new policy of charging churches and other religious institutions water and sewer taxes that had previously been waived.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW. Dec. 21

title: U.S. Jet Crashes in Germany
description: RAMSTEIN, West Germany, Dec. 19 (AP)  A United States Air Force jet fighter crashed today in a field at Ahlhorn in northern West Germany, a military spokesman said. The pilot, Maj. Eugene Santarelli, 34 years old, of Canton, Ohio, parachuted to safety, the spokesman said.

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY, DEC. 19, 1978

title: MARIANO C. SAVERI
description: Mariano C. Saveri, president of the Atlantic Appat el Contractors Association of Pennsylvania, died yesterday in Easton Hospital in Easton, Pa. lie was 8.1 years old.

title: Soviet Spacecraft Drops Cameras And Other Material Onto Venus
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 19 (UPI)  A Soviet spacecraft flew into the outer fringes of the atmosphere of Venus today, split in two and dropped a package of television cameras and other scientific equipment onto the hot, cloudcovered planet.

title: P.L.O. Said to Offer Israel Peace In Exchange for Palestinian State
description: PARIS, Dec. 19 (Reuters)  An official of the Palestine Liberation Organization said today that guerrilla movement was prepared to cease hostile acts against Israel and give it de facto recognition if the way was opened to the creation of a Palestinian state on the West Bank of the Jordan and in the Gaza Strip.

title: Gold Brings $214.17 at U.S. Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP)  Th Treasury Department said today that it sold 1.5 million ounces of gold at an average price of $214.17 an ounce.

title: Chess:
description: Why would anyone deliberately play a secondbest opening system? This very question already holds parts of its answer because it's bound to occur to the opponent, rattling him and rousing his suspicions. He may shy away from the sharpest counter to the secondbest, fearing that some refutation has been found.

title: Auxiliary to Bishop Named
description: ROME, Dec. 19 (AP)  Pope John Paul II has named the Rev. Robert F. Morneau auxiliary to Bishop Aloysius J. Wycislo of Green Bay, Wis., the Vatican Announced today. The new auxiliary, who for the last year has served at the Church of the Holy Redeemer in the Green Bay diocese, was also named Titular Bishop of Massa Lubrense.

title: A SENATOR CHARGES DECEIT ON CHINA TIE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  Less than three months before the United States and China agreed to normalize relations, the White House informed a prominent conservative Senator that there were no plans in the months ahead to recognize Peking, the Senator, Jesse A. Helms, said today.

title: 3 Who Died in Fumes Suffered Similar Symptoms 2 Weeks Ago
description: A defective gas furnace that flooded a Bronx bungalow with carbon monoxide was blamed yesterday for the deaths on Monday of an elderly couple and their middleaged son.

title: Senate Panel Tells Talmadge That Its Inquiry Will Focus on 5 Issues
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  The Senate Select Committee on Ethics announced today that its fullscale investigation of Senator Herman E. Talmadge's financial affairs would focus on his handling of office expenses, campaign funds, taxes and gifts but would not delve into any of his land transactions.

title: The War on 138th Street
description: On a warm Friday evening the men of Team C of the Eighth Homicide Zone like to eat early because they know that once it gets dark they will be too busy to stop for a meal. There will almost certainly be a murder on a hot weekend night in the South Bronx.

title: Koch Finds Difficulty Adjusting to Ski Fame
description: CABLE. Wis., Dec. 19  Ever since Bill Koch, a lean, quietmannered crosscountry skiing specialist from Vermont, won a silver medal in the 30kilometer event of the 1976 Winter Olympics, he has been a man of mystery.

title: Advertising
description: THE city's ad agencies, anticipating a strike by the talent unions, apparently rushed to completion some broadcast, commercials that ordinarily wouldn't have been done until the new year.

title: A Hard Lesson for Newark
description: The Newark Board of Education is about to dismiss a thousand employees in a major economy move that officials say will rid the system of excess and have little effect on school programs. In response, city unions have banded together and promise a mass rally tomorrow that could lead to a general strike. That strikes us as exactly the wrong response. What Newark's schools sorely need now is not more turmoil but constructive efforts to make the best of a difficult situation.

title: Jury Selection Starts in Oregon Trial of Man Accused of Raping Wife
description: SALEM, Ore., Dec. 19  A jury of eight women and four men was selected today in the trial of a man accused of raping his wife. The trial is to begin tomorrow.

title: Train Crash Kills 5 and Hurts 40 Near Resort in Southern England
description: BRIGHTON, England, Dec. 19 (Reuters)  Five people were reported killed and about 40 were injured when two passenger trains collided late tonight near (this seaside resort. Other passengers were said to be manned inside cars.

title: Money
description: TUESDAY, DEC. 19, 1978

title: Trustee for Bankrupt Railroad Amends Reorganization Plans
description: NEWARK, Dec. 19  The trustee of the bankrupt Central Railroad Company of New JerSey announced he had filed an amended plan of reorganization that would create a new company whose two million shares of common stock would be owned 78 percent by present bondholders and 22 percent by the Federal Government.

title: Audit Criticizes OTB On Expense Vouchers And Recreation Aide
description: A draft audit sent by the office of City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin to the Offtrack Betting Corporation challenges expense vouchers submitted by OTB executives and contends that they paid a fulltime staff member $20,000 a year to arrange recreation for employees.

title: Japanese Tea Ritual Distills Perfection
description: ALL is calm in the tatamimatted tea room. A lone white narcissus rests within a thin bronze vase. Slowly and gently, steam rises from the kettle in the sunken hearth. The guests are in their places.

title: CARTER SAYS SOVIET ACCEPTS CHINA STEP
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  President Carter said tonight that he had received a message from Leonid I. Brezhnev that was very positive in tone and conveyed the Soviet leader's understanding of the United States decision: to normalize relations with China.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS; The MexicanOilHigh
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.The most pervasive drug coming out of Mexico today is no longer marijuana but rather oil. One dizzying estimate of Mexican potential follows another, all of them promising that Mexico will become another Saudi Arabia and so provide a miracle solution to the protracted energy crisis. Excited politicians in the United States call for a hemispheric energy policy when the United States cannot even manage to get together a domestic energy policy.

title: CocaCola to Co on Sale in China As U.S. and Peking Expand Ties
description: CocaCola, probably the one product most symbolic and symptomatic of the American way of life, is going to China.

title: Religious Leader From Iran Says Torture Made Him Nearly Deaf
description: PARIS, Dec. 19 (Reuters)  An Iranian religious leader said today that he had been whipped, chained and rendered virtually deaf by Savak, the Iran intelligence agency, during a recent imprisonment.

title: Concert: Valerie Capers
description: SING ABOUT LOVE, Valerie Capers's Christmas Cantata, had Carnegie Hall singing and shouting on Monday night. Miss Capers, a blind composer and pianist with classical training, extensive jazz experience and a special feeling for gospel music, has done some worthwhile things in the past, but nothing this reviewer had heard really prepared him for Sing About Love.

title: News of the Theater
description: THE stage is turning out to be no wonderland for Elizabeth Swados's new musical, Alice.We have suspended the production, said Joseph Papp, producer of the Public Theater, where the show, based on Lewis Carroll's Alice in Wonderland, was to have begun performances next week. I saw two runthroughs and felt it was at an impasse at this point. Liz needs a few months to work on the music.

title: WASHINGTON
