description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, is trying to make a party. issue and even a constitutional issue against President Carter's decision to end this country's 23yearold mutual defense treaty with Taiwan, but there is little chance that he will succeed.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) announced yesterday that its board of di roctors had approved a 1979 capital and t.xolorat ion budget totaling a record $2.9 billion. The 1979 budget is 30 percent, or about $650 million, more than the 1978 budget.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 20, 1978

title: Entertainment Events
description: AN EVENING WITH QUENTIN CRISP, oneman show for four weeks. Presented by Hillard Elkins and Sill Sargent. At the Players Theater, 115 Macdougal Street, at 6:45.

title: The Cost of Stalling on China
description: The debate over the terms of President Carter's agreement to establish normal relations with China is inevitable and welcome. It will help this country to think more clearly about the character and aims of a China that is not only embarking on a new relationship with the United States but is also straining to escape millennia of poverty and isolation.

title: A Bronx Councilman, 2 Assemblymen Lead Race for Abrams Post
description: Three Bronx officeholders  Councilman Stanley Simon and Assemblymen John C. Dearie and George Friedman appeared to be leading a shifting field of contenders for the post of Borough President after an unusual sixhour interview session conducted yesterday by the Bronx members of the City Council.

title: 6 Killed as Plane Hits Barn
description: BORDELONVILLE, La., Dec. 19 (AP)  A twinengine plane carrying a group of neighbors on a pleasure flight crashed into a concrete barn shortly after takeoff today, killing five persons in the plane and one in the barn. A sixth passenger was injured. Arthur Bordelon Jr., 70, was killed in the barn. Those killed on the plane were David Brumfield, 31, operator of a flying service who worked as a crop duster; Kenneth Juneau, 30; Ross Armand, 27; R.E. Coco, 98, and A. J. Gremillion, 27. Bordelonville.

title: Rabin Predicts Softening Of Begin View of Treaty
description: PARIS, Wednesday, Dec. 20 (Reuters)  Former Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel predicted today that peace negotiations between Israel and Egypt would resume within weeks and that Prime Minister Menachem Begin would soften his stand in the talks.

title: Two Indicted In Options Sale
description: Two men who managed the Miami office of a company that sold commodity options were indicted in Manhattan yesterday on Federal fraud charges involving a highpressure sales campaign that allegedly bilked investors of millions of dollars.

title: San Francisco Is Shifting Inquiry on Voter Fraud
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 19  San Francisco's District Attorney, Joseph Freitas Jr., today asked the State Attorney General, Evelle Younger, to take over the investigation of possible voter fraud that may have involved the People's Temple in the 1975 election here.

title: Aircraft Exports Rise
description: WICHITA, Kan., Dec. 19 (UPI) Exports by United States manufacturers of business aircraft other than airliners and private airplanes will total about $400 million this year, up 11 percent from the 1977 figure of $354.5 million, Frank E. Hedrick, president of the Beech Aircraft Corporation, reported. Mr. Hedrick said he saw no slackening in the pace of foreign sales of general aircraft in 1979. He said that Beech's own export sales topped $100 million in 1978 for the first time.

title: Mayor Suggests Compromise Plan That Cleveland Council May Back
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 19  Mayor Dennis J. Kucinich compromised his stand against the sale of the city's moneylosing light plant today in a proposal that could produce an increase in the city income taxand a breakthrough in Cleveland's race against bankruptcy.

title: Legislators in Westchester Endorse Referendum on a Con Ed Takeover
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 19  The Westchester County Board of Legislators, expressing its longstanding concern with the high cost of electric power, approved tonight a November referendum authorizing the creation of a county utility to replace Consolidated Edison.

title: Around the Nation
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 19 (UPI)  Defense attorneys have laid the groundwork for T. Cullen Davis to testify in his own defense, but they also have left a loophole for someone else to suggest an explanation for his activities before his arrest on murder conspiracy charges.

title: Carl Soyland, 84
description: Carl Soyland. the retired editor of a Norwegianlanguage newspaper, died Monday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 84 years old.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
description: REMEMBER THE NEEDIEST!

title: Breach Grows as Top Labor Official Quits U.S. Posts
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  The growing bitterness between President Carter and the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations cracked open into a wide breach today when a ranking labor official announced his resignation from his government advisory posts.

title: Avoiding Credit Pitfalls
description: Give yourself credit. Here are some tips from Luther R. Gatling, director of BUCC$: 1. Shop for lowestpriced credit. Savings bank passbook loans can be a bargain and an alternative to depleting your nest egg. A loan with the passbook as security (no withdrawals in the meantime) costs 7 percent or less. Meanwhile the money on deposit is earning 5 percent. Net cost: 1 percent.

title: Moynihan Urges Priority For Jobs in South Bronx
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York said today that jobs, not housing, were needed for the South Bronx, and then cast doubt on the wisdom of New York City's effort to build housing there.

title: Music: Mass of Elizabethan Era
description: WILLIAM BYRD's Mass for Four Voices is a work of haunting serenity written by a heretic. The composer, a contemporary of Shakespeare, was apparently a closet Catholic. In any case, he wrote three Latin masses that could not have been sung in public in Elizabethan England.

title: Gromyko Expresses the Hope For an Arms Accord at Geneva
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 19 (AP)  Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko said tonight he hoped that he and Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance could find mutually acceptable solutions and conclude a new treaty on the limitation of strategic arms at Geneva.

title: 2 Views on Kent State Shootings
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 19  Two sharply different views of the May 4, 1970, shootings at Kent State University  one holding that the act was needed to save National Guardsmen's lives, the other that the shooting was an unwarranted attack on students  marked today's opening arguments in the civil lawsuit under way in Federal District court.

title: Banks List Savings Loss
description: The nation's mutual savings banks had a net loss of $125 million of deposits in November, the first for the month since the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks began compiling statistics in 1947.

title: Real Estate
description: INTRODUCING Haworth White. He came to New York from Kansas in 1951, worked as a business manager with CBS and lived in a rented apartment. Now, at 55, he is vice president of the American Society of Corporate Secretaries Inc. at One Rockefeller Plaza and is living in his own fivestory brownstone on Clinton Avenue in the Clinton Hill neighborhood of Brooklyn, near the Pratt Institute.

title: Egypt Said to Recall Delegation From Peace Talks in Washington
description: CAIRO, Dec. 19 (Reuters) Egypt has recalled its threemember military delegation from the deadlocked peace treaty talks with Israel in Washington, the Cairo newspaper Al Gomhouria reported today. It gave no source and there was no confir. mation here of the reported withdrawal.

title: One Dies, Nine Injured in Bronx Fire
description: Rescue workers coming to the aid of a resident of 3045 Grand Concourse early yesterday, after a smokey fouralarm fire raged through the Bronx apartment house in the Bedford Park ??eighborhood. One person died and nine were injured in blaze that left 23 families homeless.

title: Market Place
description: IF no one remembers exactly when International Business Machines last sold for under $100 a share it won't be surprising. It was in 1933.

title: A Correction
description: In The Living Section last week an incorrect amount of pepper was given in a recipe for chicken with asafoetida. The correct amount is  teaspoon.

title: Graduate Is Accused of Falsifying Marks
description: The name of James Chin seemed to be synonymous with excellent grades during his years at Queens College. He had a Phi Beta Kappa key and had been named to the dean's honor list.

title: Bid to Halt Times Series Is Dismissed by a Justice
description: A State Supreme Court justice in the Bronx yesterday turned down a defense lawyer's request that The New York Times be enjoined from publishing the remaining articles in a series on a drug war in the South Bronx until the end of his client's trial.

title: Companies Report Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates Stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchance, (A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Katherine Litz Dead of Cancer; Choreographer, Soloist Was 66
description: Katherine Litz, a choreographer, dancer and actress known for her satirical dance solos, died of cancer on Tuesday at New York Hospital. She was 66 years old.

title: Deaths
description: GREENAbraham N. Devoted father of Marvin. Jerome & Burton. Loving latherinlaw of Harriet. Cherished grandfather of Robert, Barbara & Joshua. Services Thursday LOAM, Schwartz Brothers. Forest Park Chapels', Queens Blvd & 76 Rd. Forest

title: 600,000 Gallons of Fuel Oil Leak From a Barge Near Puerto Rico
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 20 (AP) About 600,000 gallons of fuel oil leaked from a barge in rough seas today, threatening 65 miles of Puerto Rico's northeast coast and one of the island's major beaches.

title: ISRAELI JETS STRIKE AT LEBANESE PORT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 20  Israeli jets struck at Palestinian positions in and around the southern Lebanese port of Tyre today in retaliation for guerrilla operations in Israel.

title: Boston Chapter Is Suing Jaycees Over Ban on Women Membership
description: BOSTON, Dec. 20 (AP)  The Boston Jaycees have filed a lawsuit to prevent the national leadership from revoking their charier fur having women members.

title: Deaths
description: PASANTEPeter J on December 13 Beimted husband of Margaret Lov ing father of Norma. Lydia & Ma ryann. Devoted son of Aurea Nunez Dear grandfather of Andrew Funeral mass was held Wednesday Contributions to your favorite charty would be appreciated.

title: Swiss Inquiry on Citibank
description: ZURICH. Dec. 20 (AP)  The Swiss National Bank is examining whether Citibank's Zurich branch has violated Swiss laws restricting the inflow of foreign capital, a spokesman said today. The spokesman said that the inquiry also would seek to establish whether Citibank's Swiss operations had flouted any of the nation's banking rules.

title: Insurer Risks In Asia Studied
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP)  The United States decision to recognize China and end diplomatic relations with the Government of Taiwan raises questions about Federal insurance of private business ventures in both Taiwan and China, officials said today.

title: Backgammon:
description: Skillful play in backgammon depends on two factors: determining the proper strategic plan by assessing the overall board positions  and then using the most effective tactical means to carry out this plan.

title: Around the Nation
description: AUSTIN, Texas, Dec. 20 (AP)  A state court overturned the conviction of Elmer Wayne Henley today, four years after he was sentenced to six life terms in a case stemming from 27 sextorture killings in the Houston area.

title: Pop: Rhythmic Quartet
description: ALTHOUGH the stylistic basis for Grover Margret and ZaZuZaz, a quartet that appeared at the Other End on Tuesday evening, is primarily the tight, rhythmic, jump style of Louis Jordan and his Tympany Five and the King Cole Trio, before Nat Cole shifted his emphasis to ballad singing, the group reaches out in so many other directions that it has the potential for presenting a performance that could be dazzling and exhilarating in its variety and changes of pace.

title: Carey Barring Role on City U. Head
description: Governor Carey told the Board of Higher Education yesterday that he would not interfere with its decisions about the future leadership of the City University. But in a meeting with the board, the Governor said again that he has been unhappy with the performance of Dr. Robert J. Kibbee as chancellor.

title: Fairbanks to Coach Patriots, for a While
description: Chuck Fairbanks, who was suspended as head coach by the New England Patriots two days ago for accepting the top coaching position at the University of Colorado, agreed yesterday to rejoin the National Football League team for the postseason playoffs.

title: RossmanGalindez Set
description: Mike Rossman, who admits he has been reveling for three months as the world lightheavyweight champion, agreed yesterday to give Victor Galindez a chance to win back the title he held for four years.

title: Christmas Comes To a Jewish Home
description: IT seems that every year, just as we are taking our carefully selected Christmas tree off the top of the car and dragging if into the house, the rabbi who lives down the block walks by. I smile sheepishly and my neart begins to pound. Being a Jew who celebrates Christmas, and there are many of us, needs some explanation. Certainly it's a sign of assimilation, of a generation with dim memories of the ghettos of Russia and Poland. it's a signal, all right, of religious and ethnic breakdown. It's a sign that the melting pot is still simmering if not boiling.

title: Quentin Crisp in Monologue
description: STRAIGHT out of the neoEdwardian epicene, out of a time when he would parade down Piccadilly, possibly without poppy or lily but with aggressive eye shadow and hair dyed purple, and count on shocking, the 70yearold Quentin Crisp arrives in New York.

title: Head of OTB Charges Abuses by Predecessor
description: Bernard Rome, president of the Offtrack Betting Corporation, said yesterday that OTB investigators had turned up bogus expense claims and other payroll irregularities involving his predecessor, Paul R. Screvane.

title: Turner Unit to Guide Project in Mecca
description: The Turner Construction Company disclosed that a subsidiary, Turner International Industries, had been selected as construction manager for the new King Abdulaziz University in Mecca, Saudi Arabia.

title: Abbi Fisher Tastes Skiing Life at Top
description: VAL D'ISERE, France  Already in this World Cup ski season, Abbi Fisher of the United States has gone through peaks and valleys  tasting the sweetness of victory and the tang of defeat. The tang is not new; the sweetness is.

title: Sound
description: NOT wishing to frustrate the bulk of its readers, this column seldom concerns itself with blatantly expensive equipment. But to snub the rich is snobbish, so let us redress this social injustice with an excursion into luxury.

title: New Air Service To China Sought
description: Trans International Airlines, the world's largest charter carrier, announced that it had filed a petition with the Civil Aeronautics Board to operate a scheduled plane service between the United States and China.

title: Union Carbide Sells Units to B.P.
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said it had completed the sale of two of its European subsidiaries and other chemical and plastics interests to BP Chemicals International Ltd., a division of the British Petroleum Company, for $175 million.

title: U.S. Phone Bill Queried
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP)  The Federal Government complained today about its phone bill and asked the Federal Communications Commission to investigate whether the American Telephone and Telegraph Company was making too much money.

title: Guyana Panel Hears Cultist's Statement on Killings
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 20  A statement in which Larry Layton accepted responsibility for the deaths of Representative Leo J. Ryan and four other persons on Nov. 18 was read at a preliminary inquiry here today and was admitted as evidence in the hearing into multiple murder charges against Mr. Layton.

title: 5 Reported Hurt in Rocket Attack
description: TEL AVIV, Thursday, Dec. 21 (AP)Rockets were fired from Lebanon into the Israeli border town of Qiryat Shemona today. The Israeli military command in Tel Aviv said four or five rockets hit the frontier town in the northern Galilee panhandle, wounding at least five persons.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 20 (AP)  South Korea and North Korea played to a scoreless tie in soccer today and shared the final gold medal in the Asian Games, a competition that was enlivened by China's emergence as a major threat to Japan's dominance in Asian sports.

title: About Hamden
description: HAMDEN, Corm., Dec. 18  Moving right along, we're tracking the evershifting, marketcraving stations of the modern radio dial, having motored across the local morning commuter's drive time to deliver this actionnews exclusive from our remote unit. More after this message. ...(Kindly turn to another page to look at an advertisement for 30 seconds.)

title: China Steel Output Rise
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 20 (UPI)  The Communist Party chairman, Hua Kuofeng, announced today that China's steel output this year was expected to reach 31 million tons, 7 million tons more than last year, Hsinhua, the official press agency, reported.

title: Irish Central Bank Strike
description: DUBLIN, Dec. 20 (UPI)  More than 300 civil servants at Ireland's central bank went on strike today to press demands for extra money to deal with Ireland's switchover to the new European Monetary System. Cash supplies to banks are likely to be affected, but there is no prospect of a cash shortage in the days before Christmas, bank officials said. Yesterday, the central bank suspended 33 staff members without pay because they refused to handle questions about the new European Monetary System, scheduled to go into effect next month.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: IRAN LULL REFLECTS CONFUSED SITUATION
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 20  A lull full of ambiguity has settled over the Iranian political crisis. Demonstrations have subsided but not disappeared, the economy is functioning but not flourishing, and opposition politicians are negotiating but reaching no decisions.

title: Anchorage Woman Ski Victor
description: CABLE, Wis., Dec. 20  The inauguration of World Cup crosscountry skiing resulted in a smashing success for the Unitcd States today as Alison OwenSpencer of Anchorage triumphed by a convincing margin in a women's fivekilometer race at Mount Telemark.

title: Rivelino Ban Lifted
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, Dec. 20 (AP)  The International Federation of Football Associations today lifted the ban imposed two weeks ago on the Brazilian soccer star, Roberto Rivelino.

title: Employee Union Gets Court Order in Nassau In Battle Over Layoffs
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 20The Nassau County Civil Service Employees Association obtained an order in State Supreme Court here today requiring that the county show why it should not be restrained from laying off employees without first discussing the dismissals with the union.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: DR. J. REMBRANDT HELFRICK

title: Christmas Begonia: Cool It
description: The Christmas begonia, a cross between Begonia socotrana and B. dregei, is a holiday tradition. If you get one this holiday season, keep it cool. It needs temperatures in the 60 to 70degree range for the flowers to last.

title: Opera: A Debut in Hansel and Gretel
description: ENGELBERT HUMPERDINCK (the composer, not the pop. schlock singer) wrote only one opera that has stayed in the repertory, but it's a beauty. Hansel and Gretel. which the Metropolitan Opera revived last night after an absence of two seasons, is not just a children's opera, although the many children in the audience last night seemed enthralled, and quite resonably so. This is also an artwork very much for adults, with the entire apparatus of the Wagnerian music drama brought to bear on a Grimm fairy tale.

title: General Tire Plans New Plant
description: AKRON, Ohio, Dec. 20  The General Tire Company has said it would close its 64yearold truck tire plant here and build a new $100 million production facility in Akron if the union accepts a lower hourly pay rate and work rule changes.

title: How to Pick a Borough President
description: New York State's new Attorney General, Robert Abrams, will leave his present post as Bronx Borough President before midnight on Dec. 31. The City Charter calls for a temporary successor, to serve until the election next November. The temporary borough president will be chosen by majority vote of the nine people who represent the Bronx in the City Council, and the person they choose will have a mighty advantage in keeping the job come the November election. Theoretically, then, five Council members, a majority of the Bronx delegation, could pick the next borough president. But since the majority owe their seats to their Bronx party leader, it is he who will do the picking.

title: Brzezinski Is Said to Have Rejected Warnings About Problems in Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  Responding to White House complaints about an intelligence failure in Iran this summer and fall, State Department and Central Intelligence Agency officials are charging that key Presidential aides refused to accept any criticism of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.

title: Mead's Opposition Cited As Occidental Ends Bid
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation yesterday terminated its offer for shares of the Mead Corporation, the paper products company, bringing to an end a bitterly contested acquisition attempt.

title: Mary Michele Hilmes, Student, Wed to Bruce J. Croushore, Lawyer
description: The marriage of Mary Michele Hilmes, a student at New York University's Graduate School of Cinema Studies, to Bruce J. Croushore, a lawyer with Sterling Drug Inc., took place at the Episcopal Church of the Incarnation in New York yesterday. The Rev. Michael Stichweh performed the ceremony.

title: TV: Christmas Program
description: THE featured segment of Christmas Heritage, which will be shown on Channels 13 and 50 from 9 to 10 o'clock tonight, provides something new in this viewer's experience: A group of actors going through illustrative actions and a bit of seemingly improvised dialogue while Paul Engle reads his memoir, An Iowa Christmas, offcamera for the most part.

title: G.T.E. Decree Ends Hawaii Suit of I.T.T.
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation announced that Judge Martin Pence of the United States District Court in Hawaii had approved a consent decree in an antitrust suit instituted by I.T.T. against the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation and G.T.E.'s subsidiary, Hawaiian Telephone.

title: Entertainment Events
description: A BROADWAY MUSICAL, with book by William F. Brown; music by Charles Strouse; lyrics by Lee Adams; musical supervision and vocal arrangements by Donald Pippin; musical direction by Kevin Farrell; dance arrangements by Donald Johnston; production supervised by Gower Champion. Presented by Norman Keen and Garth H. Drabinsky. At the LuntFortanne Theater. 205 West 46th Street, at 6:30.

title: Hers
description: JEREMY is sad in Boston, I said to my friend, turning down an invitation, I think I'm going up there. Mainly I miss him. As a lot of young people do, my son had taken a semester off from school to work. He was managing two parking lots, doing well, but, on long phone calls, asking the questions everyone asks at 20: Where am I going? What does this mean? What should I do with myself? I guess we never stop asking those questions. It's only that later on one simply does what one seems to be doing with a little confidence, which makes the questions a little less urgent.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The Treasury sold fouryear notes yesterday at an average yield of 9.45 percent, the highest on record for such a maturity of securities issued by the Federal Government.

title: 2 Goals for Talafous As Rangers Win, 63
description: The Rangers finally got around to playing the Buffalo Sabres last night at Madison Squarer Garden in their first meeting of the season. The result was sweet 63 victory for the previously slumping New Yorkers.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Celtics Defeat Pacers
description: BOSTON, Dec. 20 (AP)  Chris Ford scored 32 points and Marvin Barnes added 22  season highs for both  to lead the Boston Celtics to a 121105 National Baskeball Association victory over the Indiana Pacers tonight. It was Indiana's fifth straight loss.

title: Koch Announces Coordinated SnowRemoval Plan
description: Warning that we expect no miracles, Mayor Koch yesterday made public a new snowemergency plan assigning 190 vehicles and 2,575 men from the Highway, Park and. Police Departments to reinforce a Sanitation Department force of 1,434 vehicles and 4,021 men.

title: Deaths
description: BECKWITHFannie Kirkman of Da. nen, Conn., on Dec. 19, 1978. Wife of the late Charles L. Beckwith, mother of C Gates Beckwith. Services and Interment are private. In lieu of flowers, memorials to the charity of your choice

title: Stresses Common Goals
description: Dr. Arnold Wolf as he spoke at meeting held by residents of the Borough Park section of Brooklyn in Franklin D. Roosevelt High School Monday night. He spoke of common goals and made a request for more police protection of the neighborhood. About 100 residents were present to discuss the area's problems with members of the 66th Police Precinct and the precinct community council. The speakers also talked of the invasion of the precinct station by Hasidic Jews earlier this month. Article, page B9.

title: Taiwan Said to Agree to Keep Envoy From Protest
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  The Chinese Nationalist Ambassador here, James Shen, did not appear at a scheduled news conference on AmericanTaiwan relations today because of what Senator Robert Dole said was a diplomatic illness brought on by pressure from the State Department.

title: Rockets on Top  Barry Goes After Fan
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Dec. 20  Her nard Xing, who was arrested Monday on charges of drunken driving, diving without a license and the possession of a small amount of cocaine, got a rousing welcome tonight from fans at Rutgers Athletic Center. H responded with 29 points and 15 rebounds, but the Nets lost to the Houston Rockets, 108105.

title: Drilling Leases In Gulf Bid On
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 20 (AP) total of $881.6 million has been offered in high bids for drilling leases on 88 underwater tracts in the. Gulf of Mexico believed to contain oil or natural gas.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: In what appears to be the fallout of a leadership struggle at the Manufacturers Hanovei Trust Company, John A. Waage has been named chairman of the Republic National Bank and of its parent company, the Republic New York Corporation. Mr. Waage, who was a vice chairman of the boards of Manufacturers Hanover Trust and its parent, the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, makes the move effective Jan. 1.

title: Q & A
description: Q. I recently bought an 80yearold house that had clapboard on the outside which was then covered with asbestos shingles. The shingles on the north side of the house are covered with moss. What is the best way to remove this moss and then prevent it from coming back?  R. P.A ., Philadelphia.

title: Home Improvement
description: LASTMINUTE shoppers trying to find a gift for a doityourselfer or a homeowner interested in house maintenance and improvement can solve their problem by purchasing new howto books published during the past year or so. Here are a number of such offerings that should prove helpful.

title: A Bitter Mood of Frustration Lingers Among Residents of Borough Park
description: A mood of frustration dominated a meeting of residents from the Borough Park section of Brooklyn last Monday night, some two and a half weeks after Hasidic Jews stormed the 66th Police Precinct station house to protest the murder of an elderly man on his way home from a synagogue.

title: Haldeman Leaves Prison Camp; Declines to Discuss His Future
description: LOMPOC, Calif., Dec. 20  H. R. Haldeman, former White House chief of staff in the Nixon Administration, was released on parole today after serving 18 months for his role in the Watergate coverup.

title: Miss Bergman, Jon Voight And Deer Hunter Cited
description: The Deer Hunter was voted best Englishlanguage film of 1978 by the New York Film Critics Circle yesterday. The group, reinstating a former policy of voting for English and foreignlanguage films separately, selected the Italian film Bread and Chocolate as the year's best import.

title: Lease Data Gathered In Baltimore Canyon
description: ABOARD THE BEN OCEAN LANCER, off New Jersey, Dec. 20In Houston these days, oil men are saying that the latest drink is a Baltimore Canyon  nothing on the rocks. But out here, 94 miles eastsoutheast of Atlantic City, they're gathering data on the next lease sale in the Baltimore Canyon anyway.

title: Judge Denies Custody Of Son and Daughter To a Lesbian Mother
description: DENVER, Dec. 20 (UPI)  A 36yearold lesbian was denied custody of her two children today, despite pleas to a district court judge that she loved her son and daughter and wanted to raise them.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SOLO CAMUS Daniel Nagrin is a multifaceted talent in dancetheater. His career has spanned dance leads on postwar Broadway, dramatic roles in the classics and, in the late 60's, a successful oneman dance version of Thucydides The Peloponnesian War that suggested the Vietnam conflict.

title: Witter Profits Up 54.5%
description: The Dean Witter Reynolds Organization Inc., a leading securities brokerage firm, achieved a 54.5 percent rise in profits in the first fiscal quarter, ended Nov. 30, on a 114 percent jump in revenues, a record for the period, according to the firm's report yesterday.

title: Bridge:
description: Once upon a time, when New York City was the headquarters of the American Contract Bridge League, world team championships were held here regularly, six times in a 12year period ended in 1964. Since then, a more southerly site has been favored, with Miami serving as host twice and New Orleans once.

title: The City
description: A Staten Island oil company and its president have been charged with price gouging in the sale of more than a quarter of a million gallons of No. 2 fuel oil following the Arab oil embargo in the fall of 1973. As a result. Federal officials said, consumers had to pay more than double the normal price for. fuel. Overcharges of about $80,000 in two bulk sales have been alleged.

title: Aggies On Top In Bowl, 2812
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 20 (AP)  Curtis Dickey raced for 276 yards on 34 carries tonight and led Texas A & M to a 2812 victory over Iowa State in the Hall of Fame Bowl football game.

title: Home Beat
description: IN the interest of preserving a traditional Christmas, there are, thankfully, a few purists left. Two such stalwarts are Jenny Bell Whyte and her 13yearold daughter, Alexandra, an eighth grader who explains very firmly to those interested that she doesn't believe. in bought Christmases.

title: Wendell Hadlock, 67; As Museum Director, He Discovered Wyeth
description: ROCKLAND, Maine, Dec. 20 (UPI)Wendell S. Hadlock, the museum director credited with helping catapult Andrew Wyeth to prominence as one of the nation's leading painters, died at his home Tuesday. He was 67 years old.

title: Fight on Inflation: Outlook Is Bleaker
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  Eight weeks after the unveiling of the President's antiinflation program, the outlook for controlling price increases has become bleaker and the problems of dealing with them more serious than the Administration had envisioned.

title: Prosecutor Is Shot in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP)  An assistant United States Attorney was shot and wounded today in a parking lot behind the Federal courthouse here, the authorities said. Barry Leibowitz, 31 years old, was reported in fair condition at George Washington University Hospital. The police are seeking a man seen leaving the scene in a green car.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Holiday influences began to pervade the commodity futures markets yesterday, with many traders converting paper profits into cash or generally squaring their books before the long Christmas weekend. All major exchanges will move up their closing hours tomorrow.

title: The Region
description: Two slowmoving Conrail passenger trains collided headon just west of the Somerville, N.J., station yesterday afternoon, injuring about a dozen of the 20 passengers aboard.

title: FiveCent Phoize Calls Ending in Louisiana
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 20 (AP)  Louisiana's 5cent pay phones are on the way out, but it is still possible to make a call for a nickel in some parts of the country.

title: ESSAY
description: Getting the United States to normalize relations on my terms was easier than I thought.

title: Doctor Insists on Punishment of Retarded Children
description: Dr. Matthew Israel yesterday rejected New York State's demand that he stop using physical punishment on the mentally retarded and disturbed New York State children he cared for. State officials said that they would remove the 14 children from the facility within 60 days and that he could continue to use physical punishment until they were removed.

title: Israelis Halt Pullout of Equipment In Sinai Because of Treaty Impasse
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 20  Israel has halted a withdrawal of nonessential military material, equipment and facilities from the Sinai Peninsula because of the deadlock that has developed in negotiations with Egypt on a peace treaty.

title: Panel Studying Kennedy's Death Has Information on Fourth Shot
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Dec. 20 (UPI)  Representative Harold S. Sawyer, a member of the House Select Committee on Assassinations, said today that the panel had received very disturbing evidence indicating that shots were fired from more than one position when President Kennedy was killed on Nov. 22, 1963.

title: Judge Says Tennessee Governor Illegally Used His Parole Powers
description: NASHVILLE; Dec. 20  Gov. Ray Blanton of Tennessee illegally delegated to aides the power to pardon prisoners, a Chancery Court judge said today in a ruling that could lead to the rearrest of convicts set free in a paroleselling scheme allegedly conducted from the Capitol by the Governor's key aides.

title: Vietnam said to Agee Reluctantly to Waldheim Visit
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 20 Vietnam has agreed to a visit by Secretary General Kurt Waldheim in February after weeks of quiet efforts to arrange it, diplomatic sources said here today.

title: Christmas Buying: a Mixed Bag
description: Inflationstricken consumers, concerned not only about prices but also about economic conditions in their communities and whether they should extend their credit commitments any further, are turning Christmas season results thus far into a mixed bag.

title: Women's Bank: Dour Audit View
description: The outside auditors' report accom panying the 1977 annual report of the First Women's Bank of New York, newly issued but nine months behind schedule, expresses uncertainty about the institution's ability to continue as a going concern.

title: Justice Named to Judicial Panel
description: ALBANY, Dec. 20 (AP)  Justice Isaac Rubin of New York State Supreme Court has been appointed to the state's Commission on Judicial Conduct, Chief Judge Charles D. Breitel announced today. The Westchester County jurist who has served in State Supreme Court for less than two years, will replace another Supreme Court justice, Morton Silberman, who plans to retire next month.

title: Hanukkah Takes On a ModernDay Meaning for ThirdGrade Class
description: Thirdgrade youngsters commemorating Hanukkah drew a parallel yesterday between the quest for religious and political freedom of the ancient Maccabees and of an imprisoned Soviet Jewish activist.

title: McDermott Chief Pleads Not Guilty
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 20 (AP)  The chairman and chief executive of J. Ray McDermott & Cornpahy, the giant offshore oil construction concern, pleaded not guilty today at his arraignment in a Federal antitrust case.

title: Baja California Area Flooded
description: TIJUANA, Mexico, Dec. 20 (UPI) Mexican federal policemen headed for an area south of Ensenada today, where flood waters and rock slides have closed the only major highway in t hat area of Baja California, isolating villages and stranding tourists from the United States.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 21, 1978

title: Income of Working Wives Forming Buffer to Inflation
description: The other day Jerry Brown of Houston found what he wanted in a flea market. The massive antique oak sideboard cost $550. He paid cash.

title: MRS. GANDHI BACKED IN VIOLENT PROTESTS
description: NEW DELHI, Thursday, Dec. 21 Supporters of former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi staged violent demonstrations yesterday to protest her imprisonment and expulsion from Parliament, and at least three people were reported to have been killed.

title: Taiwan Abjures Atom Arms
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 20 (Reuters)Taiwan pledged today not to produce nuclear weapons or ever use them in its fight against the Chinese Communist regime.

title: Stage: Myrna Lamb's Olympic Park
description: MYRNA LAMB's new play. Olympic Park, at the Interart Theater, is a dramatic patchwork quilt. Funny patches, touching patches, sinister patches are all sewn together to form a life seen in retrospect 30 years later. This look at a girl named Violet. growing up in wartime Newark, Miss Lamb's own hometown, could have been called I Remember Vi.

title: Financial Crisis Perils Activities Of N.A.A.C.P.
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People is gripped by a financial crisis that threatens to restrict its activities as one of the leading voices of blacks in America.

title: U.S. Concludes 2 Trade Deals
description: GENEVA, Dec. 20  The United States has completed agreements with Switzerland and Austria on all issues concerning their commercial relations that come within the framework of the world trade talks here, it was announced today.

title: Puerto Rico Rejects AMAX Copper Plan
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 20 (Reuters)  The Puerto Rican government has turned down a proposal made in 1977 by AMAX Inc. and the Kennecott Copper Corporation to develop the Adjuntas copper ore deposit in the UtuadoLares region, Gov. Carlos Romero Barcelo told a news conference today.

title: China Buys 7 Oil Rigs
description: DALLAS, Dec. 20 (AP)  The LTV Corporation said today that China had agreed to pay $40 million for seven oildrilling rigs to be used in onshore and offshore oil recovery.

title: Miss Austin Triumphs
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Dec. 20 (AP)  Tracy Austin rolled to a 62, 60 victory over Martina Navratilova before a crowd of 3,400 in an exhibition tennis match last night. Miss Austin, who turned 16 last week, had no problems with the Wimbledon champion in the 48minute match.

title: Adm. Turner of C.I.A. Will Quit Commission In Navy at Year's End
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UPI)  Adm. Stansfield Turner, the Director of Central Intelligence, will resign bis admiral's commission on Dec. 31 but will remain as head of the Central Intelligence Agency, a spokesman said today.

title: Music: Burt's Electronics
description: TIMBRE  the particular textural quality of an instrumental or vocal sound  is an important if often almost subliminal determinant in the appreciation of music. When a listener says that the playing or singing is cold or warm, he often reacting to the absence or presence of coloring in the timbre.

title: BBCTV Closed by Pay Dispute
description: LONDON, Dec. 20  The BBC's two television channeis closed down today in a pay dispute with production crews.

title: Devine May Be Named McGuire's First Deputy
description: William J. Devine, the Police Department's 49yearold chief of operations, is expected to be promoted this week to first deputy police commissioner, replacing Joseph C. Hoffman, who will take over as president of the Health and Hospitals Corporation on Jan. 1.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Gallery Brings Art And Crafts Together
description: IS it a crafts shop? An art gallery? Actually, it's trying to be both. Art Latitude, which opened in the fall at 29 East 73d Street, just off Madison Avenue, has the work of contemporary craftsmen displayed in the front and the paintings and sculpture of modern artists in the back.

title: Stocks Unfazed by Prime Rise
description: Stock prices held steady yesterday in the face of another round of rising interest rates. Some analysts attributed the market's firm but scarcely flashy performance to improved prices for such favorites as Boeing and International Business Machines.

title: Think Small
description: Can smallness solve the problems of bigness? The problems of bigness have become so large, it seems, that even the big are feeling too small to solve them. Hence their pathetic effort to seek salvation in ever vaster unions, markets and alliances, on the assumption, for which history gives scant foundation, that global difficulties can be mastered only on a global scale.

title: Funeral Held for Tennis Hatfield, Grandson of McCoy Feud Leader
description: SARAH ANN, W.Va., Dec. 20 (UPI) Services were held today for Tennis Hatfield, a grandson of Anderson Hatfield, known as Devil Anse, patriarch of the famed West Virginia clan involved in the famous feud with the McCoy family.

title: 2 Plan Wells Off New Jersey
description: The Tenneco Oil Exploration and Production Company and Aminoil U.S.A. Inc. announced plans yesterday for starting two new exploratory wells in the Baltimore Canyon off New Jersey.

title: Judge Orders Torsney Freed; Appeals Court Stays Release
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn ordered yesterday that Robert Torsney, the white police officer who was acquitted by reason of insanity last year in the killing of a black youth, be released immediately from a state mental hospital because he is now not a danger to himself or others.

title: 47 Held in Hong Kong Protest
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 20 (Reuters)Fortyseven persons were arrested in scuffles with the police outside the American Consulate today during a protest at the decision by the United States to normalize relations with China.

title: Talking Business
description: Arnold Bernhard, who cranked out the first issue the Value Line Investment Survey on a mimeograph machine 47 years ago, is today one of the deans of investment analysis. His weekly survey rates approximately 1,700 stocks for performance and safety, while his company's other services include the management of mutual funds, pension and profitsharing funds and individual investments.

title: Music: Musica Sacra
description: MUSICA SACRA'S performance of Handel's Messiah, so admired last year, was repeated Tuesday night in Avery Fisher Hall before a capacity audience that included Mayor Koch. In the conception of the ensemble's conductor, Richard Westenburg, and in the singing of the chorus and the playing of the orchestra, the performance came as close to perfection as human beings are expected to.

title: Notes on People
description: In the Blue Room of City Hall, Mayor Koch stood in shirt sleeves yesterday scanning the crowd like the host at a love feast. Get my jacket, the Mayor said. This is a biggie. He was about to present the keys to the city to Arthur Levitt, retiring as State Comptroller, and Louis J. Lefkowitz, retiring as Attorney General  the bestpublic servants the city and state ever had, Mr. Koch said. They always were the paradigm, the people who set the standards, he continued. I've taken Arthur Levitt on. He won. Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, who had sought Mr. Levitt's position as well as his backing and lost both to Edward Regan, spoke of the two men's integrity, highmindedness and dedication, but added amicably, I can't say that I can never remember when they've been wrong.

title: Planes Renew Search for Vessel After Photos Show Object in Sea
description: HONOLULU. Dec. 20 (UPI)  An air search for a missing research ship with 10 men aboard was renewed today after photographs taken from a U2 spy plane showed a shiplike object in the ocean south of Hawaii's Big Island.

title: An Artist Transforms Acrylic
description: WASHINGTON BILL BLASS owns one of his small tables; Princess Shams, sister of the Shah of Iran, commissioned a bar for her Washington Shoreham West apartment, and Edgar Bronfman displays Rodin's Eternal Spring and A Faunas on Jeffrey Bigelow pedestals.

title: The War on 138th Street
description: The only clue seemed to be the gray Pontiac.

title: Soviet Probe Is Sending Data Back From Venus
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 20 (AP)  An instrument package from a Soviet space probe of Venus was dropping through the thick, searing atmosphere of the solar system's brightest planet today and sending back information, the Moscow Radio said.

title: Founder of Synanon, in Arizona, Served With Extradition Warrant
description: LAKE HAVASU CITY, Ariz.. Dec. 20 (UPI) Charles E. Dederich, founder of Synanon, the drug rehabilitation program, was served with an extradition warrant today that demanded his return to California to face charges stemming from a rattlesnake attack on a Los Angeles lawyer.

title: U.S. Assayer Missing Over a Million in Gold From New York Plant
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  More than $1 million worth of gold is missing from the Treasury Department's Assay Office in New York and may have been stolen, the department said today.

title: Commonwealth Nuclear Contract
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 20 (AP)  The Commonwealth Edison Company signed contracts today calling for the Westinghouse Electric Corporation to provide $171 million worth of equipment for a nuclear power plant planned for Savanna. Ill.

title: 3 Found Slain in a Basement Gym
description: Three young men were found shot to death yesterday in a makeshift gymnasium that had been set up in the basement of a Harlem apartment building.

title: KLAN LEADER ADMITS ATTACK ON MINISTER
description: CULLMAN, Ala., Dec. 20  A black preacher was abducted on an interstate highway in Alabama, dragged into the woods and whipped last Friday after he publicly denounced the rape conviction of Tommy Lee Hines, a mentally retarded black man. Today the Ku Klux Klan asserted that Klansmen had been responsible for the abduction.

title: TwoHour Radio Silence Ordered In Search for a German Freighter
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, Dec. 20 (AP)  Hoping to hear a distress call, searchers ordered a twohour radio silence today in the Atlantic Ocean, a final effort to locate a West German freighter with 28 people aboard.

title: Forward Keys Early Rally, Scores 44
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 20  John Drew said what he did tonight was exactly what Bob McAdoo had done Sunday afternoon for the New York Knicks.

title: Letters
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Spain's New Charter
description: LOCARNO, SwitzerlandI do not think I'm mistaken in saying that the monarchical Constitution was one of the few that has been studied and adopted by a freely elected Parliament and subjected to a popular referendum. The real laurels for those two votes, by the Parliament and the referendum, lie with Don Juan Carlos de Borbn y Borbn.

title: Italy's Communists Renew Call for Seats in Cabinet
description: ROME, Dec. 20  For the first time in almost a year, the Italian Communist Party today renewed its call for the formation of a government of national unity that would include Communist Cabinet ministers.

title: MGM Plans a Structure For Independent Producers
description: Plans for a $16 million structure in Culver City, Calif., to serve as a home base for independent film and television producers were announced yesterday by MGM. The threestory building on the company's lot will combine 110,000 square feet of rental space with adjoining parking for 1,600 automobiles.

title: CaterpillarSoviet Deal at Issue
description: Reopening a sensitive subject, a Harvard University authority on the Soviet Union has created a stir with his pointed, public assertion that, to win more Soviet business for itself, the Caterpillar Tractor Company stood silent when the Russians arrested a competitor's employee last summer.

title: Appeals Court Upholds Ruling Clearing Tyler
description: Justice Andrew R. Tyler was cleared of perjury charges yesterday by the state Court of Appeals. In unanimously upholding a lower court's ruling that had overtuned a 1977 conviction, the appeals court criticized the special prosecutor's office for trapping the judge into giving false testimony to a grand jury.

title: A Tasty Contest In Gingerbread
description: NEW ORLEANS VANILLA wafers and gingerbread. Candy canes and gingerbread. Gum drops and gingerbread.

title: Warner Sells Stock Of National Kinney
description: The National Kinney Corporation said a majority block of the company's common and convertible preferred stock had been purchased from Warner Communications Inc. by a partnership consisting of two principal National Kinney officers and a former officer.

title: U.N. Plans New Parley On Wheat
description: GENEVA, Dec. 20  The United Nations wheat conference will reconvene on Jan. 22 in an attempt to conclude the pricestabilizing agreement that eluded it at two sessions this year, Arthur Dunkel, the conference chairman, announced today.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Ski Reports
description: (All ski areas at e operating on very limited terrain. Figures in parentheses show total trails end number open of each area.)

title: World News Briefs
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Africa, Dec. 20 (Reuters)  The newly elected Constituent Assembly of SouthWest Africa opened today, with the question of new, internationally recognized elections high on its agenda.

title: Derailment Wreckage Cleared
description: CONWAY, Mass., Dec. 20 (AP)  Boston & Maine Railroad crews have cleared the wreckage of a 22car derailment west of the Bardwell's Ferry train crossing in this western Massachusetts town, a spokesman said today. The cars were part of a 97car, threelocomotive freight train from Mechanicville, N.Y., to Lawrence, Mass. There were no injuries in the derailment, which occurred Monday.

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, DEC 20. 1978

title: White House Speeds Action on Mobile Missile, Hoping to Aid Arms Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  The Carter Administration has decided to speed up its schedule for choosing a basing system for a new mobile intercontinental missile, a step that Government officials said today would ease the way for Senate approval of the proposed SovietAmerican accord on limiting strategic arms.

title: Venezuela Oil Industry Sets Outlay
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec 20 Venezuela's state oil monopoly announced today that it would invest more than $1.5 billion in the country's petroleum industry next year, the biggest expenditure in the industry's history.

title: Music: Jazz Christmas
description: A program billed as A Jazz Christmas Celebration has a somewhat ominous ring to it. Is this going to be a swinging of familiar Christmas carols that have earned their own distinctive places in our affections? Or new, selfconsciously respectful jazz compositions?

title: Brzezinski Says Soviet Arms Pact Will Not Weaken U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  The Carter Administration said today that a new accord with the Soviet Union on strategic arms limitation, which may be close to completion, would never be allowed to weaken United States security.

title: Grand Jury Hears Aide to Jim Jones
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20Terri Buford, a former top aide and adviser to the Rev. Jim Jones, testified today before A Federal grand jury here that is looking into the murder of Representative Leo J. Ryan and the financial affairs of the People's Temple, which Mr. Jones sounded and led.

title: EARNINGS
description: The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company, which has been operating as debtor in possession since last March, reported in an unaudited, preliminary statement yesterday that its consolidated net loss for November totaled $282,000, down sharply from the $2.8 million loss for that month last year.

title: Inventor's Suit Names 79 Suppliers
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20More than 40 suits accusing the Government of patent infringement are pending in the United States Court of Claims. Most of the suits, brought by inventors and patent owners, concern the purchase of patented items by Federal agencies.

title: Moynihan, at Badillo's Bid, Will Tour South Bronx
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan agreed yesterday to tour blighted sections of the South Bronx at the invitation of Deputy Mayor Herman Badillo. The Senator had said Tuesday that the city should change the focus of its rehabilitation plans to jobs instead of housing, because of the high arson rate in the area and because putting housing into the South Bronx doesn't solve the problems there.

title: Music: Oratorio Society
description: THERE was nothing fancy about Tuesday night's performance of Handel's Messiah at Carnegie Hall by the Oratorio Society of New York. Lyndon Woodside, the society's music director, chose sensible tempos and steered clear of interpretive mannerisms. The 150voice chorus sounded cheerful and confident. It added up to a presentation that was wholesome, predictable and not terribly exciting.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Recorder Concerto, Handel; Symphony in G. Benda; Hungarian Galop, Lanner; Variations in F. Beethoven; Blue Danube Waltz. J. Strauss; Sonata excerpt, Corelli.

title: Union Camp Settles Two Class Actions
description: The Union Camp Corporation announced it had agreed to settle two groups of civil class action lawsuits resulting from charges that it and other companies conspired to fix prices on corrugated containers and fine papers.

title: Mayors Assail Carter Budget Plan; Governors Give It Limited Support
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  President Carter's plan to pare domestic programs to reduce the budget deficit to $30 billion was sharply criticized today by the National Conference of Democratic Mayors. But it won qualified support from the National Governors Association.

title: Jersey Questions Jones Cremation
description: CLARKSBORO, N.J., Dec. 20 (AP) Serious questions have been raised about the legality of cremating the body of the Rev. Jim Jones in New Jersey, a deputy attorney general said today.

title: U.S. Official Says Temple Funds In Panama Are Definitely Frozen
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  A Carter Administration official said today that People's Temple accounts, possibly containing more than $10 million, had definitely been frozen in Panama by the branches of two Swiss banks in which they had been deposited.

title: Safety Laxity Denied By Transit Authority In 2 Subway Incidents
description: Officials of the New York City Transit Authority denied yesterday that lax safety practices had contributed to a derailment a week ago in which 23 persons were injured at Columbus Circle or to the death of a heartattack victim on a Brooklyn train last Monday.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: BOSTON, Dec. 20  Angry words are not always useless in human relations. By releasing harbored resentments and letting others know of real feelings and fears, they may clear the air. Anger has its reasons.

title: Queens Judge to Replace Gribetz as Carey Counsel
description: Governor Carey has appointed a 46yearold State Supreme Court justice, Richard A. Brown of Queens, as his counsel, replacing Judah Gribetz, who has served in Mr. Carey's administration since the Governor took office in 1975.

title: Let Intelligence Customers Beware
description: In a handwritten note that did not long remain private, President Carter complained to some of his senior advisers last month that he was disappointed by the quality of political intelligence abroad. He seemed especially disturbed that our snoops and analysts had not predicted, or even allowed for, the possibility of the turmoil in Iran. It is widely reported that Mr. Carter's displeasure was aimed mostly at Adm. Stansfield Turner, the Director of Central Intelligence.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Baltimore Sunpapers announced that Donald Patterson, publisher, would take over as president and chief operating officer at the end of the month. He succeeds William Schmick Jr., who retires at the end of December.

title: HOUSE PANEL OFFERS ILLEGALALIENS PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  A House committee today proposed major changes in the nation's immigration policies to stem the flow of illegal aliens into the United States.

title: S. I. Robbery Loot Now Estimated By Police at More Than $2 Million
description: Armed robbers who surprised two Wells Fargo guards when they stopped for lunch on Staten Island on Wednesday stole $2 million to $3 million, and not $1 million. as was reported earlier, the police said yesterday.

title: Letter On Amnesty International
description: To the Editor:

title: Are Giants Using Screen Play?
description: As the Giants continue scanning North America for a new coach, it is becoming more apparent that Joe Paterno is only the smokescreen behind which the real search is taking place. At least it would seem that way with each denial by the Penn State coach that he is interested in the job.

title: Books of The Times
description: BECAUSE almost everybody in the book world from here to William F. Buckley Jr. seems to know Wilfrid Sheed, almost any reviewer of his second collection of essays is suspect. We are guilty by association. This includes me. Half of The Good Word originally appeared in the pages of The New York Times Book Review when I considered myself to be in charge of that magazine. Obviously, I can be expected to approve of at least half of this book, and I do. So much for truth in advertising. Now, said Dr. Spielvogel to Alexander Portnoy, ye may perhaps to begin. Yes?

title: Tigers Bow in Duel of Coaches
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 20  Butch van Breda Kolff, Pete Carril's coach at Lafayette College 17 years ago, gave his former pupil a lesson in disciplined basketball as the University of New Orleans defeated Princeton, 5345, in Jadwin Gymnasium. Van Breda Kolff once played for and then coached Princeton, and Carril succeeded him as the Tigers coach.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreigners Flee El Salvador as Guerrilla Violence Mounts
description: SAN SALVADOR  The recent killing of a foreign executive and the kidnapping of four others by leftist guerrillas, as well as the killing of a priest allegedly linked to rebel groups, have intensified fears in this deeply divided Central American republic.

title: Gromyko Doubts Talks Will Yield Arms Pact
description: GENEVA, Dec. 20  Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, said here today on his arrival from Moscow that he hoped his meeting with Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance would prepare the way for the conclusion of a new arms accord.

title: Basking Ridge Tries to Adjust to A.T.&T Complex
description: BASKING RIDGE, N.J., Dec. 16  At lunchtime, cars inch around the tight traffic circle in front of the Presbyterian Church here and squeeze onto South Finley Avenue, the little commercial strip of yellow and white clapboard shops with blackshuttered windows and handlettered signs. Parking spaces are rare.

title: Suit Filed in Grain Explosion.
description: A $114.1million negligence suit was filed in Federal District Court in New York City yesterday over a grain elevator explosion and fire that killed 34 people a year ago. The defendants are six officials of the Continental Grain Company, operator of an elevator that exploded and burned Dec. 22, 1977 in Westwego, La. The suit was filed by injured survivors and relatives of the deceased.

title: JOB SAFETY AGENCY REDUCES FIRE RULES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  The controversial Occupational Safety and Health Administration took another step to disarm its critics today by drastically streamlining its rules to protect workers from fire.

title: Chileans Search for More Bodies Near Site Where 14 Were Found
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 20 (AP)  A new excavation for bodies and skeletons began today at a roadside hollow near an old lime kiln where human remains were found thre weeks ago.

title: A Chrysler Borrowing
description: DETROIT, Dec. 20 (AP)  the Chrysler Corporation has borrowed $231.5 million from two of the nation's largest insurance companies. In a sale of 15year notes, the Prudential Insurance Company of America purchased $175 million. worth and the Aetna Lite and Casualty Company bought $56.5 million. The loan is the most recent in a series of moves to help the cashshort company, which is expected to lo??e $250 million this year

title: First Visit To a Grand New York House
description: IT was last Sept. 6 that Benjamin Sonnenberg, the flamboyant public relations genius who managed to make himself as celebrated as his clients, died at the age of 77. And it was on Sept. 8 that a passerby, pausing at Mr. Sonnenberg's great fivestory town house on Gramercy Park, noticed Arthur Horn, the butler, out in front of the house, polish and cloth in hand, scrubbing away as usual at the huge brass door knocker.

title: GARDENING
description: THE beautiful tuberous begonias have long been favorite houseplants in Europe  and usually miserable indoor failures in America, although they thrive as bedding plants in the summer garden. But now all that is changing, as a small esthetic bonus (if one wants to think of it that way) of the oil crisis. The fact is, American homes were always too warm for these begonias' comfort. With the thermostats turned down, many of them even lower at night, things are looking up for tuberous begonias.

title: Police Officers in Suffolk Awarded A 15.9% Increase Over Two Years
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Dec. 20  Superior officers of the Suffolk County Police Department were awarded a twoyear wage increase totaling 15.9 percent by a state arbitrator today. County Executive John V. N. Klein described the award as outrageous and a violation of President Carter's 7 percent antiinflation wage guideline.

title: Joseph A. Lippman Is Dead at 74; Managed Singers and Musicians
description: Joseph A. Lippman, executive vice president of Herbert Barrett Management and for decades a major figure in the management of concert and opera performers, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital of complications resulting from lung cancer. He was 74 years old.

title: Silence Shrouds Dictaphone Talks
description: The Dictaphone Corporation declined yesterday to disclose the results of a meeting of its board of directors it had scheduled to consider the offer by PitneyBowes Inc. to acquire Dictaphone for $120 million in cash and stock.

title: Israel Lists 3 Targets of Raids
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 20  Israel said today that its jets had carried out a 15minute attack on three targets in an area of southern Lebanon controlled by the main Palestinian guerrilla organization, Al Fatah.

title: $20 Tickets Offered As King Tut Exhibit Has Its Opening Day
description: An even flow of 500 people every half hour filed into the Metopolitan Museum of Art yesterday after its doors were opened at 8:30 A.M. to permit the general public in for the first time to see the Treasures of Tutankhamun exhibition.

title: NEW & USEFUL
description: Decorative Carolers

title: Bucharest Hails U.S.China Links As Outstanding Event for Peace
description: VIENNA, Dec. 20 (Reuters)  The establishment of diplomatic relations between the United States and China was hailed by Rumania today as an outstanding event in the service of peace.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a transmission error, the word not was omitted from an article in The Times yesterday on proposals to limit searches by lawenforcement officials. The article should have said legislation proposed by the Carter Administration had been hailed by news executives because it would not he limited to the press, thus avoiding the appearance of special privileges.

title: Environmentalists Praise Carter But Are Critical on Some Issues
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  President Carter received a rare tribute from a major interest group today as leaders of environmental organizations declared that his record on conservation and environmental protection was outstanding.

title: Christopher Fremantle, a Painter Of Abstract Landscapes, Was 72
description: Christopher Fremantle, a painter of abstract landscapes died Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 72 years old. Mr. Fremantle's work had been exhibited in New York, London, Paris and Mexico City.

title: Official Winter Time: 12:21 A.M. Tomorrow
description: At exactly 12:21 A.M. tomorrow in New York City the sun will reach its southernmost point and winter will officially begin, according to the Hayden Planetarium. Sunshine, strong winds and, not surprisingly, cold weather are forecast for the day.

title: No Time to Lean on the I.C.C.
description: There is nothing unusual about Federal regulatory agencies getting advice from members of the Congressional committees that oversee their activities. But the advice recently offered the Interstate Commerce Commission by Representatives Harold Johnson and James Howard  the chairmen of the House Public Works Committee and its subcommittee on Surface Transportation  was anything but ordinary. The Congressmen demanded that the independent agency restore privileges to the regulated trucking industry monopoly that would cost the public hundreds of millions a year, until Congress gets around to deciding whether such changes are in the public interest.

title: Russia Places Soybean Order
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 20 (UPI) The Soviet Union has entered the American soybean market for first time this year, with major purchases of 700,000 metric tons, or 25.8 million bushels, the Agriculture Department said today. The beans will be shipped luring the 197879 marketing year, which ends Aug, 31.

title: ABC to Purchase R. L. White Co.
description: American Broadcasting Companies Inc. said it had signed a purchase agreement for the acquisition of the R. L. White Company of Lousiville. Ky. Terms of the purchase were not disclosed.

title: TV: Gift of the Magi Gets New Life as Musical
description: THIS Christmas seems to be O. Henry's turn to get battered about in television adaptations. A couple of weeks ago on ABCTV, his Gift of the Magi was used as the inspiration for A Gift of Love. which served as a vehicle for Marie Osmond's acting debut. Miss Osmond played a rich orphan who fell in love with a poor Swiss immigrant as conceived by Timothy Bottoms.

title: 3 QUASARS REPORTED RELATIVELY NEARBY
description: MUNICH, Dec. 20  An astronomer who has long challenged the view that quasars are the most distant observable objects, suggesting instead that they are related to relatively nearby galaxies, has reported finding what he and his colleagues believe to be three quasars within or near the galaxy NGC 1073, which is relatively near the Earth's galaxy.

title: Gains in Economy Cause Split in secession Views
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  Thanks to substantial gains in employment and therefore personal income, the economy is moving along faster than expected, and the growth rate for the fourth quarter of the year may reach as high as 5 percent.

title: Some Polishing Tips For Furniture Buffs
description: FREQUENTLY I am asked which is the best polish to use on furniture. My answer is that there are a number of good liquid polishes on the market that produce durable lustersfrom a high gloss to low satin look  and all with minimal effort.

title: DAYAN AND KHALIL TO TALK WITH VANCE ON PEACE DEADLOCK
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  The United States announced today that Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance would meet with Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel and Prime Minister Mustafa Khalil of Egypt in Brussels this weekend to try to revive the deadlocked Middle East peace negotiations.

title: Combustion Engineering To Acquire Basic Inc.
description: Combustion Engineeing Inc. announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement to acquire Basic Inc., a producer of refractory, chemical, building and electronic products.

title: Knicks and Rangers Donate $2,500 to the Neediest Cases
description: Two of the professional sports teams in New York City, the Knicks Kicks basketball team and the Rangers hockey team, were among the 198 contributors yesterday to the 67th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. A gift of $2,500 was received from Michael Burke, president of Madison Square Garden Center Inc.

title: Prime Rises To 11% at Chemical
description: The Chemical Flank, the nation's sixth largest, yesterday raised its prime rate on corporate loans to 11 percent  just a quarterpoint below the peak 12 percent rate that banks charged in mid1974  and the Federal Reserve nudged shortterm interest rates higher for the second day in row.

title: Deaths
description: FRIEDMANLeopold. The Board of Directors of the Quaker Ridge Golf Club records with deep sorror the Passing of its esteemed member, Leopold Friedman. On behalf of the membership. we extend sincerest sympathy to the family,

title: Franco Daughter Fined $97,000 For Attempt to Take Out Jewels
description: MADRID, Dec. 20 (Reuters)  Carmen Franco, the daughter of the late Spanish dictator, was fined the equivalent of $97,000 today on charges of trying to smuggle jewels of national importance out of the country.

title: Fugitive Indicted for Murder
description: A 24yearold Bronx grocer who last week jumped $15,000 cash hail was indicted yesterday by a Bronx grand jury for the murder of a youth. The fugitive, Dede Nikllaj, a native of Albania, faces 25 years to life if convicted of the Nov. 29 shooting of 19yearold Anthony Rossetti.Mr. Nikollaj allegedly shot Mr. Rossetti after a snowball thrown by someone else hit a wall of the grocer's store. Mr. Nikollaj had complained in the past of harassment by local youths and damage to his store.

title: Books: A Collection for Collectors
description: WE are, it seems, a nation of squirrels, acquiring and stowing away collectibles to enjoy at our leisure. At least, the books issuing from publishers this season seem to suggest that the nation  indeed much of the Western world  is gripped by a compulsion to collect virtually anything that has some age and artistic appeal. The following are among the more notable volumes published recently.

title: Bombings Damage 3 Major Hotels in Northern Ireland
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 20 (Reuters)  Irish Republican Army guerrillas carried out a wave of bombings tonight against leading hotels in Northern Ireland. the police said.

title: Design Notebook
description: IT was six years ago this week that Walter Hoving, chairman of Tiffany & Company, made frontpage headlines by issuing a formal denunciation of the Christmas decorations on the front of the Park Avenue headquarters of the First National City Bank, now Citibank. The trio of sevenstory Christmas trees, abstract in style and, in fact, made up of metal branches and yellow lights hung on flagpoles, were loud and vulgar, according to Mr. Roving, who said that the bank was polluting the esthetic atmosphere of Park Avenue.

title: Deaths
description: FISCHERSidney beloved husband of Ruth Ince Koff), devoted father of Robert Charles & Alan Samuel, brother of Emanuel. Services Fri 12 Noon at the Riverside, 1250 Central Ave, Far Rockaway.

title: A.T.&T. Net Up 18.3% For 3 Months to Nov. 30
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday that earnings for the quarter ended Nov. 30 rose 18.3 percent, while revenues climbed 12.2 percent. It also announced a record construction budget for next year of $14.8 million, up $1.2 billion from 1978.

title: Advertising
description: LOTS of ad agencies are involved in the production of TV shows and series that are syndicated among stations in exchange for commercial time. It is rare, however, that an advertiser gets into the act.

title: Ban on Arms to Pretoria Worrying U.S. Businesses
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  The State Department tried today to resolve a prob lem concerning trade with South Africa that has sharply divided liberals and con, servatives in Congress and the executive branch as well as some companies and unions.

title: The Seventh New England State
description: Now that Chuck Fairbanks has decided to remain at the University of Sullivan for the time being rather than transfer to the University of Colorado, the New England Patriots would appear on course to the Super Bowl again. But life is never that simple for the team that Billy Sullivan has owned for nearly two decades. Among those close to the franchise, the rule of thumb is that when all seems peaceful, that's the time to worry. And unless the Patriots do win Super Bowl XIII in Miami next month, Chuck Fairbanks can't win. Any loss in the playoffs will be considered his responsibility for disrupting theteam by indicating his preference to work in Boulder, Colo., rather than near Plymouth Rock, proving the theory that college football in the Big Eight Conference is pro football too. But the Chuck Fairbanks fiasco is in keeping with the Patriots tradition.

title: Disks: Beethoven's Diabelli Variations
description: AT the end of Beethoven's Diabelli Variations, following a series of 32 miniatures that is one of the triumphant achievements in the piano literature, the musical fabric dissolves to reveal, as if in heaven, a final, rapturous episode: Anton Diabelli's cocky little waltz not merely transformed, but transfigured into an idealized minuet. Then, as a further rite of purification, the minuet itself decomposes.

title: Market Place
description: THE prevailing view of Consolidated Edison is a company in recovery after a disastrous liquidity crunch several years ago that led to the omission of the dividend.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Chemical Bank raised its prime lending rate to 11 percent from 11 percent in a move expected to spread through the banking community shortly. Bankers again predicted that the basic rate would eventually climb to about 13 percent, well above the previous record of 12 percent reached in 1974. [Page D1.]

title: Furniture as Art: To See and to Sit On
description: WHEN is a chair not a chair? When it's a feathercovered sculpture by Alice Haber. Or a stool metamorphosed by Anneli Arms into a throne for a giant roach. Or Barbara Zucker's elongated Giraffe Chair, with a seat so high only a giraffe could perch on it.

title: VANCE AND GROMYKO REPORT SOME GAINS IN NEW ARMS TALKS
description: GENEVA, Dec. 21 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko said today that they had made progress in their first day of discussions toward resolving the issues holding up a new treaty on the limitation of strategic arms, but they also said that some difficult problems remained.

title: Market Place
description: NOW that the United Technologies Corporation is actually paying for shares tendered by Carrier Corporation stockholders under its plan to  acquire 49 percent of the company, it may seem that the first step of this hostile takeover is a fait accompli. However, the Justice Department appears likely to continue with its efforts to stymie the deal.

title: When Cunningham Broke 4 Minutes
description: Howard Schmertz, director of the Millrose Games, stopped by Glenn Cunningham's table in the Penn Plaza Club in Madison Square Garden. How many races did you win in the Garden? he asked.

title: City Rings In Holiday Music And Pageantry
description: BARE trees bud with tiny white lights. The Empire State Building glares green and red. A benevolent witch ushers forth Christmas in an exhibition on 43d Street. And in the Bronx, a pointsettia stands eight feet tall.

title: Film: California Lovers:Pretty Kid, Older Woman
description: "MOMENT BY MOMENT" is this year's California "problem" picture, that is, a movie in which people suffer for reasons that never seem very urgent in settings that, though not particular to California, are emblematic of what we think of as the California culture  elaborate beach houses, imported automobiles (public transportation is nowhere in sight), on throughways that are the main arteries of late 20th-century rootlessness.The film, which opens today at the Coronet, stars the usually incomparable Lily Tomlin as Trisha, a soon-to-be-divorced woman of 38, and John Travolta as Strip (which is his name as well as what he does), the none-too-bright drifter in his early 20's that she falls in love with.At the start Trisha is skeptical, being unable to imagine what a pretty kid like him would see in a rich, available, attractive, humorous older woman like her. After Strip's kid-magnetism gets her into bed, Trisha begins to fall in love with him and to see in him what she calls "great potential," though he can't form complete sentences with much ease. When he does form sentences, they are often funny, but they indicate no great potential for anything. "All my friends are undependable," says a gloomy Strip, "except Greg, and he's in jail."Trisha tells Strip he can be anything he wants, and Strip thinks fleetingly that he might like to be a veterinarian or paint billboards. Trisha is depressed, not by Strip's limited ambitions, but by the sudden realization that she has never wanted to be anything. Later she puts into a bottle a message reading simply "What a world," which makes one realize that things are tough all over California.It's very difficult to understand what Miss Tomlin and Jane Wagner, who wrote and directed the film, wanted to do in "Moment by Moment." As romantic drama it's pretty tepid. That the two stars look enough alike to be brother and sister is no help, and though Miss Wagner's camera comes in for some tactful close-ups of flesh in the love scenes, they are singularly unerotic. One has the impression that these two lovers would prefer to be doing something else.Then, too, it's impossible to tell what we're to make of Trisha. Mr. Travolta has an easier time of it. Strip is not a terrifically interesting character, but he's a recognizable one, and the actor clearly has a point of view about him.
