Strip, who dropped out of school when he was 14 and now has no time for education, may luck onto something into the future, but his chances will diminish with age. He has a certain integrity that, instead of giving him direction, actually prevents him from being the successful hustler he was meant to be.This is the character we see in the film, though Miss Wagner and Miss Tomlin apparently want us to believe he is some kind of misunderstood innocent. If we are to believe the character of Trisha, who is supposed to be intelligent, then we can't believe the character of Strip. If we see him for what he is, it's not possible to go along with Trisha, unless Miss Tomlin is sending her up, which I don't think is the case.Maybe "Moment by Moment" is meant to be a call for sexual liberation  in the way in which it reverses the usual roles of seducer and seduced. I'm not sure. The script doesn't seem to have been thought through to a finish, but there is a further problem with the picture.In her one-woman Broadway show, "Appearing Nitely," Miss Tomlin, with the help of Miss Wagner, created a series of remarkable characters, memorable misfits, men and women who were out of step with themselves, with other people or with the times. They were sketches, line drawings, fragments so artfully conceived that entire lives came and went in a matter of a few minutes of stage time.It was a curious and fascinating performance since Miss Tomlin herself seemed scarcely to exist. She was a medium to be shaped into somebody else. She's a marvelous monologist and can be a riveting actress, as she showed in "Nashville" and "The Late Show." In "Moment by Moment," in a full-length, comparatively uneccentric role, she is completely miscast. The no-nonsense native intelligence of the real-life performer obscures the character she is trying to play.Watching her in "Moment by Moment" is to see an actress in the process of preparing a role, while she's still working on its psychological foundation. It's not an uninteresting performance, but it's cold, without shape yet, and it characterizes the movie that contains it.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: I'm a lawyer. I like to take on difficult cases, John M. Doer once said. During the course of his career, he has been Assistant United States Attorney General in charge of the civil rights division, president of the New York City Board of Education, director of the BedfordStuyvesant Development and Services Corporation and special counsel to the House Judiciary Committee during its Nixon impeachment investigtion. Thus, he has handled any number of difficult cases, inside and outside of a courtroom.

title: Prisoner Led Rare Life of Crime
description: Federal authorities have called him a James Bond character. A biographer says he is a brigand from another era. But the police call him a cool, cynical con man who has robbed banks, hijacked planes, pulled jewel thefts, smuggled guns to Cuba, lived under aliases too numerous to count and befuddled batteries of psychiatrists.

title: Cleveland's Crisis a Decade in Making.
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 21  It ballooned into a nightmare almost overnight. But the fiscal crisis in which this industrial city is locked  one that pushed it into fiscal default last week and threatens to force it into bankruptcy by spring  has been a decade or more in the making.

title: Economic Scene
description: STATELY, cashplump International Business Machines jollied up Wall Street at least for while this week with its decision to split its expensive stock 4 for 1.

title: Brokers Guilty In Tax Fraud
description: Two brokers were convicted in Manhattan yesterday on Federal charges of conspiracy to defraud the Government by creating $27 million in fraudulent tax losses from 1974 to 1976. The fraud involved rigged trading of commodities and manipulation of prices on the crude oil futures market of the New York Cotton Exchange.

title: The Nights Peking Let a New Flower Bloom
description: MADISON, Wis.I was not at Peking's Democratic Wall that first night in a bitterly cold late November. Thousands upon thousands of people had been gathering daily to read wall posters. Then, spontaneously, one evening some began to discuss China's political future. Hundreds circled around to listen to and join in a discussion that previously could only occur in the secure privacy of one's home. The evening ended with the singing of The Internationale and the selection of a small group to prepare the next evening's meeting.

title: Market, Greece Set Entry Rules
description: PARIS, Dec. 21  Greece completed the details of its entry into the European EConomic Community today. agreeing on terms for full membership with the nine present member states in an accord that has farreEiching economic and political implications for Western Europe.

title: Step by Carter In 1956 Is Cited In a Racial Case
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 21  A resolution offered by Jimmy Carter while he was a member of his county school board in 1956 is being used by the American Civil Liberties Union as part of its effort to bolster an argument that there has been a historical pattern of racial discrimination by public officials in the county.

title: Dance: Limn Troupe
description: THE Jos Limn Dance Cornpany remains worth arguing about. Wednesday evening's program at the City Center contained works exemplifying two radically different choreographic theories.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Mazurkas, Chopin; On Christ's Nativity, Tans'ur; The Nightingale, Aliabiev; . Hungarian Dance in F minor, Kreisler(after Brahms); 16thCentury Italian Music; Tarantellas, Various Composers.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Inquiry Into Ryan's Death Falters
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 21 A preliminary inquiry into the slaying of Representative Leo J. Ryan and four other Americans made little headway today as prosecution efforts to prove a conspiracy faltered. Only two witnesses were heard and the prosecution initially failed to show up.

title: Music: Chamber Favorites
description: CHAMBER Music at the Y, popular sixconcert subscription series at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A., has followed a frankly traditional course since its inception four seasons ago. Rather than aiming for novelty, Jaime Laredo, the artistic director, is chiefly interested in presenting the masterpieces of chamber literature. However familiar the music, Mr. Laredo believes, superior concert performances remain indispensable.

title: Board of Estimate Votes Against the Westway Plan
description: After a session punctuated by catcalls, hisses, cheers and boos, the city's Board of Estimate approved a resolution yesterday evening condemning the Westway highway project.

title: Money
description: THURSDAY, DEC. 21, 1978

title: Gerry Mulligan, BigBand Fan and Sometime Leader, Is Trying It Again
description: If Gerry Mulligan had grown up in the 19301 instead of the late 30's and early 40's (he wound DD in 1927), he does not think he would be a thusician today.

title: New KucinichCouncil Conflicts Peril a Plan to Overcome Default
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 21New conflicts between Mayor Dennis J. Kucinich and the City Council leadership devel5ped today, threatening the city's plans to pull itself out of default.

title: RapeCase Wife Quoted About Becoming Rich
description: SALEM, Ore., Dec. 21  Greta .Rideout, whose husband is on trial here for raping and beating her, boasted to her neighbors shortly after her husband was arrested that she was going to become rich and famous, three witnesses testified today.

title: At the Movies
description: AMONG the more than 400 name credits (in. cluding 91 speaking roles) for Superman, which zoom endlessly past audiences, are those of Mario Puzo, David Newman, Leslie Newman and Robert Benton, to whom the screenplay is attributed. The Newmans, who are husband and wife, provided an analysis of the contributions made by, each over luncheon the other day, and in the process gave an instructive look at the way films are put together. They alao created a kind of double image of Superman  as it exists on hundreds of screens around the country and as it might have been if other decisions had been made.

title: Braniff Planning Dallas Concorde
description: Braniff International Airways announced yesterday that it would begin on Jan. 12 regularly scheduled flights of the controversial Concorde into the DallasFort Worth airport. The service between Dallas, London and Paris via Washington will be a cooperative venture with Air France and British Airways.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a transcription error, State Supreme Court, Justice Donald Zimmerman was misquoted yesterday in an article about the denial of a request that The Times be restrained from publishing remaining articles on the drug war in the South Bronx. What he said was, You don't mess with press in advance of trial unless you are in extremis.

title: Soviet Probe Radios Information From Venus Surface for 2 Hours
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 21 (AP)  A Soviet spacecraft landed on Venus today and radioed back nearly two hours of information on the searing atmosphere of the planet nearest the Earth before going silent in the intense heat, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported.

title: Executive Reflects Optimism on Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 21  Dead silence reigned in Taipei's big municipal stadium, save for the thud, thud, thud of feet hitting the ground as Y C. Wang and his aides circled the track in almost complete darkness.

title: Soviet, Citing Its Note to Carter, Indicates Concern on China Ties
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 21  The Soviet Union, in an unusual step, made public today details of Tuesday's personal message from Leonid I. Brezhnev to President Carter in an apparent effort to show that the Soviet leader did have questions about the new ChineseAmerican relationship and would watch it closely.

title: Broadway
description: Bojangles! to bring the old soft shoe to New York stage.

title: Felix Meier's Recipe for Profits
description: Many prominent chefs are known for their expertise in preparing turnovers. But Felix Meier, a Swissborn chef, has a flare for turnabouts. For as president of the restaurant division of Restaurant Associates Industries  which encompasses the company's tablecloth restaurants, mostly in New York  the 53yearold culinarian has concocted a recipe that has helped to pull the company out of the red over the last two years.

title: Pop Music: Steve Forbert
description: PEOPLE who like to be in at the beginning of things must have enjoyed themselves at the Other End Wednesday night, when Steve Forbert played the first two sets of a twonight run. Not that Mr. Forbert is entirely unknown here. But he has just put out his first record, which seems to be doing very nicely. And never before was his obvious potential for stardom more apparent.

title: TV Weekend 'Tis the Season For Documentaries
description: THIS being the holiday season, a period when viewing levels are normally low, the television schedule grows unusually generous to news documentaries, which rarely attract blockbuster audiences anyway.

title: S.I. Ferryboat Captain In Battery Park Crash Given 40 Days Ashore
description: A board of inquiry into the crash of a Staten Island ferryboat into the Battery Park seawall on Nov. 7 has recommended that the boat's captain be assigned to shore duty for 40 working days from the date of the accident and his assistant for 35 days. The board also recommended that both be reprimanded.

title: Devine Gets No. 2 Police Job
description: Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire said yesterday that he had selected William J. Devine, the city's highestranking uniformed police officer, to be the new first deputy commissioner.

title: City's Takeovers On Foreclosures Gaining Rapidly
description: The number of occupied apartment buildings falling under city ownership because of landlord abandonment or tax defaults, already up sharply, is expected to triple over the next 18 months, city officials say.

title: Two Messages of Joy for Neediest
description: Two letters, one from Bridgeport, Conn., the other from West 48th Street here in New York, carried the same message yesterday to the 67th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Screen: Simon's 'Suite' Comes Back Home:Things Go Wrong
description: NEIL SIMON deals in the kind of lethal wisecracks  putdowns with dum-dum bullets for centers  that often have a way of destroying the wrong people. In the mouths of unknowing characters they are dangerous weapons, instruments for the sort of accidental suicides that demolish everything in the neighborhood. His wisecracks define a world of mighty desperation in which every confrontation, be it with a lover, a child, a husband, a friend or a taxi driver, becomes a last chance for survival.When he writes a work in which this desperation is built into the situations Mr. Simon can be both immensely funny and surprisingly moving. Such were "The Heartbreak Kid" and "The Sunshine Boys" and such is his new "California Suite," which opens today at the National and Loews Tower East and is the most agreeably realized Simon film in years.The screenplay was adapted by Mr. Simon from his four short plays, all set in the Beverly Hills Hotel in Beverly Hills, which were done on Broadway under the collective title of "California Suite" with the same actors tripling in several roles. For the movie Mr. Simon has intercut the stories, now played by eight stars, so that the film simulates the drive and cohesion of a single, seamless comedy.Despite its title, "California Suite" is anything but a California movie. It's about as far as you can get from the Pacific Ocean if your heart is in New York. Though the locale is California, the sensibility is of New York  rude, fast-paced, uproariously blunt and so insistently contemporary it could have been written tomorrow and (who knows?) out of date the day after.Here is Mr. Simon in top form, under the direction of Herbert Ross, one of the few directors (in addition to Elaine May) who can cope with the particular demands of material that simultaneously means to be touching and so non-stop clever one sometimes wants to gag him. It all works in "California Suite," not only because the material is superior Simon, but also because the writer and the director have assembled a dream cast.Chief among these are Maggie Smith, who has her best screen role since "The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie," and Michael Caine, who is seldom acknowledged as the fine actor he is, playing a celebrated English actress and her antique-dealer husband who come to Hollywood for the Oscar ceremony. After having wrestled so long with movie material that offered no real contest, Miss Smith now has a part that makes use of her unique gift for comedy that has its origins in things far from pleasant.In the film's early scenes she is pricelessly funny, getting ready for her big night in a magnificent display of hope, panic and despair, knowing that she doesn't have a snowball's chance of winning the Oscar, but listening eagerly to even the dimmest person who thinks she has. When, without melodramatic effort, the tale becomes an examination of a marriage that has slipped into compromised intimacy, she and Mr. Caine create characters of unexpected depth and compassion.Jane Fonda and Alan Alda must deliver quintessential Simon dialogue, the sort that can undercut a comic situation of less importance than the one Mr. Simon has provided here. They are a long-divorced couple  he a successful Hollywood writer, she a confirmed New York career woman  who meet in Beverly Hills to discuss the future of their daughter, who has run away from her mother. Miss Fonda is superlative as the glib, semi-intellectual New Yorker whose only way of dealing with desperation is through sarcasm. Mr. Alda, playing it more or less straight, nicely complements her as the sort of man who doesn't have to be told when he's making a fool of himself. With him, that has been a conscious decision.Walter Matthau and Elaine May play the principals in Mr. Simon's boisterous West Coast version of bedroom farce. He is an aging middle-class businessman, very much the conservative husband, whose one night alone in Los Angeles almost destroys his marriage after his brother presents him with the present of a prepaid hooker. Watching Mr. Matthau, as his wife awaits on the other side of the door, trying to pull pantyhose onto the rubbery form of a very drunk hooker, is one of the more cheerful moments of the entire movie season.Richard Pryor and Bill Cosby appear as a pair of Chicago doctors who, with their wives, are sharing a vacation of the sort Mr. Simon cherishes. Everything goes wrong, including friendships. This sequence is the film's most frantic and, perhaps because of that, it runs out of breath before the end, but then no comedy can be completely perfect."California Suite," which has been rated PG ("parental guidance suggested"), contains some mildly racy language and situations.

title: Suburban Sites Offer Taste of Christmas Past
description: WHEN Santa flies over the metropolitan area, his beholding. pattern Will have him peering down into the suburbs, where, if he is as keeneyed as ever, he will behold visions of Christmases past in splitlevel, even gingerbread environs packaged in green or, if nature wills it, white.

title: Bridgeport AT A GLANCE
description: A 17.5squaremile city of rolling hills at the mouth of the Pequonnock River on Long Island Sound. 56 miles east of New York.

title: Erie Lackawanna Bids U.S. Approve Plan to Settle $470 Million in Claims
description: The trustees of the bankrupt Erie Lackawanna Railway Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Norfolk & Western Railway, filed a proposed reorganization plan yesterday with the United States District Court in Cleveland.

title: World News Briefs
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 21  Argentina, in a diplomatic note, accused Chile today of intransigence and inflexibility, and it rejected a Chilean proposal that their dispute over three islands at the entrance to the Beagle Channel be submitted to Pope John Paul II for mediation.

title: Where They Deal With Psychiatric Emergencies All Night Long
description: In the sleepless small hours of the morning, problems can seem gigantic, insurmountable. In the daylight that follows, the anguish may ease, but that fact doesn't make the night more bearable.

title: Books of The Times
description: E.K. FORSTER, A LIFE. By P. N. Furbank. In one binding: Volume 1, The Growth of the Novelist,18791914; 260 pages; Illustrated; and Volume 2, Polycrates Ring, 19141970; 359 pages; Illustrated. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95.

title: Modem Begins Screening the Stormy Years of RKO
description: For the next five months, the Museum of Modern Art will be doling out 137 of the more than 700 films made by RKO between the time the studio was pasted together by David Sarnoff and Joseph P. Kennedy in 1928 and the day it was sold to Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz in 1958. The show began last night, and on today's bill is Rio Rita (1929) at 2:30.

title: China to Build a Hall in Yemen
description: SANA, Yemen, Dec. 21 (Reuters) China will extend technical aid to Yemen to build a $20 million international conference hall just outside Sane, under an agreement approved by the Council of Ministers yesterday. China has built several, highways in the country as well as a textile mill.

title: New Troupe, Old Innocent Merriment.
description: What makes the operettas of Gilbert and Sullivan forever popular? Norman Meadmore, founderdirector of the London Savoyards, believes that they are the only thing in the theater today to which you can take your aunt or grandmother or young daughter without being embarrassed. To use Sir William Schwenk Gilbert's own words, they are a source of innocent merriment! Gilbert's librettos and lyrics are funny, witty, satirical. No matter how dated the source of the satire  most of the operettas are a century old  their humor retains its freshness. The intricate rhymes are a delight, and they are inseparable from the wonderfully apt music of Sir Arthur Sullivan.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UPI)  A Federal jury, breaking a deadlock after 10 hours of deliberations, today found Robert L. Oswald innocent of charges he peddled his influence as an officer of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

title: Taiwan to Press for Advanced U.S. Jets and Missiles
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 21  Prime Minister Sun Yuirsuan said today that Taiwan was seeking to buy highperformance American fighter planes that were denied to it earlier this year and the defensive Harpoon missile system and others as part of a relatively long shopping list'.

title: Minimum Reform for Minimum Wages
description: Increases in the minimum wage, scheduled for this January and next, will . price thousands of unskilled workers out of jobs and send inflationary ripples through the labor market. It is too late to stop the first increase, from $2.65 to $2.90. But White House economists hope that the 1980 jump to $3.10 can be postponed, or at least that some exemption can be granted for teenage workers.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, DEC. 21, 1978

title: Jean Stapleton Is Leaving All in the Family
description: ONE of the bestknown families in America may be breaking up. A year after Gloria and Mike Stivic elected to leave Archie Bunker's bluecollar nest, Archie's wife, Edith, has decided to follow their example. As a result, All In the Family, one of the most popular shows on television since 1971, is likely to drop out of the CBS schedule next fall.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 6:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY. THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. title: Vehicle Output For '78 a Record
description: DETROIT, Dec. 21 (AP) United States manufacturers of motor vehicles will have built a record 12.9 million cars and trucks when production lines shut down Saturday. That output would be 1.4 percent ahead of the 12.7 million cars and trucks built in 1977, Ward's Automotive Reports, a trade publication, reported today. Record output had been predicted for weeks.

title: Movies: 'Force 10':Long Delayed Sequel
description: "FORCE 10 From Navarone" must be one of the longest-delayed sequels in film history, coming, as it does, 17 years after "The Guns of Navarone." The original was a World War II adventure yarn about British saboteurs assigned to destroy an "impregnable" German position.A fast-moving, simple-minded script by Carl Foreman, who also produced, and the performances of Gregory Peck, David Niven and Anthony Quinn, brought it considerable box-office success.Mr. Foreman has also written what is called in the credits the "screen story" for "Force 10," with a screenplay by Robin Chapman.As was the original, it is based on a novel by Alistair Maclean, and continues the adventures of two members of the same suicide squad, here played by Robert Shaw, who died soon after the completion of the film, and Edward Fox, who played the title role in "The Day of the Jackal."From the Aegean they have moved to the Balkans, where they are seconded to an American Ranger unit, led by Harrison Ford, of "Star Wars," that has been ordered either to destroy a bridge that the Wehrmacht can't do without or not to bother coming back.There the resemblance between the two films ends. The plot of "Force 10" is banally improbable. Guy Hamilton's direction is sluggish and the camera work, by Chris Challis, makes the least of the picturesque locations in the mountains of Montenegro.There is, moreover, an unmistakable air of haste and cost-cutting that suggests that most of the production budget went to pay the high-priced stars.Featured in the cast are Barbara Bach, a beauty miscast as a partisan fighter, Franco Nero, also miscast, as another of the locals, and Carl Weathers as the obligatory black member of the squad."Force 10," in passing, considerably romanticizes the activities of the partisans, the irregular troops commanded by Marshal Tito, who has been the freely chosen president of Yugoslavia for 32 years now, and turns the Chetniks, who were linked to the Yugoslavian royalist government in exile in London, into eager Nazi collaborators.This film has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), possibly because of several violent episodes.

title: Price Warning By OPEC Aide
description: KUWAIT, Dec. 21 (AP)  The newly elected Secretary General of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries warned today that the group might consider a further increase in the price of oil before June if the United States dollar continued to fall and international inflation continued to rise.

title: Ferry Sinks Off Canary Islands
description: CORRALEJO, Canary Islands, Dec. 21 (AP)  A ferry with 32 persons aboard sank in heavy seas during the night after breaking apart on the rocks off Fuerteventura, one of the Canary Islands, and 12 persons were drowned or are missing, the Spanish Navy said today. The ferry was carrying 30 German passengers and two Spanish crewmen.

title: ROSE MARIE REID, 66; SWIMSUIT DESIGNER
description: Rose Marie Reid, the bathing suit designer, died Monday at her home in Provo, Utah. of complications after surgery. She was 66 years old.

title: Albert Bellas Weds Kay Mazzo, Dancer
description: Ray Mazzo, a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet, was married in Glenview, Ill., yesterday to Albert Constantine Bellas, an executive vice president and a member of the management committee of Loeb Rhoades, Hornblower & Company in New York. The Rev. George Scoulos performed the ceremony in the Greek Orthodox Church of SS. Peter and Paul.

title: Dictaphone Approves Pitney Deal
description: The Dictaphone Corporation announced early yesterday that its board of directors had approved the offer by PitneyBowes Inc. to acquire Dictaphone. The transaction, involving cash and securities, is valued at about $131 million.

title: Asset Rule Shift Sought
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board, the group that sets the standards by which companies report their financial results, yesterday proposed a tequirement that companies capitalize interest costs as part of the cost of acquiring certain kinds of assets.

title: Art People
description: I'M trying to bring back a little oldworld stuffiness to museums again  grandeur, culture, class, Red Grooms was saying the other day. They're so pop these days you can't get in to see anything.

title: Jo Jo Starbuck Skates Between Marriage and Career
description: Jo Jo Starbuck is best known in Pittsburgh as the wife of Terry Bradshaw, quarterback of the revered Pittsburgh Steelers. But in New York these days she's the razzledazzle ice skater with the smile that won't quit, the one who signs her autograph by drawing a fivepointed star and a dollar sign (Starbuck., get it?), the one who almost steals John Curry's Ice Dancing show from John Curry himself.

title: Trainer Martin Banned 25 Days
description: Frank (Pancho) Martin, the leading trainer of thoroughbreds in New York, has accepted a reduced 25day suspension for running a horse with an illegal medication in its system.

title: Associated Dry Goods Shifting Its Retail Appeal
description: The Associated Dry Goods Corporation, one of America's oldest and once one of its most profitable departmentstore chains, is seeking to shift some of its traditional carriagetrade appeal toward attracting the younger and more contemvoraryminded customer.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
description: REMEMBER THE NEEDIEST!

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Girl in Spanking Case to Go Home
description: SYRACUSE, Dec. 21  A childcustody dispute regarded by some people here as a churchstate controversy and by others as a simple case of child neglect ended yesterday with a court order returning 15yearold Shirley Roy to the custody of her parents, the Rev. and Mrs. James Roy.

title: Tired Nations and the United Nations
description: The mindmanagers are at it again over at the United Nations, this time without even pretending (as in UNESCO last month) that their sanction of censorship is balanced by a concern for freedom of speech and press. Denunciations of the creeping totalitarianism at the world organization are becoming almost tedious as the documents in which the totalitarian spirit is now regularly enshrined. We return to the subject only to make two observations.

title: 20,000 Seized in India as Protests Demand Release of Mrs. Gandhi
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 21Supporters of former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi continued to stage violent demonstrations in several parts of India today, demanding that she be released from prison.

title: The War on 138th Street
description: The assistant district attorney was still in couit, so the old woman took a seat on the wooden bench outside his office. For more than half an hour she waited, hardly Moving, sitting very erect in a corner at one end of the long bench. She did not Mind the wait and, in fact, would say later that she wad not even aware of the delay. Her thoughts centered on a mother's most naturalconcern  the lives of her chilflren.

title: Jeannette McElvenny Is Wed to A. C. Sanger
description: Jeannette Watson McElvenny, cofounder and coowner of Books & Company, a Madison Avenue bookstore, was married yesterday to Alexander Campbell Sanger, a lawyer with the firm of White & Case. Civil Court Judge Charles S. Whitman Jr. performed the ceremony at the New York apartment of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Watson Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and North Haven, Me., parents of the bride.

title: Dance: Balinese Enchantments at Theater Lab
description: Alittle girl, 10 years old and wearing a crown of flowers with a costume of beautiful gold appliqu silk, shoots out toward the audience. Her knees are bent closely together in a narrow skirt, her elbows are held out, her fingers are curved and splayed, her wideeyed expression is broken by a sharp turn of the head. She carries incense in a basket, from which she eventually flings a small shower of flower petals.

title: New Stage Panel Plans O'Neill Celebrations
description: A committee of professional theater people and noted admirers of the plays of Eugene O'Neill has been formed to mount annual observances in his honor, culminating in 1988 in nationwide celebrations of the hundredth anniversary of his birth. on Oct. 16.

title: Business and the Law
description: FEW subjects have captured the fancy of the corporate bar as thoroughly as the corporate governance debate, and like most legal concepts, the phrase is opaque enough to lend itself to several different interpretations.

title: 0.E.C.D. Pessimistic On Inflation
description: PARIS, Dec. 21  President Carter's antiinflationary policies will not lead to any reduction in the American inflation rate next year, according to the latest forecasts by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. In fact, with the cost of oil imports going up, prices are likely to rise a shade faster than they did in 1978.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW, Dec.23

title: Five Sketches Released in Holdup on S.I.
description: The police released sketches yesterday of five of the six suspects in the robbery Tuesday in which more than S2 million was taken from a Wells Fargo armored car on Staten Island.

title: A New Drug Is Reported to Help Failing Heart Pump More Blood
description: Doctois have discovered a new drug that they say helps a failing heart beat more forcefully and that someday may be added to digitalis treatment for congestive heart failure, one of the most common afflictions throughout the world.

title: Art: If You Can't Get Tickets to Tut...
description: IF you don't have tickets for nitankhamun, and it irks you, there are several things that you can do. You can leave town, for instance. You cah go to Cairo. This is the right season for Egypt, and you will see much more of the treasures of Tutankhamun than has ever been seen in the West

title: Guyana Cost to U.S. $3.5 Million
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP)  It has cost the Defense Department $3.5 million to $4 million to conduct airlift and other operations in the Guyana cult tragedy in which more than 900 followers,ot the People's Temple died; a report said today.

title: High U.S. Aides to Go To Taiwan to Discuss New, Unofficial Links
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21  The White House announced today that Deputy Sec retary of State Warren M. Christopher would lead a highlevel mission to Taipei next week to discuss a framework for unofficial relations between the United States and Taiwan after Jan. 1.

title: President May Be Facing Surgery After NewAttack of Hemorrhoids
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21  President Cartet canceled his appointments today because of an aggravated attack of hemorrhoids, and the White House press office said this evening that he might undergo surgery this week.

title: MESSAGE FROM POPE CENSORED IN POLAND
description: WARSAW. Dec. 21 (AP)  The Communist authorities censored Pope John Paul's Christmas message to his home diocese of Cracow, cutting out all references to Poland's patron, St. Stanislaus, a newspaper editor said today. A separate papal message to the entire nation was printed in full by the Cracow Catholic weekly.

title: Threat From Oil Spill Grows in Puerto Rico
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Dec. 21 (AP)  A barge oil spit, already affecting beaches along Puerto Rico's Northeast coast, now threatens another tourist area on the island, a Coat Guard spokesman said today.

title: Policies Defended At Women's Bank
description: Lynn D. Salvagei president of the First Women's Bank of New York, told a turbulent initial meeting yesterday that the financially troubled bank was, in the process of turning around and defended the current policies that she said were responsible for, the bank's making its first profit since it opened its doors in 1975.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 Even to write about it seems to contradict the point. But these continuing public arguments and recriminations between officials in Washington and Jerusalem are obviously not helping the cause of peace in the Middle East.

title: Short Interest Increases to 42.6 Million Shares
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose 3.2 million shares to 42.6 million shares in the month ended Dec. 15. The short interest for the yearearlier level totaled 35.3 million shares.

title: After Bakke: Jobs Decision
description: The case that Brian F. Weber has brought against his employer, Kaiser Aluminum, and his union, the United Steelworkers, has led some people, since the case was accepted for review by the Supreme Court, to begin calling Mr. Weber the bluecollar Bakke. That is because Mr.

title: Art: Warhol's Gang Pops Back Again
description: JACKIE and Liz, Marilyn and Mao: they are all riding again, along with Campbell's Soup and the electric chair. In other words, some of the images chosen by Andy Warhol during the period 1960 to 1973 are being paraded in their original form at the Blum Heimann Gallery (13 East 75th Street). Numbering 12 canvasses in all, the show is an invitation to reflect, yet again, on the confusion which, begun by Duchamp, was brought to a boiling point by one of his brightest descendants.

title: Gable May Change Name
description: Gable Industries said yesterday that its shareholders would vote Dec. 27 on a proposal to change the corporate name to the Hajoca Corporation, which is the name of the largest of three Gable operating units.

title: OTB Simulcast Bid Hits Snag
description: Offtrack betting's proposed marriage to live television hit a major snag yesterday when the State Racing and Wagering Board decided to withhold its blessings at this time.

title: San Diego Gets AirTraffic Plans
description: The Federal Aviation Administration yesterday acknowledged several discrepancies in control of the jet airliner and the small private plane involved in the Sept. 25 midair collision in San Diego and announced an 11point program to prevent a similar accident there.

title: Books: The Bible, as Told to Clausewitz
description: BATTLES OF THE BIBLE. A Modern Military Evaluation of the Old Testament. By Chaim Herzog and Mordechai Gichon. 247 pages. Random House. $17.95.

title: Basque Militant, Linked to Killing Of Madrid Leader, Slain in France
description: ANGLET, France, Dec. 21 (UPI)  A bomb killed the Basque guerrilla leader Jos Mara Benaran Ordenana today, five years and a day after he allegedly detonated the explosion that took the life of Prime Minister Luis Carrero Blanco of Spain.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The growth of the nation's basic money supply slowed for the third consecutive week, decelerating to an annual rate of 6.7 percent  the lowest since early April.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21 (AP)Two quarterbacks, Chuck Fusina of Penn State and Terry Bradshaw of the Pittsburgh Steelers, have been selected by the Maxwell Football Club as the nation's outstanding college and professional players for 1978, the club announced today. They will receive the awards at the club's banquet Jan. 31.

title: Laura Sconocchia Is Bride of Saul Steinberg
description: Saul P. Steinberg, chairman and president of the Reliance Group Inc., and Laura Bordoni Sconocchia were married Wednesday. Rabbi Irving Hiat performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue apartment the couple will occupy.

title: Music: Vespers of 1610
description: ONE of the most beautiful musical works. or collections of works, surviving from the Baroque era is Monteverdi's Vespers of 1610, which is also known as Vespers of the Blessed Virgin. Here, in a profusion of arias, duets, trios and choral pieces, lyric and contrapuntal marvels abound, some wrapped in instrumental compositions of striking personality and color.

title: ExAide Links Threats and Violence to Jones Adviser
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21  Terri Buford, until two months ago a top aide to the Rev. Jim Jones, told reporters today that every violent, illegal or reprehensible act that he or members of his Peoples Temple undertook had been initiated or approved by Timothy O. Stoen. Mr. Stoen, once a prosecutor here, was the chief legal adviser to Mr. Jones before resigning from the sect two years ago.

title: Iran Parliament to Adjourn Early
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 21 (Reuters) A new threat to the Shah's military Government was headed off today by a surprise move to adjourn Parliament and delay a censure debate.

title: Iran Unrest a. Nightmare For Many U.S Concerns
description: The political crisis in Iran has turned into an economic nightmare for many of the 300 American, companies operating there. The upheaval has already meant the loss of billions of dollars in military orders,, property. damage and delayed payments. and has caused worries about loans made by American banks.

title: Willard Mullin Dies; Cartoonist Created Bums
description: Willard Mullin, the sports cartoonist who created the Brooklyn Bum  the quintessence of the Brooklyn Dodger baseball fan  died of cancer yesterday at the age of 76 in Corpus Christi, Tex.

title: Knotty Brazilian Political Issue
description: BRASILIA, Dec 21 (Reuters) Several Brazilian Indians have been refused an audience with President Ernesto Geisel because they were not wearing ties. One of their leaders told a television interviewer that they would insist that any governmental official visiting an Indian village wear a feathered headdress and body paint.

title: An Overview of Japanese Architecture
description: There has always been a certain curious relationship between Japanese architects and their American counterparts. It is not quite a case of direct influences, although that has existed, even in the work of architects as original as Frank Lloyd Wright, who often used elements of classical Japanese architecture, and in the work of the Japanese themselves, who in more recent times have tended to pick up aspects of contemporary Western architecture. But what is more interesting than the literal use of one other's forms is an attitude which might be described as a mix of wariness and, admiration that the two architectural communities seem to have for one other.

title: Adult, 27 Pupils Killed in Wreck Of Spanish Bus
description: SALAMANCA, Spain, Dec. 21 (AP)  A school bus and a locomotive that was making test runs collided at a railroad crossing in morning fog today, killing 27 children and an adult and injuring 36, according to railroad authorities.

title: News Summary
description: Some progress in arms talks was reported in Geneva by, Secretary of State Vance and Foreign Minister Gromyko. They said that they had made gains toward resolving the issues holding up an accord to limit strategic weapons, but that some hard problems remained. After five hours of meetings, American officials insisted it was premature to say whether the latest negotiations would succeed. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: The Region
description: WEST ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. (AP) At least 12 persons were injured, one apparently seriously, when a van and a bus carrying about 40 elderly shoppers collided yesterday on U.S. Route 40 about four miles west of Atlantic City. The injured were taken to the Atlantic City. Medical Center.

title: Movies: 2 Soviet Films Offer Treat for the Spirit:Symbolic Struggle
description: BLACK shapes in an infinity of snow and wind, a knot of men and women stumble from hill to hill, children piled onto weary backs, pots and pans clanking in the vast silence. Two men leave to find food for their friends, on the run from "the Jerries" in wartime Russia. Captured by venal Nazi sympathizers, the two are pushed to psychological limits almost beyond endurance. One holds back his useless scraps of information, but the other betrays his friend and the hapless peasants they have unknowingly incriminated. It is a simple and familiar story that is told by "The Ascent," a 1977 Russian film that opens today at the Thalia in a double bill with "The White Ship," another prize-winning Russian film here receiving its New York premiere.But, though familiar, this is a fable re-created with an unabashed sense of grandeur as well as deeply touching humanity. Based on a story by Vasil Bykov and directed by Larisa Shepitko, "The Ascent" pits the idealism of the young schoolteacher, Sotnikov, against the driving will to live of his fellow soldier, Rybak. Rybak is a bear of a man who risks his life repeatedly to protect Sotnikov, but he cannot risk it for the good of so vague an entity as his country. It is he who escorts Sotnikov to the gallows. Sniveling, he lags behind his newfound traitor friends, botching a suicide attempt and terrified by the open gate that beckons so ironically at the end. And yet Rybak is never a villain. He is seen with surprising compassion throughout.Both men have the force and simplicity of symbols. We begin to know them in a deeper sense through their exchanges with the richly nuanced characters with whom they come in contact in an already vivid, shifting landscape scanned with a loving eye for detail. Vladimir Chukhnov's camera moves across stark snow, a remembered summer idyll, a peasant's cluttered shack, a harshly functional police torture roomone can almost smell the disinfectantand a village square peopled by peasants summoned to the hanging. The carnival atmosphere along the long climb to the gallows, where a band is playing, tells of the ordinariness of evil. Heroes do not die in heroic landscapes.The performances all have a searing luminosity, particularly those of Boris Plotnikov, as Sotnikov, and Vladimir Gostiukhin, as Rybak.It is the actors, too, who make "The White Ship" more than a lyrical little folktale. Nurgazi Sudygaliev, the child who plays a dreaming, naughty 7-year-old in this 1977 film, directed by Bolotbek Shamshiev and based on Chinghiz Aitmatov's rendering of Kirghiz legend, must have given the performance of a young lifetime here. He moves with mesmerizing lucidity and lack of artifice through this tale of a boy and his grandfather who nourish themselves on the myths of their people while their family claws its way to self-destruction.Photographed by Manasbek Musayev, "The White Ship" provides a tantalizing look at the rolling mountains and lush pastures of Soviet-Chinese border country, with occasional glimpses of a sterile modernistic city and mysterious rural shrines to the gods of the past. Like "The Ascent," it is a treat for the eyes and the spirit.

title: Up From the Great Depresion. Up. Up. Up. Up.
description: Fifty years after the Great Depression, we have the Great Inflation. Is there any connection between the two? I think so.

title: The Governor's Environment
description: If they do their job too well, get rid of them. That appears to be Governor Carey's prescription for handling environmental officials who try to enforce the law. The Governor is urging the White House to fire the regional administrator for the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, Eckardt C. Beck. And soon, aides say, he will ask the state's environmental commissioner, Peter A. A. Berle, to resign.

title: Screen: 'Body Snatchers' Return in All Their Creepy Glory
description: THERE's a little something extra in virtually every frame of "Invasion of the Body Snatchers," Philip Kaufman's dazzling remake of one of the cleverest of horror classics (and has there ever been a better title for a movie of this sort?). In a shot of someone's office, the camera catches all of one window but just a tiny, ominous corner of another. Two characters go for a friendly drive in a car with a broken windshield. There are too many reflections, outstanding odd details, rays of curiously colored light. The leaves are covered with gelatinous ooze. Whatever the trouble is, it's everywhere.The trouble, as any horror buff or late-show aficionado well knows, is pod people. They have arrived "from deep space," according to the ads for the new film (whatever that means, it has a lovely sound). At first they're only spores, but they mean to hatch everywhere  and every time a pod person appears, a human person vanishes. The pod people look just like their human counterparts, but they seldom blink and never smile. Their mission on Earth is never explained, but obviously they're up to no good. In Don Siegel's 1956 version, the story was swift and scary, set forth with a nightmarish economy. But Mr. Kaufman's film, which opens today at the Rivoli and other theaters, is after something different. Mr. Kaufman's direction is so showy, constantly heralding its own ingenuity, that the film operates as both a valentine and a rich, good-hearted joke. Mr. Kaufman entices his audience with a running what-will-he-think-up-next? technique, and each time you begin thinking he's tried every trick in the book, he writes another new chapter.In its keen, loving attention to beautiful minutiae, "Invasion of the Body Snatchers" recalls Nicolas Roeg's "Don't Look Now"; in its intimations of cool, constant peril, it suggests Alan Pakula's "The Parallax View." (And, like "The Parallax View," Mr. Kaufman's film climaxes on a split-level set, to emphasize a running element of duplicity.) But Mr. Kaufman adds to this an element of comic exaggeration: The creepiness he generates is so crazily ubiquitous it becomes funny.Accordingly, "Invasion of the Body Snatchers" isn't as frightening as it might be (even though special effects involving the pods and their hairy tendrils are brilliantly unsettling, as is the gruesome moment when one character tries to murder his own half-formed clone). And in the latter half of the film, when the story slows down considerably, Mr. Kaufman's inventiveness begins to seem a bit untethered. The screenplay, by W. D. Richter, remains bright and lively throughout, but the plot just isn't full enough to carry a feature film.The characters are vivid, and uniformly well-played, and their pre-pod lives are fairly well established. But an hour into the film, once the menace is identified, the few remaining humans begin fleeing for their lives, and after that it's just run, run, run. It hardly helps that they are essentially heading for a dead end, or that in this age of ubiquitous news reports there's not a glimmer of information about what's going on outside San Francisco, no hint as to whether they can possibly be saved. Nor is it useful when Danny Zeitlin's excellent score evolves into an electronic version of "Amazing Grace" very late in the film. This may amount to an epiphany of sorts, but it's no substitute for a dramatically effective ending.There's a new character in this version, a hip, successful psychiatrist who explains away the legitimate fears of others with a surfeit of self-help jargon. But Leonard Nimoy isn't right for the role; he isn't funny enough. And, besides, in a movie like this it's much too easy to figure out which side he's on.The problem with Mr. Nimoy's character goes deeper than casting, though. Because Mr. Kaufman generally shoots his extras matter-of-factly, with no clear indication of who's been taken over and who hasn't, the feelings of contemporary urban mistrust that the film plays upon need a focus. And Mr. Nimoy's character, like the doctors in "Rosemary's Baby," is meant to embody the essential unreliability of which one sometimes suspects one's fellows. If there were just one character in "Invasion of the Body Snatchers" who successfully conveyed that kind of menace, the entire film would take place in a more intimate arena, and cut closer to the bone.Playing a foursome of embattled good guys, Donald Sutherland, Brooke Adams, Jeff Goldblum and Veronica Cartwright are individually impressive and a very smooth ensemble, too. Miss Adams displays animation and intelligence that were far less apparent in "Days of Heaven." Mr. Sutherland is by turns personable and opaque, affecting in a way that he hasn't been since "Klute." Miss Cartwright stays on one's mind even during long intervals when she isn't on the screen. And Mr. Goldblum, who's had similar small roles in a number of movies, at last comes into his own. When it comes to playing nervous hot-heads with maniacal wit, he can't be beat."Invasion of the Body Snatchers," which is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains brief nudity and one quick but frightening bloody episode.

title: EGYPT SAYS ISRAELIS RENEGED ON ACCORD
description: CAIRO, Dec. 21  Senior Egyptian officials contended today that Israel, not Egypt, had caused the present deadlock over a peace treaty by reneging on understandings reached earlier by the two countries.

title: Kahn Offers Gasoline Tax Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21  Alfred E. Kahn, head of the President's antiinflation program, suggested today that taxes on unleaded gasoline be cut and taxes on leaded gasoline be increased as the Administration continued to reassess its oil policy.

title: Bridge:
description: One of the biggest scores ever recorded in a New York regional championship was posted here a week ago by Kitty Bethe and Karen McCallum, both of New York. They captured the women's pair title at the New York Hilton Hotel with a score of 435 match points, equivalent to almost 70 percent.

title: EARNINGS Beatrice Foods Sees 27th Peak Year
description: With record sales and earnings for the third quarter and the nine months ended Nov. 30, the Beatrice Foods Company expects to have its 27th consecutive peak year, Wallace N. Rasmussen, chairman, said yesterday.

title: COMMODITIES. Soybean Futures Gain In Dull Trading Session
description: In an otherwise dull trading session in most commodity markets, soybeans grabbed center stage, with enough good news to please traders.

title: Shirley Baig SucceedS Paganelli As the Manager of NYT Pictures
description: Shirley Baig will succeed Raphael Paganelli as manager of NYT Pictures, it was announced yesterday by Rob Roy Buckingham, editor and general manager of The New York Times News Service. Mr. Paganelli recently became deputy picture editor of The Times.

title: ExJudge Sentenced to 10 Years
description: ST. PAUL, Dec. 21 (AP)  Roger C. Hennings, a former judge, has been sentenced to up to 10 years in prison for swindling almost $500,000 from elderly clients, a church organization and two banks. He was sentenced yesterday in gamey County District Court on four counts of grand theft. Once a Municipal Court judge in surburban Maplewood, he formerly practiced law in St. Paul.

title: The Pop Life
description: IT'S time again for the 10bestrecords list, and not a moment'too soon for lastminute Christmas shopping. But caveat emptor: as usual, subjectivity is the criterion. This means that the list consists of only those records that fall in any way into the pop category and that have given me the most pleasure during 1978. For example, words, Steve Reich's disk, No. 3 below, might normally be considered a classical record, because Mr. Reich is a classical avantgardist of im peccable credentials. But it was released by a jazz label and aimed deliberately at the progressiverock market, so it qualifies. But Klaus Tennstedt's recording of Mahler's Symphony No. 1, which also gave me a lot of pleasure, doesn't qualify.

title: L.S.U. Victor; Iona Falls
description: Jim Valvano, the Iona coach, and Dale Brown, the Louisiana State University coach, are trying to build basketball empires. Valvano is in a small Westchester school and using local talent; Brown is at a large state university with national talent.

title: Empire Savings Gets a Chairman
description: The Empire Savings Bank, a New York mutual savings bank with 10 branches and assets of $715 million, has not had a chairman for a decade. But, effective Jan. 1, the bank will have one.

title: Colombian Writer Starts A HumanRights Group
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 21  The prominent Colombian novelist Gabriel Garcia Marquez has formed a humanrights organization to promote political amnesty and to investigate cases of people in Latin America who have disappeared.

title: Coalition of Newark Unions Votes A Stoppage if Layoffs Take Effect
description: NEWARK, Dec. 21  A coalition of municipal unions today voted to call a general work stoppage in the city unless Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson rescinded layoff notices to more than 1,400 municipal and school employees.

title: The Case of Officer Torsney
description: Thanksgiving evening, 1976: Robert Torsney, a white New York City police officer on duty in Brooklyn, fires a fatal shot into the head of a 15yearold black youth, Randolph Evans. Officer Torsney says the shooting was in selfdefense; he charges that the boy pulled a gun.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Domtar Inc., a leading Canadian maker of pulp and paper products and chemicals, said yesterday in Montreal that its directors have approved in principle a proposal to acquire MacMillan Bloedel Ltd., Canada's.largest forest products concern.

title: South Africa Curb Sought in U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 21 The General Assembly asked the Security Council today to meet to consider sanctions against South Africa for not agreeing to a United Nations plan for supervised elections in SouthWest Africa.

title: Basis of Iranian Conflict: A Mishandling of Modernization
description: QUM, Iran, Dec. 19 Iran is a country of two worlds that are locked in a battle for supremacy.

title: Theft of Gold by Meher Disclosed
description: About $200,000 in gold in the form of small, highly refined bars was smuggled out of the United States Assay Office in lower Manhattan earlier this year by a 31yearold melter who was arrested and, after pleading guilty, was sentenced to a year in prison, Federal authorities said yesterday.

title: Screvane Quits OTB Post in Dispute on Padding
description: Paul R. Screvane, the former president of the Offtrack Betting Corporation, resigned yesterday from his unsalaried post on the agency's board of directors following a public dispute with his successor over accusations of expenseaccount and overtime padding.

title: Extradition In Textron Sale Barred
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 A Federal District Court judge has ruled that the Securities and Exchange Commission cannot compel an Iranian sales agent, wanted in connection with the agency's investigation of payments by Textron Inc., to come to the United States and testify.

title: Notes on People
description: Unfortunately, said Lee Strasberg, any orphans of the night who show up on New Year's Eve outside his Central Park West home will have to find shelter elsewhere to welcome 1979. For 30 years, a Strasberg party has been a Dec. 31 ritual. Last year's drew 700 peonumber were theater and movie people such as Robert DeNiro, Ellen Burstyn, Michael Moriarty, Faye Dunaway and Elia Kazan. Why is this year different from other years? For one thing, Mr. Strasberg is weary from a busy schedule. For another, he'll be in California shooting a movie, ... And Justice for All, with Al Pacino. So, no party.

title: KOCH WARNS CARTER ABOUT NEED FOR AID
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21  With a warning that New York City does not have the resources to close its budget gap by itself, Mayor Koch formally called on President Carter today to fulfill the commitments that we feel were made to increase Federal aid this year and next.

title: BEGIN PUTS A LIMIT ON BRUSSELS TALKS
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 21  Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that a meeting in Brussels this weekend by representatives of the United States, Israel and Egypt would not be a resumption of the stalled peace talks, but would serve to determine how, when and where future negotiations could be held.

title: ALABAMA REQUESTS INFORMER'S RETURN
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 21  An Alabama prosecutor asked the Georgia authorities today to extradite Gary Thomas Rowe Jr. on the ground that new evidence would prove that Mr. Rowe murdered a civil rights worker while he was on the payroll of the Federal Bureau of Investigation as its chief soy inside the Ku Klux Klan.

title: Restaurants
description: ALTHOUGH one might not consider the Upper West Side a likely locale for a restaurant that is romantic, charming and elegant, that is exactly what is to be found on the corner of 119th Street and Morningside Drive, at the Terrace Restaurant atop the Columbia University residence, Butler Hall. A small, intimate bar and cocktail lounge and a candlelit flowery dining room both afford one of the more breathtaking views of the skyline, for though this penthouse restaurant is just 16 stories up, the building itself is set on a hill and has an overview of all the sparkling lights north to the George Washington Bridge, west to the Palisades and soutlfas far as the World Trade Center. Add to that polite and friendly service, a concerned proprietorchef, Dusan Bernie, some very pleasant live chamber music, and the very good food, and you have the makings of one of the pleasantest dining experiences in town.

title: World Gold
description: THURSDAY, DEC. 21, 1978

title: Jazz: The Rock Of Cosmology
description: THE concept of a jazzrock group as a section of jazz horns over a rock rhythm section that started 10 years ago with Blood, Sweat and Tears has worn thin since then. But one group that still has faith in the formula is Cosmology, a sixpiece ensemble that has been around for six years and that was at Seventh Avenue South, Seventh Avenue at Leroy Street, on Tuesday and Wednesday.

title: Bridgeport Is Struggling With Its Image and Reality
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 21  This struggling city's application for a $2.5 million Federal loan to help build a huge amusement parkrestaurantmarket complex has been turned down by the Department of Housing and Urban Development, and the Mayor responded today by characterizing the agency's position with a vulgarism and said the application would beresubmitted next month.

title: Ulster Guerrillas Kill 3 Soldiers in Ambush Near Ireland's Border
description: CROSSMAGLEN, Northern Ireland, Dec. 21 (Reuters)  Three British soldiers were shot to death today on the main street of this boider village. It was the worst attack against British forces in the province in nearly three years.

title: Toshiba to Halt Exports Of Color TV's to U.S.
description: TOKYO, Dec. 21(AP) The Toshiba Corporation, one of Japan's largest manufacturers of consumer electronics equipment, said today that it had halted exports of color television sets to the United States because of high import duties and the yen's rise against the dollar.

title: The City
description: The New York State Court of Appeals gave final approval yesterday to special laborcost rent increases of up to 7.5 percent being paid in about 40,000 rent controlled apartments in New York City.

title: Advertising
description: CABLE television, with only about a 20 percent penetration of American households, is already a viable national advertising medium without having a negative impact on broadcast TV, Young & Rubicam said yesterday.

title: Stage: Bayou Voodoo at N.E.C.
description: AIN'T you ever noticed anything strange about your family? asks one young woman of another, and then answers her own question, There ain't no men in your family.

title: Publishing: An Antediluvian Weighs the Future
description: AT an abstemious lunch the other day at the Algonquin of one martini, red snapper, salad, and creamless coffee, William Targ was in a melancholy mood. He had announced a little earlier that after 45 years in publishing, be was leaving Putnam where be had served since 1964 as a senior editor and editor in chief. His many years in the trade included stints at Macmillan and World, where be had started thetrade division.

title: Television
description: 6:00(4)Transportation

title: About Real Estate Zoning Appeals Raise Issue Of Jurisdictions of 2 Boards
description: Footnote connoisseurs who have an interest in the development process in New York City may find this one intriguing: In all probability, the board. would limit its appellate review to a very few matters involving major policy issues.

title: Locusts Threatening East Africa
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 21 (AP) Tens of millions of desert locusts that have matured in southern Ethiopia and Somalia now threaten to spread destruction there and across northern Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda and the Sudan, the East African Desert Locust Control Organization warned today. Swarms of locusts from the Arabian Peninsula moved into parts of Ethiopia and Somalia earlier this year.

title: Islanders Turn Back Blues, 51
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Dec. 21The Islanders keep winning, Glenn (Chico) Reach remains virtually unbeatable in goal, and the fans are, getting so bored they leave with half a period remaining.

title: Art: Two Collagists Tease the Eye
description: EVER since Max Ernst made the discovery nearly 60 years ago that old engravings from 19thcentury magazines and commercial catalogues could be effectively transformed through the medium of collage into mysterious symbols of the irrational, the way has been open for artists to employ every sort of printed pictorial matter  regardless how commonplace  for the creation of a private iconography.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Amstar Corporation, has elected Howard B. Wentz Jr. executive vice president and chief operating officer. George A. Chandler was elected vice president of the corporation and designated president of Amstar's Industrial Products Group.

title: Mime: Body Russian
description: MIME is traditionally the silent art. Not only is the artist mute, but a respectful pall of silence seems to hang over his audience. Simon Kudrov, however, is a mime with a difference. His performance on Wednesday at the Nat. Home Theater was greeted by chortles, helpless giggles, cries of Ol and even a little verbal audience participation.

title: Warren Olney 3d, at 76; ExAide for U.S. Courts
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21  Warren Olney 3d, founder of the Federal Judicial Center and a former director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts, died yesterday in Berkeley, Calif., after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

title: Chrysler Promised Discipline By Iacocca
description: DETROIT, Dec. 21 (UPI) After six weeks as president of the Chrysler Corporation, Lee A. Iacocca says the beleaguered No. 3 auto company is suffering from discipline problems, but he expects to turn it around with tough leadership.

title: Lafayette Radio Fears Default on Bank Loans
description: Under severe business pressures in recent years and after two recently abortive attempts to secure new financing, the Lafayette Radio and Electronics Corporation said yesterday that preliminary indkations Were that the company would not be. able to reduce its bank borroWings and would be in default under its credit agreement.

title: Pro Hockey's Violence Sends Police From Arena
description: WALKER, Mich., Dec. 21 (AP) The Walker police said today they would no longer patrol International Hockey League home games of the Grand Rapids Owls because the safety of the police was jeopardized by managementinspired rowdiness.

title: Ashe Loses, 62, 36, 63, To Stone in Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 21 (AP) Alan Stone of Australia, a parttime performer on the pro circuit, upset thirdseeded Arthur Ashe, 6.2, 36, 63, today and moved into the men's quarterfinals of the $175,000 New South Wales tennis tournament.

title: Skiing Limited In Most Areas
description: A threeinch snowfall in much of upper New England has given ski areas in that region muchneeded added cover as the holiday weekend approaches. However, skiing will be available on only limited terrain almost everywhere from the Poconos to the upper regions of Vermont and New Hampshire.

title: HELEN D. HARMON
description: Helen D. Harmon, one of the first women to graduate from Pratt Institute in New York, died yesterday at Doylestown (Pa.) Hospital. She was 90 years old and lived in Newtown, Pa.

title: Stage: Musical About a Musical
description: ABROADWAY MUSICAL was designed as a Broadway musical about the making of a Broadway musical. The originator and the coproducer of the show, Norman Kean, has apparently experienced many of the typical tribulations of the genre  false starts, hirings, firings, rewritings on the road. As A Broadway Musical entered its own tryout, life began imitating art imitating life. Before the show opened at the LuntFontanne Theater. last night, it had changed its director and lost two of its stars.

title: Dictaphone Leads Roster Of Modest Stock Gains
description: The Dictaphone Corporation, jumping more than 5 points, was the latest wimier yesterday in Wall Street's surging list of corporate takeovers. It ranked as one of the few big gathers in a session that generally showed modest price changes.

title: Hanukkah Celebrations Sunday in Wayne
description: Two holiday events are planned this Sunday at The Y.M.  Y.W.H.A. of North Jersey, One Pike Drive, in Wayne, N.J.

title: Clearing a Blackened Name And Molly Maguire Legend
description: GIRARDVILLE, Pa., Dec. 21 Here, on a windy corner of a narrow street, there stands an aged tavern where people of Irish stock take shelter from the cold. It is called Wayne's, and it is the kind of place where old men remember, with startling authenticity, things that did not happen, and old women refuse a shot of whiskey, for the sake of propriety, but drink enough beer to float a skiff.

title: IN THE NATION A Measure of Apartheid
description: South Africa's mineral wealth verges on the fabulous. But that resource is not likely to be enough to avoid serious political trouble stemming from a weakening economy.

title: I.C.C. Head Rebuffs 2 House Officials
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21  The chairman of the Interstate Commerce Cornmission rejected today demands by two House committee chairmen that the agency stop its moves to deregulate the trucking industry.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The upheaval in Iran has meant the loss of billions of dollars in military orders, property damage and delayed payments for many of the 300 American companies doing business there. All hard currency payments are at .a standstill and many contracts will never be fulfilled, analysts say. [Page A1.]

title: Events and Openings
description: BRASS TARGET, directed by John Hough; starring Sophia Loren and John Cassavetes, at the Victoria, TransLux 85th Street, Coliseum, and Quad 3.

title: Auctions
description: EACH December the auction world pauses just long enough to evaluate its performance since the beginning of the season in September. And this year, the news from New York, London and around the globe bears out what most people in the art world already knew the auction boom is continuing in virtually every area of art, antiques and other valuables. Even taking into account soaring rates of inflation in the art centers where most of the auction action takes place, sales figures are up, and scores of records have been rewritten in a host of categories.

title: Class Suit: Fee Based On Total
description: Legal fees in classaction suits can be based on the total amount of money awarded toall members of the class, even if many members fail to come forward to collect their share of the award, according to a decision yesterday by a Federal appeals court.

title: A Holiday Package for the Youngest Theatergoers
description: The Paper Bag Players, who are 20 light years ahead of most children's theater, are also 20 years old this year. To mark their score of years delighting children in New York and abroad, they are back in town, topping a sackful of firstrate holiday weekend theater for youngsters.

title: Screen: Patton Plot:Historical Speculation
description: IT is the dubious premise of "The Brass Target," a film full of dubiety, that Gen. George S. Patton Jr. was assassinated in Germany in 1945 by a motley crew of United States Army officers in an attempt to hide their theft of $250 million in Nazi gold.History says that General Patton died in Germany in 1945 following an automobile accident, but Frederick Nolan, who wrote "The Algonquin Project," this film's source material, has connected various unsolved mysteries to make a wobbly case for his conspiracy theory.As historical speculation goes, it's less interesting than wondering where we might be today if Ford's Theater had been playing "Uncle Tom's Cabin" that fateful night in 1865, instead of "Our American Cousin."Would Lincoln have attended, or might he have said, "Mary, I just can't sit through it again"?You may elect not to sit through international claptrap like this film, which doesn't measure up even to "The Cassandra Crossing.""The Brass Target" was shot in Germany and (I assume from the landscape) Switzerland, with a cast headed by John Cassavetes, Sophia Loren, Max Von Sydow, Robert Vaughn, George Kennedy, Bruce Davison and Patrick McGoohan, under the direction of John Hough ("Dirty Mary, Crazy Larry") from a script by Alvin Boretz.Mr. Cassavetes, as an intelligence officer investigating the theft of the Nazi gold, grimaces a lot, like someone doing anything to stay awake; Miss Loren looks wan; Mr. Von Sydow, Patton's fictitious assassin, looks like a man earning a good salary for a foolish job, and Mr. Kennedy, never a very interesting actor, gives General Patton the personality of a sadistic supervisor at a fat farm. He yells a lot but is immediately forgettable.Mr. Hough does nothing to improve a bad script. Among his problems is not knowing how to end a scene. Mostly someone just walks out of the frame and he cuts to the person remaining for a reaction shot when no reaction is due.Sometimes he tries to incite our interest by jumping into the dialogue from the scene to follow. Sometimes he blows a whistle or rings a bell. He's a man of ideas, all of them poor."The Brass Target," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains a lot of violence, all of it simulated but random in the way of simple-minded movie-making.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249, or to any of the following organizations:

title: GUERRILLAS ATTACK ISRAELI BORDER CITY
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 21  Palestinian guerrillas fired rockets at the northern Israeli town of Qiryat Shemona today, retaliating for air attacks against guerrilla positions in southern Lebanon yesterday.

title: Dominica Picks First President
description: ROSEAU, Dominica, Dec. 21 (UPI) The parliament of this new Caribbean island nation elected its speaker, Fred DeGazon, as the first president of the republic today. Mr. DeGazon, candidate of the Dominica Labor Party of Prime Minister Patrick John, won with 16 votes in the House of Assembly, against 10 for John Bully, candidate of the opposition Dominica Freedom Party. Dominica became independent of Britain Nov. 3.

title: A LowKeyed Yet Tough Negotiator
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21  At the State Department, for everyone except the Secretary, it is counted a virtue to be lowkeyed and chary of the spotlight. It is a virtue that Warren Miner Christopher, Deputy Secretary of State and second only to Setretary of State Cyrus R. Vance, apparently has in abudance.

title: Algeria Gas Plan Denied
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP)  The Energy Department denied today a proposal to import large amounts of liquefied natural gas from Algeria through a planned terminal on the Texas Gulf Coast.

title: Doubt Expressed On U. S. Report Of Missing Gold
description: Expressing skepticism over an announcement that $1.1 million in gold was missing from a Federal facility in New York City, officials on Wall Street and in the private preciousmetal industry suggested yesteniay. that faulty arithmetic by the Treasury Department, rather than thefts by its employees, might account for the reported loss.

title: November Orders Down; First Time in 4 Months
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP)  A sign of possible weakness in the economy emerged today in the Government's report that orders for major factory gemis declined in November for the first time in four months.

title: A Norwegian Skier Wins CrossCountry
description: CABLE, Wis, Dec. 21  On a subfreezing, overcast afternoon, Norway got the jump on its international rivals in the season's first World Cup men's crosscountry skiing event by placing two of its runners in the first three places at Mount Telemark.

title: Jet Hijacker, 16, Seized; All Safe As Her Bid to Free Prisoner Fails
description: MARION, Ill., Dec 21 A 16yearold girl hijacked a Trans World Airlines jet and held the passengers and crew hostage for nine hours on an airstrip here, then relented tonight, released the hostages and surrendered.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: The Regency Theater, Broadway and 67th Street, has had several film retrospectives this year, but calls its new one The Best. The series, running through Jan. 13, is a collection of the most popular films shown at the theater in 1978. The double feature today and tomorrow: Pride and Prejudice (1940), with Laurence Olivier and Greer Garson, and Kind Hearts and Coronets (1949), with Alec Guinness. On Sunday, two more films open for a threeday run: The Threepenny Opera (1931), with Lotte Lenya, and The Blue Angel (1930), with Marlene Dietrich. Admission is $3. Information: 7243700.

title: House Panel Hears New Evidence Of a Fourth Shot Fired at Kennedy.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 The House Select Committee on Assassinations has received additional evidence that four shots were fired at President Kennedy in Dallas 15 years ago, reopening the debate over whether he was attacked by one or two assassins, committee sources said today.

title: 5 Nuclear Protesters Sentenced
description: HAMPTON, N.H., Dec. 21 (UPI) Five members of the antinuclear Clamshell Alliance were sentenced yesterday to 60 days in jail and were fined $200 each in connection with demonstrations Sept. 23 and Nov. 11 at the Seabrook nuclear power plant. The five men, who were charged with criminal trespass, were released on $100 bail each, pending an appeal.

title: Grunwald Promoted at Time Inc.
description: Henry A, Grunwald, the former managing editor of Time magazine, will become Time Inc.'s top editorial officer, editor in chief, when Hedley Donovan, who currently holds the title, retires at the age of 65 on June 1, 1979.

title: Griese and Pastorini Listed as Doubtful
description: Neither Bob Griese of the Miami Dolphins nor Dan Pastorini of the Houston Oilers has been practicing this week because of injuries and both were listed yesterday by the National Football League as questionable performers for Sunday's playoff game at Miami.

title: Smith, Former Coach, Charges Army Broke Recruiting Rules
description: Homer Smith, who was dismissed as head football coach at Army two weeks ago, said yesterday that the United States Military Academy had repeatedly violated National Collegiate Athletic Association recruiting rules during his five seasons at West Point.

title: For Children
description: A YEAR WITH CHILDREN, the eighth annual display of paintings, sculpture, drawings, collages and photographs by 600 children In the 1978 Learning to Read Through the Arts Programs Inc., will be on display today through Jan. 7 at the Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue. Free. Information: 8601300.

title: Monetary Study Aided
description: The Rockefeller Foundation has announced that it is financing a study group headed by H. Johannes Witteveen, former managing director of the International Monetary Fund, to examine the problems confronting the international economic and monetary system. The group will be composed of 30 prominent bankers, economists and businessmen.

title: Just What I Always Wanted!
description: Sometimes Christmas shoppers buy as though they've been nipping at the eggnog.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: City to Ask TradeIn of Aid Set for L.I. Expressway
description: Governor Carey and Mayor Koch will ask the Federal Highway Administration to let New York City trade in $270 million earmarked for rebuilding the Long Island Expressway in Queens and use the money instead for mass transit, bridge repair and smaller highway improvements, it was learned yesterday.

title: Accord on Pay Ends BBC Strike
description: LONDON, Dec. 22  A twoday strike that had blacked out the British Broadcasting Corporation's television and radio programs ended tonight.

title: Bulgarian Art Being. Promoted Abroad
description: WASHINGTON  Ivan Boudinov came to town recently, toting his wares  contemporary Bulgarian art. It was a case, be said, of Mohammed coming to the mountain since the mountain would not go to Mohammed. He had been trying for more than a year, without success, to interest American curators and dealers in coming to Bulgaria to look over its art scene.

title: Three Bodies Found Under Home; Illinois Suspect Accused of Murder
description: DES PLAINES, Ill., Dec. 22 (AP) The remains of three bodies decomposed in lime have been found under the house of a convicted sex offender.

title: G.M. Plans Price Rise On '79 Cars
