description: DETROIT, Dec. 22 (AP)  The General Motors Corporation will raise the price of the averageequipped 1979model passenger car by 1.7 percent, or $108, at the start of the new year.

title: National Air's Suitors Under Study by S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22  The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun an investigation into efforts by Pan American World Airways and others to acquire National Airlines.

title: ROBIN REED
description: SALEM, Ore., Dec. 22 (AP)  Robin Reed, winner of a wrestling gold medal at the 1924 Paris Olympics and a threetime National Collegiate champion at Oregon State University, died Wednesday at a Salem hospital. He was 78 years old.

title: Feb. 15 Deadline On Guideline Data
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22  The Council on Wage and Price Stability has decided to set Feb. 15 as the deadline for large companies to submit for review the formulas they will use to determine whether they are complying with the voluntary wage and price standarts, a council spokesman said today.

title: Berle Is Forced To Resign Post; Flacke Gets Job
description: Peter A. A. Berle was forced to resign yesterday as the state's Environmental Conservation Commissioner, and Governor Carey named Robert F. Flacke, chairman of the Adirondack Park Agency, to succeed him.

title: Carter Drops Nomination of Head of Law Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22  The Justice Department announced today that President Carter had withdrawn his nomination of Norval Morris, the dean of the Law School of the University of Chicago, to head the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration. His selection had been bitterly opposed by Senate conservatives.

title: Court Upsets a Refusal Of Access to Nixon Data
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP)  A Federal appeals court said yesterday that the ownership of Richard M. Nixon's Presidential tapes and papers was still an open question, even though the Wilted States Supreme Court has said their custody and control rests with the Government.

title: Limn's Dancers Share All With Danscompany
description: The Jos Limn Dance Company is calling its current season at the City Center 55th Street Dance Theater Roots of American Dance, and Thursday's program did reach into the past with excerpts by the father and mother of modem dance, Ruth St. Denis and Ted Shawn. These pieces were not originally scheduled, but after injuries to several guest artists caused rescheduling, Joyce Trisler's Danscoznpany agreed to step in with part of its wellknown The Spirit of Denishawn program.

title: RISE IN PRICE INDEX 0.5% FOR NOVEMBER, SMALLEST SINCE JULY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22  The Government reported today that consumer prices rose by onehalf of 1 percent in November, the smallest increase since July.

title: 15 Lawmakers File Suit to Prevent Termination of Taiwan Defense Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22  Senator Barry Goldwater and 19 other legislators filed suit today to block President Carter's planned termination of the 1955 mutual defense pact with Taiwan, insisting that Congress had a constitutional role in ending treaties.

title: Seoul Will Free Opposition Chief In Amnesty for 4,000 Prisoners
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 22  The South Korean Government announced today that about 4,000 prisoners would be freed next week, among them President Chung Hee Park's chief political rival, Kim Dae June.

title: Dow Rises 13.68 to 808.47 On InflationLag Report
description: Stock prices bounded ahead yesterday, with energyrelated and glamour issues leading the rally, as investors received some unexpected preChristmas cheer in a favorable inflation report. The Dow Jones industrial average ran ahead 13.68 points to 808.47.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, DEC. 22, 1978

title: Jurisdiction Is Debated in Case of Girl, 17, Who Hijacked Jet With 87
description: MARION, Ill., Dec. 22  Federal and state officials were still trying to determine today who would have jurisdiction over the case of Robin Oswald, the 17yearold St. Louis area girl who commandeered a Trans World Airlines jet yesterday in an attempt to free a prisoner at the maximum security Federal penitentiary here.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 19.

title: OBSERVER
description: The struggle to carbonate man's stomach enters a new stage. CocaCola is moving into China in bottles and cans. Syrup will soon follow. The company's agreement with Peking specifies that no other cola drink will be sold anywhere in the Middle Kingdom.

title: Navy Aide Gets Pentagon Post
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP)  Togo D. West Jr., now the Navy's general counsel, will become Defense Secretary Harold Brown's top civilian speCial assistant Jan. 1. Mr. West will be the first black to hold that post. He will replace John G. Kester, who is returning to private law practice in Washington.

title: Corporate Earnings Reported
description: For periods as shown. (N). Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock E xchanoe, (A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Ski Reports
description: (All ski areas are operating on very limited terrain. Figures in parentheses show total trails and number open at each area.)

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Dutch Buy 13 P3C's From Lockheed
description: BURBANK, Calif., Dec. 22 (UPI) The LockheedCalifornia Company has announced that the Dutch Parliament has approved a Cabinet decision to buy 13 Lockheed P3C Orion patrol planes at a cost of $300 million.

title: Mary E. Anderson Bride Of Capt. Edward Adler
description: Mary Elis Anderson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Frank Bayles Anderson of New York, was married yesterday in the Episcopal Church of St. Luke in the Fields to Capt. Edward Henry Adler, U.S.A.F., son of Mrs. Arthur Edwin Adler of Evansville, Ind., and the late Mr. Adler. The Rev. Paul C. Weed Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 23, 1978

title: Kennecott Peace Pact: Timing a Puzzle
description: For more than a year, ever since he set sights on the Kennecott Copper Corporation, T. Roland Berner, the sharptongued, Harvardeducated board chairman of the CurtissWright Corporation, had seemed the least likely person to be admitted to the inner sanctum of the nation's largest copper company.

title: New Hampshire G.O.P. Aligning for Presidential Primary
description: CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 19  New Hampshire Republicans don't want to be left without a date for the prom, even though it's 14 months off.

title: Ethiopians Stir New Somali Fears With Bombings and Army Buildup
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Dec. 21  A series of Ethiopian bombing raids on northern towns in Somalia and reports of Ethiopian troops massing across the border have generatdd alarm and rekindled fears of war here.

title: Downey Named By Mrs. Grasso To Head Agency
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 21 John T. Downey is not your typical political appointee, although a cursory glance at his rsum may make him seem so  a 48yearold graduate of Yale and Harvard Law School who is interested in politics. But Mr. Downey, named yesterday to the newly created post of Connecticut Secretary of Business Regulation, spent 20 years in a Chinese prison after his plane was shot down near the Manchurian border in 1952 while he was on a mission for the Central Intelligence Agency to bring out a Chinese agent.

title: Broadway Musical Closes After One Performance
description: A Broadway Musical closed Thursday night at the LuntFontanne Theater after one performance. Producers of the musical, which was about the making of a Broadway musical, decided, a spokesman said, that given the nature of the reviews it was not feasible to continue.

title: Tennessee Governor Questioned By Grand Jury on Alleged Bribes
description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 22  Gov. Ray Blanton of Tennessee spent two hours before a Federal grand jury today answering questions about an extortion scandal and later denied any wrongdoing on his part in the alleged sale of executive clemency by his aides.

title: Shah Rebuffed on Coalition Effort
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 22  Gholam Hussein Sadighi, who has been asked by the Shah to form a coalition government that could lead the country out of its crisis, moved today to recruit respected academicians and technocrats after being rebuffed by most wellknown opposition politicians.

title: Dangerous Prisoners Who Fled Jail in Fall Escape a Second Time
description: LONOKE, Ark., Dec. 22 (UPI)  Four prisoners forced a county jailer into a cell at gunpoint early today and escaped.

title: 1970 Murder Conviction Voided; Judges Criticize Queens Officials
description: A 34yearold auto mechanic smiled broadly yesterday as he strode into the brisk fresh air of freedom after eight years in prison for a murder conviction that a judge said never should have happened.

title: Lefkowitz Calls Esposito Evasive
description: The state's Attorney General, Louis J. Lefkowitz, accused Meade H. Esposito yesterday of engaging in diversionary tactics to avoid answering charges that he did business with a licensed quarterhorse race track on Long Island while serving as the Democratic Party's county leader in Brooklyn.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 22 (AP)  A late telephone campaign by the wife of the Georgia Tech coach, Pepper Rodgers, apparently has saved the future of the Peach Bowl, which earlier this week had been given up for dead.

title: A Warning to Sleeping Princes Of France's Left and Right
description: PARISSince the defeat of the Union of the Left in the French legislative elections last March, the positions of the majority and the opposition have seemed fixed for an eternity ... that will last until spring 1981, when the French will have to choose a new king, or confirm their preference for the present incumbent.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: WELCOME BACK With most home Christmas trees decorated by now, chances are that today many family groups will head for Rockefeller Center to see the towering traditional Yuletide symbol by the skating rink.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Several figures in an article in Business Day on Wednesday on the stock split of the International Business Machines Corporation were incorrect. The article should have said that the company has 580,000 shareholders and $3.8 billion in cash and marketable securities and that the additional total dividend payout would be $330 million.

title: POPE TO TAKE PART IN MEXICO MEETING
description: ROME, Dec. 22  Pope John Paul II announced today that he will fly to Mexico next month to take part in a meeting of Latin American bishops scheduled to lay down the longrange policies of the church in the southern hemisphere.

title: Aerosols, Fluorocarbons and the Ozone
description: For months now many Americans have been feeling virtuous about using a rollon deodorant  and so helping to reduce the threat to global survival posed by aerosol sprays containing fluorocarbons. The fluorocarbons, it will be recalled, are gases that percolate slowly up into the stratosphere, where they are split apart by sunlight to produce chlorine, which then erodes the ozone layer that shields the earth from deadly ultraviolet radiation. The consequences, though distant and highly uncertain, could be grim: an increase in skin cancer, genetic mutations, damage to plants and animals, and drastic changes in climate.

title: New Lease With 79th St. Marina Concern Is Opposed
description: Gordon J. Davis, the New York City Parks Commissioner, said yesterday that he would recommend that the company that manages the West 79th Street Boat Basin in Manhattan be refused a renewal of its concession agreement with the city.

title: New York Prices Post Slight Rise
description: Consumer prices in the New York metropolitan area rose a modest threetenths of 1 percent last month. Seasonally adjusted, it was the smallest increase since August and twotenths of a percentage point below the national rate, the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Lynn Dickey Surgery Set
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Dec. 22 (UPI) Lynn Dickey, the Green Bay Packers' quarterback, will undergo surgery on his left leg at the Research Medical Center in Kansas City on Jan. 2. Dickey .broke his leg Nov. 13, 1977, in a game against the Los Angeles Rams at Milwaukee County Stadium. He sat out the remainder of last Season and this season.

title: Zambia Reports Raid By Rhodesian Planes On Its Military Camp
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 22 (AP) Rhodesian planes bombed a Zambian military training camp today, a Zambian Government spokesman said.

title: Six Disaster Areas Named
description: PHOENIX, Dec. 22 (AP)  President Carter has designated six Arizona counties as Federal disaster areas because of flooding earlier this week that took at least 11 lives, left 10 persons missing and caused an estimated $30 million in property damage.

title: Donald Nixon Denies GemSale Fraud Allegations
description: Donald A. Nixon, themephew of former President Richard M. Nixon, yesterday denied allegations by State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz that he had participated in what had been called the fraudulent sale of diamonds by a defunct Manhattan company with which he was formerly associated.

title: Bethlehem Scene: Idyllic, Pastoral and Tense, Too
description: BETHLEHEM, IsraeliOccupied West Bank, Dec. 18  There are still shepherds abiding in the field, keeping watch over their flocks just outside this town as they were, according to St. Luke, at the time Jesus was born.

title: Frederick A. Ficken, 68; Mathematics Professor
description: Frederick Arthur Ficken, professor of mathematics emeritus at New York University, died Wednesday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 14 Benedict Place in Pelham. N.Y.

title: Your Money
description: THOUGH the stock market generally is a disaster area, shareholders are plowing cash back into automatic dividend reinvestment plans as if they had never heard of the Dow Jones averages.

title: A North of Italy Christmas
description: Milan, the sprawling, newold, yellowbrown city of the north, tight frozen in the December cold.

title: Jersey Officials Open Drive to Free Black Leader Held in Kidnap Case
description: TRENTON, Dec. 22  A growing ad hoc committee of public officials and clergymen has begun a drive to win the release from state prison of a black community leader from Orange, N.J., who in what they call a miscarriage of justice  began serving a 30year sentence last month for assault and kidnappning.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON CIRCUITRY that was once too large to fit on a desktop can now be squeezed down to a quarterinch square. The miniaturization has been added by plastic coating invented by two scientists at the Bell Telephone Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J.

title: Internal Memo Reportedly Noted Firestone Tire Failures in 1972
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP)  Company documents show that Firestone Tire and Rubber Company officials knew of major problems with their steelbelted model 500 tire as early as November 1972, The Washington Post reported in tomorrow's editions.

title: Sunshine Mining Sued by Hunt
description: The Sunshine Mining Company said that it had asked Hunt International Resources for 21 business days to examine its revised merger proposal to acquire Sunshine.

title: Books of The Times
description: Death seems easy, but dying sometimes seems impossible, Archie Hanlan, author of Autobiography of Dying, says. Death is oblivion, and dyng is intense, unrelenting awareness.

title: ExClerk of C.I.A. Gets 40 Years In Sale of Space Secrets to Soviet
description: HAMMOND, Ind., Dec. 22 (AP)  A former Central Intelligence Agency clerk, William Kampiles, was sentenced today to 40 years in prison for selling topsecret satellite plans to the Soviet Union.

title: Caller Denies Charges by Former Manager of Cult
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 22 (AP)  A caller identifying himself as Tim Stoen, accused by the former financial manager of the People's Temple of maintaining a hit list of temple enemies, says his accuser is still working for the Rev. Jim Jones, the cult leader who died with most of his followers in a death ritual at their Guyana commune.

title: Carter Cancels Cuts of $2 Billion Proposed in Social Welfare Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22  Responding to recent appeals from the nation's mayors and froth minority groups, President Carter today restored $2 billion in proposed cuts in the social welfare budget for the coming fiscal year.

title: Rangers 42 Victors On Two by Esposito
description: Leave it to the Rangers to make an easy game turn out hard. Outshining the Detroit Red Wings in nearly every department last night at Madison. Square Garden, they were nearly squeezed out of the bottom line where it counts.

title: About New York
description: Outside in the cold night, beyond the bargain aisles of the America Boutique in East Harlem, a man is selling Christmas trees in Spanish. For an attentive family, he is going through the lovely ritual of holding each tree out from him and thumping its base on the sidewalk so it shudders in dark inviting forest tones in the spirited heart of the city.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, Dec.23

title: Syracuse, Kentucky Are Upset
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 22 (AP)Rob Judson sank four free throws in the final 20 seconds tonight, as undefeated Illinois upset Syracuse, 6961, in the first round of the University of Kentucky invitation tournament. In the second game, the host Wildcats were stunned by Texas A & M, 7369. The Aggies will meet Illinois in the final tomorrow night.

title: German Company To Buy Hycel
description: Hycel Inc. said an agreement in principle had been reached under which a unit of Boehringer Mannheim G.m.b.H. of West Germany would acquire all of Hycel's capital stock at $6 a share in cash. Based on the 6.47 million common shares of Hycel outstanding, the transaction is valued at $38.9 million. Hycel makes automated blood analyzers.

title: Article 6 -- No Title
description: DO NOT FORGET THE NEEDIEST!

title: Austin Hearst Weds Miss Patton
description: The marriage of Denise Louise Patton; daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles William Patton of San Diego, to John. Augustine Chilton Hearst took place in San Simeon, Calif., yesterday. The bridegroom, known as Austin, is a son of William Randolph Hearst Jr., editor in chief of the Hearst Newspapers and chairman of the executive committee of the Hearst Corporation, and Mrs. Hearst of New York and a grandson of the late William Randolph Hearst, founder of the publishing empire.

title: Carter Leaves Sickbed to Return to Plains for Holiday
description: PLAINS, Ga., Dec. 22 (AP)  President Carter arrived home today for the Christmas holiday after leaving his sickbed.

title: Bridge:
description: In the early days of contract bridge, a direct cue bid in a suit already bid by the enemy was used to show a massive hand, with sufficient values for game. Among tournament players that treatment has become quite outmoded.

title: William Ellison, 59, a Caseworker
description: William McLaren Ellison, a retired senior caseworker for the New York City Department of Social Services and a former freelance writer, died Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness. He was 59 years old and lived at 407 Bleecker Street.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Trading was slow on most commodity futures market yesterday because of the approach of the Christmas holiday weekend, and much of the actvity centered on evening up positions.

title: Betsy Wade Is Elected President Of Newspaper Guild of New York
description: Betsy Wade of The New York Times was elected president of the Newspaper Guild of New York yesterday, defeating the incumbent, Thomas P. Murphy, by a vote of 1.730 to 1.355.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249, or to any of the following organizations:

title: CaliforniaWorld In Continental Tie
description: The Continental Group and the CaliforniaWorld Financial Corporation announced they had signed an agreement on the proposed merger of CaliforniaWorld and the Continental Financial Services Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of Continental Group.

title: Brief News Spots on TV High in Profits, Ratings
description: The biggest little news shows on network television are deliberately tuned in by almost no one and are over and done with in one minute. Yet they are seen by more viewers than watch any other news programs.

title: New York State Minimum Wage To Rise to $2.90 an Hour Jan. 1
description: ALBANY, Dec. 22 (UPI)  Beginning Jan. 1, New York State's hourly minimum wage will rise from $2.65 to $2.90.

title: Striking a Bargain Over Peddlers
description: Hey, getcher anything! cries the Manhattan street peddler. Hats and gloves, handbags, umbrellas, jewelry, watches, pots and pans, toys  all are available on the sidewalk, despite regulations to the contrary. There are an estimated 25,000 peddlers In New York, and some people are very much upset by them. They pay no taxes, complains a spokesman for the Fifth Avenue Association. They have no overhead and they mess up the streets with their trash. Some pedestrians are bothered by their merchandise, often strewn across the sidewalk, or by the carts and crowds of customers who block the walkways. And the bargains are sometimes suspect.

title: 10,386 See Arrows Win Debut
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Dec. 22  Soccer moved indoors tonight and the fans turned out to get a look.

title: Nigeria Approaches Civilian Rule With High Expectations
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  With a new, Americaninspired Constitution, more than 40 political parties and 47 million registered voters, Nigeria is moving with great expectations, considerable excitement and some real fears toward the selection of a president in April and the return from military to civilian rule in October.

title: Cleveland Putting 2 Plans On Fiscal Crisis to Voters
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 22  The Cleveland City Council approved by decisive margins today Mayor Dennis J. Kucinich's proposal for referendums on two controversial revenueproducing measures that could direct this fiscally troubled city away from a course toward bankruptcy.

title: Danish Education Chief Is Ousted Over Funds for a Junket to Paris
description: COPENHAGEN, Dec. 22 (UPI)Prime Minister Anker Jorgensen ousted his Minister of Education today for refusing to refund part of the $10,000 in bills she ran up durin,g a 12day stay at the Ritz Hotel in Paris.

title: Radio
description: 6 A.M., WKCR. Sacred Music Festival.

title: Snowplow Men Chipper On First Day of Winter
description: SYOSSET, L.I., Dec. 22 Today was the first day of winter and, although the temperature was in the 40's and the sky was clear, road crews from the Town of Oyster Bay practiced plowing snow.

title: Knoetze's OutofRing Record in South Africa Stirs Protest
description: Three human rights groups have threatened to demonstrate and picket next month when Kallie Knoetze, a white former policeman from South Africa who is the secondranked heavyweight of the World Boxing Association, makes his United States debut in a fight copromoted by Madison Square Garden and Chris Dundee.

title: World News Briefs
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Africa, Dec. 22 (Reuters)  The new Constituent Assembly of SouthWest Africa agreed today to United Nationssupervised elections leading to its independence from South Africa, but it posed major conditions.

title: Japanese Adventures of Sinbad Live and on Film
description: There is nothing more amazing about The Amazing Adventures of Sinbad, at the Beacon Theater, than its technical aspects. Film and live theater have been ingeniously mixed by the Hikosen (Airship) Theater Company of Japan to produce one of the season's more novel holiday entertainments for children.

title: Rise in Avocado Use; Aids Coast Investors
description: LOS ANGELES  They are dubbed green gold  but, tuflike a gold hoard, they also bring in steady earnings. They are the ultimate fruit for the gentleman farmer: a cash crop requiring minimal care that waits patiently on the tree for the most propitious moment to be plucked.

title: Citibank Holds Prime at 11%
description: Citibank decided yesterday to keep its prime rate on corporate loans unchanged at 11 percent.

title: REV. JAMES H. RAY
description: The Rev. James H. Ray, a Maryknoll priest, died Wednesday of a heart attack in Danbury, Conn. He was 71 years old and lived in Sherman, Conn.

title: In the Streets of Paris, Mickey Is a Mouse. That Carries Clout
description: PARIS, Dec. 22  Mickey is still a very big mouse in Europe. And a big moneymaker as well. Last week, a collection of Mickey Mouse antiques, some of them dating as far back as 1977, went on the block here and brought a total of $12,000.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Punitive Action In Grain Case
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP)  An Illinois concern designated to perform official Federal grain inspection and three of its officials have been suspended for up to 60 days, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: For the Problems Women Have in Common, Finding Sources of Help
description: Every day the women call, with problems as diverse as they themselves are.

title: JURY BLAMES JONES FOR GUYANA DEATHS
description: MATTHEWS RIDGE, Guyana, Dec. 22  Under the forceful direction of magistrate who shouted and banged on his desk, a coroner's jury declared today that the Rev. Jim Jones and some person or persons unknown murdered all but three of the more than 900 persons who died at Jonestown.

title: Around the Nation
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 22 (UPI)  Dr. Peter Bourne, the former White House health adviser, has been publicly reprimanded by the State Board of Medical Examiners for writing a tranqUilizer prescription under a false name.

title: Americans Still Held in Ecuador
description: QUITO, Ecuador, Dec. 22 (UPI)  The Government said today that charges had been dropped against eight Americans suspected of aiding a plot to assassinate the presidential candidate Jaime Roldos. It added, however, that they would be dharged with illegal trafficking in archeological treasures, which they were said to have confessed.

title: Jascalevich's Lawyer Sues Times
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Dec. 22  Raymond A. Brown, the lawyer who success. fully defended Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich against charges of murdering three hospital patients, has sued The New York Times for nearly $22,000 in expenses incurred by his office during the 34week trial.

title: House Panel Plans Public Hearing On Hint of a 2d Kennedy Gunman
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP)  Members of a House committee, raising questions about new evidence suggesting involvement of a second gunman in President Kennedy's murder, decided today that their investigation should not be ended until the findings were further scrutinized.

title: Soviet Police Said to Raid Homes Of Dissident Jews in Three Cities
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 22  Soviet policemen raided several apartments in Moscow, Leningrad and Riga yesterday and confiscated articles being prepared for publication in the underground journal, Jews in the U.S.S.R., dissidents reported today. The police also seized materials connected with an unofficial scientific seminar next week to which Western scientists have been invited, one of the dissidents said.

title: Dr. Sanford Sall, Gynecologist, 44
description: Dr. Sanford Sall, a gynecologist and cancer researcher, died yesterday of a heart attack at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 44 years old, lived in New York City and had an office at 1107 Park Avenue, near 85th Street.

title: Teasing Cities About Welfare
description: The Carter Administration's current coyness about welfare reform must be exasperating to mayors and county executives burdened by welfare costs. White House aides tantalize them by reaffirming the President's unswerving commitment to reform, only to dash their hopes by saying how determined he is to trim spending for social programs. It, is a cruel tease for such financially strapped cities as New York and Newark, which, unlike most cities, underwrite some of the costs of welfare themselves. Washington has talked for years of federalizing the burden. Candidate Jimmy Carter promised it. But now, sadly, the signs suggest that the President, like his predecessors, will probably not make good on the promise.

title: Flushing Flea Market Closes Under Pressure From Area's Retailers
description: One of the largest flea markets in New York City, at Shea Stadium in Flushing, Queens, has closed down under pressure from neighborhood merchants, who complained that the vendors competed unfairly because of their low occupancy costs and nonpayment of sales taxes.

title: Letter: On Trucking Deregulation
description: To the Editor:

title: Consumer's Guide to Agents
description: In sports, the popular image of an athlete's agent is that of a bloodsucker. But an agent can also provide a blood transfusion. For an athlete, there is nothing better than a good agent, and nothing worse than a bad agent. But which agents are good or bad? More important, which are honest or dishonest?. Until now, about all an athlete could rely on was hearsay. But now there is a list of 208 lawyers and agents willing to put their credentials and fee structures on the line for an athlete's inspection in a 50page directory published by the Association of Representatives of Professional Athletes, whose administrator is William Weston, a University of Baltimore Law School professor. I got tired of hearing how terrible agents are, he says. I wanted to do something to improve the image and professionalism of agents and at the same time protect the young athlete. More than 2,000 directories have been distributed so far.

title: Alice at the Public
description: An evening of musical pieces from Elizabeth Swados's adaptation of Alice's Adventures in Wonderland and Through the Looking Glass will be performed at 8 P.M. next Wednesday, Thursday and Friday at the Public/ Newman Theater. Performers in Wonderland in Concert will include Meryl Streep as Alice.

title: Parsifal Unlikely Christmas Fare From Leinsdorf
description: A big chunk of music from Wagner's Parsital, which is associated with Good Friday and, therefore, the crucifixion of Christ, may not be everybody's idea of apt fare for the Christmas season, but Erich Leinsdorf is not everybody, and Parsifal is what he turned to for his concerts with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall this week. The postintermission portion of the conductor's program was taken up with the Prelude and Transformation Music from Act I and the Prelude, Good Friday Music and Conclusion from Act III. The Wagner was preceded by Brahms's Symphony No. 3.

title: Spurs Beats Bulls, 10392, For 6th Straight Triumph
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 22 (UPI)  George Gervin scored 15 of his gamehigh 33 points in the first period tonight to pace the San Antonio Spurs to a 10392 victory over the Chicago Bulls. It was the sixth straight National Basketball Association triumph for the Spurs.

title: Navy Wins Holiday Bowl
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec.22 (AP)  Bob Leszczynski hit Phil McConkie with a 65yard scoring pass and Bob Tata kicked three field goals tonight as Navy rallied to defeat Brigham Young University, 2316, in the first Holiday Bowl college football game.

title: 2 Rape Trial Witnesses Declare Accuser Lied
description: SALEM, Ore., Dec. 22  Two witnesses today in the trial here of a man accused of raping his wife said that Greta M. Rideout had lied about alleged sexual relationships with them.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, Hurncierdinck's Hansel and Gretel. 2; Puccini's Tosca. 8.

title: EARNINGS
description: Bolstered by higher prices, the earnings of the Federal Company in its second fiscal quarter ended Nov. 30 rose 48 percent as revenues increased 22.8 percent, according to company reports yesterday.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 26.

title: Japan Consumer Spending
description: TOKYO, Dec. 22 (UPI)  October consumer spending in Japan ran at the fastest yeartoyear increase for the current fiscal year, the Prime Minister's office has disclosed. Preliminary information released by the office put October's average consumer expenditure at $1,008, up 3.2 percent in real terms from the same month last year.

title: Kendra Hamilton Wed to Executive
description: Kendra Stearns Hamilton, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Kendall Stearns of Hudson, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Patrick O'Donnell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles P. O'Donnell of providence, R. I. The Rev. Robert Lewis of the Christ Episcopal Church in Hudson performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Allon Suggests Egypt and Israel Accept Interim Peace
description: Yigal Allon, the former Israeli Foreign Minister, has suggested that if the deadlock in efforts for an FgyptianIsraeli peace treaty persists, the two sides should accept an interim secondbest agreement.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Are Higher
description: Yields rose yesterday in the Treasury's latest sale of threemonth and sixmonth bills, climbing to their highest levels since Aug. 26, 1974, when they hit their most generous levels on record.

title: The City
description: A Coast Guard investigation has found that the Staten Island ferryboat crash on Nov. 7 that injured 335 persons was caused by negligence on the part of the captain and assistant captain.

title: Larry Kert Sings at the Ballroom
description: Larry Kert is looking to both his past and his future in his performances at the Ballroom, where he will be singing through next weekend.

title: 4% Export Dip Seen by Toyota
description: TOKYO, Dec. 22 (Reuters)  The Toyota Motor Company, Japan's largest vehicle manufacturer, predicted today that its exports next year would drop by about 4 percent.

title: State University Staffs At 32 Campuses Vote To Keep Same Union
description: The United University Professions won the right in an election yesterday to continue representing faculty members and nonteaching professionals on 32 campuses of the State University of New York.

title: On City's Fashionable Streets, European Shops Proliferate
description: Once, immigrants came to America because they believed the streets were paved with gold. Guess what? They are coming here again with the same dream. The big difference is that back in the early days of this century the immigrants were mainly poor people. Today, they are merchants with enough capital to invest in prime space on Madison or Fifth Avenue or on such fashionable cross streets as 57th and 60th.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET UNION APPEAR NEAR A TENTATIVE AGREEMENT ON LIMITS FOR STRATEGIC ARMS
description: GENEVA, Dec. 22  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said tonight that the United States and the Soviet Union were close to the end of the road in their long negotiations for a new agreement limiting each side's longrange bombers and nucleararmed missiles.

title: The Region
description: Justice L. Kingsley Smith of State Supreme Court, who had declared unconstitutional New York State's present method of financing education through property taxes, yesterday denied a request by the state to have the court reconsider its decision of last June.

title: ExOfficial Suing to Balk Move Barring Book on C.I.A. Failures
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22  A former Central Intelligence Agency officer filed suit in Federal District Court here today to try to prevent the agency and the Justice Department from blocking publication of a partly completed book that would deal, in part, with alleged intelligence failures in Asia.

title: PitneyBowes Starts Dictaphone Offer
description: PitneyBowes Inc. announced it had begun its offer to acquire up to two million common shares of the Dictaphone Corporation for $28 a share in cash, in accordance with the agreement announced between the two companies on Thursday. The offer will expire Jan. 2 unless extended. Dictaphone has 4.3 million common shares outstanding.

title: Egyptians to Seek New Procedure for Peace Talks
description: CAIRO, Dec. 22  Prime Minister Mustafa Khalil will seek a new procedure for resuming peace negotiations with Israel when he meets with Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan in Brussels this weekend, Acting Foreign Minister Boutros Ghali said today.

title: Schools Ruled Eligible for Funds Despite TeacherPlacement Bias
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that even though the New York City Board of Education had not eliminated the effects of alleged racial discrimination in the assignment of teachers, it should not be denied Federal funds if it was making goodfaith efforts to do so.

title: Obituary 6 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516)7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6001500; CONNECTICUT (203)3487767.

title: SAMUEL RUBIN DIES; ARTS PATRON. WAS 77
description: Samuel Rubin, founder of Faberg Inc., philanthropist and patron of the arts, died Thursday of cancer at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: For New Yorkers, a Christmas To Delight In and to Cope With
description: It really didn't matter that yesterday's weather had warmed up to a degree traditionally unfit for Christmas, because there is a tantalizing promise of snow for the holiday. Nor did it matter that the prices of everything from perfume flacons to plastic robots  are up considerably this inflationary year. Nor did it matter which of the 14 Santa Clauses or 62 elves were on duty at Macy's North Pole.

title: Coast Court Voids GunCase Law
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 22 In a longawaited decision on an issue that had embroiled the California Supreme Court in a bitter controversy, the court ruled today, 4 to 3, that a judge could not be forced to sentence a defendant to prison for using a gun in committing a crime.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Consumer prices rose fivetenths of 1 percent in November, the Labor Department reported. The increase, which translates into a 6 percent annual rate of gain for inflation, was the lowest in four months. Prices for food and housing were the chief contributors to the slowing in the rate. But some analysts suggested that bigger gains in the consumer price index were in prospect for coming months, partly reflecting the anticipated impact of oil price increases announced by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. [Page 1.]

title: Carrier Won't Bar United Link
description: The Carrier Corporation, which up to now had been opposing a $1 billion takeover by the United Technologies Comoration, said yesterday that it had decided to begin negotiations with United on a taxfree merger.

title: Italian Jetliner Sinks Off Sicily; 26 of 129 Saved
description: PALERMO, Sicily, Saturday, Dec. 23 (AP)  An Alitalia jetliner carrying 129 people to Sicily for Christmas ditched in the Tyrrhenian Sea early today, and airline officials officials here said fishing boats had picked up 26 survivors and there were 103 people missing.

title: How Fund Aids the Neediest
description: During the last several months, 8yearold Steven had his first birthday party, received his first mail and is about to have the Christmas of his life.

title: Stenmark Triumphs In Slalom
description: KRANISICA GORA, Yugoslavia, Dec. 22 (AP)  Ingemar Stenmark, the Swedish star, displayed overwhelming superiority today and captured his second World Cup event within 24 hours, skiing to victory through fog and snow in the giant slalom.

title: Talks Stalled in Actors' Walkout
description: Spokesmen for the 70,000 striking actors and announcers who make radio and television commercials reported yesterday that there was no immediate prospect of a resumption of talks toward ending the walkout, which began Tuesday. No comment was forthcoming from the management side.

title: Brinkmann to Sell Assets to Sybron
description: Brinkrnann Instruments Inc. announced that it had agreed in principle to sell substantially all of its assets to the Sybron Corporation for $9 million in cash subject to certain adjustments.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Goulds Pumps Seeks Goyne Pump
description: Goulds Pumps Inc. said it had made a tender offer to the stockholders of the Goyne Pump Company of Ashland, Pa., offering to buy all of the Goyne shares outstanding at $400 a share, of which $40 is subject to satisfaction of certain conditions specified in the offer. The offer will expire on Jan. 5 unless extended.

title: Now MacMillan Wants Domtar
description: TORONTO, Dec. 22  In a dramatic, transcontinental salvo of corporate takeover announcements, MacMillan Bloedel Ltd., Canada's largest forestproducts company, announced today a bid to swallow Domtar Inc., the industry's thirdlargest company.

title: Original Lou and Walter Story Staged at Kitchen
description: Jill Kroesen's appearances in various SoHo events in the last few years have, found her singing, dancing and acting. And in The Original Lou and Walter Story. her current mixedmedia show at the Kitchen, she reveals talents in playwriting and choreography as well. But The Original Lou and Walter Story, which runs through tonight, is not so much a mixedmedia piece in the contemporary manner as it is an Oldfashioned musical comedy. As such, it deserves to survive its present threenight run, perhaps in an Off Broadway theater.

title: Army to Investigate Smith's Allegations
description: Lieut. Gen. Andrew J. Goodpaster, superintendent of the United States Military Academy, yesterday ordered an immediate investigation into charges by Army's former head football coach, Homer Smith, that the Academy violated National Collegiate Athletic Association rules.

title: Ominous Stalemate in Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 21  Although they welcome the respite from bloodshed and turmoil, some Western analysts view the current stalemate in Iran as an ominous development.

title: U.S. and E.E.C. Cite Gain in Trade Talks
description: GENEVA, Dec. 22  The United States and the European Economic Community announced today that they had made significant progress toward overall agreement on the broad array of measures tinder discussion here in the Tokyo Round of trade talks involving 99 nations.

title: Mailbox: Aid the Hunted, Not the Hunter
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: One of the longer operatic eras came to an end a week ago Wednesday, when the New York City Opera announced that Beverly Sills would replace Julius Rudel as the company's director. In case you missed the news, Mr. Rudel has announced that he wants to concentrate on his conducting career. He will remain with the New York City Opera until June 30, 1979, after which Miss Sills will assume her new duties.

title: Debra Susan Hall of Gimbels Fiance of Douglas Tishman
description: Harriet Hall of New York, director of corporate communications for Lane Bryant Inc., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Debra Susan Hall, to Douglas S. Tishman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Tishman of New York.

title: A Double Bill
description: The Gold Rush,  Charlie Chaplin once said, is the picture I want to be remembered by. It will be shown tonight and tomorrow night at the New Community Cinema in Huntington with another of his masterpieces, City Liuhts.

title: Touring Trouper
description: LEADING LADY The World and Theatre of Katharine Cornell. By Tad Mosel with Gertrude Ma?? Illustrated. 534 pp. Boston: AtlanticLittle. Brown. $15.95.

title: THE DICTIONARY Of BIOGRAPRICAL QUOTATION
description: EVERY great man nowadayshas his disciples, wrote Oscar Wilde in 1887, 'and it is usually Judas who writes the biography.

title: A Son of the Hungry South
description: ANYBODY over 40 who grew up in the rural Deep South will tell you stories similar to those in A Childhood: the brilliant mules, the mysterious sicknesses, the witchcraft remedies, the deadly coachwhip snakes, the beguilingly intimate relations between the races, the daylong fistfights, and so on.

title: Professor Marries Rabbi Laura Geller
description: Rabbi Laura Geller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Geller of New York, was married yesterday to Michael Goldstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Goldstein of Astoria, Queens, and Danbury, Conn.

title: The Stephen Goldens Have Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Stephen A.O. Golden on Dec. 12 at the New York Hospital. The child has been named David Adams Ochs. Mrs. Golden is the former June Tauber, daughter of Mrs. Abraham Tauber of Yonkers and the late Dr. Tauber, who was University Professor at Yeshiva University. The child is a grandson also of Mrs: Ruth S. Holmberg, publisher of The Chattanooga Times and the late Ben Hale Goldan.alie emid's father is assistant to the vice presidentAor personnel of The New York Times.

title: FILM VIEW
description: It was the day after the opening of Superman, the comic stripinspired film that reportedly cost four times as much as the Louisiana Territory and is somewhat less big. The reaction to the film was decidedly mixed. What, asked a friend of mine, went wrong? What went wrong?. I said. I'm not sure anything went wrong. If they insist on making a movie about Superman, this is probably as good as can be done.

title: N.F.L. Playoffs Begin
description: The second season, the monthlong race to the super Bowl, starts today in Atlanta and Miami with two distinctive matches.

title: Islanders' Trottier Scores 5 In 94 Romp Over Rangers
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Dec. 23  The New York Rangers, who are last in the Patrick Division, were hoping to accomplish two things tonight against the New York Islanders at Nassau Coliseum. They hoped to beat the Islanders for the first time this season, and more importantly, they wanted to become the first team in the National Hockey League to end the Islanders' unbeaten status at home.

title: Krishna Santas Move In On the HoHoHo Trade
description: On a corner near Filene's, the flagship otBoston's downtown shopping district, a bigbellied Santa Claus hands out candy eines and solicits money for needy children.

title: Air Shuttle to J.F.K. Raises Doubts
description: BEGINNING Jan. 1, two major airlines are scheduled to offer free air shuttle service from Long Island MacArthur Airport to Kennedy International Airport for westbound passengers, and the possibility that the service may become a permanent fixture has raised concern over the impact on the Islip Town airport and some of the businesses the airport supports.

title: Neediest Cases Stir ExResident
description: Elizabeth H. Noble of Lansdowne, Pa., is a former New Yorker who continues to be a donor to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. She sent the 67th annual appeal a check for $25, and in her letter 5rote:

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: GREENWICH decided that it could not afford to run its own private railroad so the line  an Ogauge layout instead of the Conrail variety  probably will go to a Boston museum.

title: Southwesterns
description: WILLA CATHER, in her littleknown April Twilights, wrote some excellent verses about the old West, the old time, when oliveskinned sheepherders on the Southwestern plains still sang the songs of Spain. Who, having read it over twice, could get Miss Cather's poem about Spanish Johnny and his mandolin (he played it while waiting to swing for a murder) out of his mind and memory? But Willa Cather unfortunately deserted this part of her frontier heritage when she came to write her novels. She celebrated the settlers, not the mobile frontiersmen who went before them.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: ART

title: Leinsdorf Conducts Revival of Elektra at the Met
description: Richard Strauss's Elektra was revived by the Metropolitan Opera on Friday night after a threeyear absence from the repertory, and it was a respectable performance. That is not, however, what one wants and expects in this most searing of the composer's theater pieces. Elektra needs to go at white heat and to be sung by great voices, factors that used to be present in the Met performances of the past but were absent on this occasion.

title: Farmers in India Rally to Support Rival of Premier
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 23  Several hundred thousand farmers staged a peaceful political rally here today to demonstrate support for former Home Minister Charan Singh, a rival of Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai.

title: Janet Debra Epstein Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Epstein of York, Pa., have rumnoturced the engagement of their daughter, Janet Debra Epstein, to Barry Mark Wolper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Wolper of Edison, N.J.

title: Tire Company Says It Plans to Stay in Akron if Union Takes Pay Cut
description: AKRON, Ohio, Dec. 23  The General Tire Company plans to replace its aging Akron truck tire plant with a new production facility, either here or in the South. The choice depends on whether the union local accepts a pay reduction and changes in work rule that the company says are needed to make a factory in the North profitable.

title: Deaths
description: FISHKINSimon, beloved husband of Ida, devoted father of Jesse, Leona Auerbach, dear brother, grandfather and greatgrandfather. Services today, 12 noon at the Brooklyn Chapel, 1 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn.

title: Unspent Arts Funds Stir Suffolk Controversy
description: OPERATING under a new method for financing the arts, Suffolk County is not distributing almost onefifth of the funds earmarked for cultural activities in 1978. More than $33,000 out of a proposed budget of $172,626 will be returned to the county's general fund, unless a move to carry the funds over to the 1979 budget is approved at the next meeting of the County Legislature on Thursday.

title: Vance Arrives Late, Then Starts Separate Talks With Dayan and Khalil
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 23  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance arrived shortly before midnight tonight to hold separate meetings with top Egyptian and Israeli officials who had been waiting for him to bring them together in an effort to revive stalled Middle East peace negotiations. The signs were that both sides had hardened their positions and that the Camp David agreement was in trouble.

title: Nairobi: Tinsel in the Palm Trees
description: The only snow anywhere near Nairobi is on the 17,000foot summit of Mount Kenya, which straddles the Equator. The closest sound to jingle bells comes from the dangers around the necks of humpbacked cattle foraging among the thorn trees on the African plains. And the Santa Claus who comes to the American School is apt to be a musclebound, crewcut and somewhat embarrassed Marine guard from the United States Embassy.

title: C. C. Bell to Wed Candy Collins
description: Eda. Grace Collins, an assistant counselor with T. Rowe Price Associates, investment counselors in Baltimore, and Charles Christopher Bell, a marketing representative in the dataprocessing division of International Business Machines there, plan to be married in June. Miss Collins, known as.Candy, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul D. Collins of Rye, N. Y., who have announced the engagement. Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Bell of Baltimore are the future bridegroom's parents.

title: Robustelli's Legacy: Giants Ready to Win
description: The one gripe Andy Robustelli says he has about leaving his job as director of operations of the Giants is that some people don't think he worked at his job.

title: Use of Hotel by Military Retirees Is Questioned by a House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP)  A luxury hotel built on a Hawaiian beach for warweary Vietnam troops is getting about $1 million a year from taxpayers and is being used chiefly by retired military personnel, a Congressional panel says.

title: STAMPS
description: For Pa?? traditionalists who cherish the religious paintings of the old masters, and the carols, toys and recollections of earlier times, this is a richly rewarding Christmas.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: The best thing that has happened to the Guggenheim Museum in quite some time is that the Thannhauser Collection has got itself desegregated.

title: Rapprochement Is Only
description: HONG KONG  Not too many years ago there was a Secretary of State, John Foster Dulles, who firmly believed the United States must exert every effort to contain monolithic Communism in the Soviet Union and China. One of his successors, Dean Rusk, argued just as passionately that the United States must go to war in Vietnam to check Chinese expansion.

title: Karen Grode Engaged To Alan Neal Terner
description: Karen Ruth Grode, an assistant to the producers of America Alive on NBCTV, plans to be married in September to Alan Neal Terrer of Bayside, Queens, a sales representative for the O. Berk Company, container distributors in Linden, N. J.

title: SHOP TALK
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR THIS is not the place to shop if you want to buy something simple like a needle and thread, but if you're looking for unusual toys and knickknacks, Cold Spring Harbor's Main Street is a shopper's paradise. There are only a few stores here, but they are well stocked and prepared to cater to the whims of their affluent clientele, who are easily among the most polite shoppers anywhere on the Island.

title: Holiday Morning
description: Twas the morning of Christmas, and not even dawn,

title: ART VIEW
description: The history of American art between the two World Wars is a subject likely to undergo some serious revisions iii the years ahead. Only lately has it dawned upon a new generation of art historians that many of the socalled classics of the period  paintings and sculptures familiar to us from constant display in the museums and repeated reproduction in the history books  might not represent the last word on the subject. New research is turning up the work of artists scarcely even remembered as names 20 years ago, and certain aspects of the period  the contribution of photography, for example  are now attaining a new visibility. A decade hence, the entire period between the wars will probably look vastly changed.

title: The Region
description: Governor Carey, who took office in 1975 with what seemed to be firm commitments to cleaning up New York's air and water, has since spent much of his environmental effort cleaning out the State Department of Environmental Conservation. Last week, Mr. Carey demanded the resignation of Peter A. A. Berle, making him the second Commissioner of Environmental Conservation with whom the Governor has been unable to live. Mr. Berle's replacement will be Robert Flacke, director of the Adirondack Park Agency.

title: MUSIC
description: MOST of us have a good deal to be thankful for in this holiday season, but the folks in Chappaqua may have received the nicest Christmas and Hanukkah present of all: After repeated delays stretching out over 15 months, the new Chappaqua Library has finally opened for business, musical as well as literary.

title: SHAH SAID TO PLAN CALIFORNIA PALACE
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 23 Reports are circulating among real estate brokers that the Shah of Iran is shopping for a large amount of land here in the Bel Air section.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAMSJuliet, beloved wife of Melvin, dear mother of Jonathan K., Laurence K. and Gall K., loving grandmother of Eileen, David and Catherine. Services Sunday, 12 noon at Gotterman's, 9860 Queens Blvd, corner of 66 Ave, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Food
description: Afine Hanukkah menu was demonstrated last week at Rosalie Waldman's cooking classes at the MidIsland Y.M.Y.W.H.A. in Plainview. In two hours Mrs. Waldman, a highly organized minidynamo, prepared an attractive meal that was remarkable for its ease of preparation as well as its sensible combination of fresh ingredients.

title: CONSUMERS UPHELD ON ACCESS TO DATA
description: A decision supporting the right of consumers to obtain information from Government agencies about commercial products has been issued in Manhattan by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: Susan Camp to Be Bride Of J.N. Tryforos in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Camp of Haverford, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Warren Camp, to James N. Tryforos, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas J. Tryforos of College Point. Queens.

title: Design
description: Taking a 15thcentury ruined castle and making it livable might seem to be an architect's nightmare. But two who have done it  Percy le Clerc, working for a client. and Robert Brown, on his own behalf  agree that in many ways it's easier than restoring a house of a later date. Both the castles shown here (actually, they are medieval towers or keeps) were in advanced stages of disintegration when restoration began. Neither had been lived in for centuries and, in both cases, most of the original wood beams and roofs had rotted and collapsed. However, their massive, fourfootthick walls had survived most of the ravages of man and nature and the basic structures were sound.

title: The Region
description: Continued

title: When the Money's Low at Christmas
description: THE ring looked almost like a Christmas ornament. A cluster of small rubies and diamond chips set in gold, it sparkled in the light as its owner juggled it in his hand. Then he asked, How much can you lend me for this?, and the illusion was broken. The man was in a pawnshop, and the ring, far from being a holiday bauble, was to be his means of getting cash for Christmas.

title: INTERVIEW
description: THERE had been ice on the roads all afternoon and AnneMarie Rasmussen, the former Mrs. Steven Rockefeller, was troubled. Her son, Steven Jr., now 18 years old, admitted he had not yet put snow tires on the car. Jennifer, who was three years younger, had to leave their New Canaan home within the hour for her father's house in Vermont. What to do?

title: FollowUp on the News
description: Like many a news story flowing out of Washington, it had the ring of authority and action:

title: Notes: More Women Flying on Business
description: They tote briefcases, wear welltailored suits and take 10 business flights a year, frequently to attend conventions. They are becoming more significant in the business world  and a key market for the airlines.

title: Music in Review
description: Singers by and large tend to be conservative musicians, particularly in their choice of material for a debut recital. Roxolana Roslak, who sang her first solo New York concert Tuesday night in Alice Tully Hall, proved to be an exception to this rule by devoting her energies primarily to unconventional and potentially unpopular 20thcentury fare by Webern, Hindemith and Shostakovich.

title: NEW JERSEY HOUSING
description: THE way in which some tenants describe it, the planned conversion of the fiveyearold Bristol House apartment building in Hackensack into a condominium is the greatest thing since sliced bread.

title: A College Where Education Ends Inside the Classroom
description: I remember last spring watching the theatrics of the National Collegiate championship basketball game. Kentucky was playing Duke. The fans packed in the stands shouted school cheers through cupped hands. Announcers in loud gold jackets and polished hair told the viewing audience how well Kentucky was playing and isn't this basketball at its finest?

title: Sarah Cooper Betrothed To Charles Klingenstein
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Cooper of Alta, Wyo., formerly of Fairfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Wright Cooper, to Charles Paul Klingenstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Klingenstein of Orleans, Mass., formerly of Purchase, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

title: Wendy Netkin Affianced To Dr. Jesse M. Cohen
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irving Netkin of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Netkin, to Dr. Jesse M. Cohen, an intern at the Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla. N. Y.

title: L.I. Woman Is Awarded $750,000 in Suit on Pill
description: A jury in Federal District Court in Brooklyn has awarded $750,000 to a woman from Stony Brook, L.I. who contended that a birthcontrol pill she had taken for five years caused her to have a paralyzing stroke.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station; New York, N.Y. 10249, or to any of the. following organizations:

title: GARDENING
description: MOST everyone has heard that it was Martin Luther who brought a fir tree in from the woods, decorated it and thereby invented the Christmas tree. Actually, evergreens of many sorts were used throughout much of Europe long before the Christian era in midwinter pagan rites, intended to insure the return of spring. As the region became Christianized, this custom was adopted as a part of the Christmas festivities.

title: BigName OwnerDrivers Making Things Hot for USAC
description: The United States Auto Club, hardly without a controversy of some sort in its 23year history, is currently beleaguered by the worst rift it has ever had. This schism is costing USAC the cream of its most valuable asset  championship racing, a series of 19 to 16 events nivoted on the Indianapolis 500.

title: Boat People Stir New Concern
description: PARIS  When France relinquished colonial rule over Indochina in 1954 after a sixyear war, it was thought that the emergence of the independent states of Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia would mark the end of French involvement. But 24 years and another  this time American  war later.

title: Betty Satterwhite and Laurence Sutter Will Wed in June
description: Betty Archer Satterwhite and Laurence B. Sutter, both of New York, plan to be married in June.

title: A Loss of Innocence, but Not Christmas
description: SAGAPONACK, N.Y.It had to happen sooner or later, of course. My youngest daughter, Tapp, is seven now, and with two bigmouth older siblings, I'm surprised it had lasted as long as it did. Nonetheless, there was an undeniable stab this season when Tapp not only expressed indifference toward writing to Santa Claus, but downright contempt.

title: Deaths
description: Abrams, Juliet

title: Mass Cult Immigration Violated Jones's Agreement With Guyana
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana As the remote agricultural station of Jonestown turned into a crowded armed camp in its last 15 months, the Guyanese Government turned a blind eye to the mass immigration of Jim Jones's followers and deaf ear to numerous warnings that the camp was out of control, according to interviews and documents.

title: ANTIQUES
description: The stockings were hung by the chimney with care, / In the hopes that St. Nicholas soon would be there.

title: A StrippedDown Tale
description: BAD things happen to Luke Carr, the magazinewriter hero of Thomas Williams's eighth novel. The book opens just after Carr's wife and two children die in an airplane crash. An assignment to do a piece about a Manhattan construction disaster

title: Tommie Smith at 34: His Struggle Goes On
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  They challenged him on the first day of class with greetings like, Hey, man, what's happening?

title: ...And a Help Line
description: THREE weeks after the birth of their first child, reality intruded into the Smiths' household. Their plump and pink child, instead of cooing, cried most of the time. The new mother said that she began to feel like a failure; the new father began to mumble that he had not wanted a child in the first place. He called the PostPartum Help Line.

title: Oil Price Rise Cuts Two Ways
description: Oil prices, Alfred E. Kahn remarked last week, are a natural environment for schizophrenia. The perspective was that of an oil importer, and the context, price controls. Although few American officials like them, they may be needed, on gasoline at least, to curb down spiraling costs at the pump.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: It is a far cry from the murderously charming Danny in Night Must Fall or the upwardly mobile coal miner in The Corn Is Green, but it is all in a night's work for Emlyn Williams, the noted playwrightactor who has become a youthful 19thcentury Playboy of the Weekend World in a oneman show at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, Tuesday through Dec. 31.

title: At Odds Over Corporate Governance
description: WASHINGTON  Last June, around a burnished mahogany table in the 11thfloor board room of the law firm of Wilmer, Cutler & Pickering, a group of seven very public men met very privately. Their goal: to seek a consensus on an issue that, perhaps more than any other, promises to exacerbate the battle between government and industry in the year ahead  an issue that goes under the rubric of corporate governance. Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, who had brought them together, set the stakes at the first of what would be three meetings. Gentlemen, he said, if this group can agree on a legislative proposal, I can almost assure you that it will become law.

title: Kathy A. Metzler Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Metzler of Far Rockaway, Queens, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Kathy A. Metzler, to Colin L. Hoogoboom, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roel Hoogeboom of Wallkill, N.Y. A weling planned in June.

title: AllEast Football
description: Wide Receivers  Dave Shula, Dartmouth, Soph.; Gordon Jones, Pittsburgh, Sr., and Joe Senser, West Chester, Sr.

title: Damage of Grasshopper Invasion Falls Short of Early Predictions
description: TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 23 (AP)  Grasshoppers caused millions of dollars in damage across the Middle West last summer, but the destruction was not nearly so great as agriculture officials had at first expected.

title: Stephanie Wolf to Wed in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin P. Wolf of Randolph, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Stephanie Wolf, to Michael Rosenbium, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Rosenblum of Levittown, L.I. A wedding in May is planned.

title: To Dream the Impossible Chic
description: THE minimal look in home decoration  spare as a nun's cell, as devoid of unnecessary clutter as a spacecraft  is In. So are childless marriages, the minimal look in human relationships. My husband and I sigh a lot these days, considering the hopelessness of our situation in such a culture. We who were so fearlessly chic in our white buck shoes, Peter Pan collars, early American furniture reproductions and spectacular fertility are irretrievably Out.

title: CRIME
description: A couple of years ago Max Wilk wrote a thriller  a chase novel set in Greece. Nothing could be more different than his latest book, THE MOVING PICTURE BOYS (Norton,$8.95). Now the locale is Hollywood, with a neat caper involving a screenwriter and the film industry, and a couple of crooks newly released from jail.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: AN acquaintance of our recently returned to the world of the hourly wage etiner, interrupting her career as an artist to make some instant money for the holidays. She took a job as a partime clerk in a department store somewhere on the Island.

title: A Place to Learn Parenting...
description: PARENTS PLACE is my salvation on a rainy day, a young mother confided. Other days, it's still a good place because I always learn something new that will help me  and Allison, too. She's three, an only child. Both of us can get lonely in the suburbs.

title: Convict Says Confession to Killing Was Only Ruse
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Dec. 23 (AP) Bob Williams was 18 years old, a selfdescribed punk kid, when he slapped his girl friend in an argument and wound up in a California juvenile correction camp in 1956. While there, he says now, he got word that the girl was planning to marry someone else.

title: DINING OUT
description: I'M Just Wild About Harry was written in the 1920's, but it has been revived this season in Eubie! the Broadway musical. Now Westchester has another reason to singalong: Harry Bruce Kirchner, chef and owner of Harry's Sauteuse, turns out a very fine dinner at very modest prices.

title: Ann G. Fairlie To Be a Bride
description: Ann Gelston Fairlie and Konrad M. Michelsen, both of New York, plan to be married May 12.

title: $50 Million in Tickets Sold for Instant Lottery
description: ALBANY. Dec. 23 (UPI)  The 1 Love New York instant lottery has sold $50 million worth of tickets, with 6,000 people claiming prizes of $50 to $5,000, according to the lottery's director. John Quinn.

title: Miss Green Plans Bridal
description: Mrs. Griffiths Green of Summit and Green Island, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter. Catharine Evans Green, to Fletcher Clement Booker 3d of Boston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Booker Jr. of Dallas, Pa. The couple plan to be married Jan. 27 in Boston.

title: Elizabeth Judge to Be Bride Of Ronald Weldon April 21
description: Mrs. Kathryn Rockelmann Judge of New York and David Howard Judge of West Springfield, Mass., have an. flounced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Martha Judge, to Ronald William Weldon, son of Mrs. Richebourg Gaillard 3d of Pensacola, Fla., and Ronald Hamilton Weldon of Mobile, Ala.

title: College Football AllStar Teams
description: ALLAMERICA

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE EISENHOWERS Reluctant Dynasty. By Steve Neal. 493 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $10.95.

title: Jaycee Ban on Women Set Back
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 23 (AP)The national Jiycees have been temporarily banned by court order from removing women members from Massachusetts chapters. Judge Thomas A. Morse Jr. of Middlesex County Superior Court, acting on a request by a women's organization, ruled yesterday that the national organization could not enforce a menonly policy for at least two weeks. He said he will decide Jan. 5 whether to grant preliminary injunction.

title: Editors' Choice
description: THE COUP, by John Updike. (Knopf, $8.95.) Rich, surprising, Wien funny novel set in a mythical African country.

title: Poor Little Rich Lady
description: FOR the purposes of biography, the life of Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney would seem to offer everything. She was, first of all. immensely rich. In 1875, when Gertrude Vanderbilt was born, B. H. Friedman reminds us in the opening sentence of this new book, she was the eldest daughter of the eldest son of the richest American family. She was therefore born into a world of privilege and celebrity that is now, for the late 20thcentury reader, almost as much a legend as the world of Versailles. Simply as a figure in the social history of American wealth, Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney is a literary subject of tremendous interest  and all the more so, of course, because of the literary tradition that, from Henry James and Edith Wharton onward, has formed around the figures of her class.

title: INVESTING
description: With consumer prices continuing to soar at discouragingly fast rates, investors  especially retirees  often need to squeeze every last penny of income from their savings. Investing in Governmentguaranteed loans may be a way to do it.

title: Leaders as Celebrities
description: IN our day, leaders have given way to celebrities, according to James MacGregor Burns, the Woodrow Wilson Professor of Government at Williams College and Pulitzer Prizewinning biographer of Franklin D. Roosevelt. Interest in the texts of Winston Churchill's speeches has given way to fascination with the contents of Henry Kissinger's garbage. This, in Professor Burns's view, is our loss, for we need leaders.

title: SPORTS
description: IT'S now official. Skiing is a risky sport. As if y'u didn't know already. But for the first time since the slatsage, ski area operators are being forced to admit that the oncehorrendous concept is true. One can get hurt sliding down the snowy side of a mountain, or worse, going up.

title: Patrolmen Slain; Reward Offered
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 23 (AP)Rewards totaling $16,000 were offered for information in the deaths of two veteran California Highway Patrol officers found. shot to death beside their patrol car. The officers, Roy Blether, 50 years old, and William Freeman, 35, were killed early yesterday while patrolling Interstate 80, the police said. The two officers, both shot in the head, were found face down behind their patrol car, which was parked with its red light flashing. Their service pistols and the shotgun from their car were missing, the police said No arrests have been made.

title: Miss Heyman, Ira Sedransk Are Married
description: Lynne Rose Heyman, daughter of Mrs. Geraldine L. Heyman of Aspen, Colo., and D. John Heyman of Armonk, N.Y., and Stony Brook, LI., was married yesterday to Ira H. Sedransk, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley J. Seclransk of Hewlett, L.I.

title: 21 Are Reported Dead In Turkey in Attacks And Riots by Rightists
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 23 (Reuters)  Twentyone people were killed and at least 150 were injured today in rioting by rightists in the southern Turkish town of Kahramanmaras, 310 miles from Ankara, according to local news reports.

title: Doctor: Jones Was Close to Death
description: NEW ORLEANS; Dec. 23 (UPI)  The Rev. Jim Jones had an extremely high fever and other ailments and only a few weeks to live at the time of the killings And suicides in Guyana on Nov. 18, a physician who had treated the People's Temple leader said in an interview published today.

title: East End Places to Ring In '79 On a Somewhat Different Note
description: NEW YEAR'S EVE, to twist an old phrase, could be said to be a time to wring out the old and fling in the new. For all its pretensions to newness, however, the partyladen evening is usually thick with familiar rituals ranging from Guy Lombardo's Royal Canadians' rendition of Auld Lang Syne to midnight champagne and noisemakers. While :host of the Island's East End bars and restaurants facilitate the traditional observances, many also feature local bands whose idiosyncrasies add a touch of the unfamiliar to the proceedings.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: In theory, the Extradition Clause of the Constitution makes it impossible for a person to escape the consequences of a crime by crossing a state line. In practice, however, particularly in politically charged cases, one state sometimes refuses to honor another's request to return a fugitive. Last week the Supreme Court barred most such refusals.

title: Thomas Lincoln Fianc Of Maryann M. Bohner
description: Maryann Margaret Bohner, a clinical instructor at the University of Virginia School of Nursing in Charlottesville, and Thomas Branson Lincoln, a land surveyor with Kurt M. Gloeckner, a Charlottesville engineersurveyor company, plan to be married in March.

title: 2 Carter Aides Reflect White House Budget Battle
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23  Two top Presidential advisers, disparate in appearance and outlook, have come to personify the dispute within the White House over how much money to allocate for social welfare.

title: New XRay System Can Detect Child Abuse Cases, Expert Says
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 22 (UPI)  An Xray system has reportedly been developed that helps physicians to diagnose cases of child abuse and also halves radiation exposure to patients.

title: Rise in Crime Rate Is Laid to Track
description: EAST RUTHERFORD OFFICIALS of this Bergen County borough contend that the crime rate here has increased by almost 50 percent since the opening of the Sports Complex in the Hackensack Meadowlands in September 1976.

title: Evening Papers Say Good Morning
description: Question: What is an afternoon newspaper?

title: 50% GUT IS WEIGHED IN CITY'S HOSPITALS
description: Mayor Koch will seek to reduce the number of municipal hospitals the city operates by as many as half by 1982, according to the Mayor's top health adviser, Dr. Martin Cherkasky.

title: Stopping At The Savoy
description: When the general manager of the Savoy Hotel, in London, reaches for his silver cigarette case, he thinks about the Queen Mother of Bhutan. I didn't know Bhutan existed, the manager said not long ago, when he recalled the Queen's first stay at the hotel, in 1972. She is a charming woman, and I was summoned. Royal command. She presented me with a cigarette case, and told me that she was touched by the fact that the flowers in her room were the colors of the Bhutan flag. And she was intrigued  how did I know the national colors? I told her I had a book of flags, and always looked up the colors when there was a chief of state or a Prime Minister at the Savoy. And then she asked, how did I get the name Bhutanfava?

title: NoFrills Help
description: IN a woodpaneled office, tucked between the stamp and coin and major appliance departments, a woman quietly planned her longawaited divorce. Her lawyer's office was just 50 feet away from the toy department at the Levittown TSS store.

title: Composers Who Sang Praises Of New York City
description: As several recent records demonstrate, leading musical theater composers and lyricists, including talents as diverse as Irving Berlin and Kurt Weill, were fascinated by New York City's sights and sounds, its complexity, its attractions and contradictions, and wrote numerous songs and shows on every aspect of the urban experience.

title: A Town's Budget: Another View
description: AS Supervisor of the town of Greenburgh, I feel it is incumbent on me to respond to unfounded allegations made by Joel C. Holiber on this page last week concerning the town budget and administration. Unlike Mr. Holiber, a political activist and a defeated candidate of the opposition political party in the last municipal election, I personally vouch for the accuracy of all my statements.

title: Other World Events
description: The Provisional section of the Irish Republican Army had threatened to ring in the holiday'season with bombings in England, and last week they started to make good on their threat. Bombs exploded in shopping sections of London, Manchester, and other English cities. There were also more bombings in Northern Ireland, where sniper attacks also killed four British soldiers.

title: How They Run On
description: Once, a few microwaves ago, there were a couple of books about Ordinary Running that, told you how to put one colorful foot in front of the other  and run. But Ordinary Running, given a psychoanalytic age with biorhythm, was not enough. And so one publisher brought forth Existential Running, a slightly more exalted concept allowing that you could Run and Be at the same time, which proved a popular idea (I am who I am and can be nothing but that. Running and Being), if somewhat simpleminded. With the 20th century only threequarters done, 25 million Americans had run very far, very fast. They had about exhausted the Human Potential Movement.

title: Cleveland Tunnel Sees Light Plant
