Jacobsen Antiques, a twostory brick building on the corner of Main Street and Shore Road in Cold Spring Harbor, provides an elegant setting for the collection of one of the Island's largest dealers in fine 18thand 19thcentury American and English antiques. The opening of the shop this month represents a milestone in Mr. Jacobsen's 20year career in the antiques business on the Island.

title: States Get $239 Million In U.S. Forest User Fees
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP)  A record of $239.3 million is being sent to 39 states and Puerto Rico as their share of Federal collections from timber sales and other fees charged users of national forests, Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland has announced.

title: Picture Credits
description: 1ED KOREN

title: Trees and Their Decorators: All Dressed Up
description: There was an embarrassment of Christmas trees at Club El Morocco Thursday night, but not to worry. The trees should, by now, be in the children's wards of. six hospitals. Let no one say the rich are selfish.

title: What's Doing in KANSAS CITY
description: Raised on a diet of Westerns, many Americans think of Kansas City as a stereotype: a cowtown isolated mid dry, dusty plains and prairies, impervious to cultural currents from the coasts. Truth is, this city set among rolling green hills is riding the crest of en economic boom. Kansas City belongs in spirit to the Sunbelt, despite sometimes bitter winters. Secure in the supremacy of its steaks and its jazz, Kansas City is experiencing growth and expansion that portends well for the next decade.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: A touch of natural color is always welcome these days, so if your shopping is done; you might want to get over to the Planting Fields Arboretum today to take in the annual winter poinsettia diiplay. In addition to hundreds of brilliant redflowering poinsettias,, the main greenhouse will also feature a wide variety of other seasonal plants: Christmas. cactus, cherries and peppers, cyclamen and kalanchoe. Although it is closed tomorrow, the greenhouse exhibition will be open from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. daily through midFebruary. Admission to the arboretum, on Planting Fields Road, Oyster Bay, is $1.50 on weekends, free the rest of the time

title: Ronald MacKenzie, 75, Dies; Led Lake Placid Olympic Organizers
description: Ronald MacKenzie, the 75yearold president of the Lake Placid Olympic Organizing Committee, collapsed of a heart attack and died yesterday afternoon during a dedication ceremony for a new 70meter ski jump outside Lake Placid, N.Y., just as the first skier was about to begin.

title: Rouben TerArutunian's Designs That Work for Ballet
description: If playwrights check out performances of their plays and composers give ear to the way their music is rendered, it should surprise no one that stage designers monitor the mounting of their scenery. And so it is that Rouben TerArutunian, probably today's most influential creator of sets for dance, was spotted in the audience at a recent performance of The Nutcracker, the joyful, toyful Christmas perennial choreographed by George Balanchine for the New York City Ballet.

title: The Pregnant Pause Challenges Actress
description: PICTURE this: You're a young wife, a struggling actress without too much experience. You audition for a part on the CBSTV soap opera Love of Life, and the powers that be like you enough to let you appear for a couple of days.

title: MAILBAG
description: To the Editor:

title: Antitorpedo Devices Are Returned to Navy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) Three classified antitorpedo devices mistakenly sold as surplus last year have been voluntarily returned to the Navy.

title: Bused Blacks and Whites Gain in Tests, Study Says
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 73 (AP) Ten years after this university city went against national trends by voluntarily and peacefully integrating its public schools by busing, studies show that whites as well as members of minority moos have benefited.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23  The major themes of 1978 in the United States have been reform abroad and reaction at home. It has been a year of painful change, and is ending in contention between those who would prefer to conserve the past and those who would rather risk the innovations and uncertainties of the future.

title: The World
description: Some of the edge might have been taken off President Carter's announcement of full relations with China had CocaCola gone public first. Two days before his statement, it won exclusive rights to sell cola beverages in China.

title: Randi Greenberg Sets May Nuptials
description: Randi Lynn Greenberg, a producer, and Jeffrey D. Kapelman, a New York lawyer, will be married in May at the Old Westbury (L.I.) Country Club.

title: THE LIVELY ARTS
description: WHEN Cheryl Rosen of Worcester, Mass., recently went on a dream date  courtesy of Sixteen magazinewith Billy and Bobby Alessi, she toured the Glen Head home of the singersongwriter team of identical twins, rode their dirt bikes, sailed and was taken to dinner at the Milleridge Inn in Roslyn.

title: Ensemble Of Early Music Plays
description: Christmas music comes in many forms, not all of them familiar. Friday evening in Alice Tully Hall the Early Music Ensemble began a threeconcert series there (the others are Jan. 12 and Feb. 2) with a Christmas program. But instead of carols, this was a collection of English Christmas music from the 13th through the early 17th centuriesmostly anonymous, but with three works by John Dunstable, Richard Pygott and Henry VIII.

title: It's Christmastime In the County
description: CHRISTMASTIME in Westchester is long lines at department stores, the Nutcracker or, as at Sunnyside in Tarrytown, a trip back in time to Christmases past. It is teenagers who step up to the Counter at McDonald's and order a $5 gift certificate instead of a Big Mac, and street deCorations that are matched in their splendor by those on the front lawns of homes.

title: Andrew Mark to Marry Marke Ellen Rubenstein in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert Rubenstein of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marke Ellen Rubenstein, to Andrew Mark, son of Dr. and Mrs. Julian Mark, also of Stamford.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE modest 19thcentury brick building at 237 Washington Street, Hoboken, conceals a lot of surprises. Once a bar so tough that it was used for a scene in On the Waterfront, the place is now a neighborhood center that attracts regulars who eat there every day.

title: DINING OUT
description: CHINESE dining is given distinctive treatment at Choung's in Roosevelt Field. It's partly the setting, a lovely one by any standard, but particularly unusual in a Chinese restaurant. Picture comfortable gray EMU burgundy velvet banquettes, deep wine carpeting and a shower of pinpoint lights to set off pristine white tablecloths, pretty dishes and silver. The teacups have handles, the flatware includes knives. A row of ceramic figures and a couple of wall panels merely hint at the Oriental scene.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: This Week:

title: Indoor Soccer Gets Off to Successful Start
description: To some players, coaches and soccer administrators, the inaugural game of the Major Indoor Soccer League on Friday night was close to a revelation  a good concept. To others, the game had plenty of rough edges. To the 10,386 mostly young and curious fans, it was exciting.

title: Beverly Dawn Eisenstadt And Physician to Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leo Eisenstadt of the Bronx have made known the engagement of their daughter, Beverly Dawn Eisenstadt, to Dr. Martin Samuel Bilsker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Bitsker of Miami. A wedding is planned in June.

title: GARDENING
description: WE LIVE in a world of stars. It is at Christmastime, of course, when the stars in our children's eyes outshine those in the Christmas tree, that we are most aware of them.

title: Vienna: Sounds of Sacred Music Mexico City: Posadas and Piatas
description: The glory of Vienna at Christmas is its music, and midnight mass on Christmas Eve, a rite known locally as mette, is often an artistic event as well as an act of worship or social custom. The music offered this year will be mostly by Schubert, who has been honored throughout the year on the occasion of the 150th anniversary of the death  on Nov. 19  of the only great Viennese composer native to the city. Choirs and orchestras have been rehearsing his masses for weeks, and some of the performances will later become available on records.

title: The Problem of NoShow Repairmen
description: CHAPPAQUA DEAR MADAM, the communiqu from the appliance refinishers read, our representative will call at your home on Wednesday between 8 A.M. and 5:30 P.M. Please be at home.

title: The Uncommon Artistry of Joan Armatrading
description: Joan Armatrading is an unlikely star in today's music business, where personality usually counts more than character at the cash register. Miss Armatrading, the British singer and composer of West Indian descent, is an international star in the British Commonwealth, where her five albums since 1973 have sold in the milBong; yet, she remains vastly unknown to America's massive teenage market. A reluctant performer in her early years, she remains a private artist who shuns pop music's social circuit. Nevertheless, her remarkably individual composing and vocal talents are so considerable that she has attracted some powerful admirers (Bob Dylan and George Benson among them), and with the release of her latest A&M album, To the Limit, she seems on the verge of wider recognition.

title: Hofstra Beats Manhattan, 7270, On Late Foul Shots by Swanson
description: Doug Swanson scored on two free throws with four seconds remaining yesterday to give Hofstra a 7270 basketball victory over Manhattan. It was the Jaspers sixth straight loss.

title: Washington Plans Affirmative Action Push in '79
description: Thirteen years after Lyndon Johnson issued the first Executive Order calling for affirmative action programs in industry, corporate America is today confronted by a bewildering crosscurrent of developments in that area. Among them: A major reorganization of the Government's enforcement machinery along with promises that 1979 will see an unprecedented Federal agency effort to increase compliance; a decision by the Supreme Court to consider whether an affirmative action program constitutes reverse discrimination and is thus illegal.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: TWO of the county's longestrunning extravaganzas, the Solid Waste Show and the Con Edison Takeover Revue, seemed to come together last week even before the curtain had fallen on the decision by the County Board of Legislators to put the proposed takeover to the voters as a referendum next November.

title: Roller Skating + Disco Dancing = Two Hit Rinks
description: TAKE equal parts roller skating and disco dancing, stir in some flashy lighting and mix with hard, fast music. The result is roller disco, and it is here. In just one year, the county's two new rinks have attracted the young, their parents and those in between in such numbers that expansion is being considered by both Skate City Inc. of Yorktown Heights and Easy Glider in the Baldwin Place Mall.

title: The Man at the Controls
description: MIAMI  Lewis B. Maytag, 52 years old, has run National Airlines for 16 years. Born into the washingmachine family, he still sits on the Maytag Company board. But his real love is aviation.

title: Article 13 -- No Title
description: Christmas in Mexico City is, first of all, a feast for the eye. With a profligate expenditure of energy that dazzles visitors and residents alike, Mexicans paint their buildings with light. The skyscrapers that mark the capital's center are awash with neon, creating pictures of the Holy Family at the Manger, the Three Kings following the Star of Bethlehem, and sometimes even that holiday invader from the North, Santa Claus. And in the Dimlo, the city's vast central plaza, strings of electric bulbs outline every pilaster, cupola, arch and pediment of the Spanish colonial facades of the great Cathedral and the Palace.

title: Marita Koch Selected As Track Athlete of Year
description: LOS ALTOS, Calif. (AP)ast Germany's Marita Koch, who set or tied five world records during the year, has been named women's track and field athlete of the year by the monthly magazine Track and Field News.

title: Way Cleared for Hudson's Bay to Pursue Major Merger
description: A dramatic battle in Canada for control of the Simpsons departmentstore chain ended abruptly last week when Simpsons withdrew from a plan to merge with SimpsonsSears. That left the Hudson's Bay Company free to pursue its rival bid for Simpsons.

title: Peyton Morris, Mark E. Petty Plan to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Morris of Southport., Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Peyton Can Morris, to Mark E. Petty, son of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Petty of Charlottesville, Va., formerly of Cincinnati and Manila. An April wedding is planned.

title: Goldwater Attacks Tie to China As Illegal Yielding to Expediency
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23  President Carter's Dec. 15 television address announcing the normalization of relations with China and the ending of the United States defense treaty with Taiwan may be remembered in history as 10 minutes that lived in infamy, Senator Barry Goldwater said today.

title: T.F. Breen Fianc Of Deidre O'Brien
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward R. O'Brien of Westbury, L.I., and Tortola, British Virgin Islands, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deidre O'Brien, to Thomas F. Breen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis.1. Breen of ManhasSet, L.I.

title: Departing Regulator Recalls Banking Battles
description: BOSTON  Carol S. Greenwald, the outgoing Massachusetts Commissioner of Banking who for four years raised the hackles of the industry she regulated, wants to be remembered for her management skills as well as for her reform efforts.

title: Indians' Tribal Courts Prepare to Take Over Child Custody  Cases
description: DENVER, Dec. 23  For years, Indian children have been taken from their families and placed in foster care or put up for adoption in such great numbers that Indian leaders, church groups and child welfare experts have been putting increasing pressure on the Federal Government for change.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, DECEMBER 25, 1978

title: Flash, From Pentagon: Victory Over CRations
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 24 (UPI) The Pentagon, in effect giving a present to the armed forces, is phasing out the canned Crations that made servicemen of three wars wonder if they really wanted to eat.

title: Manhattan Theater CIub Books Play on Beethoven
description: Beethoven/Karl, a play based on the tempestuous relationship between Ludwig von Beethoven and Karl, his nephew, will be presented at the Manhattan Theater Club, 321 Fast 73d Street, Jan. 328.

title: Here Is Israel to Conclude Its CoasttoCoast Tour
description: Here Is Israel, a multimedia songanddance production, is to conclude coasttocoast tour with a performance at 8 P.M. Thursday in Town Hall under the auspices of the Israeli Consulate General.

title: Sports World Specials
description: The trim, baldish man strode briskly through the rain as he walked crosstown to Times Square the other night, easily outdistancing any taxi he might have taken in the evening traffic. No one stopped him for his autograph or to talk about his favorite sport. He doesn't have an American Express card, but so what? A lot of people wouldn't recognize his name on a credit card anyway.

title: Helping Schools to Help Themselves
description: Frank Macchiarola, the New York City Schools Chancellor, is testing the city's budget climate by proposing 197980 expenditures of $3 billion, up $170 million from this academic year. Mr. Macchiarola. not oblivious to New York's fiscal woes, hopes to tap Federal and state sources for the new money. The school budget also represents the first formal statement of the new Chancellor's instructional and administrative priorities. While his educational philosophy seems sound, his revenue projections may be unduly optimistic.

title: Judge Frees Inmates for Holiday
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24 (AP) Municipal Court Judge Daniel Weinstein ordered at least two dozen inmates released from the San Francisco City Jail over the weekend on their own recognizances. I was at the Jail anyway on weekend duty, Judge Weinstein said. They were misdemeanants  a few drunks who are better off at the Salvation Army and at St. Anthony's; a few charged with petty crimes; at least 10 in there with under $150 in traffic warrants.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HALLELUJAH! Quick. Name three presents this season that New Yorkers have cause to treasure. It's easy.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Boat Hopes For Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 24  Sailboats are expected to emerge as an im portant new export for South Korea, accoto industry sources.

title: 71 Flee Apartment Building Fire; Arson Unit Asked to Investigate
description: LOWELL, Mass., Dec. 24 (AP)  For the second consecutive Christmas season, more than 70 residents of a tenement building here had to be evacuated yesterday because of a fire.

title: Murder in Cambodia Said to Be Meant as a Lesson
description: PEKING, Dec. 24 (Reuters)  Cambodian officials were quoted today as saying that a terroriststyle attack that killed a Briton in Phnom Penh was motivated politically to show that the Government could not protect its friends.

title: Iona Makes The big Time A Good Time
description: BROTHER JOHN DRISCOLL, the president of Iona College, couldn't understand. He had authorized the maximum number of scholarships and the maximum number of games permitted under intercollegiate regulations, but still the school wasn't winning.

title: Radical Changes by New Leader Leave Many Muslims Disaffected
description: As the fourth anniversary of the death of Elijah Muhammad approaches, the World Community of AlIslam of the West, formerly the Black Muslims, is still reeling from the radical changes instituted by Mr. Muhammad's son and successor, Wallace Deen Muhammad.

title: A Carol for Children
description: Now and then, Ogden Nash, admired for his humorous poems, would write one straight. At Christmastime, 1934, with the nation in a depression and European dictators riding high, he produced A Carol for Children. It began:

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. N249, or to any of the following organizations:

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Freight Train Cars Leave Tracks
description: SPRING CITY, Tenn., Dec. 24 (AP)As many as 41 cars of a Southern Railway freight train derailed today seven miles from here, the authorities said. No injuries were reported, and no hazardous materials were being carried on the train, the authorities said. The train was carrying mosly lumber, new automobiles and farm tractors.

title: Christmas in EnglandA Dickens of a Holiday
description: LONDON, Dec. 24  It was 135 Christmases ago when Charles Dickens told how poor Bob Cratchit had been humiliated by his boss when he dared ask for a few extra hours off.

title: Help Is Offered For Alcoholics In Construction
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 22  Building construction workers and their employers in Westchester have joined in a threeyear, federally financed pilot program to find and assist alcoholic carpenters, bricklayers, laborers and others who are threats to themselves as well as to those who work with them.

title: Holiday Closings
description: Banks, businesses, stock markets, commodities exchanges, government offfices and most retail establishments in the United States, Canada and Europe will be closed today for Christmas.

title: Britain Joins Dream Of a DeLorean Auto
description: LONDON, Dec. 24 So formidable is the reputation of John Z. DeLorean in auto circles that dealers bought 30,000 of his proposed sports cars long before ground was broken for the plant to build them  a plant on which he persuaded the British taxpayers to risk more than $100 million.

title: Chess:
description: Joseph Bradford, a darkhorse entrant, won the 79th annual United States Open Championship in Phoenix, Ariz., with a 101 score in the Swiss system tourney.

title: TROUBLED COLLEGES KEEP BUSINESS GOING
description: SCRANTON, Pa., Dec. 22  The closing two weeks ago of a small liberal arts college in Vermont has focused national attention on an even smaller educational consulting company, run by a jackof alltrades former military man out of his home here.

title: Wilkison Prevails in 5 Sets
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 24 (UPI)  Unseeded Tim Wilkison won a fiveset match in brutal heat today against Kim Warwick of Australia and captured the $200,000 New South Wales tennis championship on the White City Court.

title: Louis de Rochemont, 79, Is Dead; Producer of Film Documentaries
description: Louis Charles de Rochemont, the documentary film maker who introduced the nonfiction approach to Hollywood featurefilm production, died Saturday night in a nursing home near his Newington, N.H., home. He would have turned 80 wars old next Jan. 13.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: BOSTON, Dec. 24  At this season, just six years ago, American aircraft were carrying out the heaviest bombing campaign in history: the Christmas bombing of North Vietnam. Over 11 days, starting Dec. 18, 1972, B52's and other planes made 2,000 strikes against Hanoi and Haiphong.

title: De Gustibus The Spaghetti For a Holiday
description: In a recent moment of reminiscence, I recalled the early years in my mother's boarding house and spoke specifically and with some fondness of a holiday meal when, in lieu turkey and at the request of the children of the house, we dined on  were indeed regaled with  my mother's chicken spaghetti. Many people wrote or telephoned to ask for that recipe which was printed in this paper about three years ago. Here is that recipe again. It is a chicken spaghetti with mushrooms, ground beef and a tomato and cream sauce seasoned with garlic. It is a fine dish to serve for a crowd. And, incidentally, you could substitute leftover turkey meat for the chicken.

title: The Editorial Notebook Tut Tut
description: Impossible as it seems, the Treasures of Tutankhamun live up to their advance billing. There are greater periods in Egyptian art, but none with more appeal. The impressions are vivid; the gold is dazzling; the colors breathtakingly fresh. Set against the drama of the photographs of the search and discovery in the desert, the Tutankhamun story has no peer. But it has its price.

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON CAUGHT in the middle: the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service. The Government's labornegotiating arm faces a conflict between its traditional role of mediating labor disputes and the new question of the Administration's antiinflation program.

title: RULING IS EXPECTED ON POLICE RECORDS
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Dec. 24  A Federal district judge will decide tomorrow whether three city officials have complied with a subpoena directing them to turn over records on police internal affairs and personnel to a grand jury investigating alleged use of excessive force in a 1977 incident involving two Hispanic couples.

title: What Makes 76ers Click?
description: George McGinnis is gone and so is Lloyd Free. Julius Erving is the Philadelphia 76ers captain, Bobby Jones is the other forward and there is a new whirling offense. Henry Bibby is the shooter and Maurice Cheeks, a rookie from West Texas State, the playmaker. Joe Bryant is the first substitute at forward and Steve Mix's playing time has been cut considerably.

title: Robert A. Lehrman Weds Susan Thaul
description: Susan Jo Thaul, a singer and storyteller, and Robert A. Lehrman, a senior writer for Texaco Inc., were married yesterday at the Swan Club in Glenwood Landing, N.Y. Rabbi David Teutsch of Spring Valley, N.Y.. officiated, assisted by Nancy FuchsKreimer, a rabbinical student and a childhood friend of the bride.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Flushed with success over deregulating the airlines,Washington is now focusing on the trucking industry, but the overcrowded bandwagon of advisors working on the effort indicates a bumpy road ahead. [Page 33.]

title: World News Briefs
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 24 (AP)  At least 55 people were killed in rioting between two Moslem sects in southeastern Turkey during the weekend, officials said today.

title: Q. Oh, Ghost of Mr. Arbuthnot Past, how should we celebrate the Christmas holiday?
description: A. In a nutshell, the man in the street should hurry to the bosom of his loving family, place the Yule log on a crackling fire, open gailywrapped gifts, then sit down to a feast fit for a king. And afterward one and all should frolic in the blankets of snow outside.

title: Chilton to Print Chinese Textbook
description: The Chilton Company, a magazine and book publisher, announced that, starting next November, it would print in Chinese the first volume of American Engineering and Industry, a series of books providing technical information about American products and services. Chilton noted that a similar series had become popular among Russian and Polish businessmen.

title: Eagles Miss LastMinute Field Goal in 1413 Loss
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 24  In the kind of frantic closing sequence that has marked their play all season, the Atlanta Falcons defeated the Philadelphia Eagles, 1413, today in a National Football League wildcard playoff game.

title: 3 Found Dead After Georgia Fire
description: BARNESVILLE, Ga., Dec. 24 (AP)The bodies of three members of a family were found today after a fire last night in their rural frame house southwest of here, the authorities said. Matt Haisten, director of a funeral home, identified the dead as Dewey Emanuel Nicholson and his wife, Della Pauline Berry Nicholson, both 53 years old; and her brother, Walter Benjamin Berry, 48.

title: Norway to Sell Notes
description: Norway disclosed over the weekend that it planned to sell $100 million of notes through a group of investment banking firms headed by Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. The notes, which will come due Jan. 15, 1984, are expected to be offered for sale in midJanuary.

title: Venus Is to Be Eclipsed By Moon at 6:18 A.M.
description: Beginning at 6:18 A.M., the planet Venus, which is currently the morning star, will be covered by the moon and will remain eclipsed until 7:36 A.M.. following sunrise.

title: Interest Groups' Campaign Gifts To House Leaders Doubled in '78
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24  Political committees representing corporations, unions and controversial causes gave more than twice as much money to House committee chairmen seeking reelection in 1978 as they did in the previous campaign.

title: Arrival of Christmas and Hanukkah. Captures the Spirit of New Yorkers
description: New Yorkers marked Christmas Eve and the arrival of Hanukkah yesterday with a crescendo of cheer and celebration and commerce.

title: WNET's Special Edition Receives $100,000 Grant
description: Special Edition, the WNETTV, Channel 13, news program that was born in late summer of the New York newspaper strike, has received an underwriting grant of $100,000 to allow it continue.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. 15thCentury Christmas Music, Anon.; Noel from Burgundy, Balbastre; Chorale Preludes for Christmas, Bach; Hark! Hear you not a cheerful voice?, Billings; Harpsichord Sonata in G minor, Durante.

title: Mexican Oil and U.S. Policy
description: A diplomat once remarked that since we took away Lhe best third of its land, United States relations with Mexico haven't been too bad. Both propositions may need revision.

title: Recruiting Alien Students
description: When China announced recently that it would be sending students to colleges and universities in the United States, some academic officials in this country remarked that now they could recruit students among the Chinese masses, so there was no longer a need to worry about impending enrollment declines. Of course, the Chinese intend to send only about 2,000 students here. Those who were jesting realize that they will have to find another solution to the enrollment problem.

title: Around the Nation
description: SCOTLANDVILLE, La., Dec. 24 (AP)  A storage tank filled with almost 3.3 million gallons of crude oil burned out of control today, destroying two homes and forcing the temporary evacuation of LOW persons in this Baton Rouge suburb.

title: U.N.'s Session: Plus for P.L.O.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 23  If anyone has profited from the 33d General Assembly, now in recess for the holidays, it is the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Brazil Requires PreEntry Visas
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 24 (AP) Tourists who wish to visit Brazil will need to get visas before they leave the United States, the Brazilian Government announced yesterday. American tourists had been able to enter Brazil with only passport and receive a visa at the port of entry.

title: The City
description: A 51yearold woman was arraigned in Manhattan Criminal Court and held in $25,000 bail yesterday in the fatal stabbing of her husband at their apartment during an argument over a Christmas present.

title: Problems of Success At Commercial Shearing
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio  There are no organization charts. Board members gather at a round table in the office of the chairman for meetings. The two top officers of Commercial Shearing Inc. still meet weekly with most of the management staff, who can drop in unannounced into their offices.

title: Richard E. Abramson Marries Mary J. Doerr in Boca Raton
description: Mary Joe Doerr, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alphonsus L. Doerr, was married yesterday afternoon to Richard E. Abramson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold B. Abramson. Both families live in Clifton, N.J., and Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Merle Singer performed the ceremony at the Beth El Temple in Boca Raton.

title: Urban League President Sees Elements of Unrest
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UPI)  The ingredients that contributed to urban unrest in the 1960's exist now and could precipitate a return to street protests, Vernon E. Jordan Jr., president of the National Urban League, said today.

title: Oil Sands: A Boomlet In Process
description: CALGARY, Alberta, Dec. 24  The pace of development in the oil sands region of western Canada is quickening as the result of escalating oil prices and the growing uncertainties over imported energy supplies.

title: Brazil's U.S. Trade Slowing
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  In 1974, Brazil imported $3.1 billion of products from the United States, making it America's sixthbiggest export market. Last year Brazil dropped to 13th place, importing only $2.4 billion of United States goods.

title: The Coach as Cult Figure
description: HAS anyone found it at all unseemly that there has been so much emphasis during this past week on the football coach as messiah? As that, and scapegoat. The Giants, having sacrificed John McVay, are seeking some new Helmsman wno can save them from themselves. The University of Colorado sees Chuck Fairbanks as such a wonder man that it tried to claim him even as he was preparing the New England Patriots to ascend toward the Super Bowl. And the Patriots are clinging Fairbanks, on scriptural authority. No man can serve two masters, the Patriots are saying. But what they mean to say is, He's our master, not yours.

title: An Outdoorsman Makes A Christmas Wish
description: COMING down off a mountain in the Catskills a few weeks ago, with the constellations blazing overhead and frozen snow crunching under foot, I was both startied and pleased by an owl that passea within a few feet of my head, hunting for mice among the bare bones of secondgrowth hardwoods. My hunting had ended, and his had just begun.

title: VANCE, IN BRUSSELS, IS UNABLE TO REVIVE ISRAELEGYPT TALKS
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 24  High officials of the United States, Egypt and Israel met today but failed to arrange a resumption of Middle East peace negotiations. They agreed, however, to maintain contacts and to try to avoid further mutual recriminations.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn Factory Blaze Injures Three Firemen
For a Small Texas Town, Oil and Gas Everywhere
description: MENARD, Tex., Dec. 21 This is season of contrasts in these parts, where the Texas Hill Country, crowned by cheery, evergreen garlands of live oak, flattens out into the great, treeless plains of West Texas.

title: 100 Cuban ExPrisoners Resettle In Venezuela  1,400 More Due
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 24 (Reuters)  More than 100 former Cuban prisoners arrived here today from Havana, a spokesman for Venezuela's airline said.

title: U.S. Embassy Guards In Iran Fire Tear Gas At Student Protesters
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 24  Students ran wildly through stalled traffic today, pounding car roofs with their fists and slipping sheets of paper that said Death to the Shah under windshield wipers.

title: The Menorah
description: The following, excerpted article by Theodor Herzl, the founder of political Zionism, first appeared in The Menorah Journal in 1915.

title: HoHoHo to You, Too!
description: Comes now the time if there is a timeFor greetings couched in rancid rhyme To the guys and dolls in the world of sport From Muhammad Ali to Margaret Court. It is Christmas Day! Make the welkin ring For Robert Arum and Donald King! (See them cheek to cheek by the light of the moon Like Charlie Finley and Bowie Kuhn.) Saludo! Sant! Joyeux Noel! To Alex Webster and Pete Rozelle, to Petey Anderson, Upton Bell, Carl Yastrzemski, Art Modell, That old meatwagon, Ray Arcel, And the pride of Canada, Jeffrey Fell! May Reggie Jackson put his heart in Every play so that Billy Martin Learns to love him as Billy should. Harrah for the knuckles Wilbur Wood!

title: Aide Says U.S. Discussed Issues Of Human Rights With Chinese
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24  The United States discussed human rights problems with China before making the decision to recognize the Peking Government and normalize diplomatic relations, a highranking State Department official said today.

title: Americans Flee Iran After Killing
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24  About 100 American oil company employees and dependents in Ahwaz, Iran, left the country today by plane after yesterday's murder there of Paul E. Grimm, the acting general manager for the Oil Services Company of Iran, a State Department spokesman said today.

title: Barbara Lehmann Married to Eugene Siegel
description: Barbara Lee Lehmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Manfred R. Lehmann of Lawrence, L.I., was married there yesterday in Congregation Beth Sholom to Eugene Isaac Siegel. son of Mrs. Jacob Siegel of Baltimore and the late Mr. Siegel. Rabbi Isaac Hutner performed the ceremony.

title: 1 Slain, 1 Hurt in Subway Shooting
description: A 17yearold boy was shot to death and a 16yearold girl wounded early yesterday morning when a gunman opened fire on a group of youths in a subway station in Washington Heights, the police said.

title: Faithful Donors Honor Custom To Help Needy
description: As Christmas and Hanukkah arrive, many of the contributors to the 67th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund make a special effort to support the yearly campaign.

title: DualLanguage Policy Accused of Dividing Canada
description: TORONTO, Dec. 24  Bilingualism, a policy instituted by the Canadian Government 10 years ago to promote national unity and mutual understanding, is instead causing divisiveness, misunderstanding and widespread waste, a growing number of critics are charging in both English and French.

title: Contributions to Chairmen
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25  Following is a list of chairmen of two Senate and 22 House committees, all those up for election in 1978. The table shows the percentage of the vote they received in last month's election, the amounts they raised and spent during the 1978 campaign, what was left over, the contributions they received from political action committees (PAC's) and the share of their spending that such contributions provided. All are Democrats.

title: TV SPORTS
description: TODAY

title: CambodiaVietnam Battles Spur U.S. Concern Over Proxy War
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24  The Carter Administration has become more concerned in recent days over increased fighting between Cambodia and Vietnam, which knowledgeable officials now characterize as fullscale war.

title: Spiritual Influence of Merton, the Author, Growing Stronger 10 Years After His Death
description: Thomas Merton, the Trappist monk who led thousands of readers toward a deeper spiritual life, died 10 years ago this month, but his influence seems to grow stronger all the time.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON  The best piece of legislation sponsored, fought for and signed by Jimmy Carter in the past year was what he liked to call civil service reform snatching management power away from the redoubtable Government bureaucracy and transferring it to elected officials. The longoverdue assault on civil service abuses could only be accomplished by a Democrat and the President deserves credit.

title: 8 in Family Die in Louisiana Fire; Lights on Christmas Tree Blamed
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 24 (UPI)  A fire, apparently touched off by a shortcircuit in an artificial Christmas tree's lights, killed eight children in a family today.

title: A Princess of Fashion Arrives on Seventh Avenue
description: Princess Irene Galitzine was showing her readytowear styles for the first time in her new headquarters at 530 Seventh Avenue with the same aplomb with which she presents her couture collection to wealthy private clients in her Rome salon on the Via Veneto.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: $5 to $25 Tab Placed On BreadWater Meal
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 24 (UPI) To raise money for its campaign against the death penalty, the Ohio chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union is holding a bread and water dinner.

title: Cerebral Palsy Telethon Set for Next Weekend
description: A 20hour United Cerebral Palsy Telethon, featuring entertainers from New York, Hollywood and Las Vegas, will be shown by 77 stations across the country, including WORTV, Channel 9, in New York.

title: Gerald B. Brophy, at 77, a Lawyer And Aviation Industry Authority
description: Gerald B. Brophy, a retired partner in the law firm of Chadbourne, Park, Whiteside & Wolff, died yesterday at Ozanam Hall, a nursing home in Bayside, Queens. He was 77 years old.

title: Baltimore Home Fire Kills 3
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 29 (AP)  A young woman, her 18monthold daughter and a guest were killed early today when a fire destroyed a threestory house on the city's east side, the authorities said. The victims were identified as Donna Juratoyac, 20 years old, her daughter, Ann, and a visitor, Michael March, 18, of Baltimore. Thomas Juratovac, the dead woman's husband, escaped by diving from a thirdstory window to a secondstory roof, fire officials said.

title: SOVIET'S RELUCTANCE ON FINAL ARMS PACT LINKED TO CHINA TIE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24  A deepseated Soviet concern over President Carter's sudden decision to normalize relations with China was seen by some American officials today as a major factor in the Soviet Union's reluctance to conclude a strategic arms limitation agreement with the United States in Geneva yesterday.

title: ALGERIA AT IMPASSE OVER A NEW LEADER
description: ALGIERS, Dec. 22  With President Houari Bouniediene still clinging to life, to the astonishment of the Algerian and French doctors who control his sophisticated lifesupport system, the eight men of the governing Council of the Revolution appeared today to be deadlocked on the question of who should succeed him when he dies.

title: Books of The Times
description: ZOLA. By Joanna Richardson. Illustrated. 283pages. St. Martin's. $14.95.

title: SCIENCE FINDS CLUES. ON ENERGY IN SPACE
description: Among SCIentitic puzzles, none is on a grander scale than that of what astronomers refer to as The Machine, the superefficient process that generates vast amounts of energy within the cores of such celestial objects as quasars and radio galaxies, the latter being the largest objects known.

title: Monumental Sues Sun Life Insurance
description: The Monumental Corporation, a life insurance holding company, said it had filed suit in Baltimore against the Sun Life Insurance Company of America and two other companies to enjoin Sun Life from exercising its option to purchase Monumental common shares.

title: City Sets a Date to Try Again on New Rent Ceilings
description: The New York City Rent Guidelines Board last week set a meeting for March. 7 to determine new ceilings on rent increases in about 300,000 of the city's rentstabilized apartments. The board also announced a timetable for public comment prior to the meeting.

title: A Reporter's Notebook: Humorists in Cleveland Cash In on Default
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 23  The city is grinning and bearing it.

title: Hearings Are Scheduled on Use Of Snowmobiles on Park Lands
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP)  The Interior Department has scheduled eight public hearings on a proposed policy governing the use of snowmobiles on national park lands.

title: Duryea Facing Sizable Campaign Debt
description: Perry B. Duryea is likely to be reliving his losing campaign for Governor over the months and years to come. That is because Republican Party leaders now expect him to undertake a different kind of campaigning to pay off his considerable debts.

title: Trade Dispute on Clothespins
description: WEST PARIS, Me., Dec. 24  Unlike the buggy whip, the clothespin has managed to stave off obsolescence in the face of modern technology thanks in part to the energy crisis.

title: Hamilton Smith, 75, ExChairman Of Atlas Corp. Board of Directors
description: Hamilton K. Smith, a financial consultant and former chairman of the board of directors of the Atlas Corporation, died Friday after a long illness. He was 75 years old.

title: Bridge:
description: When a player challenges you to guess how many tricks he made on a given deal with a given trump suit, you can reasonably assume that he, or she, made two or three more than a quick analysis would suggest.

title: Miss Putnam, Soprano, In Philharmonic Debut
description: It can't really be said that the special holiday program offered Saturday night at Avery Fisher Hall by Andre Kostelanetz and the New York Philharmonic had much that was very Christmassy about it (or very Hanukkaish or New Yearsy either, for that matter), even with some rather fancilied Christmas carol arrangements during encore time at the end.

title: Events
description: Music

title: Notes on People
description: None the worse for wear from his recent attack of hemorrhoids, President Carter slogged through a heavy rain with his family yesterday to attend Christmas Eve services at two Baptist churches in his hometown of Plains, Ga. In a sense, one bitter controversy that arose during Mr. Carter's Presidential campaign had come full circle. One of the services was at the Maranatha Baptist Church, which broke away from the established Plains Baptist Church after a controversy in 1976 over whether to admit a black minister. That minister, the Rev. Clennon King, was on hand at Maranatha yesterday. So was the Rev. Bruce Edwards, who was dismissed by the deacons of the older church amid considerable wrangling over what to do about Mr. King. Mr. Edwards now lives in Hawaii, and he spoke briefly with Mr. Carter after the service. In a benediction he was asked to deliver, the President called for love and Christian understanding during the holiday season.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Since the inception of professional football's suddendeathovertime rule for regularseason games, how many times has the team that won the coin toss before overtime gone on to win the game?

title: Holiday Wisdom From P.S.41
description: If today is not all that Christmas is cracked up to be, well, there are a number of 8yearold realists at P.S. 41 in Greenwich Village who will not be surprised.

title: Exhibit Hall Counters Criticism
description: CHICAGO  McCormick Place, Chicago's lakefront exposition hall, billed as the nation's largest trade show facility, is making headway in eliminating criticism heaped on it earlier this year.

title: Joy to Acquire Driltech Company
description: The Joy Manufacturing Company said it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire the Driltech Company and that the merger agreement had been approved by the boards of both companies.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Remains In Jail Christmas Eve As Protests Continue
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 24 (AP)  Indira Gandhi spent Christmas Eve alone in Tihar Jail here instead of beside the family Christmas tree, while supporters in Bombay set fire to buses and other vehicles to protest the former Prime Minister's arrest.

title: Pastorini Passes for 306 Yards in 179 Triumph
description: MIAMI, Dec. 24  Dan Pastorini, Houston's rugged quarterback who had not been sure he could perform because of a variety of ailments to ribs, knee, elbow and hamstring muscle, was the hero today in the Orange Bowl as the Oilers defeated the Miami Dolphins, 179, in the American Conference's wildcard elimination game.

title: Wine Cuts Into Spirit Sales
description: A year ago, a man called Forest Hills Liquors, a retail store in Queens, and ordered 500 cases of Scotch as Christmas gifts for his business clients. This year the same man was back, but for wine  800 separate packages, each containing three expensive bottles.

title: Wendy Hecht Becomes a Bride
description: Wendy Hecht, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Hecht of Clifton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Stephen M. Offen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Offen of Somerville, N.J. Rabbi Eugene Markovitz performed the ceremony at the Clifton Jewish Center.

title: Joseph Schwartz, Ohio Pianist, Plays Schubert and Schumann
description: Joseph Schwartz's appearance Saturday night at Carnegie Recital Hall marked the.20th anniversary of his debut in New York as winner of the Naumburg Award. He is now professor of piano a t the Oberlin Conservatory.

title: North Carolina State Beats Pitt, 30 to 17
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 24 (AP) Ted Brown, an allAmerica running back, punched through Pittsburgh's defense for 126 yards and a touchdown and Mike Nall picked off a key interception for another touchdown as North Carolina State rolled to a 3017 victory over the Panthers last night in the 33d Tangerine Bowl.

title: Finding on Jonestown: Few Facts Emerged
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana  The conclusion of the coroner's jury's that the Rev. Jim Jones murdered nearly all of his followers in Guyana was less a conclusion to the Jonestown saga than a departure point for new chapters.

title: Janys Gelberg, Student, Bride of Glenn R. Silbert
description: Janys Gelberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Gelberg of Teaneck, N.J., was married yesterday evening to Glenn R. Silbert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Silbert of Woodbury, L.I. Cantor Emanuel Yavne performed the ceremony at the Sheraton Heights Hotel in Hasbrouck Heights, N.J.

title: Trucking Reform Tactics
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 The Administration, enthusiastic over the outcome of its efforts to deregulate the airline industry, is now gearing up for a big push to relax the regulations governing trucking. But a host of diverse governmental interests are trying to get in on the act, and their views do not all coincide.

title: Sporting Gear
description: One tabletennis equipment manufacturer calls it Phantom Pubber; others prefer names like Magic Carbon Soft Rubber. Whatever the name, it is what good players today glue to the face of their bats to improve their games, confusing opponents with added spin, speed and control. This product, especially effective with the new carbonfiber bats, is the latest in sponge rubber from Japan, and it comes in eight types, varying in hardness and length of pips. There are four thicknesses of each type. Prices range from $7 to $25 a sheet (you cut your own). Order from Table Tennis America, Box 32111, Oklahoma City 73132. (405) 7217424, or McCleskey Enterprises, 1923 Rosemond, Jonesboro, Ark. 72401. (501) 9356066.

title: Worker's Death Spurs City Review of Permits At Construction Sites
description: The city's Department of Environmental Protection has ordered a review of the licenses of all heavy equipment at municipal construction sites following the death last week of a construction worker killed by a crane allegedly being operated without a valid license or certificate of fitness.

title: Road to Peace Gets Bumpy In Wealthy Darien Enclave
description: DARIEN, Conn., Dec. 24  There is discontent on Contentment Island, and Tokeneke is troubled as residents of this wealthy enclave on Long Island Sound fight each other in court over speed bumps.

title: The Region
description: CENTRAL ISLIP, L.I. (UPI) Three persons were killed when a fire, possibly started by lights on a Christmas tree, swept through their Long Island home, the Suffolk County police reported.

title: China's Drive to Modernize Opens Vistas of the Outside
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 23  Soon after student from China arrived at Stanford University in California recently, he was taken on a tour of a large suburban shopping center and shown the campus library's computerrun catalogue.

title: Canary Islands Strike in 3d Day
description: LAS PALMAS, Canary Islands, Dec. 24 (Reuters)  Some 100,000 vacationers went without hot meals and room service for the third day today as 40,000 hotel workers continued to strike for more pay.

title: Fear Is Speeding Flight From Rhodesia's Farms
description: CASHEL VALLEY, Rhodesia, Dec. 19  White Rhodesia's battle with black nationalist guerrillas is all but forfeit in this lush valley along the border with Mozambique, where relentless terror tactics have driven dozens of farmers off land settled by whites in the pioneer days of the 1890's.

title: Dr. Lois Gray Floyd, 68, Professor of Psychology
description: Dr. Lois Gray Floyd, professor emeritus of both psychology and anthropology at Montclair State College in New Jersey, died Friday in Woodland, Calif., where she was visiting a relative. She was 68 years old, and maintained homes at 111 East 85th Street and in Twilight Park, Haynes Fall, N.Y.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Evanitsky Aerodancers Add Acting to Illusions
description: The Multigravitational Aerodance Group, directed by Stephanie Evanitsky, is an innovative ensemble that has worked seriously at extendingthe possibilities of dance for the hit eight years. Its basic set is a scaffold  to which ropes, trapezes, slides, cylinders, bars and inner tubes have been variously attached. These devices allow the performers to dance in the air. And so they did again Saturday afternoon at the Intermedia Theater, 12th Street and Second Avenue.

title: Illinois, Wisconsin Aid Big Ten Image
description: John Orr, the Michigan basketball coach, was asked before the season to evaluate the strength of the Big Ten Conference.

title: Philip B. Taylor, 79; Engineer Gave Help On Lindbergh Plane
description: Philip B. Taylor, the technical engineer who helped prepare the engine of The Spirit of St. Louis for Charles A. Lindbergh's historic transAtlantic flight, died Thursday at his home in Upper Montclair, New Jersey. He was 79 years old.

title: 2 Victims of Mao's Purges Honored At Big Memorial Service in Peking
description: CANTON, Dec. 24  In an extraordinary gesture of atonement, China held a large memorial service in Peking today for two of the most prominent victims of purges by Mao Tsetung.

title: Health Plan at Bellevue Offered As a Test for National Insurance
description: An experimental prepaid medical health plan, described as a laboratory for a national health insurance program, will be tested by 4,500 members of a municipal union at Bellevue Hospital with the help of the faculty of New York University's Medical School.

title: The Region
description: BRENTWOOD, L.I. (AP)  Two local 17yearolds, Michele Noren and Dean Langen, were arrested and charged with assault in a shooting incident here in which Mr. Langen allegedly shot and wounded two teenaged friends of Miss Noren's and she in turn shot and wounded Mr. Langen.

title: A Rembrandt Is Among 4 Works Stolen on Coast
description: A group of intruders clambered up to the roof of the M.H. DeYoung Memorial Museum in San Francisco this weekend, deactivated an elaborate alarm on the skylight, cut out a large glass pane, lowered themselves into an art gallery and made off, through the skylight again, with more than $1 million worth of 17thcentury Dutch paintings, including a Rembrandt.

title: Consultants Give Ideas for Changes to a BudgetTight City
description: From suggestions for small changes in daytoclay operations to elaborate plans to rebuild neighborhoods. ideas volunteered by outsiders jostle for the attention of the New York City government.

title: Machine Tools Shipments Still Strong
description: Orders and shipments for machine tools continued at their strong pace in November, with shipments running 17 percent ahead of those in October and 41 percent higher than in November 1977.

title: Yellow Freight at Crossroads
description: LANCASTER, Pa. This tranquil Pennsylvania Dutch community of 57,000 people is a 20thcentury anachronism, a place where narrow winding roads are lammed with horsedrawn buggies ambling alongside thundering, 55foot tractor trailers headed for the mammoth truck terminals that line bustling Route 72.

title: Brief Runs of New TV Series Wait in Wings for Tests of Public Acceptance;
description: FRIENDS,. Duke, Hizzoner, Joe and Valerie, Wonderland Cove and Married: First Year are not among the titles of the 20 or so replacement series that are part of the networks huge midseason overhaul. Yet all these series, and perhaps a halfdozen others like them, will find their way into the network schedules between now and June, popping in for short runs, with little fanfare. Yet all these series, and perhaps a halfdozen others like them, will find their way into the network schedules between now and June, popping in for short runs, with little fanfare.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Christmas shoppping season reached a frenetic crescendo over the weekend with heavy crowds thronging the stores. Many retailers reported that last Saturday was their biggest day of the year and was followed by strong sales on Sunday. The three final days the shopping season helped some retailers achieve gains of 10 to 15 percent over the year before. [Page A1.]

title: Cabot a Real Estate Force Again
description: BOSTON  Two years ago, Cabot, Cabot & Forbes, the big Boston realestate development company, was $150 million in debt. Stuck with numerous land holdings bringing in no money, the oldline concern seemed about to collapse into the mud of undeveloped lots and vacant properties.

title: Illegal Privy Of Sect Family Starts Debate
description: CENTRAL LAKE, Mich., Dec. 23 A white outhouse that a member of a conservative sect of the AmishMennonites built behind his new home is the hub of a debate in this northwest lower Michigan village of some 500 people.

title: National Football League Playoffs
description: Sat., Dec. 30  Denver at Pittsburgh, 12:3O P.M.

title: Upstate N.Y. woman Is Israel's Skiing Team
description: VAL D'ISERE, France  Clifford Spiesman and his wife of Kingston, N.Y., are planning to take a twoweek vacation from their bakery next month to visit their, daughter, Penny.Israel's onewoman ski team.

title: Duke's Basketball Osprey
description: Jim Spanarkel can score. By the end of the college basketball season, barring injury, he will have set a Duke career record, breaking Art Heyman's total of 1,984 points. And he can pass; he leads the Blue Devils in assists. But what Jim Spanarkel does best is understand the game, the nuances that coaches appreciate. Defense and team offenses that's basketball, he says. I think the thing I enjoy most is getting a good steal that leads to a quick basket. With so much emphasis on slam dunks and 25foot jump shots, basketball players like Jim Spanarkel are almost an endangered species, like the osprey. But for ospreywatchers, Jim Spanarkel can be observed in the Holiday Festival at Madison Square Garden later this week. Duke, the nation's topranked team, opposes Ohio State on Friday night, with the winner qualifying for Saturday night's title game against the RutgersSt. John's survivor. In this tournament, Jim Spanarkel has another attribute. Because of their captain's Jersey City following, Duke might even have the homecourt advantage.

title: MiddleEar Disease Is Linked to Learning
description: RECURRENT middleear disease during the first three years of life may cause serious learning problems in children with otherwise normal intelligence, pediatric researchers at the University of Tennessee have shown.

title: Radio Station Makes Toys Run
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., Dec. 25 (UPI)  Radio station WCHS came to the rescue of harried parents whose children found toys on Christmas morning without batteries. The station offered free batteries to anyone willing to pick them up. We have several cartons on hand, said Steve King, an announcer. All sizes. We're giving them away as long as the supply lasts.

title: Michigan's Coach Gives Players Gift
description: PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 23 (UPI)  Bo Schembechler, in a turnabout, today gavel permission to his University of Michigan football players who have relatives or friends in southern California to spend Christmas Day with them.

title: Thousands of Pilgrims Worship in Bethlehem
description: BETHLEHEM, Occupied West Sank, Dec. 25 (AP)  After a night of caroling and merrymaking. Christmas pageantry came to an end today in the town where, according to Christian tradition, Jesus was born.

title: Books: Federal Theater Recalled With Fondness
description: USING archives that had been hidden away in a hangarwarehouse for a decade, John O'Connor and Lorraine Brown have compiled Free, Adult, Uncensored, a history that offers a synoptic view of one of the most dynamic and fervent periods in the American theater: the four years, 193539, in which the Federal Theater Project flourished in the land.

title: Controlling Hazardous Wastes
description: Reckless disposal of hazardous chemicals may be the single most important environmental health issue of this decade, says Congressman Albert Gore, who has chaired hearings on the problem. The dangers were dramatized at Love Canal in Niagara Falls, N.Y., when 200 families had to leave their homes last summer because chemicals buried 25 years earlier had seeped into their yards and basements. Federal agencies have documented some 400 cases of damage from improper disposal of hazardous waste in recent years. Yet the Federal Environmental Protection Agency is moving only sluggishly to control the problem.

title: Science Watch
description: A 4,600yearold wooden boat that belonged to Egypt's King Cheops has been restored and is expected to go on display next summer alongside the Great Pyramid Giza.

title: Growing Numbers of Clergy Turn to Outside Work
description: The Rev. William Beery is a clergyman, but he doesn't have a church. He earns his living by running a counseling service for troubled youths, which he considers to be the way of fulfilling his religious calling.

title: Dollar Unchanged In Tokyo Trading
description: The dollar remained stationary against the yen in Tokyo yesterday, closing at 195.35 yen, unchanged from Friday. Trading over the Christmas holiday was very thin, with no quotations for the British pound or Swiss franc.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILINOTODAY

title: Commodities
description: Almost lost in the glitter of the precious metals markets, copper prices have also been staging a determined comeback for several weeks. Unlike gold, silver and platinum, however, copper is a key industrial raw material and is closely watched as a basic economic indicator as well as a commodity.

title: Tasty, But Illegal
description: In an effort to offer foods that are unusual, noncommercial and original, many restaurants and shops are selling dishes prepared by home cooks in their home kitchens. As pleasant as those foods may be, their sale is illegal, and New York City Health Commissioner Dr. Reinsldo A. Ferrer warned that it could possibly be hazardous because the foods are prepared on premises that have not been inspected and approved for sanitary standards. He announced today that his department will begin to take action against commercial establishments that sell homecooked foods.

title: The City
description: One man was shot to death and two others were critically injured in Brooklyn during a dispute over noise coming from a Christmas party, the police said.

title: Notes on People
description: Nothing works quite like the personal touch, even when the message conveyed falls in the nonnews category. Tiny Bennington College in Vermont was in something of a stir over reports that its president, Joseph S. Murphy, was on a list of possible successors to Robert J. Kibbee as Chancellor of the City University of New York. Dr. Kibbee's inability to impress Governor Carey was wellknown, and Dr. Murphy seemed a likely candidate since, among other things, he had been president of Queens College until two years ago. To reassure the folks in Vermont that he was not about to abandon ship, Dr. Murphy dropped a mimeographed note into the mailbox of each of the school's 600 students. In case you are interested, it said, the rumors that I am leaving Bennington are false. It was signed Joe.

title: Strong Impact on Poor Reported From Cut in Medicaid Abortions
description: In Akron, Ohio, a woman applied at hospital for prenatal care. She said that she would prefer to have an abortion but was having the baby because Medicaid, which would not pay for an abortion, would pay for a birth, and welfare would pay to rear the child.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: MOMBASA, KenyaThe domino theory was largely discredited by those who exaggerated its importance in Southeast Asia to justify military intervention in Vietnam. There now appears to be some risk of erring in the opposite direction by denying any validity to the notion that major power changes can have a chain reaction in sensitive regions.

title: Holiday Giving Supports Fund For the Needy
description: Employees in the Rainbow Room in the RCA Building presented a Yuletide gift of 6100 to the 67th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. They said it was being given to the fund on behalf of our employers, Brian Daly and Tony May.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Visitors to South Africa usually get their news from the Englishlanguage newspapers. But while these journals are vigorous and outspoken. the Afrikaner press more importantly reflects and influences the Afrikaner Government.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Yields on Treasury notes and bonds hit their highest levels in history last week, and they are likely to climb still higher in 1979.

title: Hostages Freed After Five Hours Of Protest in a Delaware Prison
description: THORNTON, Pa., Dec. 25 (UPI) Three hostages, held at knifepoint for five hours in protest over conditions at the facility, were released early today by four inamtes at Delaware Country Prison.

title: Thousands of Homes Are Dark In Pennsylvania Power Failure
description: INDIANA, Pa., Dec. 25 (UPI) Power blackouts in central western Pennsylvania plunged thousands of homes into darkness last night and today and many families were without heat, the authorities said.

title: Sica to Head European Bank
description: Nicholas A. Sica has been elected president of the European American Bank, effective Jan. 1. He succeeds Klaus Jacobs, the West German banker, who resigned unexpectedly last week because of internal policy differences.

title: Chinese Party Statement Sets New Economic Goals and Stresses Public Rights
description: The plenary session discussed the international situation and the handling of foreign affairs, reaching the view that the foreign policy of the party and the Government was correct and successful. The plenary session also discussed the question of how to speed the growth of agricultural production and arrangements for the national economic plans for 1979 and 1980 and adopted relevant documents in principle.

title: Job Security Issue in Racing Contract
description: Job security will be the major issue today when the New York Racing Association resumes contract negotiations with its parimutuel clerks.

title: Quebec Industry Facing Pressure on Many Sides
description: MONTREAL  A few bright patches have appeared in the economy of Quebec in recent months, but La Belle Province is still troubled by some deep structural problems that resist shortterm solutions.

title: Ten Rowers Reenact Washington's Crossing
description: MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Dec. 25 (UPI)  Ten men rowed across Marblehead Harbor today in a reenactment of Washington's crossing of the Delaware on Christmas Day in 1776.

title: New Convertible Boots Rise or Fall to Any Occasion
description: There have been cowboy boots, kneehigh boots and ankle boots. By next fall, there will be a new classification: convertible boots. They're the rage. In next year's shoe collections, presented this month by leading shoe designers in New York. What they mean by convertible is a boot that can be worn high or low, depending on whether the top is folded down or cuffed. Some styles can be worn either taut or crushed, depending on whether a smooth chic or casual look is warranted  or whether a skirt or pants are worn.

title: New Battle on Canal Nearing in House
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25  When the Senate approved, with just one vote to spare, the second of two Panama Canal treaties on April 18, a relieved Carter Administration and almost everyone else assumed that the long fight was over.

title: Issue and Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25  Former Transportation Secretary William T. Coleman called it the biggest ripoff in Washington. Those who love it call it one of the last remaining civil ways to travel from here to there. It is rail passenger travel, or Amtrak.

title: Spain Gets 2 Christmas Pandas
description: MADRID, Dec. 25 (Reuters)  Two giant pandas, a Christmas present from China to Spain, arrived here last night from Peking, an airport official said today. The pandas, called Shao Shao and Chiang Chiang, were promised to King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofia during visit to China last June.

title: Pigeons' Instincts Tied to Moon
description: SEEKING a definitive explanation for the pireon's remarkable ability to find its way home, Cornell University scientists have come up with a new clue  the birds can sense the position of the moon even when they can't see it.

title: Bridge:
description: Any group of knowledgeable players could happily spend hours debating the rights of various experts to the title greatest player in history. A name that would certainly figure in the discussion would be Howard Schenken of New York, who recently celebrated his 75th birthday.

title: Movies Discover Christopher Walken
description: IF Christopher Walken were not such an experienced actor, he might well qualify as Rookie of the Year. Until he won the New York Film Critics Award last weeK for best supporting actor, he had been a fairly unfamiliar face to movie audiences, even though he had won numerous awards for his work on the stage.

title: About New York
description: All the Times Square faces are bathed in a pale gruel of movie light reflected from the screen, so that this audience seems quite ripe for pornall males, sitting in the dark apart from one another, a gathering lonely and anonymous and hungry to be stirred.

title: President Says He No Longer Expects Brezhnev Meeting in MidJanuary
description: PLAINS, Ga. Dec. 25  President Carter said today that he would delay his meeting with Leonid I. Brezhnev, originally planned for midJanuary, because American and Soviet diplomats were unable to conclude an armslimitation treaty in Geneva last week.

title: U.S. Counts 1975 Court Cases
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP)  The Law Enforcement Assistance Administration has reported that more than 6 million cases were filed in general jurisdiction courts of 43 states and the District of Columbia Ouring 1975. About 63 percent were civil cases, 28 percent were criminal and 8 percent were juvenile cases. The Bureau of the Census discontinued similar studies in 1946.

title: Operetta: The Savoyards From London at the Y
description: CAN New York ever have too much Gilbert and Sullivan? Apparently not. Hardly a week passes without a production by one of the city's several professional companies that specialize in presenting these perennial operettas, and the works have always been popular with innumerable amateur groups as well.

title: Talking. BusinessI with Kitchen of Chase Manhattan
description: The air has filially cleared well almost. On Dec. 15, the Government implemented a ban on nearly all aerosol products containing chlorofluorocarbons because of determinations by the Environmental Protection Agency, the Food and Drug Administration and the Consumer Product Safety Commission that they were damaging the ozone layer or the earth's upper atmosphere. Scientists have contended that the erosion of the protective ozone layer could cause an increase in skin cancer, the most common form, and cause damage to plant and animal life.

title: Less PriceRule Advice
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25  It was feverish time for lawyers, those formfilled years in the early 1970's when President Nixon instituted his mandatory wage and price controls.

title: Dr. Walter R. Kessler, at 65; Specialist in Pediatric Allergy
description: Dr. Walter R. Kessler, who developed pediatric allergy medicine and diagnostic tests for cystic fibrosis, died last Friday of heart failure at the Cabrini Health Care Center. He was 65 years old.

title: Alfred Tree, ExBanker, Is Dead; Expert on International Finance
description: Alfred Tree, a retired banker and authority on international finance, died of a heart attack last Saturday in Cambridge, Mass. He was 70 years old and lived in Madison, Conn.

title: Christmas Day Service at the Waldorf
description: A man named Andy, dressed in a faded blue raincoat, sat at a folding table covered with a red paper tablecloth at the Salvation Army Service Center in the Bowery, and shoveled up mashed potatoes and gravy with his fork.

title: EDUCATION
description: KENOSHA, Wis. THE minimum competency movement  until now confined to elementary and secondary schools concerned about students' deficiencies in basic skillshas arrived on the college campus.

title: Rains Flood Northeast England
description: LONDON, Dec. 25 (AP)  Unseasonably heavy rains deluged northeast England early today and the fire brigade in Newcastle reported being overwhelmed by hundreds of pleas for aid from people with flooded homes. Firefighters pumped out many houses in the city that were flooded to a depth of, six feet as water poured in from the surrounding fields, officials said, No injuries were reported.

title: 3 Plans Weighed By State to Keep Music Hall Open
description: The New York State Urban Development Corporation is considering at least three kinds of real estate ventures that might be used to subsidize Radio City Music Hall and thus keep the landmark theater open, sources close to the agency say.

title: Latins' Imports Rise but Economies Are Sluggish
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 25  Latin American imports, mainly from Western industrial countries, increased 9 percent to an estimated $52 billion this year, but economic growth remained sluggish for the third consecutive year, according to the United Nations Regional Economic Commission.

title: Cape Canaveral Missions Listed
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 25 (AP)  The National Aeronautics and Space Administration will launch eight missions from Cape Canaveral next year, including the first manned Space Shuttle mission, set for September 28. The shuttle is being built in California and will be delivered to the space center here in March, officials said. The other seven missions planned for 1979 will be unmanned.

title: Oregon Wife Due. to Testify in SpouseRape Case
description: SALEM, Ore., Dec. 25  Greta Rideout is expected to testify tomorrow as the last prosecution witness in her husband's trial on charges of beating and raping her.

title: OBSERVER
description: Most Americans will become poorer next week. The new, bigger Social Security tax starts eating into takehome pay on the first of the year. At the same time, the international oil monopoly will start raising prices so that almost everything will cost more.

title: For Many Couples, Infertility Means Prolonged Anxiety
description: Every month, she said, it hits her like a bomb went off. When she gets her period and has to face, one more time, the fact that she still isn't pregnant, she sits and sobs for hours. I'm getting better, she added grimly. I used to cry for two days; now I only cry for one.

title: Fire That Killed 8 Spurs a Dispute
description: Police and fire officials doublechecked dispatchers recordings yesterday and denied charges that New Orleans firemen took 20 minutes to reach a fire that killed eight youngsters early yesterday. The fire was believed to have been caused by a shortcircuit in Christmas tree lights.

title: Market Place
description: INTERNATIONAL Business Machines, which hasn't been part of the Dow Jones Industrial average since 1939, is of greater significance in terms of dividends than twothirds of the Dow 30 stocks combined.

title: WLIW Returns Feb.4
description: A month ago, WLIWTV, Channel 21, on Long Island, went off the air for what was expected to be two weeks to install a new transmitter. The antenna has been erected at Channel 21's new facilities in PlainviewOld Bethpage, but because of delays in receiving crucial components, the station will not return to the airwaves until Feb. 4.

title: Ron Lyle Still Facing Fights on Many Fronts
description: DENVER, Dec. 25 (AP)  Ron Lyle says now that the ordeal of a murder trial is over, he is determined to do whatever is necessary to get back into condition for a shot at the heavyweight boxing title.

title: Advertising
description: IT is in order to attract the people who are listening so intently to E. F. Hutton and thanking Paine Webber that Dean Witter Reynolds with the aid of its new ad agency, Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborne  has appropriated the smile as its very own symbol and added a song. And, the results will be seen in three commercials that will run on the three TV networks 52 times in five weeks starting Friday.

title: Raoul Calas, 80, Communist Aide And Leader in French Resistance
description: PARIS, Dec. 25 (Reuters)  Raoul Calas, who was a leader in the French Resistance during World War II and an official in the Communist Party, died yesterday in Paris at the age of 80, friends said today.

title: Aspin Argues Civil Defense Need Is Overestimated by Strategists
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UPI)  Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, today disputed contentions that the Soviet civil defense effort could upset the strategic balance between the major powers, even if the Russians launched a nuclear strike first.

title: Two Words From the Coach With Expletives Undeleted
description: TEMPE, Ariz., Dec. 25 (AP)  The broadcasting technique of placing microphone at the sidelines backfired today at the Fiesta Bowl football game between the University of California, Los Angeles, and Arkansas.

title: First Bank Revises Merger Terms
description: Managements of the First Bank and the Connecticut BancFederation of Hartford say they have agreed in principle to a revision of the terms of their original merger agreement of March 27,1978.

title: TV: CBS Reports Surveys Care of Mentally Ill
description: ANYPLACE BUT HERE, CBS Reports documentary being broadcast tonight at o'clock, looks at mental illness largely from the perspective of the mentally ill. They have been locked up in institutions for more than 100 years. Now, all but the most serious cases are being released to halfway houses in the outside world. In just a few years, the population of mental hospitals has been reduced by twothirds.

title: Second Soviet Spacecraft Lands On Venus and Sends Back Data
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 25 (AP)  A Soviet space probe parachuted to the rocky, heatseared surface of Venus today and beamed information back to Earth about the cloudy planet, Tass, the official press agency, reported. It was the second soft landing on Venus by a Soviet spacecraft in five days.

title: Six Pedestrians Killed By a HitRun Motorist
description: Six persons, huddled together under a couple of umbrellas on their way back from a Christmas Eve party early yesterday morning, were killed by a hitandrun driver whose rusty tan station wagon flew out of the rain and dark at 40 miles an hour, scattering their bodies down two blocks of New Utrecht Avenue in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn.

title: Fight Inflation, Not the Inflation Plan
description: The President's voluntary controls program is not yet fully designed but the pall bearers are already eager to bury it. They say the program will not hold down food, fuel, housing or health costs, all major causes of the current inflation. They claim the wage insurance plan, designed to win moderation in union contract settlements, will prove costly and unworkable.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: JOHN WILLIAM MILLER

title: 2 Killed in Phoenix Plane Crash
description: PHOENIX, Dec. 25 (UPI)  A parachute entangled in a plane making a parachute drop tore away a section of the tail assembly, sending the plane spiraling into the ground and killing two men while a third jumped to safety. Killed in the crash of the Piper Cherokee were David Schultz, 40 years old, who was the pilot, and Gene O'Donnal, 34, both of Phoenix.

title: Goldin Audit Charges City Hospitals Wasted $20 Million on Elderly
description: Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin's office has concluded that New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation wasted more than $20 million a year by keeping many elderly patients in hospitals needlessly beyond the time for which hospital care is required.

title: Tanker Still Aground Off Tampa, But No Danger of a Spill is Seen
description: TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 25 (AP)  A tanker carrying more than 9 million gallons of gasoline was still aground in mud off Tampa today, but a Coast Guard spokesman said there was little danger of a spill.

title: Syracuse Fights to Keep Deaf Pupils in Program
description: CAMILLUS, N.Y., Dec. 24  Outside yes no which? is a typical question. The words are English. The structure of the language is not.

title: Interferon, Virus Foe, Comes Of Age
