description: INTERFERON, a seemingly ideal weapon against virus infections that was discovered in 57 and scored its first great medical triumph a 1960 Flash Gordon comic strip, is now just beginning to make its presence felt in the real world of medicine.

title: DICK MACKEY
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 25 (UPI)  Dick Mackey, sports columnist for The Kansas City Times, died yesterday of an apparent heart attack.

title: Film: More Wilderness Family Fun:Suburb in the Wild
description: BY the time the Wilderness Family gets around to "The Further Adventures of the Wilderness Family, Part II," most of the excitement is behind them. In Part I, this wholesome foursome evidently decided to give up city life, retreated to a spectacular site in the Pacific Northwest, built a log cabin, learned to read by candlelight, and found themselves a couple of pet bears.As Part II begins, life in the middle of nowhere is very, very calm. Dad splits logs, Mom cooks dinner, and the children  depending on the season  either pick wildflowers or horse around in the snow. Though there's nary a station wagon in sight, the quality of this privileged life is eerily suburban.One hour and a lot of animal shots later, someone on the production end of "Part II," which opened yesterday at the Embassy and other theaters, has decided that songs about snowflakes and footage of the Robinson family on snowshoes don't amount to much of a plot.So Mom wigs out, complaining that she can't stand bears in the house, and promptly catches pneumonia. The children weather a blizzard. Dad gets stuck in an avalanche. The cabin catches fire while the meanest wolf in the neighborhood  Old Scarface, he's called  is right outside the door. All of this happens in a hurry, and afterward everything is calm once more.As Dad, Robert F. Logan is a great success, full of reassuring smiles by day and dressed in long underwear by night  so he can leap out of bed in a hurry whenever there's trouble in the smokehouse or the chicken coop.Mr. Logan is a personable fellow who doesn't mind being upstaged by the odd cougar or raccoon. And he has played this same kind of Dad in a string of family wildlife adventure films, among them the recent and much better "The Sea Gypsies," directed by Stewart Raffill, who also directed the first Wilderness Family film.But this time, his talent for patiently explaining the wonders of nature, and for providing useful object lessons for children, isn't put to much use. The small details of the Robinsons' daily life would doubtless be of interest to a young audience, but they're never really explained. The big action sequences have a trumped-up feeling, and they're over almost as soon as they begin.The other members of the cast don't make a very convincing family. There are a mother (Susan Damante Shaw), who doesn't really look as if she'd spend one night in a house without carpet; a young son (Ham Larsen), who's too noisily adorable, and an older daughter (Heather Rattray), who's too restrained.From time to time, the family is visited by a grizzled trader named Boomer, whose favorite words are "heap" and "varmint" and "tarnation." Boomer arrives whenever the plot seems particularly slow, and the sight of the children invariably brings sentimental tears to his eyes. He always outstays his welcome.

title: Around the Nation
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 25 (UPI)  The Cleveland City Council, meeting in special session tomorrow at the request of Mayor Dennis J. Kucinich, will be asked by his administration to approve an ordinance aimed at getting six local banks to refinance $15.5 million worth of notes on which the city has defaulted.

title: The Arms Agency Fight: Doubts Over ExGeneral
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25  When the White House announced in October that a retired Army lieutenant general had been chosen to head the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, the reaction was chiefly one of surprise.

title: Taxes and Accounting
description: ACCOUNTANTS for years now have been arguing the relative merits of the LIFO versus the FIFO method of valuing inventories with all the heat of Scholastics debating the number of angels that can dance on the head of a pin.

title: Oil Worker Killed in Accident
description: BAY CITY, Texas, Dec. 25 (AP)  A platform on an oilfield drilling rig collapsed on six workers yesterday, killing one and injuring the others. The victim was identified as Bobby Lee Reed, 19 years old, of Blessing, Texas.

title: Holiday Closings
description: Banks, businesses, stock markets, commodities exchanges, government offfices and most retail establishments in the. United States, Canada and Europe were closed yesterday for Christmas.

title: 15 Die on Philippine Vessel
description: MANILA, Dec. 25 (UPI)  A boat loaded with holiday travelers capsized yesterday, the Philippines News Agency reported today. Fifteen persons were killed and one was reported missing

title: A Lot of Very Real People to Stalk Through the Pages of Next Year's Fiction
description: ONCE upon a time, actual persons and events were carefully disguised in novels. Nowadays, with more lenient interpretation of libel laws and with everyone's privacy fair game for the gossip columnists and personality magazines, many novelists hardly bother to conceal reallife characters. A small sampling of some of the titles on the 1979 fiction horizon points up the trend.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HERS AND HIS A tree 80minute program this afternoon at Lincoln Center promises to be something different. In their dramatic presentation titled Daughters and Father. Phyllis Behar, Bonnie Max and Dorothy Scharf are using excerpts from plays, biographies, poetry and song to illuminate significant paternal influences on such wellknown offspring as Liv Ullmann, Jane Fonda, Sylvia Plath, Eleanor Roosevelt and others. As fathers, such writers as Joseph Heller, Carl Sandburg and Budd Schulberg will be quoted, with an emotional range spanning the humor of Jules Feiffer and the tragedy of Shakespeare's King Lear.

title: Letter: On the Tombigbee Project
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Race for Governor Attracted Big Givers Despite '74 Law
description: Despite a 1974 state law designed to curb the influence of big money in state political races, major contributors played a key role in the latest gubernatorial campaign.

title: Books of The Times
description: IT had been the reviewer's solemn intention to avoid at all costs contracting Tutankhamun fever, even to the extent of boycotting the Metropolitan Museum exhibition. He had been succeeding too, although admittedly with the aid of two circlunstances  first, Use failure of anyone to attempt forcing tickets on him, and second, his unique innocence of the Tutankhamun story, which extended even unto never having read Howard Carter's The Tomb of TutankAmen the firsthand account by the English archeologist who made the fabulous discovery in 1922.

title: Japan Trade Post Filled
description: TOKYO, Dec. 25 (AP)  The Governent has approved the appointment of Michio Takeuchi, former Vice Finance Minister, as president of the ExportImport Bank of Japan. Mr. Takeuchi will formally take office on Thursday. He succeeds Satoshi Sumita. Mr. Takeuchi, 57 years old, served as deputy finance minister from 1970 to 1977 after having served in such Finance Ministry posts as director general of the financial and budget bureaus.

title: Under Apartheid: Life in One Black Family
description: SOWETO, South Africa  Viewed from Sarah Tshetshe's home at 85 Mkhize Street, the sun makes a striking sight as it rises over the flattopped mounds of goldmine slag that surround this brooding ghetto.

title: Bukich 15Yard Run Gains 1010 Draw
description: TEMPE, Ariz., Dec. 25 (AP)  Steve Bukich, a surprise starter at quarterback, raced. 15 yards for a touchdown with 8 minutes 32 seconds to play today to give the University of California, Los Angeles a 1010 tie with Arkansas in the eighth Fiesta Bowl.

title: Effort to Control Intelligence Units Reported in Jeopardy in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25  The effort to win Congressional approval of the first comprehensive law regulating the activities of the nation's intelligence agencies is in danger of foundering, according to some officials involved.

title: Four Arreited at Power Plant
description: PLYMOUTH, Mass., Dec. 25 (UPI) Four antinuclear demonstrators dressed as Santa Clauses were arrested today for trespassing at the Pilgrim atomic power plant, the police said. One of those arrested said they were members of the Reindeer Alliance, an antinuclear group. They were released on $5 bail and were to appear Tuesday in Plymouth District Court.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Television
description: Morning

title: He Even Brought His Own Pots and Pans
description: PRINCETON, N.J.Louis Price was the pride of the Southern Crescent. The Southern Railway has lots of men it can be proud of. but Louis Price was the man it made famous, the most famous railroad chef of them all. On Dec. 3, he was one of six persons killed when the Southern Crescent derailed at Shipman, Va.

title: The Eyes Have It
description: URBANA, Il.When the Congress adjourned recently, it had failed to act upon 13 bills that sought to carry out the recommendations of the United States Privacy Protection Commission. The possibility of such bills again being introduced will be brightened, believe, if President Carter delivers his own longexpected privacy initiative before the new Congress convenes next month.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of schaduled meetings for work follows:

title: Pope, in a Christmas Message, Urges All Mankind to Pray for Peace
description: ROME, Dec. 25  Pope John Paul II, speaking from the central balcony of St. Peter's Basilica today, wished a happy Christmas to each and every human being and urged all mankind to pray with him for peace.

title: Antibiotic Introduced By Merck
description: In a move that could place it in a stroig position in the field, Merck & Company has entered the antibiotic market with a new drug  Mefoxin that works against infections caused by strains of bacteria resistant to penicillin and similar antibiotics.

title: Books: Two Approaches To Understand Poetry
description: THE titles of the two books at hand are a good index to their substance. John Wain has just completed his term as Professor of Poetry at Oxford, and his book, made up in part from the lectures he delivered there, is the conventional vol ume we have come to expect from an academic gathering of essays. They include assessments of W.H. Auden, Emily Dickinson and Philip Larkin. One article takes a new look at William Empson; another is an eloquent tribute to Edward and Helen Thomas. There are also discourses on more general subjects: On the Breaking of Forms and Poetry and Social Criticism. Many of Mr. Wain's judgments are shrewd enough, but the book didn't strike this reader as highly original.

title: Canada, Cuba to Expand Exchange Of Athletes
description: OTTAWA (UPI)  Canada will send more than 120 athletes to Cuba in 1979 to compete in the largest sports exchange ever between the two countries, Canada's Sports Minister, Iona Campagnolo, has announced.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Clarino Concerto, L. Mozart; Mephisto Polka, Liszt; Berceuse Heroique, Debussy; Feuillet d'Album, Chabrier; Of All the Birds That I Do Know, Bartlett; Piccolo Concerto, Vivaldi.

title: Secret Teams to Enforce Prescription Law
description: People with prescriptions for generic drugs to be filled at pharmacies in the New York metropolitan area from now on might be ordinary patients, or they might be undercover investigators.

title: How  and What  to Name Judges
description: New York State's brandnew Commission on Judicial Nomination has just finished its first job, developing a roster of seven candidates from which Governor Carey will soon select a successor to Charles Breitel, who is retiring as Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court. This new process has already spared New Yorkers and the judiciary the demeaning practice of judicial candidates campaigning for election. The commission's work insures that someone worthy of respect will succeed to a chair that has been graced by judges like Benjamin Cardozo, Stanley Fuld  and Judge Breitel.

title: Analysts Discount the Impact of Firestone Memos
description: AKRON, Ohio, Dec. 25  Having taken a multimilliondollar loss to pay for the recall of its steelbelted radial 500 tires,, the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company now is defending itself against liability suits whose plaintiffs are armed with a Government disclosure that company officials knew as early as 1972 that the tires had serious problems. Independent tire industry analysts say, however, that the documents do not prove the tires were unsafe.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 26, 1978

title: Hartford Official Insists He Seeks Taxpayer Revolt
description: HARTFORD  By the hundreds, ordinary people have rallied in auditoriums across the city in the last month, cursing and boning Nicholas R. Carbone, the man they blame for what they have been told is likely to be a 50 percent increase in property taxes. And that's just the way Mr. Carbone planned it.

title: Campbell Gets Footing And the Oilers Get Going
description: MIAMI, Dec. 25  When Earl Campbell stands still, he measures 5 feet 11 inches from top to toe, and 224 pounds of power are packed, into the solid Texan's frame.

title: Samuels May Cut Bank Ties
description: John S. Samuels 3d, a millionaire New York businessman, is close to a deal that will cut his ties with Chicago's eighthlargest bank.

title: Hen's Feed Reduces Cholesterol in Eggs
description: Union N. J. A SPECIAL diet supplement for chickens that could result in lower cholesterol levels in humans has been devised by a New Jersey pharmacologist using combinations of common and esoteric plant material.

title: Chiefs Urges Zulus Quit Drinking, Have Children
description: MZUMBE, South Africa (Reuters) A Zulu chief has called on his men to give up drinking and produce more children to help the political struggle of blacks in South Africa.

title: Revised Guidelines Are Hailed
description: That sound of air escaping from corporate headquarters these days might be an expression of yearend fatigue, but more likely it is a sigh of relief over the Administration's amended wage and price guidelines.

title: Judge to Determine Fate of Louisiana Abortion Law Soon
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 25  A Federal judge will decide next month whether Louisiana's antiabortion law, believed to be the strongest in the nation, should stand. His ruling is expected to have an impact on abortion legislation now being considered around the country.

title: Sports Today
description: Harlem Holiday School Classic at City College's Nat Holman gymnasium, West 138th Street and Convent Avenue; first game, 3 P.M.

title: Entertainment Events
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoin Center. Strauss'sElektra. s.

title: Monthly Medicare Fee For Millions Will Rise On Jan. 1 and July 1
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UPI)  Millions of elderly Americans will have to pay more out of pocket for hospital care under Medicare beginning Jan. 1.

title: About Education
description: THIS is the Age of Jargon, writes Thomas Postlewait in the journal of the National Council of Teachers of English. And, adds the professor of humanities at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, to fight against it is about as wise as the Charge of the Light Brigade.

title: PEOPLE AND BUSINESS
description: Volkswagen of America produced its 40,000th Rabbit automobile on Friday, a milestone for the American subsidiary of the German automotive manufacturer that began production in the United States last April 3. It also announced that Richard S. Cummins, the plant manager of its sole American production facility, in New Stanton, Pa., had resigned.

title: FuelSale Data Is Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP)  The Interior Department, which is seeking to hold a 1980 sale of Ail and gas leases, is asking for recommendations from the petroleum industry, state governments and the General public. The Proposed sale would include an area 135 miles long and 195 miles wide, along the coasts of Maine, New Hampshire, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, Connecticut, New York and New Jersey.

title: SOVIET JEWS IN WAR: A SEARING ACCOUNT
description: MOSCOW  With all the publicity about the plight of Soviet Jews who wish to leave their country, much less attention has been given to the lives of those who stay.

title: Music: A Yule Concert By New York Strings
description: IN every respect but one, Sunday's midnight concert by the New York String Orchestra under Alexander Schneider was a typical Christmas Eve at Carnegie Hall.

title: Marina Lezcano Rides Into Argentine Sunrise at 21
description: BUENOS AIRES  As Marina Lezcano walked the big red horse, Telescopico, past the crowded paddock railing, a bettor, fingering his five tickets to win, called out, Save us, doll.

title: Inept Knicks Drop 3d in Row by 10994
description: The Knicks did everything a pro basketball team is not supposed to do, playing as if they hated one another as they were soundly trounced by the Philadelphia 76ers, 10994, yesterday before a national television audience and a capacity crowd of 19,511 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Japanese Buy Foreign Ships
description: TOKYO, Dec. 25 (AP)  Twelve Japanese shipping companies have purchased 21 foreign ships, among them large tankers and car carriers, with longterm, lowinterest, foreigncurrency loans from a Government bank, the Transport Ministry announced today.

title: MARTIAL LAW IS SET IN 13 TURKISH CITIES
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Tuesday, Dec. 26The Turkish Government declared martial law in Istanbul and a dozen other cities today to end three days of street fighting that left 93 people dead in the southeastern city of Kahramanmaras.

title: Archeologists Find a Mayan Pompeii
description: IN El Salvador, archeologists have uncovered a 1,500yearold Maya farmhouse, outbuilding and nearby cornfield that, like Pornpeii, were buried and preserved in sudden fall of volcanic ash.

title: Sadat Criticizes Failure of Arabs To Support Him
description: CAIRO, Dec. 25  President Anwar elSadat told Egyptians tonight that the refusal of other Arabs to unite behind his peace efforts was helping Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel frustrate a proper settlement in the Middle East.

title: Carter Obtains Pece: Christmas With His Family
description: PLAINS, Ga., Dec. 25  Jimmy Carter came home for the holidays in search of spiritual sustenance, and, like millions of Americans on similar journeys, appeared replenished by his family, friends and church.

title: Final Weekend Flurry Of Christmas Buying Cheers Retail Business
description: The Christmas, shopping season, the source of considerable concern because of sluggish early results, reached a frenetic crescendo over the weekend with heavy crowds thronging stores across the country.

title: Materials Spawn New Technologies
description: PRESSED by shortages of energy, basic resources, skilled labor and capital, scientists are inventing a vast family of new materials in the hope that technological progress can be maintained despite economic strains.

title: An Upstate White Christmas  And Then Some
Mormons' Aid to Iiidian Children Preserved by New Law
description: DENVER, Colo., Dec. 23  In the longtime practice of putting large numbers of Indian children up for adoption or in foster care, the Mormon Church has played a role recognized for its benevolent intentions but marked by frequent criticism from Indians.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Bathe Halsey Stuart Shields Inc., a securities firm, has named Raymond J. O'Connor senior vice president to head the corporate finance department of Bache.

title: State Audit Finds City Still Neglecting to Get Approval of Contracts
description: A state audit released yesterday found that New York City was still remiss in submitting contracts to the Financial Control Board for approval before they take effect.

title: World News Briefs
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 25 (Reuters) Hundreds of Vietnamese refugees were given brandy and cigarettes by officials of this British crown colony today but were told that they could not come ashore. The refugees, estimated at 2,700, spent the day on a freighter oft Hong Kong.

title: HEAD OF OPPOSITION SEES NO IRAN PEACE UNLESS SHAH QUITS
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 25The leader of Iran's main opposition movement said today that all compromise attempts to solve the country's political crisis and bring a halt to continuing violence here would fail if the Shah does not abdicate.

title: Herrmann Standout For Boilermakers
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 25.  Georgia Tech's football team, unlike this city's pro Falcons. had no miracle to present to Atlanta's fans this afternoon. Local rooters in the crowd of 20,277 at Fulton County Stadium that turned out for the 11th Peach Bowl saw the Engineers crushed by Purdue, 4121.

title: Frontiers: Space
description: PASADENA, Calif. THE National Aeronautics and Space Administration is developing a new solar electric propulsion system, known as ion drive, that engineers are increasingly confident will become the workhorse of interplanetary travel within the next decade, opening for exploration parts of the solar system beyond the effective reach of chemicalfuel rockets.

title: Gubernatorial Race Contributors
description: The following are the major corunbutors to Governor Carey and Perry B. Duryea either directly or through committees or through loans during the last year. The lists were compiled from financial reports filed with the State Board of Eleclions by the candidates and their committees.

description: GENERAL

title: TV: Adding Up to Zero
description: IF you don't take it, I'll stab you, Zero Mostel's widow, Kate, recalls telling him when it seemed that he might reject the offer of the starring role in A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum on Broadway in 1962.

title: Bengals Honor Browner
description: CINCINNATI (AP)  Ross Browner, a rookie lineman, has been selected as the Cincinnati Bengals mostvaluable player for 1978 in a poll of local fans and sports reporters.

title: TeksidLynchburg Tie
description: TURIN, Italy, Dec. 26 (UPI)  The Teksid Company, a subsidiary of Fiat, announced today that it was considering joining the Lynchburg Foundry Company, a subsidiary of the Mead Corporation of Dayton, Ohio, in a venture to make aluminum automotive engine castings in the United States. Teksid would put $15 million to $20 million in the venture. The principal customers for the products would be the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation, which plan to start using them in 1981model cars.

title: Recluse in Jersey, 72, Decides to Come Back To Society for Holiday
description: VINELAND, N.J., Dec. 26 (AP)  A 72yearold recluse whose home for the last 28 years was in the same southern New Jersey chicken coops he cleaned for a living has apparently decided to rejoin society in time for the holidays. And officials say Ivan Rusin, who seems delighted to be occupying a hospital bed here, saved up a surprisingly large amount of money over the years.

title: Rangers Defeat Flames
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 26  The New York Rangers climbed all over the Atlanta Flames before a crowd of 10,546 in the Omni tonight, spotting the borne team 31 lead, outshooting them, 4323, and posting a 53 victory.

title: Personal Health
description: JEAN'S husband was about to be promoted and relocated, which was good news to both of them. But Jean was not feeling well and was having trouble sleeping. She was easily upset and jittery and worried about her persistent abdominal cramos.

title: Islanders Beat Leafs For 17th at Home,51
description: UNIONDALE,.L.I., Dec.26  The bouncy and confident New York Islanders, tedby their 94 rout of the Rangeril last Weekend and relaxed afte! the Christmas holiday, skated all over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight, 5.1 in a National Hockey League gaine before a capacity house of 14,995 in Nassau Coliseum

title: Victim's Brother Knew Accused In Hit and Run
description: A close relative of two of the six per. sons killed in Brooklyn on Monday by hitrun driver said yesterday that the 27. yearold man be held as the driver was a friend of the family whom he had known for five years. The suspect was arraigned yesterday morning.

title: U.S. Limits PayPrice Sanctions
description: WASNINGTON, Dec. 26  The club in the closet, the weapon kept by the Carter Administration to encourage compliance with its wage and price standards, is intended, it now appears, to be wielded against relatively few transgremon.

title: In Wilds of Canada, the Pioneers Wear Hard Hats
description: LG 2 CAMP, Quebec  Claude Caron has a somewhat longer commute to work than others  938 miles. But then he goes only every eight weeks.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: CAIROTo those so inclined, divine will must be sending a message to the Moslem people of this region and making known its disapproval of what has come to pass in the age of affluence and oetroDower.

title: American Land Chief Accused
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26  The Securities and Exchange Commission has accused Steven Silverberg, president of the American Land Company, of violating securities laws in the purchase and sale of the company, which had been trying to Obtain financing for a hotel casino in Atlantic City.

title: ProDemocracy Group Active
description: PEKING, Dec. 26  One of several activist groups here has begun taking the message about democratic rights from the Peking wallposter stage to four other cities, it was learned from Chinese sources.

title: Durham Life Reorganizing
description: The Durham Life Insurance Company announced yesterday that it planned to reorganize into a holding company. It said that under the proposed plan, shareholders would exchange their Durham Life shares for those of the new holding company, the Durham Corporation, subject to approval by shareholders and by the North Carolina Department of Insurance and to a favorable Internal Revenue Service tax ruling.

title: New York City as Landlord
description: Federal housing officials are suggesting that they may have to stop New York City from using Community Development grants to pay for managing and maintaining 5,000 partially occupied old apartment houses it has taken over for tax delinquency. Washington has a good point. Community Development grants are intended to make urban improvements; to use them for mere maintenance of housing stretches the law's meaning. If the city does not begin now to address the problem, the consequences could be severe.

title: Saga of the Morgan Horse
description: Most letters from Sparse Grey Hackle are about trout fishing, but not all. Recently Sparse read a magazine piece about the Morgan breed of light harness horse and was shocked he writes by two things:

title: Mrs. Gandhi Is Let Out of Prison
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 26 Indira Gandhi was released here tonight after spending one week in jail as punishment for having harassed officials in 1975, when she was Prime Minister.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Holiday Closings
description: In Canada and most European nations, banks, government offices, exchanges and most businesses other than retail establishments were closed yesterday in an extended Christmas holiday.

title: Budget Officers Gave President Choice on Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26  When President Carter announced that he was restoring $2 billion for domestic social and economic programs to his planned 1980 budget laSt Friday, he was doing just what the prepared script called for, according to officials in his budget office.

title: Of Harvard, Elitism and Amorality
description: BOSTONThe Westinghouse Electric Corporation recently pleaded guilty to charges stemming from the bribery of a former deputy prime minister of Egypt in return for contracts worth millions of dollars. In announcing the penalty in the case. Federal District Judge Barrington D. Parker criticized earlier attempts by the Federal prosecutors and the corporation to keep secret the identity of the parties involved. This incident represents two serious flaws in contemporary American leadership: an elitist disdain for the public and an amoral disrespect for the law.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Tuesday, Dec 26, 1978

title: Court Overturns City Regulation And Allows Reactor at Columbia
description: Columbia University yesterday won the right to operate its nuclear reactor for teaching and research purposes  after years of litigation  when a Federal judge in Manhattan decided that the city had exceeded its authority in attempting to regulate the use of atomic energy.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Charcb Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249, or to any of the following organizations:

title: Advertising
description: AFTER two and a half years of existence, Avenue, a successful free magazine that is distributed on Manhattan's chic, fashionable East Side, has had its first circulation audit. Judy Price, founder and publisher, is sorry she waited so long.

title: Q&A
description: Q. In a recent column you mentimed black walnuts that you ate as a child. I, too, have a black walnut tree, but I hate the task of cracking open that stonelike shell. I use a hammer, of course. Do you know a better solution for cracking black walnuts?

title: James C. Kelly, a Vice President Of Straus Communications, 51
description: James C. Kelly, who last Tusday was named executive vice president of Straus Communications, died Monday in Nassau Hospital, Mineola, L. I., of a cerebral hemorrhage following an iceskating accident Sunday. He was 51 years old and lived in Garden City. L.I.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: AS has been noted often, there are some main courses in this world that demand such brevity of cooking, the preparation of a side dish can become the greater event. One such is a standard item on the menu of many restaurants in Paris and, in fact, almost any given corner of France. This is a rib steak simply and briefly cooked in butter and flavored at the last minute with a touch of shallots, winevinegar and parsley.

title: Private Lives
description: SHE is wearing gold shoes. I've never met her, but I can imagine her in her gold shoes in the quad or high school cafeteria. She teaches English literature, from Beowolf to Barthelme, somewhere down in inscrutable Florida. She is familiar with the secrets of William Blake. She has been known to dilate on the critical discourses of Roland Barthes in front of 11th graders, all of whom are fanatically devoted to her because she makes them sweat and she assumes that they are smarter than turnips and, obviously, she has style.

title: Woman in Oregon Rape Trial Says Husband Beat Her
description: SALEM, Ore, Dec. 26  Greta Rideout took the witness stand here today in the rape trial of her husband, John, and told a Marion County jury that he forced her to have intercourse with him Oct. 10.

title: Hinkle Named President Of Ramada Gaming Unit
description: Jess W. Hinkle, former president of the Del Webb Hotels and a longtime casino Orator, has been named president of Ramada Inns new gaming subsidiary, Adamar of New Jersey Inc., and general manager of the company's planned new hotelcasino in Atlantic City, the Phoenix. Adamar is Ramada spelled backward.

title: Show Feeds Mystery of Le Nain
description: PARIS  Grand, scholarly retrospectives usually help tosolve enigmas. In the case of Le Nain, the subject of the most impressive exhibition in Paris, the result has been to make the riddle more obscure.

title: Sauted Quail With Brown and Wild Rice
description: The quail:

title: For New Year's, Polish Stew
description: THERE is a winter holiday dish in Poland called bigos. A bigos is a hunter's stew. It is one of those rare dishes that is best made a few days in advance, because per classic tradition it must be reheated three or more times before serving.

title: For a Nobel Math Prize
description: BERKELEY, Calif. Mathematicians like to say that Alfred Nobel's wife was seduced by the eminent Swedish mathematician Gosta MittagLeffler  and that is why there is no Nobel prize in mathematics. But this story is far too good to be true.

title: CLAUDIUS PHILIPPE, LONGTIME HOTELIER
description: Claudius Charles Philippe, the suave, Paristrained hotel executive who became worldfamous as Philippe of the Waldorf, died in New York on Monday of heart failure. He was 68 years old.

title: TURKISH PARLIAMENT BACKS MARTIAL LAW
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 26 (AP)  The Turkish Pigliament gave overwhelming approval today to the Government's declaration of martial law after a weekend of clashes that took at least 97 lives.

title: Hershey Set to Buy Friendly Ice Cream
description: The Hershey Foods Corporation, in a major diversification step away from the chocolate business, offered yesterday to pay $23 a share, or $162 million in cash, for the Friendly Ice Cream Corporation, operator of more than 600 restaurants in 16 states.

title: Kitchen Equipment
description: THE Cuisinart has so many passionate advocates that it almost pains me to say this: The truth is that there are some things that the Cuisinart does not do especially well. While it is fine for grinding, mixing or pureeing, it is far from perfect as a vegetatne slicer. i ne variety of thicknesses is limited by the blades available. And the Cuisinart cannot be counted on to give absolute uniformity to its slices, so there is tendency for them to cook unevenly. Also, vegetables have to be trimmed to fit into the funnel.

title: U.S. Recalls Mediators And Criticizes Somoza
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26  The United States recalled its negotiating team from Nicaragua for consultations today because of the the refusal of President Anastasio Somoza Debavle to accept what a spokesman called a fair and workable plebiscite to determine the country's political future.

title: Soviet Denies FootDragging on Arms Pact
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 25  The Soviet Union issued oblique denials today that it had delayed the conclusion of an armslimitation treaty because of concern over the new AmericanChinese relationship.

title: PAF Playhouse Grows
description: Its financial growing pains in the past, the PAF Playhouse, Long Island's only resident professional theater, is set to open. its $450,000 new theater with the American premiere of An Angel Comes to Babylon, by Friedrich Durrenmatt, author of The Visit. The cast will Include Michael Egan, Heather Lupton, Gary Krawford and C.K. Alexander.

title: Timer in Sun's Heart Said to Control Cycle
description: The sun, source of lifegiving warmth, long assumed to be constant and predictable, has been found surprisingly inconstant both in its rotation and its sunspot activity. Yet it also appears that sunspot occurrences, while irregular, are controlled by a highly precise timer deep within the sun, according to new evidence.

title: U.S. Warning On Oil Imports
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (Reuters) A Commerce Department staff study says that, buying in anticipation of the 14.5 percent price Increase by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, which begins Jan. 1, could widen the United States monthly trade deficit to much as $2.5 billion to $3 billion in November and December, officials said today.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Republic Steel Price Rise
description: The Republic Steel Corporation plans to increase the price on hotrolled stainless sheet and coldrolled stainless strip by about 5 percent, following an increase by Allegheny Ludlum Industries, which increased prices on the same products by the same amount. The increases are effective Jan. 1.

title: Study Finds Health Perils in Rotating Work Shifts
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 26  A 62yearold cheese maker in a Sacramento dairy suffered a heart attack that would not allow him to work.

title: Experts Argue: Does U.S. Need Global Policy?
description: Senator Gary Hart recently proposed the establishment of a grand strategy for the United States, and thus joined military men, civilian specialists and academic writers who have been debating whether the country needs such a strategy and if it does what form it should take.

title: Math Haters Get Piece Of the Pi
description: MANY people believe that if they cannot add and multiply in their heads, quickly find percentages or correctly sort out the facts from tables and graphs, they are dumb in math, congenitally miswired, wrongheaded.

title: Atlantic City Officials Are Assailed by Byrne For Stand on Casino
description: TRENTON, Dec. 26 (AP)  Governor Byrne today sharply criticized Atlantic City officials who have offered to defend Resorts International against state charges that threaten the company's application for a permanent casino license.

title: Chess:
description: A positional sacrifice generates marvelous excitement: will the defense painstakingly consolidate and nurse the extra pawn, or Whatever else it may have been offered, to a stubborn victory? Or will the aggressor press one attack here, another there, like a whole series of needlepricks, until an exhausted defense collapses?

title: Bias Against Secretaries In State Courts Charged
description: A suit charging the New York State court system with discrimination against women in the hiring and promoting of court clerks was filed yesterday by the Federal Government.

title: U.S. Ends Fee On Fuel Import
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26  The Department of Energy announced today the removal of a small import fee on heavy industrial fuel oil, designed to lower prices for New England and Michigan users.

title: Sports Today
description: Nets vs. Knicks, at Rutgers Athletic.Center, Piscataway, N.J., 8 P.M. (RadioWVNJ, 8.)

title: Cash Prices
description: TUESDAY, DEC. 26, 1978

title: Christmas Mail Tops 1977's
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP)  A lastminute surge put this year's Christmas mail ahead of that in 1977 by 17 million pieces, a Postal Service official said today. The service figured the total pieces of mail between Dec. 2 and Dec. 23 as 1.693 billion. The figure for last year was 1.676 billion.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Overture to L'Italiana in Alfieri, Rossini; Lisbon, Grainger; Abegg Variations, Schumann; Symphony in B flat, Mozart; Sonata in F minor, Loeillet.

title: Bridge:
description: It is to be hoped that the recent change in United States policy on China will not lead to an increase in political maneuvers in international bridge. Like Israel and South Africa, Taiwan has frequently been the target of such efforts

title: Economic Scene
description: HARTFORD HARRY Jack Gray, the 59yearold chairman of the United Technologies Corporation, appears to have won a billiondollar prize with United's impending takeover of the Carrier Corporation, the world's largest air conditioning manufacturer. However, there are plenty of details to be negotiated, ana there is still Justice Department opposition to the merger to be overcome or finessed. It could take a year before the UnitedCarrier merger is consummated.

title: New I.B.M. Stock Surge
description: International Business Machines, last week's star on Wall Street, gave rousing repeat performance yesterday by racing ahead 14 points to 309.

title: Smoked Salmon: Buying the Best
description: ALONG with caviar, fole gras and oysters, count smoked salmon among the luxurious foods that are standard accompaniments to New Year's Eve champagne. And because this year, salmon, like almost everything else, is more extravagantly priced than ever, it's a good idea to master some of the quality points in judging this fish so that you at least get top quality for your top dollar.

title: Books of The Times
description: IT was inevitable that modern art should have been attracted to the idea of nothingness. The search for originality seemed to have nowhere else to go. Every revolutionary mind takes the position that history has exhausted the world, that time has faded all qualities.

title: TV: Les Misera bles In New Version on CBS
description: THE first several scenes of tonight's Les Miserables, being presented on CBsTV at 9, hold the promise of delicious things to come. The costumes and onlocation settings are convincing. The story of gross injustice is absorbing. And a parade is about to begin of marvelous actors in cameo roles: Sir John Gielgud, Dame Flora Robson, Celia Johnson, Cyril Cusack, Ian Holm and Claude Dauphin. Bring on the popcorn.

title: News of the Theater
description: IT was only a few years ago, when Purlie, The. Wiz and other shows with black casts came along, that Broadway producers found themselves attracting sizable black audiences for the first time. Now there is an intense effort under way to fill theater seats with another minority group that rarely comes to Broadway  Hispanic people.

title: Money Shortages Threatening High School Athletic Programs
description: Quarterbacks sell pretzels outside schools, while female volleyball players bake cakes, teachers and students run in jogathons and booster clubs stage marathon dances  all in fundraising attempts to halt what appears to be a national phenomenon: the erosion of highschool athletics.

title: COMPANY NEWS Pullman Unit Set to Aid Major Chinese Oil Project
description: Pullman Inc. announced yesterday that its Pullman Kellogg division had been awarded a multimilliondollar contract to provide engineering, procurement and construction advisory services for a large petrochemical facility in China.

title: VW Expects U.S. Sales Rise
description: WARREN, Mich., Dec 26 (Reuters)  Volkswagen of America, which began assembling Rabbit model cars in the United States last April, expects to sell more than 300,000 imported and domestic vehicles here in 1979, up 24 percent from this year's total, the West German automaker said today.

title: Running With the PAC in Congress
description: The new accounting of 1978 contributions by specialinterest groups to select members of Congress should resolve any lingering doubt about why those groups give so much money  and about the need for public financing as well as spending limits for Congressional campaigns.

title: IRANIAN OIL EXPORT IS REPORTED HALTED AS OUTPUT PLUNGES
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Wednesday, Dec. 27  Iran's oil production, hampered by strikes and reported new threats to oil workers by opponents of the Shah, fell yesterday to the level of 26 years ago, stopping all petroleum exports, a qualified source in the industry said.

title: Just a Simple Brunch For 120 College Men
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. If you think that cooking for a family of five is hard work, imagine cooking for a family of 120. Maggie Lettvin does. She says it's easy enough, if you own large skillets and keep the meals simple.

title: Exotic Betting Viewed as Detrimental
description: When you put enough cheese on the table, a racetrack prophet once warned, all the rats will come out after it

title: New Yorkers,etc.
description: A NEW year is like a baby. Everybody wants to give it a name. Let the last few leaves appear on the calendars, and a tantivity of forecasters thunders up, vying to affix a tag to the year about to arrive. Mere numbers, like 1979 or a stately MCMLXXIX, no longer seem to suffice. The more humans are reduced to numbers by a computerized society, the more determined humans become to give names to numbers.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: A Labor Package

title: A Real Estate Agent Is Tied Up By Four Fugitives in Arkansas
description: JACKSONVILLE, Ark., Dec. 26 (UPI)  Four men who escaped from the Lonoke County Jail last week tied up a real estate agent and a client who walked into their hideout today, the state police said.

title: Seoul Sets Export Mark: $11 Billion in 11 Months
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 26 South Korea has passed an economic milestone with exports valued at the equivalent of more than $11 billion in the first 11 months of this year, a record for such a period.

title: Small Quarter Loss Reported by Gimbel
description: Gimbel Brothers Inc. reported yesterday its smallest quarterly loss in years and its highest annual profit since the 1973 fiscal year.

title: World Oil Output Up
description: TULSA, Okla., Dec. 26 (AP)  World oil production climbed this year, but only because of increases in Communist nations' output. Output in the rest of the world declined, partly because of declines in Iranian production at the end of the year, according to The Oil and Gas Journal, a trade publication.

title: MEXICANS PROPOSING CUTS IN. LATIN ARMS
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 26 Mexico, one of the few countries in the world that spend little on arms, has called for a regional accord to slow the buildup of Sophisticated weanons in Latin America.

title: U.S. Denies Bias in Basketball
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP)  The Government has rejected complaints that several states discriminate against female high school students by offering basketball programs only in a halfcourt, sixplayer format, the HEW Secretary, Joseph Califano, said today.

title: Growing U.S. Expenditures for the Aged Cause Concern Among Policymakers
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26  An increas ing segment of the American population is elderly, and every year, people over age 65 eat up a growing percentage of the Federal budget. This year, 6112 billion, or 24 percent of the budget, will go to the elderly, and in 50 years, the outlay will be $635 billion, 40 percent of the total, according to Federal estimates.

title: About Real Estate
description: The Koch administration is in the process. of tightening the standards it will apply before granting partial tax exemptions for new office construction projects in midtown Manhattan. The incentives play a part in determining whether and when new office projects, an important element in the city's economic strength, will proceed.

title: Companies Report Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchanoe,(A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 27, 1978

title: Toxicologist Search
description: It may not be like finding the proverbial needle in the haystack, but part of the United States Government is having trouble finding toxicologists. These are scientists who have been trained identify bad effects of poisons aid other substances on people and animals.

title: EARNINGS
description: The International Systems & Controls Corporation, currently in default in certain provisions of its loan agreement, reported yesterday a final net loss of $42.6 million for fiscal 1978 and of $676,000 for its first fiscal quarter ended Sent. 30.

title: Four Children Join in Aiding Those in Need
description: The four children of the Wasserstrom family in Phoenicia, a village in the Catskills in Ulster County, were thinking yesterday not just of holidays and presents but of the 67th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Picketing Threatened if So. African's  Bout Goes On
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson promised yesterday to be on the picket lines myself if his appeals to Madison Square Garden and CBS Sports do not succeed in preventing the United States debut of Kallie Knoetze, the heavyweight boxing contender whom antiapartheid groups here are opposing because of his record as a South African policeman.

title: Gliders Escape Connecticut Winter by a Flight South
Letters
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Begin Says He Is Ready for New Talks With Egypt
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 26 Prime Minister Menachem Begin appeared tonight to be opening the door slightly for a resumption of peace treaty negotiations with Egypt, suggesting that Israel was willing to discuss the question of Palestinian autonomy on the occupied West Bank of the Jordan and in the Gaza Strip.

title: Television.
description: Morning

title: The City
description: The Transit Authority has reopened, on a parttime basis, 15 of the subway token booths it shut down two years ago to save money.

title: Army Finds Few Drug Abusers
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 26 (UPI)  A Penta gon directive to step up random urine checks for drug abuse among members of the military has uncovered relatively few instances of drug abuse. Between 3 percent and 4 percent of the samples tested have been found to have traces of drugs, but less than 1 percent were found to be drug abusers.

title: Phasing Out of Subsidies To 3 City Agencies Urged
description: The Citizens Budget Commission recommended yesterday the gradual phaseout of Nevi York City's annual subsidies to the Health and Hospitals Corporation, the City University and the Transit Authority, to achieve a balanced budget in the fiscal year 1982.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 3-$900 WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAMS 9-5300; NASSAU CO. (51??) 7470500 SUFFOLK CO. (518) ??1800 CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: The City at Work: A Study in Contrasts
description: Labor wears many faces in New York City  from the steady stares of the electricians who light the subways beneath its streets, to the delicate concentration of ballet dancers at rehearsal.. At left, painters decorating construction barriers made their own graceful motions  and whimsical faces on woodwith paint and brush. New York is a city of working people, whose faces reflect the diversity of life in the metropolis.

title: Nuclear Plant Sale To China Approved
description: PARIS, Dec. 26 (AP)  The French company Societe Framatome, which builds nuclear power plants under license from the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, said today that it had won United States Government approval to sell two power stations to China.

title: Brace Yourself: Here Come Quail
description: MARSHVILLE, N.C. IT worked for Frank Perdue and Bill Odom thinks it just might work for him, too.

title: Article 4 -- No Title
description: for an Atlantic fish. The meat was a delicate pink, the whole smoked crust was carefully removed and the meat was firm and sliced thinly. There was one bad blood spot on the side, but the rest of the fish seemed in good condition. Except for a very faintly bitter aftertaste, the flavor was good.

title: Guendel New J.I. Case Chairman
description: The /J.I. Case. Company said that Thomas J. Guendel had been named chairman of the board to succeed Morris W. Reid, who resigned early last week for personal reasons. Mr. Guendel, who had been president, will continue to be chief executive officer. Jerome K. Green, who had been executive vice presidentinternational, was named president and chief operating officer.

title: FIVE NEW SENATORS ARE MILLIONAIRES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26  The Senate has traditionally been home for a fair sprinkling of wealthy individuals, and that tradition will be continued when the 96th congress convenes nest month.

title: Banker Is Proud of Role in Freeing Cubans
description: MIAMI  Bernardo Benes, the master dogooder of this city's Little Havana district, is as redhaired as a stump on fire and, these days, so proud of himself he could just pop.

title: Another Nastase Steals Show
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Dec. 26 Elevenyearold Mihnea Nastase, a nephew of the noted Ilie Nastase, stole the show in the opening program of an international junior indoor tennis tournament at the Port Washington Tennis Academy today.

title: House Panel Calls for More U.S. Control of Surgery
description: A Congressional subcommittee called on Congress and the Department of Health, Education and Welfare yesterday to take a stronger hand in regulating the amount and quality of surgical care delivered to Americans.

title: U.S. Predicts Rise of 10% In Retail Sales Next Year
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP)  Consumers are expected to spend 10 percent more at retail stores in 1979, but the outlook is clouded by the threat of more inflation, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center. Humoerdinck's Hansel and Gretel. 7.

title: Republican Aide Leaves To Join Reagan's Drive
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26  Charles R. Black, political director of the Republican National Committee, has resigned to join the 1980 Presidential campaign of Ronald Reagan, former Governor of California.

title: Foster Parents in L.I. Questioned on Injuries  Of Abused Dead Girl
description: GREENLAWN, L.I., Dec. 26 Suffolk County homicide detectives today questioned the foster parents of a 3yearold girl found dead in her bed early Friday with head injuries and other marks of severe abuse.

title: Gold Futures Prices Up By $5 in Late Buying
description: A modest flurry of late buying on the Comex in New York pushed gold futures prices up an average of $5 an ounce yesterday. The most active delivery, February 1979, closed up $4.90 an ounce at $221.60. That contract's rise last week was $8.60 an ounce.

title: New Laws Make Public Broadcasting More Public
description: Public broadcasting is about to become more public than it has been.

title: French Working Class Is Still Wary of Universities
description: PARIS, Dec. 22 Last year, Aniaud Berthiel became the first member of his workingclass family to attend a university when he enrolled as a sociology major at the Nanterre campus on the western outskirts of Paris.

title: GUERRILLAS RESUME ATTACKS IN OGADEN
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Dec. 21Nine months after Ethiopian and Cuban troops swept through the Ogaden desert to reclaim it from outgunned Somali soldiers, Somalibacked guerrillas are waging a growing campaign of ambushes and hitandrun attacks that has rendered that victory nearly futile.

title: 3 Found Dead in Fire At Closed Bar on S.I.; 2 Believed Murdered
description: The bodies of two men and a women were found in a burning Staten Island building early yesterday morning, the men apparently slain in a groundfloor bar and the elderly woman burned to death in her secondfloor bedroom, the police said.

title: Cambodia Will Let Tourists Visit Ancient Temple Ruins of Angkor
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 26 (AP) Cambodia is scheduled to open the ancient temple ruins of Angkor to foreign tourists tomorrow for the first time in eight years.

title: Rev. Matin Dunne Is Dead at 70; In Maryknoll Order for 40 Years
description: The Rev. Martin Dunne, a Maryknoll priest, died Monday at the Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 70 years old and lived in New York City.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP)  One of the nation's largest coal companies has settled a Government job bias complaint by agreeing to pay $370,000 to 78 women, the Labor Department said today. Department officials said that it was the largest such settlement ever reached in the coal industry.

title: Toyo Kogyo Deal With Ford Motor
description: TOKYO, Dec. 26 (AP)  The Toyo Kogyo Company has signed a contract to supply transaxles for frontwheel drive passenger cars made by the Ford Motor Company for five years beginning in 1980, Yoshiki Yamazaki, the president of the Japanese company, announced today.

title: World News Briefs
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 26 (AP)  A Vatican envoy mediating a territorial dispute between the military governments of Argentina and. Chile met with President Jorge Rafael Videla today.

title: Giants ReSign Speedy Jones
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 26  More than four years after they released him, the Giants today resigned Larry Jones, a kickreturn specialist

title: Surette Among 3 Promoted at Union Pacific
description: William F. Surette was named senior vice presidentfinance of the Union Pacific Corporation in one of three major appointments announced by the company yesterday. Harry B. Shuttleworth was named vice president and treasurer, and Chester A. Rose was named vice president and controller.

title: Howard Nicholson, 82, Coached Sonja Henie and Other Skaters
description: Howard Nicholson, a figureskating coach whose students included Sonja Henie, died Monday of cancer in Lake Placid, N.Y. He was 82 years old.

title: Gunman Robs Bakery In Borough Park Area
description: A gunman last night robbed a bakery in the Bomugh Park section of Brooklyn and fled with $294 in a van after firing at its driver. A suspect was captured a few blocks away by police officers of the Brooklyn South Task Force, who cut him off in their patrol car.

title: 4 More Bodies Found Under House Of Contractor, Bringing Total to 9
description: KNOLLWOOD PARK TOWNSHIP, Ill., Dec. 26  A light dusting of new Christmas snow sparkled under a bright December sun in this quiet suburb of Chicago today as Cook County Sheriffs investigators unearthed four more skeletons from the crawl space under the home of a pudgy contractor who reveled in playing a clown at children's parties.

title: For a Nobel Math Prize
description: BERKELEY. Calif.Mathematicians like to say that Alfred Nobel's wife was seduced by the eminent Swedish mathematician Gosta MittagLeffler  and that is why there is no Nobel prize in mathematics. But this story is far too good to be true.

title: BUSINESS
description: Iran's oil production fell to a 26year low and all petroleum exports have halted, according to an industry source in Teheran. The Government acknowledged that its terminal at Kharg, which handles 90 percent of Iran's total exports, had closed. [Page A1.]

title: American to Halt 3Tier Fares
description: American Airlines announced yesterday that it would discontinue on Jan. 8 the threetier fare system that offered extras to economyclass passengers paying full fare rather than one of the discount rates.

title: A Joyless Nol For Niagarans. Still Remaining
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Dec. 22 Santas smiled and wreaths sparkled in the windows of seven houses in the Love Canal neighborhood here tonight. Plywood boards filled the windows of 239 others.

title: Pullman Elects Four New Vice Presidents
description: Donald J. Morfee; James A. McDiv. itt, the former astronaut; Thomas A. Micali, and Roger J. Kowalsky have been elected vice presidents of Pullman Inc. Clark P. Lattin Jr., who became president and chief executive officer of Pullman last month, said the election of the four men represented fhe creation of four new jobs.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The prices of convertible boots shown on the Style page yesterday were transposed. Golo's crushable boot is $100; Carol Horn's cuffed one is $175.

title: Investigating Cults
description: LOS ANGELES  In the aftermath of the Jonestown tragedy in Guyana, many critics have'demandtd United States Government intervention in connection with such ginups as the Unification Church, Synanon and Hare Krishna, claiming that they preach distrust of society, demand absolute obedience of their members, and use psychologically manipulative tactics in recruiting and indoctrinating new members.

title: Hunter's Stew for New Year's Parties
description: the beets are not sweet enough, add the sugar.

title: WASHINGTON
description: LONDON, Dec. 26  This has been an offholiday season in London. The streets are bright and the shops, with their inflated prices and new inviting Arabic signs, have been frantically busy, but somehow it doesn't seem very merry.

title: Filipinos Seek Energy Sources
description: MANILA  The Philippines is searching for energy sources to support its ambitious development plans to the year 2000. It has spudded two new exploratory, oil wells and signed on a major multinational company to explore for uranium. Nine other multinational concerns are involved in the billiondollar energy search.

title: Chrysler Cuts Diesel Plans
description: The Chrysler Corporation, bowing to low customer demand, has canceled plans to install disel engines in some of its 1979model pickup trucks and vans.

title: Posters in Chinese City Call Rallies to Air Grievances
description: BANGCHOW, China, Dec. 26  Wall posters have been put up in this ancient lakeside city calling for unofficial mass meetings in the next few days to discuss democracy, political persecution and the local situation.

title: Cleveland's Problems Deepen as Mayor Fails to Get Council Quorum
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 26  City Hall's political rift, which for weeks has hurt the prospects of resolving this city's fiscal crisis, widened today.

title: Making Federal Construction Expensive
description: Even as Alfred Kahn, the White House inflation fighter, pleads for wage moderation from unions, Labor Department officials are policing the earnings of workers on Federal construction projects, lest unskilled laborers willing to accept $4.50 an hour get less than $9.50, or pipelayers happy to take home $8 are paid less than $10.

title: TV: Politics of Torture
description: RESOLUTELY simpleminded seems to be the best way to describe The Politics of Torture. This ABC News Closeup, which will be seen from 10 to 11 o'clock tonight. can't get it through its head that the United States cannot easily transform repressive and unstable governments into humane ones by cutting off aid, removing military bases and declaring trade embargoes.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 26 (UPI)  Three inches of rain over the last two days forced the postponement of firstround matches of the 3000,000 Australian national tennis championships today.

title: Notes on People
description: Much as he'd expected, but to his disMay nonethelets, Bill Bradley has been forced to abandon all hope that Clifford P. Case will step idown early as Senator from New JerseY to give his successor a useful leg up in the seniority system. It's unfortunate, Mr. Bradley's campaign manager, Susan Thomases, said yesterday. It Would have been good for New Jersey. She added with a sigh, As usual, Mr. Case is operating to a different drummer.

title: Careers
description: ECONOMIC predictions may be somewhat dismal, but apparently there is nothing dismal about the job opportunity outlook for economists. Here are two recent openings:

title: Home Insurance Mahes Redlining An Albany Issue
description: The New York State Legislature is forced to face a new battle over redlining  this one involving the inability of people in poor neighborhoods to get borne insurance at reasonable rates.

title: Cambodia Labels Slayer Of Briton an Assassin
description: TOKYO. Wednesday, Dec. 27 (AP) China's official press agency said today that a British scholar who was killed last week in Cambodia had been assassinated by Cambodian dissidents.

title: Most Major Banks Raise Prime Loan Rate to 11%
description: An 11 percent prime rate spread through the banking industry yesterday, as banks from coast to coast raised by onequarter point the base lending rate they charge their most creditworthy corporate customers.

title: Watkins Ends Iran Deal
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 26 (UPI) The WatkinsJohnson Company announced today that one of its subsidiaries had stopped work on a contract to supply communications equipment to Iran. The company said the Iranians had fallen behind on the payments. The amount involved was not immediately specified, but the company said it would mean a reduction for uncollected receivables of 38 cents a share against fourthquarter earnings.

title: Technology
description: CONTINUOUSWEAR contact lenses that can be left in the eye for several months at a stretch may soon become a commercial reality  but only for a very limited number of people. At least that was the tentative conclusion reached by the Opthalmic Device Advisory Committee of the Food and Drug Administration last month.

title: Market Place
description: INSTITUTIONAL investors searching the stock market universe for longterm investments usually avoid shares selling for under $10  and that can mean opportunities for small investors. The institutions usually shun such shares because market capitalization is too small for them to take a meaningful position.

title: East Side Area Loses Water and Is Flooded When a Main Erupts
description: A 20inch water main ruptured under the intersection of 78th Street and Madison Avenue yesterday morning, buckling the pavement. flooding the surrounding streets and some basements and disrupting the water supply of about 800 business and private residents in some of New York City's more exclusive East Side blocks.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: The Region
description: New York State authorities yesterday reported the escape and recapture about two hours later of 16yearold Willie Bosket, whose involvement in two New York City subway murders persuaded Governor Carey to endorse the idea of adult trials for violent juvenile offenders. Young Bosket escaped along with nine other inmates of the Division of Youth's detentidn center for boys at upstate Goshen.

title: Knicks: A Team Seeking Teamwork
description: In the anteroom adjacent to the Knicks lockers an arrangement of Christmas holly sits withering in a pot. The leaves have turned brittle. The berries have wilted. Even the two stalks of evergreen have started to yellow. There is no water in the pot, and the plants have no future. It may be too early to say the same about the Knicks. Then again, it may not.

title: Wine Talk
description: FOR most merchants, the holiday rush is over, except for returns. In the wine business, however, the next few days are likely to be just as hectic as last week. If you are contemplating buying wine for a New Year's celebration or just be cause you have a few dollars left over from Christmas, here are a few suggestions on bottles you might like to acauire.

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY, DEC. 28, 1978

title: Japanese Expect Lag In '79 Trade
description: TOKYO, Dec. 26 (AP)  Japan's trade surplus will be reduced to $12 billion in the 1979 fiscal year from the $17 billion estimated for the current fiscal year ending March 31, the Japan Trade Council forecast today.

title: Carter Is Reported to Seek Increase Of $10 Billion in Military Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26  President Carter has decided to propose a $10 billion increase in next year's military spending, to $122.8 billion, to meet an Administration pledge to Europe, Administration sources said today.

title: George McQuinn, 68; Former Major Leaguer
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) George McQuinn, a former majorleague first baseman who once hit safely in 34 straight games, has died of a stroke. He was 68 years old.

title: Carter Sets Fastener Tariff Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 President Carter, reversing a position taken 10 months ago, granted tariff pntection today to manufacturers of industrial fasteners. His decision could have a slight inflationary impact but could help passage of trade legislation next year.

title: French Output Seen Growing
description: PARIS, Dec. 26 (AP)  French industrialists believe that industrial production will continue growing at its present modest rate over the coming months, following the stagnation observed during the summer, the National Statistics Institute said today.

title: U.S. Aides on the Way To Taipei for Meetings
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 26 (AP)  A United States delegation is on the way to Taiwan to establish a framework for trade and cultural relations between the two countries once they sever formal diplomatic ties on New Year's Day.

title: Frederick Guinzburg, Westchester Sculptor
description: Frederic V. Guinzburg, sculptor and landscape artist who founded the Westchester County Arts and Crafts Guild, White Plains, N.Y., died last Wednesday of a heart attack in West Palm Beach, Fla. Mr. Guinzburg, who was 81 years old and lived in Chappaqua, N.Y., suffered from emphysema

title: A Season of Discontent
description: For a time that is supposed to signify hope, Christmas 1978 may have seemed singularly somber for American foreign policy. Even the worldly reporters who travel with Secretary of State Vance were described as stunned when he and Soviet Foreign Minister Gromyko emerged from 20 hours or negotiations in Geneva to announce not an expected agreement on a strategic arms limitation treaty, but continued disagreement.

title: Best Buys
description: BECAUSE of slightly lower prices for meat and fish. items and a few holiday sales, the cost of feeding a family of four in New York City declined by fourtenths of 1 percent last week. According to the 41item market basket survey conducted by the city's Department of Consumer Affairs, the weekly cost went from $84.75 to $84.42, a 33cent drop. But that is a 12 percent increase over the market basket total of Just one year ago, when consumers could purchase the same items for $75.31.

title: Shakespeare's Dark Lady Peers From the Shadow
description: ALTHOUGH A. L. Rowse, editor of the newly published The Annotated Shakespeare, has devoted decades to the threevolume work  and thought he had done with it  he is still haunted by an Elizabethan woman. She is the dark lady of the sonnets, and Professor Rowse is still pursuing research into her life as a clue to Shakespeare's personality.

title: Bonn Gives Immigration Data
description: BONN, West Germany, Dec. 26 (AP)About 43,000 people immigrated to West Germany from Eastern and Southeastern Europe in 1978, an increase over the 39,000 rpported for 1977, the Government said tray. In addition, about 9,000 people, approximately the same as in 1977, came from East Germany, the report said.

title: Koch Reappoints 19 to Judgeships; Picks 2 He Vowed to Bypass in 77
description: Mayor Koch reappointed 19 judges to the Family and Criminal Courts yesterday, including two men he pledged last year not to reappoint because they had been found not qualified by a committee of the City Bar Association. The two were found qualified this time by a second screening committee, the Mayor's Committee on the Judiciary, which passes on reappointments.

title: Flyers Tie Wings In Last 2 Minutes, 22
description: DETROIT, Dec. 26 (AP)  Bobby Clarkeand Mel Bridgman scored goals 15 seconds apart in the final two minutes of play today to give the Philadelphia Flyers a 22 tie with the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game.

title: Official Asks Jail for Girl in Piracy
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Dec. 26  A state prosecutor vowed today to try to send a 17yearold girl to prison if she did not receive a Federal prison sentence for allegedly hijacking a Trans World Airlines jetliner last week and demanding the release of a Federal convict.

title: Pistons Trounced By Bucks
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 26 (AP)  The Milwaukee Bucks, with a clubrecord 45point second quarter, were led by Ernie Grunferd; Junior Bridgeman and Kevin Restani in a 14384 romp over the Detroit Pistons tonight. Grumfeld scored 27 points, Bridgeman 24 and Restaini 22.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: AS visitors from Britain, temporarily camping out in New Jersey, writes Elizabeth Savory, we love all the goingson in New York and on Sunday took our kids to see Fifth Avenue while it was closed to traffic.

title: Israeli Tells of Site Preparations For New West Bank Settlements
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 26 (Reuters)  Israel is continuing preparatory work for more Jewish settlements on the occupied West Bank of the Jordan River, Deputy Defense Minister Mordechai Zri said today.

title: Indian Express Train Hits Bus
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 26 (Reuters)  Fourteen people died and 40 were injured when an express train crashed into a bus today at a crossing near Trichur, in the south Indian state of Kerala.

title: Informant Says Concerns Dealt In Stolen Goods
description: Speaking in a muffled voice through bluegray hood and poncho that covered most of his body to conceal his identity, a confidential informant for the New York State Commission of Investigation described yesterday how supposedly legitimate businesses arranged to buy goods from him that they knew had been stolen.

title: Taiwan Is Said to Deed Embassy to Lobby Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26  The Chinese Nationalist Government, in an effort to keep its Washingtonowned property out of the hands of the Chinese Communist Government, has deeded over its embassy and chancery to a nonprofit lobbying organization called Friends of Free China, Inc., it was reported tonight.

title: 3 Chemical Sites Near Love Canal Possible Hazard
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Dec. 22 Documents released by the state this week show that three chemical dump sites here are larger and potentially more dangerous than the muchpublicized Love Canal. One, like the Love Canal, is leaking toxic pesticides into groundwater and threatens its immediate neighborhood.

title: Japan Studies Loans for China
description: TOKYO, Dec. 26  Top Japanese banks and other financial institutions are slowly evolving a th??part strategy to make massive loans to China to finance rapidly expanding bilateral trade, according to sources here related to Chinese trade and banking.

title: VIVIAN DEPINNA
description: Vivian DePinna, an artist, died Sunday at the Glen Hill Convalescent Home in Danbury, Conn. She was 95 years old.

title: 12 Children Baptized During a Drug Project; Some Born Addicted
description: Twelve children, some of whom were born addicted to drugs, squirmed in their mothers arms and cried as their heads were splashed with holy water, the sign of the cross was made on their foreheads and the attending Roman Catholic priest and Protestant minister performed the christening ceremony.

title: Word of Mouth . . . to Order
description: DAIM I knew they'd catch on to the whole thing sooner or later.

title: Books: Life/Death Ratio Studies Drug Regulation
description: I MAGINE a druggist unable to fill a prescription for penicillin or a supermarket unable to sell aspirin. Yet, were both compounds to be introduced today as new drugs in this country, their toxicity in

title: A Special Treat At the Oyster Bar
description: One of the most unusual and delicately delicious smoked salmons in town is made right at the Oyster Bar in Grand Central Terminal, where it is served sliced or sold unsliced in whole sides.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: WARM PORT Jazz buffs have cause to rejoice now that the Brecker Brothers, Randy and. Michael, are appearing for the first time with their own band at Seventh Avenue South. Last summer, the two brothers and a partner, Kate Greenfield, opened their own jazz lair and restauiant in Greenwich Village. Since then, Seventh Avenue South has developed an enthusiastic following of music fans from all sections of the city, with an impressive lineup of performers, new and established, performing nightly except Mondays.

title: IceDancing Is Extended For Another Two Weeks
description: John Curry's IceDancing, which had been scheduled to close next Sunday, has been extended for two weeks. The 12member iceskating troupe, which is presenting nine ballets, will remain at the Minskoff Theater, 200 West 45th Street, through Jan. 14.

title: Rhodesia Invoking Harsher Measures to Stem Guerrillas
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 21 Under virtually unrestricted martiallaw powers granted three months ago, Rhodesian Government security forces are reported to be resorting to harsher measures than ever before in an attempt to stern the growing success of a guerrilla force now estimated at close to 10,000 men.

title: Around the Nation
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 27  Cook County sheriff's police today unearthed six more bodies at the Norwood Park Township home of John Wayne Gacy, bringing to 15 the number of decomposed corpses removed from beneath the suburban ranchstyle home in six days.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Sinfonietta in B flat, Albinoni; Three Ars Antigua Motets, Anon; Sonata in A, Mozart; Overture to Judas Maccabaeus, Handel; Four German Dances, Schubert; Trio Sonata in A minor, W. F. Bach.

title: Knicks Defeat Nets; Webster Is Standout
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Dec. 27  The pregame traffic snaked back to the Route 287 exit tonight as a standingroomonly crowd of 9,061 jammed Rutgers Athletic Center to see the ailing New York Knicks face the New Jersey Nets. It was the Nets first sellout of the season.

title: West Is Fearful Of Soviet Gains In Iran's Crisis
description: The crumbling of Shah Mohammed Rim Pahlevi's power in Iran has upset the fragile military and political balance in the Persian Gulf area.

title: F.A.A. OFFERS PLAN TO REDUCE DANGER OF MIDAIR CRASHES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27  In a concerted effort to reduce the danger of collisions between aircraft, the Federal Aviation Administration proposed today wide increase in the flight areas in which all planes would be under strict radar control from the ground.

title: Fairfield County Finds Few Jobs In the Factories
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 27  As new steelandglass corporate headquarters spread over southern Fairfield County, the brick and cement factories of a oncediverse manufacturing industry are shutting down.

title: ReBuilding
description: We architects stand at a watershed. There is a shift in sensibility so revolutionary that it is hard for us to grasp because we are right in the middle of it.

title: Detroit to Lay Off 348 Employees
description: DETROIT, Dec. 27 Mayor Coleman A. Young announced today that he was laying off 348 city employees, including 96 firefighters, as part of a plan to further trim a budget deficit that had reached $61 million earlier this year.

title: Disks: AfroAmerican Folk Music
description: BLACK music may exhibit more African traits here than anywhere else in the country, writes David Evans of Tate and Panola Counties in northwestern Mississippi. Mr. Evans knows the area intimately; he has been doing anthropological field work there since 1969. In the past he has published an occasional scholarly article on his findings, and several years ago Testament issued an album of his field recordings, Traveling Through the Jungle, that documented the region's remarkable black fife and drum music.

title: Somoza Rejects Mediators' Plan Despite Warning by Washington
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 27 (UPI)  President Anastasio Somoza Debayle rejected today the key points of a United Statessupported mediation to end the civil strife in Nicaragua despite a warning from Washington that his action could affect the whole gamut of relations with the United States.

title: COMMODITIES
description: The surging preciousmetals markets dominated the commodity futures trade again yesterday. The Comex in New York opened to the bullish news that the second bullion price fixing in London was $220.50, off 25 cents from the first round but up $5.40 an ounce on the day.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
