description: Alan J. Hirschfield, who was dismissed as president of Columbia Pictures Industries last summer, will become a consultant to Warner Communications, the company announced yesterday. Although he will have the title of consultant, he will work fulltime and only for Warner.

title: Two Share Title in Soviet Chess
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 27 (Agence FrancePresse)  Grandmaster Vitali Chechovski won his lastround match in the Soviet Union chess championships to share the men'stitle with Mikhail Tal, the Soviet press agency Tass announced today. Both men finished with 11 points. Tal gained a share of his sixth title. It was Chechovski's first championship. Third place went to Lev Polugayski, who finished with 10 points.

title: ArtificialBreast Concern Charged With Cheating
description: A Manhattan concern is under inquiry for allegedly having victimized cancer patients who had ordered artificial breasts after mastectomies.

title: About New York
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Dec. 22  As the crow flies, the jagged peaks of Manhattan are only a score or so miles from the flat earthhugging precincts of suburban Garden City, but there are no records of anyone making the journey by crow. The trip is more often than not a landlocked experience trying to man and machine along highway or railroad track, and the only devices that comes close to emulating the crow are the helicopters that rise from an unnoticeable industrial enclave alongside the Meadowbrook Parkway and buzz, more like big bees than crows, toward the distant skyline.

title: Hitachi Sales to China
description: TOKYO, Dec. 27 (AP)  Hitachi Ltd., a leading maker of general electric and electronic equipment, said today that it would export to China $35 million worth of equipment to unload ore. The equipment will be used for a modern steel plant now under construction near Shanghai.

title: H.E.W. Aide's Fight to Rescue Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27  I lost my temper, said Hale Champion, shaking his head. I couldn't believe it.

title: DAYLONG VIOLENCE CRIPPLES TEHERAN; IRAN TO RATION OIL
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 27  Iran's political crisis appeared today to have reached an acute and decisive stage after a day of wild shooting and lawlessness in the capital and a strike that effectively shut down the oil industry.

title: Temple at Angkor Found Neglected but Unscathed
description: ANGKOR, Cambodia, Dec. 27 (AP) Cambodia today reopened Angkor Wat to foreigners barred from viewing the ancient temple by eight years of war and revolution.

title: Pretoria Said to Agree to Namibia Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27  South Africa has agreed to cooperate in carrying out a United Nations plan to bring SouthWest Africa to independence in 1979 as Namibia, Richard M. Moose Jr., Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, said today.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Monarch Wine Company of Brooklyn, makers of Manischevtitz wines, announced yesterday that it would import Chinese beer and vodka and distribute it nationally starting in May.

title: L.I.R.R. Refines Definition of Late
description: The Long Island Rail Road announced yesterday that starting next Monday it would count as late most, but not all, of its late trains. In the past, many of the late trains had been counted as on time  to the dismay of commuters and some New York State officials.

title: Talking Business
description: WASHINGTON Next week, Kenneth Young will take over as head of the department of legislation of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, thereby becoming organized labor's top lobbyist. He will succeed Andrew J. Biemiller, who held the post for 25 years and who was one of the most familiar figures on Capitol Hill for a generation.

title: U. of Washington Crew Scores a Sweep on Nile
description: CAIRO, Dec. 27 The University of Washington scored a sweep in the eightoared events at the annual Nile International Rowing Festival by winning the final today.

title: Yale Drama Names Lloyd Richards
description: Lloyd Richards, the prominent stage director, has been named dean of the Yale School of Drama and artistic director of the Yale Repertory Theater. He replaces Robert Brustein, who will move to Harvard after his term at Yale expires next June 30.

title: Hawks 115, Spurs 107
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 27 (AP)  John Drew scored 28 points, tonight to lead the Atlanta Hawks to a 115107 victory over the San Antonio Spurs as the two National Basketball Association teams met for the second time in two nights.

title: Price of Sunday Times Will Rise to 85c Jan. 7
description: The suggested newsstand price of The New York Times on Sundays will rise by 10 cents on Jan. 7, to 85 cents.

title: $10,000 Is Sent To the Neediest By Trust Fund
description: A contribution of $10,000 from a New York City trust fund was received yesterday by the 67th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases. It was requested that it be an anonymous gift, but in a letter to Arthur 0. Sulzberger, the publisher of The Times, the trustee wrote:

title: Smithsonian Is Given Jeweled Czarist Statue
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27  One of the statuary treasures of 19thcentury Czarist Russia  the bejeweled gold and platinum St. George and the Dragon, created in 1882  has been acquired by the Smithsonian Institution here, museum officials announced yesterday.

title: Western Electric to Lift Product Prices 2.1% Jan. 1
description: The Western Electric Company, the huge manufacturing and supply branch of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, announced yesterday that it would raise prices an average of 2.1 percent, effective Jan. 1, on the many thousands of telecommunications products it makes.

title: Carter and Meany Plan Private Meeting Jan. 12
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP)  President Carter and George Meany, president of the A.F.L.C.I.O., will confer Jan. 12 at a meeting that could help patch up their rapidly deteriorating relationship.

title: Bobby Orr Gets FrontOffice Post
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 27 (AP) Bobby Orr, former National Hockey League allstar defenseman, was named assistant general manager of the Chicago Black Hawks, the club announced today.

title: I.C.C. Issues Rail Guides On Mergers
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27  Proposed railroad mergers will be judged primarily by the extent to which they improve operating efficiencies and reduce excess facilities in moving freight, the Interstate Commerce Commission said today.

title: Books of The Times
description: IN New Orleans, on New Year's Eve 1972, 21yearold Mark James Robert Essex, a former United States Navy seaman, opened fire on the city's Central Lockup building, killing Police Cadet Alfred Harrell and wounding another cadet. A week later, Essex was gunned down on the roof of the Howard Johnson Motel in downtown New Orleans.

title: Capital Group Helps Women Get Top Federal Jobs
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 27  Donna Shalala, an assistant secretary in the Department of Housing and Urban Development, might use it to locate a woman at the state level qualified to head a public service commission.

title: Begin Confirms Offer of Talks
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 27 (AP)  Prime Minister Menachem Begin affirmed in a speech today that Israel was ready to reopen talks with Egypt on a possible joint letter to outline procedures for setting up Palestinian autonomy. But he again rejected Egyptian demands for a target date for electing a Palestinian governing council.

title: Sanyo May Equip China for Fast Food
description: TOKYO, Dec. 27  And next, frozen TV dinners for the Chinese?

title: Sound
description: THE year's end invites reflections on the past and makes me remember a remarkable man I knew as a neighbor during my youth in Vienna. He was Egon Friedell, a historian of some renown whose threevolume Cultural History of Modern Times is so full of maverick notions that it Can be recommended as a source to any student wishing to scandalize his professors. It is just the sort of book one would expect from a man like Friedell, whiz liked to make the rounds of Vienna's literary coffeehouses, scattering epigrams like confetti. One of his typical remarks stuck in my mind and has served me as intellectual stimulus  and irritant  ever since: No subject can possibly be as interesting as its own history. Friedell insisted.

title: Con Ed Plans to Open A Conservation Center
description: From Texaco Touring Center to Consolidated Edison Company Conservation Center  that's the signofthetimes conversion set for the ground floor of the Chrysler Building at 42d Street and Lexington Avenue.

title: Union Proposes Tax Changes
description: The nation's major union of public employees has called for changes in the tax laws at the state level as well as Federal level that would put a much greater buiden on business and on upperincome and uppermiddleincome taxpayers.

title: Under The Japanese Influence
description: EASTERN cultures, especially the Japanese, have understood minimalism for millenniums. Theirs is a quiet, restrained esthetic  as one antiquarian put it, gentle in the arts of peace. Negatives are played against positives, symmetry juxtaposed to asymmetry. Long before designers in this country eliminated furniture in lieu of carpeted platfors, the Japanese knew the value of reducing the elements of decorating to an essential few.

title: Beautiful Crafts Of Old Japan
description: ANYONE accustomed to furnishing their needs for domestic odds and ends from Azuma is in for a shock at Mingei, a serene and beautiful new shop that opened this fall at 398 West Broadway in SoHo. The inexpensive, massproduced china mugs and plastic trays, the packaged matches and Japanese paper lanterns made Azuma a household word during the 1960's. But little of the exquisite traditional crafts produced for centuries in Japan for domestic use have managed to reach us here outside of museums or Madison Avenug antiques shops.

title: Pistons 131, Rockets 119
description: PONTIAC, Mich., Dec. 27 (AP)  M. L. Carr poured in 36 points, 21 in the first half, to lead the Detroit Pistons to a 131119 victory over the Houston Rockets tonight.

title: Carter Budget Aims at 81 Surplus
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27  The budget [or the 4980 fiscal year that President Carter will send to Congress next month will include a provisional projection for 1981 showing that the budget is narrowly in balance and perhaps even has a surplus, Administration officials disclosed tonight.

title: Financial Futures: New Hedge
description: Wall Street is learning a trick or two from Hershey Foods.

title: Iron Will Helped Boumediene Gain Power in Algeria
description: Shrewd use of power, an iron will and sense of mission to improve the life of the poor helped make Houari Boumediene master of Algeria and one of the spokesmen of the developing world.

title: The Region
description: WHITE PLAINS  Eighteen of Westchester County's longawaited advancedesign buses made their appearance yesterday as county officials congratulated each other and took demonstration rides. The buses are part of a planned fleet of 105 vehicles.

title: TV: House Divided Views Congress
description: WATCHING A House Divided, which will be seen from 8 to 9 o'clock tonight on WNEWTV, is enough to make one heartily ashamed of ever having criticized, let alone having voted against, a member of Congress.

title: Oregon Man Found Not Guilty On a Charge of Raping His Wife
description: SALEM, Ore., Dec. 27  A jury of eight women and four men found John Rideout not guilty today of a charge of firstdegree rape brought by his wife, Greta.

title: Design Notebook
description: To wake up thder.a ceiling of goddesses reclining on rosy clouds against a cerulean sky, chariots drawn by putti racing across the heavens, or to gaze up at chastely draped maidens tending delicate white garlands  this is not the rising experience, as a rule, of less than dukes or kings. To start the morning with the visual fanfare of frescoes overhead, foreshortened figures plunging down to earth in gilded cartouches, or with the snowandlace fantasy of sculptured and Molded plasterwork emulating nature and ancient Rome, is a very special way to greet the day.

title: ABROAD AT HOME The Stakes In China
description: BOSTON, Dec. 27  After thirty years of oppressive controls on every aspect of its citizens' lives, the most populous country on earth is taking tentative steps toward a more humane order. After thirty years of nearisolation from the main economic currents of the capitalist world, it is eagerly seeking foreign investment and trade.

title: Contract to Hedge On Price Index?
description: Your salary isn't keeping pace with inflation? The futures markets may someday offer a solution.

title: Max Blitzer, 88
description: Max Blitzer, founder of and head of Pinesbridge Farm, a New York City packer of specialty foods, from 1936 until he sold the business in the 1950's, died Sunday at a nursing home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 88 years old, and had moved to Cambridge from Manhattan in 1955

title: MacMillan Target of 2d Control Bid
description: TORONTO, Dec. 27  In yet another surprising takeover bid, Canadian Pacific Investments, an arm of a conglomerate that runs a major railroad and airline, announced today an offer to buy all the outstanding shares of MacMillan Bloedel Ltd., Canada's largest forestproducts company.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Dec. 18 Incorrectly indentified the defendant in a Supreme Court case involving the liability of stockbrokers. The defendant is Neil T. Naftal in.

title: Papal Envoy Meets With Leaders Of Argentina Over Rift With Chile
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 27  A papal representative seeking a peaceful solution to the Beagle Channel controversy between Argentina and Chile completed his first round of talks here today and prepared to fly to Chile to hear the views of its Government.

title: Philippine Oil to Flow
description: MANILA, Dec. 27 (UPI)  The Philippines, which first struck oil in 1976, will start commercial production Jan. 12, President Ferdinand E. Marcos announced today. He said that the oil would be produced from the Nido1 exploration complex operated by a consortium led by the Cities Service Company of Tulsa, Okla.

title: Stage: Martin Halpem's Total Recall
description: THE central character in Martin Halpern's Total Recall, running this week in the Late Show series of oneact plays at the Circle Repertory. Company, is a holy ghostwriter, tailoring sermons to the individual measurements of preachers.

title: Adopted Son of People's Temple Leader Balks at Grand Jury Questions
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 27  An adopted son of the Rev. Jim Jones appeared before a Federal grand jury here today and, his lawyer said later, refused to answer more than a dozen questions about his membership in the People's Temple because of possible selfincrimination.

title: Keeping the Peace Around Cape Horn
description: Pope John Paul II has lifted the threat of war that has been clouding the southern tip of South America. Bitterness between Argentina and Chile had been mounting over ownership of three small islands at the mouth of the Beagle Channel, which runs south of Tierra del Fuego.

title: U.S. Defends Its Right To End Taiwan Treaty
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP)  The State Department, reaching back to the Founding Fathers, says President Carter has the right, acting alone, to terminate the United States defense treaty with Taiwan.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27  After acceding to China's demand for recognition on its own terms, did President Carter try to deceive the American people about the Soviet reaction?

title: Egypt Said to Work on Arab Ties
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 27  A message received today by President Hafez alAssad of Syria from King Khalid of Saudi Arabia was reported by Arab diplomatic sources to be related to a new Egyptian diplomatic effort to improve its relations with other Arab states.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ONCE IS NOT ENOUGH A recent issue of Playbill stated that the only existing filmed performance by Katharine Cornell is her cameo in Stage Door Canteen (1944). There are actually two more.

title: Cost of Hareburger Meat Expected to Rise Sharply
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP)  Hamburger prices may go up 40 to 50 cents a pound next year, making ground beef as costly as round steak was early this year, a meat industry spokesman said today.

title: Dollar Dip And Iran Hurt Stocks
description: The highriding glamour issues took a spill along with the rest of the stock market yesterday as the deteriorating political situation in Iran and a weak dollar dampened investor sentiment.

title: 76ers 122, Pacers 110
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 (AP) Doug Collins scored 25 points to lead the Philadelphia 76ers to a 122110 victory over the Indiana Pacers tonight.

title: William E. Knox Dies
description: William Edward Knox, retired head of Westinghouse Electric International Company, a businessman praised for his genius in selling big projects abroad and who played a key role in the communication between the United States and Soviet Premier Nikita Kruschev during the Cuban missle crisis, died yesterday at his home at 267 Milford Lane in Jamesburg, N.J. He was 77 years old.

title: Business Records
description: Wennesday. Dec. 27.1911

title: Four Gunmen in Geneva Snatch $1.7 Million in Holiday Receipts
description: GENEVA, Dec. 27 (Reuters)  Four masked gunmen snatched 2.7 million Swiss francs ($1.7 million) from bank employees at a shopping center today and escaped in a stolen car, the police said.

title: Armistice on Military Pensions
description: The military pension system is unfair to noncareer soldiers, interferes with good personnel management  and costs billions of dollars a year to boot. These considerations prompted a blueribbon Presidential commission last spring to propose radical but sensible reforms. The plan nearly fell victim to conservative opposition within the armed forces, but now appears that Defense Secretary Harold Brown has fashioned a compromise that retains the traditional lifetime benefit structure so dear to the military, yet meets the commission's reform objectives.

title: Advances In Housing
description: Construction of new housing in the third quarter reached 520,989 units, 7.5 percent above the figure for the corresponding period a year earlier, the F.W. Dodge division of the McGrawHill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Carter Lauds Algerian For Independence Role
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (Reuters) President Carter expressed regret today over the death of President Houari Bountediene of Algeria.

title: Dillingham Sells Reef Cattle Unit
description: The Dillingham Corporation said it had sold Reef Cattle Management Ltd., an Australian subsidiary, and as a result expected a yearend tax credit that would increase its 1978 operating earnings by about $6.4 million, or 50 cents a share.

title: Boumediene, Algerian Chief, Dies; Legislator Is Temporary President
description: ALGIERS, Dec. 27  President.Houarl Boumediene, who ruled Algeria for 13 of its 16 years of independence and made it leading champion of third world nations, died here early today after almost six weeks in a coma. The Speaker of the National Popular Assembly, Rabah Mat, was proclaimed interim President.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The Treasury Department announced yesterday that it would sell $1.5 billion in 15year bonds next Thursday.

title: Vanderbilt Eviction Expected in Newport
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 27  The growing middleclass movement back into the nation's cities, which is simultaneously revitalizing decayed neighborhoods and displacing poor people who cannot afford the increased rents, may have its latest victim this week when a local judge is expected to order the eviction of Louise M. Vanderbilt.

title: Home Improvement;Water Filters: What They Can and Cannot Do
description: ONE result of the nation's increasing concern with the ecology and the desire to eliminate pollution has been an increased demand for better drinking water. Water filters that take out rust and sediment and chemicals and other foreign matter that can cause bad tastes and odors, have been around for many years. But it is only recently that many, people have started buying and installing them (often to eliminate the need for buying bottled water).

title: The City
description: Borough President Andrew J. Stein of Manhattan charged that the city's Emergency Medical Service was grossly incompetent in its handling of disasters. He cited as an example the service's performance during the Staten Island ferryboat crash at Battery Park in November.

title: Grafton, Iowa And Its Garbage
description: In a striking example of what can be produced when the business and private sectors work together, two major American corporations and a typical small town have gotten together to make garbage.

title: Westchester Medical Unit Allows Private staff Practice on Premises
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 27  The newly built Westchester County Medical Center will permit doctors on its staff to conduct their respective private medical practices there as part of an effort to increase the number of patients at the underused facility.

title: High Court Backs Project Of Museum of Modern Art
description: A major'obstacle to the MuseiM of Modern Art's controversial plan to erect luxury apartments atop an expanded gallery was removed yesterday by the State Court of Appeals. In reversing a lower court's decision, the state's highest court upheld the constitutionality of a law giving the project an exemption from realestate taxes.

title: Diesel Cars Said to Emit High Levels of Pollution
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Dec. 27 (AP) Dieselpowered automobiles emit unacceptably high levels of air pollution and must be changed to ward off a possible health hazard, a Federal air quality expert has said.

title: KING OF SPAIN SIGNS A NEW CONSTITUTION
description: MADRID, Dec. 27  King Juan Carlos signed Spain's democratic Constitution today and pledged to remain above the political fray in the new era that he was inaugurating.

title: Notes on People
description: Edward Vilella's venture onto the stage of city government proved to be at the very least, a tarantella. So the New York City Ballet principal dancer said yesterday in confirming his resignation as chairman of the unsalaried Commission for Cultural Affairs, a job to which he was appointed on May I. His letter to Mayor Koch was dated Dec. 12, but was made public by the Mayor's press office only after repeated queries by The New York Times.

title: EARNINGS
description: The Palm Beach Company, manufacturers of men's, boys' and women's clothing and sportswear, yesterday reported a 24 percent gain in net income for the quarter ended Oct. 28, on a 22 percent sales gain. Earnings for the full fiscal year were also up.

title: Former Screvane Aide Accused by Chauffeur In PayFraud Scheme
description: A chauffeur for the Offtrack Betting Corporation has told New York City investigators that he was pressured into falsifying his overtime records by an aide to Paul R. Screvane, the former president of the corporation.

title: The Screen: Arab Jews:A Silent Majority
description: THE Film Forum, that pocket-sized theater on Vandam Street in the lower reaches of Greenwich Village, continues to offer the most consistently rewarding programs of any film showcase in the city. This year the theater has presented the local theatrical premieres of two of the most interesting films to be seen here in 1978, Kenji Mizoguchi's "A Geisha" (1953) and Andrzej Wajda's "Landscape After the Battle" (1970), both films that could have not survived the economic rigors of conventional New York City first runs."We Are Arab Jews in Israel," which opens at the Film Forum today, is not in the same category with those fiction films but it is a provocative, remarkably even-tempered movie, a two-hour documentary about a subject not often explored by the press because of the pressure to cover day-to-day events.The film is the work of Igaal Niddam, a Moroccan Jew and Israeli citizen, at present a resident of Switzerland, who strongly believes that Israel's population of Arab Jews could provide "a natural bridge" leading to an Israeli-Arab understanding.Though 65 percent of Israel's citizens are so-called Arab Jews, that is, Jews with origins in Arab countries, Mr. Niddam believes they are still a silent majority, inarticulate citizens who, often because of their low economic status, are ignored by the power structure. As a result, says this film, the political policies of the nation are largely determined by Jews whose attachments are to Western Europe and America, people whose cultural sympathies make it impossible for them to understand their Arab neighbors, or to be understood by them."We Are Arab Jews in Israel" seems to have been completed last year, before Israeli Premier Menachem Begin and Egyptian President Anwar el-Sadat began their negotiations for an Israeli-Egyptian settlement, though there's nothing in the film to make it seem dated. If anything, it offers clues to the present situation.It is obviously Mr. Niddam's belief that until Israel's Arab Jews find their voice, the present stalemate will continue. This point is eloquently made toward the end of the movie by a young man working on a kibbutz, an Iraqi Jew who also suggests that Zionism, in addition to defining Jewish nationalism, encouraged the previously undeveloped feelings of Arab nationalism. In effect, he says, one is responsible for the other.Mr. Niddam's method is straightforward and direct, without cinematic artifice. "We Are Arab Jews in Israel" deals with highly emotional, extremely complicated issues, but it never attempts to mask the emotion or the complexity, or the film maker's own point of view. The movie will play at the Film Forum tonight through Sunday at 7:45 P.M. and next week, Thursday though Sunday, at the same hour.

title: Backgammon:
description: Patiecs is a virtue in many talkies, but probably In no other game is it as important for winning as in backgammon. The caprice of the dice try even the most experienced player, often leading him to make rash judgments. For example, the inability to reject an unsound double and move on to the next game probably accounts for more losses in backgammon than any other single factor. What is seldom realized is that patience is often the best strategy in not only the use  of the doubling cube, but also moving the checkers.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: A competing offer for MacMillan Bloedel, Canada's largest forest products company, was announced by Canadian Pacific Investments, an arm of Canadian Pacific Ltd., which operates the Canadian Pacific Railroad as well as numerous other businesses. Earlier, Domtar Ltd. had announced a bid for MacMillan, and MacMillan then offered to acquire Domtar, in a series of corporate moves attracting wide attention in Canada. [Page D1.]

title: Taiwanese Attack U.S. Motorcade As Officials Arrive for Negotiations
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Thursday, Dec. 28 The Deputy Secretary of State, Warren M. Christopher, and other members of an American delegation were caught in an angry mob here last night as they arrived to discuss problems arising from the decision of the United States to sever diplomatic relations with the Chinese Nationalist Government on Taiwan.

title: Iran Voids Helicopter Contract
description: Textron Inc. announced yesterday that the Government of strifetorn Iran had formally canceled a $575 million contract with Textron's Bell Helicopter subsidiary.

title: Texan Accused of a Murder Plot Says He Meant to Help the F.B.I.
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 27  T. Cullen Davis, the Fort Worth executive and multimillionaire accused of paying Charles David McCrory to have a judge killed, testifed today that he merely played along with Mr. McCrory because he thought that doing so would help a Federal effort to catch Mr. McCrory in an extortion scheme.

title: Anaconda ExAide in Guilty Plea
description: Charles H. Kraft, who was treasurer of the Anaconda Company until last September, pleaded guilty yesterday to charges that he had fraudulently induced major banks to lend $34 million in the last seven years to companies controlled by two business promoters.

title: Probation Sentences Ended in Death in Jonestown
description: SAN FRANCISCO  One thing remem bered by most of those through whose hands Ruthie Mae Quinn passed was that her arrest record was eight pages longarrests for prostitution, marijuana, lewd conduct, petty theft and mail theft.

title: Queens Women's Five Reflects Talent in City
description: Lucille Kyvallos thinks the skeptics will be wrong this year about the women's basketball program at Queens College.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: AMERICAN ARCHER (U.S. Lines). Rotterdam Jan. 13 and Felixstowe 14; sails from Howland Hook, Staten Island.

title: Bridge:
description: Two of the world's greatest bridge personalities, friendly rivals for half a century, met recently in Hawaii, talked about old battles, and, of course, played some bridge. Both were New York residents for most of their bridge lifetimes, but have departed to wanner climes.

title: HOLOCAUST REACHES UNWITTING VICTIM
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 27 (AP) When Charles Kane's mother died, he discovered that she was not his mother, that the sister he grew up with was not his sister that 30 years after World War II he was an unwitting victim of the Holocaust.

title: U.S. Awaits Views From Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (Reuters) The United States is still waiting for Israel and Egypt to respond to suggestions aired by Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance's in his Brussels talks, the State Department said today.

title: Where to Shop for Japanese Decorative Objects
description: TRADITIONALLY sparse, Japanese interior design has definitely influenced the vogueish minimal look, according to Richard Knapple, Bloomingdale's home furnishings fashion director.

title: Helmsley In Motor Inn Bid
description: Helmsley Enterprises, owned by Harry B. Helmsley, the real estate developer, said yesterday it was offering to pay $25 a share for any and all shares of Hospitality Motor Inns, a deal that would involve more than $36 million on the basis of nearly 1.5 million shares outstanding. Last October Helmsley reached agreement with the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) to buy Sohio's 49 percent stake in Hospitality Motor Inns at $25 a share.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Woman Killed on Roller Coaster
description: VALENCIA, Calif., Dec. 27 (UPI) 20yearold woman fell out of a car of roller coaster yesterday as it plunged downward at 60 miles an hour and was killed. She was identified as Carol Flores of East Los Angeles. Deputies immediately closed the popular roller coaster, the Colossus at Magic Mountain Amusement Park.

title: Phil Meyers, Founded and Led The Standard Wine & Liquor Co.
description: Phil Meyers, chairman and founder of Standard Wine & Liquor Company of Woodside, Queens, died yesterday at his home at 900 Fifth Avenue, after a long illness. He was 77 years old.

title: 7Year Itch Sends Horse Back to Track
description: Seven years after being retired to stud, an unwanted breeding stallion named Lola Wantz is back on the race track trying to improve his image so that his $500 fee as a sire can be increased.out of Lola's Luck, was shipped north for the Meadowlands race from his base at Garden State Park in Cherry Hill, N.J., by his trainer, Richard Damon. In what could have been racing's understatement of the year, the comment on Lola Wantz by Sweep in The Daily Racing Form read: Been idle long time.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Technicare Meeting Set
description: The Technicare Corporation said yesterday that it would hold a special meeting of shareholders on Feb. 21 to vote on the proposed merger with Johnson & Johnson. Technicare is a maker of medical equipment.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: WILLIAM L. ERPENBECK

title: Unbeaten Irish Roll, 96 to 43
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 27 (AP) Orlando Woolridge scored 18 points and Bruce Flowers added 16 tonight as No. 2 ranked Notre Dame ended an 18day layoff with a 9643 rout of St. Francis of Pennsylvania.

title: Wilkison Upset Victim; Vilas Struggles to Win
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 27 (UPI)  Alan Stone dashed Tim Wilkison's hopes of being the new international tennis standout by beating the young American, 6.3, 62, 63, in the first round of the $300,000 Australian open championship at Kooyong.

title: St. Peter's 76, F.D.U. 65
description: JERSEY CITY, Dec. 27  St. Peter's College scored 12 of the final 14 points and defeated Fairleigli Dickinson, 7665, tonight as the Peacocks improved their record to 64.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Associated Dry Goods Corporation, operating 16 department store divisions, has appointed Richard Rusthoven president of Stix, Baer & Fuller.

title: German Jesuit Missionary Slain At Remote Outpost in Rhodesia
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 27 (Reuters)  A white Roman Catholic missionary was shot dead yesterday at a remote mission in northeastern Rhodesia, church sources said today.

title: 100,000 Berliners Visit the East
description: WEST BERLIN, Dec. 27 (Reuters) About 100,000 West Berliners visited relatives and friends in East Berlin and East Germany for Christmas, a Government spokesman said today. A similar number is expected to leave the city for the East during the New Year holiday, be added.

title: 10 Food Places Found Violating The New York City Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health issued yesterday a list of 10 food establishments it said had violated the Health Code and two restaurants that had corrected earlier violations. The establishments are:

title: 52 Chinese Scholars Arrive in U.S. for 2Year Stay
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27  Fiftytwo Chinese scholars arrived here today, the first such group since the American decision to normalise relations with Peking.

title: SADAT IS OPTIMISTiC ABOUT PEACE TALKS
description: CAIRO, Dec. 27  President Anwar elSadat said today that be believed there was a very good chance that peace talks with Israel could resume soon and suggested that there might be movement within two days.

title: Hers
description: IWRITE a lot about myself and my life, and yet am quite cautious writing about the central fact that has changed my life for the better, which that I don't drink. People who drink in deadly earnest call New Year's Eve amateurs night. And most people, including 15 million practicing alcoholics., careen into the new year drunk.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 28,1978

title: Washington Post Split
description: The Washington Post Company said yesterday that its shareholders had approved a previously proposed 2for1 split of its Class A and Class B common stock and a related increase in authorized shares of both classes. The split will take effect tomorrow, with split shares to be distributed on Jan. 5. As previously announced, the company expects to pay a 36cent annual dividend on the split shares, which is a 20 percent increase over the 60cent dividend in effect before the split.

title: Corporate Earnings Reported
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exdsange,(A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) over thecounter.

title: National Delays Meeting
description: MIAMI, Dec. 27 (AP)  National Airlines has postponed its Jan. 15 shareholders meeting so that directors can consider revised proxy statements reflecting the offer by Eastern Air Lines to buy National for $50 a share. Material previously prepared had considered only the takeover offers of Texas International Airlines and Pan American World Airways. When the new meeting is held, stockholders of record Jan. 5 will be entitled to notice and a vote.

title: Steel Output Off for Week
description: Steel production declined to 2.67 million tons for the week ended Dec. 23, down 1.6 percent from the previous week's 2.71 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Bank of Japan Chief Asks Curb on Money Supply
description: TOKYO, Dec. 27 (AP)  The head of Japan's central bank warned today that the nation must limit the growth of its money supply in 1979 to avoid economic problems. Japan's basic money supply has been growing by an average of 12 percent a month since June, increasing inflationary pressure.

title: Shawn Advises New Yorker Colleagues He'll Stay
description: A twosentence note went up on the bulletin board in the editorial offices of The New Yorker magazine late yesterday afternoon, putting an end for now to the continuing rumors that William Shawn, the magazine's editor for the last 26 years, was about to retire.

title: Robin Williams: Comedy For a Narcissistic Time
description: THE mind of Robin Williams is a cosmic trash can where old movies collide with legless shortorder cooks and a peevish old man feeding his methadone to the pigeons; where, in parody of Shakespeare, he wonders whether 'tis nobler to fight the god Nielsen or take the money and build a house in Malibu.

title: Rubber Union Bars Guidelines
description: AKRON, Ohio, Dec. 27 (UPI)  The United Rubber Workers union will not comply with President Carter's wage guidelines in contract negotiations with the rubber industry next year, its international president, Peter Bommarito, said today.

title: Carter Plans to Limit Civil Defense Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27  President Carter has decided to limit spending on civil defense amid growing skepticism in the Administration about its effectiveness and doubt about which path, if any, to take to protect the population against nuclear attack.

title: Guardians of a Sleeping New York
description: The lights begin to go out all over the city, in Brooklyn Heights, Forest Hills, Greenwich Village, Coop City. The sidewalks grow still. Much of the city sleeps.

title: Raku: An Ancient Craft And Ceramic Fantasy
description: NESTLED amid decaying brownstones and condemned factory buildings at 549 West 52d Street is the Women's Interart Center, which, like the inside of a ceramic box on display, surprises the visitor with an unexpected show of interior beauty.

title: Letters: Readers Respond on Jews Celebrating Christmas
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: SouthWest Africa Frees 6 Nationalist Executives
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Africa, Dec. 27 (Reuters)  Six executives of the SouthWest Africa People's Organization, arrested early this month after bombings here, have been released, the police said today.

title: Steelers' Mike Webster: The Anonymous AllPro
description: Mike Webster. You know him. Well, maybe not. He's only the best center in pro football, according to a lot of people, including other centers in pro football, like Jim Clack of the Giants.

title: Comedy Series Maintain Leads in TV Ratings
description: A profusion of holiday specials did little last week to divert the attention of television viewers from such popular situationcomedies as Laveme and Shirley, Happy Days, M*A*S*H, One Day at a Time and Mork and Mindy.

title: Market Place
description: KEOGHPLUS, which is being suggested as a highpowered way to increase retirement deductions and benefits for the selfemployed, may not be as exciting for some participants as it is for others.

title: Frederick R. Childs, 70, PostImpressionist Artist
description: Frederick Robbins Childs, a New York postImpressionist painter, died Monday in St. Joseph's Hospital in Stamford, Conn. Mr. Childs, who lived in New York City and Noroton, Conn., was 70 years old.

title: Basil T. Horsfield, a Metallurgist And Consultant on Aluminum, 83
description: Basil T. Horsfield, a metallurgist and a consultant on aluminum, died Monday at a hospital in Florence, Ala. He was 83 years old and had lived in Florence.

title: Taiwan Flag Vanishes, Mortifying U.S. Aides
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UPI) Somebody jumped the gun at the State Department, and protOcol officials said today that they were mortified and embarrassed.

title: A More Potent Marijuana Is Stirring Fresh Debates
description: Most marijuana now being sold throughout the United States is three to 10 times more potent than the marijuana that was sold two years ago, according to Federal drug enforcement officials and promarijuana groups.

title: 15 Young Episcopal Women Presented to Bishop Witcher
description: Fifteen young women in their senior year of high school were presented to Bishop Robert Campbell Witcher of the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island at the Cathedral of the Incarnation in Garden City, L.I., last evening. The presentees, communicants of the Cathedral, St. Peter's Church in Bay Shore, L.I., St. John's of Lattingtown in Locust Valley, L.I., qualified by service to church and community. Each received a commemorative gold medallion.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: KARLSTAD, Sweden, Dec. 27 (UPI)  Both the United States and Canada were beaten today in opening matches of the 1978 World Junior Hockey Championships.

title: Pop: Rita Gardner Sings
description: THIS week's Salute to Great American Song Writers in the Atrium of the Citicorp Center, Lexington Avenue at 54th Street, is a doubleheader. Two songwriters are being saluted  Sheldon Harnick, mostly in collaboration with Jerry Bock, and Cy Coleman, with lyrics by Carolyn Leigh and Dorothy Fields  a division that allows Rita Gardner, who is singing their songs through tonight, to show two distinctively different sides of her personality.

title: Braniff Fined In Trust Case
description: LAKE CHARLES, La.Dec. 27 (AP)  Braniff Airways declined to contest charges of violating Federal antitrust laws and was fined $100,000 today for using unfair tactics in squeezing a rival airline out of the commuter business.

title: Parade in Chinatown Is Set Jan. 1 to Mark Gain in Peking Ties
description: The U.S.China Normalization Celebration Committee, a newly formed group of Chinatown business leaders, met yesterday to announce that it would hold a pa rade this Monday to celebrate the Carter Administration's normalization of relations with the People's Republic of China.

title: DOCTOR HELD LIABLE IN ABNORMAL BIRTHS
description: If a doctor fails to advise a patient properly that she faces particular risks of bearing an abnormal child, and she then gives birth to such a child, the doctor may be required to pay the lifelong special costs of caring for it, the New York State Court of Appeals ruled yesterday. The court split 5 to 2 on the issue.

title: Boy King of the Islanders
description: The relics of the boy king, known as King Tut, glisten the Metropolitan Museum of Art; another boy king glistens with the New York Islanders  call this one King Trot. But he's no mummy.

title: Judging Justice Tyler
description: In clearing State Supreme Court Justice Andrew Tyler of perjury the other day, the New York Court of Appeals drew some useful lines. The court made it clear that perjury is not just telling a fib to some official body like a grand jury. It is a crime of the utmost seriousness, a deliberately false answer to a question pertinent to an official investigation or judicial proceeding. But in this case, the court found that the former state special prosecutor, Maurice Nadjari, showed more interest in trapping the judge in a lie than in eliciting faCts material to the investigation of corruption. When the prosecutor tailors his questioning to extract a falseanswer, the court said, he so exceeds his function that even a false response does not frustrate any valid purpose of the grand jury.

title: Chinese Nationalists Are Selling Their Only Property in New York
description: The Chinese Nationalist Government on Taiwan is selling its only New York City real estate holding, a fourstory brownstone on Lexington Avene that houses the Chinese Information Service, a Nationalist Government official said yesterday.

title: Key Oil Well Closed In Baltimore Canyon
description: In what amounts to the biggest disappointment yet in the search for, oil and gas off New Jersey, the Mobil Corporation announced yesterday that it was abandoning its first well in the Baltimore Canyon after tests had uncovered no significant quantities of either.

title: Jazz: Brecker Brothers 6
description: THE Brecker BrothersRandy, the trumpeter, and Michael, the tenor saxophonistare celebrating the holidays by bringing their sextet into their own club, Seventh Avenue South, the splitlevel jazz room at Seventh Avenue South and Leroy Street, where they will be playing through Sunday.

title: Three Czannes Worth $2 Million Are Discovered Stolen in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 27  Three paintings by Paul Czanne, the 19thcentury French master, were discovered missing today from the Art Institute of Chicago.

title: Music: P. D. Q. Bach
description: WHO would ever have thought, 15 years ago, that popular entertainment could be made out of the spoofing of musicology, that scholarly branch of music that frightens off most practicing musicians and is a mystery to almost everyone else? No one could have guessed then that such a thing might be possible, not even Peter Schickele.

title: HARRINGTON WIMBERLY
description: DUNCAN, Okla., Dec. 26 (AP)  Harrington Wimberly, editor and publisher of The Duncan Banner, died Tuesday. He was 77 years old.

title: Advertising
description: KENT Rhodes likes problems, and that's nice. On Jan. 15, at the age of 66, he begins as fulltime president of the Magazine Publishers Association; a job with problems, real and potential, up to here.

title: Tourists Discover New Delight in City's Traditional Pursuits
description: Last week they were here with a purpose, trying not to panic at the relentless reminders that told them that they had only four more days... three more days... two more days... in which to get it all done.

title: Fighting Inflation
description: Since 1950, the Federal budget has been in balance in only five years. Since 1970 a deficit has occurred in every year. Budget deficits have thus become a chronic condition of Federal finance; they have been incurred in years when business conditions were poor and also when business was booming. Traditional rules for incurring deficits only when the economy was weak have been ignored. Not only that, but the deficits have increased sharply in size in recent years.

title: So. African's Bout Given GoAhead by Werblin
description: David A. (Sonny) Werblin may be vacationing in Florida, but his work continued back at Madison Square Garden yesterday where he left word that the fight between Kallie Knoetze, the controversial South African heavyweight boxer, and Bill Sharkey will go on.

title: Topics Innovations
description: The 1970 census cost $220 million, or about $1 for each person in this country. The 1980 census will cost almost a billion dollars, or about $4 a person, and the General Accounting Office wonders whether Congress will be getting its money's worth. G.A.O. is paid to be skeptical; but the increased census costs seem inescapable.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in,companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.

title: Students Clash in a Turkish City; MartialLaw Courts Are Set Up
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 27 (AP) Leftist and rightist students clashed at a vocational school in a southern Turkish town today, leaving one person dead, but calm was reported elsewhere under the new martiallaw administrations.

title: Nancy Sterling Is Wed to David W. Cudlipp
description: Nancy Macdonald Sterling, who is with Rash & Hertz Personnel in New York, was married in Short Hills, N.J., yesterday to David Wisner Cudlipp, a divisional vice president of J.P. Stevens & Company, the textile concern. The ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church was performed by the Rev. Alfred Niese and attended by members of the couple's immediate families.

title: Head of BookofMonth Club to Retire Next Month
description: In January 1934, Axel G. Rosin, a young lawyer working for the Supreme Court of Prussia, emigrated from his native Berlin to the United States. The Nazis had told him that Jews would no longer be allowed to enter the courthouse.

title: Wouldbe Ski Thief Tripping Over Bug
description: Officials of the Killington ski area in Vermont are convinced that, at long last, they have developed a foolproof system for detecting ski thieves.

title: HUGE MEDICAL TEAM TREATED ALGERIAN
description: President Houari Boumediene of Algeria, who died yesterday after being in a coma kir almost six weeks was treated by perhaps the largest international medical team ever to care for one patient..

title: World News Briefs
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 27 (Reuters)  A white Cabinet minister in Rhodesia's biracial transitional government resigned today, saying that he favored the BritishAmerican plan for advancement to majority rule rather than Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's formula.

title: 4 U.S. Aides Say Albany Delays Westway Plan
description: Four top officials of the Carter Administration have told Governor Carey that New York State, not the Federal Government, is holding up the controversial Westway highway project.

title: Radio Jam Session To Welcome 1979
description: Back in the 1930's and 40's, it was common to hear live jazz and swing concerts broadcast from clubs across. the country.

title: Japanese Oil Imports
description: TOKYO, Dec. 27 (UPI)  Japan imported 150.1 million barrels of crude oil in November, a 9.9 percent increase over October but a 2.5 percent drop from November of last year, the Petroleum Association reported today. The association said that imports from the Middle East amounted to 120.5 million barrels, up 17.9 percent from a year ago.

title: Official of A.M.A. Finds Threat to Regulatory Role
description: Jim Sammons's soft Texas drawl and country countenance were beginning to take on an edge as he discussed the threats posed by a string of court decisions and Federal rulings to the power and influence of the American Medical Association.

title: Ground Broken for Housing
description: Eleven years after it was first proposed, ground was finally broken yesterday for the construction of 330 units of lowincome public housing in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn.

title: Continental Phone Buys 7.4% of WUl
description: The Continental Telephone Corporation, in an unfriendly takeover bid, disclosedyesterday that it had bought 7.4 percent of WUI Inc., also known as Western Union International.

title: Israeli RightWingers Ousted From 2 Camps Set Up on West Bank
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 27  The Israeli Army quickly routed about 70 families of Jewish nationalists who established two illegal settlements today on the occupied West Bank overlooking Jerusalem.

title: Q&A
description: Q Our house has a large studio at ys ground level with a slate floor that is hard to keep clean. This room is heated by hot water pipes in the floor under the slate. We would like to apply a coat of stone sealer to the slate floor, but we wander what will happen to the sealer when the heat is on. The floor in an attached room was treated with something by the previous owners, and it has turned white in the Joints. Mrs.J.P.II., Weston, Cont.

title: Home Beat
description: LUCKY for Giana Pisacano that the parakeets were affected first. For when the toxic sulphur fumes from the new clay with which she was experimenting fouled the air, she didn't smell it right away. But the birds, she said, flew low. And then she started to cough. There was time to grab her feathered companions, stash them in their cage near an open window in a back room away from the kiln  and get herself out to the fresh air of Spring Street.

title: Cyclamens: Brilliant But Temperamental
description: OF all the plants given as holiday gifts, perhaps none is so magnificently beautiful as the cyclamen. Everything about it is elegance. The flowers have long silken petals in beautiful colors  rose, pink or white. They flare back as if caught M a windstorm, and many people say the petals remind them of orchids or butterflies. Don't forget to sniff them; they have a lovely fragrance.

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, DEC. 27, 1978

title: City Lots: Chance To Grow Wild
description: DESPITE the recent enthusiasm for community gardening that has transformed acres of urban ugliness into thriving vegetable plots and flower beds, there are still some 32,000 cityowned lots scattered in the five boroughs which are filled with rubble and strewn with garbage. While local residents might welcome a garden face lift for these vacant spaces, especially in such harsh environments as the South Bronx, Harlem, the Lower East Side and Brownsville, they are often daunted by the sheer size of the problem and the hours needed to build up the quality of the soil, weed, water and generally coax life back to the land.

title: U.S. Backs Shah On the Forming Of New Regime
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27  With Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi's position apparently more tenuous than ever, the Carter Administration said today that he should continue to play an important role in leading Iran to a new government of national reconciliation.

title: NEW & USEFUL
description: Versatility  la Cart

title: Sports Today
description: Knicks vs. Washington Bullets, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:30 P.M. (Television  Channel Channel E (cable), 7:30 P.M. Radio WNEW, 7:30 P.M.)

title: City Weighing Sale of Golf Courses As Way to Help Close Budget Gap
description: The New York City Parks Department is seriously considering selling one or more of the city's 13 public golf courses, all of which are on park land, in an effort to help close the city's budget gap, Parks Commissioner Gordon J. Davis said yesterday.

title: Diners Sues Air Canada
description: Diners Club Inc. filed a $30 million civil antitrust suit yeSterday charging Air Canada with conspiring to monopolize the Canadian credit card market and with attempting to exclude Diners Club from participation.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows of the past week (Monday. Dec. 18, to Sunday, Dec. 24), listed according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Needlest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249, or to any of the following organizations:

title: First Offer, by Gulf Oil, Made in Contract Talks
description: The first economic offer in the negotiations between the refining industry and the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers union was made today.

title: Arms Snag Linked to Demands By Soviet on New U.S. Missiles
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 American officials said today that lastminute Soviet proposals calling on the United States to curb new generations of advanced missiles were a key factor behind the failure of Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko to complete a new armslimitation agreement in Geneva last week.

title: Tropic Monkey Registers  In Meadowlands Feature
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 27  With a crowd of 28,361 looking on, Sidney M. Baer's Tropic Monkey scored tonight in the $40,000 New Jersey Holiday Sweepstakes at The Meadowlands. A $1 million lottery was based on the outcome of the mile and 70yard event for Jerseybreds.

title: Avenue of Presidents Reviving As Main Street of the Country
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27  It was designed as an avenue of ceremony, America's ChampsElyses.

title: Another Slaying Of Older Person Studied in Bronx
description: An 84yearold woman was found beaten to death after intruders had entered her Bronx apartment through a window on the fireescape in an apparent robbery attempt.

title: Seaboard Coast Line Sets Record Budget
description: Seaboard Coast Line Industries announced a record capital budget of $329 million for 1979. Prime F. Osborn, chairman and chief executive of the railroad holding company, said that the 1979 budget compared with estimated capital expenditures of $179 million this year and $254 million in 1977.

title: Some Optimism at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 27 Western and African diplomats and other officials here were cautiously optimistic today about the prospects for obtaining an agreement with South Africa to carry out United Nationssupervised elections in SouthWest Africa.

title: The Holidays: Reply To Anne Roiphe
description: Anne Roiphe's article, Christmas Comes to a Jewish Home, published last week, drew widespread reaction, most of it negative. Many representa7 tive letters are printed on Page C9. Another answer, by the writer Cynthia Ozick, appears below.

title: 2 Beaten and Robbed at Jamaica IND Station as Clerk Watches in Booth
description: Two youths were beaten and robbed at gunpoint late Tuesday night in the Sutphin Boulevard IND station in Jamaica, Queens, while a clerk watched through the window of his token booth without calling the police for assistance, a Transit Authority spokesman said yesterday.

title: PHILIP HITTI, EXPERT ON ARABIC CULTURE
description: Philip K. Hitti, professor emeritus of Semitic literature at Princeton University, died Sunday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center after a long illness. He was 92 years old.

title: Metropolitan Club Annual Ball
description: The Metropolitan Club held its 13th annual debutante ball last night in honor of five young women related to club members. Mrs. Paul Porzelt, ball chairman, and Harold B. Hamilton, club president, headed the receiving line in the great hall at the clubhouse.

title: Sites Included In F.A.A. Plan On Radar Use
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP)  The following are the locations of the 80 new terminal radar service areas to be established by the Federal Aviation Administration in three phases.

title: Market Place
description: WHEN the BorgWarner Corporation, the a billion producer of auto parts, announced that it was acquiring Baker Industries back in 1977, there were those in Wall Street who seriously questioned the wisdom of the deal.

title: Money Pact In Europe Hits Snag
description: PARIS. Dec. 28  Western Europe's ambitious plans to lock its leading currencies together next week to form a new zone of monetary stability was thrown into doubt today by the eruption of a politically charged quarrel between France and West Germany over farm prices.

title: Zapata Stockholder Sues Officers
description: William H. Flynn, the chairman of the Zapata Corporation; Ronald C. Lassiter, its president, and three other current or past officers of the company are being sued by a stockholder for receiving alleged excessive compensation. The suit further charges that certain loans to these officers, certain alleged amendments to the company's stock option program and certain exercises of stock options by the senior officers were unlawful.

title: IRANIAN STRIKERS SHUT DOWN CENTRAL BANK AND IEFINERIES; FOREIGN OIL AIDES EVACUATED
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 28  Opponents of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahievi effectively pressed strikes in all sectors of the Iranian economy today, trying to bring down the monarchy by dislocating every aspect of national life.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a misplaced digit, an article in Business Day Wednesday incorrectly reported what shareholders of Louis Sherry Inc. would receive as a result of the company's merger with the Norin Corporation. They will recive 0.0441 shares of Norin for each share of Louis Sherry.

title: Seaford Lists Activities For Young Naturalists
description: The Tackapausha Museum and Preserve on Washington Avenue in Seaford, L.I., will offer activities for youngsters 8 to 12 years old this weekend.

title: Analyst Sees Favorites Dominant in N.F.L. Playoffs
description: The weekend's four playoff games in the National Football League appear to be cutanddried affairs, a substantial favorite existing in each match and none with a player of likely import lingering on the injured list.

title: Oil Setback In Caracas
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec 28Venezuela's state oil monopoly, Petroleos de Venezuela, reported today that its 1978 profits totaled $1.19 billion, down a surprising 35 percent from last year, on sales of $9 billion, down slightly from last year's $9.2 billion.

title: Israeli Urges Egypt Pact Await West Bank Deal
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 28  Haim Landau, a hardliner in Prime. Minister Menachem Begin's Cabinet, proposed today that an agreement be reached with Egypt on autonomy for the West Bank and the Gaza Strip before starting to carry out a treaty normalizing relations between the two countries.

title: Schools in Soviet Are Thorough, But Leave Many Things Unsaid
description: MOSCOW  What do Soviet children learn in school? They learn to read; no illiterate highschool graduates here. They learn mathematics; not the new math, but thoroughly. They learn that individuals are not as important as the collective. They learn that Soviet leaders since Lenin have always been right. They are disciplined, but they also dance.

title: Notes on People
description: Serendipitously, Natalia Makarova was in Paris this week, and so was the Kirov Ballet of Leningrad, the company the dancer was with when she defected to the West eight years ago. There was Miss Makarova, with little to do. A strike by stage hands had canceled her scheduled performances in Swan Lake at the Paris Opra with another Russian defector, Rudolf Nureyev. What better way to spend her evenings than to go across town, to the Palais des Congrs, and watch her old troupe, the first time she had done so since she left it in London.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: A shutdown of Iran's oil industry for an indefinite period is in Prospect, energy experts said, reflecting the departure of foreign employees of oil companies operating there. Iran is not considered capable of producing its oil without the help of foreign technicians. The country normally accounts for about 12 percent of supplies for the nonCommunist world. But officials in Washington expressed hopes that a severe shortage of oil could be avoided. [Page A1.]

title: Publishing: A Big Volume on the Little Magazine
description: COMING at the end of January from Pushcart Press, the house that brings out the highly regarded annual Pushcart Prize: The Best of the Small Presses is a volume that should fascinate anyone who is at all interested in the course of American letters in the last four decades: The Little Magazine in America: A Modern Documentary History. The making of the book, a thick 770 pages, edited by Elliott Anderson, editor of TriQuarterly and Mary Kinzie, executive editor of the same magazine, is a story in two parts involving Mr. Anderson and Bill Henderson who is, for all intents and purposes, the Pushcart Press. (Among his other chores, Mr. Henderson wraps his orders and drags them to the post office for mailing.)

title: Mets' Maddox Undergoes Operation on Thumb
description: Elliott Maddox, the New York Mets third basemanoutfielder, was recuperating in Roosevelt Hospital yesterday following surgery for the removal of cartilage in his right thumb. The operation was performed Wednesday.

title: Koch Is Booed by 200 For Refusal to Renew Group's Service Pacts
description: Mayor Koch was heckled and booed yesterday by more than 200 people angry that the Board of Estimate had refused to renew $1.2 million worth of socialservice contracts with the Congress of ItalianAmerican Organizations.

title: WASHINGTON. Swimming Pool Summit
description: PARIS, Dec. 28  President Valry Giscard d'Estaing of France has suggested that the Western summit meeting on the West Indian island of Guadeloupe, Jan. 56, should be held around a swimming pool. No agenda, no big staffs and, God forbid, no reporters.

title: HighLevel Purge in Cambodian Regime Retorted
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 The Cambodian Government has apparently carried out a highlevel purge of Cabinet members who oppose stringent economic and political programs, United States officials said today.

title: Steelworkers' Union Renews Strike Threat At Virginia Shipyard
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28  A top official of the United Steelworkers of America renewed today the union's threat to strike the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, the country's largest shipyard unless the company retreats from a yearlong refusai to bargain for a union contract.

title: Bacteria at Roots of Rice Plants Found to Form Natural Fertilizer
description: Bacteria living in the soil near the roots of rice plants can fix nitrogen from the air into 9 to 20 pounds of nitrogen fertilizer per acre per season, agricultural researchers have discovered.

title: Old Roads for New in Queens
description: New York State and City officials have announced that in an unprecedented move they are asking the Federal Government to let them cancel a pending application for $200 million to widen a few miles of the Long Island Expressway in Queens. In exchange for that ephemeral improvement, they hope to receive $270 million for scattered but serious projects intended to cure specific subway, bridge, highway and bus defects in several parts of the city.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 29, 1978

title: Merrill Settles In S.E.C. Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed public administrative proceedings yesterday against Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, the manager of its Detroit institutional office and a former salesman of that office. The commission simultaneously accepted an offer of settlement from Merrill Lynch and the manager and scheduled a hearing to give the former salesman an opportunity to respond.

title: Where You Can Still Go to Greet the New Year
description: FOR metropolitan New Yorkers who have resolved that this Nevi Year's Eve will be different, there's reason aplenty to be of good cheer. No need to stay at home and merely sip something soothing and perhaps watch television as the lighted ball drops second by second into Times Square at midnight.

title: Credit Markets
description: The nation's money supply held about even in the week ended Dec. 20, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

title: Leader of Big Oil Workers' Union Says Offer of Pact Will be Rejected
description: A contract offer that approaches the limits of President Carter's voluntary wage guidelines will be rejected by the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers Union. its president said yesterday.

title: Bid to Drop Routes Spurned
description: NEWARK, Dec. 28(AP)  De Camp Bus Lines lost a bid today to discontinue moneylosing bus routes that shuttle 465,397 commuters through four North Jersey counties each year. The state Board of Public Utilities said it could not allow a bus line to leave more than 460,000 passengers in the lurch with no access to public transportation.

title: Books of The Times
description: MEDICINE. AN ILLUSTRATED HISTORY. By Albert S. Lyons, M.D., and R. Joseph Petrucelli 2d, M.D. 616 pages. Harry N. Abrams. $60.

title: Islanders Rout Flames, 104; Bossy Scores 3 in 6:42
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 28  The New York Islanders, cruising high above the tough Patrick division of the National Hockey League, shifted into overdrive tonight and signed off with a big 104 victory over the Atlanta Flames in the Omni, pushing the Flames deeper into the division cellar.

title: Around the Nation
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Dec. 28 (AP)  A stolen safe containing experimental drugs from the University of Michigan was recovered today. It was still locked and the drugs were inside, the authorities said.

title: Japanese Companies Plan China Export
description: TOKYO, Dec. 28 (AP)  A group of four Japanese companies will export four petrochemical plants valued at $205 million to China, it was announced today.

title: The Pop Life
description: A COUPLE of weeks ago a band called the Contortions played at Max's Kansas City, and its performance set one listener to brooding about an issue broader than anything the Cortortions themselves have accomplished. That issue is hostility in rockandroll.

title: A New Lombardo Picks Up the Baton
description: When Guy Lombardo's Royal Canadians reach the 50th anniversary of their annual New Year's Eve broadcasts Sunday, evening, The Sweetest Music This Side of Heaven will be conducted by  can you believe it?  a onetime rock drummer whose current first love in music is jazz.

title: Antonio Meucci: Ma Bell's Papa?
description: If the name Meucci does not ring bell, the Italian Historical Society of America is trying to correct that by restoring to the record the name of the man it says is the true inventor of the telephone, Antonio Meucci, an Italian immigrant who lived on Staten Island.

title: Flyers Outlast Rangers
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28  The first fight preceded the first shot on goal tonight as the Philadelphia Flyers set the tone early and defeated the New York Rangers, 65. The Flyers took sole possession of second place in the Patrick Davision. The game ,was won for the home team on Paul Holmgren's goal with 3 minutes 22 seconds remaining.

title: Bridge:
description: Those who make their living directing bridge games, whether at club or tournament level, often have a secret sorrow: Their occupation makes it difficult, perhaps impossible, to show the world what remarkable players they are.

title: Profiles of Seven Whose Faith in Jim Jones Carried Them to Death in Guyana
description: The Rev. Jim Jones, who founded the People's Temple in Indianapolis 1953 and perished with it last month in the tropical jungt that became its last refuge, had been followed there by young and old, black and white, the privileged the and poor, the welleducated and the barely literate. Following are closer looks at seven of the more than 900 who died at Jonestown, Guyana, Nov. 18.

title: Purchasing Optimism; Drop in Construction
description: Purchasing managers still are having difficulty envisioning a recession next year despite almost unanimous predictions to the contrary, E. F. Andrews, chairman of the National Association of Purchasing Management's business survey committee, said yesterday.

title: Liquor Agency Faces a Charge It Violated Law
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union has filed suit in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, charging the State Liquor Authority with multiple violations of the state's openmeeting Law.

title: Bloedel Weighs A New Offer
description: TORONTO, Dec. 28  The board of directors of MacMillan Bloedel Ltd., Canada's largest forestproducts company, announced today that it was giving serious consideration to a takeover bid by Canadian Pacific Investments.

title: N.Y. Schoolboy's Vault Breaks Record at Relays
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Dec. 28 Thomas Yelverton of Susquehanna Valley (N.Y.) High School posted a meet record today, with a pole vault higher than any schoolboy has ever gone in the Lehigh University field house. He cleared 14 feet 6 inches on the second day of the Christmas City Relays.

title: Radio
description: 7.8 A.M., WNCN. Concertino No. 5, Pergolesi; Quartet No. 2, Nocturne, Borodin; The Fairy Queen, Suite No. 1, Purcell; Sonata for Two Trumpets and Strings, Alberti.

title: Open Admission Found of Benefit To Whites, Too
description: A detailed study of the first three freshman classes admitted under the open admissions policy at the City University of New York has found that white students as well as minority students benefited significantly from eased entrance requirements.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: A Judicial Panel Will Admonish Justice Spector
description: The New York State Commission on Judicial Conduct said yesterday that it would publicly admonish Justice Morris E. Spector of State Supreme Court for awarding lucrative court appointments to relatives of other judges, who, in turn, gave similar assignments to Justice Spector's son.

title: Mrs. Sakharov Is Given New Visa to Go to Italy
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 28 (Reuters)  Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and human rights advocate, said today that his wife had been given permission to travel to Italy for medical treatment after a 10month wait.

title: U.C.L.A. 95, Southern Cal 67
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 28 (AP)Rebounding from its first conference loss ever under Coach Gary Cunningham, the University of California, Los Angeles defeated Southern Cal, 9567, tonight. Brad Holland and Roy Hamilton combined for 36 points, and Kiki Vandeweghe, a reserve center, added 19.

title: Indefinite Shutdown Feared
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28  On the advice of their companies, foreign employ4 ees of oil concerns operating in Iran are leaving the country in large numbers, raising the prospect of an indefinite continuation of the threedayold shutdown of Iran's oil industry, energy experts said today.

title: Soviet Harvest Called Stable
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 28 (UPI)  The Soviet Agriculture Minister, Valentin K. Mesyats, said today that this year's record grain crop  and the results in other areas of Soviet agriculture  showed that the Soviet Union had been able to stabilize production despite unpredictable weather conditions.

title: R.I. Tops Denver, 76 to 65
description: DETROIT, Dec. 28.(AP) Sylvester (Sly) Williams scored 19 points tonight as the University of Rhode Island defeated the University of Denver, 7665, in the opening round of the 27th annual Motor City basketball tournament.

title: Philip Morris Lifts Cigarette Prices
description: Philip Morris U.S.A. yesterday announced a wholesale price increase on cigarettes that may translate into an rise at retail of as much as 2 cents a pack.

title: The Coolest Ice Cubes Around Town
description: Quick, before they melt. Perrier ice cubes are tinkling in party glasses around the city. Having developed an addiction to the chic and sparkling mineral water from the south of France, some purists now refuse to defile their Perrier with ice cubes from the water supply system of the city of New York. Thus, they are freezing their own.

title: Auctions
description: RARELY in recent years have art collectors had the edge they have today as sellers, especially at auction. But as strong as the art, antiques aria jewelry markets are, there are numerous considerations that owners of Rembrandts or diamond necklaces must bear in mind before deciding to sell, even after they decide to try the auction houses. For not all of those establishments offer the same terms or achieve the same results.

title: Business and the Law
description: LAWYERS have always been able to promote themselves. Some have been sly and subtle, while others have been conspicuously unsubtle.

title: Opera: 'Hodges & Co.
description: THE 14yearold Harlem Opera is currently installed at the Enlarmedia Theater, 189 Second Avenue, where it is offering two works in repertory, Hodges & Co. and Solomon & Sheba. The latter Ras been given in various auditoriums around town before, but Hodges is new locally. It had its premiere in Houston last June and its first performance in New York Teesday night.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: The Uncut Tristan Concert With a Life of Its Own
description: The telephone kept ringing in Eve Queler's upper West Side apartment on Wednesday morning, but she made others answer it. I don't think I can face any more crises at the moment, she told a visitor. She was referring to the fact that the two leading singers in the concert performance of Wagner's Tristan and Isolde, which she was scheduled to conduct in Carnegie Hall on Sunday night had had to withdraw because of illness.

title: Lefkowitz Seeks to Dissolve CORE
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz has asked in State Supreme Court in New York City that the Congress of Racial Equality be dissolved, or its officers removed, in a petition charging its officers with fraud.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP)  The Continental Grain Company, one of the world's largest exporters of farm commodities, pleaded guilty in United States District Court and was fined the maximum of $18,000 for using deceptive grain loading methods at its Norfolk, Va., elevator, the Government said today.

title: Jersey Is Considering Taking Over The State's Largest Bus Company
description: TRENTON, Dec. 28  Governor Byrne and New Jersey transportation officials are discussing the possible takeover of Transport of New Jersy, the state's largest bus company, as the key to realigning bus service around the state.

title: At the Movies
description: IN California Suite Michael. Caine plays the consort of an English actress, played by Maggie Smith, who, after being nominated for an Academy Award, Is flown to Hollywood for the ceremony. It is a lovely seginent in a funny and stylish adaptation of Neil Simon's Broadway hit, and if Mr. Caine was especially sympathetic in his role it was because he knows what it feels like.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Tough Broncos' Defense Is Matter of Team Pride
description: It is time to take the Denver Broncos seriously. Forget the oranges, forget that they are the only National Football League team to play home games on Rocky Mountain time, forget even that Craig Morton is the starting quarterback.

title: Students at Schools in Brooklyn And Bronx Help Neediest Cases
description: Pupils at the Riverdale Country School in the Bronx and at Public School 197 in Brooklyn came forward yesterday with donations to the 67th annual appeal of The New York TiMes Neediest Cases Fund.

title: America's Loss Of Face
description: The longoverdue normalization of relations next Monday between the United States and China is one of President Carter's foreignpolicy spectaculars that, like the Camp David agreements, doesn't look quite so good once you read the fine print.

title: About Real Estate Home Buyers Get Tax Aid
description: The first few years of owning a house it's usually a tight squeeze, said Louis Lynn. Too tight for the Lynns, as it happens, before a new legal wrinkle for New York City known as Section 421b was enacted into law in Albany last summer.

title: No Fast Break for Senator Bradley
description: There's been some public fussing about Senator Clifford Case's refusal to step down a few days early so that his successor, Bill Bradley, could gain a mite of seniority for New Jersey in the United States Senate. Sometimes defeated incumbents, who must retire by noon of Jan. 3, do resign early, but Senator Case regards this as a bad custom. We think he is right.

title: 7 Leaders Meeting on Economy
