description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Dec. 29 (AP)  Maryland defeated St. Joseph's of Philadelphia, 6256, in overtime tonight as Albert King scored 27 points, including the basket that forged the regulation tie, in the first round of the Maryland Invitational Tournament.

title: Import Fees Rise for Sugar
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) Beginning Jan. 1 the import fees on sugar will be raised by more than a halfcent a pound in an effort to protect American sugar producers, the Agriculture Department has announced.

title: If Our Leaders Were Making New Year's Resolutions...
description: The economic soothsayers have already prophesied that the new year will be less happy than the old. Real Gross National Product (as opposed to fake Gross National Product) will slacken in 1979. The lines before the unemployment compensation windows will lengthen. The inflationary pot will bubble. In brief, toil and trouble.

title: Even the Experts Don't Know
description: Sorting out the welter of bargain air fares is a job best left to travel professionals. But even the experts are often stumped. Earlier this month, I approached airline clerks and travel agents in Manhattan with a seemingly simple request: please advise the lowest scheduled (noncharter) fare for two common vacation trips, one foreign and one domestic, for 1979. Here is what happened:

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Shall we face n fact and the New Year at one and the same time? The fact is that no matter how hard you try to count up, on your handy fingers, the 10 best plays of 1978, you're bound to get stuck somewhere along about four and onehalf. There aren't 10 best plays of 1978. Oh, I do understand that the word best is at best a relative notion. If a season has 11 plays and one of them is such a clinker that it blushes with shame alongside the remaining 10, then the remaining 10 are the best, aren't they? I say they're not. If they aren't good, they can't he best. I stand on good, better, best, and that's an end of it.

title: S.R. Kluss To Wed Carleen H. Lyden
description: The engagement of Carleen Hunter Lyden to Stewart Radford Kluss has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Edward E. Lyden of Grosse Ile, Mich., parents of the bridetobe. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred M. Kluss of Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Light on the Dark Continent
description: J. D. FAGE, professor of African history at the University of Birmingham in England, has dedicated his academic career to disproving the clich that Africa is without a history. He has succeed

title: A Winter's Day at the Races
description: Three or four days a week these wintry days, 80yearold Edward Metz, a retired textile salesman, leaves his home in Queens for an afternoon at Aqueduct Race Track. He goes upstairs to the track cafeteria for a bowl of soup and is joined frequently by Al Bennish, 70, a former newspaper truck driver who has come by subway from his hotel in Upper Manhattan. They study racing sheets and discuss the day's races.

title: Dance Festival in Stratford
description: HAVING spent much of the fall previewing a couple of Broadway shows and reviving a couple of others, the Connecticut Center for the Performing Arts is preparing a fourpart dance festival to spark some of the winter and spring weekends at the American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford. It starts this Friday and Saturday with performances by the amazing youngsters of Pilobolus, and with later visits due from the Joyce Trisler Danscompany, the Jose Limon Company (which just wrapped up a New York City Center engagement a few weeks ago) and the Matteo Ethno American Dance Theatre.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: IT SEEMED like such a good idea, the City of White Plains amending its Housing Standards Ordinance last year to provide some security for more than 25,000 apartment dwellers. It still is a good idea, as well as a lesson in how good intentions are not always good for everyone.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: IF holiday parties have left unsightly burn marks or ugly stains in your walltowall carpet, don't despair. You may still be able to do something about it.

title: Westinghouse Relay Team Sets Mark In Rhode Island
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 30 George Westinghouse High School of Brooklyn broke a meet record today at the Johnson and Walls schoolboy meet over a slow track at the Providence Armory.

title: POLITICS
description: WATCHING a sixhour session of the Suffolk County Legislature can be grueling and at times even boring, but the patient witness will be rewarded with a graphic lesson in the tangled politics of the county.

title: David W. Kratovil And Lyn Sedergren Plan Spring Bridal
description: The engagement of Lyn Sedergren to David W. Kratovil has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Erling D. Sedergren of Woodbury, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Emil A. Kratovil of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Will It Work?
description: Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi found a cup of oil for Iran's troubled waters last week. He will need barrels. Facing the worst crisis of his 37year reign, the Shah succeeding in splitting the opposition by getting a civilian politician to attempt reforms that will calm the nation. He is Dr. Shapur Bakhtiar, a 62yearold Frencheducated lawyer and a moderate leader of the National Front, Iran's main opposition party, who agreed to attempt formation of a civilian cabinet to replace the military Government.

title: Yonkers Community Fights Sewage Plan
description: YONKERS SYLVIA ITKIN and her neighbors in the Ludlow section of southwest Yonkers say they like their community of big, old homes and quiet, treelined streets  a pocket of serenity that has seen urban deterioration creep to its borders but has not succumbed to it. The residents of Ludlow have also refused to be driven away by the odors drifting in from the county sewagetreatment plant between Ludlow and the Hudson River, a plant that blemishes what was once a picture postcard view of the Palisades.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Wefer Is Frostbite Victor
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Dec. 30  Doug Wefer, 17 years old, sailed his Penguin dinghy named Evelyn to first place in the only race held today in the opening of the threeday, 48th annual frostbite regatta on Manhasset Bay. Wefer is the International Penguin Class junior champion.

title: It's the Last Day for The Finest Legal Mind in the State
description: Upon beginning his judicial career in 1950, Charles D. Breitel, who retires today as Chief Judge of the New York Court of Appeals, was praised by Gov. Thomas E. Dewey as possessing the finest legal mind in the state. That was no small compliment from Mr. Dewey, who, as the racketbusting prosecutor in Manhattan during the 1930's, had recruited several young, aggressive and talented lawyers who went on to become leaders of the legal profession.

title: Catering The Year In
description: Following are excerpts from the book For Special Occasions by the playwright und producer Dore Schary.

title: Puma Trio at Gregory's; Plus a Change, Indeed
description: At Gregory's, the tiny bar and music room at 63d Street and First Avenue, the less things change, the less they stay the same. According to the billing, there has been a change in the last couple of months in the group playing there Wednesdays through Sundays. For the previous year, the music was provided by the Hod O'Brien Trio Mr. O'Brien, pianist; Frank Luther, bassist; Joe Puma, guitarist. It has now been replaced by the Joe Puma Trio, which is made up of Mr. Puma on guitar, Mr. Luther on bass and Mr. O'Brien on piano.

title: STAMPS
description: Happy New Year, Year of the Sheep, begins late in January, according to the traditional Chinese lunar calendar, and brings promise of good fortune, peace and prosperity as it succeeds the Year of the Horse.

title: DINING OUT
description: THIS being the wrapup season, we have decided to do a culinary recapitulation of 1978. At this time of roast goose and glogg, of cranberries and Christmas cookies, the gustatory pictures in one's mind's eye become a little blurred. Then, like a kaleidoscope, the pictures spin  and one is reminded of all too many mealocre quiches, cheesecakes and heavily breaded stuffed shrimp. It takes time to sort out the eating expeditions of an entire year.

title: Diane de Cillis Plans Nuptials
description: Mrs. Joseph L. de Cillis of Old Greenwich, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Diane de Cillis, to Bruce W. Firkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce J. Firkins of Scarsdale, N. Y. A March 31 wedding is planned.

title: Grocery Prices: Destroying a Myth
description: IT will be a year ago tomorrow that the county's Department of Weights and Measures began its marketbasket report, a survey of the increase or decrease in the cost of the 41 items most purchased weekly by the average family of four.

title: Grumman Families Recall Iran
description: BETHPAGE THE Alford family of Hampton Bays and the Ablan family of Port Jefferson Station had hoped to spend their Christmas and New Year's Day holidays in Bangkok and Hong Kong with several other families from the Island who have found it easy to get to many exotic places in the world from their temporary homes inIran.

title: Town Controls DrugGear Sale
description: WESTFIELD, Mass., Dec. 30 (AP)Mayor Garreth Lynch has signed into law an ordinance to control the sale and display of drug paraphernalia such as the socalled roach clips used to hold the butts of marijuana cigarettes, and water pipes. The law would require anyone selling items used in the consumption of controlled substances to get a license.

title: The Doctor's Prescription
description: THIS earnest, repetitious book manages to encompass all that is wrong with contemporary American medicine. It does so by detailing most of the problems and then topping them off with the author's magnificently wrongheaded suggestions for reform. It is hard to tell which is more depressing, but it is not surprising that Dr. Steven Jonas, dili gent as he is, should fall apart when it comes time to suggest change  not surprising because he appears as remote from the actual practice of medicine as Armand Hammer, M.D.

title: Solar Heating Potential Of States Is Evaluated
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP)  Central Washington state and western New York are the areas where homeowners would get the least benefit from solar heating units, while the southern tip of Florida receives the most energy from the sun, a new Government study shows.

title: An Appreciation of Westchester
description: A PRESENCE or a lack of talent can cause the art world to star or stop or at least change speeds, but not the Gregorian calender. The art world goes its own way, whether it is the end of one year or the beginning of another. Nonetheless, ?? step over the threshold from 1978 to 1979, it is still rewarding to make summation of what was and to risk an??cipa?? of what will be.

title: Football Gets a Local Assist
description: WHEN Penn State takes on Alabama tomorrow in the Sugar. Bowl, a match that will determine the nation's No. 1 college football team, a number of its players will have New Rochelle on their minds and close to their hearts, or, to he more specilc. on their left and right pec??oral muscles and covering their craniums.

title: Down Under
description: IF you think the United States has strained relations with countries like the Soviet Union. Angola and North Korea, wait until yon hear what is happening with Australia. We may he on the verge of war. And all be cause of a little woman from Westchester. My wife Ethel Sloan.

title: JUDGE BARS U.S. BID ON LEFTISTS' CLAIM
description: A judge has rejected the Government's move to dismiss $10 million in damage claims arising from the infiltration of the Socialist Workers Party by informers.

title: His and Hers Approach to Gardening
description: His Story

title: Long Island/This Week
description: ALBERTSON Photographs by Linda Cohen; Tuesday through Jan. 31; Shelter Rock Library, 165 Searingtown Rd. For hours, CH 7363.

title: How Companies Are Digging In
description: There was a time, as recently as five years ago, when recessions came like the flu, by surprise. Not so the Recession of 79, if it comes. For never has a relapse of the nation's economy been more anticipated, more analyzed, more advertised.

title: World News Briefs
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 30  Brazil's military chief, in a gesture toward political reconciliation after 14 years of military rule, has lifted the ban on the return of more than a hundred Brazilians who are living abroad as political exiles.

title: Jerald Brown Will Marry Sheila B. Jackson in June
description: Mrs. Richard N. Jackson Jr. of Upperco, Md., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Sheila Bond Jackson. to Jerald Edmunds Brown of Newport, R.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Victoria Calcagnini Is Married To Jonathan Price, a Student
description: Victoria Lynn Calcagnini, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur B. Calcagnini of New York, was married yesterday to Jonathan Wood Price, son Of Dr. and Mrs. Neel J. Price of McLean, Va.

title: Cover art.
description: A year ago we had a visit from a young Dutch architectural student named Hans Oldewarris. Like a number of other Netherlanders, he collects covers of antique American paperbacks those published before 1955 that are prized for their attempts to abandon the macho look of pulp magazines for styles of their own. What we wrote about Mr. Oldewarris at that time put him in touch with a number of American artists and collectors willing to share their memories and hardtocomeby covers in preparing for an exhibilion to he held at Utopia Rotterdam, a center for cultural activities in which he's a partner.

title: Text of Report Summary Issued by Committee on Assassinations
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30  Following is the Summary of Findings and Recommendations issued today by the House Select Committee on Assassinations as a result of its investigations of the deaths of President Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.:

title: Author's Query
description: For a biography of the English authorjournalist Robert Harborough Sherard (1861 1913),bestknown as the good friend and first biographer of Oscar Wilde, I would he grateful if anyone can direct me to U.S. Sherardiana in private hands.

title: GARDENING
description: CONIFEROUS evergreens are the dominant feature of our winter landscape. From the tall white pine, picturesque against the sky, to its floorgrowing counterparts alongside the foundations of our homes, they bring life to an otherwise drab winter scene.

title: Susan Pettibone, Bank Executive, Is Wed To Dod Fraser
description: Susan Marie Pettibone of New York, a second vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, was married last evening to Dod Allan Fraser, who is with Lazard Freres & Company, investment bankers in New York.

title: Oliveira, Violinist, In Recital
description: Elmar Oliveira was out to dazzle his audience at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. Thursday night. Perhaps the 28yearold violinist felt he had to be especially on his mettle, appearing in place of Nathan Milstein, who was originally scheduled to play that evening. Or perhaps he understandably wanted to show off a bit at his first New York recital after winning the gold medal in last summer's Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow.

title: ART VIEW
description: This has been another year of the long lines for the art world, or at least for the museum world  when, from Seattle to Manhattan, unprecedented numbers of people have eagerly and pat iently endured the tedium of the teeming queue in order to secure the pleasure and prestige of having a glimpse at exalted, rarely seen works of art organized in socalled blockbuster exhibitions.

title: Foreign Policy Trio Learns To Play in Tune  Mostly
description: WASHINGTON  They have been as different in background, personality, and foreign policy experience as any President and his two senior foreign policy advisers could be. Yet, after two year on the job, Jimmy Carter, Cyrus P. Vance and Zbigniew Brzezinski have produced a creditable record, more impressive, in fact, than secmed possible a year ago

title: CRIME
description: Perhaps one shouldn't stop to examine William H. Hallahan's KEEPER OF THE CHILDREN (Morrow, $7.95) too closely. But it must be said that anybody who gets into the book will feel little inclination to stop. The author has dreamed up a mixture of horror and occultism, and has told it with driving force. The result is a story that takes you along with it all the way.

title: Anne Murphy Wed To Arthur R. Bence
description: At Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church in Dewitt, N.Y., yesterday Anne Winslow Murphy, a thirdyear student at the Fordham Law School, was married to Arthur R. Bence, a counselor with the Beth Isreal Hospital outpatient clinic in Harlem. Msgr. Daniel O'Brien performed the ceremony.

title: POINT OF VIEW The Threat Behind HumphreyHawkins
description: One of the last frantic acts of the 95th Congress was to rush through the HumphreyHawkins bill  a measure that had been before Congress and going nowhere for some time. The President, with a sensitive car to the political ground, signed it last fall.

title: Dr. Michael Siegal To Wed Miss Kann
description: Announcement has been made by Kurt Kann of New York and Fran Farrell of San Francisco of the engagement of their daughter, Sheila Janet Kann of New York, to Dr. Michael Selig Siegal, son of Mr. and Mrs. Saul I. Siegal of Bayside, Queens.

title: House Panel Reports a Conspiracy Probable in the Kennedy Slaying
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30  President John F. Kennedy was probably assassinated as a result of a conspiracy, the House Select Committee on Assassinations concluded today. It said, however, that it was unable to identify the other gunman or the extent of the conspiracy.

title: Farm Families of $40,000 Status Increased by 76% From 1970.75
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UPI)  Although the actual farm population is declining, the number of farm families who have achieved annual sales of $40,000 or more rose by 76 percent from 1970 through 1975, according to a Government report.

title: 20 YEARS WITH
description: Some pilgrims arrive at the shrine of San Lazard in El Rincon on their knees. Some come crawling in the dust on their bellies in garments of sackcloth that rub the skin raw. Most Cubans walk to El RincOn, however, and in the week before Christmas  during the Feast of San Lazaro  two or three thousand pilgrims make the 18mile journey from Havana on foot. The trek is the most open display of defiance against the regime of Fidel Castro that is countenanced in Cuba today.

title: NEW JERSEY HOUSING; In Plainfield: Upstairs, Downstairs
description: BEATRICE DOYLE and Katie James shop together, sometimes watch television together and, for the most part, care and watch out for each other.

title: CRITICS SCRUTINIZE COAST WATER BOARD
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 30The nation's biggest water merchant marked its 50th anniversary this weekend and moved into a new era of the state's chronically contentious water activities.

title: Ohio State's General. Loses His Command
description: He coached football and he studied military history. For Wayne Woodrow Hayes there was no conflict of interest. Football and war were a perfect fit, the apple pie and ice cream of his being. The offense was the strike force, the defense the repel force. Football was game of territorial acquisition through controlled violence. The only difference in war was in the degree of control. And a good general hatl nothing he didn't have control.

title: Title IX Supporters Dissect The Major Sports Syndrome
description: In recent weeks, articles on this page and in the daily sports section have reflected the growing controversy over the ramifications of Title IX or the 1972 Federal Education Amendment. Some people believe that Title IX may portend the end of revenueproducing collegiate sports such as basketball and football. Others say there is adequate room for both equalaccess athletic programs and major collegiate sports. Printed here are just a small portion of the letters received in reply to these articles.

title: ART
description: IN an exhibition of WPA art, held earlier this year at New York University's Grey Art Gallery, there was a cartoon by Abe Ajay. One of several done by artists protesting government cutbacks in the program, it showed a small figure labeled project worker painting at an easel as a sword of Damocles, lettered WPA cuts. hovers over his head.

title: Anne M. McDonald Wed to M.M. Mayo
description: Anne Marie McDonald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. McDonald of Rumson, N.J., was married there yesterday to Marc M. Mayo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Mayo of Jacksonville, Fla. The Rev. William Carton performed the ceremony in Holy Cross Roman Catholic Cnurch. Rabbi Roy Rosenberg assisted.

title: Judge Postpones Ruling to Avert Closing of The Washington Star
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30  Federal District Judge Charles R. Richey postponed today his decision on whether to issue restraining order to prevent The Washington Star from closing the newspaper in a labor dispute, but the paper's management still held to its threat to close the city's 115yearold afternoon daily at midnight on New Year's Eve.

title: GARDERING
description: THERE is alway a twinge when it is time to take down the Christmas tree. The youngsters wish it could stay up forever and their parents are eager to get it down and put the house back in order.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error, a sentence was incorrect in the Dec. 16 article by Beatrice G. Kowalski and Robert H. Cagenello on the Connecticut Weekly Opinion Page. The sentence should have read: Most commissions in other states are autonomous or have more flexibility in the hiring of personnel.

title: What' s Doing in PASADENA
description: HAPPY NEW YEAR  Given the wonders of television, nearly all eyes will be fixed on Pasadena tomorrow morning, when the United States Air Force Drum and Bugle Corps of Colorado Springs, Colo., steps smartly out onto Orange Grove Boulevard and thereby sets in motion the 90th annual Tournament of Roses parade. Sixty floats and uncounted marching units will participate in this year's spectacle, which goes on for approximately four miles and exactly two and a half hours.

title: Buckeyes Knew Game Was in the Bag
description: The coaches always tell the players that the game isn't over until the time runs out, that only fools and losers celebrate victory before the buzzer sounds. But, with 1 minute 4 seconds left in overtime, and their lead merely points, the Ohio State players knew this game was over. They knew Duke was no longer unbeaten, no longer No. 1. They knew they had danced on the Blue Devils.

title: Tulsa 77, Manhattan 74
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 30 (AP)  Tulsa University reeled off 15 straight points in the closing minutes to defeat Manhattan College, 7774, in the thirdplace game of a tournament tonight. Bill Keys led Tulsa with 20 points. For Manhattan, Sergio Bardaji scored 21, followed by Mike Bruno with 20.

title: T.D. Rowe jr. Plans to Wed Dr. Anderson
description: Dr. Elizabeth L Anderson, executive director of the carcinogen assessment group of the United States Environmental Protection Agency in Washington, and Thomas D. Rowe Jr., an associate professor at the Duke University School of Law in Durham. N. C.. plan to be married May 19 in the Catawba Baptist Church of Nathalie, Va.

title: Author's Query
description: For a biographical sketch and critical study of Weldon Kees, letters, manuscripts and anecdotes would be appreciated.

title: Insurance Mystery Deepens
description: TRENTON I CAN'T tell you what I wish the Governor would do with his stock, said Ephriam Weiniger, president of the Intercontinental Life Insurance Company.

title: NED
description: By Paxton Davis. Drawings by Harold Little. 140 pp. New York: Atheneum. $7.95. (Ages 12 and Up)

title: Rutgers Wins in 3 Overtimes, 9796; St. John's Hands Duke 2d Loss in Row
description: Duke University's basketball team was the big loser in the Holiday Festival tournament at Madison Square Garden after it let another giant lead slip away last night in falling to St. John's, 6966, in the consolation game.

title: Nancie Rathbun Wed to Thomas Roan, Divinity Student
description: Nancie McNutt Rathbun, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Rathbun of Bronxville, N.Y., and Ashley Falls, Mass., was married yesterday to Thomas Alden Roan, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Roan of Longmeadow, Mass.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249, or to any of the following organizations:

title: New York Is Intensifying Efforts To Draw More Foreign Business
description: As Hedi Nouira, Prime Minister of Tunisia, stepped from his limousine at 1 Liberty Plaza one evening in ear'y December, icy wind whipped paper scraps down the dark and virtually deserted corridors near Wall Street. The scene mirrored for a moment the chilly welcome foreign dignitaries often feel they get in New York.

title: IRAN DESIGNEE SEES A NEW REGIME SOON, WITH SHAH ON LEAVE
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 30  Shahpur Bakhtiar, who was chosen by Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi to form a new government, said today that Iran would have a new civilian government within a week, and that a month later the Shah would leave the country for a long period, naming a council to exercise power in his absence.

title: Three Novels
description: PATRICK ANDERSON served in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations and was Jimmy Carter's speechwriter in 1976. So it is no surprise that First Family is a roman  clef, and the clef fits several locks.

title: BRIDGE
description: The unlikely trump suit is one of the most intriguing areas in bridge theory. You have an eightcard fit in one suit, for example, but a fourthree fit in some other suit produces more tricks. Rather more rarely, one finds, usually in the postmortem, that the only playable game contract was in a fourtwo fit.

title: Letters: No Samples at the World's Largest Coin Factory
description: To the Editor:

title: Be Armed With Facts
description: I'D thought myself inured to cockeyed gynecologist stories; but I heard one recently that seemed to me to border on the bizarre. An acquaintance of mine, who was interning in an obstetricsgynecology service, was called to assist in an emergency hysterectomy that took place in the middle of the night. The chief resident on the ward, who performed the procedure, did so with what my friend considered impeccable style and skill. But just afterward, as the patient lay unconscious upon the table, the physician held the newly detached uterus aloft. My friend glanced at his face, and said quizzically, You look . pleased? Ah yes, I am, he answered. Another small victory in Man's unending battle against the womb.

title: TeenAgers Pick Up Disco Beat
description: FRANKLIN SQUARE THEY might be able to walk straight into Studio 54, but no matter how hard they might try, not even Bianca Jagger or Truman Capote could get into Guys and Dolls, a discotheque here that is packed every Friday and Saturday night.

title: Editors' Choice
description: A CHILDHOOD, by Harry Crews. (Harper & Row, $8.95.) A novelist's fresh and touching reminiscences of his boyhood in the rural Deep South before World War II.

title: Less Pupils, More Problems
description: A MEETING is being ?? ?? parents and other ??m?? ?? school somewhere in West chester County. The sub??t the dec??ning enrollment in that school and the publication of a report that the school may close.

title: Signs Point To High Rates
description: As we move into the new year, forces at work in the nation's money markets are similar to, but stronger, than those making 1978 so remarkable. In trying to anticipate what the 1979 holds for the money markets, therefore, it is useful to review the events of 1978.

title: PLAIN GEOMETRY IN A FLORENTINE HOME
description: Fashion and Beauty

title: Lake Erie Hunters Rescued
description: DETROIT, Dec. 30 (AP)  A group of 21 hunters have been rescued and evacuated from Lake Erie's Pelee Island, where their tugboat ran aground. A Coast Guard officer here said the hunters sent a distress message around noon Thursday and were rescued yesterday.

title: Judicial Screening Committees are Working, but Not All to Specifications
description: WASHINGTONThe Mayor of Detroit, the president of the United Auto Workers, a former congresswoman from Michigan and a former lieutenant governor of Kentucky are members of one committee appointed by President Carter. Another, headed by a former senator from Maryland, includes members of politically connected law firms, a human rights activist and a state education official.

title: And There She Was, In Title Role at Met
description: SINGING at the Metropolitan Opera, said Patricia Craig, was a goal'that I'd looked toward and wondered if it was ever really going to happen. But on the night of Nov. 25, 1978, 10 years after winning a scholarship in the Met auditions, and after some seven years with the New York City Opera and with companies around the United States and in Europe, it really happened.

title: Trail Guides
description: Ski Touring: Guide and Directory 1979 is published by the National Ski Touring Operators' Association. The brochure pinpoints New England ski touring areas on a map and describes facilities and services. Available free from the association, Bretton Woods, N.H. 03575.

title: Saint Jack
description: Although Jack Kerouac has been dead for nearly a decade, neither the man nor his works have been adequately understood. The works suffered from the most malicious early reviewing ever accorded a major American novelist  reviews full of unsubstantiated conjecture about Kerouac's iutolligence, his life style, his ambitions, his literary sense, Ins creative methods. the suggestion was that he lived irresponsibly, exploited publicity shamelessly, wrote solely for money, indulged freely in drugs, loved promiscuously and drank himself to premature death at 47. In part because of the unfavorable notices, publishers doing one of his hooks precipitously lost courage when offered the next; and when they urged him to repeat his previous successes rather than create something different, Kerouac'spublishers revealed a limited sense of his literary talent. Not only were his manuscripts distributed among a dozen different imprints, but his most extraordinary book, Visions of Cody, did not appear in print until 1973, four years after his death.

title: 9 TeenAgers Held in Terrorizing Of New York Subway Passengers
description: A group of teenagers wielding knives and clubs terrorized passengers on a Manhattanbound IND subway train in Brooklyn early yesterday and robbed a woman of her necklace, Transit Authority police officers reported.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: On the basis of sheer quantity, newly released recordings of Maria Callas and Herbert von Karajan have dominated the classical record world over the past year. This is an especially curious paradox in the case of Callas, who died just over a year ago and who last visited the recording studios in 1969. Yet suddenly a flood of complete operas and recitals featuring the late soprano have appeared on a variety of different labels.

title: A Guide to New Year's Day Bowl Games
description: Alabama (101) vs. Penn State (110)

title: Late TV Listings
description: 11 A.M. (Channel 2) Camera Three: One Man's England Paul Mellon and the art critic Rosamond Bernier tour Melton's Yale Center for British An

title: John Cale, Rock Star, At CBGB
description: If Lou Reed is the godfather of punk rock, John Cale is its minence grise. A member with Mr. Reed of that seminal 1960's band, the Velvet Underground, and the producer of early recordings by Patti Smith and Jonathan Richman and the Modern Lovers, Mr. Cale combines the sophistication of a classically trained musician with the deliberate primitivism of a passionate rockandroller  a combination that characterizes and, in Mr. Cale's case, antedates the sensibility of much of the new wave music New York City has spawned in the last five years.

title: Barbara Lord Married in Buffalo
description: Barbara Hartley Lord, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Couper Lord of Buffalo and Southampton, L.I., was married in Buffalo yesterday to James Cook Edwards Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwards of New York and East Hampton, L.I. The Rev. Robert G. Hetherington performed the ceremony in Christ Chapel of Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: F.D.U. Five Awaits New Home
description: TEANECK A WEEK or so ago, they were in Jacksonville, Fla. Last night, they were in WinstonSalem, N.C. The college basketball season isn't even half over yet, but the Fairleigh Dickinson University cagers lead the nation in miles traveled in futility.

title: FILM VIEW
description: In a world where everything must eventually pass, the decimal system of priorities may be the last thing to go. As the planet is consumed by flames someone will be compiling the definitive list of the 10 most important events in the history of the world  and there will be one other person around to tell him he's all wet. That last list won't change the course of the apocalypse but it may help to make it seem comprehensible. Which is why we all make lists of the 10 best movies or the 10 best anything; lists don't change history, but they give us a certain perspective.

title: Import Duties
description: Last February President Carter turned thumbs down on a recommendation by the Government's International Trade Commission to raise import duties on nuts, bolts and screws from Japan and other countries. The decision was explained as being in line with Mr. Carter's freetrade principles.

title: Other World Events
description: South Africa agreed to agree again last week, accepting a United Nations plan for black majority rule in SouthWest Africa (Namibia). The Western diplomats who mediated the accord were pleased but still understandably wary of Pretoria's intentions. Prime Minister John Vorster originally accepted the proposals in April, but reneged before he retired in September. Threats of sanctions apparently convinced Mr. Vorster's successor, P. W. Botha, to reconsider, though not until elections had been held in SouthWest Africa under Pretoria's supervision and a prowhite Government chosen. Assuming Mr. Botha keeps his word, that election will be superseded by a new vote next year under United Nations auspices.

title: Hostos Courses Help Small Businesses
description: On Tuesday and Thursday nights, Rosalia Santana leaves her bodega in East Harlem and goes to college.

title: The Grasso Administration Wants to Show It Is FourSquare for Good Government
description: HARTFORD  Starting tomorrow, Connecticut's state government will have a new look; whether or not the bureaus and the bureaucrats will work any better remains to be seen. Even its most outspoken advocates do not claim that reorganization will mean a bonanza for the taxpayer. I never maintained that reorganization would make a really significant difference in the size of the budget, John H. Filer, the insurance executive who headed the commission that drafted much of the reorganization plan, said last week. If well managed, though, it could probably result in a more efficient delivery of services.

title: SchoolAid Fight Is Shaping Up Anew
description: EDUCATION formulas are traditionally an exercise in raw legislative power, a legislative aide said last week.

title: Forestry
description: At a time when natural resources seem to be disappearing and energy costs are soaring, one of the oldest settled regions of the United States is burgeoning with an astonishing amount of man's oldest fuelwoodlargely going unused.

title: Turtle Habitat to Be Preserved
description: PLYMOUTH, Mass., Dec. 30 (AP) Help is on the way for 10 Plymouth redbellied turtles threatened by encroaching humans. The rare turtles, which have coralcolored undersides, dwell in two ponds near the Myles Standish State Forest here and are endangered by surrounding development. But the Nature Conservancy, a private environmental group based in Washington, has announced plans to purchase the ponds and 183 acres to preserve the turtle sanctuary.

title: 2 Gold Medals Were Enough
description: LAUREL HOLLOW SHE bicycles 10 miles a day now, about the same distance she used to swim when she won two gold medals in the 1960 Olympics.

title: The Nation
description: With a little creative help from his budget office, President Carter kept some promises last week  at least on paper.

title: TV Stars No Guarantee of Top Rating
description: Hit television programs are harder to come by than they used to be, and a chief reason, network executives suggest, is that star performers no longer can be counted on to capture a large audience.

title: A New Comedy Team Comes To Broadway
description: It was only last summer that Monteith and Rand  that's John Monteith and Suzanne Rand  first appeared as a comedy duo in a theater, Off Broadway at the Theater East. At that time the two unknowns inspired notices studded with such adjectives as hot, clever, funniest and madcap. Walter Kerr, in The Times, called them a decidedly engaging and often inventive couple, and a number of reviews compared them to Mike Nichols and Elaine May.

title: Concert Without Harmony
description: In the basic agreement between baseball players in the major leagues and their employers, the section dealing with players who become free agents includes a precautionary note. It reads: The utilization or nonutilization of rights under this Article XVII is an individual matter to be determined solely by

title: Religious News: Is the Press Ignoring An Important Beat?
description: IN THE wake of the Jonestown tragedy, one question needs to be addressed: In a society that separates church and state, what methods of control exist to check excesses within religious groups?

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: ELDERSBURG, Md.  What we want, says Jonathan Myers, is for every person in this country to walk into a store and say I want a London Fog instead of I want a raincoat.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: IF holiday parties have left unsightly burn marks or ugly stains in your walltowall carpet, don't despair. You may still be able to do something about it.

title: In Winter, a Legislator's Fancy Turns to Thoughts of Color TV
description: MEMBERS of Connecticut's state legislature, having won their elections and chosen their leaders, are now getting down to the really serious battleover perks.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Jill Kreher To Marry in March
description: The engagement of Jill Cathryn Kreher to Dennis Joseph Mayne has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. James Charles Kreher of Upper Saddle River, N.J. Mr. Mayne is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph D. Mayne of Malden, Mass. A March 17 wedding is planned.

title: Experts for Hire: Authenticity, HollywoodStyle
description: BURBANK Gene Wilder is standing ankle deep in a fake snowstorm while two men toss plastic flakes in front of electric fans to keep the blizzard going. The actor is starring in NoKnife, a forthcoming film comedy about the journey of a 19thcentury Polish rabbi to San Francisco, where a congregation and a bride await him. At the moment, the rabbi, whose name is Avram Belinski, is caught in a Midwestern whiteout; hence, the plastic snowflakes.

title: INTERVIEW Taking the Initiative on Voter Action
description: JOHN L. LOEB Jr., investment Hanker and occasional political activist, has moved into a new area: initiative and referendum. He is leading an organization called Voice of the Electorate, or Vote, to introduce this increasingly popular device in New York State.

title: For a Parliament In the U.S.
description: ANNANDALE, Va.It is becoming clearer every day that a better way must be found to evoke a strong, effective yet responsible leadership in our Government.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Moscow now has the second series of coins to be issued for the 313th session of the Olympic Games ready for distribution. Five of the coins are in silver and one in gold. (The first platinum piece was issued in October.) Three of the silvers are in 10ruble denominations, and the others are 5ruble. They are 900 fine, and measure 39 and 33 millimeters in diameter. The weights are 33.3 and 16.67 grams.

title: J. I. Moore Weds Sally Puchta
description: Sally Ann Puchta of New York, widow of Lawrence C. Puchta, was married yesterday to James I. Moore, a New York lawyer. The ceremony was performed at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Brittain 3d in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Robert Sanders of the First Presbyterian Church of Greenwich. The bridegroom's previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Medicine
description: Of the 5,000 socalled medical devices now on the market, manytoothbrushes and eyeglasses, for instance  are simple, mundane objects. Others pacemakers, fetal monitoring equipment, kidney dialysis systems, and the like  are complex instruments vital to the diagnosis and treatment of serious disorders. Despite the lifeanddeath importance of such equipment, comprehensive Government control over its safety and effectiveness has been extraordinarily late in coming. But this month, unheralded by consumer groups or health care organizations and unnoticed by those most concerned  the patients the first significant Federal regulations covering medical devices went into effect.

title: Failure Along the Baltimore Dome
description: Oil explorers, who have been drilling for nine months in the Atlantic off New Jersey, came up emptyhanded again last week. The Mobil Corporation abandoned a well in the Baltimore Dome, a geological formation in the Baltimore Canyon.

title: Hayes of Ohio State Is Dismissed
description: Woody Hayes, the Ohio State University foot ball coach for 28 years, was dismissed yesterday after he had attacked a Clemson University football player in the closing minutes of the Gator Bowl game in Jacksonville, Fla., Friday night, as Ohio State lost. 17 to 15.

title: Mailbox: The Final Nonword
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Caroline Ray, R.F. Brown Jr. Are Married
description: Caroline Savage Ray and Robert Fisher Brown Jr., investment officers with the First National Bank of Boston, were married in the Eastern Shore Episcopal Chapel in Virginia Beach, Va., yesterday by the Rev. Charles Riddle.

title: Budget Fight In Nassau
description: MINEOLA THE legality of Nassau County's controversial budget for 1979, which provides for a lesser increase in property taxes than one originally submitted by the County Executive, will be determined in the next few days.

title: Catherine F. Miller, Actress, Is Engaged
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Catherine F. Miller, a television actress in New York, to George A. Spadora Jr., a lawyer in Edison, N.J., and New York.

title: Air Fare Bargains Create Confusion
description: New York to Los Angeles for $99 round trip. Miami to Los Angeles for $133. Los Angeles to Hong Kong for $299. San Francisco to Honolulu for $49 and to Sydney for $258. New York to Amsterdam for $130. Washington D.C. to Miami for $52.

title: A Recession Glossary
description: There was a time when everybody knew the word for an economy in trouble. The word was depression. But economists have since come to examine the qualities of booms and busts more closely, and here are some of the words they now use.

title: Chinese Leader Is Expected to Sign Several Accords on His Trip to U.S.
description: PEKING, Dec. 30  The United States hopes to conclude several accords on scientific and technical exchanges with China during the visit of Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping next month, Leonard Woodcock, chief of the United States liaison office here, said today.

title: Miss Jones, a Secretary, Fiance of Robin Jordan
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Stockton Jones of Freehold, N.J. of the engagement of their daughter, Antoinette Micaela Jones, to Robin Coleman Jordan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Coleman Jordan of Washington. The wedding is planned for July.

title: Pope's Message Last Week Was a Test of Strength in Poland
description: CRACOW, Poland  For 30 year, Eastern Europe has maintained a careful balance in affairs involving the Roman Catholic Church and the Communist states. In recent months, the balance has begun shift toward the church. The consequenced will be significant for the area's 60 million Catholics  and for everyone else in the pine countrires involved , since they affect the broad social and political structures which maintain the stability of the regimes.

title: SPORTS; They Swim 9 Miles a Day, Eyeing the Olympics
description: MILL NECK FIFTY teenagers sit listening, working, concentrating. Only the sound of bodies moving swiftly through the water fills the pool area in the Mill Neck School for the Deaf, as the Islanders Swim Club team practices. The coach, Bill Davis, prowls the pool edge like a lion tamer.

title: PEOPLE
description: The former treasurer of the Anaconda Company pleaded guilty last week in Federal District Court to three counts of fraud. Shortly after Charles H. Kraft, 62 years old, admitted that he had fraudulently induced several large banks to lend $34 million to companies controlled by two business promoters, the two promoters, Nicolas Reisini and James L. Fallon, were indicted on fraud charges.

title: A Papal Envoy Began Mediation Last Week
description: BUENOS AIRES  The Beagle Channel controversy that has brought the military regimes of Argentina and Chile to the brink of war is an expression of the turbulent revisionism underway in Argentina in reaction to frustrations in national life. Argentine policy is made by military men whose nationalist values are mixed with personal ambitions, phobias against politicians, progressive priests and corrupt businessmen, and a moralistic justification of military rule. When military commanders ousted the discredited Government of President Isabel Martinez de Peron in 1976, much of the social and economic structure was in critical disarray. To its new leaders, this included a serious weakening of Argentine interests visa vis its neighbors. They set out to reassert Argentine claims and prestige.

title: Remembrance of Things Eternal
description: I WENT to church on a recent Sunday for the first time in many years. Neither a believer nor a nonbeliever, I went out of curiosity. I wanted to see why other people went.

title: Best Sellers
description: NONFICTION

title: The People Watch Pelicans in Florida And They Watch Too
description: Games. Everybody plays them. Animals, too. Even birds. Like the peoplewatching pelicans of Florida's PassaGrille Beach on the Gulf of Mexico near St. Petersburg. Their game is pretending they are not watching people.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Nets divide their time equally between road and home game visiting Houston Wednesday and New Orleans Thursday before playing host Friday to San Antonio and Sunday to Phoenix. The Knicks will me Phoenix at 8 P.M. Tuesday at Madison Square Garden. They play in Cleveland Thursday night and return to the Garden Saturday for a game wi?? San Antonio.

title: Two Republicans Fill Vacancies In Suffolk County's Legislature
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec. 30  The Suffolk County Republican Party's candidates have won two vacant seats in the County Legislature in a vote by legislators along strict party lines.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, DECEMBER 31, 1978

title: Sports Today
description: FOOTBALL

title: Iran's Crisis Unnerves Friends and Foes
description: PARIS  As crisis has mounted in I ran, ripples of unease and insecurity have spread throughout the Persian Gulf and to more distant Moslem countries, from Turkey in the west to Pakistan in the east.

title: Miss Young Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Young of HastingsonHudson and Carmel, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Melinda Young, to Richard David Rosengarten, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Rosengarten of Harrison, N.Y. A March wedding is planned.

title: Jacqueline McEWen Plans April Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph McEwen of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., and Boca Raton, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jacqueline McEwen, to David Edward Griffith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Griffith of New Canaan, Conn., and Johns Island, Fla. An April wedding is planned.

title: Volume Boom In Commodities
description: In 1978 commodity futures finally received the recognition they deserved as an important additional investment instrument and riskoffsetting vehicle. The major stock exchanges, hundreds of securities firms and millions of their clients now have direct access to commodity futures. Their participation in 1978 pushed the volume of futures contracts traded on United States exchanges past the 58million mark in transactions worth well over $1 trillion, compared with just 3.8 million contracts traded in 1958.

title: Simple For Sale Signs Are Not So Simple
description: When John and Eleanor Mahr decided to sell their house in Malverne, L. L., they felt that the best way to attract a buyer was to put a for sale sign on their lawn.

title: Cure for Common Spectator: Adult Play Areas
description: IN RECENT years, taxpayers throughout the country have been asked to spend millions of dollars in support of the construction and refurbishing of stadiums and arenas, which are used primarily by a relative handful of highlypaid professional athletes. Bonds are floated to raise money for these projects because civic pride is said to be boosted. But buildings such as Yankee Stadium, reconstructed at a cost exceeding $150 million, are used only for our enjoyment as spectators.

title: Iranian Police Reported to Curb Religious Gatherings
description: BAGHEFAIZ, Iran, Dec. 30  Villagers in the and countryside just outside Teheran said today that Savak, the Iranian secret police, had been restricting Moslem religious gatherings in an effort to curb the opposition to Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: CONFERENCE OF THE BIRDS

title: Levitt, in Last Report, Warns City and State
description: In his final report after 24 years as New York State's Comptroller, Arthur Levitt issued stern warnings yesterday about the condition of the state's finances and called for the restructuring of its entire system of financing public education.

title: POLITICS
description: TRENTON SIN, scandal, snow, sports, the Senate and sex were among the big newsmakers in New Jersey in 1978. In a year of events that frequently focused national attention on the state, gambling went overnight from sin to a success story. The Dr. murder trial turned out tr; be not only a test of guilt innocence for Dr. Mario A. Jascalevich, but also trial of the press's Firs: Amendment rights. And winter snows crippled the state's billiondollaraweek economy.

title: A Maturing Sport Faces Growing Pains
description: Will success spoil ski touring? As skiers glide into the woods this winter  in expected record numbers  they will find more organization, more prepared trails, more sophisticated equipment and smarter clothes. Such developments have a familar ring, for it was the surge in the growth of downhill skiing, and the resultant crowded lift lines, that steered many skiers away from what they regarded as expensive slopes to  in many cases  free crosscountry trails.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: Thursday

title: WASHINGTON;To Hell With the Old Year
description: PARIS, Dec. 30  At the turn of the year, officials in Western Europe seem less anxious about the problems of the Middle East and military arms control with the Soviets than about political opinion in the United States. They are more relaxed here. To hell with the old year, they seem to say.

title: The Eilshemius Legacy
description: TRENTON WHEN Louis Eilshemius died of pneumonia in New York on Dec. 29, 1941, an obituary on the 77yearold artist described him as being penniless. bitter and famous.

title: M.D. Ross To Wed Amy Ellen Chaiklin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack C. Chaiklin of Liv. ingston, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Amy Ellen Chaiklin, to Mitchell David Ross, son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Ross of Palm Beach, Fla., and Montreal. A June wedding is planned.

title: Retirement Law Stirs Concern
description: ANEW state retirement law goes into effect tomorrow, to the dismay of the some private colleges and businesses in Connecticut that are still trying to figure out its implications and are beginning to work towards changing it.

title: Miss White, James Brush Are Married
description: Catharine Lutz White, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Erskine N. White Jr. of Barrington, R.I., was married there yesterday to James Blanton Brush, son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Brush Jr. of Webster, N. Y.

title: E.J. Henderson 3d Weds Angela Jay, Book Editor
description: Angela Harriet Jay, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Peter Jay of Port Washington, L.I., was married yesterday to Edward Juel Henderson 3., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henderson Jr. of Manhasset, L.I. The Rev. Vitalis Pedzik performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in Port Washington's St. Peter of Alcantara Roman Catholic Church.

title: Pregnancy, Motherhood And Decisions
description: DEAR June: Congratulations on your baby son David. A new baby at midlife maturity is indeed a special joy  for some of us. I myself had a fourth child, a son, not at 43 after a 15year interval, but at 35 after a fiveyear pause. Unlike yourself, I made a deliberate decision which was followed by special pleasures: greater confidence in how to rear a child, less fear of making a harmful mistake than with the first child, more leisure to enjoy his babyhood than with the middle children, and somewhat more economic security to ease the difficulties of making the ends meet the means. So, having experienced the triumphant joy of a beautiful baby at just the right time in life (whatever year that may be), I would like to discuss your choice with you, since you opened the matter to the public.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Federal Watchdogs Face a Full Platter of Mostly Invisible Substances
description: WASHINGTON  Edward Munger suffers lifethreatening reactions when he eats foods containing milk, eggs, citric acid and cottonseed oil. Dee Anne Atheson breaks out in hives when she eats food colored by yellow dye No. Emilie Mittel is highly allergic to peanut oil. In these cases  and thousands of others  one might assume that persons afflicted by such diverse allergies might be easily able to avoid these foods because the labels on the containers would tell what is inside.

title: GARDENING
description: THE new year will be a big outdoor gardening year for me. So much so that, unless I happen upon something totally irresistible in the new catalogues now beginning to arrive, I will grow no house plants from seed.

title: Tennis Tourneys Booming in Met. Area
description: At the East River Tennis Club the talk is not about whether Connors or Borg is No. 1, but whether Eric Fromm can beat Joel Ross in the Holiday Festival.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: ROSLYN THE 12yearold had to go to the city. It made one think about getting around in the suburbs. If your car doesn't start, how do you get to the movies from your house?

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: William Manchester says that before beginning his biography of Douglas MacArthur, he regarded the general as a conceited commander and political reactionary whose first objective was always to draw attention to himself. He has since changed his view. During three years research, Mr. Manchester discovered facts that caused him to call his man and his book, American Caesar.

title: TeenAgers Held in 4 Burglaries
description: Two Long Island teenagers were arrested and charged with four burglaries during which a total of $5,800 and two firearms were taken in the last two weeks, the Suffolk Ccrunty police reported yesterday. They said they had admitted committing as many as 60 such breakins, mostly for cash. The suspects were identified as Donald E. Steve, 17 years old, of Patchogue, L.I., and James F. Lyons, 16, of Central Islip, L.I. They were accused of taking $3,000 and the two guns in a burglary of Angelo's Restaurant in Patchogue.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Dean. Ever since May, when Helen Meyer retired as head of Dell Books, the paperback publishing corps has had a new dean. Characteristically, Oscar Dystel, who has presided over the affairs of Bantam Books for nearly a quartercentury, hasn't rushed forward to accept the title. Bantam is generally acknowledged to be the leader in the field, accounting for nearly onefifth of all massmarket sales; but. Mr. Dystel, a short, slight man, is content with a low public profile.

title: Sunday Observer
description: A year is 1,095 meals long. That's a lot of dirty dishes, not to mention hardtoclean pots, pans, skillets and griddles. Yet you still hear oldtimers saying, The years just seem to fly by.

title: Rally to Defeat Falcons, 2720
description: IRVING, Tex., Dec. 30 The year of the comeback continued in spots today, but this time it was the Dallas Cowboys who manufactured the miracles in a 2720 National Football Conference playoff victory over the Atlanta Falcons.

title: Warren Commission Study Had Emphatically Ruled Out Conspiracy
description: The Warren Commission report on the assassination of President Kennedy concluded emphatically in 1964 that there had been no conspiracy, foreign or domestic, in connection with the shooting.

title: Poems and a Companion
description: RORGE OPPEN'S ninth collection of verse with ats spare clarity and Vigor appears at the same time as Mary Oppen's autobiography.Meaning a Lafe, much of if about their fives together, written out like a Chinese poem, precise in detail(gists and piths, Pound would have said of it), nuanced and evocative. To read the books together is to discover not how they Meaning a Lafe, much of if about their fives together, written out like a Chinese poem, precise in detail(gists and piths, Pound would have said of it), nuanced and evocative. To read the books together is to discover not how they lean on each other  quite the contrary, in fart  but how they signal across the ground of their authors common experience, signal to what George Oppen on his has suggested man eat her poem.

title: Chicago Tragedy of '03 Brought Safer Theaters
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 30 (AP)  A match fell from the ashtray to the carpet. Soon, flames were eating their way along the ornate corridor and wall.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Tom Tyler Marries Julia Louise Vitale
description: In the United Methodist Church in Woodbury, LI., yesterday afternoon, Julia Louise Vitale, daughter of Judge and Mrs. Alexander Vitale of Woodbury, became the bride of Tom Richard Tyler, son of Dr. Forrest Tyler of College Park, Md., and Dr. Bonnie Tyler of Garrett Park, Md. The Rev. Howard E. Velzy performed the ceremony.

title: William W. Lockwood, 74, Dies; Professor and an Expert on Asia
description: William Wirt Lockwood, a professor emeritus of politics and international affairs at Princeton University and a leading authority on the economy and politics of Asia, died yesterday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. He was 74 years old and lived at 74 Jefferson Road in Princeton.

title: Nastaseness Runs in Family
description: PORT WASHINGTON, LI., Dec. 30  Just like his uncle Ilie, 11yearold Mihnea Nastase of Rumania battled line calls and asked for an umpire today in his semifinal victory in the boys' 12year and under division of an international junior indoor tennis tournament at the Port Washington Tennis Academy.

title: RhythmandBlues Pioneers On Disk
description: 0ne night in 1947 a black ballad singer named Roy Brown put on his one suit, stuffed a piece of cardboard in the bottom of one of his two shoes, wrote the words to a song he'd made up on a brown grocery bag, and took a bus across New Orleans to a night club where the successful blues shouter Wynonie Harris was appearing. Mr.Harris, who'd recently left the Lucky Millinder big band, was a handsome, flamboyant character from Oklahoma with a piercing voice and a smile for all the ladies, and when the bedraggled young Roy Brown showed up at his dressing room door, he had other things on his mind. Not another one of those songs, he said irritably.

title: Disco Dancers Take a Fling at TV
description: EAST HAMPTON WHILE teenagers elsewhere are watching such televised disco shows as Soul Train and Hot City, youngsters in East Hampton are producing and starring in one of their own.

title: EMPLOYEES PASS HAT FOR NEEDIEST CASES
description: Employees in factories, offices and laboratories throughout the metropolitan area are passing the hat in behalf of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. At Bell Laboratories in New Jersey, 22 employees of the Quality Assurance Centers contributed a total of $208 in 22 separate checks ranging from $3 to $25.

title: Birth Notice 2 -- No Title
description: Births

title: Iran's Oil Output Is Down Sharply; Accord Reported
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 30  Iran's daily crude oil production, sharply curtailed by strikes and fear of terrorism and sabotage, fell to a level of 250,000 barrels today, an independent oil industry official reported.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Former President Gerald Ford, explaining that he is an avid baseball fan: I watch a lot of games on the radio.

title: The World
description: As the victim, and survivor, of two purges, Teng Hsiaoping knows the risks of clashing with the leadership of China's Communist Party. But now the 74yearold Mr. Teng himself sets the party line, and to insure that his policies are not son reversed when he is no longer able to command, the Central Committee last weekend collectively committed China to economic modernization and an admission of past error under the now not sorevered Chairman Mao.

title: As 1978 Closes, Ecopolitics Motivates the Powers
description: PARIS The sudden and apparently profound change in China's policy this year has shifted the United States position in the world. The contest with the Soviet Union remains, but now Washington finds itself in a pecular middle position between the rival Communist powers. It is a vast improvement on the chessboard of world power balance, but a risky one.

title: FINAL REPORT ISSUED ON KOREA SCANDAL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP)  The House ethics committee, although it lacks proof, believes that officials of the South Korean Government made cash gifts to members of Congress in an effort to buy their influence, the panel said in final report issued yesterday.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Abrams Names Two To Key Jobs in Office Of Attorney General
description: Attorney Generalelect Robert Abrams yesterday named two New York City lawyers, one a former deputy to Mr. Abrams when he was Bronx Borough President, to top positions in the State Department of Law, which he will take over Monday from the Republican incumbent, Louis J. Lefkowitz.

title: Coach Hayes Ousted by Ohio State for Punching Player
description: Woody Hayes was dismissed as Ohio State's football coach the morning after he punched a Clemson player in Friday night's Gator Bowl.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: Anna Northrup was openly and notoriously sharing bed and board with a new man. New York's highest court said last February, and Ray A. Northrup had stopped paying her $160amonth alimony. The judges ruled she was entitled to the money, her new domestic arrangement notwithstanding.

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: The Christmas shopping season, which began with a whimper, ended with a bang. Stores throughout the nation reported a surge in sales in the days just before Christmas.

title: Gaylen Kemp Bride Of Jeffrey C. Baxter
description: St. Francis Episcopal Church in Stamford, Conn., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Gaylen duBois Kemp, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Walter Wyckoff Kemp of Stamford, to Jeffrey Claflin Baxter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Baxter of Katonah, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Richard Mayberry.

title: GARTER PLANS CUTS IN SOCIAL SECURITY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30  President Carter will propose cutting back some Social Security benefits for future beneficiaries as part of his plan for an austere Federal budget in 1980, according to Administration officials.

title: A Study List by the State Brings School Controversy
description: STATE officials are expected to receive a chilly reception when they come to Westchester next month to begin checking on the information used in selecting schools in 14 county districts for a new state program to improve the performance of students. A spirit of cooperation would be missing not because of any philosophical differences that local educators have with the assistance program, but because they have been forced to defend their districts to residents who have concluded that the schools were chosen because they were among the worst in the state.

title: 373 Contend at Pan Am College Chess Tournament
description: DES PLAINES, III., Dec. 30  No announcer called the plays today when Yale clinched its first national title, and no fans cheered the top 20 teams.

title: The Effects of Angel Dust
description: PCP (angel dust) is known to trigger violent behavior and psychosis in some users. And yet its use is on the increase.

title: New York Gained Jobs in 1978, First Such Increase Since 1969
description: The number of jobs in New York City rose this year for the first time since 1969, and the metropolitan area recorded its largest increase in the same period, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Gwyne Wedepohl Wed to William Shore 3d
description: Gwyne Agnes Wedepohl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Wedepohl of Tokyo and Prescott, Ariz., was married in Washington yesterday to William Francis Shore 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Shore 2d of Oyster Bay, L.I. The Rev. Gene Geinzer performed the ceremony at a nuptial mass in the Dahlgren Chapel at Georgetown University, from which the couple graduated in 1977.

title: Around the Nation
description: PORTLAND, Me., Dec. 30  The United States Fish and Wildlife Service said yesterday that the continued existence of the bald eagle in this part of the United States would be threatened by a proposed oil refinery at Eastport, in the only location in the northeastern United States where the Eagle population has begun to recover.

title: 18th Home Game Without Loss
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Dec. 30  The New York Islanders, riding a stong winning steak, won their sixth consecutive game tonight, beating the Atlanta Flames, 42, before a capacity house of 14,995 in Nassau Coliseum.

title: TV RatingsThere Just Might Be a Better Way
description: The Nielsen ratings, the numbers upon which the entire commercial television industry pivots, might some day have competition in determining programming popularity. Instead of an estimated headcount of the number of people viewing a particular TV program, new form of measurement  qualitative ratings  is being advocated by influential individuals within the government, the broadcasting industry and the nonprofit sector. This new measuring procedure, which would be used to supplement rather than supplant the Nielsens, would report not just how many people are watching a program but how much  or how little  those viewers actually like it. This proposed system would use polls to measure whether the viewer found the program engaging, enriching and enlightening or simply an empty diversion.

title: Hotel Rate Survey: Most Going Up
description: Travelers, bombarded by offers of special fares, cutrate package tours and discounts, recognize a simple truth: no matter what happens, the bottomline cost of traveling seems to rise higher year after year. Hotels are a case in point. Their bills go up, whether or not the rooms are upgraded, the ambience enhanced or the service improved. But 1979. brings some extra problems for vacationers trying to pen. cil out the dollars and cents ahead of a trip: varying blasts of inflation around the world and the effects of the changes, mostly downward, in the value of the dollar against other currencies in the past year.

title: Who's No. 1 in Women's Tennis, Evert or Navratilova?
description: The controversy still rages. Is it Navratilova or Evert? Who was really the No.1 women's tennis player in 1978? With the new season starting this week at a $125,000 tournament in Washington, D.C., the debate is likely to intensify.

title: Strikes Declined in November
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP)  Working days lost because of strikes in November fell to a threeyear low for the month, the Labor Department reports. The department's Bureau of Labor Statistics said that employers lost 1.9 million worker days due to walkouts, down from 2,3 million days in October and 3.2 million days in November 1977.

title: Merger Action Heats Up in Canada
description: Canada continued to hold the merger spotlight last week. A unit of Canadian Pacific jumped into the bidding for MacMillan Bloedel Ltd., the nation's largest forestproducts concern, with an offer valued at $515 million (Canadian).

title: What Those New Year's Eve Parties Tonight Are All About
description: NEW YEAR'S EVE in our house is a time for rituals, the first of which are the family promises.

title: Marijuana: The Hazards For Young Users
description: THE ISLAND has the highest proportion of students in the state using marijuana and hashish, according to a recent state report. And, depressingly, Long Island junior and senior high school students exceed the state average in the use of other drugs as well.

title: The Dollar May Weaken
description: Foreignexchange markets greeted the dollarsupport measures unveiled by President Carter on Nov. 1 with enthusiasm, and  aided by heavy central bank intervention  the dollar staged a strong recovery. The dollar's climb since Oct. 31, on a tradeweighted basis, has averaged almost 6 percent, offsetting by nearly onehalf its effective depreciation over the preceding twelve months.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: DURING the Middle Ages, there were lists on which brave knights entered their names and then went forth to do battle.

title: CHESS
description: Every player must, at one time or another, make a workable compromise between the object?? requirement,: of the position lull confronting him and his subjective preferences. Thus, it made sense for that great master of attack, Alexander Alekhine, world champion from 1927 to 1935 and from 1937 to his death in 1946. to sacri fice for counterattack when pressed rather then to attempt passive defense, at which he was notoriously inept. It made equal sence for the greatest defensive master?? .Emanuel Lasker, world champion from 1894 to 1921, to do the opposite.

title: D.J. Rendall to Wed Sandra Smallwood
description: The engagement of Sandra Linkrourn Smallwood to Donald James Randall Jr., son of Mrs. Randall of Lakewood, N. Y., and the late Mr. Randall, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frank Smallwood of Norwich, Vt. A July wedding is planned.

title: The Region
description: Howard Jarvis is the maverick Californian whose taxcut ideas have spread all over the country. Nicholas R. Carbone is a maverick from Connecticut who, in a kind of perverse application of Mr. Jarvis's message, has become one of the most unpopular men in the state. He insists he planned it that way all along.

title: It's Called Career Education And It Caters to a New Elite
description: Once they were derided as dumping grounds, what a student would setitle for if he or she couldn't enroll in a collegepreparatory program at an academic high school. Today, with unemployment on the rise and colleges increasingly allowing credit for occupational skills, vocational schools are gaining a new respectability.

title: At the S.E.C., A Good Staff Is Getting Hard to Find
description: WASHINGTON  Stanley Sporkin, the powerful director of the enforcement division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, says that the balance in his checking account the other day was down to $13.

title: GARDENING
description: THERE is always a twinge when it is time to take down the Christmas tree. The youngsters wish it could stay up forever and their parents are eager to get it down and put the house back in order.

title: Marriage Announcement 1 -- No Title
description: Engagements

title: POLITICS
description: THOUGH many Connecticut officials would prefer that the issue just go away, officials on the other side of Long Island Sound are beating the drums again for a bridge linking Long Island and Connecticut.

title: Good Neighbor Policy Brings Peice to South Asia
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 30  Across the subcontinent, India is pursuing new diplomatic initiatives or vigorously continuing those begun during the last year of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's term. As a result, the subcontinent is generally more at peace than it has been in years.

title: Dialogues of Carmelites Sung at Met
description: When the Metropolitan Opera staged a new production of Poulenc's Dialogues of the Carmelites two seasons ago, the opera, perhaps to the Met's surprise, turned out to be a critical and popular hit. No one expects a contemporary opera, even one as melodically appealing and potently dramatic as this one, to capture audience imagination quite so forcefully.

title: Searching For the Self
description: F poems are successful when their execution perfectly fulfills the aims of their writers, then these new collections by Donald Hall and Donald Junkins leave little room for complaint.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Rustlers Prey on Jersey Livestock
description: CLAYTON, N.J., Dec. 30 (AP)  There are rustlers on the range in rural Gloucester and Salem Counties, and more than 15 livestock raids have been reported in the last few months.

title: Efforts to Bring Intrepid To City Prompt Exhibit
description: A fourweek exhibition on efforts to bring the aircraft carrier Intrepid to New York City as a floating aerospace museum and Navy memorial will open Thursday at the Custom House, 6 World Trade Center.

title: Nubians Yearn for Lost Lands on Nile And Some Have Managed to Go Back
description: NEW ADENDAN, Egypt  On the deck of a felucca moving languorously along the Nile under a large white sail  past cliffs with hieroglyphs that were chiseled into the stone thousands of years ago  a Nubian farmer known as Hassan the Elder stared at the water and said: This is our home.

title: 56 rears After Tut Discovery, Hunt for Fine Things Widens
description: LUXOR, Egypt  On a November day in 1922. the flicker of a candle disturbed the darkness of centuries, and the British archeologist Howard Carter assured his anxious patron, Lord Carnarvon, that he saw wonderful things within the gloomy chamber.

title: A War of Discounts On Buses and Trains
description: If you are planning a vacation in the United States in 1979 and prefer not to drive, you may find it substantially cheaper and easier to travel by bus or rail rather than fly. At least that is what is being touted by Greyhound and Trailways, the nation's major bus systems, and by Amtrak, the corporation that Congress created and subsidizes to run most of the nation's longdistance trains. They are all hurting because the plethora of discount air fares have siphoned off many of their former passengers, and they are eager to win them back.

title: ANTIQUES
description: BOONTON WHEN the door at 922 Main Street is open, the sounds from inside sometimes go up and down the block and across the street, and passersby pause for a moment or two to listen.

title: Obituary 6 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCLEMANTE OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 PM IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 AM TO 4:30 PM MONTDAY THROUGH FRIDAY, NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900 WESTCHESTER CO AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95100, NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500, SUFFOLK CO (516) 6691800. CONNEC PLAINS (203) 3487767

title: West Indies Closes Gap With India in Test Match
description: CALCUTTA, India, Dec. 30 (Reuter)  An aggressive 111 by Basil Williams put the West Indies within striking distance of India's firstinnings score of 300 on the second day of their cricket test today. The first two matches in the sixtest series were drawn.

title: 3 Earliest Urban National Parks Vary in Stages of Development
description: Congress has authorized four urban national parks in addition to the three that were created in the early 1970's. While is too early to know just how those four will shape up, the three in operation are in various stages of development. Following is a closer look at each of the three:

title: Crush Broncos in Playoff
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 30  With Terry Bradshaw passing unerringly, Franco Harris running spectacularly and Joe Greene sparkling on defense, the Pittsburgh Steelers crushed the Denver Broncos, 3310, today in an American Conference playoff game.

title: Marjorie Quay Becomes Bride
description: Marjorie Brownlee Quay, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Roberts Quay of Litchfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Robert Livingston Gaines of Hawley, Pa., and New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Strother Gaines 3d of Naples, Fla.

title: Getting the Most for Your Traveling Money in 1979
description: If you are planning a foreign vacation in 1979 and want stretch your travel dollars to the breaking point, you do not have to be Einstein, Sherlock Holmes and Jimmy the Greek all rolled into one. But it would probably help.

title: ART Perfection and Decadence
description: IN an exhibition of WPA art, held earlier this year at New York University's Grey Art Gallery, there was a cartoon by Abe Ajay. One of several done by artists protesting government cutbacks in the program, it showed a small figure labeled project worker painting at an easel as a sword of Damocles, lettered WPA cuts, hovers over his head.

title: Editors Choice 1978
description: Eleven years ago the staff of the Book Review began selecting the best books of the year. From the start the method of choice was what might be called dictademocratic: that is, the staff nominates titles (this year 40) nominaions ore discussed, sometimes coolly, sometimes not; finally, the editor chooses.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE FORBIDDEN FOREST

title: ART
description: HUNTINGTON STATION THE print has often been called the democratic medium, and one has only to consider the impact of the social satires of Hogarth and Daumier and the popularity of the inexpensive Currier & Ives lithographs of the last century to realize the print's potential to reach and move a wide audience.

title: Food DINING OUT IN THE NEW CHINA
