description: Though I have been eating overseas versions of Chinese food almost since infancy, I had never sampled it on its native soil until early this autumn. The oppor tunity arose when an old friend who had made many visits to China asked me to join a group of other interested firsttimers she was gathering together. I was as eager as any of them to see the Great Wall, the Forbidden City, the Ming Tombs and such other wondrous sights as the 6,000 lifesize terracotta figures being unearthed near Sian even the model communes, classrooms and nurseries that seemed to be mandatory  but my primary reason for making such a long journey was China's ancient and venerable cuisine, long a personal and professional favorite of mine.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: ELMSFORD The ?? ?? tonight and Tuesday to next Sunday. (through Feb. 18). Opens 6:15 P.M., buffet at 7, show at 8:30. Sundays one hour earlier. $18.15 to $20.35. New Year's Eve package includes buffet, cocktails, show and dancing. $95 a couple. Reservations. An Evening Dinner Theater, 11 Clearbrook Rd. 5922222.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: IF holiday parties have left unsightly burn marks or ugly stains in your walltowall carpet, don't despair. You may still be able to do something about it.

title: Modest CivilRights Gains in '78 Are Cited by Legal Defense Unit
description: The year 1978 brought modest gains for civil rights amid trench warfare in the courts, according to Jack Greenberg, the director of the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc.

title: MUSIC
description: THERE are 12 days of Christmas, as the song goes, so we can stretch the Yuletide spirit out to Jan. 4 in good and happy conscience, especially because Thursday happens to be Westchester Night at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Taiwan Leader Sees Difficulties for U.S.China Tie
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 30  President Chiang Chingkuo predicted in an interview today that the United States would find illusory the supposed benefits of establishing diplomatic relations with Peking.

title: THE MARKETS;Those Sweet Dividends
description: Heftier dividends typically bring joy to the hearts of stockholders and cash to their pockets. With this fact of financial life in mind, Standard & Poor's Corporation delivered itself of some reflective remarks at the onset of a new year.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstand varlety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computerprorcessed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40.000 outlets across the United States.

title: Urban Parks Getting Aid In Remedying Some Ills
description: The year 1978 may well prove to be the turning point for the nation's urban parks, ravaged by overuse, vandalism, shortage of space and shortage of funds.

title: Bacquier  A Singer Who Likes to Act
description: When Gabriel Bacquier attributes his success in opera to the ladies with whom he has shared the stage, he is speaking partly out of modesty and partly in truth. His first important step, from the Theatre Royal de la Monnaie in Brussels to the Opera Comique in Paris was made possible by an approving soprano whose husband was director of the latter company. The invitation to make his Metropolitan Opera debut came about when a Met official who had gone to Philadelphia to hear Joan Sutherland in La Traviata was deeply impressed by Mr. Bacquier's Germont. And most recently, the baritone has been making a strong impression on critics and audiences in the tit le role of the Met's new Don Pasquale, a production mounted at least in part as a vehicle for Beverly Sills. The Donizetti comedy can be seen this Thursday and Saturday at the Met.

title: Television This Week
description: Morning

title: Ava Horowitz Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack Horowitz of East Meadow, Queens, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Ava Horowitz, to David A. Steiner.

title: Shaker Relics in Enfield
description: MORE than 150 years ago thriving religious community, along with its hired hands and apprentices, lived in pious seclusion on a 3,000.acre farm in Enfield. They designed and built their own buildings, made their own tools, furniture ana clothing, and raised their own food. The only early commerce allowed with the outside world was the sale of vegetable seed, some furniture and a variety of household utensils.

title: Laden With Civilizing Powers
description: ITAKE it as a general good that the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York will exhibit (in Nelson Rockefeller's words) on a par with art of all the other great civilizations of the world, the longneglected creative work of the socalled primitive artists of Africa, the Americas, and the islands of the Pacific and that we have in this book more than 250 examples from Mr. Rockefeller's collection. If ever there were a nation in need of precisely this kind of revelation, it is ours, for the United States intersects with Polynesia in Hawaii, with American Indian culture in Alaska and New Mexico and other places, and with African influence in the South and in many of our Northern cities, not to mention the Yoruba beads and herbal cures West Indians keep bringing to the botnicas of our largest city, a mixing of art and medicine in the manner of certain markets in West Africa.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: IF holiday parties have left unsightly burn marks or ugly stains in your walltowall carpet. don't despair. You may still be able to do something about it.

title: New Payments Facing Those Under Medicare
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) Twentyseven million patients under Medicare who are hospitalized next year will have to pay the first $160 of their hospital bills before the Government begins picking up the tab under the Federal health insurance program for the elderly.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: I DON'T have any business acumen, James Laughlin once told a reporter. I'm not good at deals and can't cope with agents  a statement that seems to dispose neatly of highpowered commercial publishing. Mr. Laughlin has followed his own philosophy for the more than 40 years he has headed New Directions, the house he founded in 1936. But the evidence is accumulating that his contribution to American letters is not going unnoticed. It was, after all, New Directions that first brought out Tennessee Williams, Vladimir Nabokov, Dylan Thomas among other writers and kept publishing William Carlos Williams and Ezra Pound when their books scarcely sold enough to pay for mailing costs.

title: Aristides Macris To Wed Martha Giddings, Student
description: The Rev. and Mrs. Randall Clinton Giddings of Redding, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter. Martha Schoonmaker Giddings, to Aristides Macris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Efthimios Macris of Athens.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: We are hoping for a blizzard, said Dick Taylor, who runs the Saturday programs for children at the Hillside Education Center, Gage Road in Brewster. A crosscountry ski workshop for 12yea rolds and up is planned Saturday from 10 to 3. Bring skis and a sandwich. Hot chocolate and soup are available at the fireside. Check the weather first  no snow, no show. Registration $5, phone 2799237. On the same day, from 9:30 to noon and from 1:30 to 4, children from to 12 years will he busy in the center's log cabin grinding corn and baking corn biscuits on an old wood stove. The $2 fee includes takehome biscuits.

title: Dance and the Still Photographer
description: It could he argued that dance and photography ought to be incompatible, for whereas dance is an art of constantly changing threedimensional images, photography freezes isolated images upon twodimensional surfaces. Nevertheless, dancers have often collaborated happily with photographers, and photographers seem challenged by the task of selecting, from a multitude of images, those key images that may epitomize an entire dance.

title: Intruders Get $300,000 in Jewelry
description: Three armed robbers forced their way into an apartment in a lower Fifth Avenue apartment building at noon yesterday, tied up its occupants and made off with a reported $300,000 in jewelry, according to the police.

title: Looking Ahead to '79? Look Back
description: Question: What's the dernier cri in dress for ushering in the last year of the 70's?

title: Jo Fortune Is Bride Of Steven M. Belser
description: Ensign Jo Jeanne Fortune and Ensign Steven Michael Belser, both of the Naval Reserve, were married yesterday in Westport, Conn., where Justice of the Peace Ellen Gordon performed the ceremony in the Unitarian Church.

title: Obituary 8 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: New 70Meter Jump Opens in Lake Placid
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 30  The first of the skiing facilities that will be used for the 1980 Winter Olympics here was introduced to competition this afternoon with more than 80 jumpers participating in the first of two weekend tournaments on a new 70meter hill.

title: New Soviet Immigrants Uplift Brighton Beach
description: Brighton Beach, a haven for East European immigrants in the 1920's, has become home to a new generation of refugees, this time from the Soviet Union.

title: Wasting Money on Teakettle Oil
description: Texaco's refinery in Convent, La., processes about 140,000 barrels of crude oil a day into gasoline, diesel fuel and assorted petroleum products. It uses largescale, uptodate equipment to keep refining costs to a minimum.

title: Realty News
description: A new Japanese restaurant has taken retail space at 10 East 52d Street, the annex building to the Olympic Tower at 64551 Fifth Avenue.

title: Dr. Bruce Leslie To Wed Nancy Tarbell on June 16
description: Nancy Jane Tarbell, who expects to graduate next May from the State University Upstate College of Medicine at Syracuse, plans to be married June 16 to Dr. Bruce Maynard Leslie, a graduate of that medical school.

title: Mary Ellen Koebel Wed To Anthony C. Catalano
description: The Roman Catholic Cathedral of the Sacred Heart in Newark, was the setting yesterday morning for the marriage of Mary Ellen Koebel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank E. Koebel Jr. of Upper Montclair, N.J., to Anthony Charles Catalano, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent V. Catalano of New Bremen, Ohio. The Rev. John E. Doran performed the ceremony and concelebrated the nuptial mass with Msgr. Edward Larkin and the Rev. Januarius M. Carillo.

title: Lawrence Marshall And Sarah C. Witte Plan June Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas H. Witte of Bedford Hills, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Coffin Witte, to Lawrence McCall Marshall, son of Dr. and Mrs. Gordon L. Marshall of Brookline, Mass., and New London, N. H. A wedding in June is planned.

title: Jodi Sutton Engaged to Doctor
description: Dr. and Mrs. Albert P. Sutton of Kings Point L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jodi Sutton, to Dr. Jeffrey Gershel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Gershel of Roslyn, L.I. Miss Sutton is a thirdyear student at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and her fianc is pediatric resident at Jacobi Hospital. Miss Sutton's father is a urologist.

title: Responding to the White Peril
description: EDUCATED people around the world know about Rohespierrre. How many of us have ever heard of the Chinese revolutionary Hung Hsiuch'uan? In a world grown increasingly small, often as a result of Western actions, Westerners remain shockingly unaware of any culture but their own. It is salutary, therefore, that the influential series of Cambridge histories has, in recent years, turned increasingly to the nonWestern world. Projects have been started on Africa, Islam, Iran and China; and, as is traditional with the series, the works are meant both for scholars and the general public.

title: Dana Buckley Plans May Bridal
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Richard Dimes Buckley of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., of the engagement of her daughter, Dana Ellen Buckley, to Christopher Charles Bickford, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold E. Bickford of Greenwich, Conn., and North Palm Beach, Fla.

title: The Guerrilla War Steps Up; Rhodesia's Transition Shifts Over To Bloodshed
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia Rhodesia was supposed to change its name and government today, becoming Zimba bwe under black majority rule. At least that was the an nounced intention of Ian D. Smith on March 3, when he signed an agreement that seemed to presage the end of his I4year struggle to keep the nation's destiny in white hands

title: Inflation Front
description: There were signs of both strength and weakness in the Administration's antiinflation program and the economy last week.

title: Rams' Mack: We've Run Out of Excuses
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 30  In the last II years the Los Angeles Rams have been in 10 playoff games and lost seven of them, four to the Minnesota Vikings.

title: At Home: Cathedrals of the Mind
description: IWFNT to church two Sundays for the first time in many years. Neither a believer nor a nonbeliever, I went out of curiosity. I wanted to se why other people went.

title: A Chinese New Year
description: The new year sees a new China policy begin to take tangible form. As of tomorrow, the United States recognizes the People's Republic in Peking as the sole legal government of China, and withdraws recognition of the Nationalist Government in Taipei. And tomorrow, also, President Carter will give formal notice of America's intention to terminate the 1954 mutual defense treaty with Taiwan a year from now. To be sure, special offices, staffed by former or furloughed diplomats, are to be set up in Taiwan to maintain, and probably expand, trade and cultural relations with the United States. But Peking and Washington are to exchange ambassadors on March 1.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Jim DeRienzo, formerly of Fordham but now competing for Villanova, took the onemile run Friday night at the final development meet of the indoor season sponsored by the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union at the 102d Engineers Armory. The meet drew many leading college runners who live in the area and were home on Christmas vacation.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Thoughts on China

title: Manhattan Plaza Stores: Making Gains in Rentals
description: The Main Street of Manhattan Plaza is not a single street, nor is it a typical shopping strip. It is a group of stores, restaurants and other businesses that are geared to the particular needs of the tenants in the giant residential complex, which is for the most part occupied by people who work in the performing arts.

title: Bomb Blast Injures At Least 37 At Resort in SouthWest Africa
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Africa, Dec. 30 (AP)  A powerful bomb exploded today in a crowded bakery and delicatessen in the coastal resort town of Swakopmund, injuring at least 37 people, the police here reported.

title: LETTER TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: Theodore Foot's views on financing the state's schools were appropriately placed under Opinion on Dec. 10. He spoke like a true administrator, especially a superintendent.

title: Ashe and Pfister Victors; Rosewall Bows in 5 Sets
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 30 (AP)  Peter Feigl, ranked second in Austria and 57th in the world, upset Ken Rosewali in the third round of the $300,000 Australian open tennis championships today. Ile was joined in the quarterfinals by topseeded Guillermo Viles and two Americans, Arthur Ashe and Hank Pfister.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: WESTCHESTER HOUSING
description: POTENTIAL homebuyers and sellers who used to expect real estate office to be a mom and pop operation are confronting a new phenomenon: sales persons dressed in uniforms, wearing name badges and turning over flip charts. In the last year, Westchester real estate offices have been going national, joining franchises and real estate groups that advertise on television.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: AVON  Signs of Intelligent Life: Photographs by Jeff Weiss, Saturday through Feb. 4, Farmington Valley Arts Center, Camera Workers Gallery. Information 6781867.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: LIKE the Xerox and Exxon Corporations, the Continental Group is finding out that the support of local officials and the courts is sometimes not enough when it comes to moving into a town. There can be problems if a determined group of residents raises the specters of traffic congestion, pollution and loss of residential character.

title: Author's Query
description: For a dissertation on John Ruskin and J.M.W. Turner, I would appreciate.any special information about their relationship.

title: DINING OUT
description: ONLY a few Italian restaurants in Westchester take the time and the trouble to make spiedini, an appetizer that one Italian cookbook calls superbly luxurious. Spiedini can be created from a variety of ingredients chees...!, chicken livers or meat  usually skewered with alternating bread squares, then deepfried or broiled. La Riserva does theirs with cheese and bread, and serves it on an anchovy sauce, a classic version. That makes La Riserva a very good restaurant, right?

title: McAdoo Paces Knicks' Victory
description: When Bob McAdoo is led into speaking about no longer being a starter, his contempt for the idea starts to show. It's bad for the ego of someone like McAdoo, who earns $500,000 a year and has won three National Basketball Association scoring championships to be benched at the start of a game.

title: TV VIEW
description: In terms of what goes into television, 1978 was the year of Fred Silverman, the reputed programming wizard who moved from booming ABC to the presidency of sagging NBC at a reported salary of $1 million a year. There are those who insist that much of Mr. Silverman's success with ratings can be traced to a knack for being in the right place at the right time, for leaving at the crest (CBS) and arriving just before takeoff (ABC). The theory will be fully tested at NBC. which for years hasn't shown the slightest sign of taking off. Meanwhile, Mr. Silverman has unveiled his schedule for the first half of 1979. Content could turn out to be more substantial than it appears on paper, course, but only the incurably optimistic could find much encouragement in plots about supertrains and pet chimps.

title: ANTIQUES
description: Marlene Dietrich is larger than life and sleekly appealing in the poster for the 1932 film The Blonde Venus. Greta Garbo's beauty is eerily compelling when rendered giantsized to announce her performance 44 years ago in The Painted Veil. And King Kong seems more ferocious than fictional shown straddling the spire of the Empire State Building in 1933.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: Here, in the order of their appearance during the year, are the 10 New York photography shows (including one in Yonkers) that in this observer's judgement should have been seen in 1978 even if no others were. They are not necessarily the most publicized shows of the year or the biggest and most scholarly. They are, however, with one or two exceptions, the shows that at the time gave the greatest pleasure and that, in retrospect, seemed to have added most to an understanding of what photography is.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Ports in Iran Storm
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 30  This American businessman is unbelievable. He is in a good mood. The soldiers are shooting, buses are burning in the streets, the whole country is creaking like a wornout ship about to come apart in the waves, and the businessman insists on seeing the positive side.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: BEGINNING tomorrow, the price of drugs for those of New Jersey's elderly covered by a state program known as P.A.A. (Pharmaceutical Assistance to the Aged) will rise from $1 to $2 a prescription.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: LONG ISLANDERS concerned about a repetition of the snowclogged highways and roads of last winter should not worry, the State Department of Transportation says.

title: Letter
description: Thanks to Nora Ephron (Having a Baby After 35, Nov. 26) for reminding the followers of Lamaze of its limitations. The tyranny of the obstetrician has indeed given way to a new tyranny  that of the liberated female healthcare consumer, frequently guided by romanticized misconceptions.

title: IN BRIEF
description: France blocked the start of the European Monetary System, which had been scheduled for Monday, by insisting on changes in the Common Market's agricultural policy before the new currency system begins operations.

title: NEW DEBATE OVER EXPERIMENTING WITH ANIMALS
description: The professor was late leaving the medical school because he'd had to review papers by his thirdyear students in experimental surgery. It was well after 11 when he wearily drove his car into the garage. The house was dark except for a hall light left on for him. His wife and youngsters were already asleep, he realized, and the professor suddenly felt lonely as he fit his key in the lock. But even as he pushed open the door, Sabrina was there to welcome him. She was always waiting for him, lying on the rug just inside the door.

title: In the Attic Mode
description: AS a historical novelist writing about the ancient world, Mary Renault has few peers. Robert Graves comes to mind, and Gore Vidal.

title: POP MUSIC
description: It's become a clich in popmusic retrospectives to complain about conservatism. In 1978 there were indeed signs of a continued consolidation in mainstream pop music, but at the same time the forces of radical creativity had plenty to offer, too. There is still a lot of good music in the air  as long as you're willing to appreciate it as art and not insist that it be an anthem for social change, as well.

title: Design
description: In Italy, if it's old we don't tear it down, we convert it, says architect Bruno Sacchi of the house he created in a 16thcentury former convent on the outskirts of Florence. The convent had already been divided into two homes when his clients, a young couple with two small children, bought half of It But it was certainly not ready to be moved into lacking, as it did, such elementary necessities as a bathroom and kitchen.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: BLOOMFIELD (Bloomfield College, Franklin and Fremont Streets)  Long Day's Journey Into Night, in an Actor's CafeTheater production. Opens Friday (through Feb. 3). Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. $3.50$5.50; students and the elderly, $2.50$4.50. (201) 4297662. Westminster Theater

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: I love this piece myself, if you'll pardon the immodesty, said Dave Brubeck about his La Fiesta de la Posada, one of six religious works composed by the popular and prolific musician. His wife, Iola, wrote the text, and this Saturday at 6 and 8 P.M. Mr. Brubeck himself will play the piano at the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich. Richard Vogt, the conductor, also led the prepreview of the work in 1975.

title: Nutmegs and Buckeyes
description: THINK for a moment about what could have been. Hartford could have been the capital of Ohio. UConn could have played in the Big Ten. And Connecticut could have been rolling in money as it looks for a new way to pay for its public schools.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: I enjoyed Michael P. Sheehan's Opinion Page article on train commuting (Dec. 17), As an excotntnuter, I offer the following supplement to his valuable advice:

title: Dr. Anne Shrivastava Plans Nuptials in July
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. Nevita Shrivastava of Bhopal, India, and Dr. Bhagwan Shrivastava of Boston, England, of the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Anne Shrivastava. to Capt. Steven Charles Gamer. U.S.A.F., Medical Corps, son of Dr. and Mrs. Harvey Garner of Brooklyn.

title: Mary Lyon Booth Married to Naval Officer
description: Mary Lyon Booth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lea Booth of Lynchburg, Va., was married yesterday evening to Ens. Thomas Patrick Verlin, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ambrose Bernard Verlin of Richmond Hill, Queens. The Rev. George Bean of St. John's Episcopal Church in Lynchburg performen the ceremony at the Langhorne Memorial Chapel of the Virginia Episcopal School in Lynchburg. The Rev. Scott Duarte of the Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church in Lynchburg, assisted.

title: Birth Notice 1 -- No Title
description: Births

title: Key West: Anyone's Place in the Sun
description: After years of decline, Key West has become the in place again for writers, artists, eccentrics and just. plain tourists. Why? The tropical island may not be paradise, but it is a safe, stillinAmerica resort that caters to a liveandletlive breed attracted to its blend of sun, salt water, salubrity and a soupcon of sin. Story begins on Page 14.

title: DINING OUT;A Stylish and Ambitious Menu
description: EXCALIBUR opened in Roslyn with considerable fanfare about two months ago. Previously, the white Victorian house on Old Northern Boulevard had done a stint as Truman's. The handsome contemporary bar, the polished wood, tile floors and metal bead curtains in the downstairs dining alcoves and the warm beige and brown dining rooms upstairs remain from its former identity.

title: Hard Way To Beauty
description: HARLES TOMLINSON is what John Berryman would have called a thinky poet. To those who have unaccountably missed all 14 of his books or booklets (counting from Calvin Bedient's bibliography) let it be said, once again, that together with Philip Larkin and Donald Davie, fellow luminaries of the 1950's movement in England, he is a poet of altogether exceptional interest.

title: The Prospects For Investors
description: My 1979 stock market outlook is divided into two phases: before the peak and after the peak. The principal indicator of the peaking, in my view, is the level of interest rates. Before the peaking of interest rates, the market will be very skittish and subject to wide swings of sentiment as the investor

title: The A.B.C.'s of Selecting a C.P.A.
description: EVEN with all of the simplifications recently publicized by the taxing authorities, most Americans prefer to share with professionals the burden of preparing their tax returns. However, unlike the purchase of food or clothing, the basis for selecting an appropriate professional is not readily apparent.

title: DINING OUT In Stockton, It's All in the Family
description: IN THE galloping rot of fastfood chains, a family enterprise such as Colligan's Stockton Inn is all the more valuable for its rarity. The original stone building of the inn dates from 1710, and the first Colligans took over in 1835. Except for a brief hiatus five years ago, the establishment has been owned, managed and kept up to date by Colligaos ever since. The current management consists of Charles, Jack and Kiff.

title: The World's Biggest Brokerage? It Calls Tokyo Home
description: TOKYO  The quiet, silverhaired executive leaned back in his chair, his hands placed squarely on its arms. We are the number one broker in the world, said Kiichiro Kitaura.

title: Old Need, New Beginning
description: The week's mail to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund brought a check from a widower in memory of his wife who had contributed regularly for nearly 50 years, and another from a young woman at the end of her first year in the real world of earning a living. Like the eve of the new year, these two letters symbolize continuity and a new beginning.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Of Special Interest

title: Most Near 65 Are Expected to Retire Voluntarily
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP)  Some 700,000 workers who will become 65 years old in 1979 can remain on the job because of a new law that bars forced retirement before the age of 70. Despite this, most are expected to retire voluntarily, choosing free time and benefits over full paychecks.

title: Author's Query
description: For a biographycritical study of Edgar Wilson (Bill) Nye, I would appreciate any leads on the whereabouts of manuscripts or printed editions of his two Broadway plays of the 1890'sThe Cadi and The Slag Party or any other related material.

title: A Gift for Pen and Ink
description: THIS is the second volume of Virginia Woolf's diaries, for the years 192024, a calm and productive period during which she wrote Jacob's Room and Mrs. Dalloway, turned 40, and moved back to London from suburban Richmond, where she and Leonard Woolf had gone nearly 10 years before search of a calm and restorative environment after her early breakdown. Now strong enough for fiction writing, she tried to cut down on book reviewing, which she distinguished from criticism and which she had been doing a lot of, mostly because they needed the money but also because she was by temperament an arbiter and, suffering what is no doubt the fate of all great writers  the irritation of hearing her inferiors praised above her  could by reviewing seek to modify a little the public taste.

title: Gotbaum Asks Mayor to Dismiss Hospital Adviser Over Conflicts
description: Victor Gotbaum, head of New York City's largest municipal union, called yesterday for the dismissal of Mayor Koch's top health advisor, Dr. Martin Cherkasky, who has recommended the closing of half the city's 17 municipal hospitals, accusing him of the most blatant conflict of interest.

title: First Cautious Steps: Dancing in a Changing China
description: PEKING, Dec. 30  How do you ask a Chinese woman at a party in Peking to dance after a decade of no dancing in China and tight restrictions on contacts with foreigners?

title: New York Police Have No Leads In Slaying of Denver Student, 19
description: The New York City police said yesterday that they had no leads in the investigation of the murder of a 19yearold college student from Denver who was shot to death in an apparent robbery attempt Thursday night near City College in West Harlem.

title: Two New 12Meters May Enter 1980 Cup
description: There will be at least one new 12Meter yacht entered by the United States for the 1980 America's Cup competition and plans for a second 12 appear to be waiting in the wings.

title: Obituary 7 -- No Title
description: GEN. CHARLES S. KILBURN

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE GRAB, by Maria Katzenbach. (Pocket, $2.25.) Upon the death of a very upperclass Georgetown lady, her three daughters suffer the ordeal of dividing the memories and possessions of their mother and grandmother. This exceptional first novel explores, in the style of a poet, the relationships between daughters and parents, sisters and sisters. Anna Quindlen, our reviewer, called it something of a Faberg egg of a book.

title: The India Few Americans Know: SelfSufficient and Technological
description: BOMBAY, India  In the txximing industrial heartland that runs for a thousand miles northeast from here, the land is rich and strong, producing almost everything it needs, from automobiles to zinc and, increasingly, exporting finished goods.

title: ExFlier Finds His Alaska Rescuer of 1953
description: IRVINE, Calif., Dec. 30 (AP)  Lionel W. Levin set out last September to find the dogsledder who had rescued him after a plane crash nearly 26 years ago in the middle of an Alaskan winter. When he did, he said, it was a miracle.

title: Queen Mother of Iran, Flown to Los Angeles, Getting Medical Care
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 30 (AP)  The Shah's mother was undergoing medical care here today after being flown out of Iran.

title: Patriots Brush Aside Woes. Set for Oilers
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Dec. 30  For while a few weeks ago, it seemed as if Billy Sullivan and Chuck Fairbanks might exchange pistol shots at 10 paces. But then they made up and exchanged Christmas gifts instead.

title: Government By the People For the People
description: THE State Legislature will start a new year on Wednesday with a very new and different look. The House Democrats and House and Senate Republicans have new leaders. With a freshmen class of 14 Senators and 40 Representatives, about onethird the General Assembly is new on the job.

title: Byrne Sets Stage for the Budget Drama
description: THE coalescing of the annual state budget is like the preview of a new play. There are roles to be acted out and some rewriting to be done before the final product is unveiled. And the taxpayeraudience, which eventually is expected to pay the production costs, must be carefully prepared for the climax.

title: THE ASSASSINATION LIVES ON IN DALLAS
description: DALLAS, Dec. 30  Every day, at almost any hour, people can be seen standing near the corner of Elm and Houston at the west end of the downtown section of Dallas, staring at the red brick building with the dilapidated Hertz sign on top. They are staring at the sixthfloor window from which Lee Harvey Oswald fired in 1963.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: Last year, modern architecture was declared dead, but this year, it refused to lie down. The building of the year was definitely an establishment edifice in the heroic modern tradition. It was I.M. Pei and Partners new East Building for the National Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C., designed for establishment clients Carter Brown, director of the museum, and Paul Mellon, its benefactor, with other members of the Mellon family and trust, to provide a home and setting for the established masterworks of modern art. It is a smashing establishment success.

title: Clean as a Whistle
description: DR. JAMES F. X. O'ROURKE, Westchester's Republican leader, and Samuel G. Fredman, his Democratic counterpart, disagree on many political issues, but they are in accord in the belief that the county government, under both parties, has been free of corruption and scandals. On the eye of the New Year, their political organizations are also free of intraparty fighting, and both men seem secure in their leaderships. Both were elected unanimously, and there is no visible opposition to their reelection next year.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: This was the year that American dance basked in the public relations glow of increased national recognition. The United States Postal Service issued four stamps honoring the contribution of dance to this country. The First National Dance Week was accompanied by government proclamations at the state And municipal levels. It was also the year of Mikhail Baryshnikov. The ubiquitous superstar danced in everything from Studio 54 to his own production of Don Quixote for American Ballet Theater and then rocked the dance world by joining that wellknown nostar company, the New York City Ballet.

title: Tourist's Preview Of the New Year
description: With prognostications in order as the New Year rolls around, the sages in the travel industry are once again wringing out the old clichs and bringing in the new. In the process they have dusted off the old crystal ball, thrown caution to the winds and gone out on a limb to predict that 1979, from the tourist's standpoint, will be positively out of this world.

title: Dolin, 74, Finds a Ballet An Easy Nut to Crack
description: LONDON, Dec. 30  Amazingly, at the ripe age of 74, Anton Dolin is playing the character role of Dr. Drosselmeyer in the London Festival Ballet production of The Nutcracker. He is giving four performances in the threeweek season  the first last Thursday, the others next Tuesday and on Jan. 10 and 11.

title: FOOD For a Healthy New Year  Naturally
description: LYNBROOK HEALTH food has come out of the subculture. A couple of new restaurants on the Island certainly testify to that. The patrons of these bright, plantfilled, natural wood paneled places might wear blue jeans, but these usually bear designer labels.

title: THE WORLD ACCORDING TO BRZEZINSKI
description: Reston: We are now facing the last year of the 1970's  new relations with China, problems with the Soviet Union, the Middle East and Europe. Are you optimistic or pessimistic?

title: State Opera Director Calls for a Cultural Climate
description: WEST ORANGE THE chief problem with the arts in our state is to overcome the mental attitude that, if it is born and raised and flourishing here, it can't be Rood. That's the opinion of Alfredo Silipigni, artistic director and conductor of the New Jersey State Opera.

title: Rights And Diplomacy
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.Americans have always been convinced that their country has had a higher mission than the pursuit of its national interest.

title: McHargue Is Still Chasing Cauthen's Money Record
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Dec.30 (AP) Darrel McHargue failed today at Santa Anita in his bid to break Steve Cauthen's singleyear earnings record. Mcliargue rode in all nine races on the program but failed to pilot a winner. His mounts earned $12,250, which brought his total for the year to $6,136,428.

title: The Spirit of St. Stanislaus
description: Why did the Polish censors cut out all references St. Stanislaus, their nation's patron saint, from Pope John Paul II's Christmas message to his home diocese of Cracow? This is not the beginning of a Polish joke.

title: The View From the Top of the A.F.L.C.I.O. Can Be Deceiving
description: WASHINGTON  When Glenn E. Watts said earlier this month that George Meany's assault on President Carter economic policies had done a tremendous disservice to both the country and the labor movement, some saw the tip of an iceberg of unrest within the ruling circles of organized labor.

title: CAMERA
description: Many of the books and magazine articles that are devoted to photographic techniques seem to give the advanced amateur a set of rules which, carefully followed, Will instantly transform the task of creating an artistically composed photograph into a fast, sure and simple process that is almost foolproof.

title: Headliners
description: If you have to ask how much it costs to live in Newport, R.I., you can't afford it. That was the case when Cornelius Vanderbilt, grandson of the Commodore, built his showplace summer cottage The Breakers; and it's still true, even for the Vanderbilts. Last week, Louise M. Vanderbilt, the widow of Cornelius grandson George, was ordered evicted from Mailands, a more modest Newport mansion where she refused to pay the rent hikes demanded by her landlord, Harold B. Casey  who, coincidentally, is the High Sheriff of Newport County. The sheriff asked for a fiveyear lease that would have raised Mrs. Vanderbilt's rent from $950 a month to $4,013 in the fifth year. Rather than pay, Mrs. Vanderbilt said I am a tenant who has been gouged just like lots of others, and led a protest march demanding the imposition of rent controls. She has joined the Newport County Tenant's Association, a group representing Newport's dwindling number of poor people, who don't care for their rents either. I sympathize with the poor people, the sheriff said. But there are no poor people being displaced from Mrs. Vanderbilt's apartment.

title: Meadowlands Closes With DayNight Set
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 30  While the tote board flashed a rare Have a good day, the Meadowlands closed its 100night thoroughbred season today with an afternoonevening doubleheader containing enough action for even a compulsive gambler.

title: Dartmouth 54, Seton Hall 53
description: ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 30 (AP) Larry Lawrence scored 18 of his gamehigh 20 points in the second half and sank the gamewinning shot at the buzzer, to bring Dartmouth from a 12pont deficit to a 5453 victory over Seton Hall in the consolation game of the Rochester University tournament

title: Chief of Utah Bar Backs Rape Sentence Rejection
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 30 (UPI) The president of the Utah Bar Association has come to the defense of a judge who refused last week to sentence a man convicted in a rape case. The decision infuriated local women's groups and brought calls for the judge's removal.

title: For the Coast Line, Full Steam Ahead
description: CONDITIONS on the former New York & Long Branch Railroad, otherwise known as the North Jersey Coast Line, have been so bad in recent years that one commuters group has taken to regularly bestowing a Rusty Spike Award on various officials of Conrail and the state's Department of Transportation.

title: Radio
description: 7:308 A.M., WABC: Message of israel. Favorite Readings From the Bible.

title: Judge Decides 3 in Albuquerque Obeyed Subpoena on Police Files
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Dec. 30  A Federal District judge has decided that three Albuquerque city officials have complied acceptably with a grand jury subpoena of police records in an investigation of the alleged use of excessive force by two officers in a 1977 incident.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING
description: THE small family, the working woman, the rising divorce rate, the growing number of older people, the arrival at housebuying age of many of the babyboom children  all have caused a shift in traditional buying patterns and demand both in the suburbs and the cities in Connecticut this year.

title: Other Ideas & Trends
description: Rotating work shifts are no fun, as many policemen, firemen and industrial workers know from experience. Now it appears that they are also unhealthful. A recent Governmentsponsored study at the SRI International Center for Research on Stress and Health found that workers who moved from shift to shift suffered severe disruption of their physical and psychological wellbeing. They had more accidents than other workers, consumed more alcohol and sleeping pills, and reported more digestive difficulties, menstrual disorders, colds, nervousness and fatigue. They also complained of less satisfactory domestic and social lives. The probable reason, according to Donald Tasto, a clinical psychologist who directed the study, is that changes in work schedules upset the body's natural biological rhythms. After a 180degree inversion of schedules, Dr. Tasto said, it takes three to four weeks for the circadian rhythms to become synchronized again, so it you change shifts every month your rhythms may be interrupted just as you're getting adiusted again.

title: Does U.S. or Europe ack Arts Best?
description: AMSTERDAM  Twice a week, Amsterdam's deputy director of social affairs, Jaap Maasdam, meets with a few museum officials and artists to survey a large inventory of paintings and sculptures in a municipal building overlooking a murky canal.

title: Notes: A Dentist's Plan for Avoiding Trouble
description: Though they may not always be successful, most travelers take pains to protect their skins from sunburn, their feet from blisters and their stomachs from Montezuma's revenge. They are generally less likely to concern themselves with the possibility of dental troubles. Dr. Arthur Zuckerman, New York dentist; who says he loves his profession and loves to travel, thinks they should, and has done some research on potential difficulties.

title: Miss Andrews Becomes Bride Of G. M. Beck
description: Lilian Forsyth Brown Andrews, daughter of Schofield Andrews Jr. of Northeast Harbor, Me., and Mrs. A. Sydney Roberts of Wakefield, R. I., and Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday afternoon to Gordon Morison Beck. son of Mrs. H. Brooks Beck of Canton, Mass., and Northeast Harbor, Me., and the late Mr. Beck. The Rev. Lyle Hall performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of the Advent in Boston.

title: John Stallworth 's Banner Day
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 30  Until today, John Stallworth was always the other receiver on the Pittsburgh Steelers, the invisible wide receiver whom most people and most opponents ignored while they concentrated on Lynn Swann, the allpro perennial. Early this season, a banner in Three Rivers Stadium cheered

title: The Gavel Pounds Again in Hartford
description: HARTFORD THE minority leader of the State House of Representatives, R. E. Van Nostrand, was sitting in his office one Sunday just before the last election when a fellow resident of Darien dropped in to solicit a donation for the local Y.M.C.A.

title: Animals' Actions Before Quakes May Be Linked to Particles in Air
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UPI)  For years scientists have wondered why animals act so strangely just before earthquakes strike. A German biochemist thinks he knows the answer.

title: Events Today
description: The Making of Americans: A marathon reading of the poem by Gertrude Stein; starting of noon and continuing throuoh Tuesday afternoon; Paula Cooper Gallery, 155 Wooster Street. (Donations accepted.)

title: Ideas &Trends
description: John Rideout was acquitted last week, the first man in the nation to be tried for raping his wife while they were living together. But the underlying central question  does a husband have a commonlaw right to sex with his wife?  remains unresolved.

title: Oil Workers Severed The Lifeline of the Nation
description: The long battle for the hearts and minds of Iran's oil workers came to a head last week. Responding to the continuing exhortations of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi's foes, Iran's oil workers cast their vote against the Shah and his generals with a devastating strike that effectively halted the flow of Iranian oil.

title: Hawks Comeback Bid Is Foiled
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 30  With John Davidson starting because of Coach Fred Shero's new policy of rotating their three goalies, the New York Rangers concluded a fourgame road trip, their second longest of the season, against the Black Hawks tonight in Chicago Stadium.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: So far on New York's musical scene, it has been the year of Mehta, the year of an announced major change in the setup of the New York City Opera, the year of still greater relaxation in the once grim contemporary music scene. Zubin Mehta comes first. It is not every year that the New York Philharmonic gets a new music director, and Mr. Mehta's arrival from Los Angeles was naturally the focus a great deal of interest.

title: Parents of Missing Youths Hope, Fear  and Wait
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 30  The waiting and the wondering are a painful blend of hope and fear for thousands of parents all across the country.
